HEADLINE: Solar Power In Big Leap In California

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
A California electric utility has signed a big contract to buy solar cells that the utility and the Department of Energy say will push the cells' cost down to a competitive level by 2002.
The utility, the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, will buy 10 megawatts of solar cells by 2002, enough to supply hundreds of houses. The total is small by the standards of conventional power plants, but experts say it is the largest purchase ever by a utility of solar cells, which make electricity from sunlight. The type that the utility district will buy, thin-film silicon, is similar to what pocket calculators run on. 
 Outside experts say that it is difficult to predict future costs but that the contract is likely to help push prices down substantially.
The utility district expects to buy cells in 1998 at a cost equal to 16.3 cents per kilowatt-hour. The price will fall to 8.2 cents by the final year of the contract, 2002. The driving force behind the price drop, officials said, will be economies of scale possible with a long-term contract.
The utility will put 300 square feet to 500 square feet of cells on the roofs of about 4,000 customers who volunteer, and these will produce about three kilowatts of power during the day, said Donald E. Osborn, who is in charge of solar power for the utility district. Over the year, he said, the cells will produce about the same amount of power as a house uses.
Solar cells produce energy only during daylight hours, a time frame that matches Sacramento's hours of greatest need, Mr. Osborn said. The system can tolerate 10 percent to 20 percent of its production coming from such intermittent power sources, he said.
About 700 customers already have such installations and pay $4 a month extra as "PV Pioneers." Since June 1989, when voters in the district decided to shut their nuclear plant, Rancho Seco, the utility district has tried to cut demand, paying customers to buy more efficient refrigerators and planting thousands of tress that shade houses and lower air-conditioning costs. It has also installed solar cells, some on the site of the nuclear plant.
The new solar cells will come from Energy Photovoltaics of Princeton, N.J., which will build a factory in Sacramento. The Energy Department has subsidized the research.
At the Energy Department, Joseph Romm, the Acting Assistant Secretary for the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, called the contract signing "an exceptional moment for the solar energy program."
Solar experts said the size and duration of the contract made it exceptional. John P. Thornton, an expert in photovoltaic markets at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, an Energy Department laboratory in Golden, Colo., said, "It actually could have a significant influence on driving the price down."
Total worldwide production of solar cells is about 96 megawatts a year, about 45 megawatts of which is in the United States, Mr. Thornton said. Many of the cells are exported to developing countries, he said.
At the Solar Energy Industries Association, a trade group based in Washington, Scott Sklar, the executive director, said that the contract was unprecedented in size for a utility, but that several other companies were "not far behind."

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Tax-Cut Plan Faces G.O.P. Opposition in Albany

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan for $284 million in tax cuts, one of the pillars of his election-year budget, is drawing opposition from an unexpected quarter: his fellow Republicans in the State Senate, whose approval is required for nearly all of the proposals to become law.
Mr. Giuliani is seeking to do away with New York City's 4 percent sales tax on clothing under $500 and to trim taxes on small-business earnings, personal income, commercial rent and co-ops and condominiums. The Mayor is making the package a focus of his campaign for re-election, portraying himself as a leader who is overhauling what he says is a burdensome tax structure. 
 But the State Senate's Republican majority, which usually champions tax reduction, is instead resisting the Mayor's plan, largely because regional rivalries seem to be carrying more weight than political kinship with Mr. Giuliani.
Republicans from areas around New York City say they do not want the city to lower its sales tax on clothing if such a move would leave the tax higher in neighboring counties, potentially putting merchants there at a disadvantage. Some Republican Senators from outside the city contend that if Mr. Giuliani lowers taxes and loses revenue, he might then be forced in an economic downturn to ask for more state aid.
"While we applaud tax cuts, you have to be very, very careful in how you proceed," Joseph L. Bruno, an upstate Republican who is the Senate majority leader, said last week.
Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, acknowledged that the tax package, which was part of the budget that the Mayor presented earlier this month, was running into difficulties in the Senate. But Mr. Mastro said there was still time to persuade the Republican majority to approve it.
"No one ever said that this was going to be an easy task," he said.
The state wields vast control over the city's finances and tax system, so nearly all the tax reductions proposed by Mr. Giuliani require the approval of not only the City Council but also Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature.
For now at least, the State Senate has formally rebuffed the Mayor's plan to eliminate the 4 percent sales tax on articles of clothing under $500 in the city. It passed its own legislation that would gradually phase out the state's 4 percent sales tax on clothing under $500 while giving localities the option of doing the same with their companion levies.
In New York City, there is currently an 8.25 percent sales tax on clothing under $ 500: 4 percent goes to the state, 4 percent to the city and 0.25 percent to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The bill approved by the Senate would reduce the state sales tax by one percentage point a year, eliminating it after four years. Localities could reduce their part of the sales tax at the same pace.
Governor Pataki, who has close ties to suburban Republicans, has said he favors the Senate bill, though it appears that he is not as opposed to the Mayor's proposal as some Republican Senators. The Democratic-controlled Assembly, which is dominated by New York City lawmakers, has backed the Republican Mayor.
Republicans from counties around the city, a powerful bloc in the Senate majority, said their legislation would be more equitable because it would provide all localities with the same opportunity to cut taxes.
"The phase-in that we propose is a better approach," said Senator Dean G. Skelos of Nassau County, the deputy majority leader. "When you do tax cuts and you do a budget, you have to look at how it impacts the entire state, county by county. You can't just deal with one area in a vacuum."
The Mayor's plan for the sales tax, Mr. Bruno said, "is potentially very, very troublesome, when you pit one county against another."
Mr. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor, noted that even though the Senate legislation fell short of what the Mayor wanted, the very fact that the Senate had approved any measure to reduce the clothing sales tax was a tribute to Mr. Giuliani's efforts to spotlight the issue.
"That's substantial progress," Mr. Mastro said.
The Senate majority could still reverse its stance and pass the Mayor's sales tax proposal before the legislative session ends this summer. The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, is a staunch backer of the proposal and is expected to try to pressure Mr. Bruno to accept it in the coming weeks.
But some Giuliani administration officials acknowledged privately that the Mayor would probably not prevail and would have to accept a compromise that would allow the city to reduce the tax gradually.
There is a silver lining to that defeat: the Mayor can still trumpet to voters that he pushed the proposal, and he can also spend the revenue that he had expected to lose from the cut, $157 million in the 1998 fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
The Democratic-led City Council supports much of the Mayor's tax cut package, including the reduction in the clothing tax, though there are some differences. The Mayor and the Council have varying ideas for scaling back the unincorporated business tax, which is a kind of income tax for small businesses.
The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, is also calling for a tax cut for emerging industries to spur job growth, a measure that the Mayor has not embraced.
The one tax reduction put forth by Mr. Giuliani that does not require approval by Albany is the cut in the commercial rent tax, which the city levies only in Manhattan south of 96th Street.
Underlying some of the opposition from Senate Republicans is the historic antipathy of suburban and rural legislators to New York City, which is scorned as profligate and continually holding out its hand to Albany.
For instance, Mr. Skelos, the deputy majority leader, questioned whether the city could afford the Mayor's tax cuts. He pointed out that though the city has a record budget surplus this year, it is facing future projected deficits.
If the tax cuts are approved and the city loses revenue, "are you then going to come to the state for more money?" Mr. Skelos asked.
Such sentiment helps explain why the final part of the Mayor's tax cut package is also contentious. Mr. Giuliani is calling for the Governor to revamp a proposal that would give property tax relief to localities.
In its current form, the city would get about 12 percent of the property tax relief, which localities would receive as increased state aid. Mr. Giuliani, joined by Mr. Vallone, wants close to 40 percent, about equal to the percentage of the state population that lives in the city.
The Mayor and the Speaker would then use that extra state aid to make up for lost revenue from new cuts in the personal income tax and the tax on co-ops and condominiums, as well as from a tax credit intended to help move people on welfare into jobs.
The problem, of course, is that to increase state aid for the city, the Governor would have to reduce it for other areas, a change that will not please the Senate majority.

HEADLINE: The Blind, Like Others, Fish by the Sense of Feel

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
A 100-foot aluminum party boat called the Sunshine left its dock in Sheepshead Bay under a leaden sky Saturday morning with 40 people on board. Thirteen of them were members of the Helen Keller Fishing Club, an organization that takes blind people deep-sea fishing.
"Really, this club's a godsend," said Marty Ross, who has been blind from birth. "I love fishing." 
 Eric Blair, a member for 20 of the club's 48 years, observed that the air was warming up. Indeed, the sun was beginning to peep through the clouds. "Nature has presented us with a beautiful day," he said. Nunzio Russo, 76, played an Italian folk tune on his harmonica.
Membership in the club -- an offshoot of the Helen Keller Services for the Blind based in Brooklyn -- stands at 23, including 5 women. Members come mostly from Brooklyn and Queens to take part in monthly fishing expeditions. The only requirement is being legally blind. Dues are $10 a month. Each member is also expected to sell 60 $1 tickets for a yearly raffle. Beer, soda and other accessories are often donated by businesses.
Walter S. Bach, a club member who used to work for the Helen Keller agency until cost-cutting eliminated his job, spoke with Joe Lomeo, who cannot see, hear or speak, by tapping out letters on his arm. "F-L-O-U-N-D-E-R," he saidwhen Mr. Lomeo asked the day's prey.
As the Sunshine churned to a choppy stop about half a mile off Coney Island, members of the fishing club began baiting their hooks.
"Oh, it's a nasty one!" said Helen Keenan as the squirming sandworm in her hand bit her.
"Put the hook in his mouth so he can't bite you," one of the 11 volunteers on board suggested.
"But I can't see the mouth," Ms. Keenan replied.
The club members fished with concentration. Many insisted that the sense of touch is what actually matters, even for those who can see.
"It's a matter of feel," said Mr. Ross, who has been a chef for 27 years. "The fish can't see you, and you can't see the fish. It's all in the fingers."
For some members, the club offers a return to a lost pastime. "A lot of things in the past I can't do," said Robert Tobin, who became legally blind six years ago. "Fishing is one I can."
For others, it offers a new skill to master. Jonathan Emerson, who asks friends to call him Mad Dog, was eager to tell of his other exploits: skiing through trees while accompanied by a sighted guide, running a marathon and helping teach paraplegics to sail at a school on City Island.
As waves gently rocked the boat, Mr. Lomeo almost sat in the box of worms. Somebody caught a clam. Alfred Carlton puffed a cigar. When Clifton Harrell shouted that he had landed a big one, others ran over to touch it. Mr. Bach told a story about the biggest fish ever caught by the club, a 90-pound tuna off Gerritsen Beach.
Almost all club members are unemployed or work at menial jobs for the minimum wage, but on board they could relax. It almost did not matter that the fish were not biting. By day's end, only a dismal 18 flounders -- none exactly whoppers -- were caught.
"Sometimes you can't catch anything," said Mr. Russo, who lives in a group home in Queens. "But to tell you the truth, I'll sleep good tonight. The air is good."
Michael Ryan, a Farmingdale, N.Y., volunteer who works as an emergency subway car repairman, took a vacation day to drive the club members to the boat and then help them fish. He recalled how pleased he was at last year's holiday banquet when Mr. Lomeo won the award for catching the most big fish. He said he kept lining up to shake his hand again and again, thinking there was a small chance that he would be recognized by the beaming champion.
People have fallen off the boat a time or two, Mr. Bach said, and not just club members. He fell once himself, he said, because nobody warned him about the gap between the dock and the boat.
"It's an awful feeling," he said.
Lynne Luxton, a rehabilitation counselor at the agency, said that seemingly unlikely recreational activities favored by the blind like fishing and bowling are useful because they provide a chance to socialize. "You belong to this group of fishermen," she said. "You can tell a story as big as the next guy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Sometimes you can't catch anything," said Nunzio Russo, who sailed with 12 other blind members of the Helen Keller Fish Club on the Sunshine and played his harmonica when he was not at the rail. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Corporate Web Police Hunt Down E-Pirates

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SHAPLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Joshua Bauchner, who spends most workdays stalking suspected copyright pirates on the Internet, is about to make a big haul. Typing in the word "warez," he waits for a search engine to spit out sites that include the term, which means pirated software in Internet parlance.
On the list was a site maintained by an Internet service provider in Finland. And on the site was a trove of programs likely to be illegal copies of American software pilfered for the sheer thrill of it. 
 As Mr. Bauchner scrolls down the list of software available free, it proves spectacular -- a treasure chest of pirated goods that he is eager to show to his colleagues at the Software Publishers Association.
The young men and women who gather to review his findings are a new on-line breed: the Internet police.
Or perhaps one should call them the Internet's Pinkerton detectives. Most often, they are private sleuths, hired by corporations to guard their wares -- from corporate logos to comic strips, from music to software -- from the pilfering that computer technology makes so easy.
The rise of these sleuths reflects the taming of cyberspace's affinity for anarchy.
In recent years, Hollywood, the music industry, software publishers and merchandisers have pushed to enforce copyright and trademark laws on the Internet.
The Business Software Alliance estimates that of the 523 million new business software applications used globally in 1996, 225 million, or nearly one in two are pirated -- a 20 percent increase over 1995.
On other fronts, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department have built up teams of cybersleuths as well.
The response from the Internet's precincts is mixed and sometimes defiant. On one hand, many users publish their own work on the Internet in the hopes of lucrative reproduction fees. On the other, many habitues treat their sites like family bulletin boards, and object to being pursued for posting a Dilbert cartoon.
But there is also a booming subculture of pirates who collect the latest software programs -- not necessarily to use, but just for bragging rights.
The pursued have the advantage over their pursuers. The number of Internet users doubled in the last year to 45 million, according to the Gartner Group. "The biggest problem is that the number of illegal copies available to the average user is so numerous," Greg Wren, corporate counsel for Adobe Systems Inc. of San Jose, Calif., said.
The applicability of the laws the new detectives seek to enforce remains unclear. Several lower court rulings have held system operators to be like publishers and liable for illegal material posted on their networks. Last December, a Federal court in the Northern District of California held Maphia, a small Internet provider, liable for illegal copies of Sega Enterprises Ltd. games in its system, because Maphia operators knew of the activity.
But in a case that the Religious Technology Center, part of the Church of Scientology, brought against Netcom On-line Communications Services Inc., a Federal judge refused to enjoin the company from allowing texts owned by the church to remain in its system. In denying the preliminary injunction, Judge Ronald Whyte of United States District Court for Northern California noted that it could be hard for network operators to decide quickly and fairly whether an activity brought to its attention was illegal.
"There is a split at the moment at the lower court level that turns on fine distinctions of fact and law as to Internet service provider liability," Sandra Sellers, a vice president for intellectual property enforcement at the Software Publishers Association, said.
The legal uncertainty does not hamper the new on-line sleuths. "Four years ago there wouldn't have been a demand for our service," Sudeep Bose, president of Infringatek Inc. of Alexandria, Va., said.
Now, however, so many marketers of brand name goods, including Victoria's Secret catalogue, want him to track down counterfeit wares on the Internet that Mr. Bose is moving his business with its eight full-time employees out of his home and into an office.
Paramount Digital Entertainment, a unit of Viacom Inc., handles things differently. The company, which has rights to the Star Trek television series, keeps trying to persuade the on-line world to refrain from reproducing Trekkiana. It looks for illegal copying itself, and also asks fans to E-mail suspected cases to its Web site -- a kind of cyberneighborhood watch.
The detective business is beginning to pay off.
Datalytics Inc. of Dayton, Ohio, an on-line business service firm, has added Markwatch, "to help you detect potential infringement, dilution, tarnishment and genericide" of trademarks.
"We do major searches for over 100 companies," including Reebok, said Herbert Lichtman, a lawyer and software expert who developed the idea. The charge is $895 per profile per year; some companies order many specialized profiles of their products. The demand for the service is strong, Mr. Lichtman said, though he declined to disclose total revenue.
Datalytics culls references to its clients from the Internet, along with their context, and sends clients weekly lists detailing these. The clients can decide what action, if any, to take.
Company actions against Web sites are sometimes problematic. A site critical of Kmart that used a derogatory verb in its headline changed its name to "Xmart" after the operator got a notice from his service provider -- who had been reached by a public relations firm representing the retailer -- asking him to "remove the icon K and any appearance with the K and the likeness used by Kmart."
If the operator of the Web site had stood on a street corner making derogatory remarks about Kmart, "he would be within his First Amendment rights," said Michael D. Sullivan of Levine, Pearson, Sullivan & Koch. "So they use intellectual property law to come after the guy."
Ian Kitching, a resident of Cambridge, England, received a cease-and-desist letter last year from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation after posting an old spoof of a warranty card for the company's fighter jets. (A buyer, asked how he became aware of the McDonnell Douglas product, is offered several responses, including "heard loud noise, looked up," "espionage" and "was attacked by one.")
"This is a misuse of our company name and does not reflect the image of McDonnell Douglas," wrote Gary Hutti, the company's information director. Mr. Kitching is still posting the spoof.
The improvements in the technology made the need for policing inevitable, said James A. Powers, a Bethesda, Md., attorney who represents multimedia developers.
"The original Net was open," he said. "But now that we have the World Wide Web which can transmit not just data and text but graphics and multimedia, ownership and getting economic value from works has become paramount."

Sudeep Bose, foreground, Infringatek's president, said an increase in business means the company will move from his home into an office. (Photographs by Erik Freeland/Matrix for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ERA OF DOWNSIZING CREATES JOB BOOM FOR CLASS OF '97

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Ind.

 BODY:
At colleges and universities around the country, the class of '97 is graduating this spring into the most auspicious job market in memory, a product of today's soaring economy and, in many ways, the large-scale layoffs that cut a swath through their parents' generation.
From huge state universities like Indiana University here to high-end private schools like Williams College in Massachusetts, from brand-name institutions like Dartmouth College to Red Rock Community College in Colorado, from Northeastern to Northwestern, colleges, universities and professional schools are reporting record numbers of recruiters on campus, often offering more jobs than they can fill. 
 "I did eight interviews and got four offers, but I could have had more -- I ruled out two of them early on," said Vijay Bhagavan, a 21-year-old accounting graduate who got a $35,000 starting position as an auditor with Price Waterhouse in Chicago. "I'd say 90 percent of my friends have jobs, and most had them relatively early. Basically, if you did your part right, you should have got a job by November, which makes Christmas break a lot more fun."
The current job market reflects the upswing in the overall economy with unemployment now below 5 percent and the go-getter predilections of a generation of students who have made junior- or sophomore-year internships as big a growth area as full-time jobs for graduates. And Internet job searches, now the rule on most campuses, have made the process of finding employment much more efficient.
But, in an odd twist on the experiences of their parents' generation, the surge also reflects the years of layoffs for which many companies are now frantically trying to compensate. Many experts believe that companies laid off too many employees in the early 90's and now that business has boomed beyond expectations, they are recruiting college students for sales, managerial, technical and support positions.
"Corporations downsized too much," said Maury Hanigan, the chief executive of the Hanigan Consulting Corporation, which advises Fortune 500 companies on how to recruit college students. "They laid off people with a lot of experience, and they also laid off their bench strength so that they had appropriate staffing for the amount of business they were doing in, say, 1991, but hadn't anticipated how much it would grow. Now they need college graduates to replace all those people who were laid off."
The National Association of Colleges and Employers says the best opportunities are in high-technology industries, especially in hardware and software development and computer consulting, which are hiring new graduates in computer science, computer information systems, computer engineering and electrical engineering. But accounting, business administration, economics, finance and marketing graduates are also in extraordinary demand.
"There shouldn't be a senior in America who wants a job that doesn't get one this year," said Jim Greeley, director of career services at Merrimack College in North Andover, Mass.
The stories from diverse campuses around the country are uniformly upbeat:
*At Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., 366 companies conducted interviews on campus, compared with 292 at the same time last year. The number has doubled since 1992-93.
*At Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., more than 500 companies recruited, up almost 40 percent over last year.
*Caldwell College in New Jersey had 20 recruiters on campus. Last year it had one, United Parcel Service, offering mostly part-time positions.
*At the two-year M.B.A. Program at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth in Hanover, N.H., not only do virtually all graduates have plum jobs, but virtually all the first-year students have them already as well.
*At the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, the starting salaries of this year's M.B.A. graduates at investment banking firms jumped to $75,000, from $61,000 last year.
*At Columbia University, companies that usually finish recruiting by January were still posting new jobs in May. Also showing up were some businesses that have not recruited in years: public relations, communications, advertising, city government and not-for-profit organizations.
"I've been here 30 years and without a doubt there's been more interviewing activity on campus, more job offers, and more companies than I can ever remember," said C. Randall Powell, assistant dean and director of placement at the University of Indiana School of Business here. "In terms of getting a job, this is one of the premier years ever to have graduated from college."
Ms. Hanigan said undergraduate hiring at Fortune 500 companies, which has been on the rise since 1992, will be up at least 20 percent this year over last year.
For many liberal arts graduates, of course, the job prospects are not as glittering as for newly minted business graduates or M.B.A.'s.
"The philosophy or anthropology graduate doesn't necessarily have employers beating down at their doors," said Alan Goodman, director of career services at the Catholic University of America in Washington. "They still have to work very hard to find positions that call for their skills and knowledge."
But he said the spillover of the strong market will benefit those graduates as well. And liberal arts schools, like Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., or St. John's College of Annapolis, Md., say students are getting jobs ranging from investment banking to the Peace Corps or the Americorps. Others, as always, opt for wholly unconventional jobs. One student at St. John's reports going to work as a "groundskeeper/ grave digger/sausage maker/dog trainer" at a monastery.
The upbeat mood is hard to miss on this 1,860-acre Indiana campus of rolling hills, known for the volatile basketball coach Bobby Knight and the world's largest student union, where most students affect the well-scrubbed look of aspiring middle managers and where graduation speakers proudly pay homage to "Hoosier values."
Harry Jones, 26, an M.B.A. graduate, who will become an assistant product manager for the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, like most M.B.A. graduates went back to school after a few years in the work world. He knows boom times do not last forever, but he looks out to the future and sees mostly bright prospects.
"I think this is still the land of opportunity," said Mr. Jones, the father of two small children. "I know economic cycles have an impact, but the biggest factor is the attitude and skills you have. The job market is so good now it can skew your perceptions, but even in tougher times I think you can make things happen."
But for many students, the upbeat mood is tempered by the ups and downs of the economy and the wave of layoffs in the early 1990's.
John Warneke, 23, who is going to work in sales for Ikon Office Solutions in Indianapolis, at a starting salary of $30,000, was able to choose among four offers. But he remembers that when he was a junior in high school, his father was laid off from his job as a plant manager, and he keeps in mind that the work world will not always look so sunny.
"Fear drives you," Mr. Warneke said. "I'm motivated by the idea that nothing is secure, that you'd better produce or you could be gone. In fact, when I was talking with companies, I was always keeping in mind where they might be 5 or 10 years down the line. I think you've got to keep that fear, because it's when you get in a comfort zone, that you lose your competitive advantage."
As a result, the overwhelming majority of graduates see their job at graduation not as the beginning of a straight line of advancement within a company, but of what is likely to be a zig-zag path from company to company, job to job and skill to skill.
"Because these students were at least teen-agers when all the downsizing happened, and saw, if not parents, friends, uncles, someone laid off, they begin with the understanding that there's no such thing as lifetime employment, and they're responsible for their own career," Ms. Hanigan said. "You ask them how many know someone who was laid off and every hand in the room goes up. They believe it's part of life, like getting a cold, so they know job tenure is a short-term thing not a long-term commitment. It's an economic transaction that lasts only so long as it works for both sides, not a marriage."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Crime and Politics

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
Donna Ratliff was 8 years old when her uncle was convicted of sexually molesting her. Two other members of her family abused her. Her mother regularly beat and threatened to kill her.
When she was 14, two years ago, Donna poured kerosene around their house in Huntington, Ind., and set it on fire. Her mother and an older sister died in the fire. Donna pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was sentenced to 25 years in prison. She was put in Indiana's maximum-security prison for women, in a unit where some of the other prisoners threatened her physically and sexually. 
 Last week the Indiana Court of Appeals ruled that imprisoning Donna with adults violated the state's Constitution. It has a specific provision requiring separate "institutions for the correction and reformation of juvenile offenders," so they will not be hardened by adult criminals.
But if President Clinton and the House have their way, Donna Ratliff and others like her may have to be locked up with hardened adult prisoners. That is one provision of a bill that was passed by the House a week before the Indiana court decision.
The bill would offer $1.5 billion to the states if they met new standards of harshness in the way they treat young offenders. Among other things the states would have to insure that any juvenile charged with a violent crime was tried as an adult unless the state attorney general found that the public safety would be "best served" by trial in a juvenile court. And those convicted would in some instances have to be confined in adult prisons.
House Republicans turned down elements of a juvenile crime bill put forward by President Clinton, including prevention measures and a proposal for safety locks on handguns. But the two bills shared the same premise: that even though national crime figures are falling, young people are committing worse crimes and need to be dealt with more harshly.
There are shocking cases of violent crime by juveniles. They arouse public demands that the accused be tried as adults, and most states have recently passed laws to that end.
Whether trying young people as adults actually reduces crime is an open question. An article in The Economist of London last month described two recent studies -- in Florida and New York-New Jersey -- comparing the subsequent records of defendants tried in juvenile and adult courts. The latter were more likely to be arrested again, and sooner. The Justice Department questioned those findings and is sponsoring further research.
But one thing is clear: All juvenile offenders are not alike. Some really are career criminals by the time they are 15. Others are like Donna Ratliff. We know about her because her story was brought to public attention by Larry Hayes of The Fort Wayne (Ind.) Journal Gazette and Fox Butterfield of The New York Times.
Donna grew up in desperate poverty, sometimes going for days without food. The mother who beat her had herself been sexually assaulted by her father. In the maximum-security prison Donna has been with women convicted of abusing their children. She was forbidden to talk about her experiences because, prison authorities said, that would upset the others.
Those who have dealt with Donna say she is intelligent, she needs to talk and she needs counseling. She could be someone when she gets out of prison. Or she could pass on to another generation the wounds of a dysfunctional family.
Supporters of the new Federal legislation say the differences between one young person charged with crime and another can be taken care of by prosecutorial discretion. But prosecutors have too much unreviewable power already. And they tend to use it zealously because it is good politics to "get tough on crime."
Congress and President Clinton are driven by the same thing: politics. They are intruding the Federal Government into an area that has been and should be left to local decision. Washington cannot know best how to handle a juvenile in Huntington, Ind.
Where are all the politicians who talk so much about "turning authority back to the states"? For the sake of looking tough, they are putting an iron national grip on a diverse problem that needs diverse local solutions. They are showing our children a model of hypocrisy.

HEADLINE: That Fine Spring Day in 1947

 BODY:
Looking back 50 years to the dawn of the cold war, a certain modesty is in order. We now know who won, and can itemize the mileposts of victory. The nuclear peace held, the industrial democracies hung together, and over time the Soviet empire collapsed, just as George Kennan foresaw in his pivotal "long telegram" from Moscow in February 1946. There he urged collective resistance to Stalin's expansionary drive, yet presciently added that the success of the Soviet system "is not yet finally proven" and its permanence "need not yet be regarded as assured."
But the fate of the Soviet Union was unknown when Secretary of State George Marshall rose on June 5, 1947, to deliver the commencement address at Harvard. What he did know was not encouraging. In Washington, his boss, Harry Truman, had plunged in approval ratings, abetted by the first Republican Congress since the 1920's. Europe, still bleeding from the war and having just endured the century's worst winter, faced in Marshall's words "hunger, desperation, poverty and chaos." 
 Nor was it a good time to ask Americans to offer erstwhile adversaries and prostrate allies, including a no longer friendly Soviet Union, billions in loans and grants. Americans had already voted nearly $20 billion for postwar emergency programs and were in no mood to spend more. In March 1947, when Truman asked a reluctant Congress to appropriate $450 million in security aid for Greece and Turkey, the loudest applause the President elicited was when he promised the money would be promptly repaid.
Nonetheless, in Cambridge that fine June day, in six fateful sentences, Marshall said America would open its purse wide if Europe, including the Russians, came up with a promising recovery plan. These were the seeds of what Winston Churchill called "the most unsordid act in history." From 1948 until 1951, with Republican support, some $13 billion, the equivalent of roughly $80 billion today, was disbursed in Marshall Plan grants and loans. This opened the way to NATO, the Common Market, Franco-German friendship, and thus the Western world we know today.
Granted, Marshall aid was not charity, it generated a thriving market for American exports and its deeper motive was political, to shore up the European center-left and to contain the Soviet Union. But Marshall and his chief deputy, Dean Acheson, rightly gambled that Stalin would boycott the July meeting in Paris prompted by the Harvard speech. Stalin went further. He later barred Czechoslovakia from participating, presaging the 1948 Communist coup in Prague and the hardening of the Iron Curtain that Churchill had perceived two years earlier in another commencement speech, in Fulton, Mo.
With hindsight, the end of the cold war was foreshadowed in its advent. Under Stalin, the Kremlin assumed that a capitalist economic crisis would engulf and cripple the West. Certain it would triumph no matter what, Moscow proceeded to drain $14 billion from Eastern Europe between 1948 and Stalin's death in 1953, the same period in which Washington provided $13 billion to Western Europe. The Soviet bloc, for all its outward might, was rooted in subservience and rapacity.
The real surprise in newly opened cold war archives is how few surprises have thus far emerged. So writes John Lewis Gaddis in "We Now Know," a brave early attempt to distill these documents into a narrative. Stalinist Russia was as dangerous and devious as Mr. Kennan concluded in his remarkable telegram. The onus for dividing Europe rested with Moscow, and so long as Stalin was in charge, conflict was inescapable. Where Americans (though not Mr. Kennan) erred was in underestimating the political and economic weakness of the Soviet system, a misjudgment that contributed to the tragic intervention in Vietnam.
But this was not so evident 50 years ago. Facing a Soviet adversary with global appetites and a nuclear capacity, Washington rose impressively to the occasion, summoned life from the ashes of Europe and rallied support for a bold and demanding response. Today's threats are more subtle and require more nuanced responses. The planned eastward expansion of NATO mimics the grand strategies of the earlier era but seems misplaced at a time when the consolidation of democracy in Russia is paramount. Still, America has every reason to look back with awe and admiration at how it met the great challenges that followed World War II.

HEADLINE: Japan Reports Trade Surplus Soared in April

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, May 19

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose sharply in April as auto makers and others cranked up exports to compensate for slower growth in domestic demand after the Government raised the national consumption tax, economists said today.
The surplus increased 163.7 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier to 831.48 billion yen, or $7.23 billion, the Finance Ministry said. The rise, which was the second in the last three months, followed nearly three years of declines. Automobile and machine makers that lifted production to meet strong domestic orders before April are now focused on competing for market share overseas. 
 Japan's politically sensitive trade surplus with the United States rose for the seventh consecutive month, increasing 174.1 percent, to 468.97 billion yen, or $4.16 billion.
That could irritate the Big Three American automobile companies, which have seen Japanese auto makers increase their share of the United States market this year.
The rise in the trade surplus came as the dollar rose sharply against the yen, before slipping this month. A stronger dollar, and thus a weaker yen, makes Japanese goods less expensive overseas. In Tokyo trading, the dollar briefly slipped to less than 115 yen on word of the trade-surplus rise, down from 115.45 just before the release of the numbers, but later recovered.
If the dollar continues to fall from the highs it reached against the yen earlier this year, it could limit the rise in the Japanese trade surplus by making the country's exports more expensive again.
Japanese exports in April rose 21.5 percent, to 4.43 trillion yen, the Government said.
Exports of every major industrial category rose. Auto exports to the United States rose 25.4 percent in April from the corresponding month the previous year, to 230 billion yen.
Imports to Japan rose 8.1 percent in April, to 3.59 trillion yen. The Government raised the consumption tax by 2 percentage points, to 5 percent, on April 1.
 The stock market had a muted reaction to the report. At midday, the Nikkei index or 225 issues was up 97.91, to 20,422.44, or a half-percent. On Friday, the Nikkei rose 268.42 points.

HEADLINE: Rethinking the News;
Papers Seek More Personal Connection With Readers

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
Most daily newspapers save the front page for their most important news. But The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette is experimenting with a Sunday front page that has no news on it at all -- only highlights of features in the rest of the paper. And people seem to like it.
Most dailies publish letters and opinion articles from readers. But The San Jose Mercury News in California turns most of a weekly features section, Celebrations, over to heart-warming articles written by readers. It is one of the paper's most popular sections. 
 And most dailies print long, multipart series on important news or social events. But The St. Petersburg Times in Florida took the concept to new lengths by running a 29-part serial, complete with end-of-chapter cliffhangers, about a woman whose secretly gay husband contracted AIDS and died. Sure enough, sales got a lift while the serial was running.
From coast to coast, and in big cities and small ones, newspapers are embracing color and drama and intimacy in hopes of better connecting with their increasingly distracted and time-pressed readers. These efforts are squarely aimed at reversing grim trends faced by nearly all newspaper editors and publishers: declining circulation, an aging readership and weaker ties between the public and their papers.
Some of the largest dailies, like The New York Times, USA Today and The Wall Street Journal, aim for a cosmopolitan and affluent readership, reaching a national audience by publishing at distribution centers across the country and extending their geographic boundaries even further through the Internet. Such papers have retained their focus on national and international news, business news, analysis and the arts.
But editors and publishers at more locally oriented papers say they must appeal to the widest range of potential readers and particularly to their weakest audience segments -- women and young people. In the process, they have begun to question some of the basic assumptions of print journalism -- that hard news trumps soft features in the allocation of space and staff, for example. Or that, in American journalism, it is up to editors and reporters to do the talking while the customers shut up and pay attention.
In this new world of adaptive journalism, readers and newspaper marketers are getting a bigger say in what goes into the paper. Like it or not, editors and reporters are being forced to do the listening .
"We are trying to get out of the business of being the mediator between our readers and the news and into the business of listening over the back fence while people talk," said Jerry Ceppos, the executive editor of The Mercury News. Describing the reader-written Celebrations section, Mr. Ceppos said, "We are trying to solve the problem of a metropolitan newspaper seeking to maintain its connection with its readers."
Many of these changes in American journalism have their roots in the influential market research of Yankelovich Skelly & White in the late 1970's, which found that newspaper readers wanted more "self-oriented" features and local news.
The studies, paid for by a newspaper industry already concerned about declining readership, also reported that readers wanted no loss in hard news. Some critics say that in the intervening years, the hard news part of the equation has been lost.
"In one sense, it's comforting to see newspapers trying to please their readers this way," said John Polich, a media consultant and professor of media management at the Fordham University business school. "But on the other hand, it's frightening," he added, "because a lot of these things undermine what newspapers spent the first couple of hundred years in this country learning to do -- which was to be the gatekeeper, to be a filter of all the true and false and gray-area information that is out there every day and to deliver what journalists thought was important and useful."
Edward Wasserman, the former business editor at The Miami Herald who now publishes Miami Business Reviews, three business weeklies covering South Florida, was even blunter. "Newspapers have been tarting themselves up like a cheap diner's commemorative place mats for better than a decade," he wrote in the current edition of The American Journalism Review, "and they're still shutting down, and readership numbers are still declining."
Indeed, the percentage of adults in the United States who read a weekday paper declined to 64.2 percent in 1995, from 77.6 percent in 1970, according to the Newspaper Association of America. Sunday newspapers have recovered some readership in part because of the advertising supplements and discount coupons.
No one paper exemplifies all of the experimentation under way in the industry. But all of the tinkering seems aimed at the common objective of a more emotional and intimate relationship with readers.
Tom Koenninger, editor of The Columbian in Vancouver, Wash., is working down a list of 32 community groups, from real estate agents to Conservative Christians to the Clark County Saddle Club. Representatives of each group are being invited in for coffee and conversation.
"We had the medical society in, and we found out they were mad at us for an article we did on managed care in 1984," Mr. Koenninger said. "They were still mad, and we didn't find out until we asked them to come for a visit."
John G. Craig Jr., the editor of The Post-Gazette, echoes many editors elsewhere in conceding that his newsroom staff members worry that the innovations are being made at the expense of the tasks that newspapers still perform better than any other medium, which is to report and explain the news in depth.
"The internal debate was extraordinarily ferocious," Mr. Craig said of the decision to try the no-news Sunday front page. "A lot of the people in editorial were talking about integrity issues and suggesting that we were selling out to the devil."
But along with other editors nationwide, Mr. Craig insists that newspapers can become more appealing to readers without giving up their best qualities.
So last fall, Mr. Craig went to work on his Sunday bulldog, the edition that goes on sale Saturday afternoon and does not normally have much fresh news to report. It is the only edition of the week that is sold exclusively on the streets and in stores.
As a test, Mr. Craig split his bulldog circulation, printing a conventional front page of hard news and photographs for distribution in the northern and eastern parts of the Pittsburgh market. For the southern and western parts, the front page consists of color photos, drawings and brief upbeat captions highlighting the features inside the paper -- an experimental design that has been given names like "the teaser" by the circulation staff and "revolting" by the news staff.
On Sunday, April 13, for example, the conventional bulldog front page offered stories about Iowa's success in privatizing state liquor sales (Pennsylvania is moving in the same direction), an explanatory feature about high-definition television and a report on problems at the city's convention center.
The same day, the experimental front page offered cartoons and photo ads for a spring golf preview in Section DD, the promise that "Parade Magazine counts the ways America is still Number One," the lure of a travel feature on the Chesapeake Bay on page F1, and so on.
"The idea really goes to the heart of a lot of newspaper maxims, like 'A good news headline sells papers,' " Mr. Craig said. "Well, we have done one front page with a good news head and one that was mostly about what was in the TV magazine. And the grotesque and outrageous front page sells better than the traditional one."
The difference is small, 3 percent to 5 percent, said David Stolar, the director of single-copy sales at The Post-Gazette. But these days, the circulation wars are being fought over tiny increments. "There are people out there every day who are on the fence -- are they going to buy a paper or not?" Mr. Stolar said. "If we can just get a 3 percent swing in sales, that's a couple thousand more papers that we've sold."
In two weeks, The Post-Gazette will switch distribution sectors for the Sunday bulldog through December, after which the paper's executives will evaluate the experiment.
Getting that extra few thousand sales, and perhaps luring a different kind of reader, was also part of the inspiration last fall for "Three Little Words -- A Tale of Trust, Betrayal and Redemption," the 29-part series in The St. Petersburg Times about a woman's discovery of her husband's secret life as a homosexual and her subsequent ordeal as he died of AIDS.
Each installment of the serial was written to be read quickly -- the time it would take a reader to drink a cup of coffee -- said Neil Brown, managing editor of The Times.
"There is still a lot of discussion at the paper about whether it worked as journalism, but I think we can all agree that it was worth trying," Mr. Brown said. "We were intrigued about trying this as a way of reaching another kind of reader, and maybe a younger reader, who would drop a quarter in a box to read a different kind of story."
Apparently it worked, because the paper saw its sales bump slightly upward during the serial, although overall circulation remains flat.
The quest to reach young readers, especially minority youths, and develop future newsroom talent prompted The Kansas City Star in Missouri to create Teen Star, a weekly half-page pull-out section of news reporting and personal experiences by local teen-agers.
Attracting younger readers is high on the list for many newspaper executives.
The Sacramento Bee in California, for instance, closed its Mexico City bureau during the recent West Coast recession, cut its San Francisco bureau to one reporter from four and has delayed plans for a Pacific Rim bureau until business conditions improve. Right now, said Rick Rodriguez, managing editor of The Bee, the paper has a higher priority: hiring a second pop music critic.
"I think all newspapers have to be interested in getting young people as readers, and in Sacramento, we do a good job of it, but we have to do better," Mr. Rodriguez said. "And getting younger readers might mean making some changes in staffing emphasis."
In San Jose, The Mercury News's efforts to tap into readers' emotions seems to be succeeding, judging by the response to the reader-written Celebrations features. The articles occupy most of the cover of the paper's Silicon Valley Life section on Thursdays. Regular Celebrations departments include "Quotable Kids," "How I Met My True Love" and "The Seven-Second Philosopher."
One of the fans is Peter Jonnard, a math teacher at Capuchino High School in San Bruno, Calif. "I know you can't put every kid who graduates from high school on the front page," Mr. Jonnard said, "but to thousands of people like me, something like that is more important than something that happens a thousand miles away."

HEADLINE: College Minority Enrollment Slowed in 1995

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Several years of rapid gains in the college enrollment of minority students gave way to more subdued growth in 1995, according to a report to be released today by the American Council on Education in Washington.
Education officials worry that the slowdown will turn into an actual decline after recent cuts in affirmative action programs in Texas and California. 
 "Our primary concern is that the trends continue in the right direction, and that the current turbulence over affirmative action in Texas and California does not create a stall or send the trends in the wrong direction," said Stanley O. Ikenberry, the president of the council.
Gary Orfield, a desegregation expert at the School of Education and the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, saw a special significance in the report's findings.
"To see the enrollment rates slowing even before those policy changes occur suggests how incredibly high the stakes are in the reversal of affirmative action," Mr. Orfield said.
The council's study, "The 15th Annual Status Report on Minorities in Higher Education," showed a 2.9 percent increase in overall minority enrollment in 1995, the most recent year for which data were available. In 1994, the gain was 4.6 percent, and in 1993, 7.1 percent.
African-American enrollments were up 1.7 percent in 1995 over 1994, to 1.5 million. Hispanic enrollments grew 4.6 percent to 1.1 million. Asian-American enrollment rose 3 percent, to 797,000 students. And American Indian enrollment was up 3.1 percent to 131,000. Total enrollment at colleges was 14.3 million.
The study did not address why minority enrollments had slowed, but educators said a stronger economy and greater ease in finding jobs might have diverted some prospective students from college. They also cited higher tuitions and cuts in financial aid as possible obstacles. Donald Stewart, the president of the College Board, which administers many college and graduate school entrance tests, said some college officials expected a drop this fall in minority enrollment, particularly by black and Hispanic students in the West. Fewer minority students applied to public universities in Texas and California this spring, although those states have not fully imposed the cuts in affirmative action.
"It's not because of changes in admissions policies, but because of fears of changes in policies," Mr. Stewart said.
The study made clear that while college enrollment by white high school graduates had climbed significantly in 20 years -- to 43 percent in 1995, up from 32 percent in 1975 -- there was little or no improvement among minority groups.
Slightly more than 35 percent of black high school graduates from 18 to 24 years old were enrolled in college in 1995, three percentage points above the level in 1975. The rate for Hispanic graduates was 35 percent in both years, though it has fluctuated in the 20-year period.
The number of black college students is at an all-time high, but William H. Gray 3d, the president of the United Negro College Fund, said this was not good enough. The percentage of blacks in college, Mr. Gray said, should match the level for all students. The report said that 42 percent of all 18- to 24-year-olds were in college in 1995.
Officials at the American Council on Education, an umbrella organization for the nation's colleges, universities and other education associations, said their research had highlighted a variety of problems.
One was the low high school graduation rates of Hispanic students.
In 1995, the latest year for which the council had data, fewer than 60 percent of Hispanic 18- to 24-year-olds had completed high school or earned an equivalent degree, significantly less than the 77 percent rate for African-American students and the 82 percent rate for whites.
"You can't make progress in opening education opportunities in higher education if they are not graduating from high school," said Mr. Ikenberry, the council's president.
Deborah Carter, associate director of the council's Office of Minorities in Higher Education and a co-author, with Reginald Wilson, of the study, pointed out that Hispanic students who complete high school enroll in college in similar proportions to black students -- about 35 percent.
"Much more attention has to be paid to this issue," Ms. Carter said. "By 2015, the Hispanic population will be the largest ethnic minority in the United States. Not to attend to this issue would be a major travesty in terms of providing equal educational opportunity."
The council's report also highlighted problems among some Asian-American groups. Over all, 55 percent of Asian-Americans from 18 to 24 years old were enrolled in college. But among subgroups, the figures ranged from a high of 66 percent of Chinese-Americans to a low of 26 percent of Laotian-Americans.
"The Laotians, Cambodians and some Vietnamese and Filipino immigrants have some major hurdles in terms of language skills," Ms. Carter said, "and demonstrate some of the same at-risk characteristics that other low-income students face."

Oracle Seen Investing In Netscape Affiliate
Oracle is expected to announce a majority investment in Navio Communications Inc., a company established by Netscape Communications to develop Internet software for the so-called network computer and for other consumer electronics. 
 The investment could give a lift to Oracle's strategy of developing a network computer as an alternative to the personal computer, which Oracle's chairman, Lawrence J. Ellison, says has grown too complicated. [Page D6.]

The sparse ranks of minority radio and TV station owners are growing thinner, a result of the consolidation frenzy in the radio industry and compounded by the elimination of a tax credit that had favored minority groups. Broadcast ownership among minority groups, which was estimated to have slipped by a tenth last year, now represents about 3 percent of the nation's broadcast properties. [D9.]

Separately, Ammirati Puris Lintas bought Integrated Communications, an agency specializing in health care. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]
 
State Dangles Pollution Credits
New York State has recently chosen a novel approach to luring businesses into the state: offering pollution credits bought on the open market to companies willing to set up shop in the state. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Teachers Resist Teaching in English

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 18

 BODY:
On an island where English is routinely spoken in government and business, heard and read in the news media and widely accepted as a ticket to economic opportunity, a plan to begin using it as a second language of instruction in public schools has prompted demonstrations by teachers and predictions of cultural suicide.
Teacher organizations say they oppose the Puerto Rico Department of Education's "Project for Developing a Bilingual Citizen," calling it a political rather than pedagogic move by a pro-statehood government that wants to make the island more palatable to Congress. Bills are pending in Washington to give Puerto Ricans the chance to vote on the island's political status -- whether statehood, independence or some form of association with the United States -- by next year. Puerto Rico's Spanish-speaking population is a major roadblock for proponents of making the island the 51st state. A nonbinding plebiscite in 1993 showed the island sharply divided between statehood and the current commonwealth status. 
 Teachers are also concerned that the school system is ill prepared to add English instruction for subjects like math and science, mostly because most teachers are not bilingual themselves. Plans call for phasing in English instruction, beginning when the new school year starts in August. Officials with the Teachers Federation of Puerto Rico said that many teachers planned to sabotage the effort and that some were already hoarding Spanish textbooks to avoid using the new ones in English.
"I will refuse" to teach in English, said Digna Irizarry, 45, a math teacher who was among several hundred teachers protesting Friday in front of the Education Department with signs reading, "I'm Puerto Rican. I Speak Spanish" and "Math is difficult enough in Spanish, imagine in English."
The controversy echoes the national debate over English-only laws in the United States, a debate prompted by a growing population of Spanish-speaking immigrants. But unlike in the states, the invading language here is highly valued. Because of Puerto Rico's nearly century-old political association with the United States, which has kept the island as a territory since it was ceded by Spain after the Spanish-American War in 1898, there are Federal courts and agencies here that do business in English. Jobs routinely require bilingual skills, and English textbooks and tests are the norm in many university programs.
Anglicisms, long part of the vocabulary of even the educated, keep going strong thanks to cable television and the Internet.
But Spanish is held as a pillar of Puerto Rico's culture, and even the pro-statehood New Progressive Party maintains that it is nonnegotiable: even under statehood, Spanish and English would co-exist, the party promises.
The mother tongue, however, has hardly been immune to the forces of Puerto Rican politics. Just in 1991, pro-commonwealth Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon elevated it to sole official language, only to have the current Governor, Pedro J. Rossello, who is pro-statehood, obtain legislation two years later making English officially equal.
Statehood advocates put the need for bilingualism in practical terms. "We're Puerto Ricans and U.S. citizens; we're both," said Carlos Romero Barcelo, Puerto Rico's representative in Congress. "Our language of birth is Spanish, but we also understand that to widen our opportunities we must speak both languages."
But others see the latest effort as a not-so-veiled attempt to assimilate Puerto Rico, or at least to portray it as assimilated.
"Puerto Rico is a Spanish-speaking country, and to introduce in a massive way instruction in English is to try to Americanize us, to return to the past," said Carmelo Delgado Cintron, the former director of the Institute of Puerto Rican Culture, who now heads a group called Spanish First. "I don't have anything against the United States, but we have a culture that should be valued and defended."
Although English was the main language of public school instruction here in the first half of the century under governors sent from the mainland, Spanish replaced it for all courses except English class beginning in 1949. Census figures show that only about a quarter of the population of 3.7 million is bilingual.
Starting in August, the island's public schools will intensify the learning of English by using textbooks in English for the first time for courses other than English, by extending English classes to 90 minutes from 50, and by giving priority to reading and writing in English in first, second and third grades. The Department of Education also plans to retrain and certify Puerto Rican teachers as specialists in English and bring teachers from the United States to offer technical assistance under exchange programs.
Education Secretary Victor Fajardo said that he was giving teachers the option of lecturing in either language and that "we agree that English will always be the second language of education." But his goal, he said, is to introduce English in every course "so that we create a climate where English is a presence."
Mr. Fajardo said his plan was a response to test scores last year indicating that 90 percent of the island's 650,000 public school students lack basic English skills by the time they graduate from high school. He said he wanted public school students to have the same advantages as those in private schools.
But the emphasis on English comes as test scores are showing deficiencies in all other subjects, including Spanish. Teachers blame crowded classroom and shortages of books and other materials. And College Board test scores from 1980 to 1995 showed that while averages for English improved, those for Spanish were on the decline.
Although there is debate here about what the best age is to immerse children in a second language, a larger concern among many teachers is that English may be emphasized at the expense of Spanish and other subjects. They say the department would do better if it simply strengthened the existing English program.
"In three years we won't know neither English or Spanish or math or science because we're adding an element of complexity to students in their learning and an impediment for teachers to teach," said Jose Eligio Velez, president of another teachers' group, the Teachers Association.
At the Julio Selles Sola Elementary School here in San Juan, parents were generally supportive of more English instruction, although they said they knew little about the plan beyond published reports. Raul Rivera, 37, who has a 12-year-old son and an 8-year-old daughter in the school, recalled how when he went to college he was forced to use a dictionary and ask for tutorial help to understand the English textbooks.
"I wouldn't want my children to go through that experience," said Mr. Rivera, who now teaches microbiology at the University of Puerto Rico. "But I'd like both English and Spanish teaching to be improved."
The issue recently led to a rare outburst of English on the Senate floor by Senator Kenneth McClintock, a statehooder and the son of a Puerto Rican mother and a Texan father who grew up here.
"I wanted to make the point that there's nothing bad about English," Mr. McClintock said. The Senate minority leader, Antonio J. Fas Alzamora of the pro-status quo Popular Democratic Party, said the new policy was just one more example of the promotion of statehood with public money by the Rossello administration.
"They don't want to accept reality," he said of statehood proponents. "They want to disguise the fact that Puerto Rico is a distinct nation."

HEADLINE: Tenure Denial to a Woman Puts Harvard in an Uproar;
Rejection From Leader Who Vows Diversity

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18

 BODY:
The denial of tenure to a brilliant young scholar at Harvard University is hardly a rare event. Indeed, decisions over tenure -- the academic prize that confers a job for life -- are often contentious, with all the political intrigue of, say, a White House Cabinet appointment.
But the decision last month by Harvard's president, Neil L. Rudenstine, to deny tenure to a rising star in the faculty of arts and sciences -- Bonnie Honig, 37, an associate professor of political theory -- has led to a firestorm of speculation and protest the likes of which has not been seen here in recent history. 
 Mr. Rudenstine's decision has raised sensitive questions over his attitude toward affirmative action at a time when he has proclaimed the hiring of more tenured female faculty members to be one of his top priorities. The uproar, which has been front-page news in The Harvard Crimson and the talk of faculty meetings and dinners, provides a rare window into the byzantine tenure process at one of the world's most prestigious universities.
Professor Honig, who has published two books, with the manuscript for a third recently accepted by Princeton University Press, had cleared all the tenure hurdles save one: winning Mr. Rudenstine's approval. His decision, amid his administration's drumbeat for affirmative action, has mystified faculty members and students.
"I am personally very pleased with Neil's statements about diversity, and the leadership he is taking on diversity," Mary C. Waters, a professor of sociology, said in an interview. "That's why it's such a complex issue. Here you've got this real liberal guy who says all the right things. And this case comes up that's just so perplexing."
The centerpiece of the protest, itself the subject of as much talk on campus as the president's decision, is a letter that 15 of the most senior and distinguished women on the faculty sent to Mr. Rudenstine asking him to reconsider and questioning his commitment to affirmative action.
At Harvard, where the senior faculty women are not known for their militance, where even tenured faculty members, men and women, are reluctant to criticize the administration, the letter amounted to a near-revolutionary act.
Describing Professor Honig as "a brilliant, highly productive and widely respected political theorist," the letter, which The Harvard Crimson obtained through undisclosed sources and published on its front page on Monday, read: "Your decision to refuse Honig tenure has been greeted with shock and disbelief across the university and beyond. It is especially incomprehensible given your publicly stated commitment to equality for women."
The 15 women who signed the letter include Martha Minow, professor of law; Theda Skocpol, professor of government and sociology; Carol Gilligan, professor of education; Seyla Benhabib, professor of government; Laurel Thatcher Ulrich, a Pulitzer Prize-winning professor of history, and Professor Waters.
"The Honig affair is puzzling to us," Professor Benhabib said, "because according to all institutional criteria and criteria of scholarship, she has fulfilled Harvard's requirement for promotion and tenure."
The letter supplied such insider's details as the strong departmental vote in favor of Professor Honig, as well as the support she had from four out of the five members of the ad hoc committee that reviewed her case.
Another letter that was leaked to The Crimson and that startled people here was one written to the 15 women by Harvard's associate dean for affirmative action, Marjorie Garber. "I hope your argument will prevail with President Rudenstine," she wrote, "since I too think the university -- and the students -- will be much the poorer without Bonnie Honig's presence on our faculty."
The official silence from Mr. Rudenstine on his reason for denying Professor Honig tenure has only fueled the speculation.
In a letter of response to the 15 women, which was provided to The New York Times by a faculty member sympathetic to Professor Honig, Mr. Rudenstine shed no further light on his decision but wrote, "I assure you that my commitment to the advancement of women at Harvard remains unequivocal."
Affirmative action is a particularly sensitive issue here as Harvard is in the midst of a $2.1 billion fund-raising campaign. The university has been smarting from the attention given to a group of alumnae of Radcliffe College, which merged with Harvard in the 1970's, and their organized challenge to what they view as Harvard's unimpressive record of hiring tenured women.
The group has persuaded alumni to divert nearly $500,000 in gifts into a protest escrow account to try to force Harvard to act.
Of 418 tenured members of the faculty of arts and sciences, 48, or 11.5 percent, are women, and it is widely acknowledged that progress has been made during Mr. Rudenstine's five and a half years as president. From 1991 to 1996, the number of tenured women in the faculty of arts and sciences increased by 26 percent, to 48 from 38, while its tenured faculty as a whole grew by 6 percent.
At the same time that Professor Honig was denied tenure, so, too, was Peter Berkowitz, also an associate professor of government. The outcry over Professor Berkowitz's denial has been muted in comparison with that over Professor Honig's.
There are five women among the 28 tenured members of the government department.
Professor Honig said she had been gratified by the support on her behalf.
She arrived at Harvard in 1989, with graduate degrees from the London School of Economics and Johns Hopkins University. Her work, which draws on post-structuralist and feminist theory and is a critique of liberal political theory, is regarded as cutting edge.
She grew up in Montreal, where she attended an Orthodox Hebrew elementary and high school. "Talmud was reserved for the boys," Professor Honig said. "I always wanted to study Talmud. Political theory, in the end, met that need."
She said she and her husband, Michael Whinston, a tenured professor of economics at Harvard, were weighing their options. Professor Honig has received an offer of full tenure as a professor of political theory at Northwestern University. Professor Whinston has also received an offer of tenure at Northwestern.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 20, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about protests over the refusal of tenure to a woman at Harvard University omitted a response from Neil L. Rudenstine, the university president. He declined to comment, citing the confidentiality of the tenure process.
