SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORK OFFERS POLLUTION PERMITS TO LURE COMPANIES

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 18

 BODY:
New York State has long offered companies tax breaks, low-interest loans, grants and other incentives to lure them into doing business in the state. But now the Pataki administration is dangling a new kind of enticement: permission to pollute.
Over the last year, state agencies have accumulated millions of dollars in so-called pollution credits. The credits, a free-market innovation created by the Federal Clean Air Act of 1990, are generated by agencies and companies that keep their polluting emissions below Government limits. 
 The credits are bought and sold on the open market. Any company or state agency with a good emissions record can sell its credits -- essentially, the permission to pollute -- to a company unable or unwilling to meet emissions standards. Or it can retire the credits permanently and reduce the potential of further pollution.
But the Pataki administration has recently chosen a novel approach that has prompted an intense debate: offering the credits free to companies willing to set up shop in New York. Without the credits, the companies might find it hard to do business here, and either have to buy credits on the open market, or find ways to reduce pollution.
The administration says its policy will still result in reduced emissions, because a new company that receives the credits will not be allowed to produce the full amount of pollution the credits allow.
"We try to make it easier for manufacturers to move into New York," said Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation, the state economic development agency, which has already given credits to a glass company building a plant in upstate Geneva. "It was a unique and innovative idea."
But environmentalists are voicing deep concerns over the policy, saying it raises several important questions: Why should the state subsidize polluters? Isn't the environment better served by permanently retiring these credits? And is it proper to promote economic development at the expense of the public's health?
The debate in New York underscores the policy conundrum that other state and local governments face as they decide how to use or regulate such credits in the fledgling free market in pollution.
In Maine, widespread protests forced state officials to back away from a plan to offer pollution credits to a paper company. In New Jersey, state regulators require companies to retire 10 percent of any credits sold, a policy that angered some in the business community. And in Connecticut, the state no longer grants waivers to companies whose emissions exceed allowable limits, forcing them instead to buy pollution credits.
"There are a lot of ideas on how to handle this market," said Jason Grumet, the executive director for the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, a group of air pollution regulators from eight Northeast states, including New York and New Jersey. "States are having to make important choices on how to use these powerful market approaches to achieve the dual goal of environmental protection and economic development."
New York's approach, one of the first of its kind in the nation, has prompted a particularly troublesome dispute for Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who has cast himself as a staunch defender of the environment but whose policies have often been attacked by environmentalists.
The policy of handing out the pollution credits underscores what many regard as a fundamental dilemma for Mr. Pataki: how to protect the environment without alienating the business community, an important political ally of the Governor's.
To many environmentalists, it seems oddly inconsistent for Mr. Pataki to enact such a policy, given that just last month he wrote out a personal check during a news conference to buy $50 in pollution credits in order to retire them permanently and thus remove them from the market.
The environmentalists wonder why the state would undermine its efforts to reduce pollution by giving away the credits it earned. "It's disturbing that the state would turn around and give away pollution credits that it has accumulated by reducing its own pollution emissions," said Peter Ironowitz, an air-quality expert for Environmental Advocates. "The state should be retiring them for the public health, not giving them to business."
The policy is relatively new, enacted by the Governor through an executive order he signed in July 1996 with little public notice. The executive order required state agencies to do two things: conduct an inventory of their pollution emissions and then hand over their credits to the Empire State Development Corporation. That agency, in turn, was instructed to offer the credits to businesses as an incentive to move to New York or expand in the state.
To date, the state has qualified for credits equivalent to the emission of 150 tons of nitrogen oxide a year, a big component of smog. The credits are sold on the open market for between $150,000 and $450,000 in upstate New York, but 10 times as much in New York City, the administration said.
The Pataki administration has given all those credits to Guardian Glass, a glass manufacturer that needed the credits to get a pollution permit to build a 696,600-square-foot plant in the upstate community of Geneva.
The administration contends that the deal is good for both the environment and the economy. It says that the company had to obtain 1.15 tons in credits for every ton of pollutants it expects to emit.
"We're reducing emissions from the state's own facilities at the same time that we're allowing economic growth and job creation to occur," Gary Sheffer, a spokesman for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, said. "We're achieving a balance."
But environmentalists and Democratic legislators say they are concerned not only by the policy itself but also by what they view as the relative secrecy under which it was enacted.
Richard L. Brodsky, the chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee in the State Assembly, said he was disturbed that the decision to transfer the credits to Guardian Glass was reached without an extensive public review. He has begun an inquiry into the legality of the transaction.
"The process by which these decisions are made must be open and accountable," he said in a recent letter to John P. Cahill, the state's Acting Environmental Conservation Commissioner. "To the best of my knowledge, they have been behind closed doors, and the public has received no public notice or justification."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 20, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about New York's offer of pollution credits to companies that relocate in the state misspelled the surname of an environmentalist who expressed concerns about the plan. He is Peter Iwanowicz, not Ironowitz.

HEADLINE: Demystifying the Method;
Once-Exclusive Actors Studio Reaches Out to the Public

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Looking back on his career, Paul Newman said recently, "The Actors Studio can take the credit or the blame for what I've become as an actor."
Which is it, credit or blame? In answer, Mr. Newman chose the noncommittal road: "The Studio has to accept the responsibility." 
 Although there would seem to be a note of irony in the actor's voice, almost all his colleagues at the Studio, from Julie Harris to Al Pacino and Alec Baldwin, could echo that statement. With its use of the naturalistic style of acting known as the Method, the organization has had an indelible effect on American acting in films as well as onstage. It has also left its signature on the actors themselves, a gallery of the most talented performers from several generations.
This year the Actors Studio is celebrating its 50th anniversary. In the theater, an art with a short shelf life, that should make it a venerable institution. After all, the Group Theater, its prestigious predecessor, lasted only 10 years. There is something about the exploratory nature of the work that keeps it youthful. Although it has had its struggles, it remains a vibrant organization, one that seems to be changing to keep up with theatrical times. This once-secret sanctuary has opened its doors -- slightly.
The Studio was born on Oct. 5, 1947. Two months later, "A Streetcar Named Desire" by Tennessee Williams opened on Broadway. As directed by Elia Kazan, a co-founder of the Studio, the play established several careers, including that of Marlon Brando, who galvanized audiences in the role of Stanley Kowalski. The actor and his performance came to signify the essence of the Method.
The Method, Lee Strasberg's version of the acting system first developed by Konstantin Stanislavsky for the Moscow Art Theater, uses physical and emotional exercises as a way of encouraging actors to explore their own psyche while preparing for a role. Before the Method, acting training in the United States emphasized language and text rather than psychology. That was fine for dealing with the classics and popular Broadway fare, but limited with the new, emotionally revealing drama of playwrights like Mr. Williams.
Throughout its history, the Method has had its critics as well as its partisans, with detractors mocking what they thought of as self-indulgence. But it was soon clear that the best of the Method actors like Mr. Brando probed deeply into their characters, and uncovered a greater psychological truth.
Ellen Burstyn, a past president of the Studio, defines the Method as "character expressed through behavior." She said: "The Studio is truly a workshop. Lee always said that acting is an art in which the artists use themselves as the artistic tool. Actors work with the emotional life of human beings, and that's very reclusive. It is like an artist's atelier, a place for actors to find their voice."
In its lifetime, the organization has had periods of controversy, and after Mr. Strasberg's death in 1982 it seemed to be in eclipse, but it continues to have a strong influence.
Arthur Penn, the stage and film director who is the group's current president, said that the image of the Studio as a "kind of closed, almost mystical society is slowly undergoing a change." This was a feeling that was perpetuated during the 30-year reign of Mr. Strasberg, who became an all-powerful teacher. Now, the Method is taught at many other schools and conservatories, and, said Mr. Penn, "the Studio is no longer the temple it once was." Although the work sessions, the core of the training, remain private, the public is now invited to see more of the results.
In a quest to widen the perception of the organization and also to encourage the writing of new plays with large casts, Mr. Penn has been presenting a series of free workshop performances of plays by Jay Presson Allen and others at the Raw Space theater on West 42d Street.
Three years ago, the Studio moved into the educational arena, starting a Master of Fine Arts program at the New School. Today, the first class will graduate. As part of their curriculum, students have classes in dance, voice, play writing and theater history as well as acting. The students range in age from the early 20's to the early 60's. To earn their degrees, they act in their own productions of plays at Circle in the Square Downtown. After graduating, they are urged to audition for a place in the parent organization.
"We are the cadet company of the Actors Studio," said James Lipton, dean of the School of Dramatic Arts at the New School.
 
A Deep Experience That Changes a Life
One of the 77 graduates, Peggy Lee Brennan, an actress from Staten Island, had been on Broadway in "Grease" and worked in movies and on television. She regards the three-year program as a life-changing experience: "I needed to be stretched. I wanted to be something more." Robert Lavelle, an actor from Memphis, said: "I feel like I'm standing on a foundation of work now. It's a psychologically astute and informative course of study, but it also teaches you the nuts and bolts -- a means of survival in this business."
As part of the master's program, Mr. Lipton conducts public seminars with famous actors and directors, a series that is broadcast on the Bravo cable channel. The series is called "Inside the Actors Studio," although the guests include nonmembers (Billy Crystal, Julia Roberts) as well as members (Mr. Newman, Christopher Walken).
Members meet regularly at the Studio itself, a former church and now a landmark building (on West 44th Street). They bring in individual projects, and more experienced actors like Ms. Burstyn take turns as group leader. In a recent work session, an actress was so overcome that she broke down during a scene. "Work through your tears," advised Ms. Burstyn. Later she explained the reason behind her suggestion: "Very often actors become emotional and they try to control their emotion. The point is to allow it to flow and to keep on working. Then the whole scene can come alive."
Because these sessions are closed, except to certain professional observers (and students from the master's program), a certain mystery still persists. One of the questions is how the organization began.
The idea of creating a new workshop for actors was first discussed by Robert Lewis and Mr. Kazan during what Mr. Lewis describes as their "famous walk in Central Park." Cheryl Crawford was subsequently brought in, making it a founding triumvirate. Mr. Strasberg did not arrive until a year later, after Mr. Lewis had resigned, but his name quickly became synonymous with the Studio. Running his own classes, Mr. Lewis continued to have an influence on actors.
From the first, the Studio was conceived as a place, in Mr. Newman's words, where experienced actors "could reinvestigate and re-examine their craft." When he joined, he was fresh out of the Yale Graduate School of Drama, and had appeared in summer stock: "It gave me a chance to see how the most gifted American actors worked and to see the nature of their exploration,"
As the organization developed, attitudes toward it were as diverse as the stories about its creation. Norman Mailer, an active member since 1958, said that at first it was more a church than a club, and "either you were an acolyte or you resisted it." What he liked was that even as an outsider (and a nonactor) he was allowed to speak up. Mr. Mailer said that over the years the group had become more eclectic and less secretive. With dry amusement, he compares it with the C.I.A. "They have parallel histories," he said, adding, "We may not have as many scandals as they do."
It still is an exclusive club with stringent entrance requirements. Actors have to go through a rigorous audition, and if they fail they often apply again and again. It took seven auditions before Geraldine Page was accepted. Lee Grant, one of the members who opened the West Coast branch, says, "It's the only place where talent, not success, gets you in." Once people are accepted, they are members for life; there are no requirements or fees. There are currently about 800 members. Almost everyone works without pay.
During Mr. Strasberg's time, there were occasional crises, including the failure of the Actors Studio Theater on Broadway in 1963. After Mr. Strasberg died, a sequence of presidents eventually led to Mr. Penn, who has been a member since 1953. Recalling his early days there, he said: "It was much more of a fraternity or sorority. As the cult of personality grew, the exclusionary policy grew. Finally it became Strasberg's place." Although he is hesitant about criticizing Mr. Strasberg's domination, he makes it clear that his intention has been to make it more an actors' place.
 
Staying Afloat Without Any Grants
In pursuit of that goal, he plans to ease the entrance requirements so that "extraordinarily accomplished actors" can be invited to join. "I hope the 50th anniversary will be something of distinction in the diminishing American consciousness about art," Mr. Penn said. "There is something to be celebrated, that people have stayed together and have done it on a voluntary basis. We have no government support and years ago the grants ceased. But somehow the Studio has endured."
It is now supported by private contributions. During periods of economic stress, board members like Mr. Newman have stepped in with emergency money. The program at the New School and the Bravo series have finally given the group a certain financial stability.
On the outside, Mr. Lewis, now 88 and still teaching, can look back with bemusement. He remembers his differences with Mr. Strasberg, which were substantive and esthetic. When told that the organization he helped create retains its cachet after half a century and that actors still compete to become members, he said: "Well, I'm going to apply. Do you think they'll take me?"

HEADLINE: Observer;
Screams At the Window

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
American politics is dead. Government is scarcely breathing. Washington media people worth hundreds of millions of dollars are withering away for lack of news from the Potomac shore. Desperate columnists sob and say, "There is no news."
No news? Nonsense. Of course there is news. This is a country with 250 million people who don't want any news from Washington and, even if they did, wouldn't expect any news from Washington because they don't think Washington could pour stale beer out of a boot if the instructions were printed on the heel. 
 These people are mad, as in, "I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore." As in "Network," the movie that gave us that line, these people, expecting nothing of consequence from any government, can only go to the window and scream. Or write to a convenient newspaper columnist.
Here is John M. of Queens, N.Y., and he is mad about car alarms. Inspired by the President's recent dog-and-pony show about volunteerism, he wants "to donate crowbars and wire cutters to open the hood of cars whose alarms blare outside my window at all hours."
Traffic studies, too, have him steaming. "In 1993," he writes, "Queens Borough President Claire Shulman earmarked $900,000 to study the huge number of traffic fatalities on Queens Boulevard. Another $200,000 was added to this fund. The study finally began this year -- sort of. I believe they are studying how to begin the study. Yes, that's it."
He wants to volunteer to drive "a bit more slowly and carefully, on constant alert for the elderly, children and disabled hastening to make their rent of $800 a month for an overcrowded basement in Flushing."
Here is a New York woman, Phyllis H., mad about "a bus ride from hell" -- presumably New York -- to Philadelphia:
"On the 9 A.M. bus, a mandatory movie! VCR screens, the sound track loud and clear through the P.A. speaker at each ear, Sergeant Bilko barking all the way! Ditto on the return trip."
This is just one example of the entire society's determination to entertain you whether you like it or not. She lists other examples:
"Was regaled with light hillbilly music while strapped into an M.R.I. machine at N.Y.U. Medical Center -- my preference not solicited."
"Telephone 'holds' connected to loud rock music. . . . Doctors' and clinic waiting rooms with canned music keyed to the lowest common denominator."
"A neighborhood supermarket's paging system hooked up to a local radio station, commercials and all, obliterating all memory of items I came in for."
Yes, Phyllis H., your dudgeon is perfectly justifiable. But why do you omit the irritating airport wait for an irritatingly behind-schedule flight, during which there is no escape from the hundreds of TV screens assaulting eye and ear in every recess of this aviation hellhole?
If politics were not dead, if government were about anything anymore, something would be done to stop this wanton and brutal entertainment with which inhuman agencies infest the world, presumably to distract us from the temptation to think.
For dudgeon at its highest, however, our award goes to Steve V. of Pomona, Taxifornia, as he styles, I assume, the Golden State.
This irate Taxifornian has been reading news stories about how Franklin D. Roosevelt statues should pose the late President in his new monument. He has some suggested poses of his own:
"F.D.R. with his hand stuck firmly in the taxpayer's pocket.
"F.D.R. wheeling back and forth over the corpse of American liberty.
"F.D.R. torching the Ninth and Tenth Amendments.
"F.D.R. prolonging the Depression by eight long agonizing years, thanks to his idiot economic notions.
"F.D.R. creating the bankrupting pyramid scheme laughingly called Social Security."
Out of consideration for readers who have not served in the military or have been avoiding the movies lately, I omit Steve V.'s suggestion about how to pose F.D.R. with Josef Stalin at Yalta.
"These poses would be quite appropriate since F.D.R. is one of two Presidents who ruined the Republic," he concludes. "(In case you are interested, the other traitor is Abe Lincoln.)"
Mr. V. identifies himself as "President of the League to Tear Down Any D--- Monument to D--- Politicians."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Issues Flat In a Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Government securities were relatively flat in light trading yesterday, as investors waited for the Federal Reserve's monetary policy arm to meet today to decide whether another interest rate increase to slow the economy was warranted.
The 30-year bond slipped 6/32, to a price of 96 11/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.92 percent, from 6.90 percent on Friday. 
 Maureen Mooney, an analyst with GovPx, a bond pricing service, said it was the slowest day this year, including half-day sessions that preceded holidays. The value of securities traded was only about $42.6 billion by late yesterday, below the previous low for the year, $44.8 billion on Feb. 10.
The dollar rebounded yesterday in currency trading, which gave the market some early support. A strong dollar makes investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors because of the potential profits from currency translations.
But rates at the weekly auction of Treasury bills yesterday were up from the previous week, as investor interest was low before the Fed meeting. Bills and other securities with short maturities would be most immediately affected by any Fed action.
The average rate for a three-month bill was 5.17 percent, up from 5.08 percent last week. And the bid-to- cover ratio, or the number of bids compared with the total amount of securities offered, was 4.32 to 1, well below the average of 6.14 to 1 over the last 12 auctions and the lowest since 3.88 on Dec. 23, 1996. For the six-month bill, the average rate was 5.35 percent, up from 5.30 percent a week earlier, while the bid-to-cover ratio was 4.21 to 1, below the 12-week average of 5.48 percent and the lowest since 3.82 to 1 on Oct. 15, 1996.
Market participants remained sharply divided in their expectations of the outcome of the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the panel that determines monetary policy. Some analysts have pointed to signs of slowing in the economy since the Fed raised a key short-term interest rate by a quarter percentage point in March, saying no further moves were needed to reduce inflationary pressure.
But Lou Brien, an analyst with Finacor Vendome Inc., a Chicago brokerage firm, said, "It is unlikely that a quarter-point move was enough to satisfy the Fed's pre-emptive urges." The low unemployment rate and strong economic growth of the first quarter remain strong arguments in favor of another rate increase, he added.
Likewise, Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said he favored a further tightening, saying recent reports that showed subdued inflation were less important for their future implications than the employment figures, which have shown an increasingly tight labor market. Those numbers, as well as signs of strong consumer confidence, he said, "suggest that the Fed should be more opportunistic in doing another pre-emptive strike rather than take a pragmatic approach and wait through the July period for more data."
But Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said that the Fed was likely to hold rates steady.
"We now expect the Federal Reserve system to leave the Federal funds rate unchanged for two major reasons," he said. "First, we believe that the expected economic slowdown has become sufficiently evident in most of the latest business data. Second, the latest inflation data were mostly benign."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Scripps to Buy Harte-Hanks Media Assets

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The E. W. Scripps Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the newspaper and broadcasting properties of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. for between $605 million and $775 million.
Harte-Hanks, which is based in San Antonio, said in March that it would sell its newspaper and broadcasting properties in order to focus on faster-growing direct marketing and free publication businesses. 
 "Newspapers have been the heritage of the company," Larry D. Franklin, the president and chief executive of Harte-Hanks, said in a telephone interview. "But strategically this will allow us to focus all our resources on these other businesses, which together account for about 75 percent of our revenues."
The deal involves six daily newspapers -- five of them in Texas -- along with the television station KENS-TV and the radio station KENS-AM, both in San Antonio.
"This is the kind of deal we've been looking for," William R. Burleigh, the chief executive of Scripps, said. "For an attractive price, we are going to greatly increase the geographic diversity of our newspaper division through the addition of five mid-sized markets in the vibrant Texas economy, plus one growth market in South Carolina."
The price Scripps will pay for the properties depends on the outcome of Federal legislation, introduced last month, to restrict the tax-free sale of assets under a so-called Morris Trust structure. A vote on that bill is expected later this year.
If a tax-free exchange of shares is allowed, Scripps will pay about $425 million in its stock and assume $200 million of Harte-Hanks debt. If Scripps assumes no debt, the amount of stock it will issue will increase to a maximum of $605 million.
If the Morris Trust structure is disallowed, Scripps will pay $775 million in cash for the properties.
Scripps said that regardless of how the assets are paid for, the deal is expected to dilute its 1998 earnings by about 5 percent.
The deal is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission. Scripps said it did not expect the deal to close until 1998.
Wall Street analysts said the deal made sense from both sides, even without the Morris Trust provision.
"Strategically, Harte-Hanks had a reason to sell and strategically, Scripps had a reason to buy," Lauren Fine, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said. "If Scripps were to get these assets at, say, $625 million, I would say it is a home run. At $775 million, it is not a bad deal, but not overwhelmingly positive."
On the New York Stock Exchange, Scripps's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $38.125. Harte-Hanks's stock price rose $1.125, to $30.125. News of the deal appeared in The Wall Street Journal yesterday.
The properties Scripps is acquiring "fit in their core competencies of television and newspapers," Michael Kupinski, an analyst at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, said.
"The San Antonio television station is in a great market, and the newspapers are in small but good growth markets with attractive operating margins," he said.
The five Texas papers Scripps is acquiring are The Corpus Christi Caller-Times, The Abilene Reporter-News, The Wichita Falls Times Record News, The San Angelo Standard-Times and The Plano Star Courier. Also included in the deal is The Anderson Independent-Mail in South Carolina. The San Antonio television station, KENS-TV, is a CBS affiliate.
Excluding its newspaper and broadcasting properties, last year Harte-Hanks had revenue of about $600 million, Mr. Franklin said.
The Cincinnati-based Scripps has television stations in nine markets and newspapers in 16 markets. The company also has an entertainment division that includes two television production companies, a licensing and syndication branch and a cable television network. Last year, it had revenue of $1.1 billion.

HEADLINE: The Road Warriors: Battling Over Rte. 92;
The Long and Winding History Of a 'Gateway to the Jersey Shore'

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The proposed Route 92 has been on the drawing boards in New Jersey for 60 years, its path changing so much through time that the original planners would barely recognize it. After all this time, it is a road plan that is still dodging those who would make it road kill.
Once grandly styled as the "gateway to the Jersey Shore," the road was proposed in 1938 as a 25-mile-plus freeway, running from just west of Princeton through Hightstown and east to Route 33 and the Atlantic Ocean. Now it is the state's last major uncompleted road project, a $300 million, 6.5-mile, high-speed, limited-access toll road that would connect Route 1 to the New Jersey Turnpike at Jamesburg. 
 The road has been supported by a dozen governors, although not always ardently; a succession of Princeton University presidents; more mayors over time than those who have opposed it; labor unions, and blue-chip corporations.
Like the inconstant moon, it has waxed and waned, never quite disappearing from planning documents and state legislation, steadily changing as it collided with great and small events, from World War II to demographic shifts to budget problems.
Now the road, which transportation officials say has the longest history of any road project in New Jersey, has run into another problem.
The Federal Environmental Protection Administration has raised questions about the need for the road and about its environmental impact. The agency will hold public hearings on June 10. Those follow other hearings last year by state environmental officials, several two years before that by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, which is to build the road, and myriad hearings by the State Department of Transportation during previous years.
The new Federal questions have sent turnpike authority engineers scurrying to make changes that will cost $21 million. They have unearthed decades-old traffic plans and studies, and begun new studies to show why no other alternative will do to ease the traffic on Route 1.
In a time when most highway budgets focus on maintenance, proposed Route 92 is a road out of time, said Jeff Zupan, a transportation consultant with the Regional Plan Association. In the 50's, the three states of Connecticut, New York and New Jersey were building 62 miles of limited-access highways a year, 48 miles annually in the 60's and 25 miles a year in the 70's. By the 80's, there were only 7 miles of such roads built each year in the three-state region, and that figure is even lower now.
Citing sprawl, environmental effects and high costs, he said, "Projects like Route 92 now face the triple threat."
The Federal agency's intervention was a setback for the turnpike authority and the business, labor and government groups who formed an association called 92 Now, who view the Route 1 corridor as the economic engine of the region. But it elated opponents of the road, who see it as an unnecessary blot on some of the last farmland in the central part of the state.
Robert Wolfe, manager of the Princeton Forrestal Center, a research and office park campus on Route 1 that is home to 110 companies with 11,000 employees, said the Federal intervention threatened efforts to promote growth in the area and proved, "Big Brother is still staring over our shoulders. " If the road is built, the office park will have its own exit ramp.
"You would think that after it has been on area master plans for more than 50 years they would have said something before now," he said.
Cathy Dowgin, a member of a group called No-92, applauded the Federal agency's action. Now, says Mrs. Dowgin, whose house in South Brunswick looks out over farmland, she will see soybeans this summer and not the beginnings of a 300-foot-wide asphalt ribbon.
"This road is unnecessary and is a private driveway for employers like Princeton-Forrestal," she said. "There are so many alternatives that they could use that wouldn't affect the wetlands. People don't want this road. Big business does."
At $50 million a mile, many experts suggest that Route 92 will be a costly exercise that will increase, not ease, congestion. David Bernstein, a professor of civil engineering at Princeton University, said it would induce demand, bringing in more traffic. Dianne Brake, a planner with the Middlesex, Somerset and Mercer Regional Planning Council, which supports the road, noted that in many ways it was conceived to channel development. When it went unbuilt because of scarce financing and pockets of political opposition, development mushroomed anyway.
Richard W. Aughenbaugh, a former Mayor of Hightstown, said recent events are eerily similar to what happened to the roadway three decades ago, when it was mired in Federal Highway Administration demands for studies of countless alternatives.
"It was paralysis through analysis, and opposition groups sprung up like weeds," he said.
Long before there was a New Jersey Turnpike, there was a proposed Route 92. It first appeared on state maps as Route 31A in 1938. But in the war years, road work related to military efforts took precedence.
In the early 1950's, the focus was on construction of the New Jersey Turnpike. It was not until 1966 that the road seemed possible as Federal highway funds became available.
Shortly thereafter, it was redesignated Route 92, and opposition began to be heard from areas that had been pastures and fruit orchards a decade before. The road remained on state maps through the 1970's and 80's. By 1987, the Hightstown bypass was separated from the rest of proposed Route 92 in state plans. At the same time, on the western end near Princeton, the part of Route 92 that connected Routes 27 and 206 was dropped because of local opposition and environmental concerns.
The concept of Route 92 as the east-west road to the shore had been eclipsed by development along the Route 1 corridor. Spurred by the proximity of Princeton University, as well as Philadelphia and New York, the corridor was becoming a destination of its own. Office parks and subdivisions sprang up, turning rush hour on Route 1 into a nightmare.
By the early 90's, responsibility for building the road was transferred to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.
Edward Gross, the executive director of the authority, said the agency decided that Route 92 should be a high-speed toll road that, unlike most state roads, would not "have a curb cut" at every development and business along the way. The authority immediately redrew the road to have it run from Exit 8A on the turnpike to the heart of Route 1 corridor around South Brunswick and Plainsboro.
Last year, the authority lopped off the western end of the road, from Route 1 to 27, and three months ago, it extended an elevated section of the roadway over Devil's Brook to reduce the impact on wetlands from 33 acres to 18.4 acres.
The turnpike authority's many changes in the road's route effectively made it a different road from the one that state officials had been considering. This was partly why the State Department of Environmental Protection sought the greater involvement of the Federal environmental agency. New Jersey is one of two states -- the other is Michigan -- that administers the regulations of the Federal wetlands protection program, and this was the first time the state had stepped aside in favor of Federal regulators.
Despite the turnpike authority's experience in building roads and its relative insulation from local politics, Mr. Gross conceded in a recent interview that building such a road in the 90's was not for "the faint of heart."
Mrs. Dowgin and other opponents are convinced that the Federal involvement is their last hope in stopping the road. They have picked up support from the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a regional transportation and mass transit advocacy group that questions the need for the road, and from South Brunswick officials like Mayor Deborah Johnson.
Mayor Johnson ridiculed the proposed toll road as one that will do little to ease traffic on local roads. With its 75-cent tolls for cars and $3.50 tolls for 18-wheelers, it was unlikely to alleviate traffic, she said.
By 2000, Turnpike Authority planners expect that 50,000 vehicles will travel at peak hours along a 20-mile stretch of Route 1 from New Brunswick to Princeton to the offices along Route 1. Another 20,500 cars and more than 2,100 trucks will thread their way daily along narrow, two-lane local roads to get from Route 1 to the turnpike.
Mr. Gross said Route 92 would take much of this traffic off local roads and remove 9,000 additional cars daily that now use Route 1 to get on the turnpike farther north in New Brunswick.
"This is the last reasonable opportunity probably ever to make such an east-west connection in the central New Jersey region," he said. "If we don't make it now we won't be able to in the future because it is an area of such high development potential."

1936
When first approved by the New Jersey State Legislature, it was designated State Road 31A and was to be an east-west connector for the central part of the state running from Route 206 to Hightstown and around to Route 33, which runs to the Jersey Shore.
 
MID-1980's
The road had become a federally financed freeway, designated Route 92. Part of the project was split off near Hightstown, and an extension running north to connect with the New Jersey Turnpike at Exit 8A was added.
 
EARLY 1990's
Construction of the road was now the responsibility of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. To placate some residents and environmentalists who opposed the project, the western segment of the road, running between Route 27 and Route 206, was scrapped.
 
1996
To minimize opposition, the current plan eliminates another Western segment running between Route 1 and Route 27 and elevates the roadway as it goes over Devil's Brook to spare large wetlands areas.

HEADLINE: CHANGEOVER IN AFRICA: IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Accepts Kabila, but Cautions on Democracy

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration moved quickly today to extend ties and recognition to the rebel alliance now ruling Zaire, pledging its help in building a democratic government and adopting the name the rebels have given the country, the Democratic Republic of Congo.
But the Administration also called on the country's new leader, Laurent Kabila, to begin taking steps toward a democratic government by holding elections soon and by including opposition figures in the provisional government he is expected to announce when he arrives in Kinshasa on Tuesday. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said that international support -- and, implicitly, aid -- for the government depended on Mr. Kabila's willingness to establish democracy after more than three decades of autocratic rule under Mobutu Sese Seko.
"We are making it very clear that it is important for the new government to be inclusive, to be concerned and do a lot about democratic practices and human rights," Ms. Albright said at a news conference in Wilmington, Del.
The Administration's reactions today reflected both the hope and ambivalence that have greeted the fall of Mr. Mobutu and the rise of Mr. Kabila.
While officials here in Washington have expressed relief that the rebels captured Kinshasa, the capital, with relatively little bloodshed, they remain wary of Mr. Kabila's intentions, noting that the rebel leader has suggested that a transition to elections could last from one to five years. And despite repeated contacts as his rebellion swept over the country, Mr. Kabila has shown little interest in acceding to the United States' demands, even though he has told American officials he shares their views on democracy and a market economy. The officials said Mr. Kabila's announcement of a new government would be an early test of those promises.
Moving to shore up diplomatic contacts with the new leadership, the American Ambassador in Zaire, Daniel H. Simpson, met in Kinshasa today with two of Mr. Kabila's senior aides, Deo Bugera and Paul Kabungo. Mr. Simpson reiterated the United States' eagerness to see the rebels embrace political figures who long opposed Mr. Mobutu, including his longtime rival, Etienne Tshisekedi.
In what officials in Washington interpreted as a hopeful sign, Mr. Bugera, the secretary general of the rebel alliance, asked the Ambassador how to contact Mr. Tshisekedi. Mr. Simpson dialed his cellular phone and handed it to him, an Administration official said.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
A Recurring Theme Plays On: Auto Insurance

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:

The gubernatorial campaign of United States Representative Robert E. Andrews released its first television advertisement yesterday. The Democratic primary is on June 3.
 
 PRODUCER -- Axelrod and Associates. 

 ON THE SCREEN -- Scenes of highways, automobiles and Mr. Andrews in Congress.
 
 THE SCRIPT -- "In Christie Whitman's New Jersey, auto insurance rates are out of control. Seventeen hikes in four years. Highest in the nation. Who's fighting back? Rob Andrews. In Congress, Andrews took on the big polluters, pension raiders and the N.R.A. for working families. As governor, he'll go after the insurance companies. He'll end automatic rate hikes and force companies who want to sell health or home insurance to cut auto rates first. Let's fight back. Rob Andrews for governor."
 
 ACCURACY -- Although the advertisement states that the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has raised auto insurance rates 17 times, that is not correct. All of New Jersey's auto insurance companies have received automatic inflation rate increases of 3 to 5 percent in each of the last three years.
 
 In addition, Mrs. Whitman's insurance regulators approved 11 other rate increases for various companies that said the automatic increases were not enough. The Andrews campaign also counts three rate increases approved by Jim Florio when he was Governor, which took effect while Mrs. Whitman was in office, saying she could have reversed those.
 
 SCORECARD -- The advertisement focuses on drivers' anger over the high price of automobile insurance in the state, an issue that brought hundreds of protesters to Trenton last month. Mr. Andrews says he will end the automatic annual rate increases, which are a leading complaint of voters. Mrs. Whitman also says she will push through legislation to end those automatic rate increases.
 
 Mr. Andrews and his Democratic rivals have so far limited most of their attacks to Governor Whitman; this advertisement is typical of that.
 
 But Mr. Andrews also focuses on his work in Congress in an attempt to show that he has more experience in higher political office than his two other Democratic opponents, State Senator James E. McGreevey, who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, and Michael Murphy, a former Morris County prosecutor.
 MELODY PETERSEN

HEADLINE: Straining Toward an Agreement on Global Bribery Curb

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
With less than a week in which to negotiate a compromise, the United States and its major trading partners remain sharply divided over how to enact and enforce a long-sought global ban on commercial bribery.
The 29-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development hopes to announce an agreement at its annual meeting of finance ministers that opens in Paris on Monday that would subject companies in all member countries to the same restraints that United States business has faced since Congress passed the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act two decades ago. 
 But while most O.E.C.D. members acknowledge the need for a ban on kickbacks, which in some countries are not only tolerated but actually remain tax deductible as business expenses, a rift has developed between the Clinton Administration and some of its key allies on the form the ban should take.
O.E.C.D. officials say that France and Germany, with varying degrees of support from Japan, Luxembourg and Spain, remain opposed to United States calls for all member countries to make a public commitment to pass national legislation within one year to criminalize such bribery. Instead, these five countries want the organization to negotiate a treaty banning bribery.
France and Germany are struggling with record unemployment and must take further austerity measures to prepare for the common European currency They want to make sure that all O.E.C.D. members place identical restrictions on their corporations at the same time, and say that the best way to do this is through a treaty that takes effect only when everyone has ratified it.
The United States and most other O.E.C.D. countries oppose that course, saying that a treaty would take years to negotiate and that finding language acceptable to 29 governments would tend to weaken the ban.
Participants do not expect the talks to collapse. But they say that continuing differences could delay or water down a final accord.
"It's hard to say whether we can bridge the gap in time," said Alan Larson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs and the chief United States negotiator at the O.E.C.D. talks. "But we are going to make another stab at it with a series of further meetings in Paris this week."
No action, of course, will completely stamp out bribery, which is rampant throughout much of the developing world and is also common in robust economies like South Korea and China. But backers of the United States' position say that national laws would have more teeth than an international accord.
"National legislation based on the agreed common principles is the fastest way to get action against corrupt business practices," said Nancy Zucker Boswell, the Washington representative of Transparency International, a private organization based in Berlin, Germany, that fights corruption in international business.
Under a compromise proposal suggested last week by Mark Pieth, the Swiss law professor who heads the O.E.C.D.'s bribery working group, members would commit to outlawing bribery through national legislation while also setting a tight deadline for agreement on a treaty. But Germany and France refused to promise to introduce national legislation to ban bribes if work on the treaty floundered.
While the United States is now the only O.E.C.D. country with a specific statue criminalizing bribery of foreign officials, the Netherlands and Norway have similar laws in the works. And Britain, Canada, Greece, Hungary, Sweden, Turkey and New Zealand all have statutes that could be used to restrict kickbacks in certain circumstances. Despite the paper commitment from all these countries to root out bribery, however, many European countries appear reluctant to move swiftly on the issue.
For example, eight European countries, as well as Australia and New Zealand, continue to let their corporations deduct foreign bribes from their taxes, even though the O.E.C.D. countries agreed last year to end the practice.
To some extent, the gap between the American and European positions is rooted in cultural differences. When the United States Congress enacted its 1977 ban on bribing foreign officials, European countries generally derided the action as an example of American puritanism that was bound to put United States industry at a competitive disadvantage on world markets.
Since then, however, international sentiment has shifted toward the American position, as public disgust over bribery scandals has grown and as the spread of democracy across the globe has led to greater demands for public accountability.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Japan's View Of Rising Yen: Not to Worry

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 20

 BODY:
What is surprising, as the yen shoots up once more against the dollar, is that no one in Japan is screaming.
The yen has strengthened against the dollar by almost 10 percent in the last two weeks, moving from 126.70 yen to 115.60 yen to the dollar. 
 After stalling slightly in foreign-exchange trading in New York on Monday, the yen resumed its ascent today. The dollar fell as low as 113.95 yen in trading this morning. The surge in the yen is the strongest movement to roil the markets since the spring of 1995, when the yen hit a record high of 79.75 yen to the dollar.
At that time, the mightier yen -- which makes imports less expensive in terms of the Japanese currency and exports more expensive in terms of other currencies -- delighted a few Japanese consumers who relish American imported products. But it provoked fear throughout much of corporate Japan, which was worried about the competitiveness of the nation's exports.
There is none of that fear this time around, and in fact, the strengthening of the yen seems welcome all around. Exporters, for instance, may not mind the currency moves, in part because they have had previous experience adjusting to a much stronger yen and because they are still sated from a rush of profits amassed in the days of the cheapened yen.
"The Sonys and Toyotas of the world are so profitable from the windfall gains of the weak yen that any further depreciation to them is redundant," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston Securities (Japan) Ltd.
Americans may have an image of all Japanese as exporters lobbying for a weak yen, but Japan's economy has in many ways become more international so that at certain levels, a weak yen hurts more than a stronger one.
Certainly, as the yen weakened, the increasing number of Japanese who have become fond of L. L. Bean clothes and Jeeps grew miffed with the yen at 125. And domestic companies that import products watched woefully as the weakening yen brought down their stock prices at the same time that stock prices of exporters soared.
The yen was bolstered this time almost solely by verbal intervention from ministry officials, notably Eisuke Sakakibara, the director of the Finance Ministry's International Bureau. Mr. Sakakibara, who has been called "Mr. Yen" because of both his penchant and his ability to move currency markets, told the Japanese Parliament on May 8 that for the last decade, the yen had appreciated on average by 23 yen a year, and that it could hit 103 yen to the dollar by next year.
The market then debated whether 103 was a target or just a projection.
Part of the reason for buying back the dollar, economists said, is that a level of about 100 yen to the dollar would not seem to be supported by economic conditions, such as differences in interest rates and the relative strengths of the economies.
Some economists say a rate of about 120 yen to the dollar would properly reflect the gap in long-term interest rates -- which widened to 4.6 percentage points this spring -- and other economic factors.
Now for some, the quest is to pin down the optimal or most equitable range for the economy as a whole, the point where the most people in this relatively egalitarian society are relatively happy. The Finance Ministry said that it did not use such an optimal range in policy making and that its economists refrained from researching such sensitive topics.
Kenji Yumoto, an economist with the Japan Research Institute, said the optimum range of the yen for Japan's manufacturing was 110 to 123 yen to the dollar. Using a complex econometric model, he discovered that when the yen depreciated beyond 123 to the dollar, the rising prices of imported materials used in domestic and export manufacturing took a toll on industry.
At 137 yen to the dollar, he added, industry is worse off than when the yen is at 110. Thus, the current level would still be advantageous for export manufacturing.
In fact, exporters surveyed earlier this year by the Economic Planning Agency said that they had cut costs and refined their operations to the point that profits were possible in some service industries even when the yen strengthened to 114 yen, extending to the 50-yen level for the fishery industry.
Thus, when the yen was weakening most recently the biggest injury was to importers, consumers who like foreign brands and domestic companies like supermarkets that deal in imported goods. Such companies usually hedge their exposure to currency risk, but protracted weakness has an effect sooner or later.
"Supermarkets usually buy futures contracts six months forward, and if the 125-yen range persisted, the unit price of imports would have gone up significantly," said Masaei Kasahara, an official at the Japan Chain Store Association. "As it was, it was going to begin showing up in sales prices six months from now."
"If the rate stayed at a weak level, it would have been a big blow to us," he added. "But the problem is that when the yen appreciated rapidly, the Government pressured us to do 'high yen' sales to bring in benefits to consumers. On the other hand, they don't tell us to raise our prices when the yen swings toward weakness."
In trading in New York on Monday, the dollar settled at 115.68 yen, up from 115.55 yen on Friday and the dollar's first gain since May 2. The dollar rose to 1.7083 marks from 1.6925 marks, while the pound rose to $1.6393 from $1.6367.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Up, but Uncertainty About the Fed Limits Gains
Stocks rose modestly, but investors were reluctant to place big bets before today's Federal Reserve meeting on interest rate policy.
The Dow industrials stumbled in the morning, but steadily recovered, led by Disney and Procter & Gamble, and closed 34.21 points higher at 7,228.88. Broader market indicators were also higher. [Page D10.] 

Trading was light in the bond market, too, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury rose to 6.92 percent from 6.90. [D20.]
 
Annual Battle Over China Begins
President Clinton began a campaign to win Congressional renewal of normal trading status for China, in an annual exercise that threatens to be more contentious than ever this year. [A1.]
 
Scripps to Buy Harte-Hanks Units
E. W. Scripps said that it had agreed to acquire the newspaper and broadcasting properties of Harte-Hanks Communications for $605 million to $775 million. [D9.]
 
Esquire's Editor Departing
Edward Kosner is leaving as editor of Esquire magazine, a move that has been widely anticipated in the publishing world because of the magazine's weakness in advertising and in newsstand sales. [D8.]
 
Another Gold Find Disappears
One month after Bre-X's purported gold discovery in Indonesia was reported to be a fraud, another exploring company, Delgratia Mining, said that there was "insignificant gold" at its site in Nevada. Delgratia said it had requested a criminal investigation of possible tampering with ore samples. [D5.]
 
Mixed Results From 2 Retailers
Two retailers reported divergent quarterly results. Limited said that operating earnings fell 11 percent, while Toys "R" Us posted a 57 percent gain. [D2.]
 
Dangers of Secondhand Smoke
Secondhand cigarette smoke is more dangerous than previously thought, Harvard researchers are reporting in a study with broad implications for public health policy and possible impact on at least one major lawsuit, involving flight attendants. [A1.]
 
Britain's new Government said that it would ban all cigarette ads and bar tobacco companies from sponsoring sports. [D8.]
 
Office Supply Merger Criticized
Government antitrust officials said that internal company documents demonstrated that a merger of Staples and Office Depot, the office supply giants, would allow the new company to raise prices with impunity in dozens of markets. [D2.]
 
Deal to Ban Bribery Elusive
With less than a week in which to negotiate a compromise, the United States and its major trading partners remain sharply divided over how to enact and enforce a long-sought global ban on commercial bribery. [D4.]
 
Sun to Sell Russian Software
Sun Microsystems said that it planned to sell advanced data-encryption software created by a Russian company to international customers, a decision that is likely to draw Federal Government scrutiny. [D5.]
 
Irrational Exuberance in Shanghai?
China's stock markets have become prone to wild swings of buying and selling, with prices surging more than 60 percent in this year's first four months, one of the sharpest rises in the world, before falling sharply on regulatory moves to cool the frenzy. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Promising Cancer Treatment Test
Researchers from Onyx Pharmaceuticals and collaborating institutions reported promising results in an early trial of a novel treatment for cancers of the head and neck. [C3.]

HEADLINE: CHANGEOVER IN AFRICA: IN CONGO;
In Congo, a New Era With Old Burdens

SERIES: FRAGILE GIANT: The Wasted Years

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KISANGANI, Congo

 BODY:
Mauwa Funidi's face softens and glows for a few moments as she recalls happier days as a brilliant student, as a new college graduate, as a member of a prospering family in a nation seemingly about to enjoy an endless economic boom.
Then Mauwa snaps out of her reverie, and she is back in the squalid university library where she works, unpaid except in promises, trying to protect faded magazines from the wind and rain that blow through the broken windows. 
 She is back in a sordid reality where she survives by selling charcoal on the street, where her family lives in humiliation on the earnings of a cousin who sells her body at the Take-a-Peek bar.
A solid, self-confident woman of 45, one of the most successful women of her generation here in the faded city of Kisangani on the Congo River, Mauwa abruptly fought back tears.
"If my grandfather were alive today, he would be very sad," she said, choking, her eyes wet and luminous. "He would regret that his family turned out this way."
Now her country has a chance to remake itself with the rebellion of Laurent Kabila. But as Congo, known as Zaire during the three-decade dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko, looks forward to a new phase, many families are also looking back at squandered decades and wasted lives.
Congo is a nation whose 47 million people in many ways live in grimmer conditions than when this was still a colony of Belgium four decades ago. In that respect, Congo is emblematic of a group of countries in Africa that have been disasters for their inhabitants.
In most of the world, change over the last two decades has been measured by the pace of progress -- here rapid, there slow, but at least progress. In sub-Saharan Africa, in contrast, per capita income actually fell most of the time since the late 1970's, including a 10 percent drop between the mid-1980's and the mid-1990's.
The tragedy is that this was so unnecessary. Congolese are among the poorest people in the world, with an average income of just $150 a year, but paradoxically Congo is about as rich in resources as any nation in the world, blessed with diamonds, gold, copper and other minerals scattered across vast tracts of untouched jungle. For all the hopelessness that Westerners often feel about Africa today, this was in the 1950's a bustling nation that brimmed with optimism.
To visit Congo and bounce along its horrific jungle roads today is to experience a twilight world where hints of past greatness and squandered potential peek through the trees: abandoned factories, gas stations, plantations and once-stately homes, their doors creaking on old hinges.
One glimpse of the past comes on the road to Stanley Falls, the rapids at Kisangani that were once a famous tourist attraction in central Africa. The road is on the outskirts of town but has been partly overtaken by the jungle and is now so overgrown that one has to leave one's car behind and finish the trip on foot.
Yet overhead are ancient street lamps, some with bulbs intact, stripped of wire but still a reminder to the hiker that this remote and overgrown path was once a well-tended avenue and a part of the modern world.
In the little village of Mambeau in eastern Congo, peasants live in mud houses on the fringe of the jungle and survive much as their forebears did 100 generations ago, without doctors, schools, stores, electricity or any equipment more sophisticated than a hoe. But beside the village is a startling reminder that it was not always so: rows of sturdy brick houses, empty, overgrown and seemingly haunted, where local villagers once lived much more modern lives as they worked on a vast rubber plantation.
Decades ago the plantation was abandoned, becoming an eerie ghost town overgrown with brush, and now the villagers farm only tiny plots to feed themselves, using a small fraction of the land that their parents worked. The vast majority of the plantation has been claimed once more by the jungle, a habitat for elephants and leopards.
The United Nations Development Program calculates that 11 African countries, including Congo, were richer per capita in 1960 than they are today. And the decline in Congo is not just economic, for the family unit is also tearing at the seams, and the majority of children cannot even graduate from elementary school. Many illiterate young people are members of a lost generation that will impose a burden on the country for half a century to come.
Everybody says that Funidi, grandfather of Mauwa and patriarch and namesake of the Funidi family, must be tossing in his grave.
 
Colonialism
Power Preserved For Europeans
Mr. Funidi was born about 1904 in what was then the Congo Free State, the personal property of King Leopold of Belgium. Almost all of the continent had just been seized by European countries in the "Scramble for Africa" of the 1880's, but what became the Belgian Congo was a special prize: a huge country, one-third the size of the United States, with diamonds, gold, copper, ivory and rubber that made King Leopold one of the world's richest men.
To be sure, Leopold's wealth was not extracted easily. Between five million and eight million Africans are said to have died in the rush to exploit the Congo's resources, and early in this century labor bosses were notorious for cutting off the right hands of boys who did not meet their mining quotas. To demonstrate their strictness, bosses showed off baskets of hands.
Belgium also imposed a web of harsh discrimination, excluding virtually all Congolese from any hope of higher education and banning Africans from traveling without a permit, from drinking anything stronger than beer, from becoming engineers or architects or lawyers.
Yet while focusing its efforts on plundering minerals and preserving power for Europeans, the Belgians also built a country that in many respects was impressive. Kisangani, then called Stanleyville, was typically majestic, with stately buildings, broad avenues, concerts by visiting European musicians and spectacular views of the Congo River. In a description that seems incredible today, the writer John Gunther wrote in 1955 that Kisangani was a place with the "liveliness and efficiency of a miniature Antwerp."
The country in those days had one of the highest school attendance rates in Africa, a flourishing arts community, widely published poets and a dynamic economy with a bulging trade surplus and $3 billion in exports each year -- compared with about $400 million now.
"The essence of the Belgian system is to buy off African discontent by giving economic opportunity, widespread social services and a comparatively high standard of living," Mr. Gunther wrote in 1955, and one of the beneficiaries was Mr. Funidi. A tall, lean man who moved to Kisangani about 1943 from the small village where he had been chief, Mr. Funidi got a Government job as a street cleaner. Before he died in 1959, he sent all his children to school and he was one of a large number of Congolese on the verge of joining an emerging middle class.
Mr. Funidi's children and grandchildren celebrated, of course, when Congo became independent in 1960. Throughout Africa, there was elation at the prospect that diamonds and minerals plundered by Europeans would finally enrich local people. The Funidi family already was moderately well off, with educated children and such conveniences as a bicycle, a hand-crank phonograph, a battery-powered radio and a sewing machine.
"Everybody was very happy with independence, because God seemed to have decreed it and everybody expected life to get better," recalled Emmanuel, one of Mr. Funidi's sons. "But it didn't take long to realize that things were getting worse."
At first the Funidi family was relieved when Col. Joseph Desire Mobutu seized power during a political crisis in 1965, for he seemed to represent order and stability. But then everything began to go wrong. The economy stagnated as foreigners were evicted, as rubber, coffee and banana plantations reverted to jungle, as corruption began to asphyxiate business.
Colonel Mobutu became one of the "big men" of Africa, rewarding himself with a fortune usually estimated at several billion dollars.
As the economy stalled, soaring inflation eroded the salaries of Government officials like the Funidis. The pauperization meant that everyone in Congo, not just the elite, had to make do and get by with what they had. Making do has been a way of life in Congo, and it has meant that Government officials take bribes, doctors ignore patients who do not offer gifts, factory workers steal parts from assembly lines, and soldiers wave guns to get "donations."
That is why Mauwa, who as a college graduate once reflected all the hopes and promise of her country, is now a charcoal peddler.
Smart and disciplined, always the brightest student in her class, in 1976 she became the first person in her family to graduate from college. She was given a job as a university librarian, a particularly exalted post in Congo because of the prestige of universities, which were set up only on the eve of independence with the mission of cultivating an educated elite to run the country.
"It will be dangerous to educate the Africans," the country's Belgian leader ruminated at the time. "It will be more dangerous not to educate them."
Yet for all the hopes and resources invested in these university graduates, Mauwa now says bitterly that it was a mistake to go to college. Her job as librarian is almost meaningless, she said, because all classes at the university have been suspended for lack of funds. The library has not had any money to buy books or subscribe to magazines since 1982.
Inflation has diminished her salary as a librarian from the equivalent of $300 a month when she was hired to $11 a month now, and in any case the wages are theoretical. The last pay was in November, after a gap of many months, and for the last half year Mauwa has survived only by buying charcoal in big bags and reselling it in little bags on the curb.
"It's humiliating, it really is," Mauwa said moodily, as she sat at an ancient table in the dilapidated library. "But it isn't quite so debasing when all of the other university graduates are out there beside me, peddling on the street, selling cakes, palm oil, salt, sugar, soap, lemonade."
 
Independence
Hopes Dissolved Into Poverty
The Funidis live in a two-room mud house with a tin roof, dirt floor and a hole in the wall that serves as a window to let in light, in a neighborhood that resembles a remote village more than a part of a major city. A flimsy outhouse made of palm fronds is in the back, and the "kitchen" is the muddy area in front where the children cook dinner each evening over a fire.
The Funidis have no electricity and no running water. Congo is said to have more undeveloped hydro-electric capacity than any country in the world, but most families in the villages never get closer to electricity than when lightning strikes.
The bulwark of the Funidi family today is not Mauwa, who is too poor to generate much respect in the rest of the family and who cannot contribute to family finances. Instead, the main provider is her cousin, Alphonsine, 25, with her earnings from prostitution at the Take-a-Peek Bar.
Alphonsine is a complex figure, an unmarried mother and earnest Catholic who goes to Mass each Sunday and takes Communion and believes God will help feed and clothe her loved ones. And while she waits for His help, she cares for her 7-year-old son, Patrick, and younger brother and sister by peddling herself.
Pauperization has produced countless people like Alphonsine, deeply troubled men and women who fear that what they are doing is wrong but feel that they have no alternative if they are to feed their loved ones. Alphonsine has been a prostitute for only two years; if she had started earlier she might have had the money to save her other child, a baby who died of malnutrition at about the time she began to work at the bar.
"Everybody in the family criticizes me, but I'm the only one putting food on the table," said Alphonsine, a sturdy, strong-boned woman with a steely face. "Mauwa always says she's afraid I'll get AIDS, but then how come she doesn't help? She just scolds, and complaining doesn't help!"
To be sure, Alphonsine knows that the Rev. Louis-Marie Butari at the neighborhood Catholic church would disapprove. And, indeed, Father Butari argues that Congo's long slide has produced a moral quagmire that is at least as wretched as its economy.
"When someone finds himself in economic difficulties, his conscience asks, 'What should I do?' " he said. "For example, if he hasn't been paid, he says, 'I see there are pens, papers, all these other things here, and I can take them and sell them to survive.'
"So the moral framework disintegrates, and people start to steal, and their children follow and do anything to survive, and girls find nothing to eat and so they sell their bodies. For me as a priest, if there is a problem in our society, if there is a crisis, it is because our moral bulwark has collapsed."
Mauwa has university housing, but Alphonsine lives in the family home with her sister Moza, 15 -- who the family is afraid will follow Alphonsine into prostitution -- and her brother Mariabwana, 17, as well as with little Patrick. The father of Patrick is never around, for he is "a bad man," Alphonsine said. "A crook."
Several years ago he ran away and abandoned his family -- a pattern increasingly common in cities across Africa. The vast migrations to the cities by people looking for work have dramatically reshaped the sociology of much of Africa, creating huge new urban slums and undermining the village values that used to dominate society. In Congo, for example, city-dwellers have soared from one-quarter of the population at independence to nearly one-half now.
Kinshasa, the capital, had 40,000 inhabitants in 1940 and is now a vast and unplanned agglomeration of slums housing five million people.
Alphonsine's 27-year-old brother, Londeke, is also a migrant, but he moved from the city to the jungle. A broad-shouldered man with a solemn, handsome face, he searched for a job in Kisangani so that he could be with his family, but the only job he found was mining for diamonds in the jungle a day's journey north of Kisangani.
"I came here because I had nothing at all," Londeke said softly, as dusk fell on his tiny mud house in the mining camp, a three-and-a-half hour hike through the jungle from the nearest dirt road. Londeke sat on a stool, slapping away mosquitoes and flies, his face illuminated by a small fire.
Digging for diamonds is back-breaking toil in a malaria zone, and some of the miners die from cave-ins or disease. Yet countless young men dig for gold, diamonds, copper, cobalt, uranium and other minerals in Congo.
Many miners, like Londeke, work for themselves, although they must give part of what they find to the mine owner. If they are unlucky and do not find diamonds, they will simply fall deeper into debt. Moreover, most of the mines are like this one, in remote parts of the jungle, and so the men spend their time at the bottom of muddy pits, far from their loved ones, heaving a shovel and hoping for a sparkle that will transform their finances.
"I've spent the last two months digging a hole, and I just got to the point where we reached the sand that may contain diamonds," Londeke said, trying to control the excitement in his voice. "Now I'll wash the sand in the creek and see if there are any diamonds."
If he finds diamonds, he said, he will buy merchandise and go into business as a trader, perhaps bringing goods from Kisangani to sell at the mining camp. That way he would be able to spend at least some time with his wife, Marie, in Kisangani, to ease the burden of separation and the strains that have driven them apart.
"We've got tensions in our relationship, of course," Londeke acknowledged, wincing slightly. "Since I've been away this time, Marie has sent three letters asking me to come back. But I wrote back saying, 'how can I come back when I haven't found anything yet?' "
Back in Kisangani, Marie, a vivacious woman with a quick laugh that rings like a bell, grips her son and suddenly becomes edgy as she confides her worries about her husband.
"All the miners there have girlfriends," Marie said with a touch of sadness. "I can't accept it, and there's probably lots of AIDS there. But there's nothing I can do."
 
The Future
Illiteracy Imperils Next Generation
Perhaps in no area has Congo mortgaged its future so dangerously as in education. Once it was among the best-educated of African countries -- in terms of primary education, not universities -- but now Alphonsine's son, Patrick, is typical. He attended only three months of school last year, in first grade, and he is on the verge of dropping out this year.
The problem is school fees, which mostly run $1 to $7 a month per pupil. The Government stopped sending money to schools years ago, so teachers decided that instead of closing the schools down they would charge fees.
"When the students don't pay fees, we don't get paid," Bernard Mwania, the principal of the local school, explained as he sat in his tiny, dark office. The school, built in the colonial period by the Belgians, must have been pretty once, but now its lawns are ripped apart by open sewers and the windows have all been broken and boarded over with plywood so that classrooms are dim and Dickensian.
There seems to have been a precipitous drop in school attendance in the last few years as more families lost the wherewithal to pay the tuition, and now fewer than one-third of elementary school age children attend school, according to a variety of teachers and principals interviewed in various towns and villages. That is about the same proportion that attended school in the early 1950's under Belgian rule.
Now that Kisangani has been taken over by the rebels, the Funidis are cautiously optimistic that corruption will diminish, that school fees will be eliminated, that life will get better.
Another reason for optimism is that other African countries that have endured wrenching national traumas -- like Uganda and Eritrea -- have emerged, however scarred, with a greater sense of nationhood and purpose, and a much greater ability to forge a modern economy, government and society. Indeed, it is the scarred countries that provide some of the continent's greatest success stories, and certainly the rebel-held areas of Congo seem far less corrupt and much better managed than they were under Mr. Mobutu.
But the optimism is tempered by an awareness that the last time there was such hope for change -- independence -- the exhilaration quickly collapsed into a downward spiral of war, chaos and poverty. The Congolese poet Mukala Kadima-Nzuji wrote bitterly of his homeland in those years:
Gorged with blood, with blood, with blood
From the thousands of innocent souls
Lying silently, motionless, without breath
On clods of scorched earth
Even with peace at hand, it is clear that the Funidi family is much less prepared to prosper now than it was in the 1950's.
Then all the children went through elementary school at least; now all the children get little or no education and are illiterate. Then a college education, however rare, seemed a ticket to run the country; now it is seen as just a detour on the way to becoming a charcoal hawker.
"Dad would be very unhappy with the way things have turned out," Londeke said wistfully as he gazed at the embers of his fire at the mining camp. "When he was alive, conditions were better. We had food, we had clothing, and we could afford breakfast. Now we have nothing."
 
Fragile Giant
 
 Later articles will examine other aspects of Congo's troubled legacy and prospects for its future.
