HEADLINE: Funds for the Workfare Transition

 BODY:
New York City and other local governments will be required, under the new Federal welfare law, to find work for tens of thousands of welfare recipients over the next several years, a task no state has ever attempted let alone achieved. Yet New York's Governor, George Pataki, wants to deny local officials the money they need to get the task accomplished. An easy answer to a difficult problem is at hand. Mr. Pataki just needs to grab it.
Our colleague Elizabeth Kolbert cut to the heart of the issue yesterday, pointing out that Governor Pataki wants to take $354 million of a $730 million windfall available for welfare and instead dole it out for other budget purposes. That would waste a historic opportunity to reform, not just reduce, the welfare program. Yet instead of grappling with this momentous social change, the parties in Albany have been frittering away their energies on other issues as the July 1 deadline for instituting the new law approaches. 
 Federal law requires states to put 25 percent of their welfare recipients into work activities immediately, rising to 50 percent by 2002. Governor Pataki proposes to turn the task over to the counties, asking them to find job slots or create "workfare," whereby recipients clean parks or do other unskilled labor in exchange for assistance. The Governor's plan also involves eliminating cash assistance for parents after five years and immediately for able-bodied childless adults, instead giving both groups vouchers for food, clothing and shelter.
The Governor's programs will be hugely expensive to create and administer. Welfare recipients will require intensive training, counseling and monitoring to fulfill their work assignments. Voucher programs require costly individual assessments of clothing and other needs. Parents of young children will need day care, a costly component of welfare-to-work programs.
Social service commissioners from New York City and surrounding counties -- all from Republican administrations -- have told the Governor his budget would provide too little money for day care, vouchers and emergency benefits and thereby threatened to create homelessness. The commissioners are no doubt correct, and the consequences could be severe. If the Governor skimps on payments to the counties, they will have too little money to create workfare slots for everyone who qualifies. Their only realistic escape will be to change eligibility standards so that fewer families qualify for help. An increase in homeless families will be the most visible reflection of the vicious financial bind.
Fortunately, there is a way out. State coffers are flush with extra tax money from a robust economy. Even better, a quirk in the Federal welfare law will pump an extra $730 million into New York State this year. Mr. Pataki wants to take $222 million of this windfall for general state programs -- which those programs do not need given the state's healthy revenue forecasts. He also unwisely proposes to provide $132 million of budget relief to counties, a transfer of funds that is unrelated to the size of their welfare burdens.
Instead he should turn the whole of that $730 million over to counties to create their voucher, workfare, day-care and other poverty programs. Only if the counties achieve their workfare targets for less should the Governor use the Federal largess for other priorities.

HEADLINE: CLINTON LAUNCHES EFFORT TO RENEW CHINA TRADE TIES

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
President Clinton began a campaign today to win Congressional renewal of normal trading status for China, in an annual exercise that threatens to be more contentious than ever this year.
In an announcement before a group of business executives, Mr. Clinton said that trade ties are "the best way to bring China into the family of nations and to secure our interests and our ideals." 
 Mr. Clinton is facing growing anti-China sentiment on both the right and the left in Congress, with an unlikely combination of opponents lining up against renewing China's trade privileges. The coalition ranges from labor, which is concerned about economics and human rights issues, to the Christian right, which is opposing China on human rights grounds as well.
Once Mr. Clinton formally sends his decision to grant China what is known as "most-favored-nation status," the House and Senate have 90 days in which they can try to overturn his recommendation.
Originally the White House had hoped that this year relations with China could be put on a firmer footing. Mr. Clinton is expected to hold a summit meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China later this year, and the Administration is negotiating with China over entry into the World Trade Organization.
Admitting that it would not have the votes, the White House quietly shelved any hope that it might be able to win permanent, instead of annual, approval of normal trade ties for China this year.
The only debate inside the Administration, officials said, was over how much the President should personally put himself on the line to support China in the face of the campaign finance controversy.
The President won an important ally of sorts today in Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House. Although Mr. Gingrich assailed Mr. Clinton as being "virtually absent without leadership on issues of religious tolerance, human rights, and democratic freedoms," he said he would support normal trade relations with China.
Other irritants in this year's debate are China's transfer of missiles to Iran and its huge trade surplus with the United States. Congress is also swayed this year by increasing concerns over Hong Kong. The assumption in Washington is that the handover of the British colony to China will go smoothly. If it doesn't, as one senior Administration official conceded this afternoon, "this whole effort sinks in the Pacific."
The White House today sought to address concerns about Hong Kong's transition by noting that Hong Kong's governor, Chris Patton, and Hong Kong's most prominent advocates of democracy , like Martin Lee, the leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, support extension of China's trade status.
"Even those people in Hong Kong that have been most passionately identified with the cause of freedom and human rights and have been most in conflict with the Chinese have argued that we have to maintain an open trading relationship with them so we can continue to work with them," Mr. Clinton said.
Other Administration officials argued that Hong Kong is the gateway of trade between the United States and China and that to cut off China's trade status at this moment would deal a blow to Hong Kong precisely at this crucial moment of transition.
While last year's announcement about China's trade status was made in a major speech on Asia policy, this year the President made the announcement at the business leaders' event, which was held in the Old Executive Office Building.
Mr. Clinton said that stopping normal trade relations would "cut off our contact with the Chinese people and undermine our influence with the Chinese Government."
Mr. Clinton originally came into office accusing President Bush of "coddling dictators," but in the spring of 1994, under pressure from American business groups, Mr. Clinton backed down from his early attempt to link China's most-favored-nation status to significant progress in human rights. Since then Mr. Clinton has called for renewal of China's trade status annually.
Mr. Clinton has argued that economic engagement is the best way to get China to improve its treatment of dissidents. But his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, had to concede at a White House briefing today that "we cannot say that human rights conditions in China are better today than they were a year ago."
But Mr. Berger argued that commercial cooperation and openness to the world would eventually change the Beijing Government's behavior.
Yet the Administration's admissions that little has changed in human rights encouraged those who argue that Mr. Clinton's attempt to use commerce in the service of human rights has failed.
"They have to change the subject from human rights because they have nothing to point to," said Gary L. Bauer, the president of the Family Research Council, which is pressing its traditional Republican allies to abandon the party's longstanding support for renewing China's ordinary trading rights.
"It's a corrosive debate," Mr. Berger said in an interview in his office this afternoon. "Everyone in Congress knows that cutting off trade relations is far too blunt an instrument. Instead of debating how to influence China, how to shape the direction, we wind up debating a piece of the relationship. It doesn't work."
Mr. Clinton said today that "the United States has a huge stake in the continued emergence of China in a way that is open economically and stable politically. Of course we hope that it will come to respect human rights more and the rule of law more."
But Human Rights Watch/Asia immediately issued a statement asking how the Administration planned to exert influence on China on human rights, noting that the Administration's efforts to condemn China's human-rights practices in Geneva last month had failed. "What other measures is the Administration willing to use?" asked Mike Jendrzejcyk, the group's Washington director. "Or has it abandoned human rights altogether?"
Despite the growing anti-China sentiment in Congress, Administration officials and opponents of most-favored-nation trade status say that Mr. Clinton would ultimately have the votes to prevail on the issue.
The United States has economic incentives to continue the trade relationship. United States officials say that 170,000 American jobs are dependent on exports to China and that ending normal trade status would cost consumers $600 million annually in higher prices on certain consumer goods.
In fact, at this point the United States and China are so economically intertwined that even many members of the growing anti-China lobby in Congress concede that denying trade privileges to China would be tantamount to breaking off political relations with the world's most populous nation.
As the debate plays out over the next months, the only question, officials say, is whether the President will be forced into a bruising veto fight to preserve most-favored-nation status. That would occur if the House and Senate pass a joint resolution turning down normal trade status. Both chambers would then have to muster two-thirds votes to override the President's veto.
The last time there was such a confrontation over China was in 1992, a Presidential camapign year, when Congress tried to stop most-favored nation status but failed to override Mr. Bush's veto.

HEADLINE: Not All Landlords Were Hurt by Rent Control

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The error in your logic ("A Way to Compromise on Rents," editorial, May 13) is the assertion that New York City landlords have been "deprived . . . of a fair return" on their investment by the 50-year-old program of rent regulation. 
 The largest element of an apartment owner's costs is the price paid, including debt service and the assumed return on investment. Only those who owned apartment buildings when rent regulation was first imposed can claim to have been injured by it. Those who bought with knowledge of it should have paid a price informed by the reality of rent regulation.
Yet building owners have continued to pay prices justified only by speculation upon the end of a regulatory program of which they have had 50 years' notice.
It is not the duty of government to bail them out of their folly by ending a program that has seemed wise to generations of legislators and on which so many depend. To do so would grant a windfall to speculators and punish those who have relied upon continuity and stability.
If expectations of deregulation were lowered and apartment buildings sold for lower prices, owners could enjoy a fair return on their investment within the context of the long-established legal and economic reality of rent regulation.
 
E. BLUM
New York, May 13, 1997

HEADLINE: Guide to Going Shopping Without the Dropping

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
When it comes to shopping, the two women are as different as Barneys and Bolton's. One sees it as the ultimate bonding experience, while the other shops only when she really needs something. One has been known to call a $900 shearling coat a bargain, while the other's idea of a good buy is a $12 pair of flats.
But Susan B. Dollinger and Jane R. Lockshin, good friends, fellow businesswomen and now co-authors of "The New York Edge: 1997 Savvy Shoppers' Guide," both get their shopping tips from the same source. 
 "When you want to buy something that you aren't used to buying, you call your friends," Ms. Lockshin said.
"I'm giving a dinner party. Who will cater it? I'm moving into a new apartment, and I want custom shelves made. Where do I go? It's the kind of thing we do all the time. We just institutionalized it."
Their book, a kind of Zagat guide to the potentially overwhelming retail landscape of New York City, was the editorial equivalent of a barn-raising. The authors published it themselves after soliciting the insights, passions, gripes and admonitions of about 300 women (and a few men) -- mostly friends, colleagues and friends of friends.
Now in its second printing, the guide covers nearly 2,000 stores and service providers, offering advice on where to find everything from orchids to rare coins and everyone from pearl restringers to dog walkers.
It also offers a window onto a group of working women who may say they weren't born to shop but who seem to bring the same intensity to the pursuit of quality and value that they do to their careers.
Ms. Dollinger, 51, is a vice president for Citicorp and a resident of South Salem, N.Y. Ms. Lockshin, 52, lives in Germantown, Md., where she owns a company that develops data bases, Custom Databanks. The two met in New York City in the early 1970's when they were working as economists. In 1994, Ms. Lockshin, who travels to New York frequently, had the idea to create a data base that would be a guide to New York stores, and she enlisted Ms. Dollinger, a serious shopper.
Brainstorming with about 25 friends, the two compiled a list of about 1,000 stores and businesses representing a broad range of categories: books, linens, art, bridal wear and light fixtures, to name a few. In the meantime, Ms. Dollinger, with the help of paid researchers recruited from local colleges, pored over back copies of fashion magazines and newspapers to come up with 1,000 more retailers.
The partners printed up surveys with the establishments' names next to spaces for comments and ratings on quality, style, service and value. A rating of 1 meant "so-so," while a 5 indicated "excellent." And they asked the volunteers, mostly members of the Financial Women's Association of New York, to evaluate stores visited in the last year.
"I am a size 6 because I work at it, and just as I want every calorie to be worth it, I want my shopping to be worth it," said one respondent, Clarin Schwartz, a vice president at ASA, a benefits consulting firm and AT&T subsidiary in Somerset, N.J. "We're all financial women and we don't have a whole lot of time to shop. But when we do shop, we want to get good value."
For the most part, the stores in the book have at least one positive rating because the authors saw no point in publicizing retailers that were disliked across the board. Some stores were not critiqued at all, but if the merchandise was considered special or unusual, the authors included them, giving straight descriptions.
Occasionally, the book skewers a store with a pointed comment. For instance, VSF, an upscale florist in the West Village, was praised for its "English country garden look" but slapped for being "very snooty." An owner, Jack Follmer, who was unaware of the guide, expressed shock at the criticism. "We are definitely high-end and pretty up on our flowers, but I never thought we were snooty," he said.
The result of all the surveying was a computer disk, with jazzy cross-referencing capabilities. But what the authors really wanted, they decided, was a book. After fruitless inquiries at publishing houses, the women decided to be their own publishers.
Ms. Dollinger bought "The Self-Publishing Manual: How to Write, Print and Sell Your Own Book" (Para Publishing, 1995), and she walked up to managers at Barnes & Noble stores with a simple question: Who sells you your books? One name kept coming up -- Koen Book Distributors, and she picked up the phone.
"It sounded like a good idea," said Sheila Kowalsky, a buyer for Koen, a regional wholesaler in Moorestown, N.J. "I told her that as long as it was viable -- had a spine, a bar code and was produced well -- I'd be willing to consider it."
As in most do-it-yourself ventures, the authors relied on relatives. Ms. Dollinger's 86-year-old mother, Mary Dollinger, surveyed 100 stores, including all the estate jewelers. ("It's kept me out of mischief," she said.) Her husband, Allan Ermann, a high school English teacher, edited copy, while her daughter, Lynn, a freelance writer, helped with publicity. Ms. Lockshin's husband, Michael, a rheumatologist, scanned the galleys for imperfections.
With 38,000 stores in New York City, the book (soft cover, $14.95) is by no means comprehensive. But while it is skewed to the more expensive end of the retail spectrum, the guide does offer useful signposts in a city where there are districts for buttons, cameras and plants.
"There have to be holes," Ms. Lockshin said. "The book is biased by the age and income of the people who did the surveys. It's more Bottega Veneta than Kmart, but that doesn't exclude discounters, because no one likes to pay retail."
Some contributors took pleasure in sharing their sources for bargains, both high and low. Ann B. Diamond, author of "Fear of Finance: The Women's Money Workbook for Achieving Financial Self-Confidence" (Harper Business, 1994), singled out Century 21 for its deals on women's and children's clothes but also put in a word for J. S. Suarez, a Park Avenue handbag shop whose goods, though discounted, start at $150.
Among the surveyors were a few nonshoppers, busy professionals like Mary C. Farrell, a managing director at PaineWebber. "I work full-time and have two teen-agers, and I want to make shopping as effortless as possible," Ms. Farrell said. "I don't want to personally go around to five stores to find what I want. With the book, I feel like someone else has invested that time for me."
So far, about 3,500 copies of the book have sold at Barnes & Noble and Borders Books & Music, as well as at smaller book stores. "It is selling very steadily," said Eugenia Pakalik, the Northeast regional buyer for Barnes & Noble. "It keeps chugging along."
"It's a competitive field," Ms. Pakalik said of the other retail shopping guides on New York City. "But their book has an actual rating system. It's not just telling you where you can buy a leather saddle in New York. It's telling you that there are a couple of places, and this is the one with the best customer service, which is a unique element."
Zagat, the publisher of the popular restaurant surveys, does have a shopping guide called "New York City Marketplace Survey," but it focuses exclusively on food and entertaining.
The two authors are now at work on a second edition, which they plan to publish in the fall.
They intend to expand the survey to include 400 to 500 additional stores and services, while tripling the number of respondents. And it is a concept they believe will travel to other cities.
"We're looking at Washington and L.A.," Ms. Lockshin said.
But, in perhaps the first hint of corporate infighting, Ms. Dollinger said dismissively, "We're doing Europe."

HEADLINE: How Much Is Nature Worth? For You, $33 Trillion

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
HOW much is nature worth?
Some say the question is unanswerable, that it is impossible to calculate a dollar value for the natural world. Others say the question should not even be asked; that nature, like human life, is priceless and should not be devalued as if it were a mere commodity. 
 But economists and ecologists are searching for the answer anyway. Nature performs valuable, practical, measurable functions, they say; without them the human economy could not exist, and in many cases people could not duplicate them as cheaply -- or at all. And they say it is time that the value of these functions is considered when economic decisions are made.
One notable example of nature's economic value that they cite is the purification of New York City's water supply by microorganisms as the water percolates through the soil of the Catskills. The city plans to spend $660 million to preserve that watershed in good health; the alternative, a water treatment plant, would have cost $4 billion to build.
Nature performs a long list of other economic services as well. Flood control, soil formation, pollination, food and timber production, provision of the raw material for new medicines, recreational opportunities and the maintenance of a favorable climate are among them.
But like a well that is taken for granted until it runs dry, these ecosystem services, as ecologists call them, have long been overlooked until they either no longer work or are gone -- as, for instance, when the widespread destruction of Midwestern wetlands meant they could no longer perform their natural function of sponging up water from disastrous floods like those of recent years.
And to the extent ecosystem services are noticed at all, people have tended to regard them as free.
Now, as human activity gradually uses up or destroys this natural capital and eats away at the natural systems that provide many of the services, many experts are insisting that the worth of ecosystem services must be calculated and heeded.
The results of the latest and in some ways the most ambitious effort to place a dollar value on natural capital and services were announced last week.
Thirteen ecologists, economists and geographers, in a report in the journal Nature, estimated the present global value of 17 ecosystem services at $16 trillion to $54 trillion a year, with a likely figure of at least $33 trillion. Most of this, they said, lies outside formal markets and is therefore not reflected in market prices, the customary gauge of economic value. Their estimate, they said, compares with $18 trillion for the gross national product of the world, which is all the goods and services produced by people each year.
The researchers, who based their conclusion on other published studies and their own calculations, freely point out that their estimate is a rough approximation, a first step that is mainly intended to determine whether ecosystem services amount to "big potatoes or small potatoes," in the words of Dr. Robert Costanza, an ecological economist at the University of Maryland who headed the study. "We come away from this thinking this is a minimum estimate," Dr. Costanza said.
Virtually everyone agrees that without the natural world, the human economy and indeed human life could not exist. In this sense, the value of nature is infinite, immeasurable. To some conservationists, this is all that needs to be said. "Common sense and what little we have left of the wisdom of our ancestors tells us that if we ruin the earth, we will suffer grievously," said Dr. David Ehrenfeld, a conservation biologist at Rutgers University. He said he accepted the results of the Costanza study, which he regards as conservative, but added: "I am afraid that I don't see much hope for a civilization so stupid that it demands a quantitative estimate of the value of its own umbilical cord."
Dr. Ehrenfeld and some other conservationists believe that moral arguments for saving nature are more persuasive than economic ones. But in the view of Dr. Costanza and others, moral and economic arguments should be pursued in parallel.
People make economic choices involving nature all the time, according to this view, but they do so without taking all the costs into account. For example, the dollar value of a wetland's flood-protection and water cleansing abilities has not traditionally been considered when it is lost to a shopping center. The result is a creeping depletion of natural wealth.
If such costs were reflected in day-to-day transactions, these theorists say, society would pay more attention to what is lost when land is "developed."
"We can't wait until we've disrupted the planet's life-support system beyond repair," said Dr. Gretchen C. Daily, a conservation biologist at Stanford University. She is the editor of a recent collection of papers on the subject, "Nature's Services; Societal Dependence on Natural Ecosystems," published as a book by Island Press. Once gone, she noted, many of these ecological assets would be difficult, if not impossible, to replace; it can take thousands of years to recharge depleted aquifers or replenish topsoil.
Until now, fledgling efforts at what is called "green accounting" have been pursued largely at the national level. In a widely applauded attempt of this kind, Dr. Robert Repetto, senior economist at the World Resources Institute, a Washington-based research organization, has analyzed the economies of Indonesia and Costa Rica. In Indonesia, he and colleagues calculated that losses from soil erosion reduced the net value of crops by about 40 percent and that the loss of value from deforestation was four times as high as the value of the timber extracted. They also concluded that depletion of Costa Rica's soils, forests and fisheries resulted in a 25 percent to 30 percent reduction in potential economic growth.
A nascent effort to introduce a measure of natural-resource accounting into the United States' official calculation of economic worth was made in 1993, but it is on hold pending a Congressionally ordered study of the soundness of the approach by the National Academy of Sciences. A report is due this year.
The new Costanza study is not really an exercise in green accounting, and some experts question its practical usefulness while others express skepticism about its basic finding.
"There's no way of knowing how good this number is," Dr. Repetto said of the study's estimate of $33 trillion for the global value of ecosystem services. "They've made some heroic assumptions. I suppose it's useful for rhetorical purposes." But the number, he said, is less important than the fundamental point made by the study "that ecosystem services are important; I don't think reasonable people would deny that."
Other experts see more utility in the analysis. The study has succeeded in providing "a conservative estimate of what the environment does for us," said Dr. Stuart Pimm, an ecologist at the University of Tennessee who wrote a commentary on the Costanza study in Nature. "So often," he said, "people concerned with protecting the environment go up against these very highly detailed economic analyses and feel they don't have anything in kind with which to respond." In the tables of specific ecosystem services that accompany the study, he said, "what Costanza et al. has done is provide a checklist" that national and local policy makers can use in attempting to make a rough gauge of the economic worth of their natural assets.
One table, for instance, lists specific ecosystem services, and their supposed value, for 11 biomes, or types of natural areas. These include the open ocean, estuaries, seagrass and algae beds, coral reefs, continental shelves, tropical forests, temperate forests, grasslands and rangelands, tidal marshes and mangroves, wetlands and flood plains and lakes and rivers.
The next step, Dr. Costanza says, is to delineate more clearly the explicit linkages between particular local ecosystems and local economies. For example, how much of the value of the Louisiana shrimp catch is attributable to the wetlands in which the shrimp reproduce and grow? But since wetlands perform other services as well, the wetlands' value as a shrimp nursery would be only a minimum indication of their overall value.
The same applies, for example, to the Catskill watershed, which serves other economic functions besides providing and cleaning New York City's water -- attracting tourists, for instance. "Nobody thinks the Catskills are worth only $4 billion," Dr. Daily said, referring to the cost of replacing the Catskills' water-cleansing function.
Assuming the value of ecosystem services could eventually be established, how might economic policies be changed? For openers, Dr. Daily and others say, government subsidies that distort the value of natural resources -- in fisheries and logging, for example -- should be abolished. Also, tax incentives might be given to landowners to protect the long-term assets represented by natural capital rather than using them for short-term gain.
Some experts advocate applying traditional economic arrangements to ecosystem services. For instance, Dr. Graciela Chichilnisky and Dr. Geoffrey Heal, economists at Columbia University, have proposed selling investment shares in a given ecosystem. Using the Catskill watershed as an illustration, they say that the capital thus raised would pay for preserving the watershed. Returns to investors would come either from a share of the costs saved by not having to build a treatment plant or, if the investment were private, by actually selling ecosystem services. In the case of a watershed, clean water would be sold.
But, says Dr. Daily, "the first thing is getting the prices right."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk

HEADLINE: How Much Is Nature Worth? For You, $33 Trillion

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
HOW much is nature worth?
Some say the question is unanswerable, that it is impossible to calculate a dollar value for the natural world. Others say the question should not even be asked; that nature, like human life, is priceless and should not be devalued as if it were a mere commodity. 
 But economists and ecologists are searching for the answer anyway. Nature performs valuable, practical, measurable functions, they say; without them the human economy could not exist, and in many cases people could not duplicate them as cheaply -- or at all. And they say it is time that the value of these functions is considered when economic decisions are made.
One notable example of nature's economic value that they cite is the purification of New York City's water supply by microorganisms as the water percolates through the soil of the Catskills. The city plans to spend $660 million to preserve that watershed in good health; the alternative, a water treatment plant, would have cost $4 billion to build.
Nature performs a long list of other economic services as well. Flood control, soil formation, pollination, food and timber production, provision of the raw material for new medicines, recreational opportunities and the maintenance of a favorable climate are among them.
But like a well that is taken for granted until it runs dry, these ecosystem services, as ecologists call them, have long been overlooked until they either no longer work or are gone -- as, for instance, when the widespread destruction of Midwestern wetlands meant they could no longer perform their natural function of sponging up water from disastrous floods like those of recent years.
And to the extent ecosystem services are noticed at all, people have tended to regard them as free.
Now, as human activity gradually uses up or destroys this natural capital and eats away at the natural systems that provide many of the services, many experts are insisting that the worth of ecosystem services must be calculated and heeded.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Nonprofits Get Interstate Trade Protection

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
In a case watched closely by nonprofit organizations around the country, the Supreme Court ruled today that states offering favorable tax treatment to charities cannot draw distinctions based on whether a charity serves primarily in-state or out-of-state clients.
The Court declared unconstitutional a 40-year-old Maine property tax law that made tax-exempt status generally available to "benevolent and charitable institutions" but withheld it from those "operated principally for the benefit of persons who are not residents of Maine." 
 By a vote of 5 to 4, the Court said the law amounted to economic protectionism that placed an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce. The law was challenged by a summer camp operated by the Christian Science church that serves mostly children from outside the state and, as a result, had to pay more than $20,000 a year in local property taxes from which it would have been exempt had most of its campers been from Maine.
Writing for the majority, Justice John Paul Stevens said that a state law making a similar distinction among profit-making businesses would unquestionably violate the Constitution's commerce clause. "We see no reason why the nonprofit character of an enterprise should exclude it" from a similar analysis, Justice Stevens said.
He added that "any categorical distinction" between profit-making and nonprofit organizations was "wholly illusory" given that "entities in both categories are major participants in interstate markets." He noted that the nonprofit sector accounts for approximately 7 percent of the gross national product and, as of 1990, employed 9.3 million people.
Maine's law was evidently the only one of its kind in the country, and the state did not defend it in the Supreme Court. After a state trial court judge declared the law unconstitutional in 1994, the state did not appeal, and the case was carried on by the town of Harrison, about 40 miles northwest of Portland, where the camp that challenged the law, Newfound/Owatonna, is located. The Maine Supreme Judicial Court overturned the earlier decision and upheld the law in a 1995 ruling.
But although, as Justice Stevens observed drily, "the facts of this particular case, viewed in isolation, do not appear to pose any threat to the health of the national economy," the case galvanized an impressive array of nonprofit organizations to make the Justices aware of their concerns.
Groups representing universities, churches, the United Way, the Y.M.C.A. and others warned of the consequences if the Court permitted states to withhold tax exemptions from nonprofits that serve a nationwide audience. The Maine court's decision "poses a substantial threat to the financial welfare of nonprofit institutions generally," a brief from the American Council on Education and other groups told the Court.
Their concern reflected the novelty, and therefore the inherent unpredictability, of the issue. Despite a formidable list of decisions examining, and for the most part disallowing, economic protectionism by the states, the Court had not previously applied these cases in the nonprofit context.
Given the closeness of the vote, the nonprofit groups' concerns proved well founded. The case, argued last October just after the current term began, was the oldest undecided case on the Court's calendar, making it apparent that the Court was engaged in a major battle over the outcome.
The majority opinion, Camps Newfound/Owatonna v. Harrison, No. 94-1988, was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter and Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote the principal dissenting opinion, which was signed by the three other dissenters: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Clarence Thomas and Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
Justice Scalia said Maine was not trying to regulate interstate commerce. He said the challenged law "has nothing to do with economic protectionism" but was "designed merely to compensate or subsidize those organizations" that contribute "benefits the state might otherwise provide." As such, the law "survives even our most demanding commerce-clause scrutiny," Justice Scalia said.
Justice Scalia's opinion suggested, without quite saying so directly, that Court precedents protecting interstate commerce should not apply to nonprofit groups.
A separate dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas, which Justice Scalia and Chief Justice Rehnquist joined but that Justice Ginsburg did not, went much further, calling into question the Court's approach to the commerce clause going back to the 19th century.
The clause itself, authorizing Congress to "regulate commerce with foreign nations and among the several states," does not place any explicit limitations on state activity. The Court has interpreted the Constitution as containing an implicit "dormant" or "negative" commerce clause, as the precedents have labeled it, under which states are greatly limited in the way they can act, without Congress's approval, to regulate the national economy.
This entire enterprise has been illegitimate, Justice Thomas said. "The negative commerce clause has no basis in the text of the Constitution, makes little sense and has proved virtually unworkable in application," he said, adding that "we have used the clause to make policy-laden judgments that we are ill-equipped and arguably unauthorized to make."
Justice Thomas said another provision of the Constitution, which prohibits states from taxing imports or exports, should be invoked to prohibit "certain of the more egregious state taxes on interstate commerce." The Court interpreted that provision, in a decision in 1869, as applying only to foreign trade. Justice Thomas, joined in this portion of his opinion only by Justice Scalia, said the 1869 decision should be overruled.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
 
Lie Detectors
Accepting an appeal from the Federal Government, the Court agreed to decide the constitutionality of blanket prohibitions on defendants' use of polygraph evidence in criminal trials.
The case comes from the military court system, where polygraph evidence is inadmissible, by either side, under the rules of evidence. But the constitutional principle would apply to the numerous state and Federal courts that refuse to admit any such evidence as well.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces, a civilian court that is the top appeals court for military cases, ruled in a 3-to-2 decision last September that to bar a defendant from presenting "relevant, material and favorable evidence" of a polygraph examination violates the Sixth Amendment right to a fair trial. The decision did not mean that all such evidence is to be admitted, but that defendants have a right to persuade a judge of its admissibility.
In its appeal, United States v. Scheffer, No. 96-1133, the Government is arguing that the ban is a reasonable means of avoiding burdensome case-by-case litigation and that polygraph evidence should not be allowed to take the place of jury determinations of witnesses' credibility.
 
Alimony Deduction
The Court agreed to hear a challenge to a New York law under which out-of-state taxpayers who must pay income tax on their New York income may not deduct alimony payments from their taxable income. Resident taxpayers may make that deduction.
In a ruling last December, the New York State Court of Appeals upheld the law, which was challenged by a partner in a Manhattan law firm who lives in Connecticut. He reported income of $788,210, 48 percent of which derived from his business in New York, and alimony payments of $108,000. After New York tax officials rebuffed his effort to claim 48 percent of the alimony as a deduction, he challenged the law as a violation of the constitutional provision that guarantees all citizens the "privileges and immunities" of citizens in other states. The case is Lunding v. New York Tax Appeals Tribunal, No. 96-1462.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 20 about a Supreme Court ruling on tax treatment of charities misstated the sponsorship of a camp in Maine. The camp, Newfound and Owatonna, is owned by a nonprofit organization and operated for the benefit of Christian Science children. It is not operated by the Christian Science Church.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 202 words

HEADLINE: Time to Get Big Sugar Off the Public Dole

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alfonso Fanjul and J. Pepe Fanjul, owners of a Florida sugar company, claim that "there is no subsidy" for American sugar growers (letter, May 14). This may come as a surprise to American consumers, who are forced by our Government to pay the Fanjuls almost twice the world price for their sugar. 
 The program provides sugar processors with special loans, and limits fair competition with strict import quotas. The General Accounting Office says that as a result, the sugar program costs consumers $1.4 billion a year in higher food prices. Contrary to the Fanjuls' letter, the Department of Agriculture has endorsed the G.A.O. study, saying that it is "a reasonable report with no major data problems."
The Fanjuls' massive subsidies encourage and intensify production in South Florida, further degrading the Everglades and increasing the cost of restoration by $65 million to $120 million, according to the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Congress has ended welfare as we know it for poor Americans. It's time to do the same for the Fanjuls and for other corporations on the public dole.
 
DAN MILLER
Member of Congress, 13th Dist., Fla.
Washington, May 15, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Judging Beef By Its Grade, Cut and Eating Habits

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
STEAK on the grill turns a meal into a feast, the way Memorial Day turns a May weekend into summer.
The growing legion of steak lovers who want that steakhouse experience at home have more choices than ever when it comes to finding a good steak to put on the grill. First there is the matter of choosing the cut. Then, deciding on the grade. And increasingly, another option has become the brand name. Some brands of beef are "natural," that is, raised without hormones or antibiotics. 
 For steak, the best cuts are what the beef industry calls the middle cuts: the ribs, the loins and the flank, from the center of the steer. The less-tender end cuts like the chuck and the round come from around the animal's legs, where the muscles are heavier.
Shoppers who buy steak apparently know which are the best cuts. More than two-thirds select sirloin, shell, rib, T-bone, porterhouse, flank and tenderloin steaks, according to studies conducted by NPD, a market research company in Park Ridge, Ill. These cuts generally cost two to three times as much as the end cuts, about $10 or more a pound.
All the middle cuts are fine for grilling. Which one to buy is a matter of taste, serving size and budget. The loin is most often cut into strip or shell steaks. Sometimes called New York strips, these are the most popular in steakhouses and in stores. Porterhouse steaks are also from the loin and yield two or more servings. A T-bone steak is a smaller version of the porterhouse.
The tenderloin, or fillet, is a soft piece of boneless loin with relatively little fat that is usually sliced into individual filets mignons for grilling. A rib steak, which the French call entrecote, has the richest flavor, and also the most fat. The flank steak, a large flat slab of boneless meat, is economical, at about half the price of the other steaks. But it must be sliced thin on the bias, or it will be tough.
The sirloin can also be cut into large slabs that provide several servings. In his new book, "Steak Lover's Cookbook" (Workman, $13.95), William Rice explains that a big sirloin steak with a small, circular bone or pin bone will be more tender than a sirloin steak with a large, flat bone.
After deciding on the cut, the next option is the grade. The United States Agriculture Department grades beef based largely on the amount of fat marbling, the fat running through the meat, which enhances tenderness. It is a critical feature for a piece of meat that is seared over high heat rather than cooked slowly to break down the tissues. Though the department has eight categories for grading, shoppers can choose from only the top three: prime, choice and select.
More than half opt for choice, the most widely sold grade. About a third prefer select, which is leaner, cheaper and not as tender.
Prime is the beef with the most marbling, which makes it more flavorful and tender. It is also the costliest. Only about 2 percent of all the beef produced in this country these days is graded prime. Most is sold to the top steakhouses, so there is not much available for the home cook.
"The New York market is an exception," said Susan Parenty, a director of communications for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, a trade group. "The New York area probably consumes three times as much prime as anywhere else in the country and you can probably find it more easily."
New York still has about 10 butcher shops that sell prime beef. Elsewhere, mail-order companies are another good source.
Sales of brand-name beef, which first came on the market in 1979, have steadily increased, especially in the last few years, as producers take their cue from the chicken industry, their main competition. Last year, nearly half the supermarkets in the country carried some kind of brand-name beef, but it still accounts for less than 5 percent of the beef produced in this country. Almost all chicken is now sold by brand.
About half the brand-name beef is Certified Angus Beef, which is from the Angus breed of cattle and raised according to the standards set by the Certified Black Angus Beef Program in Wooster, Ohio. Certified Angus Beef is graded by the Agriculture Department to be at the high end of the choice range, closer to being prime than select, said a spokeswoman, Crystal Meyer.
Beef that is free of growth hormones and antibiotics is called "natural" and is sold in about 16 percent of supermarkets.
Coleman's, a brand of natural beef raised by a producer in Denver, is now being sold at Food Emporium, A&P, Waldbaum's, King Kullen, Shop Rite, Grand Union and Fresh Fields markets in the New York area. Coleman's, which sells prime, choice and select beef, has experienced double-digit increases in sales since 1993.
Since beef consumption hit its low of 61.6 pounds a person in 1993, it has been slowly increasing, mainly because of increased steakhouse traffic. Last year, it was 64.7 pounds, or 10 pounds a person less than it was a decade ago.
Niman Schell, a company based in Bolinas, Calif., near San Francisco that has been producing natural beef since 1979, recently began selling some of its beef at retail, outside the San Francisco area. It can be ordered from the Williams-Sonoma catalogue for $15 a pound. In Manhattan, it is sold at the Vinegar Factory for around $14 a pound, depending on the cut.
Niman Schell beef is dry-aged for three to six months before being shipped, to enhance its flavor, making it richer and earthier. Some steak-lovers like the taste. In March, Food Emporium supermarkets in Manhattan started selling choice beef that has been dry-aged for three weeks, which costs about $2 a pound more than the chain's regular choice steaks.
Steaks that are about one and a half inches thick produce the best results on the grill or under a broiler. Thinner steaks are better seared on top of the stove in a ridged cast-iron grill pan. A steak that is two inches thick or more may become too charred on the outside before it is cooked to the desired degree of doneness inside.
 
When Is It Done?
THE Agriculture Department recommends cooking beef to an internal temperature of at least 145 degrees, the temperature at which most potentially dangerous microorganisms are destroyed. It calls meat at this degree of doneness "medium rare," meat at 160 degrees "medium" and meat at 170 degrees "well done."
But do the Government's criteria for safety match up with most steak-lovers' tastes or with common restaurant practices?
As a test, Victor H. Chavez, the executive chef at Smith & Wollensky, the Manhattan steakhouse, broiled four prime boneless 16-ounce New York strips the way he usually does. The degree of doneness was based mostly on timing. As soon as the steaks came out of the broiler, they were tested with an instant thermometer. The rare steak registered 120 to 125 degrees; the medium rare, 130 to 135, and the medium steak, 145, still light pink in the center but going to gray-brown at the edges. The medium-well steak was 150 to 155 degrees. There was a difference of 15 degrees between the Government and the steakhouse.
Harold McGee in "On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen" (Charles Scribner's Sons, 1984) said, "We usually define the doneness of red meats not by their temperature, but by their inner color." The Government, more interested in safety than palatability, uses temperature, not color, as the guide. Mr. McGee writes that heating meat to temperatures of more than 140 degrees gradually makes it more solid, dense and dry, and the pigment increasingly drab. "That is why rare meat is pink and juicy, well-done meat brown-gray and dry," he said.
The way the steaks were cooked by Mr. Chavez is typical of most steakhouses. It is also the way people who want their beef medium rare are likely to cook it at home. "When people order a steak, they know how they like it and we have to cook it that way," Mr. Chavez said. "Lately, we have been getting more requests for meat a little more cooked, more medium rare to medium, instead of rare. Maybe people think it's safer."
The home cook also has to decide whether to play it safe and follow Government guidelines, or to indulge in rare or medium rare, knowing there may be a risk.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Grain and Soybean Prices Fall On Reports of Early Planting

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply yesterday after the Government reported that planting was proceeding at a near-record pace, bolstering farmers' chances of producing bumper fall harvests.
In other commodity markets, copper and palladium futures rose to new highs after Federal Reserve policy makers left United States interest rates unchanged. Coffee futures fell sharply for a third session on increasing supplies. 
 Farmers, as of Sunday, had put 88 percent of the corn crop into the ground, compared with the five-year average of 67 percent at this time of year, the United States Department of Agriculture reported late Monday.
Farmers also had sowed 46 percent of the soybean crops -- 20 percentage points above average, the department reported.
The earlier farmers get crops into the ground, the greater the chance of bumper crops. In 1994, for example, there was a record corn harvest after planting was 84 percent complete in mid-May.
Wheat futures retreated sharply despite declining winter wheat conditions. Western Kansas is expected to get rain, which could provide a late boost to the crop shortly before harvesting begins, analysts said.
Soybeans for July delivery fell 22 cents, to $8.44 a bushel; July corn fell 8.25 cents, to $2.7625 a bushel, and July wheat fell 14.75 cents, to $3.80 a bushel.
Copper and palladium futures prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the Fed left interest rates unchanged, fueling speculation that demand for the metals would increase as economic growth continues.
Palladium and copper, used in electronics, construction, automobiles and computers, would benefit heavily from cheaper interest rates.
June palladium rose $3.75, to $181.75 an ounce, the highest since April 1995. July copper was up 2 cents, to $1.178 a pound, the highest since May 16, 1996.
Coffee futures continued their retreat from 20-year highs on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York as supplies of arabica beans increased.
The exchange reported late Monday that inventories at its warehouses rose to 47,192 bags from 41,682 on Friday. Warehouse supplies have grown by nearly 25,000 bags since May 6.
A meeting of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries, which accounts for 80 percent of the world's production, also weighed heavily on the market. Analysts speculated that the group would announce today that it had loosened its self-imposed export quotas, allowing producers to sell more coffee if prices rise above a certain level.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Brokerage on Move (But Not Out of City)

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Fahnestock & Company, a securities brokerage based in Manhattan, is moving from one downtown office tower to another, with more than $1.3 million in assistance from city and state agencies.
Fahnestock's 398 employees will move from 110 Wall Street to 125 Broad Street, where the company has leased 69,000 square feet for 15 years at about $25 per square foot, people involved in the transaction said. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a package of incentives yesterday intended to keep the company from leaving the city. The incentives include at least $500,000 in sales tax exemptions and $400,000 in energy discounts, an extra $250,000 in sales tax exemptions if the company hires 125 more workers, and $440,000 in cash grants from the state's Empire State Development Corporation.
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which negotiated the incentives, said Fahnestock had been "aggressively" courted by the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development, on behalf of the owners of One Harmon Meadow Boulevard, a five-story office building in Secaucus. New Jersey had offered about "four times" the New York package, Mr. Millard said.
A spokeswoman for the New Jersey agency declined to comment.
Fahnestock & Company drew notice recently for selling $55 million in bonds backed by anticipated future royalties from the recordings of David Bowie. It is a unit of Fahnestock Viner Holdings, a Canadian public corporation.
125 Broad Street, a 40-story tower that was the headquarters of American Express, then part of the Olympia & York real estate empire, was converted to a condominium in 1995 after Olympia & York turned it over to the building's lender, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. The law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell and the insurance company Johnson & Higgins, both tenants, own about 80 percent of the building. Earlier this year, the American Civil Liberties Union bought two of the remaining floors. The Fahnestock & Company lease leaves just two floors vacant, according to William D. Brodsky of Insignia/Edward S. Gordon, who represented New York Broad Holding Inc., which owns six floors in the building.

HEADLINE: New York Is Still No. 1 -- in Taxes

BYLINE: By Raymond J. Keating; Raymond J. Keating is chief economist with the Small Business Survival Committee and author of "New York by the Numbers."

DATELINE: CENTER MORICHES, N.Y.

 BODY:
Last year there were 2.8 million private-sector jobs in New York City, down from 3.2 million in 1969. This means that New York City, once the most dynamic city economy in the world, has not created a net new job in more than a quarter century.
The cause of this decline is no mystery: City taxes and regulations are onerous, and have combined with uncontrolled municipal spending and debt to cool the private sector's entrepreneurial fires. The greatest culprits have been the city's taxes on personal income, corporate income and unincorporated businesses, all adopted under Mayor John Lindsay in 1966. Unfortunately, no current city official seems to grasp how damaging these tax policies are. 
 At first glance, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appears to understand the problem. He eliminated the commercial rent tax throughout the city except for Manhattan south of 96th Street, where the top effective tax rate has been cut from 6 percent to 4.5 percent. And his new budget proposes cutting that top tax rate again, to 3.9 percent.
The Mayor has also pushed through a few minor tax reductions, including a cut in the city hotel tax, from 6 percent to 5 percent (on top of the 8.25 percent city sales tax and $2 per night flat fee), and a property tax cut for co-op and condo owners. He has proposed eliminating the city's 4 percent tax on clothing purchases under $500 and slightly raising the limit on annual income that is exempt from the unincorporated business tax.
These are steps in the right direction. Indeed, last year the city's private sector created jobs at a greater rate than the national average. But before anyone rushes to induct Mayor Giuliani into the pro-growth hall of fame, consider the flip side of the tax coin.
New York City still has the highest combined state and city personal income taxes in the nation. It imposes the highest capital gains tax rate (11.3 percent), the highest corporate income tax rate (19.4 percent), and the highest income and capital gains taxes on unincorporated entrepreneurs (15.3 percent). Not only has Mr. Giuliani done next to nothing to reduce these levies, he has helped to keep them high.
Remember that during the 1994 Governor's race, Mr. Giuliani opposed George Pataki's proposed cut in state personal income taxes, predicting dire consequences for the city. This year the Mayor has been silent about Governor Pataki's proposed four-year extension of the 17 percent tax surcharge that city businesses pay to keep the Metropolitan Transit Authority running -- in effect, a four-year tax increase of $2 billion.
Twice during his tenure Mr. Giuliani has extended the city's "temporary" surcharges on the personal income tax, refusing to allow the overall top tax rate to drop from 4.5 percent to 3.4 percent. Extending these surcharges will bring in about $2.2 billion from 1996 to 1998.
Even if Mr. Giuliani actually gets the tax cuts called for in his budget, during 1997 and 1998 he will be responsible for a two-year net tax increase on individuals and businesses of approximately $575 million. If you want to add in the Mayor's quiet collaboration on the extension of transit authority surcharge, then the net tax increase for 1997 and 1998 will likely be more than $1.5 billion.
Mr. Giuliani's supporters claim that he is making progress, that he cannot do what needs to be done and still be re-elected in an overwhelmingly Democratic city. If true, then we should expect to see a voracious tax cutter emerge if the Mayor wins a second term this November; the city's new term limits law will not allow him a third term.
In fact, it would also be smart politics to pursue such a strategy, if his ambitions extend beyond the liberal bastion of New York City.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Meeting Gives Bonds A Modest Lift

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose modestly yesterday after the Federal Reserve decided to keep interest rates unchanged.
While investors were relieved by the decision, they quickly started to mull the possibility of future moves by the central bank. 
 "The Fed chose to leave rates unchanged, but that doesn't mean that they are out of the picture for the rest of the year," Doug Burtnick, senior fixed income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said. "The market will continue to struggle with each upcoming data release, as traders attempt to divine the course of future rate moves. There is still the risk of higher rates this summer."
Because it was the short end of the market that would have been hit hard had the Federal Open Market Committee raised rates yesterday, it was the short end that experienced the sharpest rally. The price of the three-month bill rose, driving its yield down 16 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- to 5.06 percent. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
But the dollar, which fell sharply in foreign-exchange trading after the Fed's decision, limited the day's gains in bonds. Market participants favor a strong dollar because it makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 7/32, to 96 18/32. The bond's yield -- an important benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- slipped to 6.90 percent from 6.92 percent on Monday.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, noted that had the Fed tightened, a negative reaction from the bond market might have lasted 24 hours. But since the Fed left rates steady, traders and investors will now have to begin examining again each new piece of economic data including the May employment report on June 6, considered the next market mover. "We see a trading band on the yield of the long bonds as between 6.85 percent and 6.95 percent," he said.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said he was disappointed that the Fed did not raise rates. He said there were political considerations behind yesterday's decision.
"What this does to the market is to put it on edge again as investors will again have to scrutinize economic data leading to the next F.O.M.C. meeting," Mr. Pugliese said. "My own opinion is that there shouldn't have been a tightening in the first place. We are in extraordinary times. I think the technological revolution that this country is going through has increased productivity to the point where inflation is benign for the foreseeable future. Besides, the consumer has become more sophisticated, and you just can't pass prices along."
While he expects that wages will go up, Mr. Pugliese predicted they would not reach a meaningful level. "Plus again we have lower import prices, which keep competition keen," Mr. Pugliese said. "Long-term rates will be significantly lower than they are now regardless what the Fed does over the near term. The road to higher prices will not be smooth until the Fed acknowledges that it is done raising rates."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Singapore Ranked the No. 1 Economy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Singapore again ranks first among the 53 economies rated in the Global Competitiveness Report, a closely watched study of countries' economic potential that is being released today by the World Economic Forum, a business-financed research organization in Geneva.
The United States also continued to do well in the report, moving to third from fourth. That made it far and away the leader among large, developed economies in what Jeffrey Sachs, the co-chairman of the forum's advisory board and the architect of the rating system, calls "the ability to achieve sustained high rates of economic growth." 
 There are other familiar players at the top of the list, including Hong Kong (No. 2), New Zealand (No. 5), Switzerland (No. 6) and Taiwan (No. 8), but there are some surprises, too. Canada moved to fourth from eighth, reflecting progress in reducing its budget deficit -- a problem plaguing virtually all the mature social democracies. Even more dramatic, Britain jumped to 7th place from 15th by slashing top tax rates and reducing labor market regulation that inhibits employment growth.
 The study, which was reformulated last year to emphasize the conclusions of professional economists over those of business executives, has attracted a following because many business and government leaders see it as a report card on their success in making their economies leaner, meaner and more prepared for growth.
Last year's change in the rankings process, which de-emphasized opinion polling in favor of more objective criteria, ranging from tariff rates to currency stability to the number of telephones per capita, has apparently produced a better predictor of growth prospects. Indeed, there was no statistical correlation between the old style of executive poll rankings and rates of growth, while the new method did identify some actual winners and losers last year. "We beat the gut response of business leaders," Mr. Sachs said.
 The survey of executives is still conducted, but is given less weight. It has tended to favor historically successful countries like Japan, Germany and France, whose entrenched flaws are more easily discernible under the new system. From Mr. Sachs's perspective, the principal advantage to the refurbished Global Competitiveness Report is its transformation from a high-profile popularity contest to a bully pulpit for spreading the gospel according to modern development economics.
The most successful grouping in the recent report -- what it calls the "entrepot economies," including Singapore, Hong Kong, Switzerland and Luxembourg (11th), so-called because they are very small countries that thrive on providing global trade and financial services -- got that way by virtue of the countries' commitment to openness, minimal regulation and rule of law.
 The "Anglo-Saxon" economies (Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand, Britain and the United States) are doing well, too, beating back the economic arteriosclerosis that can come with the accumulation of interest group influence in rich democracies. The United States led this pack by ranking first among all economies on management skills, second on access to technology and third on both infrastructure development and the efficiency of financial markets. It would have nosed out Hong Kong for second place in the overall rankings but for mediocre scores on taxation, bureaucracy and civil justice.
 The most disappointing group, the countries of the European Union, all provide high living standards. But their high-spending, high-tax regimes generally undermine the efficiency of markets and offer little hope of rapid growth in income or employment. "Continental Europe sits there in a mess," Mr. Sachs said. "The basic problems aren't being solved." But the Netherlands (moving from 17th to 12th) and Ireland (jumping from 26th to 16th), both bucked the general trend in Europe by making their welfare states more user-friendly for business.
 The transition economies of Eastern Europe are, at best, treading water. Russia (53d) and Ukraine (52d) have been overwhelmed by corruption and incompetent government, the report says. Poland (50th), Hungary (46th) and the Czech Republic (32d) are all striving to encourage private enterprise and attract foreign investment. But in all three, social security has priority over efficient markets and government spending still represents roughly half of national output. "Their pretensions to being Sweden are premature," Mr. Sachs said.
 Protectionism and heavy-handed regulation are holding back some of these economies, along with some others that have consistently ranked low, like Venezuela (47th), India (45th) and South Africa (44th).
Human rights appear to have no direct input on competitiveness rankings. Some economies with capital-friendly authoritarian regimes -- Singapore, Indonesia (15th) and China (29th) -- did well compared with rights-minded democracies, including Portugal (30th), Belgium (31st), the Czech Republic, Iceland (38th), Italy (39th) and Poland.
But Mr. Sachs, citing countries like Britain and the United States, suggested that the conflict between competitiveness and social justice was more apparent than real. "You don't need to spend half of national income on middle-class entitlements in order to maintain the safety net," he argued.

HEADLINE: A Slowdown In the Works Whatever The Fed Does

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Whatever the Federal Reserve does over the next few months, the American economy appears to be heading, on its own, into a period of slower economic growth.
"Weaker is not bad," said Robert D. Reischauer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "We are still talking about positive economic growth." 
 Virtually no economist is predicting a recession, only a slowdown to perhaps half the booming annual growth rate of more than 4 percent that prevailed from October through March. Many analysts consider such rapid growth to be inflationary, if it lasts long enough. Eventually, with very strong growth, shortages of labor and merchandise develop, which push up wages and prices.
But the spurts of growth during the current recovery, like the one this last winter, have not lasted long. Counting the slower periods, the gross domestic product, valuing all the goods and services that the nation produces in a given year, has risen at an average annual rate of only 2.7 percent since the last recession ended, in the spring of 1991. That growth rate has not been strong enough to create the shortages that push up inflation. And the growth rate is even less, a very mild 2.1 percent a year, if the 1990-91 recession is averaged in.
The economic expansion of the 1990's, now in its seventh year, has been marked by alternating periods of strong and weak growth. A booming 1994, for example, was followed by a weak 1995, mostly because the Fed had raised interest rates sufficiently to slow the economy. The slowdown under way now -- after a winter in which the economy boomed -- appears to reflect more natural causes.
"With the economy slowing, it is quite plausible that we can have a 2.5 percent growth rate, and the Fed does not have to lift a finger," said Lee Price, chief economist at the Commerce Department. The Fed's top officials, at their policy meeting yesterday, decided not to follow a rate increase in March with another one now.
Since early April, retail sales have fallen and stockpiles of unsold goods have piled up. This inventory accumulation accounted for a big chunk of the strong economic growth in the first quarter. Working off those stockpiles now, in the face of weaker retail sales, means cutbacks in industrial production, at least temporarily. These cutbacks have already begun to show up in Government statistics as weaker growth in the second quarter.
"What is going on now is a mini-inventory correction," said Lyle Gramley, a consulting economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association and a former Fed governor. "That is normally a short phenomenon."
The big question is how long the slowdown will last. There is no way to answer that question yet.
But if the inventory correction follows a typical pattern, the economy might be growing more strongly again by fall or winter, once retailers and wholesalers decide to step up orders to restock their shelves.
However, some ingredients of last winter's strong growth are lacking now. Warmer-than-usual weather encouraged above normal shopping and construction activity, strengthening the economy temporarily, particularly in the first quarter. So did tax refunds, which flowed to Americans in unexpectedly large amounts in the weeks before April 15.
Other factors suggest that a longer period of mild growth might lie ahead. Consumer debt is at a record high, eating into household income, and borrowing to finance purchases has tapered off. New-vehicle sales, having held above 15 million at an annual rate through the winter, dropped below that level in April, and the auto industry has responded with rebates and sales incentives.
"When the economy slows, we slow even more," said Wynn Van Bussman, chief economist at the Chrysler Corporation, "and we are confirming that slowdown because it is becoming more and more difficult to sell new vehicles."
Similarly, home construction was quite strong this winter, contributing noticeably to economic growth, particularly when all the accessories -- carpeting, appliances, furniture, remodeling -- are added in. Construction is still high, but no longer rising. "Some of the early-year exuberance has worn off," said David F. Seiders, chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders.
Slower economic growth -- 2.5 percent or less annually -- is touted by most economists and policy makers as necessary to avoid the shortages that drive up the inflation rate. Corporate executives and union officials increasingly argue that the American economy is capable of greater growth without rising inflation.
Slower growth also makes an economy more susceptible to the sort of "accident" that can tip a weakened economy into recession: the Persian Gulf crisis played a role in provoking the 1990-91 recession, along with the Fed's decision to keep interest rates up. Similarly, a sharp decline in stock prices could undermine the economy now by damaging the confidence of American households, nearly half of whom own stocks, either directly or through mutual funds and retirement accounts.
Or the Federal Reserve, trying to slow the economy to avoid a rise in the inflation rate, could push up interest rates too much, in its effort to discourage borrowing and spending. "Every recession since 1957 has been caused by a spike in interest rates or an oil price shock," Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, said.
The Fed in its decision yesterday seemed to recognize the danger of pushing up rates too much.
