HEADLINE: Minister of Objection Nettles Washington;
Boeing, Threatened, Sees Trade War

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 16

 BODY:
Who is Karel van Miert, and why is he declaring war on the Boeing Company?
As the Seattle-based aerospace giant pushes to complete its $14 billion takeover of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the biggest roadblock is suddenly being posed by a feisty European official who has bluntly branded the deal "totally unacceptable." 
 The official is Karel van Miert, a 55-year-old former Belgian Socialist who is the European Commission's Minister for Competition and, de facto, the Continent's top antitrust authority. Few Americans have heard of him, but that is changing fast, especially in corporate board rooms.
On Wednesday, Mr. van Miert is expected to hand Boeing a list of "objections" to the McDonnell Douglas deal. Never mind that the takeover involves two American companies, or that his biggest objection stems from two long-term sales contracts that Boeing recently reached with two American airlines.
"If any deal has an effect on the European marketplace, then the jurisdiction is within our territory," said Willy Helin, Mr. van Miert's spokesman. "We don't give a damn about extraterritoriality."
[On Tuesday, Mr. van Miert met with British officials and reiterated his hard line against the proposed marketing alliance between British Airways and American Airlines, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation. Mr. van Miert has complained that it would eliminate competition on many routes between the United States and Britain.]
It is in the Boeing and McDonnell Douglas case that Mr. van Miert is flexing his muscles for a showdown with both the United States aerospace industry and, very likely, the United States Government.
In numerous public comments, he has warned that the creation of an aerospace goliath would endanger competition in Europe, especially for Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium based in Paris that competes with Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. If Boeing fails to address his concerns, Mr. van Miert has threatened to block the deal or impose fines of up to 10 percent of Boeing's revenues, or about $4 billion.
For American companies, the case highlights the lengthening reach of the European Union as Europe acts increasingly as a single political entity. But experts say Mr. van Miert's higher profile is a result of the inevitable clashes that come with the rise in international trade.
Whether the United States tries to block European companies from doing business with Cuba or Iran, or Europe tries to enforce an internal ban on hormone-treated beef from American cattle farmers, international disputes over conflicting national policies are piling up. And there are few precedents for guidance.
"The whole issue of extraterritoriality is a vexing area, and it is one that is going to get worse," said Michael Hodges, senior lecturer in international relations at the London School of Economics. "Having dealt with many of the issues between borders, we are now looking at issues behind the borders."
The looming fight over Boeing could easily engulf the Clinton Administration. Although the Federal Trade Commission is not expected to decide the antitrust issues until next month, the United States Government has already approved several big mergers within the nation's shrinking military and aerospace industry. And Mr. van Miert has already attracted warning growls from Boeing's home-state senators and from Vice President Al Gore.
While Mr. van Miert has been quick to object, his bark is often worse than his bite. Indeed, most disputes that he initiates are eventually settled through negotiation and compromise rather than by taking companies to court. Of roughly 500 mergers that his office has reviewed, only 7 have been blocked outright.
Just this week, his office approved with only minor changes British Telecommunications' takeover of MCI Communications, the second-largest long-distance telephone carrier in the United States after AT&T. But two years ago, he pressed the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and Scott Paper to sell off some of their European businesses as a condition for approving their merger.
He has also provoked sputtering indignation from London to Bonn. He infuriated the British Government last fall when he first threatened to block the proposed alliance between British Airways and American Airlines. He also outraged German Government officials by challenging subsidies to Volkswagen in eastern Germany as well as state aid to areas in western Germany. And he has chastised the French Government for its billion-dollar bailouts of state-owned companies like Credit Lyonnais, the troubled bank.
In the Boeing and McDonnell Douglas case, European officials have made it clear that they do not expect to veto the proposed merger outright. Rather, they suggest, the goal is to get Boeing to address their worries about particular business practices.
The European Commission must make a final decision on the merger by late July. If it vetoed the deal, and the Federal Trade Commission approved it, the fight would probably shift to the World Trade Organization in Geneva.
Mr. van Miert seems to relish conflict. A tough-minded politician who once headed the Belgian Socialist Party, he has become one of the most powerful figures within the sprawling bureaucracy of the European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union. His attacks on a wide range of anti-competitive practices and on Europe's mountain of subsidies for industry have generally won praise as tough and honest. That is no small feat, since every country in the European Union has sacred cows that it wants to protect.
With a staff of more than 100 people, Mr. van Miert oversees a staggering volume of activity. His ministry reviews all major mergers that involve European companies as well as a few that do not. It also investigates allegations of price-fixing and a wide range of attempts to stifle competition, much like the United States Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission. (The Justice Department and the F.T.C. together employ an antitrust staff of more than 1,100 people.)
In theory, Mr. van Miert can make life miserable for those who refuse to obey his rulings. But as a practical matter, he follows the opposite of the dictim made famous by Theodore Roosevelt by talking loudly and carrying a small stick.
In Germany, for example, the Governor of the eastern state of Saxony was outraged that Mr. van Miert blocked a package of subsidies for Volkswagen to build a new automobile factory. Mr. van Miert said he had already approved big subsidies for Volkswagen and was drawing the line at more. The state of Saxony went ahead anyway and Mr. van Miert prepared to take the state to court. Over the next several months, however, the two sides worked out a compromise that reduced but did not eliminate the subsidies.
In the British Airways deal with American Airlines, Mr. van Miert argued that the two airlines would control a majority of the coveted landing slots for flights between the United States and Heathrow Airport in London. The British Government has been content to let the airlines sell off many of these slots in order to lessen their dominance, but Mr. van Miert contended that they should give the slots away and said he would take the British Government to court.
The fight has been hanging in limbo for several months and remains unresolved.
The Boeing case is likely to be much tougher. Boeing now sells more than 60 percent of the world's commercial airplanes, while Airbus has captured about a 30 percent share. McDonnell Douglas, which had about 20 percent of the market 10 years ago, is now a negligible player with only about 4 percent. Most of McDonnell Douglas's business is in military aircraft, an area where Boeing is relatively weak.
Mr. van Miert's focus has been on the commercial aircraft market. In particular, he has complained repeatedly about Boeing's two recent contracts to become the exclusive supplier of planes to American Airlines and Delta Air Lines for 20 years.
He said such contracts would be a grave threat to competition in general and Airbus in particular. "These agreements are totally unacceptable because they eliminate Airbus as a rival for at least the next 20 years," he said last week in Stockholm.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas executives argue that Mr. van Miert is merely protecting Airbus. The competition in commercial aircraft had already been reduced to Boeing and Airbus, and company executives argue that Boeing's acquisition of McDonnell's military business would not change the balance. They also defend their airline contracts, asserting that the contracts were awarded through open competition and that Airbus had itself signed an exclusive long-term contract with U S Airways in 1996.
"It's obvious he wants a war," Harry C. Stonecipher, the president and chief executive of McDonnell Douglas, said in Washington last week.
In Brussels, headquarters of the European Commission, Boeing officials have lined up numerous European attorneys and argue that Mr. van Miert has wandered out of bounds. "At least from the U.S. side, this looks like an extraterritorial attempt to impose European law," said Ray Waldman, Boeing's vice president for international business.
Mr. van Miert dismissed Boeing's warnings of a possible trade war as "totally nonsensical."
But the issue is reverberating in the United States. Members of Congress from Washington State sent Mr. van Miert a letter last week complaining that he had prejudged the issue and was trying to protect Airbus -- charges that Mr. van Miert vehemently denied.
Meanwhile, Vice President Gore fired a warning shot of his own. "We haven't been bashful about our advocacy of the rights of American businesses oveseas," Mr. Gore said earlier this month. "We will be watching the outcome of their deliberations extremely carefully, and we will take whatever action is appropriate to assure justice and fairness."

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks Squeeze Schools in Cleveland

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
The once-forsaken downtown boasts a glistening array of new office towers, hotels and sports stadiums. In the Flats, the industrial area where the brown bends of the Cuyahoga River once caught fire, the riverbanks are lined with bars and restaurants. Over all, the city's economic revival has transformed Cleveland from the Mistake on the Lake to the Comeback City.
But the city's school system is broke. 
 The Cleveland Teachers' Union sees a direct link between the downtown boom and the educational bust: the very same tax abatement policies that attracted new development to the city, they say, cost the schools $21 million a year.
Even through that represents only a small fraction of the district's budget, the teachers say the schools need every cent they can get. So, in what is apparently the first such campaign in the nation, the union has gathered enough signatures to force a special vote in August on a proposal to require that businesses winning abatements, or the city, reimburse the schools for any lost taxes.
Richard DeColibus, the union's president, said it was simply a matter of making sure that Cleveland schoolchildren did not bear the brunt of the city's development policy.
Chris Warren, the director of Cleveland's Department of Economic Development, agrees that abatements were given too freely in the past. And, he said, he would welcome a statewide ban. But a ban in Cleveland only, Mr. Warren said, would put the city at a terrible competitive disadvantage with its affluent surrounding towns, which he said would be only too happy to offer tax incentives to lure dozens of businesses out of Cleveland.
The union contends that the passage of the proposal would not hurt Cleveland, because it could still abate the portion of the property taxes that does not go to the schools.
With more local governments using tax incentives as a weapon in the escalating bidding wars for new investments, property tax abatements that siphon money from the schools have become controversial.
"The whole issue came to a head in the early 1990's, when the economy was bad, a lot of states were suffering and there was increasing competition for big-ticket projects," said Scott Mackey, of the National Conference of State Legislatures. "And in the last few years, we've begun hearing a lot about how school districts are the biggest recipients of property tax, but they don't usually have much say over abatements."
Only a handful of states allow school districts to veto abatements, Mr. Mackey said.
The debate over the long-term economic effects of tax abatements -- and who controls the decision to offer them -- has taken on new urgency as school systems hard-pressed for money look longingly at a revenue stream they see trickling away.
"Tax abatements are a two-edged sword," said Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, which represents the nation's largest urban school districts. "They can help to create and attract the jobs that cities desperately need to remain vital. But at the same time, they can strip schools of the revenues they need to educate young people to fill those jobs."
There are no reliable national statistics on how much money schools lose from tax abatements. But the Corporation for Enterprise Development, in Washington, estimates that state and local governments give up $5 billion to $8 billion in tax incentives a year -- most, but not all, of them property tax abatements. And nationally, schools receive almost half of all property tax revenues.
As abatements have proliferated and awareness of the revenue loss for schools has grown, there has been increasing concern that local governments may be giving away more than they should.
"This conversation about the impact of abatements on schools is brand new, even though it's a fairly old practice," Mr. Casserly said. "It has something to do with the evolving conversations between mayors and schools about each one's role in the other's vitality. But because there has not been adequate research on how the benefits and liabilities balance out, it can be a pretty uninformed conversation, with people just shouting at each other."
Those who think tax abatements are being abused -- that school revenue is being lost without helping the city very much -- say that most abatements go to large corporations, whose workers disproportionately live outside the city limits, rather than to the smaller businesses that employ more city residents.
"One thing that is clear, frankly, is that corporations need to understand how their rhetoric about wanting a well-educated citizenry and their demands for tax abatements are really at odds with one another," Mr. Casserly said. "If you're going to have an educated citizenry, you're going to have to pay for it."
Some large corporations and tax-exempt institutions do contribute to the schools, providing cash, internships or other forms of support. In Cleveland, for example, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum agreed to give the schools a share of its admission fees in lieu of property taxes. This year, the school's cut will be about $450,000, which is still less than it would have received if the Hall of Fame were taxed.
Some educators and legislators think abatements of property taxes that support the schools should be banned altogether. In Texas, for example, the Legislature is considering State Senator David Sibley's proposal to end school property tax abatements. The Senate's Economic Development Committee found that from 1985 to 1995, the state's school districts lost almost $480 million in local property tax revenue because of abatements.
Texas law already allows schools not to participate in abatements the local government proposes. But Senator Sibley and others say the pressure on school boards can be so great as to make it impossible for them to resist development projects that will cut into their budgets.
"School districts never really reap the benefits from new jobs or an expanded tax base created by companies that receive school property tax breaks," Senator Sibley said. "Unlike cities and counties which ultimately benefit financially, most school districts lose money which they never get back. Our children's future should not be traded for new jobs now."
Tax abatements, of course, are only the latest skirmish in the continuing battle over how to pay for schools -- and indeed, in some states, including New York, financing for schools is not directly affected by property tax abatements.
In recent years, courts in several states, including Ohio in March and New Jersey just last week, have struck down financing systems that depend heavily on local property tax, finding that the disparities between rich and poor districts' spending violate state constitutional guarantees of a proper education.
The Cleveland schools have been in disarray, and in serious financial straits, for years. In 1995, a Federal judge put the 70,000-student system under state control after it ran out of money halfway through the year. The system has an annual budget of $670 million, and is $155 million in debt -- far more than most districts its size and far more than any change in abatement policy could make up. Meanwhile, student achievement levels are dismal and school buildings are deteriorating.
"It's completely dysfunctional," said Michael Charney, a middle-school teacher in Cleveland who has been a leader in the campaign against tax abatements. "Last year, in my seventh-grade social studies class I had 32 kids and only 24 desks. And we only had one set of textbooks for the classroom, so kids couldn't take them home."
Against that backdrop, Mr. DeColibus said, the teachers' union decided it had no choice but to start a petition drive for a city charter amendment that would make sure that tax revenues earmarked for the schools would not go to businesses instead.
"Business has taken a 'let someone else pay for it' attitude toward any kind of support for public institutions," Mr. DeColibus said, "and schools are hurt the most by this total lack of fiscal morality since we rely more heavily on property taxes than other government institutions. I've come to understand that 'good business climate' is a euphemism for 'businesses don't have to pay the taxes the rest of us do.' "
Ohio has taken some steps to stem the loss of school revenue from abatements. In 1994, the state passed legislation giving school boards the right to veto abatements of more than 75 percent of the taxes that would otherwise be paid, or those that last more than 10 years. In addition, if the annual payroll of added employees of an exempted project exceeds $1 million, the city must share with the schools a portion of the income tax it receives. But, Mr. DeColibus said, those provisions have had little effect.
Mr. Warren, the Cleveland development official, said the new law has not been invoked often, because the city no longer offers abatements of more than 75 percent; 60 to 65 percent is now the average, he said. But, he said, there have been a few instances of income-tax sharing.
"We use abatements very sparingly now, only as a last resort option to assist neighborhood-based businesses, with a strict 'but-for' test showing that the proposed development would not go forward but for the abatement," Mr. Warren said. "It's also important to keep in mind that since we don't abate 100 percent, or even 75 percent any more, we're collecting extra taxes from the development that does go forward, even with the abatements."
Mr. Warren sees the abatement vote largely as a political maneuver, an expression of the teachers' frustration. But he also said he thought the teachers were wrong to make the abatement issue a local one.
"We've told the teachers they should be working on a state level," Mr. Warren said. "If there's a ban on tax abatement just in Cleveland, there will be dozens of companies that will pick up and move over to Solon, where they'll be made very welcome. We'll have abandoned properties and that won't do anyone any good. Abatements are a legitimate concern, but this isn't the answer."

HEADLINE: Another Ranking Executive At Apple Decides to Resign

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20

 BODY:
In the latest senior management departure from struggling Apple Computer Inc., George Scalise, the company's executive vice president for operations, resigned today to become president of the Semiconductor Industry Association. He will leave Apple at the end of the month.
Mr. Scalise, 63, had followed Gilbert F. Amelio, Apple's chairman and chief executive, to the company from the National Semiconductor Corporation and had earlier in his career held executive positions at Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Fairchild Semiconductor and Motorola. Mr. Scalise had also previously worked for the Semiconductor Industry Association, the chip industry's trade organization, as chairman of its public policy committee. 
 The powers and responsibilities of Mr. Amelio's chosen executives have weakened since Apple's $400 million acquisition of Next Software Inc. returned Steven P. Jobs to the company he helped found, analysts noted. Ellen Hancock, who last year joined Apple as chief technology officer, also from National Semiconductor, had her oversight of both hardware and software development management turned over to former Next executives.
"The influence of Steve Jobs has been much greater than anyone anticipated," said Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies. "But any brain drain right now, especially someone so close to Gil, has to be considered a loss."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Scalise said his departure had nothing to do with Mr. Jobs's influence but instead reflected the completion of much of what he was brought on board to accomplish. "I think a lot of what I was focused on, and what was in my area of responsibility, has been done now," he said. "The idea was to focus on getting Apple on track operationally. Now, we're satisfying demand, and we're able to bring out leading edge products on schedule."
Mr. Scalise said that Apple did not plan to replace him but that Mr. Amelio would redistribute some of his responsibilities. "We now have the team in place that can execute on the game plan," he said. "With that done, a lot of the challenge that was mine is taken care of."
For its second quarter, ended March 28, Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a loss of $708 million, compared with a loss of $740 million in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Fed Inaction Sends Dollar Down but Spurs Stock Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday not to raise short-term interest rates knocked the dollar sharply lower and provided only a little relief for the bond market. But the Fed's inaction spurred the stock market, which continues to show an exuberance that may again worry Fed officials.
The dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen and the mark after the central bank announced at 2:15 P.M. that it would leave its target for the Federal funds rate at 5.50 percent. 
 The dollar's decline restrained the rally in the bond market, analysts said, as traders and investors feared a round of selling by foreign investors because a weaker dollar was eating into their profits or enlarging their losses. The price of the 30-year bond jumped 13/32, to 96 24/32, just after the Fed announcement before retreating to finish the day up 7/32 at 96 18/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.90 percent from 6.92 percent on Monday.
In the stock market, technology, bank and financial stocks benefited the most, leading the Dow Jones industrial average up 74.58 points, or 1.03 percent, to 7,303.46. The Dow was down as much as 76 points earlier in the day but jumped nearly 100 points to within 30 points of its record close after the report of the Fed's decision.
The Standard and Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 8.39 points, or 1 percent, to 841.66, less than a half a point below its record close. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite fared even better, rising 22.64 points, or 1.69 percent, to 1,363.88.
While the slumping dollar held back the bond market yesterday, it appeared to help stocks by improving the prospects of many exporters, whose products become more competitive abroad. For example, earnings of I.B.M. -- which led the Dow higher yesterday, surging 5, to 173 3/4 -- could get a lift after its first-quarter profits were held back by the surge of the dollar earlier in the year.
"Bullish spirits remain high," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in San Francisco. "The fear of missing a rise is much greater than the concern about participating in a painful tumble.
"And when you get a sense of relief, technology tends to be a lead group," he added. "That's where a lot of the excitement has been."
Analysts were split pretty evenly over whether the Fed would act yesterday, and their forecasting of the performance of the economy in the months ahead and how the Fed will react will be just as difficult. But it seems fairly clear that the inaction of the Fed has set financial markets up for six weeks of uncertainty -- and volatile trading -- until the next Fed policy meeting July 2 and 3.
Unless economic data for May confirm the slowdown implied in April's data, the chances of a Fed rate increase this summer will be even greater than they were yesterday.
"The market will be in the same spot on July 2 as it is now -- waiting for the Fed to act," said Joseph Liro, the chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities. And the odds of a rate increase, he said, "will change with each new economic report and that will make for choppier trading."
Some stock analysts warned that while the market could climb in the near term, the threat of higher interest rates is still there and means something, given the almost 10 percent plunge in the Dow after the Fed raised interest rates in March.
"There is so little evidence that inflation was looming that they felt that their credibility would have been damaged" by raising rates now, explained Byron Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. But, he added, "the Fed not tightening is not conclusive proof that things are going to remain good."
Yesterday's decline in the dollar accelerated a slump that began on May 2 and that has left the American currency 10.8 percent lower against the yen and 2.7 percent lower against the mark. The dollar's decline this month was started by comments from Japanese finance officials who said the dollar had risen too far and implied that the Government might intervene in markets to bolster the Japanese currency.
That step has not been necessary because traders have been spooked by the comments and hints that the Japanese central bank might raise interest rates soon. It was a new round of such hints that sent the dollar lower in overseas trading early Tuesday. The decision by the Fed not to raise interest rates, which could have supported the dollar by making it a more attractive investment, adds to the near-term woeful outlook for the American currency.
"For right now the dollar is going to be under some pressure," said David Puth, the head of foreign exchange and derivatives in North America at Chase Manhattan Bank. He said that while there was still reason to expect the Fed to raise interest rates in July, the fact that such a move is not certain will be a dollar "negative."
In late trading in New York, the dollar fared the worst against the mark and other European currencies, falling even lower after the Fed's decision than it did in Asian and in early European trading. Against the mark the dollar was at 1.6823, down 1.5 percent from Monday.
Against the yen, the dollar finished at 113.04, down 2.3 percent on the day, but above the intra-day low of nearly 112 hit in overnight trading.
Other advancing stocks yesterday included J.P. Morgan, up 2 3/4, to 105 1/4; American Express, increasing 2 1/8, to 70 3/4; Intel, up 6 1/4, to 161; General Electric, rising 1 1/2, to 62 1/2, and Microsoft, up 4, to 119 1/8.

HEADLINE: Nafta Environmental Lags May Delay Free Trade Expansion

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
During his recent Latin American trip, President Clinton enthusiastically promised to extend free trade throughout the hemisphere. But a delay in an environmental study on the effect of the increased trade that has already taken place is weakening support he will need to get wider trade agreements approved in Congress.
Environmentalists in the United States, Canada and Mexico fear that the delays signal a lack of commitment by the Governments of those countries to monitor the environmental effects of free trade. Such monitoring was a tenet of the side agreements that helped get the North American Free Trade Agreement approved when it was stalled in the United States Congress in 1993. 
 "What this shows is that the side agreements really haven't delivered on commitments made by the Clinton Administration in 1993," said Dan Seligman, an official responsible for trade issues with the Sierra Club in Washington.
The organization originally opposed the passage of Nafta, but the support of other environmental groups was crucial to winning the accord's approval and the Sierra Club ultimately dropped its opposition. Mr. Seligman said the Government's weak support for the environmental agreements makes it unlikely that environmental groups could support expansion of the agreement.
President Clinton has said he will seek Congressional authority to negotiate agreements with Chile and other Latin American nations, but he has not made a commitment to include environmental accords.
"If the commission can't get the countries to study the environmental impacts of increased trade that's already taken place, how can they ever get them to do anything real about improving environmental standards, which is what they promised in 1993," Mr. Seligman said.
The environmental study is a comparatively small part of a comprehensive review of the trade pact and its effects on the United States economy, which by law must be completed this year. President Clinton must report to Congress by July.
Three areas were selected for examination: energy use, cattle raising and, in Mexico, raising corn -- the country's primary agricultural crop.
The study was considered an important milestone because the work was to be done independently of the three Governments. An advisory panel made up mostly of experts and representatives of citizens' groups was supposed to oversee the project.
The $150,000 to finance the study this year is included in the $9 million annual budget of the Commission for Environmental Cooperation, the organization set up in Montreal to oversee the environmental aspects of Nafta. But while the money has been in the budget since last fall, the three Governments have not given approval for the work to proceed. Trade officials from the United States have raised concerns about the study, but the Mexican Government has most forcefully objected, several people familiar with the negotiations say.
"The trade people in Mexico were nervous about letting any part of the Nafta process out from under their direct and total control," said Daniel C. Esty, now director of the Yale University Center for Environmental Law and Policy, who was the chief negotiator for the Environmental Protection Agency on Nafta.
Mexican officials agreed that the study teams should be independent, but they wanted so much input and oversight that it would have amounted to the ability to censor the reports, an American official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official said there appeared to be a split between Mexico's Environmental Ministry and the Trade Ministry.
Mario Aguilar, an Environmental Ministry official at the Mexican Embassy in Washington, denied that there was any split in his Government's position. He confirmed that Mexico has objected to the way the study was designed, he rejected any suggestion that there had been an attempt to censor the findings.
"We have doubts about the way the three sectors were chosen," Mr. Aguilar said. "We want the work to have a scientific base, not to deal with politics and opinion."
A member of the group advising the environmental analysis said the three areas were selected after a thorough review of the free trade agreement's first years of operation. "Case studies were needed," said Richard Kamp, director of the Border Ecology Project in Bisbee, Ariz., "to show how investments have taken place and how they have affected society."
The study on corn is considered the most potentially damaging to Mexico, since it deals with the most important staple of nearly every Mexican's diet.
Before Nafta was passed, it was widely predicted that eliminating tariffs over a 15-year period would flood Mexico with imported corn, causing great disruptions as poor farmers gave up their fields and moved to Mexico's cities or across the border.
But the early drafts of the corn study show that while corn imports indeed have already surpassed the 15-year projections, there has been no widespread dislocation.
Alejandro Nadal, a professor of economics at the Colegio de Mexico in Mexico City who is conducting the corn study, said he knows why the Mexican Government is worried about the results.
"They want Nafta to work out fine," he said. "But if they start fiddling around with the commission's work, we are going to have problems."

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Allowing Rates To Hold Steady

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy was slowing sufficiently to avert a resurgence of inflation.
The central bank's policy-making body had increased the key short-term rate it controls by a quarter point, to 5.50 percent, at its last meeting two months ago, saying that strong growth and low unemployment were creating the conditions that could push wages and prices higher and endanger the economy's expansion. 
 In passing up the chance today to raise rates again, it heeded, at least for now, warnings from some economists that a further increase would have little economic justification or political support because there is almost no sign that inflation is taking root.
The decision heartened investors, who sent stock prices surging. After falling early in the day, the Dow Jones industrial average rallied after the Federal Reserve's announcement in the early afternoon, closing at 7,303.46, up 74.58 points. Bond prices rose moderately, and the dollar -- which would have become a more attractive investment if interest rates were higher in this country -- fell. [Page D1.]
Analysts said that the Federal Reserve might still feel compelled to raise rates again this year, perhaps at its next policy meeting in July. They said the decision today was driven by clear evidence that economic growth had moderated substantially from the 5.6 percent rate of the first quarter, as well as by reports showing that inflation was almost nonexistent at the producer level and subdued at the consumer level.
Some economists also saw today's decision as evidence of an increased willingness on the part of the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to be open to the possibility that the economy could grow without igniting inflation. The alternative to such a decision is to fall back reflexively on the convention that growth rates that are more than about 2.25 percent when unemployment is less than 5 percent will inevitably lead to sharp increases in wages and prices.
"There's an experiment going on here, and the Fed is letting growth roll," said Allen Sinai, an economist at Primark Decision Economics, a consulting firm.
Mr. Sinai and others said economists were being forced to re-examine their old rules of thumb about growth and inflation because of an array of changes that are reshaping the economy. Huge investments by businesses in new technology appear to have bolstered productivity in ways that official statistics do not capture. Instead of passing cost increases along to consumers, companies increasingly try to wring them out of their own production processes. Workers are more willing to accept modest pay raises, or to tie their compensation to performance or efficiency. The globalization of commerce has intensified competition in many industries.
"So much has changed in our economy that it would be a mistake to assume the old rules apply," Mr. Sinai said. "What Greenspan has shown us again and again in his tenure is the ability to understand how the world does change and still keep his eye on the ball of price-level stability."
Today's meeting of the Fed's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, came against a backdrop of vociferous opposition to further rate increases from across the political spectrum and from both the business community and organized labor. Opponents argued that in raising rates in March to slow demand by making borrowing more expensive, Mr. Greenspan had gone too far with his policy of eradicating inflationary pressures before they took root. The rate increase caused a sharp selloff in the stock market, which has recovered since then.
While Mr. Greenspan's willingness to hold off on further rate increases no doubt has its limits, today's decision was applauded by many of the groups that had criticized the rate increase in March.
"From living rooms to board rooms, anyone concerned with economic growth and continued high employment can breathe easier," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "The Fed recognized that there is no need to fix an unbroken economy."
In holding rates steady today, the Federal Reserve was clearly betting on a repeat of the events in the economy last year: a period of unusually strong growth followed by a slowdown that bled off any mounting inflationary pressure, averting the need for action.
Still, the risks in the strategy are substantial. The economy grew 3.8 percent in the last quarter of 1996, and then by 5.6 percent in the first three months of this year. With unemployment at 4.9 percent in April, traditional economic forecasts predicted that employers would begin bidding up wages to attract the workers needed to keep increasing their output, and that wage increases would feed through to consumers in the form of higher prices.
At its meeting in March, the Fed decided that the risks of accelerating inflation were sufficient to justify a small step to cool down the economy. It therefore raised the target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans -- to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent.
As Mr. Greenspan put it in a speech this month defending the move, "The risk to the economy from inaction came to outweigh the risk from action."
But since then nearly all the economic evidence has suggested that inflation remains well contained, that the consumer spending binge that drove growth earlier in the year has cooled off and that companies have built big inventories that they must sell before placing new orders -- all factors suggesting that the economy is not overheating.
At a minimum, the Federal Reserve decided today that it could afford to wait at least until its July meeting to get a clearer indication of whether the economy was slowing sufficiently on its own to eliminate the inflation threat, analysts said.
"The real question is what the incoming information will look like over the next six weeks," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities.
Analysts said the decision today may also have been influenced by the agreement between the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership in Congress on a plan to eliminate the Federal budget deficit. Mr. Greenspan has pushed hard for deficit reduction, saying a credible plan to balance the budget would help bring down interest rates. To raise rates immediately after a bipartisan budget agreement could have undermined the considerable respect Mr. Greenspan enjoys on Capitol Hill, they said.
"Mr. Greenspan has proven himself very adept over the years in sensing which way the political wind is blowing, and apparently he decided that the Fed needed more ammunition before tightening again," economists at First Union Capital Markets said in a report today.

HEADLINE: House Democratic Leader Opposes Clinton's Budget Deal

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, broke with the White House today and said he would oppose the budget deal between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans.
"I do this as a matter of principle," Mr. Gephardt said this afternoon as the House opened debate on its budget resolution. "This is a budget of many deficits: a deficit of principle, a deficit of fairness, a deficit of tax justice, and, worst of all, a deficit of dollars." 
 While significant, Mr. Gephardt's opposition is unlikely to block passage of the budget deal that Mr. Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, signed off on last week.
His decision may influence some of his rank-and-file members, but a majority of Republicans and Democrats in both chambers support the five-year plan, which would balance the Federal budget, offer some of the largest tax breaks in decades and provide billions of dollars for education, social and health programs.
Mr. Gephardt, of St. Louis, is widely expected to challenge Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000, and his announcement drew a sharp distinction between the two.
In the coming weeks, Mr. Gephardt may wind up on the opposite side of the Clinton-Gore team on several major issues, including extending most-favored-nation trade status to China for another year, which the Administration supports.
Mr. Gephardt has also expressed reservations about giving the White House the "fast track" negotiating authority it wants for a trade agreement with Chile. But the Democratic leader tried to quash the notion that his political positions were influenced by the Presidential race.
"This is not politics, this is not about some election, this is about the future of this country and what is best for it," he said.
Likewise, neither Mr. Gore nor the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, would be drawn into talk about Presidential politics.
"Let's not run the 2000 campaign in 1997," Mr. McCurry told reporters.
And Mr. Gore limited his comments to defense of the budget, saying, "It is a well-reasoned approach, and I think that it is a good approach."
Both the House of Representatives and the Senate began debate today on their budget resolutions, the first legislative step in the budget process and the outline for specific changes to come later.
Mr. Gephardt was the only one of the top four leaders on Capitol Hill to criticize the deal when it was announced last week. From the outset, he has been one of the harshest critics of the tax cuts in the plan, which he says favor the well-to-do.
Before declaring his opposition on the House floor this afternoon, Mr. Gephardt informed the President of his position in a meeting at the White House and met privately with House Democrats for about 90 minutes to argue his case.
His decision placed him on the opposing, and likely losing, side of the most prominent piece of legislation that will be debated this year. But the arguments he made resonate with a majority of Democratic primary voters and with organized labor groups that are the base of his national following.
"I think he has positioned himself excellently to command the liberal base of the Democratic Party in the primaries," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, who added that he was "not the least bit worried" that Mr. Gephardt had the clout or support to torpedo the deal.
The package includes $115 billion in savings to the Medicare program and $85 billion worth of tax cuts, including a $500 per child tax credit, broad-based, permanent cuts in the capital gains tax, reductions in the inheritance tax and an expansion of Individual Retirement Accounts.
The proposal also provides $35 billion over five years for post-secondary education, including a deduction and a tax credit, all items that the Administration had demanded.
Republican House leaders had expected a vote on the budget resolution tonight, but that timetable fell apart after the chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania, introduced an amendment that the leaders said would wreck the entire budget deal.
The amendment -- co-sponsored by Representative James L. Oberstar, the senior Democrat on the transportation committee -- would increase spending for Federal highway and mass transit programs by $11.6 billion.
The sponsors proposed offsetting the spending through across-the-board reductions of 0.4 percent in tax cuts and spending. Programs like Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, with mandatory spending, would be exempted from the proposed cuts.
As the idea gained support throughout the day, Republican leaders hastily convened a late night meeting of their rank-and-file to try to quash the amendment and White House negotiators rushed to Capitol Hill to lobby Democrats.
The loudest clamor against the budget has come from hard-line conservatives in the Republican Party and the more liberal wing of the Democratic Party.
Representative Ernest Istook, a Republican from Oklahoma, laid out most of the conservatives' complaints in a letter today to Mr. Gingrich. Mr. Istook criticized the agreement as "a high-risk plan, feasible only if future economic conditions are ideal."
He also complained that the plan would spend too much money, expands entitlement programs, open-ended commitments that finance all who qualify, and fails to provide all of the tax relief being promoted. He urged Speaker Gingrich to reopen negotiations.
"I believe this plan focuses on solving the problems of today's politicians, when it should focus on solving the problems that threaten America's future, to preserve our children's heritage and opportunity," Mr. Istook wrote.
Mr. Gephardt that the assertion that the plan would balance the Federal budget by 2000 was based on "dubious assumptions."
And while stopping well short of criticizing the Administration directly, he said the budget fell short of many of the other goals that its backers assert it will achieve.
While Mr. Clinton has touted a provision that makes $16 billion available to children who lack health insurance, for instance, Mr. Gephardt said the "positive effect" of that program was offset by cuts in Medicaid funding to children's hospitals.
"This compromise gives to children with one hand and takes away with the other," he said.

HEADLINE: The Greenspan Dividend

 BODY:
Wall Street is supposed to react with horror when the Federal Reserve Board cowers from raising interest rates in the face of a raging economy. But yesterday, when the Fed announced it would keep interest rates steady, stocks soared and interest rates fell, a tribute to the market's faith in Chairman Alan Greenspan. Under Mr. Greenspan, the Fed has presided over nearly uninterrupted growth with steadily falling inflation. His record now gives him the leeway to sit back and let the economy grow without having to prove his anti-inflationary credentials by prematurely jacking up rates and slowing the economy down.
A year or so ago, economists debated whether the economy could operate at unemployment rates below 6 percent without driving up wages, then prices. Today unemployment hovers below 5 percent, while inflation stays below 3 percent. This good news puts the Fed in a policy predicament. It knows that its interest rate hikes take a year or more to cool off an economy. If it waits until inflation visibly rises, it risks having to throw the economy into a tailspin to wring out the inflationary momentum. But by stamping out inflation before it appears, the Fed would forgo learning whether the modern economy can operate at permanently lower unemployment rates than in the past. 
 The Fed has decided to see how good the economy can be, allowing unemployment to drop to the lowest rate in 23 years, 4.9 percent. But it could not have done so had Mr. Greenspan not firmly established his credibility as an inflation fighter by pre-emptively raising interest rates in 1994 to ward off an inflationary burst that he feared but that had not yet appeared.
Had bond traders feared inflation, they would have greeted yesterday's non-action by driving up long-term interest rates, which the Fed does not control. They did not. The economy now reaps the benefit of the Fed's record. At an unemployment rate of 5 rather than 6 percent, the economy is already operating with an extra one million jobs. The Fed has now said, in effect, that it is prepared to test how low the rate can go.

HEADLINE: PLAN TO PAY OFF U.N. DUES STALLS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's proposal to pay $1 billion in dues owed to the United Nations has run aground in Congress. Republicans are insisting on paying only some of the debt, over a longer stretch of time and only after the United Nations agrees to a series of demands.
Proposals circulating in the House and the Senate would require everything from permanently reducing Washington's annual dues, while raising China's, to slashing the expense accounts of ranking officials. 
 Under the proposals, which have the backing of the Republican leadership in both houses, the United Nations would also have to reimburse the cost of American military equipment and support for peacekeeping operations, to impose still more budget restraints and even to allow the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to check the organization's books.
While the billion-dollar battle raged in Washington, in New York, the American delegate to the United Nations discussed the diplomatic immunity as applied to traffic tickets, an issue that has rankled New Yorkers. [Page A8.]
If Republicans have their way, Washington will pay the back dues -- the total is being debated -- over as many as five years instead of the two years that the Administration proposed. And the President would have to certify that the United Nations had met the conditions. "It's not going to be a payment up front with good intentions in the back," said Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota, a Republican who has been involved in drafting the proposals. "We have to say it loud and clear: the arrears will be paid only when the reforms are made."
The Administration, in quiet negotiations with Republican leaders, has opposed many of the conditions. And while it has agreed in principle to others -- including a reduction in the United States' yearly dues for general expenses and peacekeeping operations -- it has opposed writing them into law.
To do so, officials argue, would leave the State Department little flexibility in negotiations with the United Nations over changes in the organization's budget or bureaucracy. "It is a level of micromanagement by statute that is unprecedented," a senior Administration official said today.
At the United Nations, the proposals are encountering heated criticism from diplomats who have grown increasingly resentful that the United States will not come up with dues that it is bound by treaty to pay, even as it issues new dictates.
"We feel quite frankly that it is preposterous to put any conditions to the repayment of arrears, which the United States should pay under international law," said Nicolaas H. Biegman, the representative of the Netherlands at the United Nations. "It's as simple as that."
The wrangling between the Administration and the Republicans over how to pay the dues comes only months after the new Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, swept through Washington, promising to impose reforms and receiving pledges that the United States would finally pay up.
At the time, the election of Mr. Annan, a direct result of the United States campaign to oust his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, appeared to brighten the prospects for payment of the dues, most of which date back to 1994.
But the United Nations remains a target of many Republicans on Capitol Hill despite the Administration's newly vigorous campaign, led by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, to persuade Congress to pay the dues.
There is even a bill before the House that would bar any payment, based on the argument that the United States should have been credited for all of its contributions of military materiel to peacekeeping efforts. That legislation, introduced by Representative Roscoe G. Bartlett of Maryland and sponsored by more than 60 others, has little chance of passing, but it underscores the difficulty of winning support for paying the dues.
The Republican proposals are included in a series of bills with similar, though not identical, conditions on paying the dues, including one introduced by Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York, the chairman of the House International Relations Committee, and another by Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine.
The staff of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is also drafting a series of demands. Senator Helms's demands carry added significance, since he has insisted, an aide said, on attaching them to the legislation authorizing the State Department's entire budget, as well as to President Clinton's proposal to reorganize the department and the other foreign affairs agencies.
Mr. Helms's proposals -- a draft of which was obtained by The New York Times and confirmed by Senate aides -- would pay the dues in installments over five years and set specific conditions or "benchmarks" for the United Nations to meet each year.
In the first year, for example, the organization would have to agree to erase all outstanding debt owed by the United States. That is sure to be controversial, since the organization argues that the United States owes far more than the $1 billion that the Clinton Administration recognizes.
By the second year, the United Nations would have to cap United States dues at 20 percent of the general operating budget, compared with 25 percent now, and at 25 percent of the peacekeeping budget, compared with more than 30 percent now.
By the end of the five years, the United Nations would have to accept increased auditing, start setting expiration dates on programs, consolidate the myriad environmental and development organizations and eliminate those dealing with regional economic and social affairs.
The proposal would also require the affiliated international organizations, like the World Health Organization, to reduce their budgets.
If the United Nations failed to enact any of the changes, the United States would simply not pay that year's installment.
The Administration has held a series of negotiations with Republicans in the House and Senate to try to work out an agreement on the language of the demands.
Princeton N. Lyman, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said the Administration hoped to reach an accord with Congress that included "a set of benchmarks that are achievable," though some of those proposed by the Republicans were clearly not.
Another senior Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Administration could not accept repaying the dues over five years or cementing reforms of an international body into American law, which would have the effect of making them appear to be ultimatums.
"To lock it in will only cause other countries to refuse to negotiate," the official said.
But Senator Judd Gregg, the New Hampshire Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that oversees United Nations issues, said Congress had an obligation to set rigorous conditions, since the United States paid the largest share of the organization's budget.
"Since we're carrying the load," he said, "we have some right to demand that the tax dollars be spent in an appropriate way."

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Need for Jewish Housing Is Questioned by U.S.
American diplomats have found high vacancy rates in Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, casting doubt on the Israeli Government's claim that it is expanding the settlements to accommodate natural growth. Such expansions have angered the Palestinians and hindered peace efforts. A1 

G.O.P. Fights U.N. Dues
Republicans in Congress have skewered the Clinton Administration's proposal to pay $1 billion in dues the United States owes the United Nations. They demand that the United States' annual dues be permanently reduced while increasing those of China. A1
 
United Nations diplomats in New York City said they faced growing hostility since the uproar over their parking tickets. A8
 
Kabila Arrives in Kinshasa
Unannounced and discreetly, Laurent Kabila, Congo's new President, arrived in Kinshasa to take over the capital. But he did not announce the composition of his Government, which had been expected. A3
 
Support for Organ Donors
The top religious authority in Egypt reversed the prevailing interpretation of Islamic rules by saying that he was willing to donate his organs when he died. But conservative Muslims scoffed that the cleric, Mohammed Sayed Tantawi, had been appointed as Grand Sheik of Al Azhar, the center of learning in Sunni Islam, by the secular Government to do its bidding. A6
 
Scandal Surfaces in Brazil
The Government of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil has been accused of paying five Congressmen nearly a million dollars to vote for a constitutional amendment that would allow a President to run for re-election. A daily newspaper published what it said were transcripts of secret tape recordings in which two Congressmen discussed receiving payoffs. A9
 
Qaddafi Gets Mild Rebuke
The United Nations Security Council mildly rebuked Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for violating an international flight ban against his country. In a statement, the council said it "takes note with concern" reports that the Libyan leader had flown to Niger and Nigeria earlier this month. (Reuters)
 
Taliban Makes Advance
Local residents said three provinces in Afghanistan had fallen to the Taliban, an Islamic militant group that has imposed strict rules on the two-thirds of the country it already controls. The loss of the three northwestern provinces of Badghis, Faryab and Sar-e-Paul seriously threatened the anti-Taliban alliance led by Gen. Rashid Dostum, and aid workers said heavy fighting was only four miles from his stronghold in Mazar-e-Sharif. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A10-21, B7
 
Senate Votes to Prohibit Method for Late Abortions
The Senate voted to ban a late-term abortion procedure, but the bill's supporters fell three votes short of the number needed to override the veto expected from President Clinton. While the vote may mark only incremental progress for abortion opponents, they gained some ground in the larger abortion debate. A1
 
Birdlike Dinosaur Is Found
A team of Argentine paleontologists reported finding what appears to be the most birdlike dinosaur ever found. Its anatomy appears to be intermediate between dinosaurs and Archaeopteryx, the earliest known bird. The new fossil animal has been named Unenlagia comahuensis, which means "half bird from northwest Patagonia" in the language of the Mapuche Indians of the region. A18
 
Gephardt Opposes Budget Deal
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, said he would oppose the budget deal between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans. Mr. Gephardt's opposition is unlikely to block passage of the proposal. But Mr. Gephardt is widely considered as a likely challenger to Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000, and his announcement draws a sharp distinction between him and his potential rival. B7
 
Health Care Bill Criticized
Republican senators attacked a children's health insurance bill proposed by Senators Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. They said the higher Federal tax it would put on tobacco would cut cigarette sales, costing the states more than $1 billion in annual revenues. The bill's sponsors intend to offer it on Wednesday as an amendment to the budget resolution. A20
 
E.P.A. Targets Mills' Pollution
The Environmental Protection Agency wants to force paper mills to make big reductions in their emissions of dioxins and other toxic chemicals into the water and air, at an estimated cost of $1.4 billion. The proposed rules, which are expected to be sent to the White House for final review this week, are already being denounced by some environmental groups. A21
 
Pilot's Court-Martial Delayed
The Air Force delayed the court-martial of its first female B-52 pilot, First Lieut. Kelly Flinn, on adultery, lying and other charges so Air Force Secretary Sheila Widnall can consider the pilot's request for an honorable discharge. A16
 
McVeigh Defense Faults F.B.I.
The defense for Timothy J. McVeigh attacked the integrity of the F.B.I.'s laboratory in the handling of evidence from the Oklahoma City bombing. But a senior F.B.I. chemist, Steven G. Burmeister, said he was confident that the evidence against Mr. McVeigh had not been contaminated, even though some evidence could have been handled better. A10
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Appeals Court Tells Judges To Make Juries Follow Law
The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled in Manhattan that judges had a duty to insure that jurors did not ignore the law and impose their own values to acquit or convict a defendant. The decision comes at a time when the legal community is embroiled in a continuing debate over race and the justice system, and whether it is ever appropriate for jurors to acquit a defendant as a protest against a perceived lack of fairness in the justice system, which is called "jury nullification." Thousands of tenants converged on the state Capitol to show support for extending New York's rent regulations. They protesters also demonstrated their opposition to Governor Pataki's proposal for a system that would remove rent protections from apartments when the tenants moved out or died. The crowd was the largest seen in Albany since State University students protested tuition increases two years ago. B1

Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee approved legislation that would allow Broome County to eliminate its sales tax on clothing, even though they are resisting a similar proposal from Mayor Giuliani for New York City. Republican leaders in the Senate had maintained that they did not want localities to lower their sales taxes on clothing in a haphazard fashion and preferred to give all places the chance to scale back these levies at the same pace. HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Unchanged

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City's high unemployment rate did not budge in April, remaining stuck at 9.7 percent, even as a booming national economy pushed down unemployment rates to low levels elsewhere around the country. The state's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate of 6.3 percent was also unchanged.
Nationally, only 4.9 percent of Americans were unemployed in April, the lowest level in 23 years. The gap between New York City's jobless rate and that of the rest of the nation -- 4.8 percentage points in April -- is now the largest it has been in at least 19 years, according the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. The previous record gap, of 4.5 percentage points, was set in March 1997. 
 The New York State Labor Department said that on a snapshot month-to-month basis, not adjusted for seasonal variations, the picture looked better for both the city and the state. Statewide the number of service jobs, construction, and retail and wholesale trade jobs all rose, while banks and insurance companies reduced their job totals.
New Jersey reported last week that its seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for April dropped to 5.2 percent from 5.5 percent in March. Connecticut has not reported its April rate yet, but its unemployment rate in March stood at 4.9 percent. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: On Campus;
Aid Lags, Indian Colleges Say

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Leaders of the United States' Indian-run colleges say Federal support has failed to keep up with rising enrollments that are likely to swell further as an overhaul in welfare programs drives more American Indians to seek job training.
The leaders hoped that a new report on tribal colleges being released today would again call attention to their role in moving Indians out of poverty and into higher education. 
 The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching said the tribal colleges, mostly two-year institutions, excelled at job training, business creation and community building even though money and buildings were scarce.
"Despite overwhelming obstacles, America's tribal colleges are educating thousands of our people, providing them with perhaps their only chance of economic self-sufficiency," said Janine Pease-Pretty On Top, president of Little Big Horn College in Crow Agency, Mont.
Total enrollment in tribal colleges nationally has shot up to more than 24,000 in 1996 from about 10,000 in 1989. Yearly Federal support for the institutions has remained at about $27 million since 1995, although President Clinton wants to raise that amount by $3 million in 1998.
The amount of support, about $2,890 per full-time student, is less than the $5,820 authorized in the Tribally Controlled Community College Assistance Act of 1978.
Robert Lorence, president of Northwest Indian College on the Lummi Reservation outside Bellingham, Wash., said the Indian institutions often served as bridges to four-year colleges.
Mr. Lorence said that his 650-student college struggled largely with teaching basic reading, math, and writing, and that the demand on basic training would rise.
"I'm assuming welfare reform will include some additional funds for training," Mr. Lorence said, "but I haven't seen where that is or how it will come from the colleges."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
SENATOR JOSEPH R. McCARTHY was not known as a connoisseur. But from time to time he would, said one of his chroniclers, employ a phrase worthy of inclusion in any anthology of culinary bons mots. Asked how he liked his steak, Tailgunner Joe would reply, "Charred -- like the soul of an unbeliever."
Much has changed since the Junior Senator from Wisconsin left us in 1954, but most folks still prefer their grilled meat carbonized, at least on the outside. To the wine lover, this preference poses a dilemma: forgo the grape entirely or come up with something short of cleaning fluid that marries well -- as the food esthetes say -- with charred meat. 
 A third alternative, steaks and chops rare all the way through, which might stand a better chance with wine, can be dismissed out of hand. It's un-American.
Not too long ago, real men, the major consumers of grilled meats, did not drink wine. For me, at least, this perception changed in 1985, when the late Paul Castellano was gunned down on East 46th Street in Manhattan on his way into Sparks Steak House. Mr. Castellano was, as they say, a major underworld figure, a calling in which manliness is highly valued and readily demonstrated by mayhem, which is not always convenient, and by eating steaks.
Since Sparks happens to have a great wine list, Mr. Castellano's demise, whatever else it accomplished, established once and for all a relationship between red meat and wine. Had he made it inside, he almost certainly would have ordered wine, probably Chianti, a variety much favored in his set, as anyone who listens to court-ordered tapes will attest.
Probably a Chianti, but then, Sparks' owner, Pat Cetta, is skilled at steering even the most hide-bound meat-eaters in new directions. The best Chiantis, like the best Bordeaux, are not always the best choices to go with grilled steaks and chops. They can be too subtle, too nuanced.
Granted, skilled chefs and cooks, working with the best meat and professional broilers, can prepare a steak that won't overshadow an elegant wine. But for the most part, grilled meats, and particularly those prepared by backyard amateurs, need big, assertive wines that can hold their own in any company: syrahs from all over the world, barolos and other wines from the Piedmont, petite sirahs from California, any reds from the Rhone Valley, South African pinotages and, most important, muscular zinfandels, also from California.
Zinfandel is a red grape with European roots, but it achieved its own identity in this country long before any other important variety and has been adopted, one could say, as America's own. And since, along with Argentina, we are one of the few nations seriously hooked on grilled meat, it seems only fitting that zinfandel should be our designated grilled-meat wine.
Mind you, not white zinfandel -- a sweet, slightly fizzy, pale pink concoction, more akin to soft drinks than to wine, that at times isn't even made from zinfandel grapes. Real zinfandel is a gutsy red wine, full of spice and fruit flavors and often fairly high in alcohol. Most wines these days average between 11.5 and 13.5 percent alcohol. Zinfandels regularly reach 15 percent alcohol, and some recent monsters from De Loach Vineyards in Sonoma County have gone as high as 17.5 percent.
Delicious wines, but not for the faint of heart or for anyone driving home from the picnic.
Zinfandel can display all the finesse of cabernet sauvignon and pinot noir, but even the most elegant of the breed will also be full-flavored, ready to hold up to any steak, lamb chop or loin of pork -- overdone, underdone or just right.
Stockbrokers, especially successful ones, can be enthusiastic steak eaters, which, in good times like these, can lead to excess. A few months ago, around bonus time, two Young Turks were spotted at Wollensky's Grill on 49th Street, just off Third Avenue, lunching on hamburgers and Chateau Pichon-Lalande 1970. One evening around the same time, a group of eight young men, at the Post House on East 63d Street, chose to pair their steaks with a jeroboam -- eight bottles in one -- of Robert Mondavi Reserve cabernet sauvignon.
Stock market hubris has its own rules. Under less dramatic conditions, say, around the trusty Weber grill in the backyard, more modest wines should be the order of the day. And not just for economic reasons. An unsubtle grilled steak really calls for an unsubtle wine: one of those De Loach zinfandels, for example, or one from Ravenswood, Fetzer, Rodney Strong, Kendall-Jackson or Ridge. From northern Italy, a Gattinara from Travaglini or a spanna from Dessilani would work well. So would a southern Italian red like Taurino's Notarpanaro. From France, a hearty Cote du Rhone or a Gigondas from Guigal would honor any cookout, as would a solid shiraz from Rosemount, in Australia.
These are all easy-going wines at, generally, easy-going prices, many of them at or around $10. Which means that stocking enough for a crowd is not going to be a problem. It's important to be well stocked: people get impatient waiting for the fire to get hot. And if the steak doesn't turn out as planned, well, these are all wines that will go well with the pizza when it arrives 30 minutes later as a backup.

TASTINGS
Paul Thomas Cabernet-Merlot 1995 (Washington State). About $10.
 
Like many Pacific Northwest winemakers, Paul Thomas started out with fruit wine -- in his case, Crimson Rhubarb. He moved into grapes in the late 1970's and began a few years ago to turn out some interesting wines. Washington winemakers have always emphasized that their growing conditions are more Bordeaux-like than those in California. Their leaner, less aggressive wines tend to prove the point. They may not have the full-bodied richness of the California wines, but, at their best, they display complexity and nuance that their cousins to the south sometimes lack. This blend skillfully combines cabernet structure and merlot roundness in an extremely pleasant package. The blend is 57 percent cabernet and 43 percent merlot. And the price is not unattractive, either.

HEADLINE: Time to Get Big Sugar Off the Public Dole

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alfonso Fanjul and J. Pepe Fanjul, owners of a Florida sugar company, claim that "there is no subsidy" for American sugar growers (letter, May 14). This may come as a surprise to American consumers, who are forced by our Government to pay the Fanjuls almost twice the world price for their sugar. 
 The program provides sugar processors with special loans, and limits fair competition with strict import quotas. The General Accounting Office says that as a result, the sugar program costs consumers $1.4 billion a year in higher food prices. Contrary to the Fanjuls' letter, the Department of Agriculture has endorsed the G.A.O. study, saying that it is "a reasonable report with no major data problems."
The Fanjuls' massive subsidies encourage and intensify production in South Florida, further degrading the Everglades and increasing the cost of restoration by $65 million to $120 million, according to the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Congress has ended welfare as we know it for poor Americans. It's time to do the same for the Fanjuls and for other corporations on the public dole.
 
DAN MILLER
Member of Congress, 13th Dist., Fla.
Washington, May 15, 1997
