HEADLINE: Judging Beef By Its Grade, Cut and Eating Habits

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
STEAK on the grill turns a meal into a feast, the way Memorial Day turns a May weekend into summer.
The growing legion of steak lovers who want that steakhouse experience at home have more choices than ever when it comes to finding a good steak to put on the grill. First there is the matter of choosing the cut. Then, deciding on the grade. And increasingly, another option has become the brand name. Some brands of beef are "natural," that is, raised without hormones or antibiotics. 
 For steak, the best cuts are what the beef industry calls the middle cuts: the ribs, the loins and the flank, from the center of the steer. The less-tender end cuts like the chuck and the round come from around the animal's legs, where the muscles are heavier.
Shoppers who buy steak apparently know which are the best cuts. More than two-thirds select sirloin, shell, rib, T-bone, porterhouse, flank and tenderloin steaks, according to studies conducted by NPD, a market research company in Park Ridge, Ill. These cuts generally cost two to three times as much as the end cuts, about $10 or more a pound.
All the middle cuts are fine for grilling. Which one to buy is a matter of taste, serving size and budget. The loin is most often cut into strip or shell steaks. Sometimes called New York strips, these are the most popular in steakhouses and in stores. Porterhouse steaks are also from the loin and yield two or more servings. A T-bone steak is a smaller version of the porterhouse.
The tenderloin, or fillet, is a soft piece of boneless loin with relatively little fat that is usually sliced into individual filets mignons for grilling. A rib steak, which the French call entrecote, has the richest flavor, and also the most fat. The flank steak, a large flat slab of boneless meat, is economical, at about half the price of the other steaks. But it must be sliced thin on the bias, or it will be tough.
The sirloin can also be cut into large slabs that provide several servings. In his new book, "Steak Lover's Cookbook" (Workman, $13.95), William Rice explains that a big sirloin steak with a small, circular bone or pin bone will be more tender than a sirloin steak with a large, flat bone.
After deciding on the cut, the next option is the grade. The United States Agriculture Department grades beef based largely on the amount of fat marbling, the fat running through the meat, which enhances tenderness. It is a critical feature for a piece of meat that is seared over high heat rather than cooked slowly to break down the tissues. Though the department has eight categories for grading, shoppers can choose from only the top three: prime, choice and select.
More than half opt for choice, the most widely sold grade. About a third prefer select, which is leaner, cheaper and not as tender.
Prime is the beef with the most marbling, which makes it more flavorful and tender. It is also the costliest. Only about 2 percent of all the beef produced in this country these days is graded prime. Most is sold to the top steakhouses, so there is not much available for the home cook.
"The New York market is an exception," said Susan Parenty, a director of communications for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, a trade group. "The New York area probably consumes three times as much prime as anywhere else in the country and you can probably find it more easily."
New York still has about 10 butcher shops that sell prime beef. Elsewhere, mail-order companies are another good source.
Sales of brand-name beef, which first came on the market in 1979, have steadily increased, especially in the last few years, as producers take their cue from the chicken industry, their main competition. Last year, nearly half the supermarkets in the country carried some kind of brand-name beef, but it still accounts for less than 5 percent of the beef produced in this country. Almost all chicken is now sold by brand.
About half the brand-name beef is Certified Angus Beef, which is from the Angus breed of cattle and raised according to the standards set by the Certified Black Angus Beef Program in Wooster, Ohio. Certified Angus Beef is graded by the Agriculture Department to be at the high end of the choice range, closer to being prime than select, said a spokeswoman, Crystal Meyer.
Beef that is free of growth hormones and antibiotics is called "natural" and is sold in about 16 percent of supermarkets.
Coleman's, a brand of natural beef raised by a producer in Denver, is now being sold at Food Emporium, A&P, Waldbaum's, King Kullen, Shop Rite, Grand Union and Fresh Fields markets in the New York area. Coleman's, which sells prime, choice and select beef, has experienced double-digit increases in sales since 1993.
Since beef consumption hit its low of 61.6 pounds a person in 1993, it has been slowly increasing, mainly because of increased steakhouse traffic. Last year, it was 64.7 pounds, or 10 pounds a person less than it was a decade ago.
Niman Schell, a company based in Bolinas, Calif., near San Francisco that has been producing natural beef since 1979, recently began selling some of its beef at retail, outside the San Francisco area. It can be ordered from the Williams-Sonoma catalogue for $15 a pound. In Manhattan, it is sold at the Vinegar Factory for around $14 a pound, depending on the cut.
Niman Schell beef is dry-aged for three to six months before being shipped, to enhance its flavor, making it richer and earthier. Some steak-lovers like the taste. In March, Food Emporium supermarkets in Manhattan started selling choice beef that has been dry-aged for three weeks, which costs about $2 a pound more than the chain's regular choice steaks.
Steaks that are about one and a half inches thick produce the best results on the grill or under a broiler. Thinner steaks are better seared on top of the stove in a ridged cast-iron grill pan. A steak that is two inches thick or more may become too charred on the outside before it is cooked to the desired degree of doneness inside.
 
When Is It Done?
THE Agriculture Department recommends cooking beef to an internal temperature of at least 145 degrees, the temperature at which most potentially dangerous microorganisms are destroyed. It calls meat at this degree of doneness "medium rare," meat at 160 degrees "medium" and meat at 170 degrees "well done."
But do the Government's criteria for safety match up with most steak-lovers' tastes or with common restaurant practices?
As a test, Victor H. Chavez, the executive chef at Smith & Wollensky, the Manhattan steakhouse, broiled four prime boneless 16-ounce New York strips the way he usually does. The degree of doneness was based mostly on timing. As soon as the steaks came out of the broiler, they were tested with an instant thermometer. The rare steak registered 120 to 125 degrees; the medium rare, 130 to 135, and the medium steak, 145, still light pink in the center but going to gray-brown at the edges. The medium-well steak was 150 to 155 degrees. There was a difference of 15 degrees between the Government and the steakhouse.
Harold McGee in "On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen" (Charles Scribner's Sons, 1984) said, "We usually define the doneness of red meats not by their temperature, but by their inner color." The Government, more interested in safety than palatability, uses temperature, not color, as the guide. Mr. McGee writes that heating meat to temperatures of more than 140 degrees gradually makes it more solid, dense and dry, and the pigment increasingly drab. "That is why rare meat is pink and juicy, well-done meat brown-gray and dry," he said.
The way the steaks were cooked by Mr. Chavez is typical of most steakhouses. It is also the way people who want their beef medium rare are likely to cook it at home. "When people order a steak, they know how they like it and we have to cook it that way," Mr. Chavez said. "Lately, we have been getting more requests for meat a little more cooked, more medium rare to medium, instead of rare. Maybe people think it's safer."
The home cook also has to decide whether to play it safe and follow Government guidelines, or to indulge in rare or medium rare, knowing there may be a risk.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Grain and Soybean Prices Fall On Reports of Early Planting

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply yesterday after the Government reported that planting was proceeding at a near-record pace, bolstering farmers' chances of producing bumper fall harvests.
In other commodity markets, copper and palladium futures rose to new highs after Federal Reserve policy makers left United States interest rates unchanged. Coffee futures fell sharply for a third session on increasing supplies. 
 Farmers, as of Sunday, had put 88 percent of the corn crop into the ground, compared with the five-year average of 67 percent at this time of year, the United States Department of Agriculture reported late Monday.
Farmers also had sowed 46 percent of the soybean crops -- 20 percentage points above average, the department reported.
The earlier farmers get crops into the ground, the greater the chance of bumper crops. In 1994, for example, there was a record corn harvest after planting was 84 percent complete in mid-May.
Wheat futures retreated sharply despite declining winter wheat conditions. Western Kansas is expected to get rain, which could provide a late boost to the crop shortly before harvesting begins, analysts said.
Soybeans for July delivery fell 22 cents, to $8.44 a bushel; July corn fell 8.25 cents, to $2.7625 a bushel, and July wheat fell 14.75 cents, to $3.80 a bushel.
Copper and palladium futures prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the Fed left interest rates unchanged, fueling speculation that demand for the metals would increase as economic growth continues.
Palladium and copper, used in electronics, construction, automobiles and computers, would benefit heavily from cheaper interest rates.
June palladium rose $3.75, to $181.75 an ounce, the highest since April 1995. July copper was up 2 cents, to $1.178 a pound, the highest since May 16, 1996.
Coffee futures continued their retreat from 20-year highs on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York as supplies of arabica beans increased.
The exchange reported late Monday that inventories at its warehouses rose to 47,192 bags from 41,682 on Friday. Warehouse supplies have grown by nearly 25,000 bags since May 6.
A meeting of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries, which accounts for 80 percent of the world's production, also weighed heavily on the market. Analysts speculated that the group would announce today that it had loosened its self-imposed export quotas, allowing producers to sell more coffee if prices rise above a certain level.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Brokerage on Move (But Not Out of City)

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

 BODY:
Fahnestock & Company, a securities brokerage based in Manhattan, is moving from one downtown office tower to another, with more than $1.3 million in assistance from city and state agencies.
Fahnestock's 398 employees will move from 110 Wall Street to 125 Broad Street, where the company has leased 69,000 square feet for 15 years at about $25 per square foot, people involved in the transaction said. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a package of incentives yesterday intended to keep the company from leaving the city. The incentives include at least $500,000 in sales tax exemptions and $400,000 in energy discounts, an extra $250,000 in sales tax exemptions if the company hires 125 more workers, and $440,000 in cash grants from the state's Empire State Development Corporation.
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which negotiated the incentives, said Fahnestock had been "aggressively" courted by the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development, on behalf of the owners of One Harmon Meadow Boulevard, a five-story office building in Secaucus. New Jersey had offered about "four times" the New York package, Mr. Millard said.
A spokeswoman for the New Jersey agency declined to comment.
Fahnestock & Company drew notice recently for selling $55 million in bonds backed by anticipated future royalties from the recordings of David Bowie. It is a unit of Fahnestock Viner Holdings, a Canadian public corporation.
125 Broad Street, a 40-story tower that was the headquarters of American Express, then part of the Olympia & York real estate empire, was converted to a condominium in 1995 after Olympia & York turned it over to the building's lender, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. The law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell and the insurance company Johnson & Higgins, both tenants, own about 80 percent of the building. Earlier this year, the American Civil Liberties Union bought two of the remaining floors. The Fahnestock & Company lease leaves just two floors vacant, according to William D. Brodsky of Insignia/Edward S. Gordon, who represented New York Broad Holding Inc., which owns six floors in the building.

HEADLINE: New York Is Still No. 1 -- in Taxes

BYLINE: By Raymond J. Keating; Raymond J. Keating is chief economist with the Small Business Survival Committee and author of "New York by the Numbers."

DATELINE: CENTER MORICHES, N.Y.

 BODY:
Last year there were 2.8 million private-sector jobs in New York City, down from 3.2 million in 1969. This means that New York City, once the most dynamic city economy in the world, has not created a net new job in more than a quarter century.
The cause of this decline is no mystery: City taxes and regulations are onerous, and have combined with uncontrolled municipal spending and debt to cool the private sector's entrepreneurial fires. The greatest culprits have been the city's taxes on personal income, corporate income and unincorporated businesses, all adopted under Mayor John Lindsay in 1966. Unfortunately, no current city official seems to grasp how damaging these tax policies are. 
 At first glance, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appears to understand the problem. He eliminated the commercial rent tax throughout the city except for Manhattan south of 96th Street, where the top effective tax rate has been cut from 6 percent to 4.5 percent. And his new budget proposes cutting that top tax rate again, to 3.9 percent.
The Mayor has also pushed through a few minor tax reductions, including a cut in the city hotel tax, from 6 percent to 5 percent (on top of the 8.25 percent city sales tax and $2 per night flat fee), and a property tax cut for co-op and condo owners. He has proposed eliminating the city's 4 percent tax on clothing purchases under $500 and slightly raising the limit on annual income that is exempt from the unincorporated business tax.
These are steps in the right direction. Indeed, last year the city's private sector created jobs at a greater rate than the national average. But before anyone rushes to induct Mayor Giuliani into the pro-growth hall of fame, consider the flip side of the tax coin.
New York City still has the highest combined state and city personal income taxes in the nation. It imposes the highest capital gains tax rate (11.3 percent), the highest corporate income tax rate (19.4 percent), and the highest income and capital gains taxes on unincorporated entrepreneurs (15.3 percent). Not only has Mr. Giuliani done next to nothing to reduce these levies, he has helped to keep them high.
Remember that during the 1994 Governor's race, Mr. Giuliani opposed George Pataki's proposed cut in state personal income taxes, predicting dire consequences for the city. This year the Mayor has been silent about Governor Pataki's proposed four-year extension of the 17 percent tax surcharge that city businesses pay to keep the Metropolitan Transit Authority running -- in effect, a four-year tax increase of $2 billion.
Twice during his tenure Mr. Giuliani has extended the city's "temporary" surcharges on the personal income tax, refusing to allow the overall top tax rate to drop from 4.5 percent to 3.4 percent. Extending these surcharges will bring in about $2.2 billion from 1996 to 1998.
Even if Mr. Giuliani actually gets the tax cuts called for in his budget, during 1997 and 1998 he will be responsible for a two-year net tax increase on individuals and businesses of approximately $575 million. If you want to add in the Mayor's quiet collaboration on the extension of transit authority surcharge, then the net tax increase for 1997 and 1998 will likely be more than $1.5 billion.
Mr. Giuliani's supporters claim that he is making progress, that he cannot do what needs to be done and still be re-elected in an overwhelmingly Democratic city. If true, then we should expect to see a voracious tax cutter emerge if the Mayor wins a second term this November; the city's new term limits law will not allow him a third term.
In fact, it would also be smart politics to pursue such a strategy, if his ambitions extend beyond the liberal bastion of New York City.

HEADLINE: Bridging a Gap In the Resume;
When H.I.V. Loosens Grip, It's Back to the Job Market

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
A year and a half ago, a 49-year-old man named Robert was planning his funeral instead of his future. His skin had become infected with festering pimples that refused to heal. His weight had dropped precipitously. He found it physically draining to visit old friends who were also dying of AIDS, fading like wilted flowers. He thought of death constantly.
But earlier this month, there he was, robust and tan in a blue T-shirt and khakis, pondering three job offers and attending a new evening seminar on H.I.V. in the workplace, sponsored by the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's largest AIDS service agency. 
 In a stark white conference room typically used by social workers to help H.I.V.-infected people arrange a safety net of benefits for their death, he was feeling the wonderment of contemplating a return to work after two years on disability.
Powerful new AIDS drugs called protease inhibitors have reduced the lethal virus in his blood to undetectable levels. Now Robert, who used to earn $70,000 a year in real estate and architectural design, hopes to have a new job by the end of May.
"It's like being resurrected," said Robert, who spoke on the condition that he not be fully identified because he feared prospective employers had misperceptions about AIDS. "I feel like a child."
Medical breakthroughs have left G.M.H.C. and other AIDS service agencies across the country suddenly grappling with fragile hope.
Even as they continue to assist ailing clients who do not have access to the life-prolonging treatments or have failed to benefit by them, the agencies are quietly reinventing themselves in concrete and practical ways to keep pace with thousands of people like Robert. For the first time since the beginning of the epidemic 16 years ago, the agencies are creating new classes, like how to deal with renewed health, and shifting the focus of others from finding a funeral home to finding a paycheck.
At G.M.H.C. in Chelsea, workplace issues have dominated the discussion in seminars and workshops in recent months. New classes deal with subjects like the rights of employees with H.I.V. and how to return to the workplace.
"That's all that everybody is talking about," said Lillie Mikesell, a G.M.H.C. spokeswoman. "It's all just exploded."
In San Francisco, AIDS Benefits Counselors, which used to be in the business of preparing clients for disability and death, now manages an employment service and has seen demand for job skills and placement workshops nearly triple since January.
In Atlanta, AID Atlanta, a nonprofit service agency, has conducted a series of free public forums since November to help clients with AIDS navigate the challenges of renewed health. The forums have broached everything from artfully accounting for enormous gaps in resumes (list accomplishments, putting the sizzle up front, rather than jobs in chronological order) to understanding changes in corporate culture and lingo (team leaders, not managers). For the first in the series of six public forums, a few dozen people were expected, but 200 showed up.
"We're in an incredibly pivotal time in the epidemic where we are looking at how to help people live rather than how to help them die," said Sandy Thurman, President Clinton's new director of the National Office on AIDS Policy. "It's a huge shift logistically as well as psychologically."
Even as AIDS comes to feel for some people more like a chronic disease than a death sentence, the shifting role of AIDS agencies has become a touchy subject to service providers. There are still many unknowns about the new drugs, like how long they will remain effective. But as the needs of clients change, some AIDS organizations are likely to be put out of business.
As lower-income minorities rather than white middle-class gay men have become the prime target of AIDS, racially charged tension has increased over the role that leading AIDS service agencies should play and where resources should be invested, according to patient advocates and researchers.
"There is an absolute need to help those who are now finding themselves healthier," said Mario Cooper, the founder of Leading for Life, an initiative to increase political involvement in AIDS issues among blacks, and a board member of the Harvard AIDS Institute and G.M.H.C. "But at the same time," she said, "the majority of those with H.I.V., increasing amounts of people of color, have absolutely no access to anything, period."
Viewing the availability of protease inhibitors as a new lease on life is premature for some, according to Linda Campbell, executive director of the Minority Task Force on AIDS, the oldest minority AIDS service organization in New York.
"Many of our clients have been unemployed for long periods of time and because of despair and issues of inequity have turned to drugs as a way of dealing with the horrors of everyday life," Ms. Campbell said. "For our clients, we still have to think a lot about what supports that people out of the mainstream have. What does their future look like? What is the promise of the future for our clients, given the realities of how the local, state and Federal governments are now rolling back their commitment to social support."
Officials at agencies like G.M.H.C. said they still have an important role to play for dying people, which include many low-income, minority and heterosexual clients. But they say they cannot ignore the changed reality. G.M.H.C. estimates that roughly 70 percent of its clients have taken protease inhibitors.
On a recent Tuesday evening, nearly 20 men and women filled a conference room at Gay Men's Health Crisis. Marla Hassner, a managing attorney there, was guiding them through their rights as H.I.V.-positive employees. Several in the group scribbled notes as the talk turned from insurance benefits to pre-employment interviews and disclosure of H.I.V. status to employers.
Ms. Hassner advised them against disclosing their H.I.V.-positive status to employers, saying the only reasons to do so were if they applied for disability or sought a disability-related adjustment to their job.
"Often disclosing status causes more trouble than it is worth," she said. "Your employer is not your friend. The law doesn't require companies to treat us with compassion."
One man in an elegant gray suit wanted suggestions on how to ask prospective employers about disability benefits without disclosing his H.I.V.-positive status. The lawyer recommended scooping up the summary plan descriptions of all the employer's insurance policies, rather than raising a red flag by asking for one on long-term disability.
As the men and women listened attentively, Ms. Hassner informed them that prospective employers cannot ask about their H.I.V. status, nor can employers legally ask if they are taking medication, only if they are taking medication that might affect their ability to do their job. They may be taking 30 pills a day, but if they are not experiencing any side effects, the answer would be no, she said.
Robert, the man who is weighing three job offers, was eager to know the ins and outs of individual and group insurance policies, but he was also anxious to know what to do if he became sick again. "If you do start feeling sluggish and slow and your job performance is not up to par," he said, "could you ask for a reasonable accommodation?"
The lawyer told him that it depended on whether modifications could be made to the job that would allow him to perform essential duties, but accommodate his symptoms.
Ms. Hassner reminded the group that the law says people cannot be fired because of their H.I.V.-positive status, but they can be fired for other reasons.
"If there's downsizing and a whole department is going under, you can't save your job by disclosing you're H.I.V.-positive," Ms. Hassner said.
She added that it is illegal for employers not to hire somebody or to deny them health insurance purely because they are H.I.V.-positive.
The tenor of the employment seminar echoed that of a debt-management class, where some clients -- who thought they would be dead soon -- have spent the limit on their credit cards. Within the last six months, the focus of the debt-management workshop has shifted from informing dying clients about entitlements and discussing their debts to exploring the possibility of personal bankruptcy and questions of protecting salaries from garnishment.
"A lot of the time, it's putting the client's mind at ease," said Robert Newman, a G.M.H.C. staff attorney who moderates the workshop. "You have a fear of the unknown. Are they going to put me in jail? Is there a debtor's prison?"
In a new class for women on returning to the workplace, the conversation the other day was about how the term "living with AIDS" is no longer merely a feel-good mantra but a realistic expectation.
Iris Maldonado, 41, said that for so long she "was like in a deathbed waiting for my time to come." She has a 15-year-old daughter whom she did not expect to see graduate from junior high school. Now that Ms. Maldonado is taking protease inhibitors, , which have been on the market for 17 months,she looks forward to the day when she might become a grandmother.
Ms. Maldonado, who counsels other H.I.V.-infected women, is learning to deal not only with crisis management, like finding housing, substance-abuse counseling and other help for clients, but also the emotional and practical aspects of perhaps going back to work fulltime. Ms. Maldonado, for one, is a bit worried about having less time to spend with her family.
"But it's a great challenge to go out today and help someone know there is hope for them," said the slender woman, tears welling in her eyes. "It's not the end. It's just the beginning."
She has finally gotten around to writing her will. She said she placed it on a shelf at home where she hopes it will sit for a long time, collecting dust.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Meeting Gives Bonds A Modest Lift

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose modestly yesterday after the Federal Reserve decided to keep interest rates unchanged.
While investors were relieved by the decision, they quickly started to mull the possibility of future moves by the central bank. 
 "The Fed chose to leave rates unchanged, but that doesn't mean that they are out of the picture for the rest of the year," Doug Burtnick, senior fixed income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said. "The market will continue to struggle with each upcoming data release, as traders attempt to divine the course of future rate moves. There is still the risk of higher rates this summer."
Because it was the short end of the market that would have been hit hard had the Federal Open Market Committee raised rates yesterday, it was the short end that experienced the sharpest rally. The price of the three-month bill rose, driving its yield down 16 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- to 5.06 percent. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
But the dollar, which fell sharply in foreign-exchange trading after the Fed's decision, limited the day's gains in bonds. Market participants favor a strong dollar because it makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 7/32, to 96 18/32. The bond's yield -- an important benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- slipped to 6.90 percent from 6.92 percent on Monday.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, noted that had the Fed tightened, a negative reaction from the bond market might have lasted 24 hours. But since the Fed left rates steady, traders and investors will now have to begin examining again each new piece of economic data including the May employment report on June 6, considered the next market mover. "We see a trading band on the yield of the long bonds as between 6.85 percent and 6.95 percent," he said.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said he was disappointed that the Fed did not raise rates. He said there were political considerations behind yesterday's decision.
"What this does to the market is to put it on edge again as investors will again have to scrutinize economic data leading to the next F.O.M.C. meeting," Mr. Pugliese said. "My own opinion is that there shouldn't have been a tightening in the first place. We are in extraordinary times. I think the technological revolution that this country is going through has increased productivity to the point where inflation is benign for the foreseeable future. Besides, the consumer has become more sophisticated, and you just can't pass prices along."
While he expects that wages will go up, Mr. Pugliese predicted they would not reach a meaningful level. "Plus again we have lower import prices, which keep competition keen," Mr. Pugliese said. "Long-term rates will be significantly lower than they are now regardless what the Fed does over the near term. The road to higher prices will not be smooth until the Fed acknowledges that it is done raising rates."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Singapore Ranked the No. 1 Economy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Singapore again ranks first among the 53 economies rated in the Global Competitiveness Report, a closely watched study of countries' economic potential that is being released today by the World Economic Forum, a business-financed research organization in Geneva.
The United States also continued to do well in the report, moving to third from fourth. That made it far and away the leader among large, developed economies in what Jeffrey Sachs, the co-chairman of the forum's advisory board and the architect of the rating system, calls "the ability to achieve sustained high rates of economic growth." 
 There are other familiar players at the top of the list, including Hong Kong (No. 2), New Zealand (No. 5), Switzerland (No. 6) and Taiwan (No. 8), but there are some surprises, too. Canada moved to fourth from eighth, reflecting progress in reducing its budget deficit -- a problem plaguing virtually all the mature social democracies. Even more dramatic, Britain jumped to 7th place from 15th by slashing top tax rates and reducing labor market regulation that inhibits employment growth.
 The study, which was reformulated last year to emphasize the conclusions of professional economists over those of business executives, has attracted a following because many business and government leaders see it as a report card on their success in making their economies leaner, meaner and more prepared for growth.
Last year's change in the rankings process, which de-emphasized opinion polling in favor of more objective criteria, ranging from tariff rates to currency stability to the number of telephones per capita, has apparently produced a better predictor of growth prospects. Indeed, there was no statistical correlation between the old style of executive poll rankings and rates of growth, while the new method did identify some actual winners and losers last year. "We beat the gut response of business leaders," Mr. Sachs said.
 The survey of executives is still conducted, but is given less weight. It has tended to favor historically successful countries like Japan, Germany and France, whose entrenched flaws are more easily discernible under the new system. From Mr. Sachs's perspective, the principal advantage to the refurbished Global Competitiveness Report is its transformation from a high-profile popularity contest to a bully pulpit for spreading the gospel according to modern development economics.
The most successful grouping in the recent report -- what it calls the "entrepot economies," including Singapore, Hong Kong, Switzerland and Luxembourg (11th), so-called because they are very small countries that thrive on providing global trade and financial services -- got that way by virtue of the countries' commitment to openness, minimal regulation and rule of law.
 The "Anglo-Saxon" economies (Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand, Britain and the United States) are doing well, too, beating back the economic arteriosclerosis that can come with the accumulation of interest group influence in rich democracies. The United States led this pack by ranking first among all economies on management skills, second on access to technology and third on both infrastructure development and the efficiency of financial markets. It would have nosed out Hong Kong for second place in the overall rankings but for mediocre scores on taxation, bureaucracy and civil justice.
 The most disappointing group, the countries of the European Union, all provide high living standards. But their high-spending, high-tax regimes generally undermine the efficiency of markets and offer little hope of rapid growth in income or employment. "Continental Europe sits there in a mess," Mr. Sachs said. "The basic problems aren't being solved." But the Netherlands (moving from 17th to 12th) and Ireland (jumping from 26th to 16th), both bucked the general trend in Europe by making their welfare states more user-friendly for business.
 The transition economies of Eastern Europe are, at best, treading water. Russia (53d) and Ukraine (52d) have been overwhelmed by corruption and incompetent government, the report says. Poland (50th), Hungary (46th) and the Czech Republic (32d) are all striving to encourage private enterprise and attract foreign investment. But in all three, social security has priority over efficient markets and government spending still represents roughly half of national output. "Their pretensions to being Sweden are premature," Mr. Sachs said.
 Protectionism and heavy-handed regulation are holding back some of these economies, along with some others that have consistently ranked low, like Venezuela (47th), India (45th) and South Africa (44th).
Human rights appear to have no direct input on competitiveness rankings. Some economies with capital-friendly authoritarian regimes -- Singapore, Indonesia (15th) and China (29th) -- did well compared with rights-minded democracies, including Portugal (30th), Belgium (31st), the Czech Republic, Iceland (38th), Italy (39th) and Poland.
But Mr. Sachs, citing countries like Britain and the United States, suggested that the conflict between competitiveness and social justice was more apparent than real. "You don't need to spend half of national income on middle-class entitlements in order to maintain the safety net," he argued.

HEADLINE: A Slowdown In the Works Whatever The Fed Does

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Whatever the Federal Reserve does over the next few months, the American economy appears to be heading, on its own, into a period of slower economic growth.
"Weaker is not bad," said Robert D. Reischauer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "We are still talking about positive economic growth." 
 Virtually no economist is predicting a recession, only a slowdown to perhaps half the booming annual growth rate of more than 4 percent that prevailed from October through March. Many analysts consider such rapid growth to be inflationary, if it lasts long enough. Eventually, with very strong growth, shortages of labor and merchandise develop, which push up wages and prices.
But the spurts of growth during the current recovery, like the one this last winter, have not lasted long. Counting the slower periods, the gross domestic product, valuing all the goods and services that the nation produces in a given year, has risen at an average annual rate of only 2.7 percent since the last recession ended, in the spring of 1991. That growth rate has not been strong enough to create the shortages that push up inflation. And the growth rate is even less, a very mild 2.1 percent a year, if the 1990-91 recession is averaged in.
The economic expansion of the 1990's, now in its seventh year, has been marked by alternating periods of strong and weak growth. A booming 1994, for example, was followed by a weak 1995, mostly because the Fed had raised interest rates sufficiently to slow the economy. The slowdown under way now -- after a winter in which the economy boomed -- appears to reflect more natural causes.
"With the economy slowing, it is quite plausible that we can have a 2.5 percent growth rate, and the Fed does not have to lift a finger," said Lee Price, chief economist at the Commerce Department. The Fed's top officials, at their policy meeting yesterday, decided not to follow a rate increase in March with another one now.
Since early April, retail sales have fallen and stockpiles of unsold goods have piled up. This inventory accumulation accounted for a big chunk of the strong economic growth in the first quarter. Working off those stockpiles now, in the face of weaker retail sales, means cutbacks in industrial production, at least temporarily. These cutbacks have already begun to show up in Government statistics as weaker growth in the second quarter.
"What is going on now is a mini-inventory correction," said Lyle Gramley, a consulting economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association and a former Fed governor. "That is normally a short phenomenon."
The big question is how long the slowdown will last. There is no way to answer that question yet.
But if the inventory correction follows a typical pattern, the economy might be growing more strongly again by fall or winter, once retailers and wholesalers decide to step up orders to restock their shelves.
However, some ingredients of last winter's strong growth are lacking now. Warmer-than-usual weather encouraged above normal shopping and construction activity, strengthening the economy temporarily, particularly in the first quarter. So did tax refunds, which flowed to Americans in unexpectedly large amounts in the weeks before April 15.
Other factors suggest that a longer period of mild growth might lie ahead. Consumer debt is at a record high, eating into household income, and borrowing to finance purchases has tapered off. New-vehicle sales, having held above 15 million at an annual rate through the winter, dropped below that level in April, and the auto industry has responded with rebates and sales incentives.
"When the economy slows, we slow even more," said Wynn Van Bussman, chief economist at the Chrysler Corporation, "and we are confirming that slowdown because it is becoming more and more difficult to sell new vehicles."
Similarly, home construction was quite strong this winter, contributing noticeably to economic growth, particularly when all the accessories -- carpeting, appliances, furniture, remodeling -- are added in. Construction is still high, but no longer rising. "Some of the early-year exuberance has worn off," said David F. Seiders, chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders.
Slower economic growth -- 2.5 percent or less annually -- is touted by most economists and policy makers as necessary to avoid the shortages that drive up the inflation rate. Corporate executives and union officials increasingly argue that the American economy is capable of greater growth without rising inflation.
Slower growth also makes an economy more susceptible to the sort of "accident" that can tip a weakened economy into recession: the Persian Gulf crisis played a role in provoking the 1990-91 recession, along with the Fed's decision to keep interest rates up. Similarly, a sharp decline in stock prices could undermine the economy now by damaging the confidence of American households, nearly half of whom own stocks, either directly or through mutual funds and retirement accounts.
Or the Federal Reserve, trying to slow the economy to avoid a rise in the inflation rate, could push up interest rates too much, in its effort to discourage borrowing and spending. "Every recession since 1957 has been caused by a spike in interest rates or an oil price shock," Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, said.
The Fed in its decision yesterday seemed to recognize the danger of pushing up rates too much.

HEADLINE: Minister of Objection Nettles Washington;
Boeing, Threatened, Sees Trade War

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 16

 BODY:
Who is Karel van Miert, and why is he declaring war on the Boeing Company?
As the Seattle-based aerospace giant pushes to complete its $14 billion takeover of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the biggest roadblock is suddenly being posed by a feisty European official who has bluntly branded the deal "totally unacceptable." 
 The official is Karel van Miert, a 55-year-old former Belgian Socialist who is the European Commission's Minister for Competition and, de facto, the Continent's top antitrust authority. Few Americans have heard of him, but that is changing fast, especially in corporate board rooms.
On Wednesday, Mr. van Miert is expected to hand Boeing a list of "objections" to the McDonnell Douglas deal. Never mind that the takeover involves two American companies, or that his biggest objection stems from two long-term sales contracts that Boeing recently reached with two American airlines.
"If any deal has an effect on the European marketplace, then the jurisdiction is within our territory," said Willy Helin, Mr. van Miert's spokesman. "We don't give a damn about extraterritoriality."
[On Tuesday, Mr. van Miert met with British officials and reiterated his hard line against the proposed marketing alliance between British Airways and American Airlines, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation. Mr. van Miert has complained that it would eliminate competition on many routes between the United States and Britain.]
It is in the Boeing and McDonnell Douglas case that Mr. van Miert is flexing his muscles for a showdown with both the United States aerospace industry and, very likely, the United States Government.
In numerous public comments, he has warned that the creation of an aerospace goliath would endanger competition in Europe, especially for Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium based in Paris that competes with Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. If Boeing fails to address his concerns, Mr. van Miert has threatened to block the deal or impose fines of up to 10 percent of Boeing's revenues, or about $4 billion.
For American companies, the case highlights the lengthening reach of the European Union as Europe acts increasingly as a single political entity. But experts say Mr. van Miert's higher profile is a result of the inevitable clashes that come with the rise in international trade.
Whether the United States tries to block European companies from doing business with Cuba or Iran, or Europe tries to enforce an internal ban on hormone-treated beef from American cattle farmers, international disputes over conflicting national policies are piling up. And there are few precedents for guidance.
"The whole issue of extraterritoriality is a vexing area, and it is one that is going to get worse," said Michael Hodges, senior lecturer in international relations at the London School of Economics. "Having dealt with many of the issues between borders, we are now looking at issues behind the borders."
The looming fight over Boeing could easily engulf the Clinton Administration. Although the Federal Trade Commission is not expected to decide the antitrust issues until next month, the United States Government has already approved several big mergers within the nation's shrinking military and aerospace industry. And Mr. van Miert has already attracted warning growls from Boeing's home-state senators and from Vice President Al Gore.
While Mr. van Miert has been quick to object, his bark is often worse than his bite. Indeed, most disputes that he initiates are eventually settled through negotiation and compromise rather than by taking companies to court. Of roughly 500 mergers that his office has reviewed, only 7 have been blocked outright.
Just this week, his office approved with only minor changes British Telecommunications' takeover of MCI Communications, the second-largest long-distance telephone carrier in the United States after AT&T. But two years ago, he pressed the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and Scott Paper to sell off some of their European businesses as a condition for approving their merger.
He has also provoked sputtering indignation from London to Bonn. He infuriated the British Government last fall when he first threatened to block the proposed alliance between British Airways and American Airlines. He also outraged German Government officials by challenging subsidies to Volkswagen in eastern Germany as well as state aid to areas in western Germany. And he has chastised the French Government for its billion-dollar bailouts of state-owned companies like Credit Lyonnais, the troubled bank.
In the Boeing and McDonnell Douglas case, European officials have made it clear that they do not expect to veto the proposed merger outright. Rather, they suggest, the goal is to get Boeing to address their worries about particular business practices.
The European Commission must make a final decision on the merger by late July. If it vetoed the deal, and the Federal Trade Commission approved it, the fight would probably shift to the World Trade Organization in Geneva.
Mr. van Miert seems to relish conflict. A tough-minded politician who once headed the Belgian Socialist Party, he has become one of the most powerful figures within the sprawling bureaucracy of the European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union. His attacks on a wide range of anti-competitive practices and on Europe's mountain of subsidies for industry have generally won praise as tough and honest. That is no small feat, since every country in the European Union has sacred cows that it wants to protect.
With a staff of more than 100 people, Mr. van Miert oversees a staggering volume of activity. His ministry reviews all major mergers that involve European companies as well as a few that do not. It also investigates allegations of price-fixing and a wide range of attempts to stifle competition, much like the United States Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission. (The Justice Department and the F.T.C. together employ an antitrust staff of more than 1,100 people.)
In theory, Mr. van Miert can make life miserable for those who refuse to obey his rulings. But as a practical matter, he follows the opposite of the dictim made famous by Theodore Roosevelt by talking loudly and carrying a small stick.
In Germany, for example, the Governor of the eastern state of Saxony was outraged that Mr. van Miert blocked a package of subsidies for Volkswagen to build a new automobile factory. Mr. van Miert said he had already approved big subsidies for Volkswagen and was drawing the line at more. The state of Saxony went ahead anyway and Mr. van Miert prepared to take the state to court. Over the next several months, however, the two sides worked out a compromise that reduced but did not eliminate the subsidies.
In the British Airways deal with American Airlines, Mr. van Miert argued that the two airlines would control a majority of the coveted landing slots for flights between the United States and Heathrow Airport in London. The British Government has been content to let the airlines sell off many of these slots in order to lessen their dominance, but Mr. van Miert contended that they should give the slots away and said he would take the British Government to court.
The fight has been hanging in limbo for several months and remains unresolved.
The Boeing case is likely to be much tougher. Boeing now sells more than 60 percent of the world's commercial airplanes, while Airbus has captured about a 30 percent share. McDonnell Douglas, which had about 20 percent of the market 10 years ago, is now a negligible player with only about 4 percent. Most of McDonnell Douglas's business is in military aircraft, an area where Boeing is relatively weak.
Mr. van Miert's focus has been on the commercial aircraft market. In particular, he has complained repeatedly about Boeing's two recent contracts to become the exclusive supplier of planes to American Airlines and Delta Air Lines for 20 years.
He said such contracts would be a grave threat to competition in general and Airbus in particular. "These agreements are totally unacceptable because they eliminate Airbus as a rival for at least the next 20 years," he said last week in Stockholm.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas executives argue that Mr. van Miert is merely protecting Airbus. The competition in commercial aircraft had already been reduced to Boeing and Airbus, and company executives argue that Boeing's acquisition of McDonnell's military business would not change the balance. They also defend their airline contracts, asserting that the contracts were awarded through open competition and that Airbus had itself signed an exclusive long-term contract with U S Airways in 1996.
"It's obvious he wants a war," Harry C. Stonecipher, the president and chief executive of McDonnell Douglas, said in Washington last week.
In Brussels, headquarters of the European Commission, Boeing officials have lined up numerous European attorneys and argue that Mr. van Miert has wandered out of bounds. "At least from the U.S. side, this looks like an extraterritorial attempt to impose European law," said Ray Waldman, Boeing's vice president for international business.
Mr. van Miert dismissed Boeing's warnings of a possible trade war as "totally nonsensical."
But the issue is reverberating in the United States. Members of Congress from Washington State sent Mr. van Miert a letter last week complaining that he had prejudged the issue and was trying to protect Airbus -- charges that Mr. van Miert vehemently denied.
Meanwhile, Vice President Gore fired a warning shot of his own. "We haven't been bashful about our advocacy of the rights of American businesses oveseas," Mr. Gore said earlier this month. "We will be watching the outcome of their deliberations extremely carefully, and we will take whatever action is appropriate to assure justice and fairness."

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks Squeeze Schools in Cleveland

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
The once-forsaken downtown boasts a glistening array of new office towers, hotels and sports stadiums. In the Flats, the industrial area where the brown bends of the Cuyahoga River once caught fire, the riverbanks are lined with bars and restaurants. Over all, the city's economic revival has transformed Cleveland from the Mistake on the Lake to the Comeback City.
But the city's school system is broke. 
 The Cleveland Teachers' Union sees a direct link between the downtown boom and the educational bust: the very same tax abatement policies that attracted new development to the city, they say, cost the schools $21 million a year.
Even through that represents only a small fraction of the district's budget, the teachers say the schools need every cent they can get. So, in what is apparently the first such campaign in the nation, the union has gathered enough signatures to force a special vote in August on a proposal to require that businesses winning abatements, or the city, reimburse the schools for any lost taxes.
Richard DeColibus, the union's president, said it was simply a matter of making sure that Cleveland schoolchildren did not bear the brunt of the city's development policy.
Chris Warren, the director of Cleveland's Department of Economic Development, agrees that abatements were given too freely in the past. And, he said, he would welcome a statewide ban. But a ban in Cleveland only, Mr. Warren said, would put the city at a terrible competitive disadvantage with its affluent surrounding towns, which he said would be only too happy to offer tax incentives to lure dozens of businesses out of Cleveland.
The union contends that the passage of the proposal would not hurt Cleveland, because it could still abate the portion of the property taxes that does not go to the schools.
With more local governments using tax incentives as a weapon in the escalating bidding wars for new investments, property tax abatements that siphon money from the schools have become controversial.
"The whole issue came to a head in the early 1990's, when the economy was bad, a lot of states were suffering and there was increasing competition for big-ticket projects," said Scott Mackey, of the National Conference of State Legislatures. "And in the last few years, we've begun hearing a lot about how school districts are the biggest recipients of property tax, but they don't usually have much say over abatements."
Only a handful of states allow school districts to veto abatements, Mr. Mackey said.
The debate over the long-term economic effects of tax abatements -- and who controls the decision to offer them -- has taken on new urgency as school systems hard-pressed for money look longingly at a revenue stream they see trickling away.
"Tax abatements are a two-edged sword," said Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, which represents the nation's largest urban school districts. "They can help to create and attract the jobs that cities desperately need to remain vital. But at the same time, they can strip schools of the revenues they need to educate young people to fill those jobs."
There are no reliable national statistics on how much money schools lose from tax abatements. But the Corporation for Enterprise Development, in Washington, estimates that state and local governments give up $5 billion to $8 billion in tax incentives a year -- most, but not all, of them property tax abatements. And nationally, schools receive almost half of all property tax revenues.
As abatements have proliferated and awareness of the revenue loss for schools has grown, there has been increasing concern that local governments may be giving away more than they should.
"This conversation about the impact of abatements on schools is brand new, even though it's a fairly old practice," Mr. Casserly said. "It has something to do with the evolving conversations between mayors and schools about each one's role in the other's vitality. But because there has not been adequate research on how the benefits and liabilities balance out, it can be a pretty uninformed conversation, with people just shouting at each other."
Those who think tax abatements are being abused -- that school revenue is being lost without helping the city very much -- say that most abatements go to large corporations, whose workers disproportionately live outside the city limits, rather than to the smaller businesses that employ more city residents.
"One thing that is clear, frankly, is that corporations need to understand how their rhetoric about wanting a well-educated citizenry and their demands for tax abatements are really at odds with one another," Mr. Casserly said. "If you're going to have an educated citizenry, you're going to have to pay for it."
Some large corporations and tax-exempt institutions do contribute to the schools, providing cash, internships or other forms of support. In Cleveland, for example, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum agreed to give the schools a share of its admission fees in lieu of property taxes. This year, the school's cut will be about $450,000, which is still less than it would have received if the Hall of Fame were taxed.
Some educators and legislators think abatements of property taxes that support the schools should be banned altogether. In Texas, for example, the Legislature is considering State Senator David Sibley's proposal to end school property tax abatements. The Senate's Economic Development Committee found that from 1985 to 1995, the state's school districts lost almost $480 million in local property tax revenue because of abatements.
Texas law already allows schools not to participate in abatements the local government proposes. But Senator Sibley and others say the pressure on school boards can be so great as to make it impossible for them to resist development projects that will cut into their budgets.
"School districts never really reap the benefits from new jobs or an expanded tax base created by companies that receive school property tax breaks," Senator Sibley said. "Unlike cities and counties which ultimately benefit financially, most school districts lose money which they never get back. Our children's future should not be traded for new jobs now."
Tax abatements, of course, are only the latest skirmish in the continuing battle over how to pay for schools -- and indeed, in some states, including New York, financing for schools is not directly affected by property tax abatements.
In recent years, courts in several states, including Ohio in March and New Jersey just last week, have struck down financing systems that depend heavily on local property tax, finding that the disparities between rich and poor districts' spending violate state constitutional guarantees of a proper education.
The Cleveland schools have been in disarray, and in serious financial straits, for years. In 1995, a Federal judge put the 70,000-student system under state control after it ran out of money halfway through the year. The system has an annual budget of $670 million, and is $155 million in debt -- far more than most districts its size and far more than any change in abatement policy could make up. Meanwhile, student achievement levels are dismal and school buildings are deteriorating.
"It's completely dysfunctional," said Michael Charney, a middle-school teacher in Cleveland who has been a leader in the campaign against tax abatements. "Last year, in my seventh-grade social studies class I had 32 kids and only 24 desks. And we only had one set of textbooks for the classroom, so kids couldn't take them home."
Against that backdrop, Mr. DeColibus said, the teachers' union decided it had no choice but to start a petition drive for a city charter amendment that would make sure that tax revenues earmarked for the schools would not go to businesses instead.
"Business has taken a 'let someone else pay for it' attitude toward any kind of support for public institutions," Mr. DeColibus said, "and schools are hurt the most by this total lack of fiscal morality since we rely more heavily on property taxes than other government institutions. I've come to understand that 'good business climate' is a euphemism for 'businesses don't have to pay the taxes the rest of us do.' "
Ohio has taken some steps to stem the loss of school revenue from abatements. In 1994, the state passed legislation giving school boards the right to veto abatements of more than 75 percent of the taxes that would otherwise be paid, or those that last more than 10 years. In addition, if the annual payroll of added employees of an exempted project exceeds $1 million, the city must share with the schools a portion of the income tax it receives. But, Mr. DeColibus said, those provisions have had little effect.
Mr. Warren, the Cleveland development official, said the new law has not been invoked often, because the city no longer offers abatements of more than 75 percent; 60 to 65 percent is now the average, he said. But, he said, there have been a few instances of income-tax sharing.
"We use abatements very sparingly now, only as a last resort option to assist neighborhood-based businesses, with a strict 'but-for' test showing that the proposed development would not go forward but for the abatement," Mr. Warren said. "It's also important to keep in mind that since we don't abate 100 percent, or even 75 percent any more, we're collecting extra taxes from the development that does go forward, even with the abatements."
Mr. Warren sees the abatement vote largely as a political maneuver, an expression of the teachers' frustration. But he also said he thought the teachers were wrong to make the abatement issue a local one.
"We've told the teachers they should be working on a state level," Mr. Warren said. "If there's a ban on tax abatement just in Cleveland, there will be dozens of companies that will pick up and move over to Solon, where they'll be made very welcome. We'll have abandoned properties and that won't do anyone any good. Abatements are a legitimate concern, but this isn't the answer."

HEADLINE: More Than 50 Journalists Are Fellowship Recipients

BYLINE: By TONY MARCANO 

 BODY:
More than 50 journalists from around the world will take time off from their jobs as reporters, editors, photographers and producers starting this fall for an academic year of study in fellowships offered by five universities.
The fellowships are the Knight-Bagehot Fellowships in Economics and Business Journalism at Columbia University, the Nieman Fellowships at Harvard, the Knight Science Journalism Fellowships at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the John S. Knight Journalism Fellowships at Stanford University and the University of Michigan Journalism Fellows. 
 The sabbaticals offer a range of study options for individual programs or study in groups.
 
Columbia University

HEADLINE: Another Ranking Executive At Apple Decides to Resign

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20

 BODY:
In the latest senior management departure from struggling Apple Computer Inc., George Scalise, the company's executive vice president for operations, resigned today to become president of the Semiconductor Industry Association. He will leave Apple at the end of the month.
Mr. Scalise, 63, had followed Gilbert F. Amelio, Apple's chairman and chief executive, to the company from the National Semiconductor Corporation and had earlier in his career held executive positions at Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Fairchild Semiconductor and Motorola. Mr. Scalise had also previously worked for the Semiconductor Industry Association, the chip industry's trade organization, as chairman of its public policy committee. 
 The powers and responsibilities of Mr. Amelio's chosen executives have weakened since Apple's $400 million acquisition of Next Software Inc. returned Steven P. Jobs to the company he helped found, analysts noted. Ellen Hancock, who last year joined Apple as chief technology officer, also from National Semiconductor, had her oversight of both hardware and software development management turned over to former Next executives.
"The influence of Steve Jobs has been much greater than anyone anticipated," said Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies. "But any brain drain right now, especially someone so close to Gil, has to be considered a loss."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Scalise said his departure had nothing to do with Mr. Jobs's influence but instead reflected the completion of much of what he was brought on board to accomplish. "I think a lot of what I was focused on, and what was in my area of responsibility, has been done now," he said. "The idea was to focus on getting Apple on track operationally. Now, we're satisfying demand, and we're able to bring out leading edge products on schedule."
Mr. Scalise said that Apple did not plan to replace him but that Mr. Amelio would redistribute some of his responsibilities. "We now have the team in place that can execute on the game plan," he said. "With that done, a lot of the challenge that was mine is taken care of."
For its second quarter, ended March 28, Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a loss of $708 million, compared with a loss of $740 million in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Fed Inaction Sends Dollar Down but Spurs Stock Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday not to raise short-term interest rates knocked the dollar sharply lower and provided only a little relief for the bond market. But the Fed's inaction spurred the stock market, which continues to show an exuberance that may again worry Fed officials.
The dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen and the mark after the central bank announced at 2:15 P.M. that it would leave its target for the Federal funds rate at 5.50 percent. 
 The dollar's decline restrained the rally in the bond market, analysts said, as traders and investors feared a round of selling by foreign investors because a weaker dollar was eating into their profits or enlarging their losses. The price of the 30-year bond jumped 13/32, to 96 24/32, just after the Fed announcement before retreating to finish the day up 7/32 at 96 18/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.90 percent from 6.92 percent on Monday.
In the stock market, technology, bank and financial stocks benefited the most, leading the Dow Jones industrial average up 74.58 points, or 1.03 percent, to 7,303.46. The Dow was down as much as 76 points earlier in the day but jumped nearly 100 points to within 30 points of its record close after the report of the Fed's decision.
The Standard and Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 8.39 points, or 1 percent, to 841.66, less than a half a point below its record close. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite fared even better, rising 22.64 points, or 1.69 percent, to 1,363.88.
While the slumping dollar held back the bond market yesterday, it appeared to help stocks by improving the prospects of many exporters, whose products become more competitive abroad. For example, earnings of I.B.M. -- which led the Dow higher yesterday, surging 5, to 173 3/4 -- could get a lift after its first-quarter profits were held back by the surge of the dollar earlier in the year.
"Bullish spirits remain high," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in San Francisco. "The fear of missing a rise is much greater than the concern about participating in a painful tumble.
"And when you get a sense of relief, technology tends to be a lead group," he added. "That's where a lot of the excitement has been."
Analysts were split pretty evenly over whether the Fed would act yesterday, and their forecasting of the performance of the economy in the months ahead and how the Fed will react will be just as difficult. But it seems fairly clear that the inaction of the Fed has set financial markets up for six weeks of uncertainty -- and volatile trading -- until the next Fed policy meeting July 2 and 3.
Unless economic data for May confirm the slowdown implied in April's data, the chances of a Fed rate increase this summer will be even greater than they were yesterday.
"The market will be in the same spot on July 2 as it is now -- waiting for the Fed to act," said Joseph Liro, the chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities. And the odds of a rate increase, he said, "will change with each new economic report and that will make for choppier trading."
Some stock analysts warned that while the market could climb in the near term, the threat of higher interest rates is still there and means something, given the almost 10 percent plunge in the Dow after the Fed raised interest rates in March.
"There is so little evidence that inflation was looming that they felt that their credibility would have been damaged" by raising rates now, explained Byron Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. But, he added, "the Fed not tightening is not conclusive proof that things are going to remain good."
Yesterday's decline in the dollar accelerated a slump that began on May 2 and that has left the American currency 10.8 percent lower against the yen and 2.7 percent lower against the mark. The dollar's decline this month was started by comments from Japanese finance officials who said the dollar had risen too far and implied that the Government might intervene in markets to bolster the Japanese currency.
That step has not been necessary because traders have been spooked by the comments and hints that the Japanese central bank might raise interest rates soon. It was a new round of such hints that sent the dollar lower in overseas trading early Tuesday. The decision by the Fed not to raise interest rates, which could have supported the dollar by making it a more attractive investment, adds to the near-term woeful outlook for the American currency.
"For right now the dollar is going to be under some pressure," said David Puth, the head of foreign exchange and derivatives in North America at Chase Manhattan Bank. He said that while there was still reason to expect the Fed to raise interest rates in July, the fact that such a move is not certain will be a dollar "negative."
In late trading in New York, the dollar fared the worst against the mark and other European currencies, falling even lower after the Fed's decision than it did in Asian and in early European trading. Against the mark the dollar was at 1.6823, down 1.5 percent from Monday.
Against the yen, the dollar finished at 113.04, down 2.3 percent on the day, but above the intra-day low of nearly 112 hit in overnight trading.
Other advancing stocks yesterday included J.P. Morgan, up 2 3/4, to 105 1/4; American Express, increasing 2 1/8, to 70 3/4; Intel, up 6 1/4, to 161; General Electric, rising 1 1/2, to 62 1/2, and Microsoft, up 4, to 119 1/8.

HEADLINE: Nafta Environmental Lags May Delay Free Trade Expansion

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
During his recent Latin American trip, President Clinton enthusiastically promised to extend free trade throughout the hemisphere. But a delay in an environmental study on the effect of the increased trade that has already taken place is weakening support he will need to get wider trade agreements approved in Congress.
Environmentalists in the United States, Canada and Mexico fear that the delays signal a lack of commitment by the Governments of those countries to monitor the environmental effects of free trade. Such monitoring was a tenet of the side agreements that helped get the North American Free Trade Agreement approved when it was stalled in the United States Congress in 1993. 
 "What this shows is that the side agreements really haven't delivered on commitments made by the Clinton Administration in 1993," said Dan Seligman, an official responsible for trade issues with the Sierra Club in Washington.
The organization originally opposed the passage of Nafta, but the support of other environmental groups was crucial to winning the accord's approval and the Sierra Club ultimately dropped its opposition. Mr. Seligman said the Government's weak support for the environmental agreements makes it unlikely that environmental groups could support expansion of the agreement.
President Clinton has said he will seek Congressional authority to negotiate agreements with Chile and other Latin American nations, but he has not made a commitment to include environmental accords.
"If the commission can't get the countries to study the environmental impacts of increased trade that's already taken place, how can they ever get them to do anything real about improving environmental standards, which is what they promised in 1993," Mr. Seligman said.
The environmental study is a comparatively small part of a comprehensive review of the trade pact and its effects on the United States economy, which by law must be completed this year. President Clinton must report to Congress by July.
Three areas were selected for examination: energy use, cattle raising and, in Mexico, raising corn -- the country's primary agricultural crop.
The study was considered an important milestone because the work was to be done independently of the three Governments. An advisory panel made up mostly of experts and representatives of citizens' groups was supposed to oversee the project.
The $150,000 to finance the study this year is included in the $9 million annual budget of the Commission for Environmental Cooperation, the organization set up in Montreal to oversee the environmental aspects of Nafta. But while the money has been in the budget since last fall, the three Governments have not given approval for the work to proceed. Trade officials from the United States have raised concerns about the study, but the Mexican Government has most forcefully objected, several people familiar with the negotiations say.
"The trade people in Mexico were nervous about letting any part of the Nafta process out from under their direct and total control," said Daniel C. Esty, now director of the Yale University Center for Environmental Law and Policy, who was the chief negotiator for the Environmental Protection Agency on Nafta.
Mexican officials agreed that the study teams should be independent, but they wanted so much input and oversight that it would have amounted to the ability to censor the reports, an American official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official said there appeared to be a split between Mexico's Environmental Ministry and the Trade Ministry.
Mario Aguilar, an Environmental Ministry official at the Mexican Embassy in Washington, denied that there was any split in his Government's position. He confirmed that Mexico has objected to the way the study was designed, he rejected any suggestion that there had been an attempt to censor the findings.
"We have doubts about the way the three sectors were chosen," Mr. Aguilar said. "We want the work to have a scientific base, not to deal with politics and opinion."
A member of the group advising the environmental analysis said the three areas were selected after a thorough review of the free trade agreement's first years of operation. "Case studies were needed," said Richard Kamp, director of the Border Ecology Project in Bisbee, Ariz., "to show how investments have taken place and how they have affected society."
The study on corn is considered the most potentially damaging to Mexico, since it deals with the most important staple of nearly every Mexican's diet.
Before Nafta was passed, it was widely predicted that eliminating tariffs over a 15-year period would flood Mexico with imported corn, causing great disruptions as poor farmers gave up their fields and moved to Mexico's cities or across the border.
But the early drafts of the corn study show that while corn imports indeed have already surpassed the 15-year projections, there has been no widespread dislocation.
Alejandro Nadal, a professor of economics at the Colegio de Mexico in Mexico City who is conducting the corn study, said he knows why the Mexican Government is worried about the results.
"They want Nafta to work out fine," he said. "But if they start fiddling around with the commission's work, we are going to have problems."
