HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Allowing Rates To Hold Steady

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy was slowing sufficiently to avert a resurgence of inflation.
The central bank's policy-making body had increased the key short-term rate it controls by a quarter point, to 5.50 percent, at its last meeting two months ago, saying that strong growth and low unemployment were creating the conditions that could push wages and prices higher and endanger the economy's expansion. 
 In passing up the chance today to raise rates again, it heeded, at least for now, warnings from some economists that a further increase would have little economic justification or political support because there is almost no sign that inflation is taking root.
The decision heartened investors, who sent stock prices surging. After falling early in the day, the Dow Jones industrial average rallied after the Federal Reserve's announcement in the early afternoon, closing at 7,303.46, up 74.58 points. Bond prices rose moderately, and the dollar -- which would have become a more attractive investment if interest rates were higher in this country -- fell. [Page D1.]
Analysts said that the Federal Reserve might still feel compelled to raise rates again this year, perhaps at its next policy meeting in July. They said the decision today was driven by clear evidence that economic growth had moderated substantially from the 5.6 percent rate of the first quarter, as well as by reports showing that inflation was almost nonexistent at the producer level and subdued at the consumer level.
Some economists also saw today's decision as evidence of an increased willingness on the part of the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to be open to the possibility that the economy could grow without igniting inflation. The alternative to such a decision is to fall back reflexively on the convention that growth rates that are more than about 2.25 percent when unemployment is less than 5 percent will inevitably lead to sharp increases in wages and prices.
"There's an experiment going on here, and the Fed is letting growth roll," said Allen Sinai, an economist at Primark Decision Economics, a consulting firm.
Mr. Sinai and others said economists were being forced to re-examine their old rules of thumb about growth and inflation because of an array of changes that are reshaping the economy. Huge investments by businesses in new technology appear to have bolstered productivity in ways that official statistics do not capture. Instead of passing cost increases along to consumers, companies increasingly try to wring them out of their own production processes. Workers are more willing to accept modest pay raises, or to tie their compensation to performance or efficiency. The globalization of commerce has intensified competition in many industries.
"So much has changed in our economy that it would be a mistake to assume the old rules apply," Mr. Sinai said. "What Greenspan has shown us again and again in his tenure is the ability to understand how the world does change and still keep his eye on the ball of price-level stability."
Today's meeting of the Fed's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, came against a backdrop of vociferous opposition to further rate increases from across the political spectrum and from both the business community and organized labor. Opponents argued that in raising rates in March to slow demand by making borrowing more expensive, Mr. Greenspan had gone too far with his policy of eradicating inflationary pressures before they took root. The rate increase caused a sharp selloff in the stock market, which has recovered since then.
While Mr. Greenspan's willingness to hold off on further rate increases no doubt has its limits, today's decision was applauded by many of the groups that had criticized the rate increase in March.
"From living rooms to board rooms, anyone concerned with economic growth and continued high employment can breathe easier," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "The Fed recognized that there is no need to fix an unbroken economy."
In holding rates steady today, the Federal Reserve was clearly betting on a repeat of the events in the economy last year: a period of unusually strong growth followed by a slowdown that bled off any mounting inflationary pressure, averting the need for action.
Still, the risks in the strategy are substantial. The economy grew 3.8 percent in the last quarter of 1996, and then by 5.6 percent in the first three months of this year. With unemployment at 4.9 percent in April, traditional economic forecasts predicted that employers would begin bidding up wages to attract the workers needed to keep increasing their output, and that wage increases would feed through to consumers in the form of higher prices.
At its meeting in March, the Fed decided that the risks of accelerating inflation were sufficient to justify a small step to cool down the economy. It therefore raised the target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans -- to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent.
As Mr. Greenspan put it in a speech this month defending the move, "The risk to the economy from inaction came to outweigh the risk from action."
But since then nearly all the economic evidence has suggested that inflation remains well contained, that the consumer spending binge that drove growth earlier in the year has cooled off and that companies have built big inventories that they must sell before placing new orders -- all factors suggesting that the economy is not overheating.
At a minimum, the Federal Reserve decided today that it could afford to wait at least until its July meeting to get a clearer indication of whether the economy was slowing sufficiently on its own to eliminate the inflation threat, analysts said.
"The real question is what the incoming information will look like over the next six weeks," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities.
Analysts said the decision today may also have been influenced by the agreement between the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership in Congress on a plan to eliminate the Federal budget deficit. Mr. Greenspan has pushed hard for deficit reduction, saying a credible plan to balance the budget would help bring down interest rates. To raise rates immediately after a bipartisan budget agreement could have undermined the considerable respect Mr. Greenspan enjoys on Capitol Hill, they said.
"Mr. Greenspan has proven himself very adept over the years in sensing which way the political wind is blowing, and apparently he decided that the Fed needed more ammunition before tightening again," economists at First Union Capital Markets said in a report today.

HEADLINE: House Democratic Leader Opposes Clinton's Budget Deal

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, broke with the White House today and said he would oppose the budget deal between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans.
"I do this as a matter of principle," Mr. Gephardt said this afternoon as the House opened debate on its budget resolution. "This is a budget of many deficits: a deficit of principle, a deficit of fairness, a deficit of tax justice, and, worst of all, a deficit of dollars." 
 While significant, Mr. Gephardt's opposition is unlikely to block passage of the budget deal that Mr. Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, signed off on last week.
His decision may influence some of his rank-and-file members, but a majority of Republicans and Democrats in both chambers support the five-year plan, which would balance the Federal budget, offer some of the largest tax breaks in decades and provide billions of dollars for education, social and health programs.
Mr. Gephardt, of St. Louis, is widely expected to challenge Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000, and his announcement drew a sharp distinction between the two.
In the coming weeks, Mr. Gephardt may wind up on the opposite side of the Clinton-Gore team on several major issues, including extending most-favored-nation trade status to China for another year, which the Administration supports.
Mr. Gephardt has also expressed reservations about giving the White House the "fast track" negotiating authority it wants for a trade agreement with Chile. But the Democratic leader tried to quash the notion that his political positions were influenced by the Presidential race.
"This is not politics, this is not about some election, this is about the future of this country and what is best for it," he said.
Likewise, neither Mr. Gore nor the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, would be drawn into talk about Presidential politics.
"Let's not run the 2000 campaign in 1997," Mr. McCurry told reporters.
And Mr. Gore limited his comments to defense of the budget, saying, "It is a well-reasoned approach, and I think that it is a good approach."
Both the House of Representatives and the Senate began debate today on their budget resolutions, the first legislative step in the budget process and the outline for specific changes to come later.
Mr. Gephardt was the only one of the top four leaders on Capitol Hill to criticize the deal when it was announced last week. From the outset, he has been one of the harshest critics of the tax cuts in the plan, which he says favor the well-to-do.
Before declaring his opposition on the House floor this afternoon, Mr. Gephardt informed the President of his position in a meeting at the White House and met privately with House Democrats for about 90 minutes to argue his case.
His decision placed him on the opposing, and likely losing, side of the most prominent piece of legislation that will be debated this year. But the arguments he made resonate with a majority of Democratic primary voters and with organized labor groups that are the base of his national following.
"I think he has positioned himself excellently to command the liberal base of the Democratic Party in the primaries," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, who added that he was "not the least bit worried" that Mr. Gephardt had the clout or support to torpedo the deal.
The package includes $115 billion in savings to the Medicare program and $85 billion worth of tax cuts, including a $500 per child tax credit, broad-based, permanent cuts in the capital gains tax, reductions in the inheritance tax and an expansion of Individual Retirement Accounts.
The proposal also provides $35 billion over five years for post-secondary education, including a deduction and a tax credit, all items that the Administration had demanded.
Republican House leaders had expected a vote on the budget resolution tonight, but that timetable fell apart after the chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania, introduced an amendment that the leaders said would wreck the entire budget deal.
The amendment -- co-sponsored by Representative James L. Oberstar, the senior Democrat on the transportation committee -- would increase spending for Federal highway and mass transit programs by $11.6 billion.
The sponsors proposed offsetting the spending through across-the-board reductions of 0.4 percent in tax cuts and spending. Programs like Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, with mandatory spending, would be exempted from the proposed cuts.
As the idea gained support throughout the day, Republican leaders hastily convened a late night meeting of their rank-and-file to try to quash the amendment and White House negotiators rushed to Capitol Hill to lobby Democrats.
The loudest clamor against the budget has come from hard-line conservatives in the Republican Party and the more liberal wing of the Democratic Party.
Representative Ernest Istook, a Republican from Oklahoma, laid out most of the conservatives' complaints in a letter today to Mr. Gingrich. Mr. Istook criticized the agreement as "a high-risk plan, feasible only if future economic conditions are ideal."
He also complained that the plan would spend too much money, expands entitlement programs, open-ended commitments that finance all who qualify, and fails to provide all of the tax relief being promoted. He urged Speaker Gingrich to reopen negotiations.
"I believe this plan focuses on solving the problems of today's politicians, when it should focus on solving the problems that threaten America's future, to preserve our children's heritage and opportunity," Mr. Istook wrote.
Mr. Gephardt that the assertion that the plan would balance the Federal budget by 2000 was based on "dubious assumptions."
And while stopping well short of criticizing the Administration directly, he said the budget fell short of many of the other goals that its backers assert it will achieve.
While Mr. Clinton has touted a provision that makes $16 billion available to children who lack health insurance, for instance, Mr. Gephardt said the "positive effect" of that program was offset by cuts in Medicaid funding to children's hospitals.
"This compromise gives to children with one hand and takes away with the other," he said.

HEADLINE: PLAN TO PAY OFF U.N. DUES STALLS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's proposal to pay $1 billion in dues owed to the United Nations has run aground in Congress. Republicans are insisting on paying only some of the debt, over a longer stretch of time and only after the United Nations agrees to a series of demands.
Proposals circulating in the House and the Senate would require everything from permanently reducing Washington's annual dues, while raising China's, to slashing the expense accounts of ranking officials. 
 Under the proposals, which have the backing of the Republican leadership in both houses, the United Nations would also have to reimburse the cost of American military equipment and support for peacekeeping operations, to impose still more budget restraints and even to allow the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to check the organization's books.
While the billion-dollar battle raged in Washington, in New York, the American delegate to the United Nations discussed the diplomatic immunity as applied to traffic tickets, an issue that has rankled New Yorkers. [Page A8.]
If Republicans have their way, Washington will pay the back dues -- the total is being debated -- over as many as five years instead of the two years that the Administration proposed. And the President would have to certify that the United Nations had met the conditions. "It's not going to be a payment up front with good intentions in the back," said Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota, a Republican who has been involved in drafting the proposals. "We have to say it loud and clear: the arrears will be paid only when the reforms are made."
The Administration, in quiet negotiations with Republican leaders, has opposed many of the conditions. And while it has agreed in principle to others -- including a reduction in the United States' yearly dues for general expenses and peacekeeping operations -- it has opposed writing them into law.
To do so, officials argue, would leave the State Department little flexibility in negotiations with the United Nations over changes in the organization's budget or bureaucracy. "It is a level of micromanagement by statute that is unprecedented," a senior Administration official said today.
At the United Nations, the proposals are encountering heated criticism from diplomats who have grown increasingly resentful that the United States will not come up with dues that it is bound by treaty to pay, even as it issues new dictates.
"We feel quite frankly that it is preposterous to put any conditions to the repayment of arrears, which the United States should pay under international law," said Nicolaas H. Biegman, the representative of the Netherlands at the United Nations. "It's as simple as that."
The wrangling between the Administration and the Republicans over how to pay the dues comes only months after the new Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, swept through Washington, promising to impose reforms and receiving pledges that the United States would finally pay up.
At the time, the election of Mr. Annan, a direct result of the United States campaign to oust his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, appeared to brighten the prospects for payment of the dues, most of which date back to 1994.
But the United Nations remains a target of many Republicans on Capitol Hill despite the Administration's newly vigorous campaign, led by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, to persuade Congress to pay the dues.
There is even a bill before the House that would bar any payment, based on the argument that the United States should have been credited for all of its contributions of military materiel to peacekeeping efforts. That legislation, introduced by Representative Roscoe G. Bartlett of Maryland and sponsored by more than 60 others, has little chance of passing, but it underscores the difficulty of winning support for paying the dues.
The Republican proposals are included in a series of bills with similar, though not identical, conditions on paying the dues, including one introduced by Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York, the chairman of the House International Relations Committee, and another by Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine.
The staff of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is also drafting a series of demands. Senator Helms's demands carry added significance, since he has insisted, an aide said, on attaching them to the legislation authorizing the State Department's entire budget, as well as to President Clinton's proposal to reorganize the department and the other foreign affairs agencies.
Mr. Helms's proposals -- a draft of which was obtained by The New York Times and confirmed by Senate aides -- would pay the dues in installments over five years and set specific conditions or "benchmarks" for the United Nations to meet each year.
In the first year, for example, the organization would have to agree to erase all outstanding debt owed by the United States. That is sure to be controversial, since the organization argues that the United States owes far more than the $1 billion that the Clinton Administration recognizes.
By the second year, the United Nations would have to cap United States dues at 20 percent of the general operating budget, compared with 25 percent now, and at 25 percent of the peacekeeping budget, compared with more than 30 percent now.
By the end of the five years, the United Nations would have to accept increased auditing, start setting expiration dates on programs, consolidate the myriad environmental and development organizations and eliminate those dealing with regional economic and social affairs.
The proposal would also require the affiliated international organizations, like the World Health Organization, to reduce their budgets.
If the United Nations failed to enact any of the changes, the United States would simply not pay that year's installment.
The Administration has held a series of negotiations with Republicans in the House and Senate to try to work out an agreement on the language of the demands.
Princeton N. Lyman, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said the Administration hoped to reach an accord with Congress that included "a set of benchmarks that are achievable," though some of those proposed by the Republicans were clearly not.
Another senior Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Administration could not accept repaying the dues over five years or cementing reforms of an international body into American law, which would have the effect of making them appear to be ultimatums.
"To lock it in will only cause other countries to refuse to negotiate," the official said.
But Senator Judd Gregg, the New Hampshire Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that oversees United Nations issues, said Congress had an obligation to set rigorous conditions, since the United States paid the largest share of the organization's budget.
"Since we're carrying the load," he said, "we have some right to demand that the tax dollars be spent in an appropriate way."

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Need for Jewish Housing Is Questioned by U.S.
American diplomats have found high vacancy rates in Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, casting doubt on the Israeli Government's claim that it is expanding the settlements to accommodate natural growth. Such expansions have angered the Palestinians and hindered peace efforts. A1 

G.O.P. Fights U.N. Dues
Republicans in Congress have skewered the Clinton Administration's proposal to pay $1 billion in dues the United States owes the United Nations. They demand that the United States' annual dues be permanently reduced while increasing those of China. A1
 
United Nations diplomats in New York City said they faced growing hostility since the uproar over their parking tickets. A8
 
Kabila Arrives in Kinshasa
Unannounced and discreetly, Laurent Kabila, Congo's new President, arrived in Kinshasa to take over the capital. But he did not announce the composition of his Government, which had been expected. A3
 
Support for Organ Donors
The top religious authority in Egypt reversed the prevailing interpretation of Islamic rules by saying that he was willing to donate his organs when he died. But conservative Muslims scoffed that the cleric, Mohammed Sayed Tantawi, had been appointed as Grand Sheik of Al Azhar, the center of learning in Sunni Islam, by the secular Government to do its bidding. A6
 
Scandal Surfaces in Brazil
The Government of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil has been accused of paying five Congressmen nearly a million dollars to vote for a constitutional amendment that would allow a President to run for re-election. A daily newspaper published what it said were transcripts of secret tape recordings in which two Congressmen discussed receiving payoffs. A9
 
Qaddafi Gets Mild Rebuke
The United Nations Security Council mildly rebuked Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for violating an international flight ban against his country. In a statement, the council said it "takes note with concern" reports that the Libyan leader had flown to Niger and Nigeria earlier this month. (Reuters)
 
Taliban Makes Advance
Local residents said three provinces in Afghanistan had fallen to the Taliban, an Islamic militant group that has imposed strict rules on the two-thirds of the country it already controls. The loss of the three northwestern provinces of Badghis, Faryab and Sar-e-Paul seriously threatened the anti-Taliban alliance led by Gen. Rashid Dostum, and aid workers said heavy fighting was only four miles from his stronghold in Mazar-e-Sharif. (AP)

Senate Votes to Prohibit Method for Late Abortions
The Senate voted to ban a late-term abortion procedure, but the bill's supporters fell three votes short of the number needed to override the veto expected from President Clinton. While the vote may mark only incremental progress for abortion opponents, they gained some ground in the larger abortion debate. A1
 
Birdlike Dinosaur Is Found
A team of Argentine paleontologists reported finding what appears to be the most birdlike dinosaur ever found. Its anatomy appears to be intermediate between dinosaurs and Archaeopteryx, the earliest known bird. The new fossil animal has been named Unenlagia comahuensis, which means "half bird from northwest Patagonia" in the language of the Mapuche Indians of the region. A18

Republican senators attacked a children's health insurance bill proposed by Senators Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. The Environmental Protection Agency wants to force paper mills to make big reductions in their emissions of dioxins and other toxic chemicals into the water and air, at an estimated cost of $1.4 billion. The proposed rules, which are expected to be sent to the White House for final review this week, are already being denounced by some environmental groups. A21

Burmeister, said he was confident that the evidence against Mr. McVeigh had not been contaminated, even though some evidence could have been handled better. A10

Appeals Court Tells Judges To Make Juries Follow Law
The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled in Manhattan that judges had a duty to insure that jurors did not ignore the law and impose their own values to acquit or convict a defendant. The decision comes at a time when the legal community is embroiled in a continuing debate over race and the justice system, and whether it is ever appropriate for jurors to acquit a defendant as a protest against a perceived lack of fairness in the justice system, which is called "jury nullification." Thousands of tenants converged on the state Capitol to show support for extending New York's rent regulations. The crowd was the largest seen in Albany since State University students protested tuition increases two years ago. B1

Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee approved legislation that would allow Broome County to eliminate its sales tax on clothing, even though they are resisting a similar proposal from Mayor Giuliani for New York City. Republican leaders in the Senate had maintained that they did not want localities to lower their sales taxes on clothing in a haphazard fashion and preferred to give all places the chance to scale back these levies at the same pace. HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Unchanged

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
New York City's high unemployment rate did not budge in April, remaining stuck at 9.7 percent, even as a booming national economy pushed down unemployment rates to low levels elsewhere around the country. The state's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate of 6.3 percent was also unchanged.
Nationally, only 4.9 percent of Americans were unemployed in April, the lowest level in 23 years. The gap between New York City's jobless rate and that of the rest of the nation -- 4.8 percentage points in April -- is now the largest it has been in at least 19 years, according the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. The previous record gap, of 4.5 percentage points, was set in March 1997. 
 The New York State Labor Department said that on a snapshot month-to-month basis, not adjusted for seasonal variations, the picture looked better for both the city and the state. Statewide the number of service jobs, construction, and retail and wholesale trade jobs all rose, while banks and insurance companies reduced their job totals.
New Jersey reported last week that its seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for April dropped to 5.2 percent from 5.5 percent in March. Connecticut has not reported its April rate yet, but its unemployment rate in March stood at 4.9 percent. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: On Campus;
Aid Lags, Indian Colleges Say

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Leaders of the United States' Indian-run colleges say Federal support has failed to keep up with rising enrollments that are likely to swell further as an overhaul in welfare programs drives more American Indians to seek job training.
The leaders hoped that a new report on tribal colleges being released today would again call attention to their role in moving Indians out of poverty and into higher education. 
 The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching said the tribal colleges, mostly two-year institutions, excelled at job training, business creation and community building even though money and buildings were scarce.
"Despite overwhelming obstacles, America's tribal colleges are educating thousands of our people, providing them with perhaps their only chance of economic self-sufficiency," said Janine Pease-Pretty On Top, president of Little Big Horn College in Crow Agency, Mont.
Total enrollment in tribal colleges nationally has shot up to more than 24,000 in 1996 from about 10,000 in 1989. Yearly Federal support for the institutions has remained at about $27 million since 1995, although President Clinton wants to raise that amount by $3 million in 1998.
The amount of support, about $2,890 per full-time student, is less than the $5,820 authorized in the Tribally Controlled Community College Assistance Act of 1978.
Robert Lorence, president of Northwest Indian College on the Lummi Reservation outside Bellingham, Wash., said the Indian institutions often served as bridges to four-year colleges.
Mr. Lorence said that his 650-student college struggled largely with teaching basic reading, math, and writing, and that the demand on basic training would rise.
"I'm assuming welfare reform will include some additional funds for training," Mr. Lorence said, "but I haven't seen where that is or how it will come from the colleges."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Keeps Rates Steady Amid Few Signs of Inflation
The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy was slowing sufficiently to avert a resurgence of inflation. 
 The Fed appeared to heed warnings that an increase -- on top of the one in March -- would have had little economic justification or political support because there were few signs of rising prices. [Page A1.]
 
Tyco to Acquire Keystone
Tyco International Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire Keystone International Inc. in a deal valued at $1.2 billion. Under the deal, Keystone, a manufacturer of industrial valves, will be merged into a subsidiary of Tyco, a diversified manufacturer of industrial and commercial products. [D2.]
 
Dell Earnings Above Forecasts
Dell Computer's earnings sharply exceeded analysts' estimates, as its sales growth outpaced that of other personal computer makers. Dell also announced a 2-for-1 stock split, its fourth in the last five years. [D2.]
 
Galileo Ticket System Plans Deal
The Galileo travel reservations system said that it planned to buy Apollo Travel Services, which now operates as Galileo's marketing arm, for $700 million. [D12.]
 
Toy Biz Cancels Marvel Plan
Toy Biz canceled its agreement to combine with some units of Marvel Entertainment as part of the comic book publisher's bankruptcy reorganization plan. [D4.]
 
Tokyo Bank Is Raided
The investigation into the scandal at the Nomura Securities Company widened as prosecutors searched the offices of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. [D3.]
 
Another Official Leaves Apple
George Scalise, Apple Computer's executive vice president for operations, resigned to become president of the Semiconductor Industry Association. A number of Apple executives' responsibilities have weakened since the company bought Next Software. [D2.]
 
AT&T in Deal to Add Local Service
AT&T reached a deal with Nynex to connect the companies' networks in New York State, paving the way for AT&T to enter the most lucrative local phone market. [B6.]
 
10 Charged in Argentina Scandal
An Argentine judge indicted 10 people -- and ordered 5 arrested -- on charges of bribery in connection with a scandal over an I.B.M. unit's contract with a state-owned bank. [D12.]
 
Singapore Called Most Competitive
Singapore again ranks first among the 53 countries rated in a closely watched study of their economic potential. [D3.]
 
Profits Too Good to Keep?
Insiders at Xircom, a technology concern, showed great timing when they sold shares high and bought low. But S.E.C. rules may force them to give up some or all of their profits. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D12.]
 
New Emissions Rules for Paper Mills
The E.P.A. has recommended new rules that will require paper mills to reduce greatly their emissions of dioxins and other toxic chemicals into the water and air. [A21.]
 
Oversight Proposal for I.R.S.
The Clinton Administration proposed creating a special board to oversee efforts to reform the I.R.S., whose multibillion-dollar modernization plan has been mired in problems. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Bridging a Gap In the Resume;
When H.I.V. Loosens Grip, It's Back to the Job Market

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
A year and a half ago, a 49-year-old man named Robert was planning his funeral instead of his future. His skin had become infected with festering pimples that refused to heal. His weight had dropped precipitously. He found it physically draining to visit old friends who were also dying of AIDS, fading like wilted flowers. He thought of death constantly.
But earlier this month, there he was, robust and tan in a blue T-shirt and khakis, pondering three job offers and attending a new evening seminar on H.I.V. in the workplace, sponsored by the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's largest AIDS service agency. 
 In a stark white conference room typically used by social workers to help H.I.V.-infected people arrange a safety net of benefits for their death, he was feeling the wonderment of contemplating a return to work after two years on disability.
Powerful new AIDS drugs called protease inhibitors have reduced the lethal virus in his blood to undetectable levels. Now Robert, who used to earn $70,000 a year in real estate and architectural design, hopes to have a new job by the end of May.
"It's like being resurrected," said Robert, who spoke on the condition that he not be fully identified because he feared prospective employers had misperceptions about AIDS. "I feel like a child."
Medical breakthroughs have left G.M.H.C. and other AIDS service agencies across the country suddenly grappling with fragile hope.
Even as they continue to assist ailing clients who do not have access to the life-prolonging treatments or have failed to benefit by them, the agencies are quietly reinventing themselves in concrete and practical ways to keep pace with thousands of people like Robert. For the first time since the beginning of the epidemic 16 years ago, the agencies are creating new classes, like how to deal with renewed health, and shifting the focus of others from finding a funeral home to finding a paycheck.
At G.M.H.C. in Chelsea, workplace issues have dominated the discussion in seminars and workshops in recent months. New classes deal with subjects like the rights of employees with H.I.V. and how to return to the workplace.
"That's all that everybody is talking about," said Lillie Mikesell, a G.M.H.C. spokeswoman. "It's all just exploded."
In San Francisco, AIDS Benefits Counselors, which used to be in the business of preparing clients for disability and death, now manages an employment service and has seen demand for job skills and placement workshops nearly triple since January.
In Atlanta, AID Atlanta, a nonprofit service agency, has conducted a series of free public forums since November to help clients with AIDS navigate the challenges of renewed health. The forums have broached everything from artfully accounting for enormous gaps in resumes (list accomplishments, putting the sizzle up front, rather than jobs in chronological order) to understanding changes in corporate culture and lingo (team leaders, not managers). For the first in the series of six public forums, a few dozen people were expected, but 200 showed up.
"We're in an incredibly pivotal time in the epidemic where we are looking at how to help people live rather than how to help them die," said Sandy Thurman, President Clinton's new director of the National Office on AIDS Policy. "It's a huge shift logistically as well as psychologically."
Even as AIDS comes to feel for some people more like a chronic disease than a death sentence, the shifting role of AIDS agencies has become a touchy subject to service providers. There are still many unknowns about the new drugs, like how long they will remain effective. But as the needs of clients change, some AIDS organizations are likely to be put out of business.
As lower-income minorities rather than white middle-class gay men have become the prime target of AIDS, racially charged tension has increased over the role that leading AIDS service agencies should play and where resources should be invested, according to patient advocates and researchers.
"There is an absolute need to help those who are now finding themselves healthier," said Mario Cooper, the founder of Leading for Life, an initiative to increase political involvement in AIDS issues among blacks, and a board member of the Harvard AIDS Institute and G.M.H.C. "But at the same time," she said, "the majority of those with H.I.V., increasing amounts of people of color, have absolutely no access to anything, period."
Viewing the availability of protease inhibitors as a new lease on life is premature for some, according to Linda Campbell, executive director of the Minority Task Force on AIDS, the oldest minority AIDS service organization in New York.
"Many of our clients have been unemployed for long periods of time and because of despair and issues of inequity have turned to drugs as a way of dealing with the horrors of everyday life," Ms. Campbell said. "For our clients, we still have to think a lot about what supports that people out of the mainstream have. What does their future look like? What is the promise of the future for our clients, given the realities of how the local, state and Federal governments are now rolling back their commitment to social support."
Officials at agencies like G.M.H.C. said they still have an important role to play for dying people, which include many low-income, minority and heterosexual clients. But they say they cannot ignore the changed reality. G.M.H.C. estimates that roughly 70 percent of its clients have taken protease inhibitors.
On a recent Tuesday evening, nearly 20 men and women filled a conference room at Gay Men's Health Crisis. Marla Hassner, a managing attorney there, was guiding them through their rights as H.I.V.-positive employees. Several in the group scribbled notes as the talk turned from insurance benefits to pre-employment interviews and disclosure of H.I.V. status to employers.
Ms. Hassner advised them against disclosing their H.I.V.-positive status to employers, saying the only reasons to do so were if they applied for disability or sought a disability-related adjustment to their job.
"Often disclosing status causes more trouble than it is worth," she said. "Your employer is not your friend. The law doesn't require companies to treat us with compassion."
One man in an elegant gray suit wanted suggestions on how to ask prospective employers about disability benefits without disclosing his H.I.V.-positive status. The lawyer recommended scooping up the summary plan descriptions of all the employer's insurance policies, rather than raising a red flag by asking for one on long-term disability.
As the men and women listened attentively, Ms. Hassner informed them that prospective employers cannot ask about their H.I.V. status, nor can employers legally ask if they are taking medication, only if they are taking medication that might affect their ability to do their job. They may be taking 30 pills a day, but if they are not experiencing any side effects, the answer would be no, she said.
Robert, the man who is weighing three job offers, was eager to know the ins and outs of individual and group insurance policies, but he was also anxious to know what to do if he became sick again. "If you do start feeling sluggish and slow and your job performance is not up to par," he said, "could you ask for a reasonable accommodation?"
The lawyer told him that it depended on whether modifications could be made to the job that would allow him to perform essential duties, but accommodate his symptoms.
Ms. Hassner reminded the group that the law says people cannot be fired because of their H.I.V.-positive status, but they can be fired for other reasons.
"If there's downsizing and a whole department is going under, you can't save your job by disclosing you're H.I.V.-positive," Ms. Hassner said.
She added that it is illegal for employers not to hire somebody or to deny them health insurance purely because they are H.I.V.-positive.
The tenor of the employment seminar echoed that of a debt-management class, where some clients -- who thought they would be dead soon -- have spent the limit on their credit cards. Within the last six months, the focus of the debt-management workshop has shifted from informing dying clients about entitlements and discussing their debts to exploring the possibility of personal bankruptcy and questions of protecting salaries from garnishment.
"A lot of the time, it's putting the client's mind at ease," said Robert Newman, a G.M.H.C. staff attorney who moderates the workshop. "You have a fear of the unknown. Are they going to put me in jail? Is there a debtor's prison?"
In a new class for women on returning to the workplace, the conversation the other day was about how the term "living with AIDS" is no longer merely a feel-good mantra but a realistic expectation.
Iris Maldonado, 41, said that for so long she "was like in a deathbed waiting for my time to come." She has a 15-year-old daughter whom she did not expect to see graduate from junior high school. Now that Ms. Maldonado is taking protease inhibitors, , which have been on the market for 17 months,she looks forward to the day when she might become a grandmother.
Ms. Maldonado, who counsels other H.I.V.-infected women, is learning to deal not only with crisis management, like finding housing, substance-abuse counseling and other help for clients, but also the emotional and practical aspects of perhaps going back to work fulltime. Ms. Maldonado, for one, is a bit worried about having less time to spend with her family.
"But it's a great challenge to go out today and help someone know there is hope for them," said the slender woman, tears welling in her eyes. "It's not the end. It's just the beginning."
She has finally gotten around to writing her will. She said she placed it on a shelf at home where she hopes it will sit for a long time, collecting dust.

HEADLINE: More Than 50 Journalists Are Fellowship Recipients

BYLINE: By TONY MARCANO

 BODY:
More than 50 journalists from around the world will take time off from their jobs as reporters, editors, photographers and producers starting this fall for an academic year of study in fellowships offered by five universities.
The fellowships are the Knight-Bagehot Fellowships in Economics and Business Journalism at Columbia University, the Nieman Fellowships at Harvard, the Knight Science Journalism Fellowships at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the John S. Knight Journalism Fellowships at Stanford University and the University of Michigan Journalism Fellows. 
 The sabbaticals offer a range of study options for individual programs or study in groups.
 
Columbia University
These eight journalists have been named Knight-Bagehot Fellows in Economics and Business Journalism for the 1997-98 academic year:
Sarah L. Bachman, The San Jose Mercury News, foreign policy writer on the editorial board.
Jacalyn Carfagno, The Lexington Herald-Leader, business reporter.
Kari Taro Greenfeld, The Nation, correspondent.
Michael Molinski, Bloomberg News, senior Latin America correspondent.
Bolaji Ojo, Asia Inc., business magazine in Hong Kong, correspondent.
Claire Serant, The Daily News in New York, general assignment reporter.
Colin Stewart, The Patriot Ledger in Quincy, Mass., business editor and columnist.
Lawrence Strauss, The Hartford Business Journal, editor.
 
Harvard University
Twelve people have been named to the 60th class of Nieman Fellows, the oldest mid-career fellowships for journalists in the world. They will be joined by a number of international fellows to be named later this month. The fellows, who are awarded an academic year of study in any part of the university and their subjects of study, are:
Howard Berkes, National Public Radio, Salt Lake City correspondent; public policy issues.

Julia Keller, Columbus Dispatch, television critic; history, philosophy and cultural studies to explore the technology of literacy.
Phillip W. D. Martin, WGBH Radio in Boston, senior producer; race, historical anti-Semitism, multiculturalism, foreign affairs and education.
Bryan Rich, Common Ground Productions, senior international producer based in Burundi; the relationship between ethnic relations in the United States and the content of news programming.
Joe Rodriguez, The San Jose Mercury News, editorial writer; contemporary Mexican literature, film and popular culture, emphasizing on the urban novel.
David Turnley, The Detroit Free Press, photographic correspondent based in Paris; will also take classes at the W. E. B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research and the Kennedy School of Government; Russian, film making and drama.
David Welna, National Public Radio, Mexico bureau chief; the relationship between the United States and Mexico, music theory and creative writing.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
SENATOR JOSEPH R. McCARTHY was not known as a connoisseur. But from time to time he would, said one of his chroniclers, employ a phrase worthy of inclusion in any anthology of culinary bons mots. Asked how he liked his steak, Tailgunner Joe would reply, "Charred -- like the soul of an unbeliever."
Much has changed since the Junior Senator from Wisconsin left us in 1954, but most folks still prefer their grilled meat carbonized, at least on the outside. To the wine lover, this preference poses a dilemma: forgo the grape entirely or come up with something short of cleaning fluid that marries well -- as the food esthetes say -- with charred meat. 
 A third alternative, steaks and chops rare all the way through, which might stand a better chance with wine, can be dismissed out of hand. It's un-American.
Not too long ago, real men, the major consumers of grilled meats, did not drink wine. For me, at least, this perception changed in 1985, when the late Paul Castellano was gunned down on East 46th Street in Manhattan on his way into Sparks Steak House. Mr. Castellano was, as they say, a major underworld figure, a calling in which manliness is highly valued and readily demonstrated by mayhem, which is not always convenient, and by eating steaks.
Since Sparks happens to have a great wine list, Mr. Castellano's demise, whatever else it accomplished, established once and for all a relationship between red meat and wine. Had he made it inside, he almost certainly would have ordered wine, probably Chianti, a variety much favored in his set, as anyone who listens to court-ordered tapes will attest.
Probably a Chianti, but then, Sparks' owner, Pat Cetta, is skilled at steering even the most hide-bound meat-eaters in new directions. The best Chiantis, like the best Bordeaux, are not always the best choices to go with grilled steaks and chops. They can be too subtle, too nuanced.
Granted, skilled chefs and cooks, working with the best meat and professional broilers, can prepare a steak that won't overshadow an elegant wine. But for the most part, grilled meats, and particularly those prepared by backyard amateurs, need big, assertive wines that can hold their own in any company: syrahs from all over the world, barolos and other wines from the Piedmont, petite sirahs from California, any reds from the Rhone Valley, South African pinotages and, most important, muscular zinfandels, also from California.
Zinfandel is a red grape with European roots, but it achieved its own identity in this country long before any other important variety and has been adopted, one could say, as America's own. And since, along with Argentina, we are one of the few nations seriously hooked on grilled meat, it seems only fitting that zinfandel should be our designated grilled-meat wine.
Mind you, not white zinfandel -- a sweet, slightly fizzy, pale pink concoction, more akin to soft drinks than to wine, that at times isn't even made from zinfandel grapes. Real zinfandel is a gutsy red wine, full of spice and fruit flavors and often fairly high in alcohol. Most wines these days average between 11.5 and 13.5 percent alcohol. Zinfandels regularly reach 15 percent alcohol, and some recent monsters from De Loach Vineyards in Sonoma County have gone as high as 17.5 percent.
Delicious wines, but not for the faint of heart or for anyone driving home from the picnic.
Zinfandel can display all the finesse of cabernet sauvignon and pinot noir, but even the most elegant of the breed will also be full-flavored, ready to hold up to any steak, lamb chop or loin of pork -- overdone, underdone or just right.
Stockbrokers, especially successful ones, can be enthusiastic steak eaters, which, in good times like these, can lead to excess. A few months ago, around bonus time, two Young Turks were spotted at Wollensky's Grill on 49th Street, just off Third Avenue, lunching on hamburgers and Chateau Pichon-Lalande 1970. One evening around the same time, a group of eight young men, at the Post House on East 63d Street, chose to pair their steaks with a jeroboam -- eight bottles in one -- of Robert Mondavi Reserve cabernet sauvignon.
Stock market hubris has its own rules. Under less dramatic conditions, say, around the trusty Weber grill in the backyard, more modest wines should be the order of the day. And not just for economic reasons. An unsubtle grilled steak really calls for an unsubtle wine: one of those De Loach zinfandels, for example, or one from Ravenswood, Fetzer, Rodney Strong, Kendall-Jackson or Ridge. From northern Italy, a Gattinara from Travaglini or a spanna from Dessilani would work well. So would a southern Italian red like Taurino's Notarpanaro. From France, a hearty Cote du Rhone or a Gigondas from Guigal would honor any cookout, as would a solid shiraz from Rosemount, in Australia.
These are all easy-going wines at, generally, easy-going prices, many of them at or around $10. Which means that stocking enough for a crowd is not going to be a problem. It's important to be well stocked: people get impatient waiting for the fire to get hot. And if the steak doesn't turn out as planned, well, these are all wines that will go well with the pizza when it arrives 30 minutes later as a backup.

TASTINGS
Paul Thomas Cabernet-Merlot 1995 (Washington State). About $10.
 
Like many Pacific Northwest winemakers, Paul Thomas started out with fruit wine -- in his case, Crimson Rhubarb. He moved into grapes in the late 1970's and began a few years ago to turn out some interesting wines. Washington winemakers have always emphasized that their growing conditions are more Bordeaux-like than those in California. Their leaner, less aggressive wines tend to prove the point. They may not have the full-bodied richness of the California wines, but, at their best, they display complexity and nuance that their cousins to the south sometimes lack. This blend skillfully combines cabernet structure and merlot roundness in an extremely pleasant package. The blend is 57 percent cabernet and 43 percent merlot. And the price is not unattractive, either.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up as Trade Gap Eases And on German View of Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose broadly yesterday after the Government reported a surprising shrinkage in the monthly trade deficit and a senior German central banker said he favored an exchange rate of about 1.7000 marks.
Traders said the dollar was also helped by rumors of Asian central-bank purchases of dollars as well as remarks by Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's top foreign-exchange policy maker, emphasizing the importance of currency stability. 
 The dollar's gain partly reversed a big drop the day before, when talk about higher Japanese interest rates and a decision by the Federal Reserve to leave United States rates unchanged pushed the dollar sharply lower against the yen.
At one point on Tuesday, the dollar was at a five-month low against the yen. Even with the partial comeback yesterday, the dollar has retreated with remarkable speed from its four-and-a-half-year high of 127.46 yen reached three weeks ago.
In New York, the dollar settled at 114.18 yen, up from 113.04 yen on Tuesday. The dollar cost 1.6946 marks, up from 1.6823. The pound was at $1.6450, down from $1.6570.
The main force helping the dollar was the Commerce Department report that the March trade deficit narrowed sharply to $8.5 billion, largely because of record export sales. Many traders had been expecting the deficit to widen.
The report diminished fears that the dollar's recent strength had hurt exporters by making United States goods too expensive. It also contributed to evidence of healthy economic growth and inflationary pressure that suggested the Fed may nudge interest rates higher at its next policy-making meeting in July. Higher rates tend to make dollar-denominated assets more attractive.
The currency was also helped by Hans-Jurgen Kobnick, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making central bank council, who said he favored "a quiet dollar level in the area of 1.7000 marks for the foreseeable future."
Mr. Kobnick was speaking to reporters in Mainz, where he heads the Bundesbank's regional central bank.
Some traders said the dollar was helped in early Asian dealings on rumors that the central banks of Thailand and South Korea were buying dollars and selling yen.

HEADLINE: Palestinians Detain Reporter Who Is Said to Have Irked Arafat

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 21

 BODY:
A Palestinian journalist was being held without charges by the Palestinian police in the West Bank city of Ramallah today, evidently because of Yasir Arafat's irritation with his live television broadcasts of meetings of the Palestinian Legislative Council.
The journalist, Daoud Kuttab, an American citizen and director of the Modern Media Institute at Al Quds University in Jerusalem, was summoned by a Palestinian police captain to Ramallah Tuesday night, and has been held in the police station in the West Bank city since, Mr. Kuttab's brother and his colleagues said. 
 American officials said they were told by the Palestinians that Mr. Kuttab was detained on the orders of Mr. Arafat, and was likely to be held at least until Mr. Arafat returned from a trip to Egypt. Mr. Kuttab was reported in good condition.
Though no reason was given for Mr. Kuttab's detention and no charges were filed, his brother, Jonathan, said he and his institute had several run-ins with officials of the Palestinian Authority over his live broadcasts from sessions of the Palestinian Legislative Council.
On Tuesday the council, many of whose 88 members are politically independent, fiercely assailed the Palestinian Authority and Mr. Arafat over purported corruption and misuse of official funds. Some council members demanded to see the budget for Mr. Arafat's office and accused the authority with favoritism in hiring and of subsidizing homes for its ministers.
"The council's economic committee found that taxpayers' money has been misused," declared the report of the council's economic committee, which was read by its chairman, Saad al-Krunz.
The session was broadcast in several Palestinian cities -- including Ramallah, Bethlehem, Jenin and Nablus -- through the Modern Media Institute.
The institute, of which Mr. Kuttab is the founder and director, has been broadcasting all council sessions live for about two months with financing from a European grant. In that time, it has had several clashes with the Palestinian Authority, and some of its broadcasts have been cut short by the Palestinian Broadcasting Corporation, which controls all television stations in the West Bank.
Tuesday's broadcast was not cut. But after the session ended the head of the Ramallah police, identified only as Captain Fares, summoned Mr. Kuttab to his office. Mr. Kuttab lives in Jerusalem, under Israeli jurisdiction, but went anyway.
Jonathan Kuttab said: "I attribute his arrest to some people in the Palestinian Authority, not all, wanting either to stifle the debate or at least not to have the very lively, very democratic debate that goes on in the Legislative Council to be broadcast live to the whole population." He added, "They're trying to limit it, to prevent the publicity as much as they can."
Though the 88-member council has won some concessions from Mr. Arafat, it has not directly challenged his leadership.
The detention of Mr. Kuttab, and the accusations leveled by the Palestinian Legislative Council, added to a growing list of complaints of corruption and human-rights violations by the Palestinian Authority.
Mr. Kuttab was awarded the International Press Freedom Award last year by the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists for his opposition to censorship by both Israeli and Palestinian authorities.
Several prominent Palestinians have been detained in disputes with the authority, including Bassam Eid, a human-rights monitor in the West Bank, and Eyad Sarraj, a psychiatrist in Gaza who criticized the Authority in an interview.

HEADLINE: Burmese Crack Down as U.S. Investment Ban Goes Into Effect

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 21

 BODY:
As an American ban on new investments in Myanmar took effect, the Burmese military Government was reported today to have carried out a new wave of arrests of members of the pro-democracy movement led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
The human rights group Amnesty International said that at least 50 members of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy, had been detained. 
 Foreign diplomats in the Burmese capital, Yangon, formerly Rangoon, confirmed by telephone that arrests were taking place in several cities. An official of the pro-democracy party told The Associated Press that the arrests had begun on Monday and that a number of party members were taking refuge in Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's compound.
The American economic sanctions, intended to punish the military Government for human rights abuses, were announced a month ago, signed into law on Tuesday and took effect today. In announcing the action, President Clinton said it was taken in response to increased political repression as well as to Myanmar's continued production of opium and heroin.
The imposition of sanctions drew a stubborn response from Myanmar's military leaders and from officials of neighboring nations, which are to decide at the end of this month whether to admit Myanmar into their political and economic bloc, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
"Since Myanmar is walking on a straight line towards her noble goal, there is no reason to deviate from its original path to serve the interest of a foreign government," the Myanmar Government said in a statement last month.
The arrests this week appeared to be an attempt to block a congress of the National League for Democracy planned for next week to mark the seventh anniversary of parliamentary elections in which the party won more than 80 percent of the seats. The military Government refused to honor the results and continues to hold power.
A similar round of arrests took place a year ago before similar plans for a party congress. At that time, Government officials said 262 party delegates were detained. Most were released shortly afterward, but more than 20 were tried and sentenced to prison terms.
Since then, Government pressure on the pro-democracy movement and its leader has continued, with more arrests and with tightening restrictions on the activities and movements of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi.
Her weekly addresses to supporters outside her home have been blocked and soldiers outside her home bar most visitors. Her telephone has been cut off for much of that time, and she could not be reached today for comment.
The sanctions allow existing American business contracts to remain in force, including the largest single foreign investment in Myanmar, a $1 billion natural gas pipeline being developed jointly by Unocal, based in California.
After the announcement of sanctions last month, Unocal said it was suspending exploration activities for additional deposits of oil and gas, and Anheuser-Busch said it was suspending exports of beer to Myanmar.
A number of other American companies have already pulled out of Myanmar because of the publicity surrounding its human rights record.

HEADLINE: Toronto Journal;
After 27,000 Guests, the Great Gabfest Winds Up

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 21

 BODY:
At last count he has done some 27,000 interviews, though he would be the first to admit that after all the rhubarb recipes ("Is there a way to make it less stringy?"), Celtic musicians and Quebec separatists he has introduced, 27,000 sometimes seems too low.
For 15 years, the busy interviewer, Peter Gzowski (pronounced ZAH-ski), has been host of a three-hour daily radio program called "Morningside" heard by more than 1.5 million people from coast to coast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. 
 There is even an hour of highlights rebroadcast every night, making his old plaid bathrobe of a voice far more familiar, and certainly more comforting, than any Prime Minister's or other public official's.
With so much exposure, it is no wonder that Canada has been down with a bad case of national anxiety since Mr. Gzowski announced last fall that he would leave "Morningside" at the end of this month.
The show, which features not just cooks and kooks but also political panels, economic discussions and long talks about serious issues like family values and Canadian peacekeepers, will be replaced by a program that is being developed.
"I miss him already," Beth Kaplan of Toronto, a listener, wrote in an essay in The Globe and Mail in February, months before Mr. Gzowski would do his last program. "How can this country survive in the morning if Peter Gzowski vanishes for good?"
In a country forever in search of its own voice, Mr. Gzowski has become a stand-in for Canada, as curious as he is courteous, interested in hockey heroes and indigenous customs and all the forgotten chapters of a national history and culture that he constantly challenges his listeners to cherish and defend.
"When I say this it is not in the spirit of anti-Americanism, but we live next door to the cultural monolith and it washes over us every day and in every way," Mr. Gzowski said in an interview in the downtown Toronto radio studio where he broadcasts "Morningside." "And the more globalized the world gets, the more precarious our culture gets."
It is a culture he feels is as vivid and sprawling as the Canadian landscape itself, if sometimes just as hard to reach. Mr. Gzowski is 62 and remembers how as a child in southern Ontario he did not hear Canadian voices on the radio or read Canadian voices in books. Some 40 years ago, after dropping out of the University of Toronto, he went in search of those voices, landing a job as city editor of The Moose Jaw Times-Herald in Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan.
There he "felt the wrath of prairie thunder and, in its aftermath, smelled the fresh earth and heard the meadowlark sing," he wrote in his latest monthly column in Canadian Living magazine. Out west he also brushed up against the values that separate Canadians from many Americans, mostly based on the need to act collectively to survive a harsh climate and vast empty spaces.
He said the publicly supported CBC was founded on that same shared spirit, and he has spent most of his career there. When he received a Peabody Award this month in recognition of his broadcasting work, it was the first time a Canadian working in Canada had been so honored.
Mr. Gzowski's style gives "Morningside" its wide comfort zone. He stutters often, and trips up on his questions the way, well the way most people do. His smoker's voice sounds rumpled, which is the way he looks, dressed in bulky sweater, suede loafers and shapeless pants.
Listeners find "Morningside" reassuringly Canadian, a phenomenon in these days of shock radio and talk show bombast. The program runs from 9 to noon, when the audience includes a mix of farmers, fishermen and home workers, including housewives and craftsmen.
"If I had wanted to change the face of Canadian crafts I could have said, 'O.K., everybody, today we're working in green,' and every potter in the country would have said 'Yes, Peter,' cause they all had 'Morningside' on," he said.
Mr. Gzowski's guests are unfailingly polite, and blessed with so much time that neither they nor their host ever feel much pressure. He has interviewed former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, the writer Margaret Atwood, the film producer Norman Jewison and many lesser known characters like Clarence Asham, a Winnipeg savant who can instantly replay on his accordion any music he hears. Mr. Gzowski has interviewed him twice.
"Time is one of the real luxuries," Mr. Gzowski said.
But the folksy image of the program rankles some people, and even more offensive to them is the idea that somehow it holds Canada together. "If 'Morningside,' which is listened to by less than 15 percent of the entire nation each day, is all the glue we've got, we might as well be trying to bind the Titanic with Bondfast," Geoff Pevere and Greig Dymond wrote in "Mondo Canuck" (Prentice Hall Canada, 1996).
But there is something about "Morningside" that resonates in many Canadians. During the disastrous Red River flood in Manitoba last month, Mr. Gzowski and his staff organized a fund-raiser that they called the Red River Rally, with performances by dozens of Canadian artists. They raised almost $2 million.
Mr. Gzowski said he would like to write a book when he leaves "Morningside," but beyond that he has not decided what to do. But he is certain that even after 27,000 interviews, there are plenty more interesting Canadians out there to talk to.
"Some days I get up and think, 'My God, I must have talked to everybody,' and then the next day I come in and there's someone I never heard of," Mr. Gzowski said. "And he gives me a mind-boggling interview, just filled with breathtaking wisdom and pleasure and challenge, and I didn't know that guy existed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For many Canadians, the radio host Peter Gzowski is the voice of their country. After 15 years, he is giving up "Morningside," the daily program heard by more than 1.5 million people from coast to coast. (Kevin Argue for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall on Report Of Trade Gap

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday after the Government reported a smaller-than-expected trade deficit for March. The report suggested strong economic growth, which the Federal Reserve might eventually decide to confront by raising interest rates.
Other factors, including a decline in the dollar, also weighed on bond prices; a strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments such as Treasury securities more attractive because of the potential for gains in currency translation. 
 The 30-year bond dropped 22/32, to 95 28/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.95 percent, from 6.90 percent on Tuesday, when the central bank's policy- setting committee decided to leave interest rates unchanged.
But investors were not convinced that the Fed will not act to curb strong economic growth in an effort to forestall a resurgence of inflation. The decline of the trade deficit was a further cause for concern for those who think the Fed will raise rates soon, because it suggested surprising strength in the economy.
The trade deficit in goods and services, reported by the Commerce Department, narrowed 19.3 percent, to $8.5 billion, in March, as exports and imports both rose to records. Analysts had expected a $10.2 billion gap.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said import prices in April, or prices that American businesses paid for imported goods, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, the fourth straight monthly decline. Analysts said the report was in line with other recent Government statistics that suggest inflation is still benign.
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., that operates on the Internet, said that selling by hedge funds, in addition to the effect of the report on the trade gap, fueled the decline in Treasury prices yesterday.
Next week, investors will face another factor that could weigh on prices in the Treasury market: new supply. The Treasury announced the size of auctions of new notes scheduled for next Wednesday and Thursday. Next Wednesday, the Government plans to sell $16.5 billion of new two-year notes, and on Thursday, $12 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.26 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 6.56 percent.
Today, the Treasury will sell $13.75 billion of a new 52-week bill. Yesterday, the rate on the current-issue bill was 5.46 percent.
In the municipal bond market, prices were little changed as New York City and other issuers of municipal paper sold $1.25 billion in debt securities.
New York City, the biggest borrower in the trillion-dollar municipal market, last sold bonds about a month ago. Yesterday, New York priced $739.4 million of bonds through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers. Rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's, the uninsured portion of the financing was priced to yield from 4.30 percent, for a bond due in 1998, to 6 percent for one due in 2016.
A 10-year bond, rated triple-A and insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, was priced to yield 5.20 percent. Sylvan G. Feldstein, a municipal bond analyst for Guardian Asset Management, said he thought the New York bonds were well priced. "While there were a number of variables involved, there is not too much supply out there" in the municipal market, he said. Also, reports of an improvement in the city's budget situation may have contributed to solid retail demand, he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls Fashion Ads' 'Heroin Chic' Deplorable

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Asserting that "you do not need to glamorize addiction to sell clothes," President Clinton today accused the fashion industry of making heroin seem "glamorous, sexy and cool" through advertising that enticed young people to try heroin.
"American fashion has been an enormous source of creativity and beauty and art and, frankly, economic prosperity for the United States," Mr. Clinton said, "and we should all value and respect that." 
 "But the glorification of heroin is not creative, it's destructive," he added. "It's not beautiful; it's ugly. And this is not about art; it's about life and death. And glorifying death is not good for any society."
The President spoke at the White House to 35 mayors who met in Washington to draft a plan to control trafficking and use of illegal drugs. While applauding Mr. Clinton's criticism, the mayors sounded more concerned about finding resources for drug prevention and treatment programs in their hometowns.
White House officials said that the President decided to speak out against "heroin chic" in fashion photography after reading an article about it on Tuesday in The New York Times. The article said that after the fatal overdose on Feb. 4 of Davide Sorrenti, a young photographer who posed his models looking drugged and haggard, some magazine editors admitted that glamorizing the strung-out look indeed reflected a use of heroin among young people in fashion and had a damaging seductive power.
Mr. Clinton contended that such images enhanced heroin's renewed popularity.
"We now see in college campuses and neighborhoods heroin becoming increasingly the drug of choice," he said.
While there have been reports of resurgent heroin use at some colleges, the overwhelming choice of students is still alcohol, followed by marijuana. In comparison, heroin use is relatively modest. Still, Mr. Clinton's criticism seemed to be taken seriously in fashion circles.
"The President's right," said Patrick McCarthy, editorial director of W Magazine. "There is a problem, and responsible editors and fashion designers are doing something about it."
"He has stated the obvious," Mr. McCarthy said, "but when the President of the United States states it, he states it even louder. It will have an effect. This is going to be everywhere tonight and tomorrow, and you'd have to be crazy not to listen."
Fern Mallis, the executive director of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, said, "The fashion industry should not be the easy target to blame for society's woes."
But Ms. Mallis added, "We are going to take another very serious look at this issue."
"Drugs are not fashionable and we want to make sure that nobody in the fashion industry thinks that it's the case," she said.
The President complained in 1995 about photographs of half-dressed adolescents used to promote Calvin Klein fashions, and Mr. Clinton's senior adviser at the White House, Rahm Emanuel, said today that such advertisements demeaned the fashion industry's credibility.
"This is not about art," Mr. Emanuel said. "It's about attitudes and acceptability."
At the meeting with the mayors, the President also announced new steps to make it harder to launder drug money. He said that currency exchanges and check-cashing and other money services would have to register with the Treasury Department. Such outlets, which are common in poor urban neighborhoods, have become a conduit for drug profits remitted back to Latin America and other regions. Mr. Clinton said further that more businesses would be required to report suspicious business activity, which many American banks already do.
On Monday, the Administration announced that money transmitters and check-cashing services would be required to report wire transfers of more than $750 leaving the United States. The previous cutoff was $10,000.
The 35 mayors visiting the White House represented a study group on drug control organized by the United States Conference of Mayors. In their recommendations presented to Mr. Clinton, they made the first priority persuading young people not to use drugs, which mirrors the Administration's position. They also said that drug abuse would not be reduced without adequate resources to treat drug addicts. And they linked increased prevention and treatment to strong enforcement measures.
"This is a very complex issue," Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago told reporters after meeting with the President. "It cannot be answered by simple solutions."

HEADLINE: Standing the Heat, Wanting the Kitchen

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
They were impressive in their posture, impeccable in their toques and chef's jackets. Fourteen high school students, each standing in front of trays of chocolate shavings, eggs, chives, carrots, zucchini and guinea hens.
Then came the word: On your mark, get set, cook. 
 And so began a cooking competition yesterday for $130,000 worth of scholarships to the country's top culinary schools. Now in its seventh year, the competition is sponsored by a nonprofit organization in Manhattan called the Careers Through Culinary Arts Program, which offers school-to-work opportunities to inner-city students.
With a two-hour limit, the students were expected to prepare poached guinea hen with chive sauce and turned vegetables, crepes sucrees, creme patissiere and sauce au chocolat. "As we go through life, there are many things that aren't math or science or English that we use to live," said Richard Grausman, 59, the program's founder and president. "I hope they look at food in a different way, and gain an appreciation for many things."
Since starting the program in 12 New York City high schools in 1990, Mr. Grausman has expanded it to 18 other New York schools and more than 170 schools in six other cities, reaching more than 10,000 students.
Through home economics classes, the program teaches students the basics: sanitation, safety, food preparation and interview skills. The program is financed by private foundations such as the Bank of New York, Grand Marnier Foundation and Helena Rubinstein Foundation, and companies like General Mills, Land O'Lakes and Pintelle Farms.
The program has offered 300 students more than $2.5 million in scholarships to institutions such as the Culinary Institute of America, Johnson & Wales University and the New York Restaurant School. Past winners include Diannah Pena, 22, now a pastry cook at Gotham Bar and Grill, and Alfred Stephens, 22, sous pastry chef at Mesa Grill. If it wasn't for the program, Mr. Stephens said, "I wouldn't be here today, because I had no real solid plans after high school."
This year's competition was staged at the New York Restaurant School and was judged by chefs from rarefied establishments such as Verbena, Sign of the Dove and Aquavit.
It was a chaotic scene, as students scooped salt, measured milk, cracked eggs and assembled the ingredients -- all from memory. But everyone finished within two hours and 10 minutes, offering samples that were tasty and creative. (One student presented three crepes arranged like tulips, with stems made of chocolate sauce.)
The winners will be announced at an awards breakfast sponsored by Tavern on the Green on June 3.
"I think it went pretty good," said Milton Gotay, 17, a senior at Park West High School in Manhattan. "If I had a sharper knife, it would have been better, because the meat got choppy, almost like tuna. But this is a great opportunity, and some day I hope to open my own restaurant."
