HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Retreating 12.77

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday as investors continued to worry about the possibility of higher interest rates, despite the fact that the Federal Reserve voted to leave them unchanged earlier this week.
"You wonder how long this scenario of above-normal growth and tame interest rates will last," said John Niedenberger, who oversees $3 billion as a money manager at Advanced Investment Management in Pittsburgh. "We have a lot of good news on the table, and investors are worried about what will derail it." 
 Banks, among the companies most sensitive to rising rates, fell, led by Citicorp. A report of higher than expected profits from Dell Computer a day earlier sent computer-related shares higher, leaving the overall market mixed.
The Dow Jones industrial average slid 12.77 points, to 7,290.69, after briefly touching a record high of 7,352.91. Travelers Group, the insurer and financial services company, fell 1 3/4, to 55 7/8, to lead the 30-stock average down. J. P. Morgan, the fifth-largest American bank, fell 1 3/8, to 103 7/8.
Trading surged to 538.2 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, the first time in a week that the number of shares changing hands topped the three-month average of 486 million.
A Government trade report showing a decline in the trade deficit in March raised concern that inflation could emerge because it showed record imports and exports, weakening bond prices and fueling speculation that the Fed might have to raise rates at its meeting in July.
By not acting on Tuesday, "the Fed has introduced another layer of uncertainty in the market," said Charles Crane, chief investment strategist at Key Asset Management. "Financial markets hate uncertainty."
The Fed raised the overnight bank lending rate in March for the first time in two years, and in the past it usually has raised rates more than once after it has leaned in that direction.
Bank stocks were the hardest hit yesterday by the worries about rates. Citicorp fell 3 3/8, to 116 3/4; Chase Manhattan slid 3 3/8, to 93 1/8, and BankBoston declined 1 3/4, to 75.
Wells Fargo fell 7 5/8, to 258, and is now down 7.7 percent in the last three days. On Monday, Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said it had pared its stake to 7.82 percent from 8.15 percent. The sale was noteworthy because Berkshire is run by the investor Warren E. Buffett, who is known for his "buy and hold" investing style. And yesterday, William Zuendt, one of the architects of Wells Fargo's $11 billion acquisition of First Interstate Bancorp, said he planned to retire.
The Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 2.31, to 839.35, losing an early gain that pushed it to a record, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 9.87, to 1,373.75. Dell, which jumped 7 1/8, to 106 3/4, led both indexes. The company's fiscal first-quarter earnings more than doubled, topping analyst estimates.
The Compaq Computer Corporation rose 5 3/4, to 102 3/4; Microsoft climbed 1 1/4, to 120 3/8; Intel rose 1 1/2, to 162 1/2; Cisco Systems Inc. rose 1 3/8, to 65 3/4, and Oracle climbed 1 11/16, to 46 15/16.
Schering-Plough, which makes the top-selling antihistamine, Claritin, rose 2 1/8, to 89 1/4. The company said that it expected stronger than expected growth in earnings this year.

HEADLINE: Plan Is Offered To Reorganize Finance Sector

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Retreating from its most ambitious idea allowing banks to own manufacturers or other nonfinancial companies -- the Clinton Administration today introduced a long-awaited plan to revamp the nation's financial services industry.
For more than a decade, repeated attempts to overhaul banking legislation have collapsed from intense industry in-fighting. In deciding not to press for authority for banks to engage in virtually any business -- a proposal that has drawn sharp criticism -- the Administration has provided the framework, analysts said, for a bill with solid prospects of enactment. 
 The Administration did not propose any banking legislation last year, when Congress tried and failed to pass a bill repealing the Glass-Steagall Act, the 1933 law that separates the banking and securities businesses.
The plan, outlined today by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, is an attempt to reflect the deregulatory changes that have already swept through the marketplace, paced by the efforts of Federal regulators that have allowed banks and Wall Street to move onto each other's turf.
"The old lines that separated insurance, securities and banking industries have increasingly blurred as new financial services and products have appeared," Mr. Rubin said today in a speech at the Exchequer Club here.
He predicted that increased competition in the securities, banking and insurance industries would produce savings of as much as $15 billion for consumers.
Marge Roukema, the New Jersey Republican who heads the House subcommittee on financial institutions, called the Administration proposal a "welcome contribution to our efforts to pass financial modernization legislation this year." She warned that if Congress did not act to establish order in the regulatory landscape, piecemeal approval of mergers and other activities could threaten the safety of the banking system.
Financial industry groups gave the Administration's outline cautious support pending its refinement over the next couple of weeks. "The devil's in the details," said Paul A. Equale, senior vice president of the Independent Insurance Agents of America.
Still, the idea of commercial ownership by banks is expected to remain an obstacle for any legislation.
For while Mr. Rubin signaled a retreat from the controversial proposal to allow banks to venture into a wide range of businesses, he did not abandon it all together. The Administration's plan offers such ownership as one of two alternatives.
Mr. Rubin suggested that permission for banks be linked to a specified limit on nonfinancial activity, expressed in terms of total domestic revenue. He also said that Congress might want to bar affiliation between a bank and any of the nation's 1,000 biggest nonfinancial companies.
No percentage was mentioned, but the Treasury is expected to accept a limit of 25 percent on nonfinancial business that is contained in a bill that has been sponsored by Representative Roukema and widely discussed in the financial industry.
Critics of commercial ownership by banks argue that such authority could lead to an overconcentration of economic power. The savings and loan debacle of the 1980's, when taxpayers bailed out failed institutions, has also been cited by opponents, who point to overly ambitious acquisitions and poorly supervised deregulation as a chief cause of those failures.
A coalition of farm groups, small business and small banks joined Ralph Nader and the Consumers Union today in a strong denunciation of any revamping that allows banking to mix with ordinary commerce.
"It would lead to a dangerous concentration of our nation's economic assets, jeopardize the impartial allocation of credit and place an additional strain on the Federal safety net to the potential detriment of the American taxpayer," the alliance said. Even a plan that limits nonfinancial activity is unacceptable, the alliance said, because it would "begin a slide towards massive" affiliation.
Even Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, who was an early promoter of allowing banks into nonfinancial commerce, has become markedly less enthusiastic.
If there is to be no such relaxation on nonfinancial ownership by bank holding companies, Mr. Rubin proposed breaking down virtually all the barriers that inhibit competition within the various sectors of the financial services industry so that banks, securities firms and insurers could affiliate with one another.
"Reflecting the consensus that this reform is long overdue," he said, "these affiliations would help promote a genuine two-way street, one in which all participants have the opportunity to compete and innovate."
Under this alternative, Mr. Rubin said, the likely result would be for Congress to retain a separate charter for savings institutions, meaning that the current disparities between banks and savings institutions would remain.
The American Bankers Association congratulated the Administration for putting forward a plan and said it agreed with many aspects. But the association said it opposed the idea of merging the insurance funds of banks and savings institutions without merging their charters.
Still another element of the Administration plan is creation of a new entity called wholesale financial institutions, known as "woofies" because of the initials W.F.I. These would be banks that accept only wholesale uninsured deposits and would have access to the payments system but would not be considered banks under holding company regulation.
Mr. Rubin pledged to strongly oppose any erosion of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which requires that banks lend money in the low-income areas of the communities they serve, in any overhaul of financial industry regulation.
Over all, he said, "our objective is simple: modernizing financial services in a way that will benefit consumers, businesses and communities, enhance competitiveness of our industry worldwide and protect the safety and soundness of our financial institutions."

HEADLINE: Export Surge Eases Deficit In U.S. Trade

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit narrowed in March as exports surged to a record for the second consecutive month, spurring first-quarter economic growth and suggesting more of the same in coming months.
"The economy is in an extraordinarily strong position," said Clark A. Johnson, chairman and chief executive at Pier 1 Imports in Fort Worth. "Some people feel that the second quarter will slow down a little bit. We just think we're going to continue to see this solid steady growth that we've seen for the last six years." 
 The overall trade deficit in March narrowed to $8.508 billion from $10.538 billion in February, the Commerce Department said. Before today's report, analysts expected a $10.2 billion trade gap in March.
Exports of goods and services rose 4.1 percent in March to a record $76.479 billion, led by sales of commercial aircraft, industrial hardware and consumer goods.
"The U.S. is producing goods that everybody wants and needs," said Michael Fenollosa, an economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. "We're pretty good at making airplanes and we're pretty good at high tech."
Imports rose 1.2 percent in March to $84.987 billion. They, too, set a second consecutive monthly record, reflecting more purchases from abroad of consumer goods, food and beverages. But auto imports fell.
Over all, expectations are for exports to continue growing and for imports to remain close to current levels as low unemployment helps bolster the incomes of Americans, business executives and analysts said.
"With the dollar topping out, we should see good export growth," Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said. "The economy has a lot of momentum."
A surge in commercial aircraft exports was a big reason the trade deficit shrank in March, though that trend probably will not continue, said Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. "You can expect some fallback in aircraft sales, simply based on the fact that what we've had this month is a record," he said.
Still, the Boeing Company says it expects to deliver 340 planes this year, up from 218 last year, and many of those will go to foreign buyers.
And though steel exports are lagging behind other industries, that situation could reverse itself "if the dollar keeps on dipping" and the economies of Japan and Germany improve, said John D. Correnti, chief executive of the Nucor Corporation, a steel manufacturer based in Charlotte, N. C.
Japan and China are two places where United States export growth continues to lag behind imports.
The merchandise deficit with Japan, America's second-biggest commercial partner behind Canada, widened in March to its biggest monthly level since October -- $4.608 billion. That follows a $4.255 billion deficit in February, led by imports of Japanese-made computers, electrical machinery and telecommunications equipment.
And while the annual trade deficit with Japan narrowed last year to $47.7 billion, its lowest level since 1991, the stronger dollar has reversed that trend. New statistics from Tokyo showed that Japan's trade surplus skyrocketed in April as auto makers and other manufacturers cranked up exports to their highest level in 15 years to offset sagging demand at home.
"Six months down the road, growth dynamics of the world's economies will start to shift," said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an analytical consulting firm in Essex, Conn. That could aid United States exports and cut into United States imports.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Holes in Internet Security Plan

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
A panel of computer scientists said yesterday that the Government's plans for unlocking data-scrambling software to pursue criminals and terrorists on the Internet could actually increase security risks and raise the costs of on-line commerce.
The researchers, in a study coordinated by the Center for Democracy and Technology, a nonprofit policy group in Washington, examined the technical challenges of the Government's Internet security proposal. The plan would permit American computer companies to export powerful data-scrambling software, but only if they established a system that would enable the keys to the code to be obtained by law enforcement officials with a court warrant. 
 The plan calls for these software "keys" -- lengthy numeric codes -- to be held not by a Federal agency but by third-party companies. To get the keys, law enforcement officials or intelligence agencies would have to obtain legal authorization.
The plan to use third-party key holders was advanced last fall by the Clinton Administration. It was made in response to concerns by civil liberties groups, including the center for democracy, that warned that letting a Federal agency hold the keys would make it too easy for the Government to monitor the communications of private citizens and in response to complaints by software companies that it would hurt sales.
But the 11 computer scientists -- experts in the use of software that encrypts, or scrambles, data -- concluded that the Government's so-called key-recovery plan, however well intentioned, would introduce its own set of risks and costs. "A key-recovery system is going to be extraordinarily hard to design and build economically, safely and reliably," said Matt Blaze, a research scientist at AT&T.
Another computer scientist in the group, Peter Neumann of SRI International, a research center in Menlo Park, Calif., said that having a key-recovery system in computing was similar to having a skeleton key to one's house as well as a personal key. The all-purpose skeleton key, it turns out, is easy to copy. "So the existence of skeleton keys or trap doors, as the Government is proposing, is inherently risky," Mr. Neumann said.
Jerry Berman, executive director of the Center for Democracy and Technology, said: "Key recovery may be a nice idea, but it doesn't compute yet. The technical issues are the Achilles' heel of key recovery, and they need to be debated."
William A. Reinsch, Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration, said the center's study seemed to assume a vast, centralized system that was not what the Administration intended.
Besides, Mr. Reinsch said, a number of private companies as well as the Government are pushing for key-recovery software, and the expense will not be prohibitive. Companies, he noted, want to be able to tap into communications for such purposes as thwarting industrial espionage.
Giving the Government access to the keys to pursue criminals, Mr. Reinsch said, will require the additional step of a court warrant. "But it won't require building a separate infrastructure for the Government's key-recovery plan," he said.
Still, the Administration's plan faces fierce political opposition domestically and skepticism by some foreign governments. Last week, the House Judiciary Committee unanimously passed a bill that would relax export controls on data-scrambling software and permit companies and individuals to use any encryption programs they choose.
Abroad, Germany said it would not do anything to regulate data-scrambling software for at least two years, while waiting to see how Internet markets developed. The United States cannot "force its policy down the throats of other countries," said Peter Harter, global public policy counsel for the Netscape Communications Corporation.

HEADLINE: Virgilio Barco, Ex-Colombia Chief, Dies at 75

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Virgilio Barco, an American-educated former President of Colombia whose dream of combatting rampant poverty with land reform and other ambitious social measures was sidetracked by an American-backed civil war with powerful drug barons, died Tuesday at a hospital in Bogota. He was 75 and had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease since shortly after leaving office in 1990.
Hospital officials said the cause was stomach cancer. 
 With one-third of his nation's 28 million people living below the painfully low official poverty line and an array of well-armed leftist guerrilla bands carrying out attacks and demanding reform, Mr. Barco had his work cut out for him when he took office in Bogota on Aug. 7, 1986.
Tall and lean with a shock of white hair, black horned-rimmed glasses and a tendency to stammer, at first glance, Mr. Barco hardly seemed the man to set things straight. He was such a poor off-the-cuff speaker that he refused to give interviews during the campaign. He became the butt of widespread jokes, often likened to an absent-minded professor, one, moreover, with such a pronounced American accent that his English was said to be better than his Spanish.
If so, it was because Mr. Barco had spent 17 years in the United States, earning a degree in civil engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, studying economics there and at Harvard, earning a master's and teaching at Boston University, serving as Ambassador to the United States and spending five more years in Washington as a director of the World Bank.
He married an American, the former Mary Carol Isakson of York, Pa. In addition to his wife, his survivors include four children, Carolina, Julia, Diana and Virgilio, and two grandchildren.
But for all his difficulties speaking, Mr. Barco established himself as a highly effective administrator and one of the nation's most accomplished politicians.
A native of the steamy, oil producing town of Cucuta, on the Venezuelan border, where his grandfather had obtained a valuable oil concession in 1905, Mr. Barco grew up rich. But against type, he attended public schools as a child and later joined the Liberal Party.
Drawn into politics shortly after he received his degree from M.I.T. in 1943, Mr. Barco ran the Ministry of Communications and later served in both houses of Congress, his first term interrupted by the civil war between the Liberal and Conservative Parties, which forced him to spend several years in exile in the United States.
After he returned to Colombia in 1954, Mr. Barco helped arrange the inter-party peace that laid the groundwork for a stable democracy, serving two terms in the Senate and becoming Minister of Public Works and then of Agriculture, Acting Minister of Finance and Ambassador to Britain before an appointed term as Mayor of Bogota made him something of a national hero when he successfully completed an ambitious construction program to prepare for a Papal visit in 1968.
As President, Mr. Barco made a valiant effort to carry out his economic and social reforms but he was soon sidetracked by American demands for the arrest and extradition of more than 100 drug traffickers, a demand that set off a wave of bombings, kidnappings and assassinations by the entrenched leaders of the nation's cocaine cartels.
Mr. Barco, who had barely mentioned the cartels during his campaign, favored extradition, but after the Colombian Supreme Court twice invalidated the extradition treaty, the President seemed immobilized.
With many Colombians openly favoring a truce with the drug barons, Mr. Barco continued to denounce them as leaders of a renegade state within a state, but he also began a public-relations campaign in the United States aimed at establishing that the problem was was the insatiable American demand for drugs, not the Colombian supply.
In the end, it was not so much the American pressure as the ruthless boldness of the drug barons that prodded Mr. Barco into action. After a wave of assassinations of public officials, he declared a state of siege in 1988, reimposed the extradition treaty by decree and began a full-scale war against the cartels, capturing or killing several high-level traffickers and extraditing a number of them to the United States.
When he left office in 1990 the war was still raging, and although the most powerful and notorious trafficker, Pablo Escobar Gaviria, was eventually killed in 1993, the power of the cartels was demonstrated in 1991, when the Colombian Congress overturned the extradition treaty.
Although reliable assessments are impossible to come by, by most accounts Colombia continues to supply about as much cocaine as it ever did.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Evidence for a modest impact from abolishing rent controls.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
TO economists, the persistence of rent regulation in New York -- the belly of the capitalist beast -- is a delicious irony. To some two million New Yorkers who live in rent-regulated apartments, all the tub-thumping in the world about how price controls are evil incarnate will not change a fundamental fact: While the typical rent on "stabilized" one-bedroom apartments in Manhattan hovers around $600 a month, the cracker boxes advertised in the Sunday papers cost $1,500 and up.
Economists would be delighted to calm the fears of those who worry that their rents will triple overnight. Average rents could not possibly reach the level of rents on free market units, they point out, because there simply are not enough people with both the income and the desire to live in Manhattan for $1,500 a month. But William Tucker, a specialist in housing and the author of a new report on rent regulation published yesterday by the Cato Institute in Washington, offers something better than common sense -- solid (if indirect) evidence that abolishing controls would have only a modest impact on most rents. 
 Rent controls, he points out, create an artificial "shadow market" for apartments at fantastically inflated rents. And the proof, he suggests, is in a city-by-city comparison of median rents against the rents of newly advertised apartments.
Mr. Tucker collected data on rental rates in 18 American cities, counting every "for rent" ad in a Sunday issue of the local newspaper during April 1997. Five of the 18 (New York, San Jose, Calif., Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington) have some form of rent control. One (Boston) abolished rent control in January 1997. The other 12 (ranging from Philadelphia to Chicago to San Diego) have free markets in rental housing.
In free-market cities, rents on advertised apartments cluster around the closest available estimate of the median rent today, namely the actual median rents from the 1990 Census. In Philadelphia, for example, some 200 of the 500 apartments advertised in The Philadelphia Inquirer clustered within $50 of the $498 median from the Census. In Phoenix, close to half of the advertised apartments were within $50 of the $466 median.
Compare those figures with the numbers for the most tightly controlled local rental markets. In San Francisco, the median rent in 1990 was $690, while the median advertised rent on 480 listings in April 1997 was $1,400. In New York City the 1990 median was $545 and the median rental rate of some 3,000 units advertised in April was $1,350.
In the cities with rent control, Mr. Tucker argues, the price pressure created by shortages of housing at controlled rental rates is all focused on the small portion of new, uncontrolled housing. Thus if New York played by the same rules as Philadelphia or Phoenix, rentals would be higher than the current average, and much higher in a few hot neighborhoods such as Greenwich Village. But to fill most apartments -- notably smaller units in the outer boroughs -- landlords would have to keep rent increases modest.
From Mr. Tucker's perspective, the vacancy decontrol approach now favored by Gov. George E. Pataki, is "the worst of possible worlds." The number of units coming onto the free market would be small and market-clearing rents would remain very high, validating the fears of those remaining in regulated units. Indeed, that is precisely what happened during New York's brief experiment with vacancy decontrol in the early 1970's.
What approach, short of overnight decontrol, might work -- and perhaps even persuade New Yorkers that free markets in housing are not a dastardly reactionary plot? Roger Starr, the city's Housing and Development Administrator in the Beame administration, has long peddled the "matched lease" concept, which was used to extricate the city from commercial rent control after World War II.
Under the plan, landlords would be free to look for new tenants at whatever rate the market would bear, but existing tenants would have the right to stay in their apartments at the current rent until the landlord had a bona fide offer in hand. And even then, old tenants would have the option of staying on by matching the offer.
The idea, Mr. Starr says, is to allow prices to equate supply and demand very quickly, but with minimal disruption in the lives of existing tenants. Where the free-market price was actually far above the old rent, the landlord would be able to capture the gain. However, a landlord who reached for the moon would be forced to adjust his expectations before sending his current tenant packing.
"They tell me matched leases are too complicated," Mr. Starr said, "but could they possibly be more complicated than rent control as usual?"

HEADLINE: CLINTON HELPS KILL PROPOSAL TO RAISE TAX ON CIGARETTES

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Clinton today helped kill a proposal for a tobacco tax increase to pay for children's health care, clearing the major obstacle to Senate adoption of a resolution promising to balance the budget by the year 2002.
The President acted after Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi threatened to withdraw the budget resolution from Senate consideration if the health measure, which Mr. Lott called a "deal buster," was not defeated. 
 Mr. Clinton had his aides make telephone calls to Democratic senators urging them to back off the plan, offered by Senators Orrin G. Hatch, the conservative Republican from Utah, and Edward M. Kennedy, the liberal Democrat from Massachusetts.
The plan for a 43-cents-a-pack increase in the cigarette tax was then defeated on a 55-to-45 vote.
The Senate is expected to pass the budget resolution, which sets basic spending and taxing limits, on Thursday. The House passed its version, 333 to 99, at 3:28 this morning after a 13-hour debate, but only after a cliff-hanging, 216-to-214 vote against adding $12 billion to the $125 billion already allocated for highways in the next five years.
Despite the opposition of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, 132 Democrats voted for the budget resolution along with 201 Republicans. Voting against it were 72 Democrats, 26 Republicans and 1 independent.
Both Houses are considering very similar proposals, which include $85 billion in tax cuts and curbs on spending for Medicare, defense and most domestic programs below the level needed to keep pace with inflation. The net of spending cuts would be $204 billion through 2002, and if all goes according to the expectations of the plan's supporters the budget would be balanced in that year for the first time since 1969.
But the seven-hour battle over the $30 billion increase in the cigarette tax to pay for grants to states to help buy insurance for children of the working poor kept the Senate from finishing its work on the measure tonight.
This morning, Mr. Kennedy said, Vice President Al Gore's office called to say the Vice President would come to the Capitol to break a possible tie in favor of the Hatch-Kennedy plan. A White House aide said, "If anything, there was a miscommunication among Senator Kennedy's staff, because that was never communicated by Vice President's office."
By late afternoon, after complaints by Mr. Lott and other Republicans that Mr. Clinton had promised to help produce votes to keep their budget deals intact, Franklin D. Raines, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and John Hilley, his chief lobbyist, started calling Democratic senators.
Some were impressed, some were annoyed, but in the end four likely supporters of the Hatch-Kennedy plan who had been called voted against it. So did at least three Republicans who had said they supported the plan. In all, 47 Republicans and 8 Democrats voted to kill the proposal, while 8 Republicans and 37 Democrats voted for it.
As the vote was beginning around 4 P.M., Michael D. McCurry, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, explained the White House position this way:
"As a free-standing matter, I think this President's sympathies are pretty clear on the thrust of the legislation. The problem is, the amendment doesn't stand freely. It stands encumbering the balanced budget agreement we also fought very hard for. The President is not about to see all that hard work go down the drain, and he had very clearly been told by the majority leader that this amendment is a deal buster, and he is not gong to let that agreement go down."
Senator Kennedy scoffed at the idea of dealing with the measure alone. "That's like spitting in the wind," he said, explaining that as a free-standing bill it would be subject to a filibuster and need 60 votes, and moreover would have to be attached to a tax bill from the House. As part of the budget measure, it cannot be filibustered and needs only 51 votes.
Mr. Hatch told the Senate: "There is no way of knowing, but I think we would have won this one had we held the vote at the scheduled time of 11:30. I think the President and the people in the White House caved here." He said he thought Mr. Lott had been bluffing about withdrawing the budget bill.
Mr. Kennedy was milder, though he made a point of saying his calls to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore on Tuesday had not been returned. He said he thought the vote showed that a majority was attainable, and said he thought the President was "mistaken" to work against the bill. And he said: "We shall offer it again and again until we prevail. It's more important to protect children than to protect the tobacco industry."
When he was asked at a news conference whether he expected the President's support on future efforts, he turned to Mr. Hatch and said, "Why don't you answer that." Mr. Hatch said, "Yes." Then Mr. Kennedy said, "I would hope he would."
Today's battle was not definitive. The budget resolution is a broad outline, to be followed by specific tax and spending measures. And it already includes $16 billion aimed at children's health, although it also reduces money for hospitals serving children by nearly half that much. Mr. Hatch and Mr. Kennedy argued that the $16 billion would only provide coverage for perhaps 4 million of the 10 million children without health insurance and that the additional $20 billion they wanted to spend (with the other $10 billion set aside for deficit reduction) would finish the job.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Republican whip, complained, "No one in their wildest dreams would have said we should have $36 billion to solve this problem, which I guarantee you is not that big."
Although the most effective attacks on their proposal were the ones that suggested it would destroy children's hopes for a balanced budget, it was denounced substantively from several different, and occasionally conflicting, directions.
Senator Wendell H. Ford, a Kentucky Democrat, said it would lead to reduced smoking and cause great harm to his state's economy. But Senator Lauch Faircloth, a North Carolina Republican, said it would hurt the poor because they would keep on smoking and have to pay higher taxes. He called it "an opportunity to further gouge the working people of this country."
Other Republicans called it an entitlement and said the money would not be enough and states would be stuck with additional costs, or said it was a step toward big government.
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Republican who heads the Budget Committee, repeatedly attacked the idea as contrary to the budget deal. "There can be no more frontal attack in violation of this agreement than this amendment," Mr. Domenici said. But he also contended that no vote on the budget resolution could guarantee a tobacco tax increase for it would be up to the Finance Committee to decide what taxes to recommend.
Mr. Hatch replied that everyone knew what the amendment was about and he said the Finance Committee would follow the will of the Senate. "It's Joey versus Joe Camel and no procedural niceties can obscure this reality and everybody here knows it," Mr. Hatch said. Joey is a tyke in an advertisement proponents of Hatch-Kennedy put in The Washington Post today. Joe Camel is the cartoon character industry critics say R. J. Reynolds uses to push its Camel brand on children.

HEADLINE: $15 Million In a Fund Will Provide Housing Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A group of banks and foundations led by Bankers Trust and J.P. Morgan will announce a $15 million fund today to subsidize New York City's community development corporations, the small, nonprofit neighborhood groups that have built thousands of homes and apartments for poor people since the 1970's.
The fund, about half of which has already been raised, is intended to support the community groups at a time when the Federal Section 8 program and other forms of government housing assistance are being cut, increasing the demand for the groups' services in poor areas. 
 Sponsors of the fund said it was also meant to acknowledge the huge role that the community development corporations -- many of them created by the clergy, advocates for the poor and others who are far removed from the world of high finance -- have taken on in building and maintaining housing across a broad swath of the city, from East New York to the northern reaches of the Bronx.
And since many of the city's banks and corporations have invested in the poor areas -- lured by a program of Federal housing tax credits -- they may view the new fund as a means of protecting the financial commitments that they have already made, officials said.
"These groups are the stabilizing force in their neighborhoods," said Gary Hattem, director of the Community Development Group at Bankers Trust, whose chairman, Frank Newman, is to announce the creation of the fund at a meeting of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Money raised through the fund is to be distributed equally among 50 community development corporations, and is to be used for staff salaries, work by accountants and engineers, computer equipment and other administrative costs.
"They need an infusion of capital to become more professional, and more institutionalized in their neighborhoods," Mr. Hattem said. The fund will also support an expansion of the groups' activities into such areas as job training and family services, he said.
Banks that contribute to the fund are expected to use it as a way of enhancing their standing under the Community Reinvestment Act, a 10-year-old Federal law that requires lenders to support low-income neighborhoods. The law applies to foreign banks doing business in the United States, just as it does to their domestic counterparts.
That may account for the presence of several foreign banks on a roster of those that have already contributed. They include the Bank of China, the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Trust Corporation and the Fuji Bank and Trust Company. Among New York-based banks that have contributed are the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Republic National Bank.
Among several foundations that have contributed are the Fannie Mae Foundation, the Metropolitan Life Foundation and the New York Community Trust.
Although organizers of the fund have not selected the community development corporations that will benefit, such groups as the Mid-Bronx Desperatos, the St Nicholas Neighborhood Preservation Corporation of Williamsburgh and the Abyssinian Development Corporation of central Harlem, which have been in the vanguard of low-income housing rehabilitation, were considered certain to be among them.
Since the community development corporations began their work in the 1970's -- typically to fix up a small number of blighted buildings that had become centers of the drug trade -- the groups have rehabilitated more than 500 vacant buildings and created more than 20,000 apartments.
Since the mid-1980's, the main source of financing for the groups, and the main source of their close ties to banks and other corporations, has been the Federal Government's program of corporate housing tax credits, which are limited and divided between the states. The program enables businesses that provide money to the housing groups to recoup their investment, sometimes with interest, through reductions in their corporate income taxes over 15 years.
The tax credit program is administered by two organizations, the Enterprise Foundation and the Local Initiative Support Corporation, both of which have contributed to the new fund. Executives of both groups said they considered the fund a logical extension of the corporate investments that have already been made, even though contributors will not receive the tax credits that have attracted them in the past.
"It is a matter of enabling the community groups to do their work more efficiently, and not have to spend half their time writing grant proposals," said Paul Grogan, president of the Local Initiative Support Corporation.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Worries About Fed Persist, And Stocks Are Mixed
Stock prices were mixed as investors continued to worry about the possibility of higher interest rates, even though the Federal Reserve voted to leave them unchanged earlier this week.
Banks, among the companies most sensitive to rising rates, fell. The Dow industrials slid 12.77 points, to 7,290.69. But many computer-related issues rose, and the Nasdaq was up 9.87 points, to 1,373.75. [Page D10.] 

Similar fears hurt the bond market, where the 30-year Treasury yield rose to 6.95 percent from 6.90. [D17.]
 
Trade Gap Narrowed in March
The United States trade deficit fell sharply in March, to $8.5 billion from $10.5 billion in February, as exports and imports both hit records. But the gap with Japan rose. [D10.]
 
The narrowing of the trade deficit and rumors that Asian central banks were buying dollars helped the currency rise broadly. [D8.]
 
Wells Fargo President to Retire
William Zuendt, the president of Wells Fargo and the chief architect of its transition into high- technology banking, unexpectedly announced that he would retire. Analysts said he could well be taking the blame for problems resulting from the takeover of First Interstate. [D2.]
 
Household International Adds a Unit
Household International said it would buy the consumer finance business of Transamerica for $1.1 billion in cash. [D9.]
 
Toyota Earnings Disappoint
Earnings at Toyota Motor rose 50 percent, but fell short of analysts' expectations, for the latest fiscal year. The auto maker said it spent heavily on new plants outside Japan and on advertising in Japan. [D7.]
 
Shift in Fight for Marvel
In the continuing battle for control of Marvel Entertainment, Toy Biz, which had sided with Marvel's management, defected to the other side, saying it had reached a deal with bondholders led by Carl C. Icahn. [D4.]
 
U.S. Encryption Plan Criticized
A panel of computer scientists said that the Government's plans for unlocking data-scrambling software to pursue criminals on the Internet could increase security risks and raise the costs of on-line commerce. [D9.]
 
Tyco International's Expansion
In an age when many companies would rather pare down than expand, Tyco International's growth plan -- which continued with a deal for Keystone International, an industrial valve maker -- may seem anachronistic. But it is popular on Wall Street. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Curb on Managed-Care Companies
Moving to restrict the power of managed-care companies to deny treatment to customers, Connecticut lawmakers approved legislation that will let the state overturn the companies' decisions on what medical procedures they will pay for. [A1.]
 
Higher Profile For Lawyers
In the states' fight against the tobacco industry, private lawyers have amassed extraordinary influence, extending well beyond their court representation. [A1.]
 
Times Square Gamble Succeeds
The decision to open a Marriott hotel in Times Square a dozen years ago, which was derided at the time, has paid off, and the chain has been intent on expanding its franchise in the midst of a New York City hotel boom. [B1.]
 
Hurdle for Lockheed Contract
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York City said that it would delay a vote on a $95 million contract for data processing with Lockheed Martin. The company has been barred from contracts with the city government -- of which the agency is independent -- because of its involvement in past corruption scandals. [B3.]
 
A Break From Routine for Club Med
Club Med is counting on new marketing alliances to lift it out of the financial doldrums in which it has floundered since 1990. Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Extending Its Reach, Room by Room;
Marriott Set Out to Prove Itself In New York; Now It Dominates

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
When J.W. Marriott Jr. opened the 50-story Marriott Marquis in the midst of Times Square's low-rise porn shops in 1985, the hotel was described by architecture critics as a mass of concrete looming over Times Square like a giant tombstone.
Jurgen Giesbert, the hotel manager at the time, said that many people in the lodging industry thought "Marriott was not terribly smart spending that kind of money at this location." 
 The pessimists seemed right six years later when the economy went sour. Rates plummeted as hoteliers like Marriott saw half their rooms sit empty. New hotels came on line just as corporations slashed travel budgets and laid off employees. "Even Marriott International had a difficult time," Mr. Giesbert said. "New York was not a market in the forefront."
All that, of course, has changed. Now, towering in Times Square over the beginnings of a new office tower for Conde Nast, a refurbished New Amsterdam Theater and a glitzy Disney store, the 1,972-room Marquis is 90 percent full 100 percent of the year. And no company has been more intent on expanding its franchise in the midst of the New York hotel boom. While some people worried about the "Disneyification" of 42d Street, the hotelier has quietly set about turning New York into Marriott City.
Robert Deeley, Marriott's regional lodging developer, is scouting 15 sites in Manhattan, from the financial district to Times Square and the Upper East Side, for hotel deals, according to real estate brokers and developers. The company is building a 385-room, full-service hotel in downtown Brooklyn and has completed a deal to turn an office building at 866 Third Avenue into a 320-room Marriott Courtyard.
Marriott already operates 5,200 rooms at eight hotels in New York City, ranging from the Marquis to the luxurious Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South and the more modest La Guardia Courtyard in Queens. That is 1,200 more rooms than the chain's closest competitor, Hilton Hotels, and two and a half times more than the expanding Holiday Inn chain. Over all, Marriott plans to add as many as 2,000 rooms over the next two years. In most cases, the company owns the hotels; in some cases it is just the operator.
"Marriott is in the leadership position and probably has more rooms in the pipeline than anyone else," said Michael Fishbin, a hotel consultant with the E&Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group. "They have a plan in Manhattan to insure that they remain the dominant player."
Like Disney, Sears, discount department stores and supermarkets that had previously forsaken urban areas for the suburbs -- and now find those suburbs saturated with their own products -- Marriott has gotten downright bullish on New York.
"This is a market that's going to be strong for very many years, because crime is down and cleanliness is up," said Mr. Giesbert, now general manager of the Marquis and vice president of marketing in New York City. "New York is considered the shopping capital of the universe. No other city can offer the same kind of arts, culture and entertainment. Leave alone, it's still the commercial and financial capital of the world."
Marriott's competitors say they are not worried about the company's ambitions, best expressed in a billboard depicting a panoramic New York skyline pierced by a dart, with the tag line: "Chances are you'll hit a Marriott."
"I have the highest respect for Marriott and their aggressive interpretation of the marketplace," said Arthur A. Surin, senior vice president and managing director of Hilton Hotels. "One could argue that as supply increases, we want to be sure that demand does likewise."
"They can't control the market," added Paul O'Neil, president of Sheraton Hotels in New York. "Customer demand drives price. Marriott may be the most aggressive, but everybody's looking to expand."
Marriott's growth spurt has not gone unnoticed, either, by union leaders in New York. Most hotel workers in the city are represented by a union, but Marriott has successfully fended off attempts to unionize the Marquis, and labor leaders are vowing to crack what they say is Marriott's anti-union facade.
Marriott has acquired three hotel operations in recent years -- the Marriott East Side, the Marriott Courtyard in Queens and the Ritz-Carlton -- that are part of a citywide union contract, under which the owners of those hotels are prohibited from actively opposing a union drive, said Peter Ward, president of the Hotel Trades Council.
"We have a neutrality agreement with Marriott under the industrywide agreement," Mr. Ward said. "We've had problems with them in the past, but we fully expect to organize the new properties."
The sudden boom in the hotel business has been fueled by a dramatic rise in tourism that began in 1993. Last year, 30.3 million people visited New York, boosting restaurant and retail sales. In turn, occupancy rates at the city's hotels soared to 81.4 percent in 1996 from 69.2 percent in 1992, and the average room rate rose to $161 a night, from $126 in 1992, even after the city's hotel tax was sliced to 15 percent from 21 percent.
"The city's business-based economy has expanded to encompass an enormous leisure-based sector, which the hotel industry had previously ignored," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center. "As New York becomes much more attractive to the rest of America and to Europeans, the Marriott chain realized it needed a bigger piece of the hotel action in New York."
Still, the growing presence of Marriott and other nationwide chains dismays some people.
"The hospitality industry in New York was best illustrated by the grand traditions of places like the Plaza, the Waldorf, or even the new Four Seasons," said Lee Pomeroy, a hotel architect who had proposed a design for the Marriott Marquis that would not have required demolishing two historic theaters. "Homogenous hotels like Marriott's do not appear to be in the New York tradition of special places for a special city."
In any case, the euphoria over the current hotel market seems to have wiped out memories of 1991, when a recession and the gulf war combined to all but eliminate tourism and corporate travel. Analysts and hoteliers say there is little danger of overbuilding this time, even for an admittedly volatile industry. The high cost of new construction and the paucity of development sites has kept the number of new hotels to a minimum.
"I think we're headed for another record year for New York City hotels," John Fox, a hotel analyst with PKF Consulting, said. "I'm not concerned about overbuilding yet. But if every one of these projects comes to fruition, we may be getting to the point where we have enough rooms."
Analysts and Marriott officials say that the company is in a better position today to deal with the ebb and flow of the hotel market. It offers 10 brands, each aimed at a different segment of the market, from the luxurious Ritz-Carlton to a full-service Marriott hotel to the moderately priced Fairfield Inn and the long-term stay Residence Inn.
"The strength of our hotel company is in its broad base," Mr. Giesbert said. "Something always goes down, but something always goes up. You never become dependent on just one market segment. If you do that, oh my god, the risks are huge."
When it made its decision to build in New York in the mid-80's, Marriott was a much smaller company spread across the country. For Marriott to become a major national and even international hotel company, executives said they thought the company had to develop a major presence in New York because the city is considered one of the international capitals of the world, and Marriott had almost no properties here.
"We wanted to prove that Marriott could work in the center of New York as it had in the center of Des Moines," said one executive who refused to be identified. "We needed a major property in New York."
In recent years, Marriott has added a number of hotels to its stable, including the Marriott Financial Center in 1991. Four years later, Marriott International bought a 49 percent stake in Ritz-Carlton, with plans to take over the entire company and to double the number of Ritz-Carlton rooms by the turn of the century. Earlier this year, Marriott bought the Renaissance Hotel Group, which operates 150 hotels in 38 countries, including the 305-room Renaissance Hotel that sits opposite the Marquis in Times Square.
Mr. Deeley, regional vice president of lodging development for Marriott International, acknowledged that the company was not done with New York. He said he was looking for hotel sites in both Times Square and in lower Manhattan, but he declined to say exactly where.
Real estate executives say that Marriott has talked to Prudential Insurance Company about a site at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue in Times Square for a 350,000-square-foot Courtyard, a limited-service hotel aimed at budget-conscious travelers.
Rather than erect a new hotel, the company has considered using office buildings at 17 Battery and 26 Broadway in lower Manhattan for possible hotel projects, said the real estate brokers, who refused to be identified.
Marriott is also talking with Donald Trump, the owner of 40 Wall Street, a largely vacant office tower in lower Manhattan, about transforming 10 floors in the building into a Ritz-Carlton hotel. If a deal is struck, the hotel would sit within a few blocks of the 517-room Marriott Financial Center and the 843-room Marriott World Trade Center. But a boutique-sized Ritz-Carlton would seek wealthy tourists and top executives rather than business travelers, several executives familiar with the plans said.
"The beauty of the Marriott chain is that they're never going to cannibalize the market," said Steven Witkoff, an owner of the office building at 866 Third Avenue, at 53d Street, where Marriott plans to develop a Courtyard hotel. "I'm only seven blocks from the Marriott East Side, a full service hotel. But I'm going to have a Courtyard, which is targeted at the business traveler."

HEADLINE: IN TOBACCO TALKS, LAWYERS HOLD KEY

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Until two years ago, Maryland's shopping list was like any other state's, with its government seeking bids on data processing, canned fruit and road salt. Then its Attorney General, J. Joseph Curran Jr., went looking for something special: a high-powered product liability lawyer to sue the tobacco industry.
Six law firms submitted bids. But the sweetest came from Peter Angelos, owner of the Baltimore Orioles. Maryland would not have to pay a penny to pursue its claim against cigarette companies for Medicaid money spent on smoking-related illnesses. In return, Mr. Angelos would get a quarter of any spoils. 
 By striking a deal with Mr. Angelos, Maryland joined in a rapidly expanding alliance between state governments and private lawyers. Strapped for money, manpower or expertise, states have periodically hired private lawyers to pursue claims on the public's behalf, but never have the stakes, in money or public policy, been so great as 29 states seeking tens of billions of dollars in Medicaid reimbursement.
In the fight against the tobacco industry, private lawyers have assumed a role of extraordinary influence. With a small group of negotiators meeting in New York City over the last 10 days to settle those claims and others, the lawyers now sit in important positions at the bargaining table where the nation's policies on cigarette smoking may be decided for decades to come.
The talks have moved forward on several issues that could provide a framework for a settlement, said several people familiar with the talks. Some state regulators were briefed yesterday and more may be briefed today about the "timing and potential substance of settlement proposals," said one of those people.
Among the topics on the table are the size and shape of a fund to compensate sick smokers, the nature of restrictions on cigarette marketing and possible restraints on lawsuits against tobacco companies. Most notable among the lawyers playing a decisive role in those discussions are one from Mississippi and another from South Carolina, who together represent about 20 states.
Private lawyers take much of the credit for forcing the tobacco industry to the bargaining table. And on that point they have the backing of many states, which contend that they could not have done without lawyers who were willing to invest so much of their own money fighting such formidable opponents.
But critics, including legal experts and public health advocates, are worried about potential conflicts. Lawyers may be looking for a return on their investment, they say, while the states should be single-minded in safeguarding public health.
"Going to trial is a risk for any lawyer working on a contingency fee, because they put up a lot of money and could end up with zero," said Susan Koniak, a professor of law at Boston University. "But in a settlement, lawyers are guaranteed to get their money back and more, even though that settlement might not be in the public's interest."
The lawyers reject such suggestions. But others fear that some attorneys general will cede too much control of their cases to the hired lawyers. "For a deal to work, the public is going to have to be the winner here, not the lawyers, not the tobacco companies," said David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs.
There are other potential conflicts, too. Some private lawyers involved in talks with the tobacco industry represent not only states, but also individuals. Any financial accommodation with the industry will have to be split between the states and the smokers who have sued or might bring claims in the future.
"These lawyers have interests that may be different from those of the attorneys general," said Geoffrey Hazard, a professor of law at the University of Pennsylvania who specializes in ethics. "They have a lot of money invested in these cases. They represent people who are privately suing the companies, and so they could face conflicts when it comes to dividing up any settlement funds."
Although dozens of law firms are involved in state Medicaid cases, just two firms -- those headed by Richard F. Scruggs of Pascagoula, Miss., and Ron Motley of Charleston, S.C. -- represent some 20 states in the tobacco talks, putting them in a crucial position to influence public health decisions. Mr. Scruggs, Mr. Motley and Joe Rice, a lawyer for Mr. Motley's firm, have been part of a small group of negotiators meeting in New York City with industry representatives to try to resolve legal and regulatory issues.
By retaining lawyers who have profited handsomely from lawsuits over such products as asbestos, the states also have riled businesses. Many corporations, keen to clip the wings of plaintiffs' lawyers, have campaigned for legislation that would limit awards in lawsuits over defective products.
The Texas Association of Business and Chambers of Commerce, for example, is backing legislation that would require regulators to seek the approval of state legislators before hiring product-liability lawyers. In response, the state's Attorney General, Dan Morales, has described the group as a "front" for tobacco companies, a charge the businesses deny.
Because of the expense of litigation against the tobacco companies, many states saw no other choice but to pair up with private lawyers.
"I think the trial lawyers of this country are one of the main reasons we are on the verge of tremendous change for the good," said Arizona's Attorney General, Grant Woods.
The interests of state regulators and plaintiffs' lawyers in the war against tobacco first merged in 1993. At the time, the Mississippi Attorney General, Michael C. Moore, was approached by Michael Lewis, a former classmate at the University of Mississippi Law School, who suggested that the state litigate over an untested theory: that cigarette manufacturers were obligated to reimburse the states for Medicaid money spent treating smokers for tobacco-related illnesses.
To spearhead a possible case, Mr. Moore turned to Mr. Scruggs, a longtime friend who made a fortune suing asbestos companies. Mr. Motley, who also made his fortune in asbestos litigation, was soon brought into the Mississippi case.
Mississippi filed its case in 1994, and Minnesota followed a few months later. There, Minnesota's Attorney General, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, chose Michael Ciresi, a lawyer in Minneapolis who had successfully sued the A. H. Robins Company over the Dalkon shield, an intrauterine contraceptive device.
As other states joined in, their methods of selecting plaintiffs' lawyers varied. Like Mississippi, some allowed their attorney general to make that choice. Others, like Maryland, issued bid requests. Some, including Arizona, specifically excluded the Attorney General from the selection process.
As more states jumped into the litigation, a bidding war among plaintiffs' lawyers broke out. Last summer, Steve Berman, a plaintiff's lawyer from Seattle, made a successful bid to represent Arizona by offering to take only 18 percent of any winnings. By January, when Indiana contracted with Mr. Berman and lawyers associated with him, they agreed to take a maximum of 13 percent of any money recovered from the tobacco companies.
Mr. Scruggs and Mr. Motley, who made joint bids in many states, grabbed the greatest share of the states' action. "They brought economies of scale to the litigation," said Tom Miller, the Attorney General in Iowa, which hired Mr. Motley's firm to press its Medicaid claim.
Some people wonder whether Mr. Scruggs and Mr. Motley wield too much influence in settlement negotiations with the tobacco industry.
"Plaintiffs' lawyers have been instrumental in initiating these cases," said Mr. Ciresi, the lawyer for Minnesota who maintains that other states and their outside legal advisers are pressing too eagerly for a settlement before major issues are adequately addressed. "However, clearly it raises public policy implications when one firm represents a dozen or more states."
Mr. Scruggs said that he did not foresee any problem in representing so many states because he was seeking a nationwide resolution of a long-running conflict over smoking. And he contended that plaintiffs' lawyers, by investing their money in Medicaid cases, had already benefited the public by forcing cigarette companies into substantive negotiations.
"Public health groups have been around for 40 years," he said, but lawsuits handled by plaintiffs' lawyers are "the only thing that has brought these people to the table."
The pace of the negotiations is picking up as the start of Mississippi's Medicaid case against the cigarette industry -- the first in the nation -- is due to start in early July.
Several of the lawyers representing states, including Mr. Ciresi, Mr. Motley and Mr. Scruggs, declined to comment specifically on the negotiations. But two people familiar with the talks said that one proposal now under consideration would bar current or former smokers from bringing class-action lawsuits and would prevent them from collecting punitive damages.
The cigarette industry is also seeking to limit lawsuits from those who start smoking in the future. Under a plan being discussed, companies would only be liable if they sold an adulterated product, if a smoker's injury resulted from a violation of Federal regulations or if it was found that smoking caused diseases not currently associated with it, two people familiar with the talks said.

HEADLINE: Stopgap Spending Provision Stalls Flood Relief Measure

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Billions of dollars in flood relief for the upper Plains remained bottled up today, held hostage to several unresolved issues including an impasse between the White House and Congressional Republicans over a provision intended to prevent Government shutdowns during budget battles.
House and Senate negotiators worked to narrow their differences and approve an emergency $8.4 billion spending bill before Congress left for a weeklong recess in the next few days. 
 But the anti-shutdown provision proved a major obstacle. It would provide automatic stopgap spending at this year's levels if regular appropriations bills had not been approved when the next fiscal year starts on Oct. 1.
Republicans want the provision to spare them a repeat of the political black eye they suffered with the Government shutdowns in 1995.
President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, however, are reluctant to go along, because in practice the freeze would amount to a cut in education and social programs for which the President just won more money in the separate balanced budget deal. For that reason Mr. Clinton has vowed to veto any spending bill with such a provision.
Some lawmakers said this and other disputes could prevent Congress from passing the spending bill before the break. The measure includes $5.5 billion in relief to disaster victims, giving residents in soggy Minnesota and the Dakotas more reason to fume at the Federal Government's delay in dealing with their plight.
"Can I go home this weekend?" Representative John R. Thune, a South Dakota Republican asked Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who as head of the Appropriations Committee is the lead House negotiator.
"Yeah, if you want to get scalped," Mr. Livingston told his freshman colleague in a brief exchange in the Capitol this afternoon.
Mr. Livingston suggested tonight that if the sticking points were not resolved by Thursday, the disaster relief might be stripped out of the larger bill and considered separately.
The dispute over the stopgap spending measure was just one of a handful of issues that held up the overall spending bill.
Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee and is the Senate's lead negotiator, insisted that the bill include a provision to retain states' rights to build roads through protected Federal lands.
The Administration says the proposal would clear the way for building close to a million miles of roads across national parks, wildlife refuges and other Federal lands, mostly in Alaska, Utah and Idaho.
Critics contend that under the provision, remote rights of way such as dog-sled paths and hiking trails could be expanded into two-lane highways. Mr. Clinton has threatened to veto the spending bill over this provision.
Mr. Stevens denied any scheme to pave over Alaskan wilderness, saying the provision was essential for economic development in his state.
Administration and Congressional negotiators met for two hours today, and Mr. Stevens voiced optimism that at least a temporary resolution could be reached.
Another obstacle negotiators had not agreed on was a Commerce Department plan to use a method of counting known as statistical sampling when it conducts the census in 2000.
The Administration favors sampling as a way to increase the census's accuracy in counting minorities and other groups that are usually undercounted. Some Republicans believe this would give Democrats greater representation in areas where such voters live.
Negotiators made progress on other issues, agreeing to finance $1.9 billion in Pentagon peacekeeping costs in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf region.
And lawmakers added $76 million for the Women, Infants and Children Nutrition program, and extended Supplemental Security Income benefits to elderly non-citizens through Sept. 30. Without this provision, last year's welfare law would strike as many as 500,000 people from the rolls as of Aug. 22.
Negotiators also agreed to allow American sportsmen who legally killed polar bears in Canada before April 30, 1994, to import their trophies for a $1,000 import fee. Proceeds will go toward polar bear preservation efforts.
As many as 100 polar bears are now in cold storage in Canada, some for as long as 20 years, because United States law had prohibited their import.

Reformist Hand Is Visible In Russian Budget Plan
Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin urged Parliament to slash spending on the military and state-subsidized industries to make up for a gaping revenue shortfall in this year's budget. His plan explicitly rejected printing more money and reflected the influence of reformers in President Boris Yeltsin's cabinet. A1
 
Brazil Favors Second Terms
Brazil's Senate voted overwhelmingly in favor of a constitutional amendment that would allow the president, state governors and mayors to run for second terms. The amendment must pass a final Senate vote, set for early June. The amendment was the first bill presented by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso after he was elected to a first term three years ago. A3 

Turmoil Across Argentina
Cities and towns across Argentina have been rocked by often violent protests against the market reforms of President Carlos Saul Menem's Government, which have tamed inflation but have led to record levels of unemployment. Riot police officers clashed with tens of thousands of people and arrested hundreds. A3
 
British Meet With Sinn Fein
British officials met in Belfast with leaders of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, and discussed the possibility of a new cease-fire that would allow Sinn Fein to participate in peace talks. Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, Mo Mowlam, and the head of the Sinn Finn delegation, Martin McGuinness, both doubted a cease-fire could be arranged by June 3, when formal talks resume. A9
 
New Party in South Africa
Roelf Meyer announced that he was forming a new political movement in South Africa that would focus on matters of concern to both black and white voters: housing, health care, jobs and fighting crime. Mr. Meyer, a chief negotiator during the country's peaceful transition from white supremacist rule, was dismissed two weeks ago from a key post in former President F. W. de Klerk's National Party. HEADLINE: Albert's Accuser in Virginia Faces Criminal Charges of Her Own

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The woman who accused Marv Albert, the NBC Sports announcer, of assault and battery and forcing her to perform oral sex is facing a criminal charge herself.
According to allegations in police and Superior Court records in the District of Columbia, on three occasions the woman called a former boyfriend who lives in Washington and threatened to kill him, his current girlfriend, his dog and then herself. 
 The charges against the woman were first reported by WRC-TV, an NBC affiliate in Washington, which made the court records available today to The New York Times.
The woman, 42, a resident of nearby Arlington, Va., made the calls March 13, according to a police report that quotes the former boyfriend.
The woman has accused Albert of assaulting her in an Arlington hotel room on Feb. 12. Albert has denied the allegations and said in a statement issued Tuesday that he was confident he would be exonerated.
Albert, 53, was indicted by a grand jury on Monday. A police detective testified that the woman had told the police that Albert threw her on a bed in the hotel and forced her to commit sodomy.
She said Albert had invited her to his hotel room after he had provided the play by play at a basketball game earlier in the evening. A police spokesman said that the woman "had 10 or 12 severe bite marks on her back, big red welts."
The woman was arrested near the apartment of her former boyfriend on March 29 and charged with making threats. The court papers indicate that at that time she had been unemployed for about a month, after having worked five years as a night hotel manager.
The records also indicated there were no other charges pending against her and she had no prior convictions in the District.
The woman was upset by the breakup and by the fact that the man was not taking her with him on vacation, the police report says.

HEADLINE: Abortion Opponents Begin Hunt for 3 Votes

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Abortion opponents are already remapping their seemingly nonstop Congressional campaign to abolish what they call partial-birth abortion, focusing on a handful of senators they think might change their votes to help them prevail over President Clinton's opposition.
The likely targets of stepped-up advertising include Senators Bob Graham of Florida, Max Cleland of Georgia, Dale Bumpers of Arkansas and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, all Democrats, as well as Senator Susan Collins, a freshman Republican from Maine. All voted against the ban on Tuesday, when the measure was approved 64 to 36, but they are perceived as vulnerable, either because of pressure in their home states or because they have been wrestling with their votes. 
 "There's a debate going on between some of these senators and their own consciences," said Gary Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, which has lobbied intensively for the ban. "We're hopeful that debate will continue and that fear of unemployment will move three more votes."
That is the number needed to override an expected Presidential veto.
Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, which has also been lobbying for the ban, said his organization would continue with a three-pronged approach.
First, Mr. Reed said, "You frame the issue in terms of an inhumane, indefensible procedure that even the American Medical Association has condemned, and you stay on that message and you never get taken off it to talk about the health of the mother or any other rabbit trail that takes you off-message."
He said his group's state and local chapters would organize around the schedules of pivotal senators and attend all of their town meetings, picnics and parades. And, Mr. Reed said, they would continue radio advertising.
In the abortion procedure, which doctors call intact dilation and evacuation, a fetus is partially delivered and its brain is vacuumed out so the skull can be collapsed and the head can be delivered.
The House, which needs to reapprove the measure because the Senate made some changes in it, expects to vote in early June, shortly after members return from the Memorial Day recess. The bill then goes to the White House, where President Clinton has promised a veto.
That sets the stage for both houses of Congress to try to override Mr. Clinton. The House already passed the measure with five votes more than needed for an override, and is expected to do so again.
The Senate has debated and banned the procedure three times. Each time, the ban has gained more votes, 54 in 1995, 58 in 1996 and 64 on Tuesday. But it has never received the 67 votes needed to override a veto. Abortion opponents hope they can do so this year by keeping the pressure on and the momentum up.
Mr. Bauer said, "We even send faxes and letters into the offices of the stalwarts who oppose us, even when you aren't going to change your mind, it still makes you nervous to get all these letters."
While maintaining that there was momentum, Mr. Reed acknowledged how difficult it might be to extract three more votes, in part because it seems that after three debates and three votes, all the arguments have been made.
"At this point, you've gotten every vote of everyone who wants to be with you," Mr. Reed said. "Now it's only a reluctant vote and a tough vote and someone who may resent that you got their vote."
