HEADLINE: Foreign Energy, Domestic Politics;
Burmese Project Tests Unocal Resolve

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Ever on the hunt for rich discoveries abroad, American oil companies have long had to factor in fears about the unstable nature of foreign governments when considering huge investments in capital and equipment. But now the companies are finding that politics back home is the new focus of risk.
The threat of unilateral economic sanctions, typically directed by Washington at governments accused of human rights violations, has become big enough to cast a shadow over investment decisions stretching from Southeast Asia to West Africa to the Caspian Sea, oil executives and other industry experts say. 
 No company has exposed itself more to the new unknowns than the Unocal Corporation. In an industry that is rapidly directing its investment focus offshore, Unocal has staked more of its future on overseas projects than anyone else, concentrating on Asia. Last November, it even sold its refineries, gas stations and other assets on the West Coast to free capital to invest in the region.
It has placed its biggest bet so far in Myanmar, where it is part of an international consortium that is investing $1.2 billion to develop the Yadana natural gas field. And while the field will not start operating until next year, Unocal's presence in Myanmar has already become a case study in the politics and pressures that are increasingly affecting the energy industry.
Last month, the Clinton Administration approved the use of sanctions against Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, under legislation that the President signed last fall.
Even so, Unocal will remain in business there. The sanctions, which went into effect yesterday, prohibit American companies from making new investments in the country, which is ruled by a military dictatorship that human rights groups have called one of the most repressive regimes in the world. The Yadana project as well as lesser ventures involving Texaco Inc. and the Atlantic Richfield Company, or ARCO, are shielded from the sanctions by a compromise in the legislation that exempts existing investments.
Unocal helped win that compromise through intense lobbying. It also succeeded because Washington appears to be more willing to talk tough than to act directly against the interests of American business. But Unocal's experience has exposed just how many problems sanctions can create and underscored how readily constituencies can rise up to pose obstacles to projects thousands of miles away.
While it is hanging on to its project, Unocal is also stuck with its critics, risking a legacy of bad publicity along with any profits. Just last month, the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union joined the forces opposing the company, upset that Unocal's concentrated move abroad was unnecessarily costing American jobs.
And Unocal's victory is only partial and may not be permanent. Opponents are backing new legislation to force the company out of Myanmar. Even if that effort fails, Unocal will not be able to start new projects that may look promising.
"In the oil and gas business, you continually have to reinvest as you draw down reserves," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "This is an ongoing process and not just a one-time thing."
The result is a war for public opinion -- and lawmakers' support -- that is still being waged in the halls of Congress, in letter-writing campaigns and on the Internet. The fighting even reached the City Council in New York, where a bill was passed last week that would prohibit the city from buying products from any company doing business in Myanmar. The measure becomes law in 45 days unless Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vetoes it.
What seems clear is that what is happening to Unocal will happen to other American oil companies. For example, in the Caspian Sea area, which has become one of the hottest regions for new development, "American companies are already feeling some reluctance to go into partnerships because of the sanctions that have already been applied and might be applied in the future," Mr. Lichtblau said.
Julia Nanay, a director of the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington, added: "It's devastating for the U.S. oil industry. There is an increasing list of countries that are potential targets. It's having a terrible effect." Potential flash points include Nigeria and Indonesia, experts say.
Whatever the risks and the complications, the industry has little choice but to pursue most projects overseas because that is where the oil is and because American consumers show no signs of trimming their demand.
Indeed, Unocal went into Myanmar in 1993 knowing there were troubles ahead, but saw the potential rewards as justifying the risks.
Company executives recognized that they were in for a long battle with rights groups, Unocal's president, John F. Imle Jr., recalled, but were determined to see it through. " 'This project is going to happen -- there is no way they are going to stop it,' " he recalled the Unocal executives as saying.
The critics were not long in coming. Grass-roots groups of students and immigrants, linked through the Free Burma Coalition, spread reports of rights abuses by the military regime, known as the State Law and Order Restoration Council. The regime, which seized power in 1988, gained notoriety by refusing to recognize the 1990 election victory of the opposition party, whose leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was put under house arrest for years.
The critics accused Unocal of everything from condoning the laundering of drug money -- Myanmar is the world's biggest producer of heroin -- to using slave labor. Through demonstrations and the Internet, the groups picked up support, including backing from American student groups.
By last year, Senators Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, were pushing for an immediate ban on investments, including existing projects.
Unocal fought back, denying the critics' charges and noting Washington's inconsistency when pressing for democratic reforms abroad. China, a neighbor of Myanmar's that is also accused of rights violations, has escaped Washington's wrath because it has far more commercial importance, Unocal argued. Just this week, President Clinton began a campaign to renew China's most-favored-nation status despite growing anti-China sentiment.
Top Unocal executives made the rounds in Washington, arguing that if the company was forced to quit the gas project, it would be replaced by another big foreign company, just not an American one. After all, Unocal said, it is not even the biggest participant in the project, which is led by Total S.A. of France. What's more, the company said, its presence is helping the 35,000 people who live near the project area, where Unocal and Total are spending $6 million on education, medical care and other improvements.
To spread the message, Unocal made use of such prominent lobbyists as Tom Korologos, who served as an adviser to Bob Dole in his campaign for President.
Unocal also sought to influence public opinion by having the Washington office of Edelman Public Relations Worldwide write to professors and other foreign affairs experts, urging them to support its position.
Outside Washington, Unocal worked to head off resolutions in a number of cities that would have barred local governments from doing business with companies that invest in Myanmar.
Without any direct interest in Myanmar, most oil companies kept a low profile in the dispute. One senior executive, who asked that his name not be used, said that they saw little chance to sway public opinion in a debate that pitted economic interests against human rights.
The battle in Washington reached a crucial point last summer. A breakthrough for Unocal, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., occurred when it persuaded one of its home state Senators, Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat, that any sanctions should be prospective in nature. The company argued that divestment would not only cost Unocal jobs at home, but would also lead to cutbacks at the many domestic contractors that it used.
In an interview yesterday, Senator Feinstein said she was concerned that foreign companies would have stepped in if Unocal had been forced to divest itself of its interest last summer.
"There's constantly the problem with these things -- that we can shoot ourselves in the foot and not accomplish what we hope to accomplish," she said.
Equally important to the outcome was the fact that the Clinton Administration also did not want to order divestiture, and worked with William S. Cohen, then a Republican Senator from Maine and now the Secretary of Defense, on a compromise proposal.
Ultimately, Senators Cohen and Feinstein co-sponsored legislation that limited sanctions to future investments and then only if the Myanmar regime committed further rights abuses, a judgment that would be left to the President.
Senator Feinstein said yesterday that she wanted the legislation to provide some flexibility, including time to see if the regime in Myanmar would open a dialogue with dissidents. "I wanted to create an opportunity for leverage," she said.
The legislation became law in the fall. In January, Unocal signed a contract with the state-owned Myanma Oil and Gas Enterprise to expand its operations. (Texaco and ARCO also signed deals in the wake of the legislation.)
Finally, in April, President Clinton, under renewed pressure from rights groups, activated the sanction provisions. The Treasury Department is expected to issue rules for carrying them out in the next two weeks.
Meanwhile, Unocal is proceeding with the Yadana project. Most of the gas to be produced by four offshore platforms will be delivered to Thailand through a 416-mile pipeline. Some will flow to Myanmar, which will reap $150 million or so a year in revenues by about 2000.
Unocal holds a 28.26 percent interest in the project. Total has a 31.24 percent interest. The PTT Exploration and Production Public Company of Thailand holds 25.5 percent and Myanma Oil has 15 percent.
Will Unocal and the other American companies in Myanmar get to finish their projects? Roger C. Beach, Unocal's chairman and chief executive, is cautiously optimistic. The fact that President Clinton has moved to stop future investments, he said, has taken the pressure off Congress "to implement a more onerous sanction bill."
But there are many minefields ahead. How will the Presidential order be carried out? Will opposition from the oil workers' union catch fire? Will events in Myanmar force Washington's hand?
Industry executives say that questions like these are going to come into play in one place after another where American companies will be searching for oil and gas. And while the industry has been slow to recognize the threat until now, Mr. Beach said that was no longer the case.
Six months ago, Mr. Beach said, "we were the Lone Ranger crying in the wilderness." Now, he said, "a lot of companies are sitting up and taking notice."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Sharply vs. Yen, But Is Weaker Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against the yen yesterday after comments by a Japanese finance official and fell against the mark on signs of economic vitality in Germany.
The Japanese official, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said interest rates would not be rising in Japan for a while, meaning that returns for investors would continue to be higher in other countries. The remarks were viewed by currency traders as further evidence that Japan wanted the rapid appreciation of the yen to ease. 
 Against other currencies the dollar ended mixed, but it rose solidly against the British pound, which fell broadly on reports of an economic slowdown in Britain and rumors that the Bank of England governor, Eddie George, might resign.
The dollar traded as high as 116.23 yen in intraday dealings before settling in New York at 115.96 yen, up from 114.18 yen Wednesday and up more than 5 yen from the five-month low of 111.98 yen touched briefly on Tuesday.
Against the mark, the dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7005 marks before retreating to settle in New York at 1.6934 marks, down from 1.6946. The pound cost $1.6234, down from $1.6450.
Traders said a main theme that emerged in the foreign-exchange market as the day progressed was the surprising strength in the mark, which rose against all major currencies and the yen in particular. The mark's gain also indirectly contributed to the yen's weakness against the dollar.
The catalyst for the mark's advance was a report from the Ifo economic research institute in Munich that showed a sharp rebound in business confidence last month.
The mark was further helped by news from the German central bank that the broadest measure of Germany's money supply, known as M-3, rose at a substantially slower pace in April than in March, diminishing fears of inflationary pressure.
The pound's decline reflected weak economic data in Britain and rumors that Mr. George, who has taken a tough stance against inflation, would not be reappointed next year. The Government said retail sales barely rose in April and economic growth in the first quarter was lower than previously thought.

HEADLINE: Times Appoints Managing Editor and 2 Deputies

 BODY:
Appointments of a managing editor and two deputy managing editors at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor.
Bill Keller, 48, the paper's foreign editor and winner of a Pulitzer Prize for foreign correspondence, will become managing editor at the end of September. He will succeed Gene Roberts, 65, who is completing a three-year tour as managing editor while on leave as a journalism professor at the University of Maryland. 
 The deputy managing editor for news will be Gerald M. Boyd, 46; the deputy for operations will be John M. Geddes, 45. Both positions are new. Mr. Boyd is an assistant managing editor of The Times, and Mr. Geddes is business and financial editor.
Mr. Keller, who becomes the No. 2 editor on The Times's 1,000-member news staff, joined the paper in 1984 as a Washington correspondent. In 1986 he was transferred to Moscow, where he was promoted to bureau chief in 1989. He won his Pulitzer Prize for coverage of the Soviet Union that year. He became Johannesburg bureau chief in 1992 and foreign editor in 1995.
Earlier Mr. Keller worked for The Dallas Times Herald, The Congressional Quarterly Weekly Report and The Oregonian, in Portland. He graduated from Pomona College in California.
Mr. Boyd was The Times's metropolitan editor from 1990 until his promotion to his present post in 1993. On the metropolitan desk, he managed a staff of more than 100 reporters and editors. He oversaw The Times's coverage of the World Trade Center bombing, which won a 1994 Pulitzer Prize, the paper's first for local reporting in more than two decades.
He was born in St. Louis and attended the University of Missouri. He worked for 10 years at The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, where he rose to Washington correspondent assigned to Congress. He joined The Times in 1983 and covered the Reagan and Bush Administrations as a White House correspondent. In 1977 he founded the St. Louis Association of Black Journalists and was its first president. He attended Harvard in 1980 as a Nieman Fellow.
Mr. Geddes, an economics graduate of the University of Rhode Island with a master's degree from the University of Wisconsin, joined The Times as business editor in 1994. Earlier he spent 13 years with The Wall Street Journal in several assignments, including Bonn bureau chief, managing editor of the paper's European edition and national news editor in New York.
He was previously a Bonn economics correspondent for The Times and a New York and Bonn reporter for A.P.-Dow Jones.
Mr. Roberts, who leaves The Times this fall, was a national correspondent for the paper and then its national editor before going to The Philadelphia Inquirer as executive editor in 1972. His staff at The Inquirer won 17 Pulitzer Prizes in his 19 years there.
He joined the University of Maryland in 1991, and started his leave to return to The Times in 1994.
Mr. Keller will work as Mr. Roberts's deputy for an orientation period starting July 1.

HEADLINE: Swiss Reject As One-Sided Study by U.S. Of Nazi Ties

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERN, May 22

 BODY:
Two weeks after the Clinton Administration accused Switzerland of prolonging World War II by acting as a banker to Nazi Germany, the authorities here tartly rejected the accusation today as "unsupported" and termed Washington's assessment "one-sided."
The Swiss statement, read to reporters by Foreign Minister Flavio Cotti, reflected an increasingly prickly sense of embattlement here since the publication on May 7 of a sweeping United States Government report chronicling purchases of gold by Switzerland from Hitler's Germany and the postwar refusal of Swiss commercial banks to offer access to deposits made by European Jews who later died in the Holocaust. 
 The report also accused the Swiss authorities of reneging on a 1946 agreement on the liquidation of hundreds of millions of dollars of German assets wanted by the United States and its allies as war reparations.
The underlying theme of the United States accusations is that the vaunted neutrality of Switzerland cloaked an amorality, not only in financial affairs but also in such decisions as the one in 1942 to turn back tens of thousands of Jewish refugees at its frontiers.
The report, which stunned many Swiss, seemed all the more damning to them since it followed what are viewed here as a series of efforts to atone -- even if belatedly -- for its wartime behavior. In recent months, Switzerland has set up a formal inquiry into its relationship with the Third Reich, started a fund currently valued at $120 million to help Holocaust survivors and proposed a $4.7 billion investment fund to help victims of suffering of all kinds, including those scarred by the Holocaust.
While it went further than in the past in acknowledging what it termed errors, the Swiss Government statement today said it "regards the representation of Switzerland as the bankers to the Nazis as a one-sided, blanket judgment."
"It is suggested," it continued, "that the neutral countries may have prolonged the Third Reich's ability to wage war by trading with it. At least based on the report's contents this comment must be referred to as unsupported."
Months of criticism of the Swiss record have left some Swiss battling to reconcile the disclosures about their trading with Nazi Germany against a more heroic national myth of wartime resistance to Nazism's tide.
The debate has split the small nation between young and old and between those who see the wartime conduct of Switzerland as a justifiable defense of its sovereignty and survival, and those who see the country's wartime behavior as little more than collaboration covered up by postwar propaganda.
Today's Swiss statement acknowledged that there had been "questionable deals which did not affect the survival of Switzerland" between Swiss business interests and the Nazi regime. "Neutrality led to a difficult tightrope walk between adaptation and resistance," the Swiss statement said. "Today we know that this also led to mistakes. The fainthearted refugee policy concerning Jews was inexcusable. In the business and financial sector concessions were sometimes made to the Axis powers which are very hard to comprehend today in view of the inner convictions of the population and measured by absolute necessity."
But the statement renewed the Government's bottom-line argument that the survival of Switzerland, which spent most of the war surrounded by Axis powers, was at stake.
"That Switzerland traded with the Axis powers as well as the Allies was a question of national political and economic survival," the Swiss response said. "Only hypotheses are possible to question whether Switzerland in 1943-1944 would have been in a situation to break off business ties with the Axis powers without provoking the risk of an invasion."
In the immediate postwar era, Switzerland struck the 1946 agreement with the United States, France and Britain to resolve some of the wartime financial issues. It agreed to pay the equivalent at that time of $58 million in gold to offset purchases of looted Nazi gold, and, in return, the Allies agreed to lift a variety of economic restrictions on Switzerland in the United States.
The 1946 agreement also committed Switzerland to liquidating millions in German-owned assets, depicted in Washington as Nazi loot but said by Swiss historians and officials to include prewar assets held by German citizens, including some German Jews. According to the American report, Switzerland never respected the agreement. Referring to that accusation, the Swiss statement said, "We must judge more critically from today's outlook the liquidation of German assets."

HEADLINE: U.S. Budget Surplus Hit Record in April

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The United States Government posted a record budget surplus in April as the vibrant economy generated strong revenue, according to the Treasury.
The surplus totaled $93.94 billion, the Treasury's monthly budget statement said. That is up from last April's surplus of $72.4 billion, the previous record. 
 The Treasury is benefiting from reduced spending and higher tax collections, stemming from the fast pace of economic growth, relatively low unemployment and booming financial markets.
The Treasury typically reports a deficit most months because it spends more money than it receives and borrows the rest. Monthly surpluses usually come in January, April, June and September, which coincide with quarterly tax payments. Individual income tax returns are also due in April.
In April, revenues were 12.3 percent higher than in April 1996, at $228.59 billion. Spending, meanwhile, was 2.7 percent higher, at $134.65 billion.
Since the Federal fiscal year started on Oct. 1, the budget deficit has totaled $16.9 billion, down from the first seven months of the 1996 fiscal year, when the shortfall totaled $55.31 billion.
The White House economist, Janet Yellen, recently said the budget deficit for the current fiscal year could fall to as low as $70 billion. In the 1996 fiscal year, the deficit was $107.33 billion, the lowest in 15 years.

COMPANY: TREASURY DEPARTMENT (US)

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Increase by 5,000

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits rose by 5,000 last week but remained in a range that analysts say suggests continued moderate job growth.
New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 322,000, up from a revised 317,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department said today. Claims for the week that ended on May 10 were initially estimated at 319,000. 
 Many analysts had expected an increase of about 6,000 last week.
Claims jumped into the mid-300,000 range several weeks ago after auto strikes and Midwestern floods. But they fell back to 317,000 in the week of May 10.
The four-week moving average edged up by 750 last week, to 333,250.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Welcomes Back Labor Negotiator as a Top Aide

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Randy L. Levine, who has served as chief labor negotiator for both the Giuliani administration and Major League Baseball, is returning to City Hall as a deputy mayor in the next few days, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.
Mr. Levine will be in charge of planning and economic development -- a post that has been vacant since Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter left in February to run the Mayor's re-election campaign -- and will also be responsible for City Hall administration during the months in which Mr. Giuliani will be campaigning around the city. 
 Randy M. Mastro, currently the Deputy Mayor for operations, will remain in his position supervising city agencies, the Mayor said. At least for now, there will be no First Deputy Mayor, a title the Mayor bestowed only on his friend Peter J. Powers, who left city government for the private sector last year.
Mr. Levine, who negotiated baseball's new collective bargaining agreement with the players, will remain a $1,000-a-month consultant to the game's Player Relations Committee while serving as Deputy Mayor. He is expected to return to his baseball position next year whether or not the Mayor is re-elected.
The arrangement, approved by the city's Conflicts of Interest Board, provides that Mr. Levine recuse himself from any city decisions regarding the Yankees, the Mets, or Major League Baseball. Mr. Levine, who said he would honor the provision, said he may be available to help on stadium negotiations if necessary and if allowed to by the board.
In his new position, Mr. Levine will supervise the Economic Development Corporation and the Department of City Planning, negotiating with developers and businesses and working to foster economic growth. He will also supervise the city's Office of Labor Relations, the agency that he led until September 1995.
His responsibilities over administration are slightly more ambiguous. The Mayor described him as "Mr. Inside," handling the inner workings of City Hall in a role traditionally handled by the chief of staff. Bruce Teitelbaum, the acting chief of staff, may eventually receive the permanent title, but will report to Mr. Levine. City officials said the Mayor wanted to have a trusted friend like Mr. Levine in charge of City Hall during the summer and fall months while he is out campaigning.
As the city 's Labor Commissioner, Mr. Levine negotiated several major agreements with municipal labor unions that became the foundation of the Giuliani administration's plans to reduce the size of local government. Most notably, he lowered the city's work force by 17,000 by paying workers severance money to leave. But he also attracted criticism from outside budget monitors like the Citizens Budget Commission for not seeking greater productivity savings from unions.
Mr. Levine, 42, who made $600,000 a year as baseball's lead negotiator, will be taking a substantial pay cut to return to government, earning $138,000 in his new position. But his agreement with baseball provides that he can return to his former job and salary within one year.

HEADLINE: Dow Has Decline of 32.56 on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, hurt by profit taking and by rising bond yields.
Bond prices declined yesterday on concerns that the economy was growing fast enough to compel the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The slump in prices pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.98 percent from 6.95 percent and closer to 7 percent, a level that tempts some stock investors to buy bonds. 
 "The market's just flat-out overvalued, and bonds are pretty attractive," said Arthur Micheletti, chief investment strategist at Bailard Biehl & Kaiser, who keeps both bonds and stocks in his $1 billion portfolio.
The Dow Jones industrial average declined 32.56, to 7,258.13, led by shares of I.B.M., which fell from its first record close in almost a decade.
Small stocks rose for a fourth consecutive session, and the Russell 2000 index reached a record for the first time since Jan. 22, climbing 1.40, to 371.46. The Russell 2000 is now up 2.4 percent on the year.
After months when the companies in the Dow industrials trounced their smaller counterparts, some investors said small stocks might finally break out of their inertia.
"It's a rotation of the marketplace, and it's going to go on for a while," said F. Van Kasper, president of his own investment firm, with $2.2 billion in assets. "Investors are driven to smaller stocks by slower earnings growth in the bigger companies and, I think, a reduction in the capital gains tax." Congress and President Clinton agreed to reduce the rate at which gains from investments such as stocks are taxed as part of this month's budget agreement.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 3.69, to 835.66. General Electric, Coca-Cola and the Exxon Corporation, the three largest members of the index, declined the most. The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.15, to 1,372.60. Trading was light, with just 441.3 million shares changing hands. The average for a full day of trading during the last three months is 485 million. Few investors made big bets, with little in the way of earnings reports and a three-day weekend approaching.
Initial offerings enjoyed success in the market yesterday. Hartford Life Inc. surged 3 7/8, to 32 1/8, a day after raising $655.6 million by selling 23 million shares. Summit Holding Southeast rose 3 1/8, to 14 1/8, after selling five million shares to the public late Wednesday. On Tuesday, ABN Amro Holding N.V. sold 14 million American depository receipts to investors at 18 1/2 each. Yesterday, the A.D.R.'s rose 3/16, to 18 7/8.
I.B.M. fell 2 5/8,, to 172 1/2. Among other Dow stocks, Philip Morris Companies. rose 1/4, to 44 3/4, after the Senate rejected an amendment to raise the tobacco tax.

HEADLINE: YELTSIN DISMISSES 2 MILITARY CHIEFS FOR RESISTING CUTS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 22

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed the two top leaders of Russia's military today, lambasting them for resisting spending cuts and dragging their feet on restructuring of the armed forces.
The abrupt ouster of Defense Minister Igor N. Rodionov and Gen. Viktor N. Samsonov, the Chief of the General Staff, reflects the growing power of reform-minded officials who insist the primary threats to Russia are economic, not military. 
 The Kremlin took the extraordinary step of inviting a Russian television crew to cover President Yeltsin's scathing assessment of Mr. Rodionov's tenure.
"I rank your work very low," Mr. Yeltsin declared at the start of the meeting of top defense advisers. "Russia cannot afford the current expenditure. You must have pondered over how to get out of this situation and reorganize the army, but you did not do that."
Mr. Yeltsin reaffirmed his intention to slash military spending. He said Russia currently spends about 5 percent of its gross domestic product on the military and that the expenditures needed to be reduced to 3 percent to 3.5 percent by the year 2000.
Mr. Yeltsin's evident commitment to slash military spending suggests that Moscow's objections to the expansion of NATO stemmed more from wounded pride and political considerations then fear of a military threat from the West.
Although the Russian military has been steadfast in its opposition to NATO expansion, there was no sign that this played a role in today's dismissals.
Today's move is part of a broader shift over economic policy in which reformers have pushed for budget cuts, a lower tax-burden on industry and tighter controls on energy and transportation monopolies.
In another announcement that reflected the expanding role of economic reformers in Mr. Yeltsin's Government, the Kremlin said today that Boris Y. Nemtsov and Anatoly B. Chubais would become members of Mr. Yeltsin's Security Council, which handles foreign policy and military matters. The two men are leading architects of the effort to reshape Russia's economy.
The unceremonious departure of Mr. Rodionov, Russia's second post-Communist Defense Minister, comes just 10 months after he was appointed to Russia's top defense post at the urging of Aleksandr I. Lebed, the former national security adviser who was himself dismissed after losing a Kremlin power struggle.
When he was appointed, Mr. Rodionov was touted as a thoughtful, uncorruptable general, despite his role as the top commander of Soviet troops that cracked down on peaceful protestors in Georgia in 1989.
But Mr. Rodionov's go-slow approach on reform and his strategy of publicly belitting his own military's abilities in an effort to gain more funds strained relations with Kremlin officials.
Earlier this month, while Mr. Rodionov was meeting with military officials in Japan and the United States, Kremlin aides assembled a plan to cut Government spending by 20 percent. It calls for the Government to reduce subsidies to industry and agriculture and to slash military spending from about $18.2 billion to $14.5 billion.
Mr. Rodionov, a general who retired from the military after being appointed Defense Minister, would have been a poor spokesman for the new budget plan, which the Yeltsin Government this week urged Parliament to adopt.
Not only did the new budget represent about half the funds he had sought, but Mr. Rodionov had no plan to restructure the ailing military within the new financial constraints.
Economic reformers expressed the hope that the dismissal of Mr. Rodionov would finally open the door to long-delayed reform of the armed forces, an initiative that has thus far involved more Kremlin talk than action.
"Military reform itself will be regarded as an essential way to make the armed forces combat-ready rather than a nuisance," said Yegor T. Gaidar, the pro-free market economist and former Prime Minister.
But the dismissals were denounced by hard-liners in the Parliament, who charged that the Yeltsin Government was simply looking for a more pliant defense chief who would put a good public face on military cuts.
Mr. Lebed denounced the move as a "good maneuver to distract public opinion from the failure of military reform in the country."
The ouster of Mr. Rodionov has potentially important significance for the Russian military planning. Mr. Yeltsin picked Gen. Igor D. Sergeyev, the head of the Strategic Rocket Forces, which controls's Russia's long-range nuclear arsenal, to serve as the acting Defense Minister.
Aleksei Arbatov, a military specialist and Parliament deputy from the liberal Yabloko party, described General Sergeyev as one of Russia's most intellectual and technically versed generals.
General Sergeyev's elevation is an indication of the increasing emphasis Moscow is giving to nuclear weapons to maintain its standing as a superpower. A staunch supporter of new strategic arms accords with Washington, the general could help the Kremlin in the uphill battle to win Parliament's approval of the treaty.
Col. Gen. Viktor Chechevatov, the commander of Russia's Far East military district, was mentioned in some Russian press reports as a possible successor to General Samsonov, though there was no official confirmation.
A politic general who gained favor with the Kremlin last year by withdrawing his candidacy for President in favor of Mr. Yeltsin, General Chechevatov is less highly regarded by advocates of military reform and comes from a military district with a reputation for corruption. The main military task of the new defense leadership will be to create a smaller and more effective military and not simply a shrunken version of the old Soviet armed forces. The main political task will be to accomplish that without causing social unrest.
"For us, the question of military reform is primarily the question of saving the armed forces and defense industry," Mr. Arbatov said. "It is 90 percent a question of internal stability and security and only 10 percent a question of foreign security."
The new military structure will have to be established at a time when the stature of the armed forces appears on the decline in comparison to the Interior Ministry, whose troops maintain order at home.
Mr. Rodionov himself voiced this complaint in a recent interview with the newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets, asserting that the Interior Ministry troops were better equipped and that the politicians appear to fear internal threats more than external ones.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Puts Off Effort on Trade Accords

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Just two weeks after traveling to Mexico and Central America to renew his pledge to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement, President Clinton has bowed to political necessities and postponed until the fall his effort to get authority to negotiate further trade accords, Administration officials said today.
For several weeks, Mr. Clinton and economic advisers have been engaged in lengthy behind-the-scenes negotiations over legislation, which has become entangled in sharp disagreements over whether trade accords ultimately benefit American workers. Mr. Clinton's trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, has spent nearly every day in recent months attempting to patch together a coalition that could support the legislation, but has been unable to bridge fundamental disagreements that cross party lines. 
 Technically, the legislation would only result in the inclusion of Chile in Nafta, the free trade accord that links Canada, the United States and Mexico. But much more is at stake. The legislation would also permit a wide variety of negotiations on other trade accords around the world, from agriculture to trade in such services as accounting and engineering.
Latin American nations have said that the passage of the negotiating authority is a test of whether the United States is serious about pursuing a free trade area throughout the Americas, and some Latin leaders have charged that the United States is backing away from its commitments to free trade. The White House has denied that, but all year it has declined to draft a bill for Congress to consider because of divisions within the Democratic Party over what it would contain.
Under pressure from labor unions, for example,the Democratic minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, has announced his opposition to the effort, turning it into one of several points on which he disagrees with Vice President Al Gore. The two men are considered likely opponents for the Democratic nomination for President three years from now.
This afternoon, Ms. Barshefsky and Erskine Bowles, the White House chief of staff, met with Congressional leaders in an effort to obtain an agreement to get some form of negotiating authority through Congress by the end of the year. Next spring, Mr. Clinton attends a meeting of Latin American nations on trade.
The trade-agreement authority that Mr. Clinton is seeking is known in the parlance of Capitol Hill as fast track authority. It empowers the Administration to negotiate trade accords that Congress can then approve or disapprove -- but cannot amend. The theory is that if Congress could change the contents, negotiations would never end.

HEADLINE: Fed Rate Rise On March 25 Was Backed By Full Panel

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in raising the overnight bank lending rate on March 25, though they have decided to take a more relaxed stance toward inflation in the interim, minutes of the meeting showed today.
The Federal Open Market Committee's 10-to-0 vote increased the target for the Federal funds rate a quarter percentage point, to 5.50 percent, the first rate increase in two years. However, the members also relaxed their position in favor of raising the interest rate target again, and adopted a "neutral" monetary policy directive, minutes of the March meeting showed. That stance was borne out this week, when the Fed left the rate unchanged at its most recent meeting. 
 The shift to a neutral stance suggests that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, could have been breaking from his normal pattern of lifting rates in a series of steps and, instead, firing just a single warning shot.
When the Fed last raised rates, in 1994 and early 1995, it did so seven times, doubling the overnight rate to 6 percent. Still, with the unemployment rate at a quarter-century low of 4.9 percent in April, many analysts expect that the Fed will still take interest rates higher, possibly at the next meeting of the policy-making committee, on July 1 and 2.
The March minutes showed that some central bankers wanted to maintain a tougher stance on inflation and raise the Federal funds rate higher than 5.50 percent. "In their view, the outlook called for vigilance," the minutes showed.
While not all of the committee members were willing to go that far, all agreed that the time was ripe for "a pre-emptive policy action that would head off any pickup of inflation," according to the minutes. Moreover, "it was noted that a shift to a tighter policy stance would seem to pose little risk to the expansion" of the economy, the minutes said.
By changing the interest rates it controls, the Fed's actions translate into lower or higher borrowing costs on everything from credit cards to mortgages and business loans -- and directly influence economic activity, though often with a lag of many months.
The committee meets eight times a year at intervals of five to eight weeks. Deliberations are held in secret and minutes are released several weeks later. Full transcripts of the meetings are made available after five years.

HEADLINE: Raises Arrive At Bottom Rung Of Labor Force;
For Now, Earnings Gap Has Stopped Widening

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
In late afternoon, as most people are heading home from work, a large, unmarked room on an upper floor at PNC Bank is just starting to buzz with activity. Among the rows of women in cubicles is Caren Good, 34, tall, thin and stylishly groomed. New to the job, she carefully slips checks into a whirring machine with her left hand, while her right records the amounts on a keyboard. Her evening's work will show up later as thousands of entries on bank statements wrapped around packets of canceled checks. For this she earns $7.10 an hour, her highest wage in years.
Ms. Good, whose schooling ended with high school graduation in 1981 and whose working years have been spent mostly in short-lived clerical jobs or occasional gigs as a poorly paid model, is among the millions of Americans whose earnings have seldom ranged far above the minimum wage, now $4.75 a hour. Caught up in forces that have made incomes increasingly unequal, people at the bottom of the wage scale like Ms. Good have slipped farther behind nearly every year for more than two decades. 
 Over the last 18 months, however, the wages at this low end have picked up. Today, they are rising significantly faster than the inflation rate -- faster, in percentage terms, than the pay of middle-income Americans.
For all their lack of skill, low-wage workers are in great demand today. The strong economic growth of recent years is beginning to pay off for them more than at any time since the 1970's. In a tight labor market -- the unemployment rate is 4.9 percent -- those who employ fast-food workers, retail-store counter people, office clerks, factory assemblers, telephone order takers, gardeners, maintenance workers and others like them are being forced to lift the bottom of the pay scale. An increase in the minimum wage, the first since 1991, has also raised the wages of low-paid workers.
The higher wages, in turn, are helping to draw into the labor force more black women, older men, immigrants, teen-agers and Hispanic Americans. In the last year, the labor force -- people working or seeking work -- has grown by 2.7 million, the largest annual gain in over a decade and more than twice the increase in the working-age population. The surge of new workers, particularly at the low end, tends to keep wages from rising faster than they already are, and helps to explain why inflation has remained at a mild 3 percent a year or less.
The big unknown now is whether the wage gains at the low end will continue long enough to make a meaningful difference for millions of Americans struggling to make ends meet, or whether the raises will be washed away in the next wave of economic distress.
"The primary issue here is that you are six years into a recovery, with 23-year lows in the unemployment rate, and it is not surprising that you finally see some wage improvement at the low end," Rebecca Blank, a Northwestern University labor economist, said. "I want to see how much of the gain is permanent and how much disappears in the next recession."
The improvement means that the yawning gap in earnings between the high school and college educated has stopped widening. If the upturn holds, the gap might even begin to shrink, taking some of the sting out of income inequality as a political and social issue, and providing opportunities to advance for people like Ms. Good.
"I have my foot in the door at PNC," she said, the PNC Bank Corporation being the first big company to suggest that she might have a future there. "When you have your foot in the door, you can transfer to another department. I would like to do that."
Still, the rise of America's low-wage workers is at an early stage and must go a long way to make up for all the ground lost. Starting in the mid-1970's, the weekly earnings of full-time adult workers in the bottom 10 percent of the wage distribution fell by nearly 20 percent, when adjusted for inflation. The improvement over the last 18 months has restored only about one and a half percentage points of that loss. In the late 1980's, a similarly long economic expansion also began to raise low-end wages, but by much less than now. And even that modest gain was wiped out by the 1990-91 recession.
What is striking now is that the wages of those at the bottom are advancing at a faster pace than most other workers. In the first quarter of the year, the weekly wages of full-time, adult workers in the bottom 10 percent of the wage spectrum rose at a 4.4 percent annual rate, bringing the top of that group to $259 a week, or $6.48 an hour. By comparison, the median weekly wage -- midway in the wage scale -- rose 3.5 percent during the same period, to $536 a week, or $13.40 an hour. A similar pattern had already emerged in the fourth quarter, and is also evident in hourly wage data including part-timers.
"The way it works in a recovery," said Alan Krueger, a Princeton labor economist, "is that the lower end overheats and sometimes bids up wages in the middle. This time the lower end is bouncing back, but the middle is still lagging."
Job insecurity plays a role. For people in the middle, employers can be more selective in giving raises, selecting some and passing over others. Those passed over are less likely than in the past to find new jobs that pay as well, in wages and benefits, as the ones they already have.
Low-paid workers are not so insecure. They have little to lose. Already scraping the bottom of the wage barrel, and usually without benefits, they are more willing to jump to another unskilled job that pays an extra 50 cents or $1 an hour. So when they are in short supply, employers find themselves bidding for these workers, and pay at the bottom begins to rise across the board.
To be sure, better-paid workers in short supply -- computer programmers, technicians and the like -- have enjoyed significant pay increases recently. But when employers raise wages to attract people with these skills, the raises often fail to spread to others at the next desk if they can be more easily replaced, like insurance actuaries or lawyers.
Companies that employ large numbers of low-wage workers are having to search harder and pay more to fill their ranks. Take the Aramark Corporation, a Philadelphia-based company that employs 100,000 people in the United States -- up 10,000 in the last year -- to operate food services at schools, hospitals and other workplaces. Roughly one-fourth of its work force earns the minimum wage, which rose to $4.75 an hour from $4.25 last year. Another fourth earned at least 25 cents above the minimum, and when the minimum went up, they got raises too.
"You get a ripple effect in a tight labor market," said Brian Mulvaney, Aramark's executive vice president for human resources, "because any differential you have built in, to reward people, you have to maintain to keep them."
The bidding for workers at the low end gave Ms. Good a leg up on the wage scale. She had been earning $6.10 an hour feeding documents into a Xerox machine at a copy center when she learned of openings for check processers at PNC. She jumped two months ago for $1 an hour more. "I decided that standing over a copy machine, you are not learning anything," Ms. Good said.
But if she had made the same switch to PNC just 18 months earlier, her wage would have dropped. PNC then paid its check processors $5.85 an hour, the same wage rate it had paid for the previous 10 years. By late summer of 1995, however, Jean A. Evans, chief of the check processing operation, realized that her workers were slipping away to a rival bank down the street for better pay.
"We lost our best people," Ms. Evans said. So PNC increased the wage in late 1995 to $7.10 an hour, plus a piece-rate incentive that allows the fastest workers to average as much as $12 an hour. That stopped the defections for a while, but Ms. Evans's shop, normally 100 people, is short-staffed again, and she wonders if another raise might be necessary. "We are going to sit down and see what we have to do to retain people," she said.
Rising turnover, and the higher minimum wage, also pressured Wendy's International Inc., the fast-food chain, into providing fatter paychecks for its 55,000 employees, most of them counter people. Since 1995, wages for these workers have risen by nearly 4 percent a year. Beginning pay is now $5.65 an hour. "Our turnover has dropped significantly," said Dennis Lynch, a Wendy's spokesman.
Similarly, Manpower Inc., which places 180,000 temporary workers each week, has raised everyone's pay by 5 percent in the last six months, and more than that for those earning under $8 an hour, according to Mitchell Fromstein, Manpower's chairman. Manpower also scours more intensively than in the past for workers. Its recruiters, and those of other temp agencies, visit community colleges, high schools, churches, housing projects, charities and refugee programs.
Not every employer of low-end workers is raising wages, of course. The influx of immigrants into Southern California and southern Texas, for example, inflates the supply, helping to keep down wages in those areas. And the low-end labor shortages are not as acute in the Northeast as they are in the South and Midwest. What is more, not every employer is responding to the tight labor market by raising wages. Instead, for example, Marriott International Inc., the hotel and restaurant company, invests in training those who apply for jobs as kitchen workers and maids at less than $7 an hour.
"The people we are talking about are really unskilled; not just low-skilled but unskilled people who can't get better wages," said Brendan Keegan, Marriott's senior vice president for human resources.
Low-wage jobs are often entry ports to middle-income pay. But companies that offer these jobs still find themselves bidding up their entry-level wage, to get enough workers. Sometimes that even happens retroactively, as MaryEllen Poellnitz discovered last spring.
When AT&T advertised for operators for its expanding customer service center here, Ms. Poellnitz, 32, jumped at the opportunity, even though the starting pay of $232 a week, or $5.80 an hour, was less than the $6.50 an hour she earned as a clerk at a TV cable company.
"I was unimpressed with myself, sitting at a counter taking customers' payments," said Ms. Poellnitz, who has some education beyond high school and was willing to take a pay cut to grab the lower rung of the ladder at a major corporation.
AT&T's customer representatives respond to questions over the phone about long-distance bills, rates, service problems and the like. The job is unionized, and those who pass a test and survive probation can count on step-by-step wage increases dictated by a labor contract. After four years, an employee makes more than $500 a week. Even so, AT&T could not attract enough qualified beginners at a starting wage of $232 a week. So, just as Ms. Poellnitz came aboard, it jumped the starting pay two steps, to $296.
"To my surprise, on my first day, I found myself making $7.40 an hour," Ms. Poellnitz said.
The AT&T customer service office here hired 386 operators last year. "If we had not raised the pay," said Joan Astrabe, a human resources executive, "we might have only been able to hire 250 in that time span."

HEADLINE: Price Decline In Treasuries Continues

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday for the second consecutive session, as investors grew concerned that the economy was still growing fast enough to move the Federal Reserve toward another increase in interest rates.
Bond prices were weaker after the Labor Department reported that weekly initial unemployment claims rose by 5,000, to a seasonally adjusted 322,000. Analysts had forecast 324,000 claims, which was more or else in line with expectations. Still the numbers are an indication that the labor market continues to be tight, leaving the door ajar for future inflation and higher rates. 
 "The unemployment claims this week were watched more closely than normal by financial market investors primarily because these figures were compiled during the week that the monthly employment surveys are conducted," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
"It's important to note that the data on initial unemployment claims was contaminated during April to early May by the impact of auto strikes and the Midwest floods. However, data over the past two weeks has been mostly devoid of these effects and has provided strong hints that the economy may not be slowing down as quickly as many credit market investors had anticipated."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32 , to a price of 9517/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.98 percent, from 6.95 percent on Wednesday. For the long bond, the yield has not been over 7 percent since the end of April.
Prices received a little support from the late afternoon release of the minutes of the Fed's policy-making meeting on March. Policy makers were unanimous in voting for a quarter-point increase in the target for the Federal funds rate. Some traders and analysts had been concerned that policy makers were divided.
Still, for bonds to rally substantially, market participants will have to see convincing evidence the economy will slow to a point that is sustainable, but without inflation. So far there is little evidence that inflation is quickening.
One indication that inflation remains constrained came yesterday when the Labor Department also reported that the 12-month changes in its experimental Consumer Price Index were running three-hundredths of a percentage point less than the official index.
Today, trading of Treasury securities, mortgage securities, corporate bonds, municipal bonds and secondary money market is expected to close early, at 2 P.M. Bond markets will also be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day.
Treasury auctions will commence on Tuesday, with the regular weekly bill auction, followed on Wednesday by the sale of two-year notes and five-year notes on Thursday. In when-issued trading late yesterday the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.27 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.58 percent. Both were up slightly from the previous day.
Yesterday the Treasury auctioned $13.75 billion of new one-year bills at an average rate of 5.55 percent, down from 5.72 percent the month before. Analysts said retail demand was good, but that the total number of bids was down slightly. Following are the results of that auction:

HEADLINE: Elbridge Durbrow, U.S. Diplomat, Dies at 93

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Elbridge Durbrow, a retired Foreign Service officer who served in Moscow as the wartime Soviet ally turned into cold-war antagonist and who later led the United States Embassy in South Vietnam at the onset of America's longest war, died last Friday at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif.
He was 93. 
 The cause of death was complications from a stroke, his family said. Mr. Durbrow, a longtime resident of Washington, moved to California in 1985.
Mr. Durbrow's diplomatic career spanned 38 years, most of them spent in Europe and Southeast Asia. He retired in 1968.
President Eisenhower named him Ambassador to South Vietnam in 1957, when Indochina meant little to Americans. The French, trying to recover and hold their colonies in the region, had been routed at Dien Bien Phu by the Viet Minh forces three years earlier.
Since then, Washington's determination to hold Communism at bay in the region had led to a low-profile political and military presence in newly divided Vietnam; little of it was noticed at home. For Mr. Durbrow, however, Saigon quickly turned into a diplomat's bad dream.
On the one side, he had to deal with the authoritarian regime of Ngo Dinh Diem and a morass of corruption and ineffectiveness that was hard to overlook. Another bane was American military leaders who considered themselves omniscient.
Disgruntled senior Vietnamese officers sought to enmesh him in their cabals against President Diem. He refused, telling them that Washington was supporting the Diem Government, at least for a while, even as he shed his own illusions about the situation.
In April 1961, President Kennedy formed a committee to chart an array of programs, from military to economic support to social reform, that would keep Diem in power and the Communists away from South Vietnam. Kennedy also replaced Mr. Durbrow because Diem had tired of his aloofness.
In the late 1940's, Mr. Durbrow had been posted to the Soviet Union at an equally dramatic moment in history, when the cold war nearly froze East-West relations for decades. The situation he encountered was a prelude to the confrontation that took shape in Southeast Asia 10 years later.
After serving as chief of the Eastern European division of the State Department in Washington in the mid-1940's, he spent two years in Moscow as Counselor of Embassy and Deputy Chief of Mission from 1946 to 1948 under Ambassador Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, succeeding George F. Kennan. It was his third tour in the country, and he strongly warned his superiors of Soviet expansionism and efforts to divide and subvert the West.
Born in San Francisco, Elbridge Durbrow was a philosophy graduate of Yale University. He continued his studies at Stanford University, at the University of Dijon in France, the Academie de Droit International de la Haye in the Netherlands, the Ecole Libre des Sciences Politiques in Paris and the University of Chicago, where he studied international economics and finance.
He started his career as a vice consul in Warsaw in 1930 and rose through the ranks in Bucharest, Moscow, Naples, Rome and Lisbon. He was an American delegate to the 1944 Bretton Woods Conference that chartered the World Bank.
He also served as a delegate to the NATO Council in Paris from 1961 to 1965, and as State Department adviser to the National War College in Washington and the Air University at Maxwell Air Force Base, Ala., the post from which he retired in 1968.
After that he wrote and lectured on foreign affairs. In the 1970's he was chairman of the American Foreign Policy Institute and a director of the Freedom Studies Center in Boston, Va.
Mr. Durbrow is survived by his wife of 32 years, Benice Balcom Durbrow; two sons from an earlier marriage, Chandler W. 2d of Arlington, and Bruce C. of High Point, N.C., and a granddaughter. His first wife, Emily Moore Durbrow, died in 1964.

HEADLINE: Albright Outlines Moves to 'Renew Momentum' in Bosnia

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Fearing that the American-led efforts to forge peace in the Balkans have stalled, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States remained deeply committed to supporting a stable, multi-ethnic state in Bosnia and announced a series of symbolic, if small, initiatives to revive the peace efforts.
In testimony on Capitol Hill this morning, in an interview with editors at The New York Times and in a speech tonight to military officers in New York City, Ms. Albright sought to "renew the momentum" of the peace accords negotiated in Dayton, Ohio, in 1995 to end more than three years of civil war involving Bosnia's Muslims, Croats and Serbs. 
 Nearly a year and a half after NATO troops arrived in Bosnia to stop the fighting, Ms. Albright said the leaders of the Muslims, Croats and Serbs needed to do more to keep the promises they made in Dayton, or face political and economic isolation.
"Since Dayton was signed, our initial security goals have been achieved and economic reconstruction has begun," Ms. Albright said before the Senate's appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations. "Unfortunately, there remain important areas where progress has been slow due to the failure of many Bosnian leaders to embrace true political and social integration."
Ms. Albright said she believed that the NATO troops remaining in Bosnia -- now about 30,000 soldiers, 8,500 of whom are Americans -- could do more to support implementation of the peace accords by increasing security to allow refugees to return to their homes and by rebuilding telecommunications links.
Ms. Albright, however, did not call for any real expansion of the NATO force's role, and other Administration officials later dismissed any notion that the force would have a new mandate or stay beyond the deadline of June 1998 set by President Clinton.
The new programs follow a review of the Administration's efforts in Bosnia, ordered by President Clinton in March amid concerns that the integration of Bosnia into a peaceful nation was lagging. The Muslim and Croat factions, which are supposed to have cemented a federation by now, and the Serbs have failed in varying degrees to carry out important parts of the accords, blocking the return of refugees to their homes and harboring war criminals.
The plans announced today -- like the opening of American liaison offices in Mostar, which is under Croatian control, and Banja Luka, which falls in Serbian territory -- followed a series of announcements and other steps in recent weeks.
On Tuesday, for example, the White House announced the appointment of a special envoy, David Scheffer, to focus attention on the issue of war crimes. The International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague has indicted 75 people for committing atrocities during the civil war, but has brought only eight into custody.
Although the Administration has discussed creating a special police force to capture indicted criminals, Ms. Albright announced no new plans today.
"We are still looking at a number of options," she told the editors at The Times. "I'm sure you can understand that discussing them is not very helpful."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Falls 32 Points, But Small Stocks Gain
Stocks were generally lower as bond yields rose and investors took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 32.56 points, to 7,258.13, led by shares of I.B.M., which fell from its first record close in almost a decade. 
 But small stocks rose for a fourth consecutive session, and the Russell 2000 index reached a record for the first time since Jan. 22, climbing 1.40 points, to 371.46. [Page D6.]
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond pushed nearer to 7 percent, ending up three-hundredths of a percentage point at 6.98, as prices fell. Investors grew concerned that the economy was still growing rapidly enough to nudge the Federal Reserve toward another increase in interest rates. [D6.]
 
Apple to Give Newton Autonomy
Apple Computer said it would spin off the division that produces the Newton hand-held computer into a wholly owned subsidiary, presumably to better attract a buyer for it. The move allows Apple to concentrate on its core computer business, Apple executives said, at a time when the company's Macintosh line continues to lose market share to personal computers running Microsoft Windows. [D16.]
 
Fed Unanimity on Rates
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in raising the overnight bank lending rate on March 25, though they have decided to take a more relaxed stance toward inflation in the interim, minutes of the meeting showed. [D5.]
 
Shifts in Exchange Rules Proposed
The S.E.C. is setting forth broad ideas for changing the way it regulates stock markets, in an effort to catch up with the innovation and entrepreneurship that have transformed the landscape of American stock markets.
Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
Oppenheimer in Executive Shift
Oppenheimer, which has had unsuccessful talks recently with several potential suitors, has shuffled its senior management and formed an operating committee in an attempt to recognize a new generation of executives and to organize its businesses better. [D2.]
 
Seeking Ways to Lift Digital
Holders of 30 to 40 percent of the stock of Digital Equipment plan to meet to discuss ways to bolster the shares, which have fallen 36 percent in the last 12 months. [D2.]
 
Dollar Rebounds Against Yen
The dollar rose sharply against the yen after comments by a Japanese finance official and fell against the mark on signs of economic vitality in Germany. The dollar, after its recent slide, was nearly 2 yen higher. [D4.]
 
Progress in Tobacco Talks
Negotiators in the tobacco settlement negotiations have taken steps toward a resolution of important regulatory and legal issues, but significant hurdles remain, people close to the talks said. [A24.]
 
Concerns Raised on Patents
A doctor who received a patent for noticing the relationship in tests of pregnant women between levels of a hormone and the incidence of a congenital birth defect has created a dispute by demanding royalties based on the finding, and has raised questions about the use of patent laws in medicine. [A1.]
 
Documents Lost in Fire
Bear Stearns, which has been asked to provide information to investigators and lawyers examining the collapse of A. R. Baron, was among the companies that lost records in a fire at a document storage center in Pennsylvania early this month. But the company said the loss of the records should have no effect on the investigations. [D5.]
 
Delay for 'Fast Track'
President Clinton has bowed to political necessities and decided to postpone until the fall his effort to get so-called fast track authority to negotiate trade agreements, Administration officials said. [D13.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Russian Military Leaders Are Dismissed by Yeltsin
President Boris N. Yeltsin scathingly dismissed Russia's two top military leaders, criticizing their resistance to budget cuts. The head of Russia's long-range nuclear arsenal was named acting Defense Minister, replacing Igor N. Rodionov, whose dismissal was televised as a warning to other officials. A1
 
Surprise Contender in Iran
To the surprise of the ruling mullahs in Iran, Mohammed Khatami has drawn huge crowds and emerged as a serious liberal contender in the presidential election today. No real competition had been expected for Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, the Speaker of the Parliament and the mullahs' choice. Iran's president has limited powers compared with the unelected "supreme leader," Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. A1
 
Albright Announces Sanctions
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced sanctions against two Chinese companies and a handful of Chinese executives, saying they had knowingly helped Iran make chemical weapons. She said there was no evidence that the Chinese Government had been involved in the companies' efforts to export chemicals and equipment. A1
 
NATO to Expand Role in Bosnia
NATO forces in Bosnia will add non-military tasks to their duties, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said. The change is part of an effort to renew the momentum of the peace accords signed in Dayton, Ohio, eighteen months ago. Ms. Albright is to travel to Bosnia next week. A6
 
Swiss Reject U.S. Criticism
Swiss Foreign Minister Flavio Cotti rejected as "unsupported" and "one-sided" the accusations made in a United States Government report that Switzerland had undermined its vaunted neutrality and prolonged World War II by acting as a banker to Nazi Germany. Mr. Cotti conceded that mistakes had been made but said that his country's national survival had been at stake. A7
 
Israel Plans Arab Housing
The Israeli Interior Ministry said it had approved construction of 3,400 homes in an Arab village next to a hill in Jerusalem where work on a new Jewish neighborhood has seriously frustrated Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. The Government had pledged to approve Arab housing when it authorized construction of the Jewish settlement, known as Har Homa. Palestinian officials dismissed the Israeli announcement as propaganda. A10
 
Sainthood for Jewish-Born Nun
Pope John Paul II formally approved sainthood for Edith Stein, a Jewish-born nun killed in a Holocaust gas chamber. No date for the canonization ceremony, which would make her a Roman Catholic saint, was announced. The nun's beatification in 1987 drew criticism from some Jews, who said the Nazis had killed her because of her Jewish heritage, not because of her Catholicism. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A14-24
 
Embattled Air Force Pilot Accepts General Discharge
The country's first female B-52 pilot, First Lieut. Kelly Flinn, will accept a general discharge from the Air Force rather than face a court-martial for adultery, lying and other charges that could have sent her to prison for up to nine and a half years. Air Force officials said a general discharge meant that Lieutenant Flinn would almost certainly not be allowed to fly in the Air Force Reserves and would be required to pay back about $20,000 of the cost of her Air Force Academy education. A1
 
McVeigh's Defense Begins
The lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh opened their defense by raising the possibility that someone else had been the bomber in the attack on the Federal Building in Oklahoma City and had been killed in the blast. Oklahoma's medical examiner testified that that he had never been able to link a severed leg found at the scene to a body. A1
 
Spending Plans Rejected
The Senate voted down the last major amendment to the budget resolution, a proposal to spent more money on Federal highway projects, as it moved toward a Congressional commitment to balance the Federal budget by 2002. A measure to set aside $5 billion to rebuild crumbling schools was also defeated. A21
 
Astronaut Set for Return
Jerry M. Linenger expects to walk off Atlantis when he returns to Earth on Saturday after four months on Mir. NASA wants astronauts to be carried off the shuttle after long stretches in space because that makes scientific tests easier to carry out. But only one of Dr. Linenger's three predecessors aboard the Mir was carried from Atlantis. A23
 
Times Lists Staff Changes
Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor of The New York Times, announced the appointments of a managing editor and two deputy managing editors. Bill Keller, 48, the foreign editor and a Pulitzer Prize winner, will become managing editor at the end of September, succeeding Gene Roberts, who will end his leave from the University of Maryland and return to teaching journalism there. The deputy managing editor for news will be Gerald M. Boyd, 46, and the deputy for operations will be John M. Geddes, 45. C31
 
Laurels for Longevity
Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, who, at age 94, is already the oldest person ever to serve as a member of Congress, will become the longest-serving Senator in the chamber's history on Sunday. Senator Thurmond says he feels like a "million dollars" but would vote for term limits without compunction. A22
 
Cigars Appealing to the Young
More than one-quarter of all boys and girls 14 to 19 years old smoked at least one cigar last year, a Federal study found. The findings astonished public health advocates, who immediately called for Federal warning labels on cigars. A24
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Mobsters' Guards Accused Of Making Jail Cushy
Federal officials announced the arrest of 20 people in a sting operation into corruption among guards at a new Federal jail in Brooklyn. The authorities said corrupt guards let top mobsters turn the jail into a social club, where they plotted crimes and sipped vodka and wine. A1
 
Teacher Accused of Sex Abuse
A 41-year-old Brooklyn music teacher, Michael Williams, was charged with sexually abusing a 13-year-old female student in his locked classroom last month. It was the second case in a week in which officials said administrators in a New York City public school had failed to respond promptly in a case involving charges of sexual abuse of a student. The earlier case occurred in Queens. B1
 
Pataki Yields to Indians
Governor Pataki abandoned his effort to collect taxes on gasoline and cigarette sales on Indian reservations. The move was criticized by owners of small businesses operating outside reservations, who have long complained that selling tax-free goods gaves Indian competitors an unfair advantage. But Indian leaders said the move affirmed the tribes' status as sovereign peoples. B1
 
Harassment Suit Is Filed
The Federal Government filed a sexual harassment suit against Sidney Frank Importing and All States Promotions, a liquor importer and a marketing firm, both based in New Rochelle, N.Y., charging that top executives kissed, fondled and made improper advances to more than 100 women employees. A spokesman for the companies denied the charges. B6
 
Slain Officer Is Buried
A funeral was held in West Babylon for Officer Anthony Sanchez, the first police officer killed on the job this year. His wife, Elizabeth, speaking of their 7-year-old son, said, "John says farewell to the daddy taken from him too soon, who gave him so much love." B3

Dispute Over Prenatal Test
A company headed by Dr. Mark Bogart, Biomedical Patent Management, is demanding that labs across the country pay large royalties when they conduct a prenatal test he says is based on work he patented in 1986. Some labs said they might have to stop doing the test. A1
 
Low-End Wages on the Rise
Wages at the low end of the economic scale have spurted up in the last 18 months. D1

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
$10 Million Gift to Princeton

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
A $10 million gift from the Leon Lowenstein Foundation will enable Princeton University to establish a center specializing in finance and economic public policy, university officials announced yesterday. 
 The center will be named after Robert A. Bendheim, the foundation's president and the former president of M. Lowenstein Corporation, a textile manufacturing company. Mr. Bendheim graduated from Princeton in 1937.

HEADLINE: Landlords Settle Race Discrimination Claim

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors said yesterday that the owners of an Upper East Side apartment building had agreed to pay $15,000 and promised to avoid discriminating on the basis of race to settle a Federal housing complaint.
The complaint contended that the owners of the building, at 242 East 77th Street, would not rent an apartment in 1994 to Michael Porter, who is black, until he obtained a financial guarantor for the $1,099-per-month rent. 
 Mr. Porter, who at the time was a manager with Nynex, earned a salary of more than $60,000 and had a good credit history. He said that when he questioned the requirement, he was told that his income was not adequate and that the decision was final.
The Government asserted in its complaint that the "decision not to rent to Porter unless he provided a guarantor was based on Porter's race." The complaint said that in 1994 the owners had rented at least 11 similarly priced apartments to tenants who were not black. The tenants had incomes similar to or lower than Mr. Porter's, and no guarantors were required.
Before reaching the settlement, the owners, including Lee Pokoik, the Lee Pokoik real-estate company and three other people, denied the Government's assertions in court papers. They said that they did not treat Mr. Porter differently because of his race, and that they imposed financial restrictions uniformly on applicants when there were questions about their ability to afford the rent.
Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District, issued a press release in which she said that the case "clearly shows the Government's commitment to vigorously pursue landlords who would impose different terms and conditions for rentals on minority applicants."
In reaching the agreement, the owners did not admit any liability, and one of their lawyers, Maxwell D. Weinstein, sharply disputed the Government's view of the case.
Mr. Weinstein said that his clients' decision to pay the settlement to Mr. Porter was strictly an economic one and that it "was a form of coercion, legal coercion, to settle this case." He criticized the United States Attorney's office for issuing a press release, calling it irresponsible and inappropriate.
Ms. White, in a statement, responded that the "papers filed in court speak for themselves." She said it was her office's duty to "investigate civil rights complaints within our jurisdiction and enforce the law."
