HEADLINE: U.S., Asserting Iran Link, Bars 2 Chinese Firms

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The United States has imposed sanctions against two Chinese companies and a handful of Chinese executives, accusing them of knowingly helping Iran make chemical weapons, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced today.
The sanctions are the first imposed by the United States in an effort to stop any organization in China from helping to spread chemical weapons. [In a statement early Friday, one of the companies denied the charges.] 
 Ms. Albright said the United States had no evidence that the Government in Beijing was involved in what she said were the companies' illegal efforts to export chemicals and equipment for use in Iran's weapons production.
But a senior Administration official acknowledged that Washington had raised concerns with the Government about the companies' activities for at least a couple of years, "both in expert discussions and at the highest levels."
"The Chinese Government knew of our concerns and knew of these activities," the official said today, speaking on condition of anonymity. "The Chinese Government has taken no immediate steps against these particular entities and companies to this point."
The officials said the companies, which are now banned from trading with the United States, are not state-owned enterprises, but it was not clear whether any of their executives might have connections with the Chinese Government or the military, as is the case in many Chinese companies.
The sanctions come at a sensitive time in the relationship with China, particularly as President Clinton seeks to renew China's trade status in the face of deepening skepticism in Congress over human rights and, increasingly, weapons proliferation.
Ms. Albright announced the sanctions before the Senate's appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, under questioning by Senator Robert F. Bennett, a Republican of Utah, about the extent of China's complicity in delivering weapons to Iran and Pakistan.
"We hope that this action on our part will serve to encourage the Chinese Government to improve its export controls so that these kind of entities are prevented in the future from assisting Iran's chemical weapons program," Ms. Albright said.
The sanctions were imposed under the Chemical and Biological Weapons Control and Warfare Elimination Act of 1991, which forbids companies from exporting various chemicals and equipment to countries identified by the United States as terrorist nations. The list includes Iran, Libya, Syria, North Korea, Iraq and Cuba.
Iran's chemical weapons program -- and its increasing efforts to develop missiles capable of launching them -- have been a major concern in Washington. Despite various efforts by the United States to undercut it, officials here say, the program has continued to expand, though one official said today that Iran had not yet built a missile with a chemical-weapons payload.
The two Chinese companies sanctioned are the Nanjing Chemical Industries Group and its export division, the Jiangsu Yongli Chemical Engineering and Technology Import/Export Corporation. An official here described them as "key players" in China's chemical industries.
The five executives sanctioned worked for other companies but acted individually to smuggle weapons to Iran, according to the State Department.
The Administration also imposed sanctions against a company in Hong Kong, Cheong Yee Ltd., that an official described as a "middle man" in transactions between Chinese companies and Iran.
Taken together, the companies do about $2 million a year in business with the United States. The sanctions remain in place for at least a year, after which they can be reviewed.
Ms. Albright and the other officials did not discuss the specific accusations against the companies or executives, saying they were based on classified intelligence information. But in a statement the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said they met the law's threshold of "knowingly and materially" contributing to Iran's chemical weapons program.
One official said the companies had shipped glass-lined vessels crucial for the manufacture of those weapons, as well as "sufficient quantities" of three chemicals -- thionyl chloride, dimethylamine and ethylene chlorohydrin -- used to make chemical weapons.
Many of the chemicals covered under the law have benign uses, but the officials said the United States had clear evidence that the companies and executives involved knew the intended use and helped forge documents to get them through China's export controls.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Denial by Chinese Company
 BEIJING, Friday, May 23 (Reuters) -- One of the Chinese companies being punished by the United States denied today that it had sold to Iran material that could be used in making chemical weapons.
"We have never sold any chemicals, chemical products or equipment to Iran," an official of Jiangsu Yongli Chemical said in a telephone interview from Nanjing.
Jiangsu Yongli exports mainly to Southeast Asia, the official said, and abides by Government export regulations.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Little Changed On a Shortened Trading Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday in a shortened trading session ahead of a three-day holiday weekend.
The 30-year bond was unchanged from Thursday at a price of 9517/32 to yield 6.98 percent. 
 Trading was very quiet. Some $42 billion in securities were traded, according to Govpx, a bond pricing service, about 20 percent below the average for a Friday in the second quarter. The market closed three hours early, at 2 P.M., and will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day.
Doug Burtnick, a senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that after a modest flow in the morning, trading rapidly dwindled.
There was no market-moving news or data yesterday. Investors looking for clues about the pace of economic growth and the Federal Reserve's intentions on monetary policy this summer will see only a few important reports next week.
The Government will report on April durable goods orders and the Chicago Purchasing Management Association will issue its May survey.
With the Fed's decision to leave the overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 5.50 percent this week, it means that investors will keep close tabs for any signs of growth that could cause the Fed to push rates higher. Fed policy makers meet again on July 1 and 2.
Also, next week the Treasury will sell new two-year notes on Wednesday and five-year notes on Thursday, in addition to its regular weekly bill auction, on Tuesday.
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said he believed the market would do better to focus on the supply of new Treasury debt next week.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's note auctions, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.25 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.57 percent.
Over all, Mr. Burtnick, the Technical Data analyst, said, "absolutely nothing has changed in terms of outlook for next week."

HEADLINE: Police and Troops Break Up Election Rallies in Indonesia

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23

 BODY:
The Government displayed its power today, using tear gas, rubber bullets and an overwhelming armed presence on the streets of Jakarta, the capital, to quash attempts by its opponents to hold rallies on the last day of campaigning for next week's parliamentary election.
As black-uniformed marines, riot policemen padded like hockey goalies and 20,000 soldiers in battle gear guarded key neighborhoods, hit-and-run convoys of young men on motorcycles buzzed through the city waving banners and gunning their engines. 
 Rioting erupted in south Jakarta -- as it has in several cities during this violent, monthlong campaign -- when a mob of young men from the governing party, Golkar, threw rocks and attacked demonstrators from the People's Democratic Party, the bigger of the two legal opposition parties.
As the crowds ran wild, smashing windows and storefronts along a two-mile thoroughfare, security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets as they did during more widespread rioting in the capital on Tuesday in which one person was reported to have been killed.
Starting on Saturday, campaigning will be banned during a five-day cooling-off period before the election, in which 125 million people are eligible to vote.
In his 31 years in power, President Suharto has raised Indonesia from hunger and poverty, producing one of the region's economic success stories but one of its most stunted countries in terms of democratic ideals.
Golkar has held a monopoly on power at all levels, and elections have been orchestrated more as pageants than as contests for office, so the outcome of the voting on Thursday is certain.
But widespread corruption, Government abuses, rising unemployment and underemployment and growing demands for a popular voice in national affairs have exposed a deep vein of discontent and anger here in the world's fourth-largest country. The resulting atmosphere of tension has made this the most violent election campaign here in recent times, with 123 people reported killed.
Golkar is assured of an overwhelming vote in part because millions of people in the military and in Government service -- from teachers to civil servants -- will be required to vote for the Government party.
But it was hard to find anyone on the streets of the city today who spoke in favor of the Government. They talked of corruption and unemployment and injustice, but the passionate issue appeared to be Mr. Suharto's autocratic rule.
"This is not democracy; this is power," said one man who declined to give his name. "This is not a president; this is a king."
Even a 28-year-old marine lieutenant, who said his orders were to bar opposition demonstrators, said it was time for a change.
"We want to have a place that is structured more like America, so that there is social justice for our people," he said. "People should have a voice, but in fact they don't."
Even an opposition landslide on Thursday would not oust Mr. Suharto. Voters are to choose 425 elected legislators. Together with 500 other representatives chosen by the Government and 75 members from the military, they will form a 1,000-member People's Consultative Assembly that will elect the next President in 1998.
Though Mr. Suharto has not announced his intentions, he is widely believed to be planning to continue in office. But he is 75, and already the nation is looking ahead toward an uncertain future.
The President has made no public provision for a successor, and that question mark has contributed to a growing restiveness in this country of 200 million. The last transition of power, when Mr. Suharto succeeded Indonesia's founding President, Sukarno, was accompanied by a purge of Communists that led to widespread killings in which some 500,000 people died.
The Government acted early, one year ago, to choke off potential opposition. It engineered a split in the opposition People's Democratic Party that forced the ouster of its popular leader, Megawati Sukarnoputri, a daughter of Mr. Sukarno.
When that action sparked widespread rioting in Jakarta last July, the Government launched a campaign of arrests and interrogations intended to neutralize its opponents.
A growing number of Indonesians appear to have joined a movement to boycott the election, either by staying away from the polls or by spoiling their ballots.
On Thursday, Mrs. Megawati added fuel to this movement, announcing that she would not vote. But she carefully avoided urging others to boycott the election: other people who have called for a boycott have been arrested.

HEADLINE: Foreign Aid for the Port Authority

BYLINE: By Richard C. Leone; Richard C. Leone, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from 1990 to 1994, is president of the Twentieth Century Fund.

 BODY:
One of my earliest memories of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is watching Austin Tobin, the agency's executive director for three decades, testify before a state legislative committee in 1965. Mr. Tobin carefully reminded his listeners that the authority, while a public agency, received no tax money and operated "just like a corporation."
His role, he explained, was similar to that of a company president, while the commissioners functioned like a board of directors. Before leaving the agency in 1973, Mr. Tobin was both praised and criticized for his independence, but governors and legislators usually went along with him. The agency performed so well that its special status seemed justified. 
 Flash forward to 1997: The Port Authority has announced that it will contract out the management of the general arrivals building at Kennedy International Airport to a company owned by the Dutch Government. Most of the reaction has been favorable. The company is described as exceptionally competent and creative, in large part because, while government-owned, it operates with great independence. What is striking about this description is that it fits, almost perfectly, the profile of the "old" Port Authority of Austin Tobin.
In its heyday, the authority had tremendous -- some would say almost total -- autonomy from the two state governments that created it. Politicians and the press complained that its board was unresponsive to the demands of both governors and the mayors of New York, Newark and other cities. But the authority got the job done, building bridges, tunnels, airports and the World Trade Center.
Some governors were savvy enough to support the agency (at least covertly). Gov. Nelson Rockefeller and Gov. Richard Hughes saw the value not only of having someone to blame for tolls and airport noise, but also of having an agency with the political insulation needed for long-term capital projects. They knew better than to raid the agency for money to meet budget gaps, and they understood the importance of keeping it strong enough to undertake projects that can mean the difference between a region's prosperity and decline.
But in the past two decades politics and politicians have changed. When it comes to taxes and budgets, governors practice the politics of survival. The turning point came in the late 1970's, when Gov. Hugh Carey of New York and Gov. William Cahill of New Jersey began insisting that the authority give the states the lion's share of any new revenues from, say, toll increases or commercial tenants in the World Trade Center. Thus the agency has handed over about $600 million for commuter cars and buses, and has set aside more than $1 billion for regional "development banks" that finance state projects.
The states have also appointed board members who they hope will be more responsive to their wishes and have driven out career professionals.
The cost of these changes has been immense. While there have been some successes like the Newark Airport renovation, more typical has been the attempted revival of Kennedy, a series of expensive false starts like the now-abandoned master plan for a giant central terminal and an underground baggage system, which became known as the "tunnel to nowhere."
But not to worry, a solution is at hand: We can simply pay a foreign government to do a job that we can no longer do.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Affluent Town Resents Poverty Aid

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: SAUGATUCK, Mich., May 21

 BODY:
The docks at this affluent Lake Michigan resort are lined with the powerboats and yachts of wealthy Chicago and Detroit families. The bed-and-breakfasts are stately mansions where rooms go for as much as $165 a night. When McDonald's tried to open a restaurant here a decade ago, planners refused to grant the permits, successfully arguing that fast food just did not fit with the town's cultivated quaintness.
So local residents have been mystified and a little miffed ever since they were singled out for Federal assistance at Vice President Al Gore's recent conference in Detroit on promoting local economic development to reduce poverty. The Agriculture Department announced at the conference that the its rural development division would guarantee four business loans in Michigan, including a $1.3 million loan to an investor in Grand Rapids for the construction of a Holiday Inn Express here. 
 The loan guarantees allow otherwise risky ventures to borrow at low interest rates from local banks, with the Agriculture Department repaying the loans if the borrower defaults. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman defended the guarantees for "the survival of many rural communities remains largely dependent on their ability to attract and retain businesses to fuel their local economies and provide jobs."
But Saugatuck residents say that their town's survival was never in doubt. In a town that markets itself as "the Martha's Vineyard of the Midwest," the main problem is controlling growth, not increasing it. The town's population soars from 3,000 to 20,000 each summer, as tourists and boaters pour in from Chicago, 110 miles to the southwest, and Detroit, 180 miles to the east.
Innkeepers here pay $7 or $8 an hour for summer workers, but have so much trouble finding them that they take out newspaper advertisements in other towns. The unemployment rate here was just 3.0 percent last month. The 1990 Census found that just 5.4 percent of the residents were living below the poverty line, less than half the national average.
"We are not impoverished; we cannot fill our service jobs," said Catherine L. Simon, the owner of the 15-room Maplewood Hotel, a bed-and-breakfast in a 137-year-old house with two-story Corinthian columns.
Fearing competition, Ms. Simon and the owners of the town's several dozen bed-and-breakfasts and motels have emerged in the last several weeks as the most outspoken critics of the Federal assistance. They complain that local banks never lent them any money because the season lasts only two months, making repayment risky.
Local farmers, the Agriculture Department's traditional constituency, have also been upset by the loan guarantee. The farmers contend that the agency should spend more money helping them during bad harvests instead of aiding hotel ventures.
"We cannot believe the Agriculture Department would back this venture; they wouldn't do it for a farmer," said Connie Krupka, who has been raising blueberries near here since World War II
Bart H. Chilton, the Agriculture Department's senior policy director for rural development, said that in evaluating applications for loan guarantees, the agency used a scoring system that gave preference to communities with high unemployment and a high poverty rate. But the application for the Holiday Inn Express arrived when only seven or eight applications had been submitted.
The Saugatuck application scored fairly high because the loan was for only 70 percent of the project's value instead of the usual 80 percent, thereby reducing the risk for the Agriculture Department, Mr. Chilton said. Even borrowers in wealthy communities can obtain guarantees when there are few competing applications.
Laura Trivers, a department spokeswoman, said that before issuing the loan guarantee for the Saugatuck hotel, it had checked with the West Michigan Regional Planning Commission in Grand Rapids, and that there had been no criticism of the project.
Joseph W. Gorka, the town supervisor in Saugatuck, said that he had never been in contact with the regional commission during his four years in office and was not even sure what the group did.
"They didn't ask us," Mr. Gorka said. "I was completely surprised" at the announcement of the loan guarantee.
Saugatuck has little need for more hotel jobs given the difficulty that innkeepers already have in finding workers, he added.
The loan guarantee was awarded to Shree Krishna Enterprises Inc., a company set up by Dahyalalm Patel, the owner of a bakery in Grand Rapids and an investor in several Michigan and Kentucky hotels. Shree Krishna would operate the new hotel as a franchise of the Holiday Inn chain. Mr. Patel declined to comment. The United Bank of Michigan, a tiny community bank in Grand Rapids, issued the Government-guaranteed loan.
Holiday Inn Express is a low-cost version of the Holiday Inn chain with few services, designed for business travelers.
Construction has already begun at the Saugatuck site, a large patch of dirt surrounded by groves of pine trees. There are already some budget motels in town, like the Captains Quarters, which caters to the crews aboard visiting yachts.
Borrowers default on 7.5 percent of the loans guaranteed by the Agriculture Department's rural development division, forcing the Federal Government to pay the outstanding balance of these loans. The department is setting aside $688.2 million during the current fiscal year, which began on Oct. 1, to cover these losses.
For decades, the department's rural development programs have periodically been criticized for subsidizing electricity and sewage in wealthy Colorado ski resorts and other affluent towns. But members of Congress from rural areas have had considerable success in protecting the programs from budget cuts and avoiding rules that would limit eligibility for subsidies to low-income areas.
The programs tend to be very inefficient, said Daniel A. Sumner, an assistant secretary of agriculture in the Bush Administration, and "are very prone to being diverted to help communities that don't deserve any help at all."
Mr. Chilton defended the programs, saying they often provided opportunities for economic growth in small towns with few other options.
Here in Saugatuck, though, many believe they have other options.
"We are not underdeveloped," said Felicia Fairchild, a longtime resident. "We are an extremely expensive resort town."

HEADLINE: Half Full or Half Empty?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The gap between the national unemployment rate, at 4.9 percent in April, and New York City's, at 9.7 percent, is now the greatest it has been in the 30 years extensive records have been kept, Federal labor officials said this week.
That sounds unequivocally bad. But what the gap says about New York's economy, and what possibilities it suggests for the city's and region's future, are far from black and white. 
 The causes of locally high unemployment are familiar: declines in manufacturing; the influx of immigrants; the creation of highly paid jobs that do not affect average New Yorkers, and the welfare overhaul that is encouraging people to leave public aid have all contributed. The city is creating more jobs than it has for years, though not enough.
But what is becoming increasingly important now, economists say, is not so much the causes of the gap as the consequences. Some economists believe that as the national labor market continues to tighten in Sun Belt meccas like North Carolina and across much of the Midwest, a new equilibrium could be reached that will tilt gradually back toward New York's advantage, or at least toward a level playing field. If employers cannot find workers elsewhere, so this reasoning goes, they may be drawn to move to or expand in the city and the region, because that is where the labor is.
"Employers will be attracted by New York's pool of unemployed," said Mark M. Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "It's a significant potential economic opportunity for the metro area."
Rae Rosen, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said that the real significance of the gap is what it says about the surging number of people looking for work in New York. The jobless rate is based on the number of people who receive unemployment benefits, but also on the number who say in surveys that they are actively looking for work. The latter part of the equation is what has soared, and that speaks of optimism, Ms. Rosen said.
"The changes that explain the New York rate have the potential to be significant," she said. "They could be quite positive to the city if we have the wherewithal to place these people."
The labor pool is enormous. In March, nearly 5 percent of all the unemployed people in the country lived in the New York metropolitan area, a higher proportion of the country's jobless than in any single month since at least 1987, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. And that figure does not include the hundreds of thousands of residents of the region who have moved out in the 1990's, looking for greener pastures elsewhere.
The president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, Charles Millard, said he thought that the main thing to realize about the unemployment rate is that it has risen parallel with an increase in job growth. The imbalance in the labor market that has flooded the city with job seekers, he said, is a direct consequence of New York's improved fortunes.
"The most interesting statistic is that new unemployment claims are going down, even while the number of people seeking jobs in New York is increasing," he said.
Other experts are less optimistic about the labor gap, arguing that the kinds of companies most likely to hire New York's unemployed, who are on average less educated and less skilled than other New Yorkers, are retailers or hotels that do not choose locations based on labor availability at all, but rather on market demand for their products. Wal-Mart goes where it can sell merchandise, not where it can hire clerks.
"I can't imagine any kind of economic process where a tightening in Cincinnati or Denver is going to end up increasing the demand for New York City janitors," said Bennett Harrison, a professor of urban political economy at the New School for Social Research. "There is no national market for Wal-Mart employees or parking lot attendants or janitors."
A continuing gap could have political consequences either way. For years, New York has routinely granted millions in tax breaks to corporations that threaten to leave the city for places where labor and business costs are cheaper. With workers so scarce in many parts of the country, including in the New York region -- the unemployment rate across much of Fairfield County, Conn., was about 3 percent in March -- corporate bluster about pulling up stakes is simply less credible now.
"If a company says, 'I'm going to move, lock, stock and barrel, to Tampa or Des Moines or Minneapolis,' it's a little less likely to really happen today," said Mr. Zandi at Regional Financial Associates. In those three cities, the unemployment rate is 4 percent or lower, he said. In Des Moines, it is 2 percent. "If you can't find the bodies, you can't move," he said.
The unemployment gap appears to be making New York City more competitive with the rest of the country on at least one main sticking point for employers: labor costs. Because the region has grown more slowly than the rest of the nation in the 1990's, and because the big surplus labor pool has kept wage pressures lower still, labor costs in much of the rest of the country have risen faster and have started to catch up.
In 1990, the cost of labor in the New York metropolitan area was 120 percent of the national average, according to an analysis by Mr. Zandi's firm. Now, New York's cost is only 110 percent of the national cost.
So far, state and city economic development officials can point to only a few companies, mostly in financial services and telecommunications, who said they had moved or expanded in the New York City area because of labor considerations. In all the cases they cited, the skills available in the region, rather than the supply of labor, appear to have been the consideration.
A report issued this week by the New York City Comptroller's office suggests that local hiring patterns remain mixed. In the first quarter of 1997, the report said, the number of jobs in the city expanded by nearly 20,000. But the number of city residents with jobs actually declined by nearly 21,000. Not only did city residents not get the new jobs, the report said, but apparently lost many of the ones they had or moved away.
Mark Pendrock looks out at a New York economy that might as well be Des Moines. He cannot find the workers he needs. Simple as that.
"We'd hire six people right now if we could," said Mr. Pendrock, an executive vice president at Application Consulting Group, a Morristown, N.J., business services firm. Mr. Pendrock said he wanted to recruit locally and could pay in the high $30,000 range for new college graduates with consulting and computer software skills. There are few takers. "The competition to hire people is enormous," he said, "and the demand by New York companies in hiring is putting great pressure on us. It's an obstacle to growth."
Daiser Bazan sees a different New York. Ms. Bazan, a native of Colombia who lives in Jackson Heights, Queens, used to help run the cafeteria at Grey Advertising in Manhattan, but lost her $500-a-week job last year as an assistant manager when the food service company she worked for was bought out. She has been looking for eight months and has not found anything that will pay her more than $7 an hour, which she says she cannot live on.
"I go to restaurants, the Rainbow Room, Windows on the World, and apply, and they tell me I have an impressive resume, but they only offer me $7 an hour," she said. "They say there are no problems in this city with getting work. There are lots of problems."
A comparison of the performance of various industries in New York and the rest of the country in the 1990's shows partly how and why that divergence in employment has grown. In the 12 months between March 1996 and March 1997, business services and engineering and management services -- the two biggest job engines in the city's economy over the year -- both outperformed the national economy in percentage increase in employment, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. Both industries also tend to recruit nationally and pay high salaries for high skills.
By contrast, national growth outstripped New York's in many industries that tend to hire and recruit locally and pay less for fewer skills; from food stores to hotel employment, to government and in most manufacturing categories.
One major question for the future is what a slowing national economy might mean for New York's unemployed. Some economists say the nation's unemployment rate would probably be even lower, and the city's even higher, if not for the 1.3 million residents of the region who moved to other parts of the country in the 1990's.
They argue that the population exodus, as in other major urban centers like Los Angeles, which lost 1.3 million people, has acted like a pressure release valve for the national economy, redistributing labor to places where it is needed. Immigration from foreign countries, meanwhile, has kept New York's population from falling precipitously.
Other experts say that the effect of population changes on unemployment levels is more complicated. Reputations about regions of the country are slow to grow and slow to change, and population flows are even slower to react, said James Brown, a labor market analyst with the State Department of Labor who follows the New York City economy.
Mr. Brown said he did not think that the New Yorkers who left the region necessarily moved to places where job growth has been hotter, though some certainly did. They moved, he said, for the same reason others had for generations, from older, port-of-entry cities like New York to less established areas that have been growing faster for many years.
Part of the explanation of the low unemployment rates in the old industrial belt of the Midwest and the Plains States, he said, is that those areas lost so much population over previous years of economic stagnation, and have not had it replaced, as cities like New York and Los Angeles have, through immigration. Labor markets, like cruise ships, do not turn on a dime.
"If a region stays hot over time, that does produce changes, like the oil patch in the 70's," Mr. Brown said. "But it takes a while for word to get out."

While some sectors of the city's economy are weak, part of the reason for the rise is the city has an increasingly large share of the nation's job seekers. HEADLINE: Volatile Week for the Dollar Concludes in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended a volatile week on a quiet note yesterday, closing lower against other major currencies in thin, pre-holiday trading, dealers said.
A looming three-day holiday weekend in the two largest foreign exchange markets -- the United States and Britain -- and an early close yesterday in the United States bond market, subdued trading volume and activity, dealers said. 
 In trading in New York, the dollar settled at 115.66 yen, down marginally from 115.96 yen on Thursday and little changed from its 115.55 yen level a week earlier. The dollar edged up to 1.6935 marks from 1.6934 marks. The pound rose to $1.6345 from $1.6234.
Stealing the spotlight was a sudden drop in the Australian dollar, which tumbled on news of an unexpected cut in Australian interest rates.
The Reserve Bank of Australia cut half a percentage point off the official cash rate, the fourth cut since last July, pushing the rate to 5.5 percent -- its lowest since August 1994. The Australian dollar fell to 76.7 United States cents, from 78.15 United States cents on Thursday and the lowest level in three months.
The dollar showed little reaction to remarks from Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's top foreign-exchange policy maker, who said that a rise in Japan's discount rate should be expected by the end of the year.
"The discount rate is currently very low," he said in an interview with Le Monde. " If it rises by 0.5 percent, it will be at 1 percent, which remains low. A move on such a scale should be expected in the coming year. " He also noted, however, that he did not believe the Bank of Japan would raise rates before it was sure of a solid economic upturn.
The dollar gained against the French franc as France prepared for the first round of elections this weekend. Analysts said victory for the ruling center-right coalition would bolster the dollar against the mark as the French franc should respond favorably. But gains by the Socialists could hurt the dollar because currency traders would then buy marks. The dollar rose to 5.7040 French francs, from 5.7015 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Business Bribes To Foreigners To Be Banned By End of 1998

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
After two years of negotiations, the world's largest industrialized nations have agreed to outlaw the bribery of foreign officials by the end of next year.
The agreement represents a major victory for American businesses that have long complained that the anti-corruption law passed by Congress two decades ago puts them at a disadvantage around the world. It was reached this afternoon and is scheduled to be ratified Monday in Paris by the 29-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the club that brings together officials of most of the richest nations around the globe and some of those that aspire to that status. 
 The pact would be the first global accord making it a crime to bribe foreign officials to obtain the multibillion-dollar contracts that have become the focus of increasingly cutthroat competition among multinational corporations and governments. France, Germany and Japan have historically been the most reluctant to agree to such laws; in Germany and Canada, companies have even been allowed to take tax deductions for foreign bribes simply by listing them as a cost of doing business.
The Clinton Administration has made forging an anti-bribery agreement a high priority. But Administration officials said today that they had no illusions that the corruption accord alone would put a huge dent in the multibillion-dollar international bribery business. Two of the newest member countries of the O.E.C.D. -- South Korea and Mexico -- are regarded as being among the more corrupt nations where American companies do business. And the agreement does not include countries outside the O.E.C.D., like China and Indonesia, where, as any business executive in Asia knows well, a willingness to enrich local and national officials is often considered the price of entry.
Nonetheless, Commerce Secretary William Daley insisted today in a statement that the agreement was "a major step forward in curbing international bribery.
"The O.E.C.D.," he added, "has now reached an agreement on criminalizing bribery as well as a procedure to do so within a short, specified period of time."
Under the accord reached today, each of the nations in the O.E.C.D. has until next April to introduce legislation making foreign bribery a crime. The laws must be passed by the end of 1998, and the O.E.C.D. nations are committed to opening negotiations for an international treaty to deal with bribery. France and Germany pushed for such a convention so that they would not be placed at a disadvantage by other nations that approved less stringent anti-corruption statutes.
The agreement sets out criteria for the national legislation -- some of it similar to the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in the United States -- but it does not mandate specific wording. That leaves open the possibility that some nations may treat bribery as a far more serious offense than others.
"This is an important step," said David Rothkopf, a former senior Commerce Department official who was involved in the compilation of a classified report to Congress in 1995 that detailed over 100 instances where foreign companies used bribery to beat out American bids for business around the world. "But you have to remember that bribery is usually committed by rich companies from rich countries that go into poor countries and bribe their officials. Any agreement that has teeth must be enforced, and it must also deal not just with the supply side of bribery, but with the demand side."
While it is impossible to get a true measure of international bribery, the Commerce Department has estimated that United States companies have lost contracts valued at approximately $11 billion since mid-1994 because of efforts by foreign companies to bribe officials around the world. But those include only the high-profile cases that companies report or that American intelligence officials have picked up.
In his new book "The Big Ten," about the world's 10 largest emerging-market nations, Jeffrey E. Garten, the former under secretary of commerce for international affairs, wrote that "it is often difficult to do business in any of these countries without bribing someone."
French and Japanese companies, he wrote, "routinely provide payoffs of one kind or another without penalties at home."
The new O.E.C.D. regulations will stipulate that the national laws against foreign bribery must attack conspiracy cases, and they must specify that companies cannot offer as a defense that they bribed foreign officials to comply with "local customs." The rules will also include a system that allows other nations to monitor how each country enforces the anti-corruption rules.
"This has very concrete terms in it," said Nancy Zucker Boswell, the managing director of Transparency International USA, the American arm of a lobbying group that seeks to curb corruption in business and in developing nations. The group, which is supported by the Agency for International Development, the Ford Foundation and some multinational corporations, among others, publishes an annual index of corruption in nations around the world.

HEADLINE: Russia and Belarus Agree on a New Union

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 23

 BODY:
Russia and Belarus agreed today to form a new union, a largely symbolic move intended to appeal to nostalgia for the old Soviet empire.
President Boris N. Yeltsin signed the accord with the autocratic leader of Belarus, Alexander Lukashenko, in a grand Kremlin ceremony. "Our union is aimed at forging further relations of brotherhood, friendship and all-around cooperation," Mr. Yeltsin declared. 
 Under the treaty, a new supernational body will oversee the union, headed by Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Lukashenko. Decisions must be approved by each President. But the agreement does not establish a common state or set a deadline for full-fledged unity. Such a merger has been blocked by Russian reformers wary of assuming the burden of Belarus, a poor country run by a former collective-farm director opposed to free-market reforms.
But as NATO plans to expand, the watered-down accord gives the Kremlin something to show to support its argument that Russia's influence is increasing.
As the Russia-Belarus accord was being signed, Mr. Yeltsin also appointed Gen. Igor Sergeyev as Defense Minister. The general, the former head of the Strategic Rocket Forces and a supporter of new strategic arms accords with the United States, had been named Acting Minister on Thursday. Gen. Anatoly Kvashnin, the commander of the North Caucasus military district, is to be the Acting Chief of Staff.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rise to New Highs In Broad but Quiet Rally
Stocks climbed to new highs in a broad rally. Technology and small-company stocks, in particular, posted strong gains, showing that they are catching up to the big names in the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500. The Dow reached its 20th high of the year in quiet trading, rising 87.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 7,345.91. 
 And the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index became the last of the major indexes to recover from the market's spring selloff. The Nasdaq rose 17.12 points, or 1.3 percent, to a record 1,389.72. [Page 36.]
 
Bond Market Steadies
Treasury prices were little changed in very quiet trading. For the week, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 8 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- to 6.98 percent. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged. Next week, with few major economic reports scheduled, bond investors are expected to focus on new supply coming to market. [43.]
 
The dollar slipped in thin trading. The Australian dollar tumbled after the country's central bank made an unexpected cut of half a percentage point in interest rates. [43.]
 
Boeing Seeks Fuel-Tank Checks
Boeing plans to ask all airlines that fly 747's to inspect the the planes' center fuel tanks for signs of anything that could create a spark. More than 1,000 of the airplanes are in service with airlines around the world. The call follows the failure of a 10-month investigation to find what caused T.W.A. Flight 800 to explode. [22.]

Affiliate of Big Japanese Firm Fails
Ogawa Securities, a debt-ridden affiliate of the Yamaichi Securities Company in Tokyo, will be shut down. While it is the first Japanese brokerage house to fail in 17 years, other affiliates of Japan's four biggest brokerage companies have encountered problems. [34.]
 
Ford Leads; Mazda Improves
Mazda Motor, in its first fiscal year under the control of the Ford Motor Company, said unconsolidated profit surged in the year, though it had an operating loss. Still, the report was a sign of progress for the troubled Japanese auto maker. Ford managers have helped Mazda improve its cash flow, reduce debt and cut costs. [34.]
 
Opportunity in Jobless Rate?
New York City's unemployment rate, 9.7 percent last month, has persistently been much higher than the nation's, which was 4.9 percent in April. But some economists say that as the labor market continues to tighten elsewhere in the country, New York may benefit. If employers can't find workers elsewhere, they may be drawn to move to or expand in the city and the region, because that is where the labor is. News Analysis. [1.]
 
Economic Gloom in France
As French voters head into national elections tomorrow, many are gloomy over the nation's economic outlook. Both consumers and companies have been reluctant to spend and invest amid high unemployment, only modest growth and widespread disillusionment with the country's political leaders. [7.]
 
Hot Stock in Hong Kong
In Hong Kong, investor frenzy has surrounded the initial public offering of Beijing Enterprises Holdings. The offering of the so-called red-chip company -- a Hong Kong company with backing from China -- is expected to be oversubscribed 1,000 times. Hundreds of people were still jostling to enter banks even as the noon deadline passed yesterday. The woman above implored police officers to allow her to enter a bank after the deadline for the offering expired. [34.]

South African Bottler Closes
Pepsico has shut down New Age Beverages, its South African franchise bottler, because of overwhelming competition from the Coca-Cola Company. Coke has an 81.3 percent share in the country. Pepsi's share is 4.7.[34.]

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Drug King Used Army, Mexican Court Files Say
Some prominent antidrug operations in Mexico in the last year were done at the behest of Amado Carrillo Fuentes, a powerful drug baron who had enlisted corrupt generals and bankrolled Mexican Army units in his war against a chief competitor, according to testimony in secret court proceedings. 1
 
Congo Leader Is Protested
A day after President Laurent Kabila of Congo announced his Government, his troops in Kinshasa fired warning shots to disperse a crowd protesting that former Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi had been excluded. They also expressed anger at the presence of foreign troops in the capital. Mr. Tshisekedi, a longtime civilian opponent of Mobutu Sese Seko's rule, said he would not recognize Mr. Kabila's Government. 6
 
Campaign Riots in Jakarta
On the last day of campaigning for next week's parliamentary election in Indonesia, 20,000 Government troops, helped by mobs of rock-throwing young men from the Government party, Golkar, quashed efforts by the People's Democratic Party opposition to hold rallies. Riots broke out nonetheless, as they have frequently in a campaign during which 123 people have been reported killed. 3
 
Iranians Cast Their Votes
Iranians voted for a new President in what has unexpectedly become the most competitive elections in Iran since the Islamic revolution 18 years ago. Many people who indicated that they were tired of religious rule said they cast their votes for Mohammed Khatami, who has advocated a moderate loosening of social control. Conservatives supported Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, the Speaker of Parliament and the candidate preferred by the council of mullahs who have ultimate power. 4
 
Pakistan Urges U.S. to Repay
The Foreign Minister of Pakistan told the Clinton Administration that Pakistan would soon consider suing for the repayment of $650 million it paid Washington for a fleet of undelivered F-16 fighter planes. Since Washington often disregards the rulings of international courts, Pakistani officials said, the lawsuit would be brought in the United States. 3
 
Britain's Blair Debuts in Europe
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain went to the European mainland for the first time since being elected, and quickly became the main act at a meeting in the Netherlands of the 15 European Union nations. Mr. Blair promised that Britain would be "constructive, not confrontational" in its approach to the Union. 7
 
Russia and Belarus in Union
Russia and Belarus agreed to form a new, largely symbolic union. President Boris Yeltsin signed the accord with Alexander Lukashenko, the autocratic leader of Belarus. But the agreement does not create a common state or establish a timetable for substantive unity. 7
 
NATIONAL 8-10
 
Congress Goes Home Without Disaster Action
Congress recessed for a 12-day spring break without passing a disaster-relief bill. The major sticking point on the bill has been the insistence by Republicans that it allow for a spending freeze during budget fights to prevent Government shutdowns. President Clinton has vowed to veto any bill with such a provision, saying that a freeze would cut money for education and social programs that are a part of the balanced-budget deal. 1
 
Action Against Citizenship
The Government will move to strip citizenship from nearly 5,000 people whose criminal histories should have prevented their naturalization last year or who misrepresented their records of conviction. Such broad action has never been done and it poses enormous legal and logistical challenges. The Immigration and Naturalization Service has been strongly criticized for allowing about 180,000 foreigners to become citizens without having complete criminal background checks during an election-year campaign to streamline citizenship procedures. 1
 
Surprise Bomb Testimony
A witness who defense lawyers thought would say that a man other than Timothy J. McVeigh was in the truck believed to have contained the bomb that destroyed the Oklahoma City Federal building testified that Mr. McVeigh could have been in the truck, too. The witness also acknowledged having a history of mental illness and memory problems 1
 
Miami's Nice, but . . .
So many retirees have come to appreciate the pleasures of small-town living in the South, that some states are seeing them as a source of economic development for out-of-the-way places. Newcomers find the weather good, the atmosphere pleasant and the costs low. Officials find that the newcomers generate construction jobs, retail sales and tax revenue. 1
 
Seeing Brain Remember
Scientists have, for the first time, recorded signals from human brain cells making the associations that lead to long-term memories. The signals were found by a team of neurosurgeons who were preparing epilepsy patients for an operation. 9
 
Leaving Hurts Enough
First Lieut. Kelly J. Flinn, the first woman to pilot a B-52, said leaving the Air Force, even with an honorable discharge, would be heartbreaking. She made the comment in a letter to the Secretary of the Air Force, before she was given a general discharge to avoid a court-martial. 8
 
Alaska Logging Expanded
The Forest Service authorized extensive new logging for the next 10 years in the nation's last expanse of old-growth temperate rain forests, the Tongass National Forest in southeastern Alaska. The plan calls for less logging than loggers and the state's Congressional delegation have sought, but more than environmental groups deem acceptable. 9

While the gap between the national unemployment rate and that in the New York City is worse than it has been in at least 30 years, some economist say that might lead companies to move to or expand in the city and the region, because that is where the labor is. 1
 
Asylum Plea Seems False
A man who won publicity and offers of help after he applied for asylum, claiming he was subject to persecution in Nigeria, appears to be an impostor. The man said he was a brother of Lieut. Col. Happy Kefas Bulus, who was accused two years ago of plotting the coup. But Colonel Bulus's family say there is no such brother. 24

A New Jersey man who was shot in the head during a rampage by a gunman on the Empire State Building went home. Matthew Gross left a rehabilitation center three months after he was wounded. 25

The unions representing painters and carpenters who work for New York City have sued the Giuliani administration, saying it uses welfare recipients to do jobs once done by unionized workers. 23

HEADLINE: More Retirees Discover Small-Town South

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: HATTIESBURG, Miss.

 BODY:
There are no beaches here. No mountains. The public parks are equipped for softball, not shuffleboard. If there is a regular mah-jongg game anywhere in town, it is well hidden.
Yet retirees are migrating here in a steady stream, leaving the bustle and culture (and snow and congestion and crime) of the North to spend their leisure days in the piney woods of southern Mississippi. In the last four years, 267 retired couples have settled here in Hattiesburg, not an invasion of Floridian proportions perhaps, but enough to attract attention in a metropolitan area of only 100,000 people. 
 They are not alone. All across the rural South, retirees are moving to improbable places, lured by temperate weather, inexpensive living and savvy marketing by community leaders who have learned to court senior citizens as aggressively as they recruit automobile manufacturers.
Retirees who once would have flocked to the condominium canyons of South Florida, the golf resorts of coastal South Carolina or the mountains of North Carolina are today discovering small towns and country crossroads like Guntersville, Ala.; Mena, Ark., and Bainbridge, Ga., places that have never made anyone's list of retirement hot spots.
In other cases, huge retirement villages are springing up quite literally in the middle of nowhere, often far from airports and even midsize cities. In western South Carolina, for example, Cooper Communities of Bella Vista, Ark., has sold 3,600 home sites in its Savannah Lakes Village development near McCormick, a city that was described 15 years ago as a ghost town by U.S. News & World Report.
With the aging of the baby boomers making retirement a growth industry, several states are beginning to compete tenaciously for retirees. Some have established state agencies dedicated to the task.
And local governments and business groups around the South are developing tools for working the retirement market -- Web-site testimonials about the pleasures of small-town retirement, for example, and hospitality seminars that remind waitresses to show particular courtesy to elderly diners.
Mark Fagan, a professor at Jacksonville State University in Alabama, said his studies of retiree migration had demonstrated that senior citizens could help revive a slumbering economy.
"These counties in eastern Alabama didn't really have what it takes to compete in the smokestack chase, didn't have the infrastructure," Professor Fagan said. "But there are other ways to increase spending in an area."
Retirees have come to places like Hattiesburg, which is home to several hospitals and the University of Southern Mississippi, because of a growing sense that traditional retirement destinations like South Florida, Arizona and California are not as inviting as they once were. And many have come, demographers and sociologists say, because of a yearning for a sense of community that has vanished from many cities.
"We've lived in Los Angeles and Washington and New York and London, and when you live in the city, you don't become a part of the community," said Jean W. Carbonar, who moved here with her husband, Anthony, from the Upper East Side of Manhattan two years ago. "In New York, you don't meet your neighbors unless there's a real bad fire."
On paper, the Carbonars would seem unlikely prospects to spend the rest of their days in Hattiesburg. Before retiring, Mr. Carbonar was a partner with Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon, the Wall Street law firm where Richard M. Nixon hung his hat. In Manhattan, the Carbonars rented a $4,000-a-month apartment overlooking the Queensboro Bridge, and Mr. Carbonar collected boxes of exotic cigars. For a while, they considered retiring to New Zealand.
But after looking at Hattiesburg on the recommendation of their son-in-law, the Carbonars decided they liked the climate, the cost of living, the undulating fairways at the Hattiesburg Country Club and, perhaps above all, the hospitality extended by the community.
"We just felt we could look a long time and not find a place that duplicated it," said Mr. Carbonar, 63. "My friends in New York say, 'Isn't there a big culture shock down there?' And I say, 'Yeah, people here are polite, and for no good reason.' "
In couples like the Carbonars, business and political leaders in Mississippi and other Southern states see vast potential for economic development. When retirees relocate, they bring bank deposits and buy houses. They buy food, clothing, insurance and toys for visiting grandchildren. A 1990 study by William H. Haas, a sociologist at the University of North Carolina at Asheville, concluded that the average retiree household in western North Carolina injected about $36,000 a year into the local economy.
In addition, retirees pay taxes, usually on time, and place little strain on most municipal services. They do not pollute. They rarely commit crimes. They volunteer in schools and hospitals.
"Retirees have got more money than most folks," said Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi, who created his state's Hometown Mississippi Retirement program in 1994. "They also are less of a strain on the infrastructure system. They don't use schools. They are what you might call ideal citizens."
The Census Bureau projects that the number of Americans age 65 and older, which was 33.5 million in 1995 (12.8 percent of the population), will grow to 45.6 million in 2015 (14.7 percent) and to 61.9 million in 2025 (18.5 percent).
In addition, some demographers predict that the percentage of retirees who migrate may begin to increase. From 1985 to 1990, 4.5 percent of all Americans 60 or older moved to another state, said Charles F. Longino Jr., a sociologist at Wake Forest University.
Florida, which has no state income tax, is still by far the most popular destination for migrating retirees, with 24 percent of the total moving there from 1985 to 1990, a study by Mr. Longino found.
But Florida's share of the retiree market declined by 2.5 percentage points during that period, while the share increased in states like Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee. Many of the migrants to other Southern states are moving from Florida to escape crowds, crime and traffic.
Demographers said the movement of retirees to small towns in nontraditional retirement states was too recent to have been measured by the 1990 census. But they predicted that the 2000 census would show an acceleration in the decline in Florida's share of the market and an increase in the share of states like Mississippi.
In the last eight years, several states, including Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Mississippi and Pennsylvania, have established agencies and budgets devoted solely to recruiting retirees. South Carolina has enlisted a for-profit company, the Center for Carolina Living, to do the job.
There are, of course, potential liabilities in creating an economy that is excessively dependent on retirees. In some states, notably Arizona and Florida, retirees have shown a propensity to vote against tax and bonding measures for school construction. And if the Federal Government reduces Medicare benefits, state and local governments may be forced to pick up health care costs for their elderly populations.
The potential for a heavy health care burden concerns Patrick Mason, co-founder of the Center for Carolina Living.
"We are saying to ourselves, 'Yeah, we need retirees, but we need the Cadillac-class retirees,' " Mr. Mason said. "The no-taxes, y'all-come approach in Florida drew a few millionaires but thousands of middle-class retirees. And when they spend down their assets, they're on Medicaid."
But most states seem to have decided that the benefits outweigh the liabilities. And nowhere has that conclusion been reached more definitively than in Mississippi.
The state appropriates $500,000 a year, one-fifth of all state dollars spent on economic development marketing, to the Hometown Mississippi Retirement program. To make Mississippi more appealing to retirees, the state pointedly eliminated its income tax on pensions and other forms of retirement income in 1995.
Since the state retirement program began advertising in 1995, it has helped at least 700 couples relocate to the state and fielded 100,000 inquiries via a toll-free phone number. It publishes a glossy guide to retirement cities, provides matching grants to towns that undertake their own marketing campaigns, and pays for national advertising. A typical advertisement depicts a snow shovel and the text, "You could always use it to dig out of a sand trap."
Inquiries are followed up with telephone calls, handwritten notes, Christmas cards and invitations to visit, often extended by retirees who have already moved to the state.
"A lot of states just mail out brochures," said Barbara P. McDonald, director of the program. "We knew that Mississippi, not being a traditional retirement destination, would have to go a step farther. So we try the personal touch."
A central component of Mississippi's plan is the designation of 20 cities as certified retirement communities. The state deems that the cities have met certain standards for public safety, recreational amenities, health care and housing.
In Hattiesburg, one of the certified cities, officials sell the city's proximity to New Orleans, Jackson and the casino-clogged Gulf Coast, all within a 90-minute drive. They also highlight the area's 13 golf courses, its two hospitals and large medical clinic, its four-season warmth, and its low housing costs and tax rates.
The culture of college towns appeals to many retirees. The Institute for Learning in Retirement at the University of Southern Mississippi offers bargain courses.
The Area Development Partnership, the city's chamber of commerce, sponsors outings for retirees who have moved to town. It has also put more than 200 employees of motels, restaurants, gas stations, banks and stores through a half-day refresher course in Southern hospitality. The workers are encouraged to fawn over older customers on the theory that some may be considering moving to town.
Charles Short, a marketing executive from Rochester, and his wife, Helen, a microbiologist, got a heavy dose of hospitality when they happened upon Hattiesburg while on a camping trip in 1991. After expressing interest in retiring here, they received telephone calls every other week from other retirees who had already moved to Hattiesburg.
Now the Shorts are making the calls, telling prospects how the produce manager shakes their hands when they enter the grocery store and how they bought a larger house in Hattiesburg than they owned in Rochester and still save $4,000 a year in property taxes.
They also enjoy dispelling the notion, whether held by prospects or old friends in Rochester, that they have moved to a cultural backwater.
"The response from our friends and neighbors was universally negative, that we were going to some morass down here," said Mrs. Short, 67. "So it was with some pride that I wrote them to tell them that Itzhak Perlman was headlining the symphony series. That took the wind out of their sails."

HEADLINE: VICTIMS OF FLOOD FEAR DELAY IN AID

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The White House called it short-sighted. Congressional Democrats said it was arrogant. And soggy Midwesterners and Californians worried it could hurt them in the long run.
Congress recessed today for a 12-day spring break, leaving unfinished a bill that would have provided billions of dollars in disaster aid for flood and storm victims in 33 states and subjecting Republican leaders to charges of politics-as-usual. 
 While as much as $2 billion in emergency aid will continue flowing to flood-ravaged areas from California to Kentucky, many rebuilding and economic-recovery efforts will be delayed until Congress returns from its vacation early next month. Even then, it may take weeks longer to resolve unrelated budget issues that got tangled up with the flood bill.
Midwestern ranchers will have to wait at least two weeks longer to receive Federal payments for cattle drowned or frozen in the calamities. Mayors in Minnesota will have to delay awarding contracts to repair damaged roads, bridges and water-treatment plants. Homeless South Dakota residents will have to wait longer for relocation aid. And some rebuilding in storm-struck Yosemite National Park in California will have to be postponed.
"Communities that have been depending on this funding to get back on their feet are being left short-changed by a short-sighted Congress, which does not reflect well on the Republican leaders of Congress," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry.
The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who represents one of the hardest-hit states, said Republican legislators were more concerned with getting away for the long holiday than with disaster victims.
"Republicans wanted to leave in the worst way, and they did," Mr. Daschle said at a news conference today. "They put a greater priority on plane tickets than disaster payments. They set a new low for responsibility in the Congress."
By today many House members were winging their way on Government-paid trips to China and NATO meetings in Europe. Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, attended a fund-raising event in Florida.
Democrats immediately tried to make political hay of what they saw as a glaring public-relations blunder by Republicans.
"While hard-working families in North Dakota are trying to bail the water out of their homes, it's amazing to me that Newt Gingrich has the gall to bask in the sun and rake in the bucks at a posh Palm Beach hotel," said Representative Martin Frost, a Texas Democrat who heads the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.
Officials in afflicted areas also complained. J. Edward Tewes, city manager of Modesto, Calif., which was inundated by the Tuolumne River in January, said flood repairs continue, but Congress's inaction will halt important long-term projects like studying the river flows.
"We need to get on the work now in advance of next year's storms," Mr. Tewes said. "Any delay in money will slow it down."
Republican leaders tried to play down the significance of the disaster aid in the $8.4 billion emergency spending bill that lawmakers failed to approve before packing their bags.
"Not one American in need is without assistance, not one American in need is without emergency funds," said a letter sent today to President Clinton by Mr. Gingrich, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate majority leader.
But senior House Republicans late Thursday night were divided over whether to approve at least $1 billion of the $5.5 billion in disaster aid in a slimmed-down bill.
In a closed meeting on Thursday afternoon, Mr. Gingrich and Representative Robert L. Livingston, a Louisiana Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, favored the plan, but Mr. Armey and Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the third-ranking House Republican, successfully opposed it, fearing it could weaken Republicans' leverage with the White House on a handful of extraneous issues tacked on to the disaster aid bill.
Two issues in particular torpedoed a compromise between Republicans and the White House. Republicans insisted that any emergency spending bill include a provision aimed at preventing Government shutdowns during budget fights by freezing spending at current levels.
But Mr. Clinton opposed the stopgap-funding provision, arguing that the freeze would in practice cut education and social spending for which the President just won more money in the balanced-budget deal. Mr. Clinton vowed to veto any bill that included the provision.
The other sticking point was a provision to allow the Commerce Department to use a method of counting called statistical sampling for the census in 2000. The Administration says this approach would increase the census's accuracy in counting minorities and other usually underreported groups. Some Republicans believe this approach would give Democrats greater representation in areas where such voters live.
While House and Senate negotiators were narrowing their differences with the White House on these and other resolved issues, the bill ultimately fell victim to the calendar. House Republican leaders promised to let their members go home today, and they decided that disaster aid was not urgent enough to delay that.
Before leaving on its vacation today, the Senate easily approved a balanced-budget deal between Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders. The vote was 78 to 22, with 8 Democrats and 14 Republicans voting against the resolution. The measure envisions $85 billion in tax cuts over the next five years plus savings from Medicare, defense and other programs totaling $321 billion.
One dissenting Democrat, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, said the resolution "fails to ask the rich to make a fair contribution to reducing the deficit, and rewards them with massive tax breaks instead."
But most Republicans and Democrats praised one another effusively after the vote. "It truly was a bipartisan effort," said Senator Lott. "We should be proud of it, and it's an example of what we should do more of in the future."
House and Senate negotiators will convene when Congress returns next month to reconcile the differences in each chamber's balanced-budget resolution.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Seeking To Strip 5,000 Of Citizenship

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will seek to strip the citizenship of nearly 5,000 immigrants who were wrongly naturalized in an immigration drive last year, Federal officials said today.
Revoking that many citizenships at any given time is without precedent for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and it poses enormous legal and logistical challenges for the Federal Government. Until now, the agency has never dealt with more than about two dozen revocations a year. 
 Beginning last fall, Republicans accused the Administration of mounting an election-year campaign to streamline citizenship procedures to allow more than 180,000 immigrants to become citizens before the November elections without having their criminal records fully checked.
As a result of these criticisms, the I.N.S. undertook a review of the nearly 1.1 million people who were granted citizenship from September 1995 to last September to determine how many were wrongfully naturalized.
An audit whose findings were released to Congress today found that 16,400 of the new citizens had a record of at least one felony arrest. Arrest or conviction, by itself, is not grounds for revoking someone's citizenship.
But the audit, which is nearly complete, also found 4,946 cases in which a criminal arrest should have disqualified an applicant or in which an applicant lied about his or her criminal history.
"We believe that we are on firm ground in proceeding on administrative revocations where somebody has factually made a misrepresentation on a felony arrest," Assistant Attorney General Stephen Colgate said at a news conference today.
Today's findings mark the latest blow to the beleaguered immigration agency and its Citizenship U.S.A. program. The program was started in late 1995 to address a mounting backlog of citizenship applications, but Republicans contend that it has been hijacked by White House political operatives along the way for electioneering purposes.
Doris M. Meissner, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, issued a set of sweeping safeguards to prevent immigrants with criminal records from becoming citizens. But an independent review concluded in April that many of the agency's own employees had ignored the directives.
Representative Lamar Smith, a Texas Republican who has been the Administration's most severe critic on the citizenship issue, praised the immigration service today for "making good progress" in tracking down the scofflaws.
"The big question is, 'Is the I.N.S. going to be successful in correcting their mistakes, are they going to be successful in denaturalizing these roughly 5,000 individuals who were wrongly made citizens?' " Mr. Smith said.
In some cases, the offenses may be serious enough, such as a felony conviction for rape or murder, that an individual could have his citizenship revoked and be deported to his native country.
But lying under oath to an immigration examiner is not by itself a deportable offense, and in those circumstances a naturalized citizen would revert to a legal resident alien.
The immigration agency faces enormous hurdles in revoking the citizenship of the immigrants. In the 1995 fiscal year, the latest year for which figures are available, the agency revoked the citizenship of 20 people in procedures that typically took months to complete.
In the past few months, the immigration agency has adopted a simpler revocation process that no longer requires each case to go before a Federal court judge. Under the new system, an immigration administrative officer decides a revocation case; a defendant can appeal the decision to a Federal judge.
Carole Florman, a Justice Department spokeswoman, said the time to process each revocation case would depend on whether an individual contests the process, but could range from days to months.
As to when the nearly 5,000 revocation cases would be completed, Ms. Florman said, "I have no idea."
The immigration agency's general counsel, David Martin, is expected to provide to Congress on June 22 an approximate schedule of when the agency thinks it can complete the revocation proceedings, Ms. Florman said.
At that time, the immigration agency is also expected to ask for more money from Congress to hire additional lawyers and clerks to help deal with the sudden mountain of revocation proceedings.
Of the 4,946 problematic cases that the audit identified, 296 of the immigrants were convicted felons and 2,507 had lied about their criminal history and had a felony arrest or conviction that might have disqualified them from citizenship.
The remaining 2,143 will face revocation proceedings because they lied when asked whether they had ever been arrested, but had only minor offenses. If they had told the truth and said yes, their offenses would not have disqualified them or threatened their citizenship.
In addition to the nearly 5,000 immigrants who were wrongfully naturalized, the immigration agency has been trying to determine how many of the 180,000 people whose criminal backgrounds were never properly checked might have been wrongfully naturalized, too.
It is much harder to weed out the wrongfully made citizens in this group because in many cases, their applications were filled out improperly or the fingerprints that must accompany any application were illegible or missing.
So immigration officials, working with specialists from the accounting firm KPMG/Peat Marwick, have gone through a painstaking match of each individual's name against the Federal Bureau of Investigation's criminal data base.
This review turned up 9,100 people who had the same name as someone in the criminal data base. Whether they are one and the same person, and whether their offenses would disqualify them, is still under review.
The auditors are also reviewing the records of 300 newly naturalized citizens who were arrested on misdemeanors, such as prostitution, that could result in the revocation of their citizenship.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Union Invests in Technology

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: NORTH BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. will invest $14.6 million in a state-sponsored center intended to provide emerging high-technology and biotechnology companies with lease space at a reasonable price, union officials and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's office said yesterday. 
 The funds for the New Jersey Technology Centre in North Brunswick will come from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Building Investment Trust. The center, which opened last year, has three tenants and is negotiating with several other prospective tenants, said Rose Smith, a spokeswoman for the State Economic Development Authority.
