HEADLINE: Where 'Shine' Plays And Is Played Out;
Efforts to Aid Mentally Ill Result In Happy Ending for Movie House

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: WALTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Walton's cherished old movie theater almost had the same rueful ending as the Texas theater in "The Last Picture Show," with a darkened screen taking another bite out of the spirit of a struggling country town.
But the story of Walton's theater has a happy ending because of an unlikely group of rescuers -- a mental health agency and five of its clients who now sell tickets and popcorn and help operate the projector. 
 They have made it possible for Walton's 3,500 residents to see movies like "Liar, Liar" and "101 Dalmatians," the same movies the rest of America is seeing. And the survival of weekend picture shows means the village and surrounding town, which are cut off from many modern pleasures by a ring of Catskills mountains, will keep its social center. Farmers, teachers and factory hands can go on greeting each other in the lobby with pleasantries about the weather; teen-agers can court in the balcony and younger children can have a chance to escape from the routines of small-town life.
"You lose your theater, it's like the last vestige of your sociability," said Andrea R. Paternoster, editor of The Delaware Register and Review, a local weekly. "To me it means you've given up as a town. You've given up any pretense of independence. You're leaving town to go shopping. You're leaving to go the movies. You're leaving to do virtually everything."
Although some civic leaders had misgivings about turning the theater over to a mentally ill staff last July, there are few complaints now, and Mayor Carl Vogel has become the theater's biggest booster.
"The operation is better than I ever remember it," he said. "From the service to the movies to the popcorn."
And the workers say they have found real benefits in dealing with the public.
At a midweek matinee 10 days ago, Theresa Seymour, 44, who suffers from the steep mood swings of bipolar illness, worked the concessions stand, trying to satisfy customers craving popcorn and sodas before the lights dimmed for the movie, "The Saint."
"There's seasoned salt on the table," she told one customer. "Help yourself."
"Thank you. Enjoy the show," she told another as she handed her change for a soda.
Ms. Seymour lives at home with her husband, Gerald, and two sons, Joel, 22, and Gerald Jr., 18. Trying to explain her illness, she said that as a child she was abused by her parents. Then, after she married, she lost a baby shortly after birth and the loss seemed to paralyze her, making her afraid to go out among people. She is happy, she said, that the theater job forces her to deal with the public.
"I'm growing from it," she said.
Walton is hidden away in a valley in the Catskills. Years of economic decline have given its main street the forlorn and faded look of the Texas town called Anarene in the Peter Bogdanovich movie "The Last Picture Show," about a desolate plains town in the 1950's sadly succumbing to the onrush of modern life.
Several stores in Walton's 19th-century utilitarian brick buildings stand empty, and, in those that remain, the merchandise is often shopworn and out of fashion. Though a large Kraft Foods cottage cheese plant employs 210 people, most young people leave to find work elsewhere.
Ambling through Walton, a fan of the Bogdanovich movie almost expects to see a tumbleweed come rolling down a windswept street.
There never was much to do in Walton by big-city standards. The movie theater, the bowling alley and the games of the high school football team, the Warriors, who won the state championship in their division in 1994, were about it.
The 600-seat movie house, though, was a particular treasure. It was built in 1914 with a neo-classical facade featuring four stout Doric columns. Teddy Roosevelt gave a speech at the theater, and it was a stop on the vaudeville circuit. It has been showing films since the heyday of silent movies, though television, videos and the increasing cost of tickets have put a dent in patronage in recent decades.
Last spring the latest operator of the movie theater -- an independent based in Oneonta, N.Y., -- gave up, and the village could not foresee finding a replacement. "Lights out at the Walton Theater," was the front-page headline in The Delaware Register and Review, and a sign on the theater's front door on April 1, 1996, thanked customers for their support.
A closed theater would have forced village residents who wanted to see a movie to drive 45 minutes across mountains to Oneonta. But the theater stayed shuttered for only a few weekends. On July 5, it reopened with the natural-disaster epic "Twister," and it has remained open for weekends and Wednesday matinees ever since.
The Walton Theater has been taken over by one of Walton's less publicized resources, Rehabilitation Support Services, a nonprofit agency that helps the mentally ill find housing and jobs and adapt to their communities. John Phillips, the agency's program director for Delaware County, said that the agency had already been operating a bagel shop in Oneonta for a few years and was looking for another business to employ its clients.
So when it heard about the closing of the local theater, it decided to make a bid to the village board. A couple of board members, Mr. Phillips said, wondered, "How can you have mentally ill people working with the public?" But Mr. Phillips argued that mental illness was not that different from other disabilities and that his clients could be trained to work with the public.
The agency worked out a deal to pay the town rent of $550 a month, the same as the previous operator. It purchased a new popcorn popper and replaced a Pepsi dispenser with a Coke fountain. It bought the projector and other equipment for roughly $4,000. Then it put its clients to work, paying them $4.75 an hour and outfitting them with crimson T-shirts and baseball-style caps advertising the movie theater.
Diane Fehsal, 39, runs the ticket booth. She has bipolar illness, which is also known as manic depression, and is on an antidepressant. Her four children live with her estranged husband. She has worked most of her adult life, she said, and finds it especially congenial to take movie tickets while a soundtrack drifts out of a darkened theater.
"It's the most fun for me because of the idea of going to the movies," she said. "The movie is always on. I like being around movies. And when I'm not working I get to go to the movies for free. I went to see 'Liar, Liar.' I was very tired and the more I got to thinking about it when I got home, I really laughed."
She describes seeing movies as a hobby, "something to get away from life in general, something that makes you laugh, especially with having a mental illness." But she avoids movies with violence and horrors.
"I've always been influenced by what I watch," she said. "I may have nightmares. The movies are pretty extreme."
Marjorie Johnson, 39, has been working with Stanton (Stub) Hogan, who has been projectionist at the theater since 1951. He has been teaching her how to splice movie reels and thread the film along the serpentine path of spools in a projector.
Ms. Johnson, a tall, friendly Brooklyn native who wears her red hair in a braided bun, also has bipolar disorder. She lives with her 4-year-old, Zachariah, in a trailer she rents outside town. Her 7-year-old son, Isaac, is in foster care. Over the years, she has worked as a chambermaid and landscaper, and she was dismissed from her last job as a hairdresser in Oneonta after a customer complained that her hair was cut too short.
Now, she is looking forward to operating the projector by herself.
"Hopefully, it's going to be a lifetime thing," she said. "I'll be like Stub when I get done."
Mr. Hogan, who is in his late 70's, thinks she can soon take his place. "She's doing pretty good," he said.
Don Furgeson, an agency counselor who supervises the operation, said that the theater expected to end its first year in the black and was investing its profit in a new retractable screen that would allow more space for live productions. On Thursday afternoon, the agency celebrated its first anniversary of running the theater, a tad early to be sure, with a free show, a raffle and a barbecue.
Appropriately, the movie was "Shine," the story of a mentally ill person who also manages to make a productive life for himself.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: A Question of Honor;
THE SUBVERSIVE

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis is a columnist for the Magazine. "Trail Fever," his book on the 1996 Presidential campaign, will be published next month by Knopf.

 BODY:
By the time Larry Pressler lost his Senate seat last November, he and Ernest Hollings were barely speaking. For most of the last Congress, the two Senators sat together during Commerce Committee hearings -- Pressler was the Republican chairman, Hollings the ranking Democrat -- doing their best to contribute to the general rancor. It was not a struggle for the fate of the earth; it was not really even a matter of principle; it was simple personal disdain, born of partisan suspicions. Hollings thought Pressler an incompetent fool; Pressler found Hollings overbearing. "The committee was the laughingstock of Washington, a mess," one senior staff member says. "Pressler had no control of things, and so Hollings rolled him every time."
After Pressler lost last year, even as the Republicans retained control of the Senate, the committee chairmanship fell to John McCain, the senior Senator from Arizona. One morning in late February, McCain presided over an inquiry into the television ratings system. He sat at the center of the long curved wooden dais with an expression that alternated between the earnest interest of an elder statesman and the manic impatience of a 14-year-old boy. At one point, a staff member entered and whispered into his right ear and McCain rose to leave. A dozen times each day in Congress, a chairman leaves a committee hearing and passes off the gavel to a fellow party member -- who, in this case, was Conrad Burns, the Republican from Montana. But that morning McCain did something unusual; he handed the gavel to Hollings, the Democrat. A look of alarm crossed Hollings's face; he and McCain exchanged words. Then McCain moved quickly away and was gone before Hollings could fully adjust. 
 Two weeks later, when I asked Hollings what he had said when McCain handed him the gavel, the incident was still pleasantly fresh in his mind: "I said to him, 'John, I'd be delighted to take it, but some of your colleagues might object.' And John said, 'Screw that.' . . . I do admire that John McCain."
 
To Change the Nature of Public Life
 Russ Feingold was elected to the Senate as a Democrat from Wisconsin in 1992 and quickly made it clear that he was willing to be different. His quixotic, poorly funded Senate campaign had featured a list of pledges nailed to his garage door, which, when he arrived in Washington, he adhered to with the zeal of a man who had nothing to lose. "Senators are very good at delivering a message," he explains, by way of illustrating how difficult it is for a freshman Senator to challenge a senior Senator's God-given right to spend public money on his friends. "They'll come up to you in the cloakroom and say, 'What are you trying to do, ruin the Senate?' and then vanish. You never know whether they are kidding or if there is some bite to it." Feingold has no hard evidence that he has paid a price for his cause. On the other hand, he says, "I don't have a great deal of social contact with my colleagues."
After the 1994 elections, in which the Republicans recaptured the Senate, Feingold returned to Wisconsin. He was driving around his state, resigning himself to a future not merely as a social pariah but as a social pariah in the minority party. "Out of 100 Senators," he says, "I was now ranked No. 100." Then a member of his staff handed him a cell phone and said that John McCain was calling. Feingold didn't really know McCain and had no idea why he was phoning.
"This was not a time when a senior-ranking Republican typically would reach out to the lowest-ranking Democrat," Feingold says. "I mean, I was the last Democrat. There was nothing I could do for anybody. What did this guy want with me?"
What McCain wanted was first to compliment Feingold on his conduct over the past two years and then to talk about working together. What McCain was saying without putting it into words was: You are a Democrat, and we disagree on many issues, but we agree on something more important than those issues. Talk soon drifted to the role of money in politics. "What are the odds that a Republican Senator will come anywhere near my vision -- public financing of elections?" Feingold says he asked McCain. The reason no Republican would ever sign on to radical reform, as Feingold saw it, was that money helped Republicans to remain in office even more than it helped Democrats. Why would McCain act so obviously against his party's narrow interests? Why would he jeopardize his new authority?
But as it happened, McCain's ambitions exceeded Feingold's expectations. He had an entire reform agenda that, if enacted, would shatter Washington's political economy -- by limiting Congressional perks, cutting pork and barring retired members of Congress and certain members of their staffs from lobbying for five years. McCain also had the Ferret. The Ferret was the young man on McCain's Senate staff whose duties included sitting in the Senate and blowing the whistle on Senators who tried to slip pork into bills in the dead of night.
But more than any of these things McCain wanted to change the way politicians paid for their campaigns. Private money, he maintained, was corrupting public life. Total public financing of campaigns was out of the question -- McCain objected to the burden it would place on the Treasury -- but everything else was negotiable. As far as he was concerned, a McCain-Feingold bill needed only to pass two simple tests: 1) It must limit the influence of private money in public life. 2) It must reduce the financial advantage incumbents enjoy over challengers and thus make it easier for outsiders to get in and for insiders to be tossed out.
McCain and Feingold put together their bill two years ago, and at first it was something of a joke. "We were like the guys who introduced the bill to convert to the metric system," McCain says. But early this year the joke ceased to be funny. At last count there were 58 alternatives to McCain-Feingold, a lot of them dreamed up by Senators bent on derailing specific provisions of the bill. The details of these bills vary; the message is pretty much the same: Take away his money! Take his, not mine!
Senators tight with well-financed causes (pro-life, pro-guns, pro-trial lawyers, pro-women in Congress) want to ditch the McCain-Feingold ban on political action committees, through which particular causes reward Senators with contributions. Senators beholden to broadcasters object to the McCain-Feingold provision of free television ads to candidates who accept voluntary spending limits. Senators from small states decry the McCain-Feingold provision that requires politicians to raise 60 percent of their funds from people eligible to vote for them -- that would cut into their advantage in raising money from the causes and the corporations. The minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, for instance, who raises 88 percent of his money out of state, mainly from corporations and PAC's, has told fellow Senators that as written McCain-Feingold won't fly. He's for reform, of course. Just not this particular version.
Of course, all Democrats, including Daschle, claim publicly to support McCain-Feingold. Their enthusiasm derives from their certainty that Republicans will find a way to kill it. The single biggest edge Republicans hold over Democrats is the huge sums of money available to them for re-election campaigns. Nothing would blunt the Republican edge so quickly as the most ambitious provision in McCain-Feingold: a ban on soft money.
The phrase is a euphemism for donations that can be made without limit, through a loophole in the present laws, to the political parties and that then can be doled out, in large sums determined by a complicated formula, to individual candidates. People who set out to influence politicians run directly into the $1,000 limit on personal contributions; the limitlessness of soft money is thus crucial to them. It is also important to Republicans because they raise twice as much of it as Democrats. It is especially important to the majority leader, Trent Lott, because he exercises control over the small fortune given to Republican Senators like him. When Lott rose this February at a Republican Party fund-raiser for six-figure donors in Florida and declared that soft money was "the American way," he was merely sanctifying the source of his power.
McCain's ambition is outlandish: not to win a debate (there's no one to debate), or to cut a deal (there's no one to cut it with), but to create a climate of political opinion -- a national mood -- that will overwhelm the immediate interests of some of the shrewdest characters on the planet. The goal is not merely to take money out of politics but to change the nature of public life. "This is a very seductive kind of environment," McCain says. "You are here and you are called a Senator. You have an aura of infallibility. You develop a thing where you feel you really are different and should be treated differently. And live by a different set of rules."
At the moment, any sort of money reform appears unlikely, but that is true of all reform until the moment it occurs. "The model for this," McCain says, is the gift ban. This is the Senate rule McCain and Feingold pushed through two years ago limiting the value of gifts to Senators. "Everyone was against that, too. But when it came to the floor, they couldn't control it -- in that climate nobody wanted to be seen to be against it. It passed 98-0. If campaign finance reform passes, it will pass the same way." To an outsider, it seems strange that Senators could fight a reform nearly to the death and then cave in completely, but then an outsider could not possibly appreciate the importance to Senators of keeping up appearances. To most of them, the war over the role of money in politics is not a matter of principle but a dance between perception and reality.
And so if just a handful of Republicans join with Democrats to create a majority, every other Senator will follow. A small band of Republican Senators either have signed on (Fred Thompson) or have hinted they will sign on (Susan Collins, Olympia Snowe, Sam Brownback) to reform. These politicians are organized not by common interest but by common sentiment, and McCain is not so much their leader as their inspiration. "Without McCain," says Ann McBride of Common Cause, the public interest group that has pushed hardest for campaign reform, "you could forget about it. With him, there is still a chance."
 
The Rise to Power of a Politician Who Lived Dangerously
 I had been following the 1996 Presidential campaign for three months when I first met McCain. He came as a bit of a shock. I was sitting in a private air terminal in Columbia, S.C., late one night waiting for Bob Dole's campaign plane to land when McCain ambled in, unescorted. This in itself was unusual: every big-time politician I had met over the prior months traveled with a posse of aides to rope him off from the world. McCain introduced himself without staring me in the eye meaningfully for 10 seconds, which was also unusual. But what was truly unnerving was that, even though he was a Dole backer, he violated the Dole campaign's three most sacred taboos: he praised Pat Buchanan, he called Ross Perot "a nut" and (the deepest heresy) he suggested that Dole should ignore his paid political operatives who were busy issuing anodyne statements on his behalf instead of letting the candidate speak openly for himself.
At the end of this astonishing monologue, I put down my notebook and tried to figure out what to do. A politician who lived dangerously! A politician who spoke his mind! It was all I could do to stop myself from shouting: Lie! Lie for your life! Lie or some journalist will take a quote from you and twist it around your neck! The man clearly needed to be protected.
It was then that I noticed the faint scar over McCain's right eye and asked him about it. "Oh," he said, "that was just a knife fight back in high school."
Just a knife fight?
With only the vaguest notion of who this man was, I took to following him around -- in the spirit of the beggar who looked for the loose change under the street lamp not because the money was there but because the light was better. It was hardly an original investigative strategy; every political journalist in America seemed to be mining McCain's indiscretions. Once I found myself sitting on the long leather couch in his Senate office watching McCain field calls from The Washington Post, The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times and a gaggle of local Arizona reporters while in the background a television replayed over and again some diatribe he had just delivered in front of the White House. I became used to opening the morning paper and finding McCain's quotes on the front page and his opinions echoed on the editorial page. It was a testament to the growing distrust between the press and the more ordinary politicians. Here was a Republican Senator -- a red meat, pro-life, strong-army kind of guy -- and yet somehow he had become the preferred source of the putatively liberal media.
This paradox had a self-reinforcing logic to it. In the most recent Presidential campaign, for instance, all three major candidates dodged any media they hadn't paid for. Their terror of free talk (and honest scrutiny) led directly to a greater need for paid talk, in the form of television ads that spoke directly (and sometimes dishonestly) to the voters. The greater need for paid talk led to a greater demand for cash. And the greater demand for cash led to tycoons in the Lincoln bedroom and to Chinese arms dealers at a White House "coffee" and to even more distrust between the press and politicians. But it led also to the rise of campaign finance reform -- and with it John McCain.
Every day, the street lamp shone a bit more brightly, until it took in the main events of American politics. For most of his political life, Until early last year, McCain had been effective mainly on small-bore issues: the gift ban, returning power to Native American tribal government, protecting the Grand Canyon from further noise pollution. Then a year ago he pushed through the line-item veto. He had long had an interest in international affairs; but with Sam Nunn's decision not to seek re-election and then Bob Dole's retirement last June, McCain became one of the Senate's leading spokesmen on foreign policy. Last August, he narrowly missed being selected as Dole's Vice Presidential running mate before playing a starring role at the Republican convention in San Diego; after the fall election, he ascended to the chairmanship of the Commerce Committee and was dubbed by one of the broadcasting trade sheets "the most powerful man in American television." By sheer good fortune, I was witnessing up close a politician's rise. What McCain was up to, it turned out, was rising from prominence to power. But there was something odd about this politician: his rise through the power structure seemed merely to increase his desire to blow it apart.
You can tell a lot about a Senator by who finds it worth their time to visit him. There were days earlier this spring when the reception room of McCain's Senate office was jammed with Washington's version of political terrorists: people who wanted McCain to help them to park a 900-pound pig in front of the National Press Club to dramatize the problem of political pork (he did); people who wanted him to spend his vacation flying around the country insulting people who gave large sums of money to politicians (ditto); people who wanted him to declare war on the networks by insisting that the digital television spectrum be auctioned publicly rather than simply given away for free (he did and lost). Maybe a dozen times I turned up unannounced in McCain's office (he keeps the door open) and found him pacing back and forth behind his desk, ginning up trouble. "I knew there would be a scandal because I knew the system was out of control," he would be saying. "But I didn't know there would be a foreign money scandal." Or, "Both parties are equally guilty." Or, "We need to go outside the Beltway, and we need to go hard." Or, "I'll tell you when we'll know it's time: Trent Lott will come to me and say, 'O.K., let's bring the bill to the floor."'
You can also tell a lot about a Senator by what other Senators say about him when he's out of earshot. When I mentioned McCain's name to John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat, for instance, he stopped the conversation cold and said: "That man did things for his country that few people could go through. Never forget that! And never forget that his tribal instincts do not overwhelm what he thinks is right and wrong." And when I asked Fred Thompson -- who will lead the Senate's hearings on campaign finance reform now scheduled for this summer -- whether McCain was a typical Senator, he nearly jumped through the telephone. "No, no no," he said. "He's an inspiration. It doesn't bother him to go against the grain. He feels just as strongly about how we do things, not just what we do." Before Thompson declared for his Tennessee Senate seat in 1994, he flew to Washington to talk to McCain, "to see whether or not any of this amounted to anything, whether or not it was worth it."
The unflattering view of McCain in the Senate is never offered for attribution, but it is easy to hear: that he is a creation of the media who exploits virtue for personal advancement. "What's in it for him?" is the question that lurks beneath the surface of the conversation of such Senators and their staffers. They view his desire for reform -- and his openness to the media -- as part of a cynical strategy for self-advancement. I was told more than once around the Senate that campaign finance reform is an issue McCain is seeking to ride to the White House. And, of course, there's no arguing with this line of thinking because McCain does benefit from his crusade -- reprters write about it, people care about it.
 
The Making of an Idealist
 Most Senators start out as junior-class president, shimmy their way into state legislatures or onto Senate staffs or maybe into the House, until finally their turn comes and they make a little death lunge for the big time. Occasionally, they have the passion of those who are called; more often, they have the feeling of those who suddenly can afford to move up in the world, like a Monopoly player who has landed on Park Place. But either way, they ascend to their positions, and the arc winds up defining them. When they die, they will be remembered chiefly for having been Senators.
McCain's path was different. Like Bill Bradley and John Glenn, he more or less descended into American Government: no matter what he does in the Senate, he will always be remembered chiefly for what he did before he became a Senator. But McCain differs in spirit even from the conventional heroes. From very early on, both Bradley and Glenn handled their careers with the most extreme caution; as they rose in life, both men seemed to keep politics in the back of their minds, or others, at any rate, kept politics in mind for them. McCain was a little darker and far messier: for most of his life, he seemed intent on proving that he'd never be elected to anything.
He finished 790th out of 795 in his Naval Academy class of 1958, where he set some sort of record for incurring the wrath of the authorities. On graduation, he became one of those Navy pilots who lurched from brawls to accidents to women and then back to brawls. Had he succeeded in killing himself in a Navy jet (as he nearly did twice), no one would have thought that it had any bearing on the future of American Government. Politics -- its obligations, its risk aversion, its sober responsibilities -- never crossed McCain's mind, at least not until he returned home from Vietnam. He was 37 years old, and every politician in America wanted to have his picture taken with him. Politics had found him, or at any rate his experience.
Public accounts of McCain's experience as a prisoner of war tend to focus on his physical toughness. Here is how Robert Timberg, in his gripping book "The Nightingale's Song," depicts McCain after two months in a North Vietnamese prison camp:
McCain weighed less than 100 pounds. His hair, flecked with gray since high school, was nearly snowwhite. Clots of food clung to his face, neck, hair and beard. His cheeks were sunken, his neck chickenlike, his legs atrophied. His knee bore a fresh surgical slash, his ankle an angry scar from the bayonet wound.
 His right arm, little more than skin and bone, protruded like a stick. But it was McCain's eyes that riveted [his cellmate, Bud] Day. "His eyes, I'll never forget, were just burning bright. They were bug-eyed like you see in those pictures from the Jewish concentration camps. His eyes were real pop-eyed like that. I said, 'The gooks have dumped this guy on us so they can blame us for killing him,' because I didn't think he was going to live out the day."
For nine days, McCain received no treatment for the injuries he sustained when he parachuted into a North Vietnamese mob: two broken arms, a shattered knee, a shattered shoulder and bayonet wounds in his ankle and his groin. He survived in captivity for the next five and a half years under constant, exquisite torture. His captors would hang him by his broken arms from dangling ropes for hours on end, for instance, the sort of stuff that even to read about causes sweat to pop out on your brow. But McCain's capacity to suffer was the least of what the experience revealed about him. The truly astonishing part of the story -- the moment where you cease cringing and go numb with wonder, when you, too, want to have your picture taken with McCain -- is that he did it . . . voluntarily.
McCain belongs to a distinguished military family; his father and grandfather are the only four-star father and son in United States military history, and his father was commanding the bombing of Hanoi at the time McCain's Navy fighter was shot down. The North Vietnamese planned for their famous P.O.W. to violate United States military policy, which dictated that prisoners return in the order they arrived. His early release might demoralize American troops, they figured. Except that he wouldn't go along. For five and a half years, they tortured McCain. For five and a half years, he refused to go home.
He had no choice in the matter, he later explained. To accept early release would have dishonored not only himself but his family. You just didn't do that.
When he did return home from Vietnam in 1973, McCain stepped into the arms of Republican America. He met President Nixon at the White House and Ronald Reagan, then the Governor of California, at a . Perhaps sensing a lobbying opportunity, the Navy named McCain its attache to the United States Senate. "I couldn't believe how much power a Senator could have," McCain says, by way of explaining why it dawned on him to become one. But it is easier to put the man into politics than to put the politics into the man. Just as others, including the Reagans, hoped he was grooming himself for political office, McCain ejected from his first marriage in a semipublic blaze of womanizing. In 1980, he married an Arizona native named Cindy Hensley. Two years later, having moved to Arizona, he ran for a seat in the House of Representatives.
McCain's early political career had the flavor of an arranged marriage: all that Arizona knew of McCain was his war record, but that was more than McCain knew of Arizona. "I got lost on the way to my own rallies," he says. But for so many reasons, none of this mattered, and one of those reasons was Charles Keating. Keating is the former owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan whose various machinations wound up costing the taxpayers more than $3 billion. He first offered McCain his political support in 1981, after a speech McCain gave in Phoenix at a Navy League dinner to which Keating had brought his family. A year later, McCain called him back. Together with friends and associates, Keating contributed $56,000 to McCain's first House race, another $56,000 to the second and $54,000 to his 1986 Senate campaign. Between 1983 and 1986, McCain and his family spent a week a year at Keating's vacation house in the Bahamas.
Of course, money in politics is rarely a direct bribe. Often, people give not because they expect anything in return but because they find it easier than not giving. When your biggest client calls you and asks you to contribute $1,000 to the Clinton campaign, you don't think much about it; you write the check. But Charlie Keating, it turned out, expected something in return. He expected McCain and others to pressure Federal regulators to look the other way while he played fast and loose with taxpayers' money.
All of this quickly came out when the story broke in early 1989 that McCain, together with four other Senators similarly favored by Keating -- Glenn, Donald Riegle of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Alan Cranston of California -- had gathered twice in 1987 to discuss Keating's complaint that he was being treated too harshly by Federal bank regulators. McCain was branded one of "the Keating Five" and dragged into a Senate investigation to determine exactly what he had done in exchange for Keating's money. When you go back over the Senate Ethics Committee hearings, which lasted 14 months, you see pretty clearly that he did surprisingly little. Both the committee and the transcripts are conclusive on this point. One incident in particular leaps out. When he saw that McCain would not interfere with the law on his behalf, Keating took to insulting McCain behind his back. Word got back to McCain that Keating had been all over the Senate calling him "a wimp." A McCain staff member who was present at a subsequent meeting between McCain and Keating recalled for the Senate Ethics Committee how it played out:
In all the time . . . I've been around John he, himself, although he will answer questions in response to his experience in Vietnam, I have never, except for this one occasion, heard him raise his prisoner-of-war experience. And very early on in that meeting, I remember him vividly telling Mr. Keating that he hadn't spent five and a half years of his life in a prisoner-of-war camp to have his courage or integrity questioned. And he gave Mr. Keating a dressing down, the likes of which I, in my experience on the Hill, have never experienced a Senator giving a major employer of his state. It was startling to me.
From that moment on, McCain had nothing more to do with Keating. And in the end the Senate Ethics Committee decided that McCain had done nothing seriously wrong. He was guilty only of "poor judgment." But the Senate Ethics Committee had long before lost its moral authority, and with it, its power to absolve anyone. Before the dust settled, a poll in The Arizona Republic would show that nearly half of all Arizona residents thought he should resign immediately or at the end of his term. More importantly, the motives behind his behavior would always be questioned. For example, in late 1989 McCain called Senator David Boren, an early leader on finance reform, to say that he would like to help. His offer was accepted, but no one doubted why he had made it. "McCain's only interest in a Boren bill," Boren's chief aide later wrote, "was to further distance himself from the Keating bombshell."
One of the traits McCain's staff finds most maddening in their boss is his tendency to recall for journalists only his most damning moments. Ask him about Vietnam and he'll tell you about the time he stole a washrag from the guy in the adjoining cell. Ask him about his first marriage and he'll leap right to his adultery. It was he who first mentioned Charles Keating to me. We were sitting together in the back seat of a car on the way to a fund-raiser for another candidate. McCain was flipping through an album of photographs taken during the Republican convention. The album was a Who's Who of Republican politics, and McCain seemed to be at the center of every picture. I made some comment about how much more valuable his time had become in just the few months since we had met in South Carolina. He fixed me with a stare. "One thing I learned from the Keating affair," he said, "was that this could all end tomorrow. Just like that." He snapped his fingers.
That is one kind of explanation of why he is so insistent on pressing his reform agenda: if he doesn't get it done now, he may never have another chance. But he quickly went on to saying something else, something demonstrating another motive. "You know," he said, "my honor and integrity were at stake in Vietnam when the Vietnamese offered me freedom. I was very tempted to take it. But when I didn't, it was over -- at least when the beatings stopped it was over. In the Keating scandal, my honor and integrity were at stake again: I was accused of betraying my oath of office. I've never been able to explain very clearly how I felt. How painful it was. And, by the way, I did wrong. I shouldn't have attended that meeting. But I don't think I'll ever be absolved. I'll always be known as one of the Keating Five."
 
The Realist
 We tend to assume that the trait that most clearly defines a politician is his party affiliation rather than, say, his temperament or life experience. But it is hard to imagine a man more different in this respect from John McCain than Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, his fellow Republican Senator. McConnell has sought and gained precisely those positions that give him the power to block McCain's reform agenda. As chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee, for instance, he successfully stymied the investigation of Bob Packwood. Twice he tried and failed to win the chairmanship of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which controls the tens of millions of dollars the party spends on their own. Last year he finally won the post, which gives him control over the money his colleagues need for re-election. In a meeting with the Republican leadership earlier this year, called to discuss the McCain-Feingold bill, McConnell reportedly said, "if we stop this thing, we can control the institution for the next 20 years."
It's one thing for a Senator to work behind closed doors to preserve his job and perks even when there is an overwhelming public objection to his doing so. It's quite another for a Senator to summon the nerve to go to the Senate floor and defend the role of big money in politics. But that is what McConnell has done. One morning in March, McConnell staged what must rank among the more audacious and brave news conferences ever held. He gathered together representatives of a dozen special interest groups that had banded together to fight campaign finance reform: the National Rifle Association, the Christian Coalition, the National Association of Broadcasters, the National Association of Realtors, the American Civil Liberties Union. (The list is strikingly similar to the list of names John Glenn has submitted for subpoenas in the campaign finance probe soon to be conducted by the Government Affairs Committee.)
Perhaps 60 reporters found their seats as McConnell moved to a bank of microphones. There is something old-fashioned about his appearance. A high pink tints his soft fleshy cheeks and his lips are pursed in a way that suggests perpetual disapproval. Beside him was a placard bearing the words of the House minority leader, Richard Gephardt, and his disapproval's immediate source:
 What we have is two important values in direct conflict: freedom of speech and our desire for healthy campaigns in a healthy democracy. You can't have both.
The text served as the keynote for McConnell's address, in which he came down firmly on the side of free speech. His approach was to steamroller his audience with his superior knowledge of the relevant Supreme Court decision, Buckley v. Valeo, in 1976. "How many of you have actually read the Buckley case?" he asked. Two hands rose -- not enough to stop him -- and before long McConnell was saying things like "soft money is just a euphemism for free speech." At length, McConnell finished, and one by one the lobbyists took turns at the podium decrying this threat to their First Amendment rights. Thirty minutes later, they were through, and an uncomfortable hush descended upon the room. A single hand finally went up at the front of the room. Ed Chen of The Los Angeles Times had a question.
"I'm trying to understand," he said. "Would any of you like to see any change in the system?"
The room went silent again; the lobbyists shifted back and forth; the portrait of George Washington stared down upon the proceedings; the crystal chandeliers hung ponderously from their hoary chains; the oak paneling creaked. At times like these, it's left for the architecture alone to give politics any aura of credibility.
"Next question," McConnell said.
The more you watch McConnell at work, the more you can see that it isn't only a bill at stake but an attitude toward public life. He is as pure an expression of political realism as McCain is of political idealism. The realistic view of politics these days runs something like this: the guy with the most money gets the power and the guy with the most power wins. McConnell won his Senate seat in 1988 with an expensive negative advertising campaign aimed at the incumbent, Dee Huddleston. Money has been his organizing principle ever since, which is why he went to such great lengths to get his hands on the Republican Party's senatorial war chest. His most lethal weapon against finance reform is not the First Amendment, though it is true that the best way to kill an issue is to complicate it. His most lethal weapon is the narrow interest of his fellow Senators, coupled with the public apathy that enables them to act on it. (A recent New York Times/CBS poll showed, for instance, that while 90 percent of the electorate say that money is corrupting politics, only 23 percent expect Congress to do anything about it.) "There is absolutely no chance that McCain-Feingold will become law," McConnell often declares. And when he does, you know that he knows things about his colleagues that you and I never will.
 
Building a Fire
 Next to McConnell, McCain appears naive - and doomed. One evening I left his office and went immediately next door to see the senior Republican Senator from Maine, Olympia Snowe. I was following up on a rumor that Snowe -- like her Maine colleague, Susan Collins -- was one of the Senators on whom McConnell, on behalf of the Republican leadership, paid a vaguely threatening call. At a time when McCain-Feingold needed Republican support, Snowe was an obvious candidate to provide it, since Maine had just passed strict new state campaign finance rules. When I laid out the story and asked her why she hadn't joined in, she said, "John never asked me." This was disingenuous but also extraordinary. When I asked McCain why he hadn't applied the sort of pressure on his colleagues that the other side had, he said: "I'm not good at asking people for things. If she wants to co-sponsor the bill, she will co-sponsor the bill."
There's vanity in his approach, but there's also an acknowledgment that if he sinks to the level of his opponent he undermines the source of his power. The source of McCain's power is not the money he can provide fellow Senators for their re-election campaigns but public opinion. He doesn't need to ask Snowe for her help because he knows his only hope for it is to light a fire under Maine that will have her running to join his cause. After all, the gift ban passed the Senate only because the public became enraged. "Once it gets to the Senate floor," McCain says of the finance reform bill, "it may be hard for anyone to control it."
In mid-March, the Senate Republicans met for lunch to discuss the probe into Clinton's campaign finance scandal. Republicans, led by McConnell, wanted to limit Fred Thompson, chairman of the investigating committee, to examining only illegal campaign activities. The Democrats hoped to widen the probe to include "improper" activities as well and to implicate Republicans and Democrats alike, thereby lessening the heat on President Clinton. Trent Lott told his fellow Republicans that their vote against the Democratic proposal was "a test of party loyalty."
"The thing you have to remember," McCain often says to explain why he likes and admires Lott, "is that Trent Lott only came to the Senate eight years ago. And now he is the most powerful man in Washington." But after Lott spoke that day at lunch, McCain rose and said he could not go along. How in good conscience could one refuse the chance to investigate what is obviously improper? McCain was quickly followed by Fred Thompson, who concurred. Thompson was followed by Arlen Specter, then Susan Collins, then Dan Coates and then Olympia Snowe. Just a month before, it had been unthinkable that this many Republicans would defy the leadership on this issue. But the nearly daily revelations of campaign finance scandals turned up the heat. Eventually, Lott realized that he had a full-scale rebellion on his hands and conceded the point.
Afterward, McCain told me that a broad public investigation of both parties was campaign finance reform's only hope. I asked him if it bothered him that President Clinton's authority was certain to be undermined by the scandal. Clinton has declared himself an ardent supporter of the McCain-Feingold bill, and so his authority is useful to McCain. "I'd rather have the scandal than his support," McCain said. The statement says as much about the way the political world now functions as anything I've heard: what happens to Clinton is more useful than any positive action Clinton could achieve. "If it happens," says McCain of reform, "it will happen for the wrong reasons."
 
Politics Is Not Life
 One morning not long ago, just after 7, I met McCain at his Senate office. The rest of the Senate was still asleep; the typical Senate staffer, knowing that his day might not end until well past 8, doesn't wander into his office until 9:00. But half a dozen of McCain's closest aides already were working. McCain looked as if he'd had a bad night, and with reason. "I woke up at 3 in the morning and stared at the ceiling about this McConnell thing," he said.
The previous night, an Administration aide had told McCain that he -- the aide -- was scheduled to appear the following morning before a Senate subcommittee headed by Mitch McConnell. He had been told that McConnell planned to grill him about a political trip McCain took last fall to Burma. In exchange for letting McCain pay a call on the Burmese dissident Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who remains under house arrest, the Burmese Government required the presence of the other opposition parties. The United States charge d'affaires agreed to the conditions and McCain went off to Burma. But among the opposition, it turned out, were several drug traffickers. The question McConnell intended to put to the White House man was, "What was John McCain doing in the same room in Burma with these notorious international drug dealers?"
On the one hand, it was a trivial thing. It's possible that McConnell meant nothing by it, that his target was the White House and that he merely forgot to warn McCain. On the other hand, there is no better way to stop reform than to discredit the reformer.
By 7:30 we were on the road, and McCain was reminiscing about his early political career. When he was elected to the House in 1982, he said, he was "a freshman right-wing Nazi." But his visceral hostility toward Democrats generally was quickly tempered by his tendency to see people as individuals and judge them that way. He was taken in hand by Morris Udall, the Arizona Congressman who was the liberal conscience of the Congress and a leading voice for reform. (Most famously -- and disastrously for his own career -- Udall took aim at the seniority system that kept young talent in its place at the end of the dais. "The longer you're here, the more you'll like it," he used to joke to incoming freshmen.)
"Mo reached out to me in 50 different ways," McCain recalled. "Right from the start, he'd say: 'I'm going to hold a press conference out in Phoenix. Why don't you join me?' All these journalists would show up to hear what Mo had to say. In the middle of it all, Mo would point to me and say, 'I'd like to hear John's views.' Well, hell, I didn't have any views. But I got up and learned and was introduced to the state." Four years later, when McCain ran for and won Barry Goldwater's Senate seat, he said he felt his greatest debt of gratitude not to Goldwater -- who had shunned him -- but to Udall. "There's no way Mo could have been more wonderful," he says, "and there was no reason for him to be that way."
For the past few years, Udall has lain ill with Parkinson's disease in a veterans hospital in Northeast Washington, which is where we were heading. Every few weeks, McCain drives over to pay his respects. These days the trip is a ceremony, like going to church only less pleasant. Udall is seldom conscious, and even then he shows no sign of recognition. McCain brings with him a stack of newspaper clips on Udall's favorite subjects: local politics in Arizona, environmental legislation, Native American land disputes, subjects in which McCain initially had no particular interest himself. Now, when the Republican Senator from Arizona takes the floor on behalf of Native Americans, or when he writes an op-ed piece arguing that the Republican Party embrace environmentalism, or when the polls show once again that he is Arizona's most popular politician, he remains aware of his debt to Arizona's most influential Democrat.
One wall of Udall's hospital room was cluttered with photos of his family back in Arizona; another bore a single photograph of Udall during his season with the Denver Nuggets, dribbling a basketball. Aside from a Congressional seal glued to a door jamb, there was no indication what the man in the bed had done for his living. Beneath a torn gray blanket on a narrow hospital cot, Udall lay twisted and disfigured. No matter how many times McCain tapped him on the shoulder and called his name, his eyes remained shut.
A nurse entered and seemed surprised to find anyone there, and it wasn't long before I found out why: almost no one visits anymore. In his time, which was not very long ago, Mo Udall was one of the most-sought-after men in the Democratic Party. Yet as he dies in a veterans hospital a few miles from the Capitol, he is visited regularly only by a single old political friend, John McCain. "He's not going to wake up this time," McCain said.
On the way out of the parking lot, McCain recalled what it was like to be a nobody called upon by a somebody. As he did, his voice acquired the same warmth that colored Russell Feingold's speech when he described the first call from John McCain. "When you called Feingold . . ." I started to ask him. But before I could, he interrupted. "Yeah," he says, "I thought of Mo." And then, for maybe the third time that morning, McCain spoke of how it affected him when Udall took him in hand. It was a simple act of affection and admiration, and for that reason it meant all the more to McCain. It was one man saying to another, We disagree in politics but not in life. It was one man saying to another, Party political differences cut only so deep. Having made that step, they found much to agree upon and many useful ways to work together. This is the reason McCain keeps coming to see Udall even after Udall has lost his last shred of political influence. The politics were never all that important.

PUB-DATE: May 25, 1997,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1305 words

HEADLINE: Birth of an Empire

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes's most recent books are "A Concise History of the Russian Revolution" and "The Unknown Lenin."

 BODY:

RUSSIA
 People and Empire, 1552-1917.
 By Geoffrey Hosking.
 Maps. 548 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 The collapse of the Soviet Union -- the last of the European empires -- has stimulated keen interest in the subject of Russian national identity. Britain, France and the other Western powers surrendered their colonies with varying degrees of good grace. If they resisted decolonization, it was to retain valuable economic and strategic assets. But their ultimate loss did not affect the way these onetime imperial powers viewed themselves, because their ethnic identity had been formed long before they acquired any colonies.
Russia was different. The separation in 1991 of the 15 so-called union republics not only reduced its population by nearly one-half but transformed it, for the first time since the 16th century, into an ethnically homogeneous country in which Russians, who had constituted around 50 percent of the Soviet population, make up 83 percent of the inhabitants.
Their predicament results from the fact that unlike the English, who never confused themselves with their Indian subjects, or the French, who remained French even as they lorded it over Algeria, Russians never drew a clear distinction between themselves as a nation and as an imperial power. This was partly because their empire grew at the same time as their national state, and partly because their colonial possessions lay not overseas but along Russia's land frontiers. As Geoffrey Hosking, the Professor of Russian History at the University of London, explains in the introduction to "Russia: People and Empire, 1552-1917," "There are two kinds of Russianness, one connected with the people, the language and the pre-imperial principalities, the other with the territory, the multinational empire, the European great power." The first kind is rendered by the term russky, the second by rossiisky -- a distinction impossible to translate but not unlike that distinguishing "English" from "British."
The loss of empire has left many Russians bewildered because their view of themselves as a nation had been intimately connected with their self-image as a great imperial power. It has revealed how weakly developed is the Russians' sense of national identity. Mr. Hosking attributes that weakness to imperialism overwhelming nationhood in Russia's history. Or, as he puts it in explaining the objective of his book, he is seeking to demonstrate "how the building of an empire impeded the formation of a nation." Paraphrased, this means that Russians have difficulty feeling Russian unless they rule others.
The problem Mr. Hosking raises is not new, but he is the first to explore it in depth. Because the subject is embedded in the entire past of Russia, much of his book has slight bearing on the subject at hand and turns into a straightforward account of Russia's political, social and cultural history from the birth of the Russian empire under Ivan the Terrible until the Revolution of 1917.
Following a survey of Russia's territorial expansion and absorption of many European and Asian ethnic groups, the author proceeds to a description of the Russian state. He explains the highly centralized and autocratic nature of the Muscovite regime by the "patrimonial outlook" that placed the "lands and people . . . completely at the disposal" of the ruler, with the result that society, being "structured for service to the state," failed to acquire an independent existence. It is an interpretation with which I am in full agreement: the Weberian concept of patrimonialism, under which the state treats the realm as property and assigns its subjects no rights but only duties, has always seemed to me the best explanation of the course of Russian history.
In the middle section, Mr. Hosking examines imperial Russia's social classes, religion and culture. It is not always clear what bearing the descriptions of such groups as the nobility or the army have on the subject of nation building, but they are interesting in themselves, being well informed and lucidly presented. The chapter on the peasantry, however, which at one time constituted over 80 percent of the population, does bring out clearly how their confinement to the "rural ghetto," where they lived as serfs of the state or its nobility, prevented them from feeling themselves members of a nation. Such loyalty to a larger group as they managed to develop was confined to the community of Orthodox believers. Mr. Hosking castigates the Orthodox Church, however, for its dependence on the state and its failure to socialize peasants.
The true founders of Russian national consciousness, Mr. Hosking says, were the writers and intellectuals who emerged as an independent force in the second quarter of the 19th century and assumed the role of spokesmen for the mute masses. It is they who created the modern Russian language and literature, along with the ideologies that whether radical or conservative, gave educated Russians a sense of common destiny. I believe Mr. Hosking overstates the patriotism of Russian writers like Turgenev and Tolstoy, for they rather scorned its common manifestations. But he is correct in saying that as a result of the writers' achievement, "by the end of the 19th century, a genuine Russian nation was beginning to take shape, though only as yet in the form of a reading public, an 'imagined community.' "
The concluding part of the book deals with the turbulent period of reforms, counterreforms and revolutionary upheavals. Defeat in the Crimean War (1854-56) persuaded the conservative monarchy that it could not aspire to the status of a great power without bridging the gap between the state and society. The emancipation of the serfs, along with the introduction of a modern judiciary system and of local self-government boards in the 1860's, contributed to the strengthening of national bonds. So did the constitutional regime inaugurated, under revolutionary pressure, in 1905-6, especially when headed by Prime Minister Pyotr Stolypin, who made a conscious effort to involve a larger proportion of the people in the political process and transform the monarch from a remote, bureaucratic head of state into a leader of the nation.
But even so, the links that led to the temporary bonding of Russian society at the outbreak of World War I or after the collapse of czarism in 1917 were not strong enough to prevent Russia's disintegration and the assumption of power by a Bolshevik dictatorship, "a new kind of imperial regime," which "rested on nothing more substantial than its own internal discipline." In the civil war, which decided Russia's fate for most of the 20th century, patriotic appeals by White generals fell on deaf ears while Bolshevik calls for the seizure of private property found wide resonance.
DOES it matter in an age when the world seeks to transcend nationalism that Russians have failed to develop a strong sense of nationhood? Indeed it does. Such a development "would have made their evolution less unstable, polarized and violent. . . . The nation-state has proved to be the most effective political unit . . . because it is the largest one compatible with creating and sustaining a feeling of community and solidarity, such as induces loyalty and reduces the need for coercion."
This means that the Russians of today would be well advised to give up fantasies of reconquering their lost empire -- fantasies common to both conservatives and democrats -- and concentrate on building a genuine nation-state. Nationalism, defined as "a feeling of community and solidarity," which the West has put behind itself and which it has turned into a reactionary doctrine, is distinctly progressive at the stage of history at which Russia happens to find itself.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 847 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Flying Into Sarajevo: Possible, but Not Easy

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO

 BODY:
EVEN though the Bosnian war has been over for more than a year, there is still something faintly incongruous about the idea of taking a scheduled flight into Sarajevo -- a city associated for many people with spiraling descents from the air by military transport planes, sniper fire on the streets and danger.
Yet since last fall Croatia Airlines has been flying twice-daily flights by propeller-driven airplanes from Zagreb, and earlier this year Austrian Airlines became the first Western European airline to schedule services from Vienna. 
 That being said, the Sarajevo schedules are erratic and still provide something of a frisson if only because the civilian airplanes that now compete with military planes for Bosnia's airspace fly under what aviators call visual flight regulations -- meaning that if the pilots can't physically see the runway to land, they don't fly to Sarajevo.
On one recent trip to the Bosnian capital, that made for a jagged kind of journey for a reporter who took off from Cologne airport in Germany with a confirmed ticket on Austrian Airlines to Vienna and Sarajevo, only to find, in Vienna, that the Austrian Airlines staff had just announced the cancellation of the onward flight.
Bad weather was the given reason. Snow on the runway, one Austrian Airlines official told the huddle of passengers clamoring around the check-in desk.
But there was an alternative. A flight to Zagreb, the Croatian capital, was about to board. And from Zagreb there were scheduled flights on Croatia Airlines the following day.
This is not the kind of travel easily accomplished on a tight budget, because the air fares are steep in the first place ($610 for a round-trip economy ticket from Cologne on Austrian Airlines, $250 round trip for the short hop between Zagreb and Sarajevo) and an overnight halt in Zagreb meant an unscheduled hotel stopover, not to mention the ludicrously overpriced cab fares between Zagreb airport and the downtown area (around $35 to $40 for a run that takes half the time of J.F.K. to Manhattan).
Neither is it the kind of travel for those who love their sleep. The wake-up call the next morning came at 4 A.M. because the Croatia Airlines flight to Sarajevo was leaving at 5:40 A.M. -- except that it didn't, but travelers had to get to the airport first to learn of the cancellation.
"Bad weather in Sarajevo. We wait," said a somewhat surly Croatia Airlines officer at around 5 A.M. By 6 the flight had been canceled, and passengers had rebooked on the 12:55 P.M.
Back to the hotel. Back to bed. Then back to the airport at noon. And -- presto -- the flight was on.
It is only a short hop, perhaps 45 minutes as opposed to a drive that can take anything up to seven hours. But, that April noon, it was the kind of flight to concentrate the mind, despite the assurances of people in Zagreb that the Croatia Airlines pilots know the terrain and the conditions better than anyone else.
"If they don't want to fly, neither do you," said one American expatriate in the Croatian capital.
The twin-engine airplane sped skyward and almost immediately was in cloud that provided an occasional earthward glimpse of a snowscape covering the former killing grounds of Croatia and Bosnia. Then the cloud closed in for good, which was fine while the airplane was cruising -- with all the courtesies of cabin service and coffee -- but not so fine when it started to lose altitude on a final approach that still did not reveal a glimpse of the runway.
The passengers, many of whom seemed to be business types seeking a fast buck in Sarajevo's freewheeling black market economy, were uncannily quiet, and at least one of them was trying to remember geography -- how high was Mount Igman, the mountain overlooking Sarajevo? What other heights stood on the approach line? Finally, though, the questions were answered. The airplane dropped from the clouds. Mount Igman was somewhere off and above to the right, its snowbound summit shrouded in the murk the plane had just left. The landing was smooth as silk in a city still partly in bombed-out ruins.
The airport itself was a war-battered monument to the siege of Sarajevo, with shell-pocked buildings and one passenger walkway leaning crazily out from the half-lighted main terminal toward a runway dotted with military installations. Then came a ride into town past gaping, gutted houses on the former front line.
Even today, driving along the broad boulevard between Communist-era high-rises, it is all too easy to recall that those high buildings gave cover for the snipers who, in turn, created the deathtrap known as Sniper's Alley. And lest anyone think Bosnia is even close to a normal kind of life, my hotel -- the downtown Hotel Bosnia -- insisted on cash settlement in German marks, the principal currency, of the exorbitant $180 a night it charged for a modest room.
For the return journey to Croatia, the passenger who had pondered geography from the air took a sudden interest in the terrestrial, found a friend with a Land Rover and drove back to Zagreb.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1195 words

HEADLINE: The View From: New Haven;
Day Care: What Works, What's Needed

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
IS Calvin Hill (a) the name of a former Dallas Cowboy running back (b) the father of Grant Hill of the Detroit Pistons basketball team or (c) the name of a 26-year-old day care center at Yale University in New Haven?
The answer is all of the above. 
Calvin Hill, the father of the basketball player, lent his name to the child care establishment years ago when his Yale classmate Kurt Schmoke, now Mayor of Baltimore, asked him to.
And alumni of all ages remain a loyal constituency.
Katie Halleck, 8 years old and now a third grader at Beecher Road School in Woodbridge, reminisced: "When I was younger I went to Calvin Hill every morning. I used to go to the corner to see my friend Adam. We liked the monkey bars best and meeting time." Meeting, when the children at the center may discuss whatever is on their minds, continues to be a favorite time for the youngsters.
Carla Horwitz, director of the center for more than 20 years, said, "We believe in solving problems. We help them find their own voice, negotiate and solve problems without violence. The way to do that is to model that behavior for children and help them when they feel overwhelmed. Words are the thing you want them to begin to use and make work for them because words are very powerful."
She recalled that during the Persian Gulf war the children were worried they might not be safe. During meeting time one 5-year-old asked, "Why don't they use their words?"
Calvin Hill has a complex mission: to provide intellectual, social and emotional care and make it all fun. "We want our school to serve as a bridge between home and school. We feel like family," Ms. Horwitz said. "Kids learn to take care of each other." They learn cooperation, not competition.
"We listen to the kids, pay attention to their wishes and design the curriculum based on their interests and what they already know," she said. "We believe in doing what's best for the children, which may not always be best for the parents" -- or the staff, for that matter.
For example, Calvin Hill's program runs from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. or, with special arrangements, a bit later. "I feel a little bit like a dinosaur," said Ms. Horwitz, "Society makes so many demands on parents. It used to be unusual for a child to be here from 8 until 5 P.M. Now all over the country that is the norm. Parents are asking for us to remain open later than that or earlier than that or more time than that. People used to leave at 3 or 3:30 P.M. or whenever they could get away."
Parents are enthusiastic in their praise of the center.
Melanie Ginter, a psychotherapist who lives six blocks away and is expecting a baby in June, sometime joins her daughter, Natalie, for lunch. "I feel very welcome," she said. "We love it. There is support here for parents."
Ms. Horwitz, like many professionals in her field, is deeply concerned about what she sees as a two-tiered day care system."There are those who can afford quality day care and those who cannot, who receive abysmal care," she said. She is especially troubled by some for-profit care. "It can look okay on the surface but when you look deeper you find high staff turnover and untrained people." At Calvin Hill, she sets salary and benefits high enough to keep staff members, and treats them like professionals, not baby sitters, she said.
"There is so much bad child care that when I see a place like Calvin Hill I rejoice," said Prof. Edward F. Zigler, Sterling professor of psychology and a founder of the Head Start program during the Nixon Administration. "I like their economic and ethnic diversity, their sensitivity to a developmentally advanced curriculum," he said.
Dr. Zigler also suggested that the measure of a successful day care center would be a child's reluctance to leave at the end of the day. "They love being there so much they are too busy to go home," he said.
Calvin Hill houses programs for 3- and 4-year-olds as well as the Kitty Lustman-Findling Kindergarten. The two programs share an old brick firehouse donated and renovated by Yale, which pays the center's utilities. The Yale Child Study Center also recently gave Calvin Hill a grant to support the creation of a formal internship program.
The Calvin Hill center began as a student effort to support striking Yale employees who could not find affordable day care for their children. Today 75 percent of the center's children come from Yale families with the rest drawn from the city. Families are charged on a sliding scale, ranging from $1,280 a year up to $9,224.
John Cafferty, a teacher there for 23 years, says one secret to Calvin Hill's success has been the intense involvement of parents. It is not unusual to find a Yale-New Haven Hospital neurosurgeon scrubbing little toilets next to a Korean graduate student. Parent architects planned the renovation from firehouse to school. Another parent group designed and constructed the playground.
"This is the most rewarding job. When the kids smile it makes my day," Mr. Cafferty said. In return, teachers never talk down to the children, but treat them as just people.
Mr. Cafferty, who said he briefly considered following the family tradition of working on the railroad, expressed fondness for his co-workers. "The staff does a lot for each other. Everyone brings a different strength." He also appreciates the team teaching approach, high degree of teacher autonomy and the opportunity for staff development.
The walls are covered with artwork and projects and photographs of busy youngsters at play. They dress up in firefighter's boots and hats or long shiny dresses and feather boas for dramatic plays and create fanciful stories. They earnestly tap maple trees across the street to make syrup. They draw and paint and mess around with clay. They choose vegetables to make natural dyes, dye yarn and learn simple weaving techniques. They take field trips to a museum, a pumpkin field, a weaver's studio. They chat with Cocoa and Piggy Pig, the upstairs and downstairs gerbils. They learn to count and sing the alphabet and some even begin to read. They also nap to recharge their batteries for more activities. "I like nap best," said 5-year-old Bailey Hanum of New Haven much to the astonishment of her teachers.
Libby Rinder, also 5, of Guilford, adores the recycling truck that picks up paper, plastic and metal. The driver always beeps hello to the children.
A 4-year-old from Israel named Noam spends his time with his buddies, Earl, David and Nick. His observations on his parents' employment stand out on a large wall poster: "My Mom works with neighbors. She's got a new job now. She talks. My Dad works with mice."
"Everything they learn is as important as everything else. Reading is not the only thing," explained Ms. Horwitz. Children, she said, must have "opportunities to explore an their own level."
Thus, neither mindless worksheets or teacher-directed drills ever happen at Calvin Hill. She feels preschool is a place where children begin to make sense of their world and begin to form friendships and learn to become a part of the larger community outside their own families.
