HEADLINE: ART;
An Art World Emerging Into the Cuban Sun

BYLINE: By EDWARD M. GOMEZ; Edward M. Gomez, a contributing editor of Art & Antiques, writes frequently on Latin American modern art.

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
THE PASSAGEWAY IS LONG and narrow, its thick outer wall pierced by a row of lookout slits for riflemen, the opposite wall leaning oddly inward, like a side of a gravity-defying fun-house cabin. Posters of a blindfolded man juxtaposed with pictures of tanks, baby dolls, waterfalls and sunsets line this awkwardly angled stone surface that a visitor fingers gingerly for support before emerging from the cool darkness into the bright inner court and the heavy heat of another Havana morning.
Here, a sign inside the massive Castillo del Morro, the 16th-century, Spanish-built fortress overlooking the Bay of Havana, announces this year's sixth Bienal de la Habana, a survey of contemporary art from the Americas, Europe and Africa that sprawls through several locations in the Cuban capital. 
 The show had already begun dramatically in the entrance tunnel, of course, with the Brazilian artist Claudio Goulart's posters from a series of Orwellian images called "The Toys." Now, through a portal, more work comes into view. There are the full-size metal figures by the Nigerian Sokari Douglas Camp, sculptures inspired by African ritual masks. And there is the monumental "Boat" by the young Havana artist Kcho, an exuberant but unsettling floor-to-ceiling pileup of bottles, tables, wood scraps and a rowboat that unabashedly alludes to the pack-up-and-go fantasies of would-be Cuban emigrants.
"Thank our soldiers here at the fort for helping to make this stimulating show possible," says Llilian Llanes Godoy, the Havana biennial's organizing-committee president, savoring the irony of presenting so much provocative material in a bastion of military might. "Normally we use the National Museum of Fine Arts, but it's closed for renovation, and we couldn't have done it without this facility." Other sites include the army-controlled Fortaleza de la Cabana nearby and the architecturally rich Old Havana district.
Perhaps overshadowed by Cuban music, which has long been this country's most accessible cultural export, the biennial has provided a considerable opening for local artistic expression since it began in 1984, with Cuban artists often addressing sensitive themes like emigration and economic hardship. Indeed, the event has helped lift a new generation of Cuban art makers out of isolation while also becoming a major showcase for contemporary art from Latin America and the world's developing regions. Visitors from Europe, South America and even the United States, despite travel restrictions for Americans, now attend the biennial in increasing numbers. And many American and foreign publications send reporters to cover it.
The 1997 biennial, which features 177 artists from 44 countries and runs through the end of the month, comes at a time when international awareness of Cuba's severe problems is growing and the market for Latin American art is more active than ever. This week in New York, for example, collectors from around the world will vie for works by the respected Cuban modernists Wilfredo Lam and Amelia Pelaez at Sotheby's, while Christie's will offer three definitive paintings by Ignacio Iturria, the important Uruguayan painter-sculptor, in the annual springtime Latin American art auctions.
Art-world habitues note that unlike its more famous, better-financed and traditionally more contentious counterparts in Venice and Sao Paulo, Havana's still-young biennial makes up in high spirits and unpredictable freshness what it sorely lacks in money or manpower.
"Our budget is practically nonexistent," says Ms. Llanes Godoy, an architectural historian who is also the founder and director of Havana's Wilfredo Lam Center, a Government-backed gallery focusing on Cuban, Latin American and third-world artists. The center serves as mission control for Havana's biennial bash.
"Today, with shortages abounding," Ms. Llanes Godoy adds, "Cubans have become masters in the everyday art of scrounging and making do. We welcome donations and volunteers. This year, one Ministry of Culture allocation totaled $20,000, but it immediately went to pay for the flurry of faxes between our offices and participating artists' countries. We still can't say how much this will all cost, because in this economy it's impossible to calculate."
MONEY WAS SO SHORT that many of the participating artists, who were chosen by a curatorial committee, stayed with Cuban families while setting up their works. And the event's hefty catalogue was paid for by the Paris-based Association Francaise d'Action Artistique, a partly public, partly French Government-financed organization that primarily promotes French culture abroad.
The art at the Castillo del Morro has been gathered under the heading "Faces of Memory," while works at the Fortaleza de la Cabana are grouped under the title "Interior Enclosures." Other presentations at various sites in Old Havana, including the Wilfredo Lam Center, the Colonial Museum and the Fototeca de Cuba, are united under the title "Collective Memories." Yet the themes overlap in many of the artists' works.
Throughout the show, too, the preferred modes of expression are documentation and installation, or so-called environmental art. The two central themes are the search for personal identity, especially with regard to cultural and social definitions of it, as well as the individual's place in history.
"I want my countrymen to confront the historic and everyday reality of violence in Argentine society," says Oscar Bony, 55, a Buenos Aires-based artist who is showing "Gunshots and Suicides," a series of large black-and-white photographs of families, marching workers and himself, both as a boy and as an adult, each photograph riddled with bullet holes.
"To make each piece, I used the same firearms cited in news reports of suicides or killings," Mr. Bony explains. "Some viewers are repelled. In them, others recognize references to the political terror of the 1970's and our collective capacity for violence."
The painter Edilson Viriato, 30, from southern Brazil, examines the extremes in thinking and behavior that surface when sex and religion intersect. "I come from a deeply Catholic family and region," Mr. Viriato observes with a toothy choirboy's grin. "I'm fascinated by my religion's preoccupation with sex and power, with the sacred and the profane."
Other artists have taken a more pensive look at that part of human nature where a person's sense of self takes shape. In her installation, "The Black Book of Life," the Aruban artist Glenda Heylinger features a thick book suspended, as if ready for burial, over a gravelike hole of real dirt. "That tome represents everything one has to absorb, like basic knowledge and society's values and expectations, before being able to take off and live," says Ms. Heylinger, a theater-design alumna of Gerrit Rietveld Academy in Amsterdam.
Ernesto Pujol, a Cuban-American who lives in New York, offers a kind of tableau vivant without the actors in "The Void," a grouping of dark-wood furniture pieces borrowed from various Havana homes (a seating ensemble, a dining table, a bed and an armoire). Also set on a carpet of actual dirt and dotted with white accessories -- gloves on the table, toy airplanes -- "The Void," Mr. Pujol says, alludes to the moment just before a sudden, forced departure, of a family of Cuban emigrants, for instance. "Sometimes memory is our only defense," he says. "To remember who we were is the only thing left to us when we have lost everything." (His precisely ordered environments will be the focus of a Bronx Museum of Art Show in the fall.)
Similarly, an installation by the Aruban Osaira Muyale, "Listening and Being Heard," consists of a lonely gathering of chairs and appliances around an empty metal bed frame. It, too, suggests a yearning for a special time or place, or perhaps for a lost love. Its most potent component is a cascade of white plaster ears set in a wall niche from which the sound of a heartbeat pulses through the vaultlike room.
"INSTALLATION HAS become the lingua franca of many contemporary artists from Latin America and the developing world," the French art critic Pierre Restany observed during the biennial's opening week. "Its theatrical qualities make it a good vehicle for artists who are sensitive to, and want to evoke, a sense of atmosphere -- cultural, political or historical."
Still, painting is here too, in the work, for example, of Mr. Iturria, who won critical praise two years ago at the Venice Biennale. The 48-year-old Mr. Iturria, of Montevideo, Uruguay, is presenting a group of new paintings and constructions that aptly touch upon all of this year's Havana themes; Mr. Iturria, after all, has long explored the mysterious-poetic, private-public aspects of history and identity in his deeply humanistic work.
With its oddly alluring images of trees, giraffes, speeding trains and Everyman figures, Mr. Iturria's art finds affinities both in the bittersweet nostalgia of Federico Fellini's memory films and in Francis Bacon's soul-scraping oil-on-canvas gristle. Mr. Iturria's curator in Havana, Olga Larnaudie, a fellow Uruguayan, points out that Mr. Iturria "expresses in the visual arts the magic realism and the peculiar surrealism that are so much a part of the literature of the Rio de la Plata region." Those qualities, she says, "travel well and are accessible to international audiences." So is much else here.
Miguel Kehayoglu of Buenos Aires, a senior member of the Argentine Association of Art Galleries, observed that "the broader public is catching up with the richness of Latin American modern and contemporary artists' work, whose themes unite us all and are well expressed here."
"This biennial has quickly come to have a special value for both the participants and the region," he said.
"Si, senor!" Ms. Llanes Godoy shot back to him as she walked by arm in arm with Mr. Restany, her longtime friend and consultant. Like a flamenco dancer, she rustled a little paper fan, and added, "Would you believe we've already begun thinking about the next one?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Fine Tuning Expansion at Bridgewater Commons

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: BRIDGEWATER

 BODY:
FOR nine years the sole occupant at the 120-acre Bridgewater Commons mixed-use center here has been its 900,000-square-foot namesake mall.
But after more than a year of negotiations the Bridgewater Township Council early this month approved a new agreement with the owner/developers of the center that makes its continued growth more flexible in responding to changing market trends. 
 The agreement calls for a $300-million, eight-year expansion and development program that will rearrange the size and mix of office and hotel uses at the center and strengthen its retail component.
"With this new agreement we are able to fine-tune the highest and best use for the site," said Kurt Sullivan, vice president for property management at TrizecHahn Centers, the San Diego-based retail division of TrizecHahn Corporation of Toronto. Trizec Hahn Centers is developing the center with the Prudential Realty Group, the real estate arm of the Newark-based insurer.
Approvals from the Township Planning Board still must be obtained for each stage of growth of the center, which sits at the intersection of Interstate 287 and Routes 202-206 and 22 at the core of this Somerset County community.
Under the initial 1984 agreement with the township, the center was to comprise the mall, which was to remain fixed at its current size, plus 500,000 square feet of office space and a 300-room full-service hotel.
But because of the real estate recession the office and hotel were never developed. As a result, the developers have paid a penalty of about $350,000 a year since 1988 in lieu of the estimated annual revenue that the town expected. The new agreement relieves the developers of the need to build the office space. But the penalty will only be removed once the hotel is completed.
Under the revised plans, the mall will be expanded by up to 750,000 square feet with the first 250,000 square feet scheduled to be built within the next two years. That will add about 70 shops to the 160 existing stores, which include Brooks Brothers, Williams Sonoma and the Gap. The anchors are Macy's, Stern's and Lord & Taylor.
Also within the next two years the General Cinema multiplex will be expanded to at least 14 screens from the present 7 and two free-standing restaurants, together totaling 18,000 square feet of space, will be constructed. Parking spaces will grow by 1,250 to 5,750 with the construction of parking decks.
The office building will be reduced to 300,000 square feet or replaced by an all-suite hotel or 160,000 more square feet of retail space on a separate site within the center.
"Demand from retailers is fueling the expansion," said Mr. Sullivan. "For the mall to remain competitive and service the market it needed to grow."
Mayor James T. Dowden agreed, noting that the mall was essentially the community's commercial center and that its expansion "is the renewal of our downtown."
THE expansion of the mall, and by extension the center itself, is moving ahead at a time when the retail market in Somerset County in general, and in Bridgewater in particular, is heating up. A spate of projects -- mostly power centers, which are mainly made up of big-box retailers, and shopping strips -- are in various stages of the approval process.
If realized, they could double the 6.5 million square feet of existing retail space in the county, of which 2 million square feet would be in Bridgewater Township, according to data from the county and township.
Retail brokers say the activity is not surprising given the area's demographics. "In that market there has been an increase in housing and population, and no significant increase in retail," said John G. Orrico, senior vice president of the West Orange office of Grubb & Ellis, the national brokerage based in Northbrook, Ill.
From 1980 to 1990 Bridgewater's housing stock increased from 8,804 to 11,273 residences and its population grew from 29,175 to 32,509. It is expected to increase to 38,120 by the year 2000, said Michael Sarkissian, its planning director.
Until now the only sizable retail project has been the mall, he said, noting that all the proposed developments conform to the township's master plan and have a different focus and location to serve separate markets.
Within Bridgewater's 32 square miles there are 3.5 million square feet of office space. An additional 2 million square feet have been approved and this, of course, will mean more shoppers.
For instance, not far from the mall along the strengthening I-78 office corridor, SJP Properties of Parsippany is constructing a 240,000-square-foot office building. With that building 95 percent leased and scheduled for completion in November, the plan is to start a similar size building "sometime this year," said Peter Eppie, executive vice president at SJP.
Projections are that the county's population will grow to 296,000 by the year 2010, up 23.2 percent from 1990, according to figures from the Somerset County Department of Planning.
As for jobs, the projection is that 36,000 will be added by the year 2005 to the 154,500 as of 1994, the latest figure available. The average household income in the county is $84,761.
Even with such strong demographics brokers express some caution. There are opportunities to build more retail space, said Mr. Orrico of Grubb & Ellis, but there are only so many retailers.
Some proposed projects will fall by the wayside as retailers shop for the best locations and leasing commitments, said Richard Brunelli, who heads a retail brokerage firm bearing his name in Old Bridge.
But, said Mr. Brunelli, Bridgewater Commons "has a lock on its market" since the nearest regional mall is about 20 miles away. And, he added, it "can handle an expansion."
Mr. Sullivan of TrizecHahn said all the ingredients from location to size and access -- $20 million in road improvements are in place at the site -- were there to make it a success. The timing is also appropriate, he said, noting that the mall's nine-year track record was important in securing the new expansion agreement.
When the mall was first proposed some 13 years ago community opposition and concerns of traffic congestion and crime were high. But those concerns "didn't bear out," said Mayor Dowden, who back then was an strong opponent of the mall. He now describes it as "an asset."
REVENUE generated from the center is also significant. Along with real estate taxes the township shares in the rental income from the mall, now receiving about $400,000 a year, which will increase as the mall expands, said Mr. Dowden. "With the rent revenue guaranteed for the future the township gets a stable source of income other than taxes," he added.
It also gets jobs. The initial 250,000-square-foot expansion alone is expected to add 450 permanent jobs to the 2,300 already at the mall and mean 500 construction jobs. As part of the new agreement the developers will contribute $2 million to the township for continuing improvements to Commons Way, which cuts through the site and is considered the gateway into the community. And as the expansion continues they will make the necessary road improvements to accommodate the expanded center.
Asking rents for the stores in the first phase of expansion have not yet been set. But brokers say rents in the better malls in the area range from $35 to $70 a square foot, depending on size, use and site.
Mr. Sullivan said construction on the first phase is expected to begin early next year and be completed by the fall of 1999. Construction of the remaining two phases will depend on demand for space, with the completion of the entire project expected by 2005, he said.

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: House Sales Strong as Sellers Dwindle

BYLINE: By DAVID WINZELBERG 

 BODY:
FOR the second year in a row, a strong spring selling season has brought Long Island home buyers out in force. Business has been so good that potential buyers are having difficulty finding homes to buy, real-estate agents say.
More than 2,000 fewer houses were on the market in March in Suffolk County, nearly 20 percent down from two years ago, according to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island. The area that includes Cold Spring Harbor, Dix Hills and Huntington had 40 percent fewer houses for sale. 
 In the first three months of the year, the value of home sales increased more than $94 million in Nassau and Suffolk Counties over the first quarter of 1995, continuing a trend from last year.
Last year a record total of more than $3 billion in homes was sold on Long Island through the listings service. Real-estate agents said a lack of houses to sell was holding them back.
"We have plenty of buyers without adequate housing to show them," a co-owner of Remax Shores in Massapequa, Nick Gigante, said. "It's frustrating. There's plenty of mortgage money around. There's plenty of buyers. But no inventory."
Georgianna Finn, co-owner of Coach Realtors, a seven-office chain that covers eastern Nassau and western Suffolk, said: "There are fewer homes available. We've been in an active market for so long that we've used up a lot of the inventory."
The resurgence, which began last year, is a byproduct of a strengthening economy, said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association. In the 12 months that ended in March, Long Island gained 15,000 jobs, the business group said.
"We've seen a fairly strong and recovering economy, which is driving the real-estate market," said Dr. Kamer, who also tied the increases to growth of the financial industry. "The New York City economy has been booming, which has helped the Long Island housing market," she said. "Many in the financial and professional services fields have chosen to live on Long Island."
One couple, Lauri and Bill Cutrone, and their two children are moving into a larger home next month. Mr. Cutrone is a stockbroker. "He's done well in the last three years," Ms. Cutrone said. "So we were able to make this move."
The Cutrones, who had tried to sell their ranch house in Huntington on their own, signed with a broker in November and sold it three months later for $2,000 under their asking price. "I thought there was going to be a bidding war," Ms. Cutrone said. "We sold it to a nice couple who are getting married in the fall. The husband also works in the financial industry."
Interest rates, near 8 percent for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, are another factor. "The recent upsurge in sales can also be attributed to the belief that rates will rise," Dr. Kamer said. "You have a lot of buyers trying to beat the increase."
Mark Wolf, president of Saxon National Mortgage Bankers in Hauppauge, agreed that the relatively low interest rates had helped fuel sales. Mr. Wolf also credited added flexibility in lending for housing.
"People can get into a house for less money," Mr. Wolf said. "There's a wider availability of mortgage programs and an expanded credit criteria."
Mr. Wolf said that his business had been strong since the summer and that people were feeling better about the economy. "People are more comfortable about keeping their jobs," he said. "There seems to be a general feeling of well being."
Dr. Kamer said investors in the booming stock market "are more secure about their incomes and are willing to commit long term to purchase a home." She added that "Manhattan money" had started a building boom on the East End, where land prices for new lavish houses are rising.
"We have an incredible number of new homes for sale," Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton said. "Land is going very well. There are parts of town where you almost can't find any land."
Permits for construction of single-family houses in East Hampton, excluding Montauk, increased 27 percent from 1995 to last year, according to Ms. Saatchi.
"There are a lot of builders willing to pay close to retail market value for land just to have inventory," said Jed Schutz, president of the Windemere Development Corporation in Hauppauge and Sag Harbor.
Mr. Schutz said the recent activity was different from the boom that ran from the mid- to late 80's.
"Dentists aren't spec builders any more," he said. "The market has gotten smarter. They're not paying a premium for junk. In 1986 and '87 you could put up the cheesiest house, and it would sell. Now the homes are better thought out and are better product built by professionals."
A vibrant resale market is apparently helping some new developments. When Mr. Schutz started to build 30 town houses in Smithtown in January 1996, sales were slow, he said.
"The second half of '96 it just kicked in," he recalled. "The people that couldn't sell their homes before were suddenly selling them, which enabled them to buy into our development."
A 94-unit development in Coram that Mr. Schutz began in February 1996 sold out in 15 months. He said the turnover of the houses, priced from $120,000 to $155,000, were helped by a special state mortgage program for new buyers.
"There's a lot more first-time-buyer programs out now," Bob Ragonesi, a vice president of Genesis National Mortgage in Northport. said. "The lenders are also allowing buyers to afford a larger payment. Their mortgage payment can now be as much as 40 percent of their gross income."
The dizzying pace is keeping his company busy, Mr. Ragonesi said, but sometimes frustrated. "We are doing a lot of preapprovals that don't translate into sales, because there is no inventory," he said. "People can't find a home. There is an increase in buyers, but not an increase in mortgages."
"We have more buyers for particular segments of the market than we have product," Ms. Saatchi said. "We scrounge around for listings to show. But usually we can sell them before we advertise them."
Some brokers said what they call the "move-up market" had slowed won. "People are buying homes and staying in them longer," said Ms. Finn.
Paul and Jane Longo and their two children, who have lived for 10 years in their hi-ranch in West Hills, have been looking for a larger house for two years.
"There's not much around in the price range and the area that we are looking in," said Ms. Longo.
Because the house would be their third, Ms. Longo conceded that she was being a bit fussy. "We don't want to have to do renovations," she said. "We did that with this house."
Mr. Wolf said he believed that the former widespread emigration of retirees had also slowed. "People used to retire to Florida," he said. "Now they're not in such a hurry to move. Between the floods and the droughts and the earthquakes, they say, 'We'll stay on Long Island.' "

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
On a Clear Day, Nary a Sludge Ball

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
IT first hit the news in August 1987. A huge garbage slick washed up on the New Jersey seashore, draping itself like a filthy necklace along the barrier islands from Point Pleasant to Surf City.
People were aghast. Beaches were shut. Action was demanded. But it was only Jersey at this point, and we know how they sneer from the far side of the Hudson. 
 But the next summer, during a blisteringly hot July, similar trash started to wash up on the beaches of Long Island. Suddenly, with the Hamptons in peril, the story became Armageddon. Though medical waste formed only a small portion of the garbage, it was quite photogenic. Hysterical television pictures firmly imprinted a lurid image on the cultural consciousness: A day at the beach, with bloody syringes poking from the sand like dandelions beside hairy sludge balls.
"The ocean sent back some of the nastier stuff," recalled Cindy Zipf, who runs Clean Ocean Action, a coalition of environmental and business groups she helped start in 1984 in a room above a hardware store in Sea Bright.
In 1984, there were still eight ocean-dumping sites off the Jersey coast, ranging from a few miles to more than 100 miles out to sea. At the same time, vast coastal development was overwhelming old sewage and storm-drain systems. Not to mention the river of raw sewage and trash launched into the sea whenever rainwater caused New York City's ancient sewers to overflow.
Three years later, the ocean "basically puked," said Ms. Zipf. But the hideous trash, which washed ashore like seaborne bottles from hell, was actually a cosmic press-agent's most brilliant media stunt.
"The medical waste was in some ways the best bad news we had," Ms. Zipf said. "It galvanized public attention -- and we saw that as a major opportunity, especially in fund raising and getting business on board. The business community for a long time had been, like, 'shhhhh', on the ocean dumping stuff. Suddenly, when billions were lost over those two summers, there was a greater appreciation of the economic value of the marine environment. That gave us a whole new kind of clout. We weren't just fish-huggers anymore."
Doctoral dissertations should examine the amazing story of those two summers when time and tide coincided at the media nexus and created landmark policy changes. Spurred by the medical-waste horror stories, Congress banned ocean dumping in 1988. Even now, the ripples are felt. Today, Clean Ocean Action begins a 100-day countdown until the closing of the only remaining ocean dump, six miles off Sandy Hook, where sludge dredged from New York Harbor has been piled on the ocean floor since the 19th century.
"When I was a little girl, I went to the beach at Sea Bright every single day in the summer," Ms. Zipf recalled. "Then, beachcombers found sea-shells."
"By the early 1980's, when the first plastic bags began washing up, beachcombing had become an entirely different thing," she said in a conversation the other day on the porch of a Victorian house on a former Army post in Sandy Hook, where her group shares space with the American Littoral Society, a national beach environment group.
Ms. Zipf got a degree in marine policy at the University of Rhode Island and returned to the Jersey Shore to run Clean Ocean Action. The group's first publicity coup was in 1985, when it commissioned a huge sculpture made of plastic tampon applicators and other trash that had washed up on Sandy Hook beaches. A few summers later, it hired a plane to fly along crowded beaches towing a banner denouncing a chemical company for plans to dump industrial waste at sea. The company quickly surrendered.
For years after the medical waste publicity, Ms. Zipf said, "I would still hear mothers say things like, 'I will never let my child go into the Atlantic Ocean.' I just thought that was tragic."
Now, though overloaded urban pipes still burp forth the occasional reminder that our aged sewage systems are an insult to the sea, people have a much better awareness of the complex natural and economic ecologies of the seashore. She said that even the whales seem to have noticed the improvement.
"I mean, who would have thought then," Ms. Zipf said, "that there would be a whale-watching ship leaving out of Atlantic Highlands?"

HEADLINE: At the Intersection of Supply and Demand

 BODY:

Tierney paints a rosy picture of life in New York after the end of rent regulations -- full of better homes and better neighborhoods, where landlords and tenants live together in perfect harmony. But we can see the success of this "free" housing market elsewhere in urban America -- Detroit, Cleveland, Hartford, St. Louis -- where the middle class, encouraged by tax breaks for mortgage-interest deductions, has fled to the suburbs, abandoning the inner city to its fate. That New York hasn't succumbed to this fate might very well be because of the rent regulations that Tierney so disparages for disproportionately benefiting middle-class households. 
 Tierney also relies too heavily on surveys by economists who try to blame rent control for all kinds of urban ills, in particular the abandonment of buildings. Why is it then that abandonment is greatest in neighborhoods like East New York, where the market rates are nearly the same or even lower than the regulated rates? Yet, on the Upper West Side, where the disparity between regulated and market rates is greatest, there is little abandonment. Quite the contrary. The Upper West Side, once a scene of urban blight, has improved steadily in the past three decades, so much so that residents now complain of overcrowding from all the new luxury buildings going up.
 
Jay Gans
New York

LENGTH: 3695 words

HEADLINE: Haiti Takes Policing 101

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Rubin; Elizabeth Rubin is a contributing editor of Harper's magazine. This is her first story for the Magazine.

 BODY:
To the untrained eye, Jean-Jacques Dessalines Boulevard in the heart of the Port-au-Prince business district looks like a carnival of commerce. Hundreds of Haitian vendors are whittling sugar cane or selling old light switches, stereos, knives, shampoo, batteries, even schoolbooks from cardboard boxes that spill out into a jumble of traffic and pedestrians. For Gus Tavernier, an officer with the New York City Police Department, however, the boulevard is a lesson to be mastered. To be a good cop, Tavernier explains to a Haitian rookie named Accius, you've got to know your environment: the street, the people, their wares, everything. And you've got to know yourself: the equipment you carry, your capabilities, your image -- what Tavernier calls "impression management."
 A Haitian-American from Long Island, Tavernier, 40, is one of two dozen Creole-speaking police officers who came from the United States last year to professionalize Haiti's new civilian police force. On a sweaty afternoon, he leads Accius out on the beat for a lesson in proactive policing, Yankee style. As they cut a path through the vendors, Tavernier asks Accius what he has noticed. Accius turns his head this way and that, walks back a few paces and looks up at Tavernier with no answer. 
 "What you see here," Tavernier says, gesturing to a man selling knives, "is a clue that you're throwing away if a crime is later committed." Accius is eager to learn, and he readily admits that this is all new to him. Tavernier next points out a vendor selling ice picks -- another potential weapon or clue. They move on, squeezing through more merchants, and after a few yards pass a box displaying both ice picks and knives. Tavernier again asks Accius what he sees. Accius looks around and says, "Nothing."
 Tavernier is trying to teach the basic skills of investigative policing, but he faces a peculiar challenge in communication -- even though he speaks Creole and spent the first 11 years of his life in Haiti. "The idea of policing in Haiti has always been that of an authority figure who tells the people what to do," he says.
 Under the military rule of Gen. Raol Cedras, who led the 1991 military coup that toppled the popularly elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and throughout most of Haitian history, the army ran the criminal-justice system. So there was no need for time-consuming tasks like gathering evidence, securing a crime scene, collecting testimony. When the military brought in a suspect, he was presumed guilty. No questions asked. But since 1994, when a United States military intervention returned Aristide to office, Haiti has been moving toward an investigative model of justice, which presupposes that the burden of proof is on the accusers, not the accused. This is a revolutionary idea in Haiti, where for centuries dictators like the notorious Duvaliers and Cedras, along with their militias -- known as Tontons Macoutes and attaches] -- maintained "order" by extortion, torture and murder.
 Tavernier has a visceral as well as politicial aversion to what he calls the Duvalier-macoute religion. "Duvalier's regime was very simple," he says. "You criticize the government, you're dead. So you knew what to do." Now the kind of social unrest that has accompanied the end of repression in many countries around the world is taking root in Haiti. The poor -- that is, most Haitians -- are frustrated by the fact that neither Aristide, their popular hero, nor Rene Preval, his more pragmatic successor, who has been in office since February 1996, has improved their lot.
 Tavernier walks the streets every day with trainees from Cafeteria, a busy precinct from which, only a few years ago, one of the coup leaders dispatched his hit squads. Drilling the men in the rudiments of police work is only part of the job, though. Perhaps the more important task, as Tavernier sees it, is "to dilute the mentality of the tonton macoute]."
 When Tavernier declares this idea aloud, his colleagues in Cafeteria, Officers Ives Orne and Guy Jean-Baptiste, both from the Boston Police Department, look at him as if he's dreaming. "Every Haitian is a tonton macoute]," says Jean-Baptiste, a soft-spoken immigration officer whose eyes seem permanently jacked open in astonishment by the poverty and chaos around him. "It's here," he says tapping his temple.
 "Take that cop who brought in the guy from the market," Orne says. Earlier, an undercover cop wearing dark shades and a camouflage jacket, with a Magnum and a .38 stuffed in his jeans, slammed an unarmed suspect from the market up against the wall while pushing a third gun into his head. "What would you call that cop?" Orne asks. "He has the macoute] mentality. The same guys that are telling you macoutes] did bad things will now come in and do worse."
 Tavernier disengages from the conversation. His right eye squints repeatedly, a twitch he contracted after serving in the gulf war. Tavernier, who has the compact, spry physique of a welterweight boxing champion, believes that Haitian political tyranny is rooted not only in Haiti's history but in the way Haitian men are reared to become authoritarian at home. He had his first tastes of that oppression at the fist of his abusive father, a businessman who prospered under the corrupt Duvalier regime. At the age of 11, Tavernier and an older brother escaped from their father and joined their other siblings and their mother, Jeanine Tavernier, who had fled to America two years earlier.
 His mother had made her mark in Haiti as a poet, writing about women's liberation. She raised all five children on her own in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, taught them about the injustices in Haiti and planted in them the seed of activism.
 At 19, Tavernier returned to Haiti, and as an emboldened American wound up having a lot of run-ins with the gun-toting tontons macoutes]. Ultimately he had to bargain for his life with the all-powerful district chiefs, who accused him of being a subversive. So he went back to New York, went to Queens College and drove a taxi while waiting to get citizenship so he could join the police force. Because he found it tough to make ends meet, Tavernier joined the military in 1982. As far back as Tavernier can recall, he has wanted to be a cop. "I could have been a very good bad guy," he says. But the idea of being a cop coincided with his inchoate notion of justice and "doing the right thing."
 In 1989, he married a Haitian dance instructor, and when their first daughter was born he named her Kia -- "killed in action" -- in memory of his best friend, Caco Laguerre, an anti-Duvalier activist who was assassinated and "died like a dog in the streets of Florida."
 Like Laguerre, Tavernier has always felt strong ties to his homeland. So when he heard last year that Creole-speaking cops were needed to help train the new Haitian police force, he volunteered. Ten days later, Tavernier flew down to Haiti to begin the latest chapter in a quiet war he has been waging for much of his life -- to change Haiti and teach Haitians to stand up for themselves. Tavernier's thinking dovetailed with that of Raymond Kelly, a former New York City police commissioner who commanded the international police monitors during the United States intervention in Haiti. "I thought that if we could bring in Haitian-American police officers who have a knowledge of the culture and the language and have been practicing the tradition of American law enforcement, that it would make quite an impact," Kelly says. "Policing is one of the most valuable commodities we can export to emerging democracies."
 Since last October, 48 Creole-speaking cops from police departments all over the country have been exported, at a cost of about $4 million for 10 months in one of the first such experiments in the fledgling field of international policing. Like Tavernier, almost all the Haitian-American cops were born in Haiti and fled with their parents during the Duvalier era. Some say they signed up to escape the cold northern winters. Some for the money. Some are Republicans, some Democrats. Many have, or had, ties or sympathies with the elite, anti-Aristide classes. Others profess to hate both the elite and the Duvalierists. But all of them feel that they are on a personal and professional mission to give to their homeland some of the privileges and skills they acquired in America.
 Back in 1994, after Aristide demobilized the despised Haitian Army, the Haitian Government recruited a new police force of educated young men and women and promised them a decent salary by Haitian standards -- about $500 a month. The first graduates of the police academy were heralded as pioneers of the country's new democracy. But in the year and a half since, that enthusiasm has waned in the face of rising crime, continued corruption, a bankrupt economy and a beggared criminal-justice system.
 In keeping with the Clinton Administration's determination to withdraw American troops by February 1996, the 5,200 police cadets were rushed through an inadequate four-month training course run by the United States Department of Justice. Many did not know how to drive, let alone handle a weapon or conduct investigations, and were thrust into the streets with no supervision, little or no equipment and no experienced officers to show them the ropes. Their job was made even more precarious by the fact that they were threatened by thugs of the old regime whom the American troops had failed to disarm.
 When the last of 1,300 United Nations troops pull out in July, the survival of Haiti's nascent democracy will rest almost entirely on the shoulders of this new and uncertain police force. Yet Haitians, reared in a system where impunity was the norm, tend to mistrust authority figures and thus place more stock in the old Haitian proverb "Laws are paper; bayonets are steel," than in any notion of a real criminal-justice system.
For their part, the new Haitian police officers are so undermined and demoralized by their own resourcelessness, the deaths of their colleagues and the debilitated prosecutorial process that they are beginning to adopt a policy of equally unworkable extremes: free the criminals or execute them. And as the laws fail to bind, the population is resorting to its own disciplinary codes to punish deviant social behavior -- whether murder or stealing a chicken -- by burning government buildings and publically executing criminals.
"There is an ever-growing frustration on the part of the population with a system that doesn't work," says Pierre Denize, the Director General of the Haitian police forces. "There's a delay in the treatment of cases, which has caused an appalling overpopulation of an already inadequate penal structure." The national penitentiary, built to hold about 350 prisoners, currently has close to 1,000. Many judges work two jobs just to survive and often release accused criminals almost as soon as they are arrested, either for bribes or out of fear of retaliation. "When it happens often enough," Denize says, "the policeman tends to say: 'What's the use? He's going to walk tomorrow.' Or he tends to be fearful: 'I arrest him today and he could be shooting at me tomorrow.' "
When Tavernier, Orne and Jean-Baptiste took up their posts at Cafeteria in November, they were shocked. The two-story, colonial-era building looked more like a crack house than a police station. Floorboards were missing. The roof was crumbling and leaking. There was no electricity, no potable water, no sanitation. The police lacked ammunition, radios, handcuffs.
 Some 20 detainees were jostling for space in a filthy holding cell about the size of a news kiosk. When one of the prisoners jutted his infected, swollen foot past the bars, Jean-Baptiste promised quietly to get him to a hospital, then sidestepped a bucket that was being used as a latrine. "I detain people in Boston," he says. "But I have never seen this kind of thing before. At home, if you commit a minor crime we separate you or transfer you and then you see a judge. But here? They're all thrown in together. They haven't seen a judge. And they don't eat or drink unless family brings them food."
 It's not just the squalor that the Americans find so disturbing. They are equally puzzled that the police leadership could deploy a force that is so poorly trained and equipped. When a call came in saying that a policeman had been kidnapped, Tavernier told a Haitian officer to keep him covered when they moved out. The Haitian cop asked Tavernier what exactly he meant by "cover." "If I'm running, you watch my back," Tavernier explained. "With what?" asked the Haitian cop, shooting at Tavernier with his finger to remind him that he had no gun.
 One night just two weeks into their mission, Tavernier and Orne were suddenly called upon to save their Haitian counterparts from a lynch mob. Shortly after midnight, they heard the panicked voices of seven young cops on the isle of La Gonave shouting into the radio, "If you don't send help, we are going to die." Angry residents had already torched the courthouse and were hurling Molotov cocktails at the police station to smoke out the cops.
 The riot had erupted after the police tried to make an illegal arrest of a boy they had decided wasn't showing them enough respect. In the dark, they shot and killed an innocent passerby. After months of police abuses, resulting in four civilian deaths, the people finally rose up to enact their own justice.
 Tavernier, Orne and three other international police trainers were dropped off by helicopter to negotiate with the crowd. As they made their way to the public square, they encountered some 200 men, women and children wielding machetes, knives and rocks, climbing the steps of the burning police station for the final assault and chanting: "Soldiers, charge. Whoever dies it doesn't matter."
 Yet when the people in the crowd spotted the foreigners in uniform, they broke into cheers of welcome. Someone had finally come to hear their complaints. Several young men, however, were disappointed, and were still out for blood. A voice called out, "If you'd only given us a few more minutes, we could have killed them." They had no intention of letting the captive cops go.
 Tavernier didn't doubt that the rookies were swaggering about La Gonave like macoutes], and he had no sympathy for their conduct. But vigilantism, he told the people, was not going to resolve their problems. Orne and Tavernier tried to bargain with the crowd all night long, explaining that the police would be brought to trial, that they were training good cops in the capital.
 The residents of La Gonave saw no reason to trust anyone's justice but their own. What's more, they were fed up with the new politicians. They'd had no electricity for 14 months and only one telephone line for the main town's 64,000 residents. At least under Duvalier, they said, life was cheaper and there was less crime.
 By daybreak, thousands had gathered in the town square. United Nations military and Haitian police reinforcements were flown in. Surrounded by the dancing and chanting islanders hurling stones, the U.N. officers finally managed to evacuate the rookies to the mainland.
 In the square, children were jumping in and out of the burned-out police trucks as the Haitian flag flapped at half-staff. Young men rummaged through the smoldering police house pulling out bikes and beds as flames ate away at the corners of a police poster that read: "Don't take justice into your own hands. Report all criminals and thieves to the Haitian National Police."
Simon Lepoint, the 32-year-old Mayor, said he had a premonition that such an explosion would occur. He had long ago asked Port-au-Prince to replace his corrupt police force. "Now we are abandoned -- how can we keep law and order here with one baton?" he asked, waving a wooden police club he had salvaged from the wreckage.
 A few days later, back at Cafeteria in Port-au-Prince, Tavernier and Orne, who had been smacked in the head with a rock, were still stunned by the drama on La Gonave. The last thing they had expected when they came down to the island was that they would wind up rescuing bad cops from a mob. The incident laid bare to them the political, economic and social obstacles they are up against.
 "These cops are kids with no experience," Orne says. "So before they use communication, they use force. And then the people get pissed off."
 It is this enormous gulf of mistrust between the population and the police that Raymond Kelly hopes the Haitian-Americans will bridge. But Orne is not so optimistic. Despite the fact that they speak Creole and that many still have family in Haiti, the Haitian-Americans are discovering just how far they have traveled from the culture into which they were born.
 Although Tavernier has worked the toughest precincts in Brooklyn, he insists that "N.Y.P.D. is a vacation" compared with Haiti. "I've never seen killing like I've seen here," he says. "Everybody's killing everybody, or trying to, because they are living in a punishment-free society."
 What the Haitian police need as much as training, equipment and supervision is time. But with a July pullout date for the United Nations, time is running out. One Haitian-American trainer believes that almost every middle-class Haitian family has automatic weapons. The middle class, he says, are all sympathizers with the former army and the tontons macoutes]. "If they didn't know Big Brother was watching over them, they would probably stage a coup," he says.
 Paul Desrossiers, a trainer from the Los Angeles Police Department, has been helping to gather information on the forces that are trying to sabotage the new Haitian police. He says that demobilized soldiers have either gone underground or gone out to the provinces, where they work as bodyguards for government officials.
 Coming from the L.A.P.D, Desrossiers is accustomed to a police force that looks after its own. But in Haiti, he points out, the authorities are recruiting and arming their own private security forces with automatic weapons -- which is exactly how the tontons macoutes] evolved. This practice is undermining the morale of the new cadets, who get no medical attention or insurance if they're wounded on duty. "These kids are so afraid that everybody is contemplating leaving or quitting when their contract expires in 18 months," Desrossiers says. "At the current rate, there will not be a Police Department. The army will eventually come back."
 The State Department wants to keep the Haitian-American trainers as technical advisers to the Haitian police after the United Nations withdraws from Haiti. Some Haitian officials, particularly in the Police Department, resent the superior attitude that the Haitian-Americans have carried down with them. Given the troubled history of U.S.-Haitian relations, they are also wary of being bullied by their more powerful neighbors. But the trainers have brought a commitment to, and understanding of, the country that cannot be equaled by their U.N. colleagues from other countries. "I might want to retire here someday, and I'd like to have a police force with knowledge," Orne says. "I'd also like to pay back something to the country."
 Just a couple of months into the mission, Cafeteria started to take on the air of a real police station, with signs for different offices and a receiving desk. Tavernier says that his men have learned how to talk to the population, keep their weapons clean and secure a crime scene. But he fears that after the United Nations troops pull out, Haiti will descend into a gangland like Somalia.
 With no sign of economic recovery in sight and a rather steady 70 percent unemployment rate, Haitians are losing faith in the politicians they elected and in the new system that was supposed to change their lives. And as the frustration and despair mount, everyone is looking for someone to blame. Aristide accuses his former ally Preval of being an American pawn, caving in to American economic reform packages like the privatization of state-owned companies. The bourgeoisie are aching to have one of their own back in power. And even the poor, once devoted Aristide fans, are becoming nostalgiac for Duvalier's "order."
 While Tavernier can tolerate such sentiments from the disenfranchised, he loses patience when he hears middle-class people bemoaning the rise of crime in their formerly protected neighborhoods. "I tell them, 'They're revolting against you because you've been oppressing them for centuries.' The intensity that people put into work here compared to what they are paid -- to me that's slavery or apartheid, or a form of it, anyway."
 Tavernier still clings to the ideals of the social revolution inspired by Aristide. And although he has become increasingly disappointed in the former President, he is equally disturbed that everyone he talks to is blaming him for Haiti's decline. "Aristide simply turned over the soup so everybody could see what was at the bottom of the pot," Tavernier says. "Before, people made it their business to cover up the poverty. Aristide told the people, 'Get your expletive] out there and get what you need.' People who cherish Duvalier are angry at this man because he told the people, 'This is your country.' "
 Given enough manpower, financing and authority, the Haitian-Americans believe they could have a significant impact on the police force. With only a 10-month contract and an uncertain commitment on the part of the United States, the mission looks quixotic at best. But like Don Quixote, Tavernier inspires himself with an old story: "A guy is walking on a beach where hundreds of starfish have washed up onto the sand. He sees his friend down the shore rescuing them, throwing them back into the water one by one, and he shouts to him, 'Do you think throwing one starfish in the water is going to make any difference?' The friend replies, 'It'll make a difference for this one.' "

HEADLINE: There's No Place Like Work

 BODY:

In her article "There's No Place Like Work" (April 20), Arlie Russell Hochschild misses how work contributes to the time bind in households. Why has the stress of family life increased? For too many parents, it is because the growing demands of their jobs leave them too tired to take pleasure in being with their families. 
 Hochschild's argument that many employees don't use work-family benefits because work is more fun than home ignores the reality of today's corporate cultures, where long hours are viewed as evidence of commitment to the job. Employees worry that taking advantage of flexible programs may cause them to be perceived as less committed and that as a result, their careers will suffer, threatening the economic security of their families.
 
Paul M. Rayman
Cambridge, Mass.
 
Director, Radcliffe Public Policy Institute

HEADLINE: Sunday, May 25, 1997: POLITICS;
Paul's Big Adventure

 BODY:
Seething with frustration during last year's debate on welfare reform, Senator Paul Wellstone, the liberal Democrat from Minnesota, scrapped his prepared speech and declared that he would tour the poorest parts of the country in 1997, just as Robert F. Kennedy did 30 years ago. He's starting in the Mississippi Delta, and though most Mississippians aren't aware of it, Wellstone is headed their way this week.
 Wellstone is betting that exposing brutal living and working conditions will demonstrate far better than words the absurdity of slashing the Federal safety net. There's certainly real suffering to be seen -- Rims Barber, a poverty activist who accompanied Kennedy, maintains that half the Delta's population is now as bad off or worse than it was in 1967. After holding a town meeting in the Rose Fort High School in Tunica, Miss., Wellstone will visit harsh workplaces, like commercial catfish farms where women have stood in icy water for hours on end. The goal? Wellstone aims to rattle the established political hierarchy in ways that are impossible with child-welfare amendments that go nowhere. "The Democratic Party has lost some of its soul," he insists. 
 Whether the gesture will accomplish much remains to be seen, but some Mississippi locals are bristling at being advertised as the nation's neediest. Brenda Van Cleave, director of the Tunica Chamber of Commerce, boasts that the county now has 10 casinos, 16 hotels and fast-food
 outlets from McDonald's to Subway. Van Cleave is unimpressed by talk of some residents' declining fortunes. "If that is happening," she says, "there's no reason for it."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Former B. Altman Site;
From Department Store to Storehouse of Knowledge

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WHEN the B. Altman store that occupies the block between 34th and 35th Streets and Fifth and Madison Avenues opened in 1914, it was a temple of commerce with floors devoted to ladies' bonnets and gentlemen's furnishings, with its own trade school and medical clinic.
When the landmarked building completes its transition in the summer of 1998, it will have become a temple of learning, housing the graduate school of the City University of New York, with its 32 doctoral programs and 24 research centers. Already installed on its Madison Avenue side are the Science, Industry and Business branch of the New York Public Library and, in the tower, Oxford University Press. 
 The undertaking represents a considerable investment in a building that had sat idle since Altman's went out of business in 1989, until Oxford moved from across the street at 200 Madison Avenue in May 1995. The Oxford project represented an outlay of $30 million, the library branch $100 million and the graduate school, $163 million.
Each organization owns a condominium interest in the building, with operations of facilities held in common, such as the freight elevator and roof, governed by a board made up of owners' representatives.
Peter L. Malkin, who with his partner Morton L. Olshan first became involved with the Altman properties in 1985, said selling the condominiums was a fallback strategy after efforts to redevelop the building or rent it were foiled by the real estate recession of the early 1990's. "We spent a year and a half trying to develop the building as a showroom for the contract furniture industry, but the companies involved could not make it work," he said. "So we took an alternative approach."
Daniel A. Biederman, president of both the 34th Street and Grand Central Partnerships, which meet at the north end of the building at 35th Street, said he expects the graduate center to generate street traffic and night life in the surrounding area.
"It's almost like a residential conversion," he said."You will have people walking around and spending money for food and other things and it will increase foot traffic at night."
The whole building will be quite a bookish place. In addition to the public library branch, the graduate school will have its own library, and Oxford Press has a library for all the titles it currently has in print.
The new and prospective occupants of the building happily nod to their antecedents. "People will still shop in this building, but now they will shop for ideas," said Frances Degen Horowitz, president of what is formally the Graduate School and University Center for CUNY. She said the graduate school's current location at 33 West 42 Street was no longer adequate for its needs, with faculty offices spread to two nearby buildings at a rental expense that was approaching $6 million a year.
"We outgrew the building," Dr. Horowitz said, noting that the graduate school only had a handful of programs when it opened in 1961, but now has 4,000 students. The 42d Street location was originally chosen, she said, so students would have easy access to the research collections at the main branch of the public library, which is almost directly across the street.
The location of the main branch dictated that the graduate school stay in the general neighborhood, Dr. Horowitz said, despite the presence in the same building of the Science, Industry and Business Library. "SIBL has the technical data bases, but we had to have access to the humanities collections at the library," she said. "It is just a few blocks' difference." Although inadequate for the graduate school, the state-owned building on 42d Street was deemed suitable for the State University of New York School of Optometry, which will move there from rented space once the floors have been remodeled to meet its needs.
Unlike other universities, where the graduate schools are part of an integrated academic community, the CUNY graduate school operates semi-autonomously, with a core faculty of about 100. The remaining 1,600 doctoral faculty are drawn from colleges within the university system. It is also decentralized, with science research and professional programs at college campuses around the city.
As the owner of a nonprofit condominium unit in the building, the school will be spared the real estate taxes that are passed on to tenants in rental charges, although it will have to make payments to the State Dormitory Authority until the bonds used to finance the project are retired. The school will occupy 580,000 square feet of space on eight floors and a mezzanine along Fifth Avenue. Strollers who window-shopped the latest fashions in the past will be able to see graduate students studying in the library and study spaces near the display windows.
Since one of the needs of the school was for performance and meeting spaces, the big floors and high ceilings of the old store provided a good beginning. "This building is well suited for adaptive reuse," said Robert Siegel, whose firm, Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, did the design work for both the graduate school and the library. "It's really a grand old loft building with well-placed columns and none of the load-bearing walls you often find in old buildings."
With this as a base, Mr. Siegel was able to carve out the space for a 400-seat auditorium, a 200-seat recital hall and a 72,000-square-foot library. Since they do not need windows, the two halls were placed in the basement, while the library occupies parts of the basement and first floors and all the second floor, in its section of the building.
The middle five floors of the graduate school's space are occupied by lecture halls, seminar rooms, faculty offices, a science center and computer laboratories. The top two floors are reserved for administrative offices, a conference center and a central dining facility under the skylight of the original Altman restaurant, with a view of the soaring Empire State Building diagonally across the street.
Adequate meeting space is essential at the doctoral level, Dr. Horowitz said. "In doctoral programs, education takes place as much outside the classroom as in it," she said. Meetings and seminars are an important part of that process, she said, and including the meeting spaces in the design will make such events easier to hold. Space will also be provided for a physical fitness center, a day-care center and improved laboratory and computer facilities.
The graduate school expects to move into the building in the summer of 1998 , which has the advantage of being a slow time academically.
One of the glories of the Italian palazzo-style building are its windows, both the vaulted displays at street level and the rectangular ones on the upper levels. The result is that a lot of people, in the library and Oxford Press as well as the graduate school, have or will have offices with windows. "One of the few concerns we had was that the building had too much interior space for its perimeter," Mr. Siegel said. "We had to work on getting natural light as far into the building as possible."
WITH the public library, the solution was to put the people on the outside and the books -- 1.2 million of them -- in the middle. Since the ceilings were high, the library was able to squeeze five floors of stacks into what was three floors of store. Because of the heavy loads of the book stacks, this was one of the few places in the renovation where the building's structure had to be reinforced. The new branch effectively liberated the library's technical collection, 60 percent of which had been in storage, said William D. Walker, senior vice president of the library. He said it was visited by an average of 2,400 people a day.
The appeal of the facility was obvious on a recent workday, when a crowd was waiting outside the front door for the 11 A.M. opening, and patrons raced to computer terminals to do their research. The main floor contains a reading area with periodicals and a 40,000-volume circulating collection.
But the main area is downstairs, where Altman's had its gift-wrap and mail-order operations. "The deeper you go, the more serious it gets," Mr. Walker said. He said a library facility such as his was intended for graduate-level research, with neighborhood branch libraries for undergraduate-level study. To make the below-grade space more attractive, part of the first floor was removed, allowing light from display windows to fall on an open floor intended as a meeting hall. Farther in are the service desk for the main book collection and 70 work stations in the Electronic Information Center.
Oxford University Press has its own entrance and reception area on Madison, where the latest titles are displayed in windows. Its own library occupies the second-story mezzanine and its own elevators take employees to the 9th to 13th floors.
"We have been in here since May 1995 and we like it," said Gerald Sussman, senior vice president for administration and planning. "In fact, we wonder how we managed to survive in our old quarters."

HEADLINE: More to Say On Adoption Law

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thank you for printing my letter in the New Jersey section April 13 regarding adoption in general and, specifically, the case of "Baby D." It obviously struck a chord, a very emotional chord. I would like to respond to letters printed later that alleged misstatements on my part. 
 I am not anti-adoption. When adoption provides a family for a child who needs a home, it is an honorable act. When adoption is used to satisfy the needs of adults for newborns, it is a questionable practice.
My letter accurately described New Jersey law, which provides that relinquishments of newborns may be procured 72 hours after birth. The law does not require independent counseling, nor legal representation for the birth mother. A baby may be relinquished by the birth mother, even if a minor, with a single signature only three days (72 hours) after birth, and that relinquishment serves as an irrevocable termination of parental rights. Interested readers may look at New Jersey Statutes Annotated, Title 9 Children, Subtitle 2 Adoption, Apprenticeship and Indenture at 9:2:16 and 9:3-41e.
New Jersey law also provides that when one parent surrenders custody or has parental rights terminated, the other parent's rights are not affected. (N.J.S.A. 9:2-15). This law is relevant in the Baby D case. Although the father has committed a crime, his parental rights have not been terminated. The past commission of a crime is not a bar to being a parent by birth or by adoption.
Even in cases where the surrender has been found by a court to be void because of undue pressure or coercion, and the surrender is declared a legal nullity, the baby is not automatically returned to its family of birth. Read the decision in Sorrentino v. Family & Children Services.
Another letter-writer stated that when there is a dispute in an adoption case, the child is returned to its birth family. If that were true, Baby D would have been with his father for the last 32 months or so.
That letter-writer also addressed the issue of counseling for birth mothers. Although some reputable agencies may provide psychological counseling, it is not independent. The agency's fee is paid by prospective adoptive parents. Even when agencies do provide psychological counseling, they are under no requirement to provide legal counseling.
In some cases, prospective adoptive parents pay expenses for indigent birth mothers. This can include relocation to states where they have fewer rights and where adoptions may become final more quickly than in New Jersey.
Yet another letter asserted that there is a prejudice against adoption. If anything, there is a prejudice in favor of adoption, a prejudice that denies the biological connection and asks us to believe that children will be "better off" and "grow to full potential" if adopted. This prejudice is reflected in social policy that promotes adoption rather than social and economic justice.
It is unfortunate that the procurement of infants for needy adults has created a market in babies. This is not a misrepresentation of adoption. I do not intend to insult those present and future adoptive parents who acted to provide a home to a child in need. On the other hand, those who seek to use their advantages to obtain babies from less fortunate families must recognize this is wrong.

CECILY CATHERINE MARANGOS
Fair Haven

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Dueling Gift Funds: Similar Aims, Different Styles

BYLINE: By JULIETTE FAIRLEY 

 BODY:
COMMENCEMENT season serves as an annual reminder for parents, grandparents and others to commence saving for a young child's future education.
A popular way to set aside money for college has been the American Century-Twentieth Century Giftrust fund, which combines some features of a trust with a high-growth stock portfolio. But that fund has slumped recently, at least temporarily cooling interest. 
 Royce Gift Shares presents a possible alternative. Though smaller and newer, it is much like the American Century fund in structure. Both funds allow someone to make a gift, to a child or anyone, really, other than oneself or a spouse. The gift is irrevocable, which means investors cannot touch the money once it is committed, and each fund requires the money to be invested for at least 10 years.
When it comes to investing style, though, the similarities end quickly.
Though they buy small stocks, the funds' portfolios are worlds apart. Charles M. Royce, the primary manager of the fund that bears his name, sums up the difference this way: "We have a conservative fundamental approach to investing that is value oriented. American Century has a growth momentum style."
That divergence and the market's recent preference for value investing show up in the fund's total returns. Through Thursday, Giftrust had lost 13.0 percent for the year, while Royce Gift Shares had gained 3.94 percent. Last year, the Royce fund returned 25.6 percent, while Giftrust was up just 5.8 percent. The Royce fund, which is less than two years old, achieved those gains on a slim asset base, now $1.2 million, compared with $725 million now for Giftrust, which is 14 years old.
Glenn Fogle, 36, the lead manager of Giftrust for the last four years, chalks up the underperformance to the vagaries of market cycles.
"Investors flocked to large-cap stocks and cheap stocks because of fear of inflation and fear that the economy was too strong," Mr. Fogle said. "This slump has been a short-term event triggered by obvious factors that don't worry us in the least because it doesn't affect our ability to generate long-term returns."
Indeed, the fund's long-term record has been good. For the 10 years ended in 1996, its annual return was 21.8 percent on average, 6.5 percentage points ahead of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar, the fund trackers in Chicago.
Given that investing styles come in and out of favor and that a trust fund is a long-term commitment, Kevin Kresnicka, a fund analyst with Morningstar, encourages investors not to place too much weight on short-term results. "Whenever you try to time something -- a sector or investment style -- a lot of times, investors can get whipsawed," Mr. Kresnicka said.
For the long haul, though, people who are choosing between the two funds are deciding between two approaches to investing: value and growth. And a debate has raged for years over which is preferable.
To explain the difference, Mr. Kresnicka pointed to some standard measures of valuation. "Giftrust invests in companies with high P.E. ratios and price-to-book, and is willing to pay up as long as they see strong growth rates that justify those price multiples," he said.
Consider the fund's biggest holding at the end of 1996, the latest date for which complete portfolio information is available. It was the American depository receipts of the CBT Group, a Dublin company that makes software for technology training, trading at an extraordinary 91.6 times trailing earnings, a ratio several times that of the S.& P. 500.
In an interview last week, Mr. Fogle said his fund's top holding is now McAfee Associates, a software company in Santa Clara, Calif., that produces network security and management products. It is trading at about 38 times its projected 1997 earnings of $1.60 to $1.65 a share.
Over all, Giftrust had more than one-third of its assets in technology stocks at the end of the year. Royce Gift Shares had 21 percent of assets, its biggest portion, in industrial services, and its top holding was Sevenson Environmental Services, a company that handles environmental cleanups. Its stock is trading at a more modest 18.6 times trailing earnings.
"Our approach takes into consideration risk and reward," said Mr. Royce, 58, the primary manager of 10 open-end funds and 3 closed-end funds, all in the small-cap and micro-cap area. "We don't expose the shareholder to too much risk, and we invest in small-cap stocks that have great prospects that we can buy cheaply."
Lately, he has been adding to his big position in Bassett Furniture Industries, which is revamping and is now trading at about 19 times trailing earnings. "It sells just above book value," he said, "and it's a significant brand in the furniture world."
Mr. Royce also likes Standard Commercial, which processes tobacco leaves and has a substantial wool business. "They've just completed a deal to pay down a lot of debt," he said. Furthermore, the stock is trading at a mere 9 times earnings.
BESIDES investment styles, there are a few other considerations for investors choosing between the two funds. The minimum investment in Royce Gift Shares is $5,000, while Giftrust can be bought for as little as $500.
For tax purposes, contributions are not quite the same, either. Anyone can make a gift of up to $10,000 a year to another individual without estate or gift tax consequences under the Federal annual gift tax exclusion. As a present interest trust, Royce allows such gifts.
Contributions to Giftrust don't qualify for this exclusion because they are considered a gift of future interest, explained Gunnar Hughes, a spokesman for American Century Investments. Instead, investments count against the $600,000 that each person is allowed to leave free of estate and gift taxes over a lifetime. (Congress is considering whether to raise this threshold as part of its budget package for the coming year.)
Fans of Giftrust, however, note that it pays taxes as a trust each year, sparing donors and recipients that paperwork burden. Investors in Royce Gift Shares can choose to set up their trust this way as well.
For gifts to either fund, the donor determines in advance when the beneficiary will receive the assets -- no small comfort to grandparents who worry that a grandchild will squander the money before the college bills have been paid.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GERRITSEN BEACH;
A Hop, and Another, and a Lucky Library Lands on Home

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
It was five minutes to one last Thursday afternoon, and the line outside the new Gerritsen Beach Public Library was 20 people deep.
Among the patrons were the elderly, the unemployed and two schoolchildren who were not in school because, they said, their school does not have Internet access. 
 The doors to the $4.2 million library, at 28-08 Gerritsen Avenue, opened officially on April 30, marking the end of a 65-year odyssey. "We finally have a home," said Mary Graham, the branch librarian, "a big wonderful home."
Opened in 1932, the library originally occupied a small storefront on Gerritsen and Florence Avenues. The city tried to close it in 1954 because of budget problems, but community pressure kept it open.
The next year the library moved a block north, into what is now a pet shop.
In 1989, the library moved again into a 1,000 square-foot space next to Big Al's Barber Shop. Residents say the space was too small and the 9,000 volumes woefully inadequate.
"We had to demonstrate community desire for a new library," said Debbie Dong, who led the community effort to collect 5,000 signatures and encouraged children to write letters to city officials. Borough President Howard Golden was impressed enough to pledge $4 million from the discretionary funds of his office. The new branch is the first library built in the borough in four years.
"We are now realizing our goal of having a branch library within a half-mile of every Brooklynite," said Linda Locke, a library spokeswoman.
The new library, a 10,000-square-foot brick and cast-stone building, overlooks Shell Bank Creek to the west and the Marine Park marshes to the east. It has 26,000 volumes, an archive of local history and six new computers hooked up to the World Wide Web. Last Wednesday, 27 children applied for their library cards.
"It's amazing that kids come here after school instead of loitering around the neighborhood," Mrs. Graham said. "All of the sudden, they're sponges wanting to soak up anything and everything." Some 50 children sign up for the computers every afternoon. The most popular book, she said, is R. L. Stine's horror tales, called "Goosebumps."
Two sixth-graders at Marine Park Middle School, Nicole Coppolino and Shannon Carroll, said they passed up a class trip to Philadelphia to visit the library.
"We'd rather surf the net," Ms. Carroll said. "Yeah, it's not true that all kids are spoiled and like to only watch TV," Ms. Coppolino agreed. "Some like the library." CHARLIE LeDUFF
