HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Staying Put: The Surprising Longevity of Lifetime Employment

BYLINE: By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
IN 1968, Lea Wait had just graduated from college and was looking for a temporary job to pay for graduate school. Her father suggested that she try AT&T, where he had spent his entire 45-year career as an accountant. So she donned a suit and matching hat and went to the personnel office.
"I wasn't too enthused," recalled Ms. Wait, 50, of Bernardsville, N.J. "I was a drama major. I thought they hired only engineers and secretaries, and I didn't want to be either." 
 Twenty-nine years later, she still works for AT&T. Her first job was writing executives' speeches. She has also had stints in the engineering, investor relations, strategic planning and sales departments. "It never occurred to me that I'd work here my entire life," said Ms. Wait, now a manager in public relations. "But it's not as though I've sat at the same desk for 29 years."
In a world of mergers, downsizings and reorganizations, people who spend the bulk of their careers with one employer are bound to be viewed as an endangered species. Cradle-to-grave employment and loyalty between employers and employees supposedly died long ago. Yet despite all the talk of multiple careers and the jobless future, a surprising number of midcareer workers appear to be on their way to collecting their gold watches. And many companies are thankful they have such old-timers.
At Custom Coach, a Columbus, Ohio, company that converts buses into motor homes and offices, Jerome Nunn, the president, said he could not satisfy his customers without his long-term employees. About half of the 18 workers who convert the vehicles have been there more than 10 years; one employee has been there 40 years.
"It takes a year to get an employee up to speed," he said. "If you have a customer with an eight-year-old bus who calls with a question, if there is no one here who worked on that unit, you have a problem."
IN 1996, nearly half of all American workers aged 45 to 54 had worked for their employer for 10 years or more, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics; one-fifth of those in that age group had been with the same employer for 20 or more years. And among those 55 to 64 years old, nearly one-third had worked 20 or more years for the same employer.
AT&T, like many other companies, has had its share of layoffs and reorganizations in the last 15 years. Yet, according to Burke Stinson, a company spokesman, the typical retiree last year was 55 years old with 27 years of service; in 1978, the typical retiree was 57 and had 32 years of service. About 30 percent of its domestic work force, or about 35,500 employees, have been with AT&T for more than 20 years, he said.
The oft-quoted maxim is that the average worker can expect to change employers six or seven times before retiring. But most of that upheaval occurs in the early years of a career, according to Jonathan Veum, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The agency reported that in 1992, workers held an average of 7.5 jobs between the ages of 18 and 30. That average includes all paid work of any duration, like summer jobs during college. Job-hopping, Mr. Veum said, is most intense for people in their 20's, when many workers are single, childless, and willing to play musical jobs so they can land one that is a perfect fit.
"You slow down as you get older, and you don't have quite as much mobility between jobs," Mr. Veum said. "As you age, most of your mobility occurs within one company."
There are, of course, many benefits to long tenures, like anniversary celebrations, more vacation time and seniority, which can protect workers -- especially those in union jobs -- from layoffs.
But staying with one company, and being successful there, can be tricky, especially if your mobility is more lateral than upward.
"The impression is, you're not a go-getter," said Ron Fry, the publisher of Career Press in Franklin Lakes, N.J., and the author of "101 Great Answers to the Toughest Interview Questions" (Career Press, 1996).
"You're not on the fast track; you're on the retirement track," he said. "Another question is: 'You've been here so long, you're like an old dog. Can you convince me you can learn new tricks?' "
Stan Wood, 49, an I.B.M. employee for 18 years, has not been afraid to prove that he could. He has adapted to five different jobs since he has been with the company; in 1990, he moved from marketing management to sales when he suspected that his position might be eliminated during job cuts.
"It was a calculated career move on my part to increase the odds I wouldn't be laid off," Mr. Wood, of Jacksonville, Fla., said. "I was starting to hear rumblings, and the best place to be was calling on customers."
Learning new tricks requires a bit of balancing. Most difficult tasks are mastered in three to five years, according to Judith Bardwick, management consultant and author of "Danger in the Comfort Zone" (Amacom, 1991). So for employees to stay at peak form within an organization, they must take on new challenges about that often. If the challenges are too daunting, employees may become too anxious to perform well. On the other hand, too little risk can cause them to fall into a state of complacency, losing their value to the organization.
"On the outside, your job may continue to have the same title, but the content should change," Ms. Bardwick said. "You need to keep learning, stretching, and be required to perform at the highest level you're capable of."
Stephen Cheney, 42, of Haymarket, Va., has worked for Cherrydale Harman Auto Glass for 19 years. He said that he never intended to spend his life at one company, and that he had often thought about starting his own business. But since being promoted to store manager in 1980, he has been given plenty of autonomy and just enough challenge to keep him interested. In the early 90's, the company asked him to open up a new business. Recently, he was appointed to a business development team to come up with new markets for the company.
"I couldn't go for much more than a year without something different to work on," Mr. Cheney said.
One danger of staying with one employer is that it may take long-term employees for granted, passing them over for promotions in favor of newcomers. And because companies have eliminated layers of management in recent years, it has become more difficult for everyone who wants a promotion to get one. Hence, the common complaint: the only way to move up the organization is to threaten to move out.
When Robert Sullivan, 30, a Chicago marketing consultant, announced that he was leaving his job at an advertising agency after four years, he was suddenly offered his choice of two plum overseas assignments. "When I told them I intended to leave, that's when they said: 'Yes, we do appreciate what you do. If you need a change, here's what we can do for you.' " He decided to leave anyway.
MANY longtime employees value stability and are fiercely loyal to the company, saying they enjoy passing along its lore and culture to the next generation.
United Press International has been struggling for years to stay afloat. Yet Helen Thomas, 76, who became a reporter with United Press 54 years ago, has never wavered, even as many of her colleagues have jumped ship. "It's sad when your colleagues leave," she said. "But I've been hanging in there. I have faith." Ms. Thomas started her career there during World War II, and has been covering the White House since John F. Kennedy was President. She is amused by some of the questions younger staff members ask her, like "What is D-Day?"
"You feel a little like an antique, but you're also glad that you know the answer," Ms. Thomas said.
Johnny Glaze, 65, has also tended to stay around. A salesman for Parker Cadillac in Little Rock, Ark. for 23 years, Mr. Glaze has been a pastor at Little Rock Community Church for 36 years. He has lived in the same house for 27 years. He has been married to the same woman, Denva, for 42 years. He keeps a list of every customer to whom he has ever sold a car and sends each one a card at Christmas. When he attends the Cadillac sales meeting once a year, he marvels at all the new faces he sees, and can't understand why people don't have the patience to stay put.
"I'm like the Rock of Gibraltar," Mr. Glaze said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will China Choose Power or Wealth?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
More than two centuries ago, in 1790, a crass political deal was struck. The Virginians, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, agreed to let the Federal Government assume debts issued by the states during the Revolutionary War, and in turn Alexander Hamilton, a New Yorker, agreed to let the new nation's capital be in the South.
The ramifications of that deal are still here. The political and financial capitals of this country are hundreds of miles apart, and inhabitants of each neither know nor understand the other as well as they should. 
 Nowhere is that split more evident now than in the divergent American attitudes toward Hong Kong's impending absorption into China. "The political and economic lenses are very different," said Douglas Johnston, Merrill Lynch's senior international strategist, in an understatement.
In Washington, it is assumed that Beijing will break its promises to preserve Hong Kong's separate system and basic freedoms. Most members of Congress would deem it absurd to contemplate investing in Hong Kong on the eve of Communist rule.
But in New York, where financial thinking is dominant, Hong Kong looks much more attractive. "Global investors are looking for earnings and value, and Hong Kong has both," said the bullish Mr. Johnston.
To hear some people talk, you'd think it was Hong Kong taking over China, "You've never before taken 1.2 billion people and moved from a centrally planned economy to a free-market economy," exulted Thomas B. Tuttle, the manager of the Colonial Newport Tiger fund. The fund's investments are concentrated in Hong Kong.
The Hang Seng index, Hong Kong's leading market barometer, is up 30 percent in the last year, and is 12 times higher than it was in 1984, when Britain agreed to withdraw on June 30, 1997. It has performed far better than the American stock market.
In fact, things are getting a bit giddy in Hong Kong, where regulators warned last week that some stock prices "appear to have no relation to the assets, profitability or prospects of the companies concerned." The warning was generally ignored, just as similar talk has been discounted here..
Mr. Tuttle, who wears a Mao watch, is confident that the Chinese authorities will do whatever it takes to keep Hong Kong healthy and wealthy. He thinks a greater degree of political freedom is inevitable. By 2047, when China's guarantee of a special status for Hong Kong is to expire, he thinks China will be "one of the most free-enterprise economies in the world."
That summarizes the disparity in outlook. To those versed in money, the idea that a country would not follow the path to wealth is unbelievable, and allowing more political freedom seems like a small price for China's leaders to pay. To those more attuned to ideology and human rights, the idea that one of the world's most repressive regimes will change seems equally hard to believe.
Mr. Tuttle says he would start taking money out of Hong Kong if he thought the independence of Hong Kong's courts, and with it the basic rule of law, was being compromised. Or if China tried to substitute its own paper for Hong Kong's dollar reserves, threatening to unhinge the Hong Kong dollar from its American counterpart. But he doesn't expect that either will happen.
Who's right? Markets are usually wiser than politicians. But politicians know how much people are willing to do to hold on to power. On this, Washington's crystal ball may be better than Wall Street's.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Mimi Smartypants Takes On the Assassins

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
ZIP through the aisles at the local computer store and the mayhem mounts quickly: "Ravage," "No Flesh Shall Be Spared" and "Assassin" ("Shoot first, think fast . . . or get smoked") are typical CD-ROM titles. Market research and sales show that carnage counts with teen-age boys, the target audience for many computer games.
But CD-ROM designers have discovered an emerging audience: girls 9 to 11 years old. Wired magazine recently reported that 200 new "girl games" were expected to reach store shelves or go on line this year, up tenfold from 1996. 
 Like most computer games, many will be developed on the West Coast, but one of the most critically acclaimed designers of such games for young girls, Theresa Duncan, can be found in Manhattan, in "Silicon Alley," the city's growing downtown computer district.
Ms. Duncan and two colleagues at Nicholson NY, a new-media firm in the Puck Building, at 295 Lafayette Street, just south of Houston Street, develop games with no treasures to stalk and no life forms to splatter. Their most recent CD-ROM, "Smarty," depicts the partly funky and partly dreamlike summer of a brainy 9-year-old, Mimi Smartypants.
It was widely praised by reviewers and much sought after by parents last Christmas, although it was distributed only by toll-free telephone number and sold only 6,000 copies. Wider distribution is planned for this Christmas. An earlier collaboration by Ms. Duncan, called "Chop Suey," was named "CD-ROM of the Year" for 1995 by Entertainment Weekly magazine and has sold more than 25,000 copies.
At a trade show next month in Atlanta, Ms. Duncan and her collaborators -- Jeremy Blake, an illustrator, and Wells Packard, a computer programmer -- plan to introduce a new CD-ROM game for girls. Called "Zero Zero," the game follows Pinkee Le Brun, a young French girl who explores the rooftops of Paris on New Year's Eve 1899 ("a time before Popsicles and dimestore paperbacks") and is scheduled for release in stores in September.
"I love books and I love CD-ROM's, but most of all, I love storytelling," said Ms. Duncan, 28, whose senior thesis at the University of Michigan was titled "Electric Fairy Tales: CD-ROM's and Literature."
One major difference between books and computer games is that the games can provide interactive choices, like deciding that Romeo and Juliet do not die. In "Smarty," when Mimi visits her Aunt Olive, the user can let Mimi watch television with her aunt, or double-click and have her visit Moscow, Paris or Miami Beach.
What is beginning to change the boy-dominated computer game market, however, is not computer equipment but Barbie, the popular doll by Mattel. Last Christmas, Mattel sold more than half a million copies of "Barbie Fashion Designer," making it one of the best-selling CD-ROM's ever. It enables users to design dresses for Barbie on the screen and then print them on a standard computer printer.
Headbone Interactive, a new-media company in Seattle, has been conducting focus groups with pre-teen girls, in part to find out how to duplicate Barbie's success. Their research seems to indicate that girls prefer treasure hunts, mysteries and "open-ended play" promoting collaboration. "They clearly don't like violence," said Susan Lammers, president of Headbone.
Ms. Duncan is a Detroit native, her mother a social worker and her father a factory worker. She began learning about computers in earnest when she helped edit economic fact sheets at the World Bank in Washington. There she met Monica Gesue, a photographer, who followed her to Magnet Interactive Studios, a multimedia company. Ms. Gesue illustrated "Chop Suey," Ms. Duncan's story of two sisters named Lily and June Bugg, whose adventures begin when they eat too much Chinese food.
Ms. Duncan says she bases many characters on herself (Mimi's voice is hers speeded up electronically) and on her own whimsical grandmother, Margaret Lundgren, an art teacher with an antic sense of humor. Ms. Duncan recalls the day her grandmother spilled coffee on her blouse, then painted flowers on it to disguise the stain.
Her granddaughter's approach to computers is similarly offbeat. "I don't like verisimilitude," Ms. Duncan said. "I like folk art. Computer screens are intrinsically alienating, and folk art, with its quirkiness and its hand-drawn flaws, adds warmth."
"Smarty" required 3,000 drawings, said Mr. Blake, the illustrator, adding, "Theresa and I have similar senses of humor." In the CD-ROM, a butterfly plays Chopin on the piano and a Martian shows slides of his summer vacation on Earth, both Blake ideas. "Some of our best ideas come up when somebody says, 'You've got to be kidding,' " Ms. Duncan said.
Translating her text and Mr. Blake's pictures into computer data is the job of Mr. Packard, who teaches CD-ROM programming at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan. He also has to animate things like swimming fish in an aquarium and determine the element in a scene that a child might want to click on, like a teapot at the center of a table.
Ultimately, Ms. Duncan said, what is important is not the form of the storytelling, but its content. As Mimi's Aunt Olive put it, "Poetry is what spices up smarts."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Signs of Gold in Latin America's Blue Chips

BYLINE: By LARRY DIGNAN 

 BODY:
TRUE to their name, blue-chip stocks are not cheap these days. Indeed, their increase in value has been the primary engine of the bull market. But not all big companies come with big price tags: the Latin American stocks that trade here as American depository receipts are often relatively inexpensive, even though they come from one of the world's hottest economic regions.
Yet, making money in Latin America, as in any emerging-market region, is neither quick nor easy. "If you're investing in Latin America with a three-month view, you are going to get hammered," said Stephen Oler, portfolio manager of the Templeton Latin America fund. "You will be rewarded handsomely," but only "if you take a 5- to 10-year view, and can stomach the blips." 
 Still, blue chips in Latin America often weather crises like the 1994 Mexican peso devaluation somewhat better than smaller companies do. Add in the region's recent market performance -- Brazil's Bovespa index is up 48 percent this year, and Mexico's Bolsa, about 19 percent -- and these stocks can look alluring.
Consider Telebras, the Brazilian telephone company, which accounts for 40 percent of the market capitalization of the Bovespa.
Money managers love Brazil because it has earmarked various state enterprises for privatization. On May 6, the Government sold off Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, a mining giant; the event strengthened investor confidence that the sale of parts of Telebras late this year or early in 1998 will proceed as scheduled.
These hopes have doubled the price of Telebras A.D.R.'s, from about $60 in early 1996 to $128.25 at Friday's close. But that run-up does not bother Donald Hoskins, portfolio manager for the Excelsior Emerging Americas fund, which counts Telebras among its holdings.
"Telebras is still extremely cheap, so don't be put off because it's appreciated so much," Mr. Hoskins said. He thinks Telebras will hit $150 a share by the end of the year, and will still be a buy at that level.
Mr. Hoskins judges the A.D.R.'s cheapness by the ratio of its stock price to the amount of cash flow per share, a measure often used in analyzing foreign companies. Telebras has a ratio of 5.5, based on consensus earnings estimates for 1997, compared with 6.6, on average, for the Baby Bells of the United States. That makes Telebras far cheaper than the Bells, he said, even after discounting the company because it is an emerging-market play.
Mark Madden, a portfolio manager for the Pioneer Emerging Markets fund, says Telebras has great growth potential. There are 8 telephone lines for every 100 people in Brazil, compared with 63 per 100 in the United States, he said, and Brazil's cellular market has hardly been tapped. Telebras should also be able to widen its profit margins by modernizing its network and increasing prices for local service.
OVER all, Mr. Hoskins estimates that earnings at Telebras will grow 28 percent or more annually for the next five years.
The big caveat with Telebras is regulatory uncertainty in Brazil. "They still have to set the regulatory environment," Mr. Hoskins said. "Essentially, an entire F.C.C."
Telefonica de Argentina, one of that country's two major telecommunications plays, also holds promise. The company controls the country's northern market and a large part of the business in Buenos Aires.
"Argentina hasn't been in the limelight because the focus is on Brazil," Mr. Oler said. But "economic growth has been surprisingly good" there, he said, and telecommunications, privatized in 1990, should benefit.
Argentina is coming out of a recession, and its annual economic growth rate, 4.4 percent last year, was expected to reach 7 percent for the first quarter this year. Inflation is almost nonexistent, at one-tenth of 1 percent last year, Mr. Oler said.
Telefonica also stands to gain from a growing cellular market, and from its connection to Spain's telephone company, Telefonica de Espana, which recently teamed up with MCI Communications and British Telecommunications, the industry giants that will form a company called Concert. The alliance should help Telefonica de Argentina keep long-distance costs low, improving margins.
Mr. Madden is less bullish over Telefonica, however, because Argentina has 16 telephone lines for every 100 inhabitants, double the number in Brazil. And while the regulatory framework for telecommunications is settled in Argentina, there are other unknowns, like a pending Supreme Court decision on whether the industry can increase local rates.
In Mexico, too, there is uncertainty, mostly over elections in July. The Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, long in control, is expected to lose some power. But the question is how the PRI may handle that loss.
"The key is that the transition goes smoothly," said Gabriel Wallach, an analyst for Fiduciary Trust Company International.
But many analysts are optimistic, and hope that after the elections, the Mexican market will reach levels not seen since before the peso devaluation.
ONE beneficiary may be Desc Sociedad de Fomento Industrial, which produces a wide range of goods, from foods to chemicals. Desc's primary growth business, however, is transmissions, pistons, axles and other car parts, and it has become a large supplier to General Motors, Chrysler and Ford.
"This company spent 10 years positioning itself for Nafta," Mr. Oler said. When the trade treaty took effect, Desc had much business in the United States and continued to be a big supplier to Mexican auto makers. Mr. Oler, whose fund owns Desc A.D.R.'s, estimates that the company's cash flow will grow 15 percent annually for the next two years.
Like many other Latin American A.D.R.'s, Desc's are inexpensive, Mr. Oler added. Indeed, the shares trade at just 8.6 times current earnings -- not much more than one-third of the 21.4 average multiple for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
A stronger peso could hurt Desc, Mr. Oler said, but the company, which has cut expenses, should be able to keep reasonable margins.
Mr. Hoskins likes Grupo Elektra, an appliance and electronics retailer with nearly 500 stores in Mexico. The company profited greatly during Mexico's recent recession by focusing on lower- and middle-income consumers, which account for 92 percent of the country.
Elektra is also using this network of stores to offer high-margin financial services like cash transfers and credit. The company has formed links with Western Union and with Grupo Financiero Serfin, a Mexican bank, to sell the services, which also help Elektra's customers to buy its appliances and electronic goods.
In the first quarter, Elektra's revenues were up 48 percent from the corresponding period last year. Earnings, excluding extraordinary items, were up 22 percent.
"This is a well-run company that has a store in nearly every neighborhood," said Mr. Hoskins, whose fund owns shares in the company. "And there's upside. Elektra can have a 25 percent growth rate a year for the next five years." Grupo Elektra's A.D.R.'s trade at just 14.9 times current earnings.
On the downside, the company's success will breed imitators, analysts say.
Moreover, investors in Grupo Elektra, as well as other blue-chip A.D.R.'s, may lose one of the benefits of international investing. That advantage focuses on "correlation," which measures whether stock markets move together, in opposite directions or follow no pattern.
By putting money in stock markets -- like those of emerging nations -- with low or negative correlations with the United States market, investors hope to hedge their holdings. If the American market falters, they reason, a foreign one may improve. But blue-chip A.D.R.'s, because they are big and because they are traded in the United States, often act in the same way as domestic equities and thus cancel this advantage.
"You have to watch out for who owns the securities," said Eric Fry, president of Holl International, an asset management firm in San Francisco. "Seventy percent of A.D.R.'s are owned by Americans, so it makes sense that they will track the U.S. markets."

LENGTH: 908 words

HEADLINE: RUNWAYS;
As for Best Friends, Marilyn Knew Best

BYLINE: By SUZY MENKES; Suzy Menkes is the fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune.

 BODY:
I MAGINE Courtney Love, poured into her white Oscars dress, recreating for the 1990's the breathless whisper of Marilyn Monroe. She opens her lipstick-smeared mouth and sings, "Diamonds are a girl's best friend."
Diamonds for Courtney Love? Those flashy trinkets of trophy wives are cool? 
 You would think so if you watched the celebrity lineup in high-wattage sparklers at the Cannes Film Festival. There was Isabelle Adjani with a lattice of diamonds round her John Galliano Chinese-style gown, Liv Tyler in a Harry Winston gem trellis, Demi Moore up to her neck in rubies and diamonds, the Chinese actress Gong Li in a chain of brilliants and Naomi Campbell with a diamond-fringe necklace and dark shades above a Givenchy Empire gown.
All that strutting the stuff in Cannes had followed the Academy Awards, which People magazine memorably described in 1996 as about "tears, cleavage and diamonds." This year, Ms. Love redefined glamour in her snowy Versace gown, with a cascade of diamonds at her neck -- a far cry from Sharon Stone, who last year wore a Gap turtleneck to the Academy Awards.
In "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," Marilyn's lyric goes: "Talk to me Harry Winston, tell me all about it." Did he ever! For the Oscars, that New York jeweler put Winona Ryder in cluster earrings, Mira Sorvino in dangling ruby and diamond ones. Even Brenda Blethyn had swapped her downtrodden persona in "Secrets and Lies" for razzle-dazzle.
There is nothing new about rocks and stars. An exhibition at Cannes showed photographs of a sophisticated Marlene Dietrich and an ingenue Katharine Hepburn, both draped in diamonds. Cartier's archives feature the chunky glitter bracelets that once belonged to Gloria Swanson. Elizabeth Taylor's appetite for diamonds is legendary.
Of course, we know that celebrities today are lent diamonds by jewelers so that they can sparkle in public. But they also wear them in the real world. Brooke Shields and Gwyneth Paltrow both wear a diamond solitaire on a chain (said to be engagement gifts). Models are mad for Isaac Mizrahi's "angel rings" (so dainty, they must be hung round the neck) and for Marc Jacobs's celestial sun, moon and stars scatter pins.
The final seal of approval for diamonds as the quintessence of cool came when Visionaire made them the subject of its latest issue, packaged as an oversize deck of cards. At the opening party during New York's fashion week in April, drag queens in a glitter-gulch of (fake) gems competed with the striking visual images from the Visionaire deck: Karl Lagerfeld's hunky male with a diamond tear drop in one eye; Iman with gilded nipple, ram's horns and diamond rings in a computer-enhanced photo by Inez van Lamsweerde.
It seems only a moment ago that diamonds represented stolid suburban values -- matrons (present and future) celebrating engagements and anniversaries. Or they belonged to the Ivana Trump school: if you have your man, flaunt his wallet.
To be sure, showing one's wealth has crept back into style now that the economy has picked up. But what alchemy turned diamonds from vulgar globs to the height of hip?
The jewelry revival could be dated from 1993, when Naomi Campbell and Kate Moss pulled down their mini-kilts on Vivienne Westwood's runway to show off their bejeweled navel rings. Rocks in new places became a fashionable secret.
After the great clear-out of the 90's, when fashion junked the gilt and glitzy, the absence of visible jewelry was the style. Then, fine jewelry, something precious that was inconspicuous, crept into the shows of hip designers like Mr. Galliano and Mr. Jacobs. Post-minimalism, fashion was searching for a fresh start in adornment. What could be purer than the clear-as-water diamond?
British club kids picked up on vintage jewelry that was so out of style that paste versions could be bought for a song. Think tiaras. Mr. Galliano put diadems on his models in a 1993 show, and Amanda de Cadenet and Ms. Love appeared in Los Angeles in tiaras, like trashy fairy princesses.
Gianni Versace entered a tiara anonymously for the 1996 Diamonds International Awards -- and won first prize. Miuccia Prada turned out in a diadem at a party in Milan, Italy. Improbable as such a revival might seem, when the London jeweler Wartski staged an exhibition of tiaras in March, 50,000 visitors gaped at creations belonging to the famous, from Elton John to Joan Rivers.
 A DEFINING moment for diamond jewelry came in Chanel's summer couture show, when Karl Lagerfeld sent out the wacky aristocratic model Iris Palmer with a tinselly diamond tiara, necklace, earrings -- the works. It was a smart way to celebrate Chanel's new fine jewelry line.
But hang on a minute. Wasn't it Coco Chanel who decided back in the 1920's that diamonds were irredeemably bourgeois -- heavy-handed symbols of wealth and status? Her piles of gilt chains and faux bijoux were supposed to show the world what fun fashion jewelry could be.
It is a nice irony that after the glitzy 80's, nothing looks more bourgeois and matronly than loads of gilt. The symbols that Chanel used to free women from over-opulence now chain them to an older generation.
What makes diamonds look new and modern is the attitude of the women wearing them -- forthright and independent. There is a delicious defiance in Madonna flashing her diamonds. You know that she didn't have to rely on a man to get them for her. Now, is that cool, or what?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Isabelle Adjani flashing more than a smile at Cannes this month. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Retailers Swim Against a Tide of Shoppers' Bad Debts

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
FOR much of 1996, retail analysts and investors were gleeful as they watched same-store sales at Sears, Roebuck & Company rise past their monthly marks of a year earlier. But a sizable chunk of those sales never made it into the company's coffers, let alone to its bottom line.
While Sears, Roebuck's gross sales rose 9 percent last year, to $38.2 billion, its write-offs for shoppers' bad debt increased much more quickly -- about 50 percent, to $1.0 billion. Add it all up, and the company gave away 9.6 days' worth of shirts, washing machines and nightgowns last year. 
 And Sears is not the only unwilling philanthropist in retailing. Last year was one of the worst for the industry in terms of bad debt, or customer accounts that went unpaid. High rates of personal bankruptcies and the industry's breathless pursuit of new charge accounts over the last few years combined to create the increases.
As a result, many retail companies have been struggling to bring the debt levels down. They are cooling their courtships with new credit customers and fattening reserves to cover the expanding bad debt.
"Bad debt was a record cost issue to be dealt with in 1996," said Tom Tashjian, a retail analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "Most department stores that offer credit cards had to increase bad-debt reserves and the write-offs they took."
But solving the problem may not be easy; bad debts are rising fast. At Nordstrom, for example, bad debt grew 30 percent in 1996, to $51.3 million. And in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Federated Department Stores cited a 35 percent increase in bad debts, to $172 million last year from $127 million in 1995.
Of course, write-offs are well worth it, even when they rise rapidly, if the income provided by credit card sales and the hefty interest rates and fees that accompany them is large enough.
"The finance-charge revenues we got were on plan last year," said Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Federated, adding that this made the high levels of bad debt tolerable though still unpleasant. Increases in such levels are "a cyclical thing," she added, saying that Federated is not too concerned about a continuation of the problem.
But consider it this way: Federated had sales of $15.2 billion last year -- or $41.6 million a day. So if bad debts accounted for $172 million, Federated would have needed more than four extra shopping days to recover the revenue that went up in smoke.
Investors should particularly keep their eyes on Sears, because its credit card operation is among the largest in the country. Retailers with smaller credit card businesses may not be hit as hard by bad debt come earnings time, but all investors in retailing should be vigilant.
"I think it is an issue, though not a major one," Mr. Tashjian said. "It can eat up to 5 percent of company's earnings."
The industry is trying to fix the problem in several ways. For example, Mr. Tashjian estimated that it increased reserve levels -- the amount that companies put aside to cover bad debt -- by about 50 percent in 1996.
Several companies have also slowed their energetic courting of new accounts, analysts said. Some retailers, like Carson Pirie Scott, a department store chain based in Milwaukee, started doing so in the second half of 1995, when the bad-debt monster surfaced on the balance sheets.
"We decided at that point we would be better served not going after so much new credit," said James Stoffel, vice president and treasurer of the company.
While curtailing new credit seems the easiest way to stave off bad debt, the process has big risks. For one, identifying who among potential card holders will ignore their bills is no easy science; Mr. Stoffel and other retail executives said that many of their customers who filed for personal bankruptcy were a mere 15 to 30 days late in payment, or in fact not behind at all.
Further, department store credit cards are used to drive sales and profits in several ways. Retailers send their credit card customers special-sales mailings and can easily track their spending habits and market directly to them. Interest rates and fees are generally high. Also, credit card sales tend to be about 50 percent higher than those made with cash, which not only lifts the top line but helps fatten same-store sales figures, an important number retailers use in selling their worthiness to Wall Street.
"My sense is that people are tightening their standards," said Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst at NatWest Securities. "But you don't want to do it too much or you lose market share."
Other retailers, like Sears, May and Montgomery Ward, have taken a different and more controversial route. They have asked credit card holders who have filed for bankruptcy to sign agreements reaffirming that they will pay on some sort of schedule. This aggressive approach -- which may reveal how seriously the retail industry is taking the bad-debt problem -- has prompted criticism and even lawsuits against some of the companies.
Consumer debt levels, meanwhile, are still rising, though more slowly than last year.
"The problem is not getting better in level," said David A. Poneman, a retail analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. "We are still seeing double-digit increases in personal bankruptcy. Some people say it is improving because they are seeing 20 percent bad-debt increases over last year, while last year it was up 40 percent. That is an improvement, but it remains a significant problem."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A Tale of Unraveled Fortune

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: EVANSVILLE, Ind.

 BODY:
AS Robert Z. Morris was building a fortune in southern Indiana grain and Florida real estate, his mind often flashed back to a scene from his youth. It was the middle of the Depression and his father was desperately trying to borrow money to keep his farm and grain elevator going. Finally, he turned to his life insurance policy. Mutual of Omaha came through with $500, and the family business was saved.
That powerful lesson left the younger Mr. Morris with a deep faith in the value of life insurance. As the years rolled by and his own business empire flourished, he became as addicted to insurance as some investors are to the stock market. In 1934, he started with a $5,000 policy that named his wife as beneficiary. From then on, he snapped up policies "off and on for all of my life," he said, believing he was buying protection for his family and an investment vehicle for passing on his wealth. He ultimately acquired nearly 100 policies that he expected would pay roughly $30 million on his death, squirreling them away in an office vault. To keep track, he had a secretary draw up a list of the policies in longhand on a pale green ledger sheet. 
 But 12 years ago, Mr. Morris entered into a deal that undermined his confidence in the insurance industry and wiped out a large chunk of his wealth. In the process, he became one of tens of thousands of people who say they were burned by an industry marketing push in the early 1980's to hold onto policyholders' money -- a push that has since resulted in a barrage of lawsuits and hundreds of millions of dollars in fines and compensation payments.
But the unusual combination of his wealth, his passion for insurance policies and his readiness to pay a stream of unexpected bills totaling millions of dollars with barely a peep of protest makes Mr. Morris's story one of the most spectacular financial follies of recent years.
Now 82 years old and fighting Parkinson's disease, Mr. Morris is embroiled in a bitter dispute to get some of his money back.
And the insurance companies that provided the policies -- the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company and the American General Life Insurance Company -- as well as a Michigan agent who handled the transaction, James W. O'Neill, are not budging. They say the deal was fair and square and that Mr. Morris was showered with details.
"This is a not a situation where an insurance agent goes out to Ma and Pa Kettle on the farm on one visit and sells them a bill of goods," said Brent R. Weil, an Evansville lawyer who represents Mr. O'Neill. "This is a transaction that involved at least 10 visits to Mr. Morris over the course of nearly a year and volumes of projections were generated. Mr. Morris is a very financially sophisticated person."
At the time Mr. Morris made his move, interest rates were soaring, and millions of Americans were either abandoning or borrowing from their low-yielding whole-life insurance policies -- those that accumulate a cash value over time -- and moving the money into higher-yielding money-market funds and certificates of deposit.
To stanch the flow, insurance companies urged customers to convert their old policies, with returns of 4 to 5 percent, into new ones that paid twice as much or more. At the instigation of his agent, Mr. Morris did just that. After reviewing all of Mr. Morris's insurance holdings, Mr. O'Neill reduced the portfolio to about 60 policies. In his most striking move, he converted about 30 of the old policies, with death benefits for the Morris family of $6.4 million and annual premiums of $326,012, into 15 policies with death benefits of $10.1 million.
It was almost like waving a magic wand and doubling your money. Best of all, the projected interest on $2.28 million that was being shifted into the new policies, mainly as loans from the cash value of the old policies, was expected to pay all future premiums. It seemed a rather painless way for a 70-year-old man to make his money grow for his heirs.
That, at least, is how Mr. Morris says the agent explained it to him. In truth, such a happy outcome depended on the very unlikely event that interest rates would stay in double digits indefinitely. If they fell, however, Mr. Morris would have to make up the difference. All of this was explained in the fine print, but savvy as Mr. Morris was in his own business ventures, he says he never read the fine print. He says he didn't think he had to; after all, his absolute trust in insurance companies had been ingrained for more than half a century.
Besides, he said, "You could put 100 people on the witness stand and ask them if they'd read their insurance policies, every word of them, and you might find one."
So it came as a bit of a shock when, just a year after he made the switch, he received bills totaling roughly $300,000 from the two insurers. Puzzled, he dialed the toll-free number that each company had listed on its premium notice, he said, and, in each case, spoke with a woman whose name he did not catch. Both representatives, he said, told him the payments were necessary to bring his policies up to a point where no further premiums would be required.
THOSE brief telephone conversations were enough to satisfy Mr. Morris. His belief in the integrity of the insurance industry outweighed any doubts. He wrote both checks.
He did not hear anything from the companies, he said, for nearly three years. Then in late 1989, Manufacturers Life told him he owed $142,720. He paid. The next year, it sent a bill for $243,961. He paid again.
The next year, 1991, he got a bill from Manufacturers Life for $249,521. Then for the first time since 1986, he got a bill from American General, for $54,530. He paid both.
The next year, he paid the two companies $250,682. In 1993, he forked out a total of $726,208. In 1994, he paid $683,539, and in 1995 and 1996, he paid an additional $1.3 million. In all, the policies that he says should have cost him nothing in additional premiums had drained away roughly $3.8 million in a little more than a decade.
Finally, he decided he had had enough. On July 31, 1995, Mr. Morris, his wife, Alice, and their three children -- David, Joe, and Sue Morris Leonard -- sued the two companies and the Michigan agent, for full reimbursement of all the premiums he had paid since 1985, plus interest. The suit also demanded assurances that there would be no future requests for premiums, that the policies would stay in force until Mr. Morris's death and that the two companies would pay the death benefits.
Judge David A. Hamilton of Federal District Court in Indianapolis is studying arguments from both sides and has given no indication when he will rule.
Even if Mr. Morris never recovers a penny, his potential losses -- including the initial $2.28 million and the $3.8 million in subsequent premium payments, will hardly drive his family to the poorhouse. He figures his net worth today is roughly $7 million, besides the insurance policies. Even so, he and his wife are angry at the way they believe they were cheated, and frazzled by the emotional toll of their battle with the insurance companies. "The premiums have been devouring us," Mrs. Morris said.
THE deal with Mr. Morris, who even now, at 82, can summon up minute details of business ventures he undertook years ago, was very much like those that drew in tens of thousands of other Americans. Scores of companies, including giants like the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New York Life Insurance Company, have been sued by clients who say they were coaxed into exchanging perfectly good policies for new ones in a practice known as churning, and plaintiffs' lawyers say they receive calls every week with new complaints. Most of the suits involve policies in the $25,000 to $200,000 range, not in the millions, as with the Morrises.
One company being sued by the Morrises, Manufacturers Life, is also trying to fend off policyholders seeking Federal court approval for a class-action suit.
"There are in excess of 1,800 life-insurance companies in the country and the vast majority engaged in this behavior through the 80's," said John Stoia, a San Diego partner in the law firm of Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Hynes & Lerach, which has handled many of the cases and is engaged in the class-action effort against Manufacturers Life.
So far, about a dozen insurance companies, including Prudential, Metropolitan Life and New York Life, have agreed to pay more than $815 million in fines and compensation. In one of those settlements, Prudential has said it will be paying at least $410 million to compensate up to 10.7 million policyholders, and some analysts estimate that the costs for the company, the nation's largest life insurer, could run to $2 billion.
The lawsuits generally contend that agents -- who stood to gain a lot in commissions when they sold new policies -- misled customers by telling them that if they replaced their old life insurance policies with new ones providing double-digit returns, they would get more coverage and the new policies would virtually pay for themselves. Some companies, like Manufacturers Life, armed their agents with sales literature about "Vanishing Premiums."
According to most of the suits, the agents didn't adequately explain that premiums for new policies would start higher simply because customers were older, or warn them that interest rates were likely to fall eventually, forcing up premiums.
The new policies sold like hot cakes. But interest rates did decline, and the Morrises and legions of other policyholders found themselves confronting higher premiums than they had ever imagined. Many people, unable to keep up the payments, let policies lapse and lost everything they had put into them.
Mr. Morris's unusual strategy for transferring his wealth to his heirs through insurance policies rather than trusts gets mixed reviews. His plan was to spend most of his fortune -- which by the early 1980's totaled $31 million in cash, stocks and real estate -- in his final years and leave his family with roughly $35 million in insurance benefits. His twist was to grant ownership of the policies to the beneficiaries. While he has had to pay gift taxes of up to 55 percent on the premiums, he has eliminated the far larger estate taxes of up to 55 percent that they would have to pay on the $35 million if he had maintained ownership.
"It's a rare and sophisticated person who will pay gift taxes," said Alan S. Halperin, a Manhattan trust and estate lawyer. "A lot of people would rather hold on to the money thinking they'll be able to do something magical with it. Or, they tell themselves, 'Maybe the tax laws will change.' "
On the other hand, because insurance has a relatively low rate of return, Mr. Morris might have been able to build a bigger estate -- and still distribute it through gifts -- by investing in stocks and bonds. Bart L. Fooden, a financial planner in New York, said Mr. Morris probably would have been wise to diversify his portfolio beyond insurance. "If he lives to 90," Mr. Fooden said, "he will probably come out worse than if he had invested in stocks and bonds because he will have paid so much in premiums."
No one can say what is the right number of insurance policies to own. But most experts say they usually think of a dozen as a lot. Lee Slavutin, a New York agent who represents several life insurance companies in transactions with wealthy clients, said people rarely buy insurance coverage that equals or exceeds the value of their estate, as Mr. Morris did. Dr. Slavutin, a physician who says he derives more joy from selling insurance than from practicing medicine, said people often estimate the cost of their estate taxes and buy a life insurance policy just to cover that amount.
But once Mr. Morris had amassed all his policies, consolidation may not have been the best remedy, Dr. Slavutin said. Because Mr. Morris was older, he had to pay a higher premium rate for the policies he bought in 1985. His health had deteriorated, and that pushed up his premiums, too. According to court papers, commissions drained more than $400,000 from money that might otherwise have gone to bolstering his old policies' cash value.
At the time of the consolidation, the Morrises' agent presented them written warning notices, as required by Indiana, Michigan and many other states, including New York. One warning from Manufacturers Life, signed by Mr. Morris, cautioned that the decision to buy a replacement policy "could be a good one -- or possibly a mistake." It went on to advise, "make a careful comparison of your existing policy and the proposed policy."
Mr. Morris had always displayed a razor-sharp business acumen. He grew up helping his father in the corn fields of their 200-acre farm and in the family's weathered wooden grain elevator. At 14, he took a part-time job as a handyman at a Willy's Overland dealership run by his cousin. With a small loan from the local bank, quietly backed by his father, he began raising hogs. At 15 he bought his first car, a new Willy's Overland Whippet. That same year, 1929, on the day before the banks were closed, he withdrew $900 in savings and bought a new Chevrolet truck to start an ice-delivery business. And, at one of the worst points in the economic history of the country, he made money.
He married Alice Wood out of high school and never gave much thought to college. Instead, he settled in at his father's grain business. At 22, he was entrusted with half a dozen grain elevators.
When he sold the grain business for several million dollars 29 years later, he had 13 elevators, 17 tractor-trailer rigs and a fleet of 52 river barges, making him one of the biggest independent grain-elevator operators in the country. Mainly as a hedging device, he also held a seat on the Chicago Board of Trade.
To avoid heavy taxes when he sold the grain business, he found a clever way to reduce the cash in the transaction by getting his buyers to trade him a Florida cattle ranch, which, until he had come up with it, they had not owned. Then he went on to specialize in making big profits on real estate that no one else wanted to buy. He revived a failed plastics company and invested in banks. Once, he bought 100 half-finished railroad boxcars that were headed for the scrap heap. He sold the cypress interiors for more than he had paid for the cars, then made more money by sawing the cars in half and selling them as construction sheds.
MR. MORRIS was also an incredibly trusting man. In New York to sell his grain business, he left his suitcase with a taxi driver who promised to pick him up later and take him to the airport. The buyers in the grain deal were so stunned at what Mr. Morris had done that they trooped down to the front of their skyscraper, expecting to commiserate with the naive out-of-towner. To the amazement of everyone but Mr. Morris, there was the cabbie waiting at curbside, just as he had promised.
With the 7,000-acre ranch he received in the grain-business sale, Mr. Morris moved into real estate in Florida. He bought an agency in Sarasota with 13 employees and more than quadrupled the staff, earning commissions from the sales of homes and businesses, but just as important, using the company as a way to find properties he could buy and quickly resell at a profit.
It might seem incredible for a man with Mr. Morris's Midas touch to stumble into an insurance quagmire. But it isn't unusual at all, said Melvyn Weiss, a New York partner in Milberg, Weiss who has worked out more than a half-dozen settlements between big insurance companies and angry customers.
Mr. Weiss says the wealthy are as susceptible as anyone to insurance pitches and are just as befuddled by the arcane legal language in the documents. And, like everybody else, they usually assume that agents representing brand-name companies like Manufacturers Life and American General talk straight with them.
"They don't spend an inordinate amount of time studying the policy," Mr. Weiss said. "The contracts are typically very, very confusing. The big companies have cultivated images of trust and people tend to believe what they're told."
That is just about how Mr. Morris, a hulking man with a voice that has grown raspy as a consequence of his Parkinson's disease, says it went for him. "I relied a great deal on the fact that he was a licensed agent for the insurance people and that as such, he should be reliable," Mr. Morris said of his agent, Mr. O'Neill.
Another factor leading to his imbroglio was the pride Mr. Morris took -- and still takes -- in doing things his way. While he says he calls on lawyers now and then to chisel into legalese the deals he has single-handedly shaped, and relies on a consulting firm to advise him on his taxes, he scorns the idea of seeking outside advice on whether to buy insurance or anything else.
"What for?" he asked with a crusty edge one morning, straightening himself in a barrel-backed Windsor chair in the raw-brick lounge of his office. "Who the hell could tell me when to buy or sell?" On the walls were a couple of original Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey posters. An antique slot machine sat on a roll-top desk and the brass nameplate from a Florida hotel that Mr. Morris bought and sold three times was propped up in a bookcase behind a miniature 1956 pink Cadillac convertible, like the red one he once owned.
And there really wasn't much to understand about insurance policies until the late 1970's, when companies began introducing a complex structure known as universal life. Previously, the most widely sold policies had paid a rather steady, albeit low interest rate with unvarying premiums and a gradual buildup of cash values that could be borrowed against. The new policies not only provided sharply higher interest yields, but permitted customers to vary what they paid in premiums, depending on how big a nest egg they were shooting for. They could even skip payments entirely, as long as enough cash had accumulated in the policy to cover certain basic operating expenses.
Not understanding the innovations, Mr. Morris now says, he felt he was paying up the new policies forever with the initial installment of $2.28 million. In fact, he was establishing a base against which he could earn interest. In court documents, Mr. O'Neill says that at Mr. Morris's suggestion he used 10 percent as the basis for projecting the performance of the policies. The two companies were then paying 10.5 percent and 11 percent. But interest rates fell. The two companies in the dispute are now paying between 5.5 percent and 6.5 percent. And, by not paying into the policies, but leaving them to draw down money to cover the minimum expenses, he was making matters worse, eroding the base against which interest might have been earned.
Besides, Mr. Morris says, Mr. O'Neill was pretty convincing. They had met when Mr. O'Neill bought a penthouse in one of Mr. Morris's condominiums in Sarasota. They struck up a friendship, and in 1985 Mr. O'Neill looked over Mr. Morris's vast insurance portfolio.
While Mr. O'Neill says in court documents that he showed computer projections of how the policies would perform with interest of 10 percent over 20 years, Mr. Morris says he and the agent did not dwell on the matter of interest rates. Rather, as he recalls, the agent explained that because of demographic and economic changes, insurance companies were able to offer more coverage at lower cost: People were living longer and, with higher interest rates, companies were receiving higher returns on their investments.
Mr. Morris said his understanding was that interest rates would not affect his out-of-pocket premium expenses, but would only alter how much the company made. "They wouldn't lose," in any case, Mr. Morris said. "They just wouldn't come out as well" if rates dropped.
Mr. O'Neill would not speak with a reporter. But his lawyer, Mr. Weil, said Mr. Morris's version was contrary to what he was told and shown by the agent. Spokesmen for both companies declined to go beyond the voluminous documents in the case, although John E. Pluhowski, the director of corporate communications for the American General Corporation, the parent of the life insurance company, said his company had "acted properly" and strongly believed that the Morrises' complaint was "without merit."
In a letter to Mr. Morris's accountant that is dated March 6, 1985, and is part of the court record, Mr. O'Neill wrote that the annual premium for the 15 policies would be some $300,000, about $25,000 less than Mr. Morris had been paying on the policies that were to be consolidated. His point was that Mr. Morris's coverage would go from $6.4 million to $10.1 million and he would wind up paying a tad less in premiums.
"My client never represented to him that he would not have premiums to pay," Mr. Weil said.
Mr. Weil said the computer projections that are now a part of the case record, indicated that annual payments would be required on all but 2 of the 15 policies. In letters in the case record, Mr. Morris asked in late 1986 for a clarification on interest rates and asked at one point, "Won't these policies carry themselves for the next three to five years without any additional payment." Responding to a query from Mr. Morris, Mr. O'Neill said in a letter on Nov. 24, 1986, that without further payments, 2 of the 15 policies would run for 14 years and the others would continue in force for four to seven years. Every year, Mr. Weil said, the companies sent Mr. Morris reports on each policy that included the warning that coverage would end in a few years if no further payments were made.
All that may be technically true, said Mr. Morris's son, David, a commodities trader who sat sat in on some of the discussions between his father and Mr. O'Neill. Even so, he believes his father was misled.
"I don't think he ever came out and said, 'here's a deal where I can assure you you will never have to pay any premiums again,' but that was the impression he gave," David Morris said. "No rational person would have done what we did if he realized there was such a potential downside to it."
Even Mr. Weil concedes that Mr. Morris may have been confused. As recently as a year ago, when Mr. Morris was questioned by lawyers for nearly eight hours, he was saying that no loans -- which he says he always avoided in his business ventures -- had been used to finance the 15 policies. "But the bulk of this was pure loan money coming from existing policies," Mr. Weil said. "He still couldn't fathom that."
Mr. O'Neill's letter laying out the deal on the 15 policies did not mention the balance of Mr. Morris's policies, which now number 43 with a face value of about $25 million and annual premiums of about $220,000. Some of those policies are similar to the ones in dispute. But Mr. Morris says no one ever told him he would not have to pay premiums on them and he says he has no complaints. Most of the policies are on the lives of Mr. and Mrs. Morris, but some are on the lives of their children and grandchildren; consumer advocates discourage such policies on young children because they have no one to support and because other investments often provide better returns.
Mr. O'Neill was apparently up front about the $400,000 to $500,000 in initial commissions that he would receive in the transaction. In court documents, he said Mr. Morris directed him to share $50,000 to $100,000 of that fee with an agent who would be losing commissions on policies he had earlier sold Mr. Morris and who has since died.
THE fact that Mr. Morris made a series of payments over several years before the suit was filed has provided his opponents with ammunition to argue that the six-year statute of limitations in Indiana had run its course and that the case should be dismissed. Mr. O'Neill's lawyer says that if Mr. Morris expected not to pay any more premiums, he should have either filed suit in 1986 when the first demands for premiums were made or taken action "to clarify what the situation was."
But Mr. Morris's lawyer, Henry S. Alford of Louisville, says that his client regarded the payments in 1986 as reasonable adjustments to the deal and that when no premium requests were made in 1987 and 1988 he believed the policies were doing just as he had expected. It was not until late 1989, Mr. Alford says, that Mr. Morris began to believe he had been misled. Using that benchmark, Mr. Morris would be just within the time limit for bringing suit for intentional fraud.
But Mr. Weil said there was no fraud. "There may have been some misunderstanding," he said, "but there was no intentional fraud."
Struggling to cope with the mounting costs, the family has abandoned two policies worth $1.68 million at redemption and turned over six other policies worth $5.1 million to a Chicago company that has agreed to keep up the premiums and give the family a diminishing percentage of the death benefit, depending on how long Mr. Morris lives. Five policies, with a face value of $4,605,811, are involved in the suit.
Mr. Morris still goes every morning to his rambling office on the second floor of a bank building he bought years ago in the heart of this southern Indiana city. In shirt sleeves, open collar and wide suspenders, he manages a substantial securities portfolio and a string of properties and keeps an eye out for new deals. Now, as he has for most of his life, he operates mainly on his own, assisted only by a secretary.
Over the years, Mr. Morris says, friends advised him that he had accumulated more than enough insurance. But he just kept buying, thinking he understood insurance. Now though, he confessed the other day, "I don't think I know much about it."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk
