HEADLINE: Tour of Kodak Alters Views of Legislators

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, May 22

 BODY:
In this industrial town on the shores of Lake Ontario, the Eastman Kodak Company is affectionately known as the Big Yellow Box. The film-making giant remains a powerful and ubiquitous presence here, the city's main source of jobs, taxes and philanthropy. It is the last great survivor of upstate New York's once-flourishing manufacturing base.
In Albany, the Assembly Democrats are widely viewed as the last bastion of another endangered creature, the big-city liberal. For decades, they have been the Capitol's main source of pro-union, pro-environment and anti-big-business legislation, a group that can instill dread in a corporate lobbyist by just gaveling into session. 
 So why was a delegation of 14 Assembly Democrats, several of them liberals, getting the red-carpet treatment at Kodak headquarters this week?
At the invitation of Kodak's top executives, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, brought a group of younger lawmakers -- whom he described as the Assembly's next generation of leaders -- to look inside New York's largest manufacturer (35,000 jobs) and imbibe a bit of high-octane capitalism. It was a peacekeeping mission of sorts, a chance to break bread with a company some Democrats have viewed as an undertaxed, pollution-prone bad guy.
Over two days, the legislators, who make up almost a tenth of the Assembly, toured the construction site of a $200 million plant, watched robots mix chemicals, chatted with line workers whose families and friends have depended on Kodak paychecks for decades and tipped glasses with executives, including George Fisher, the chairman.
Almost to a person, they left -- gifts of fanny packs and disposable cameras in hand -- expressing pleasant surprise at how neighborly such a big company could be and professing newfound concern about the problems confronting the behemoth.
"This was the most exciting thing I've done since entering the Legislature," said Assemblyman Steve Englebright of Suffolk County, who at the outset of the trip described Kodak as the biggest polluter in New York. "I'd like to help spread their gospel."
Assemblywoman Melinda R. Katz of Queens said that before the trip she viewed Kodak as "this huge, impersonal company."
She added: "What I found was a very friendly atmosphere. Workers really seem to like working here."
Beneath all the pleasantries, however, a more calculated political strategy seemed to be at work. Mr. Silver, of Manhattan, is the state's most powerful Democrat, charged with rebuilding a party left in shambles by the election of the state's first Republican Governor in 20 years, George E. Pataki. He is also the most conservative Democratic Speaker the Assembly has seen in decades, one who has ever so gently been nudging his fractious 97-member caucus away from its left-leaning moorings.
To many Democrats, the Kodak trip was one more attempt by Mr. Silver to reposition the party and bridge the yawning divide between conservative members from upstate and downstate liberals. Mr. Silver denied such motivations. But he acknowledged that his downstate members were not always sensitive to the needs of big corporations.
"We're expanding their awareness," he said. "We're looking at a different focus."
From Kodak's point of view, the trip was an unusual opportunity to win support for its extensive agenda in Albany, where it already holds significant sway in the New York State Business Council, an influential lobbying group. At a luncheon today in one of Kodak's opulent wood-paneled conference rooms, Daniel A. Carp, the company's president, bluntly told the Assembly members that Kodak wanted the state to further reduce taxes, regulatory burdens and other labor costs, such as unemployment insurance and workers' compensation rates.
"New York continues to be a big-tax state," Mr. Carp told the group. "I encourage you to do all you can on that front."
Kodak paid for the Assembly members' dinner and lunch as well as the parting gifts, which is allowed under state ethics laws because each cost less than $75. The legislators' travel expenses and hotel rooms were paid for by the Assembly.
As might be expected from such a mixing of cultures, the gathering had its share of awkward moments and amusing incongruities. At lunch, Mr. Carp repeatedly praised the lawmakers for having made New York State more attractive to business in recent years by cutting corporate and personal taxes, reducing regulatory requirements and cutting state spending -- not realizing, perhaps, that many Democrats, including a few seated before him, had fought those things tooth and nail.
He also not so subtly praised Mr. Pataki, saying that positive changes in the state "have actually accelerated in the last two years" -- the length of the Governor's tenure.
During a morning of plant tours today, several Assembly members raised questions about Kodak policies, only to have their concerns melt away in the face of amiable answers. Ms. Katz asked a plant manager whether robots were replacing human workers. He answered that Kodak actually had to hire additional workers to maintain the robots. Mr. Englebright fired off numerous questions about Kodak's handling of toxic waste. He liked the responses he got.
"Their pollution inventory process is excellent," he said.
By and large, the encounter was exceedingly polite. No one asked questions about the thousands of layoffs Kodak has made in recent years. Except for Mr. Englebright, no one discussed the company's environmental problems. And while Kodak officials occasionally raised the specter of moving operations out of the state, they tried to sound upbeat about staying in New York.
Mr. Silver himself sounded oddly like Mr. Pataki at times, taking credit for personal income tax cuts that had been promoted mainly by the Governor and occasionally making use of one of the Governor's pet phrases. "We all believe in making New York more business friendly," the Speaker told a group of Kodak executives at a Wednesday night dinner. This morning, he said that growing up around his father's Lower East Side hardware store had given him "an appreciation of business."
But at other times, Mr. Silver, who is considering challenging Mr. Pataki next year, also sounded like someone sounding out potential campaign themes, either for himself or his party.
He chided Mr. Pataki for not doing enough to spur new investment. And whenever Kodak officials expressed worries about the quality of public education, which was quite often, Mr. Silver chimed in with reminders about Democratic proposals to increase spending on public schools, colleges and pre-kindergarten programs. (Mr. Pataki has tried to cut spending on education, and many Democrats think this will be his major vulnerability in 1998).
Some Democrats who did not go on the trip said that Mr. Silver had invited younger members because he wanted people who would not know about Kodak's history of conflicts with the Democrats. Mr. Silver did not disagree with that thesis.
"I chose people who were not set in their ways," he said. "We're trying to break the mold."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Cash to Spare, Giuliani Is Set To Unleash Ad Campaign

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The towering pile of contributions supporting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign has already performed what may have been its paramount task: helping to scare off many of his most formidable contenders, including Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx. Now, as the summer season begins, the Mayor is preparing to open the vault and begin the more prosaic work of winning voters with all that cash.
Over the last three years, Mr. Giuliani has raised $10 million (including $1.25 million in city matching funds) faster and in larger amounts than any other mayor in the city's history. Having spent about $2.5 million already, his campaign still has available more than $2.5 million that it must spend between now and the September primary or give back in accordance with the city's campaign finance rules. After the primary, the Mayor will be able to spend an additional $5 million on the November general election. 
 Campaign aides will not reveal the precise details of their plans, but voters should not be surprised to encounter the first of the Mayor's radio and television advertisements in the next month. Adam Goodman, the campaign's media consultant, has been at work with his film crew since St. Patrick's Day, capturing Mr. Giuliani in a variety of flattering, sunlit settings around the city, and some of the footage is ready to go.
Although the ads surely will relentlessly promote Mr. Giuliani's record fighting crime and improving the city's quality of life, the most intriguing question -- still under debate in the Mayor's inner circle -- is whether to use ads to attack his Democratic opponents, particularly the most likely victor in the primary, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan.
One of the biggest concerns of the Mayor's campaign advisers is how to combat a sense of complacency among his supporters, and it is there that such attack ads can be the most effective. If voters are aware of the Mayor's substantial lead in the polls and see him as cruising toward an easy re-election, they may stay home on Election Day unless they are given a strong reason to fear one of his opponents.
To that end, Mr. Giuliani and his surrogates have with great relish begun to portray Ms. Messinger as an extremist, an anachronistic liberal who is out of touch with every borough but Manhattan. (Ms. Messinger, in turn, has been trying to link the Mayor to the far right wing of the Republican Party.) Further attacks can be expected on her management style during her eight years as Borough President and on her relationships with the "old-fashioned politicians" of the city, to use one of the Mayor's favorite catch phrases.
"This campaign should be about people's records, about their vision, and it should be about leadership qualities," said Fran Reiter, the Mayor's campaign manager. "It's all well and good to say that if elected I will do this or that, but the real issue is, do you have the skills, the management ability, the leadership ability, to in fact make the things you say you want to have happen, happen."
The danger in airing such attacks, of course, is that they could substantially increase Ms. Messinger's name recognition at a time when she remains little known to many voters, particularly outside Manhattan. On the other hand, it could define her in a negative way before voters can learn of her policies and plans. Her aides say they are prepared. "Either way he goes, we're ready for it," said Jim Andrews, the Messinger campaign's political consultant. "He has his cash advantage right now, and my guess is he'll use it."
Ms. Messinger's campaign is not expected to pick up the largest bulk of its fund-raising until about the time of the primary.
Most of the ads, however, will stress Mr. Giuliani's record, seeking to portray him as a Mayor who brought prosperity and tranquillity to a once-troubled city.
Last week, for example, Mr. Goodman's cameraman elbowed reporters aside for a shot of the Mayor at a construction site in downtown Brooklyn, where the borough's first new hotel in decades is rising from the site of an old garage. With cheering workers in hard hats carefully arrayed behind him in the camera shot, Mr. Giuliani accepted the endorsement of several of the city's construction unions, which credited him for the city's current economic upswing. It was not difficult to imagine the commercial that will be fashioned from that moment, although the hotel had less to do with the Mayor than with the decadelong persistence of Borough President Howard Golden.
The Mayor's most powerful weapon will continue to be his increasingly calculated use of ordinary news coverage of his activities and public statements. At least half a dozen television news cameras and all of the city's daily newspapers are regularly present at his daily news conferences, which are now routinely held in settings around the city chosen to make a point about the Mayor's political priorities.
At least once or twice a week, Mr. Giuliani appears with children in an effort to counter his image as a chilly leader perpetually at war with the school or hospital systems. Last week, in announcing that infant mortality rates had fallen to a new low (as they have almost every year this century), the Mayor went to the maternity ward of Metropolitan Hospital to be surrounded by babies and beaming mothers and doctors. The Mayor's rivals may be frustrated by his insistent use of such imagery -- events are sometimes delayed until all the cameras have arrived -- but they are helpless to stop it.
"He cut all that money from education, and now he's turned the schools into a photo studio for his campaign," Mr. Andrews grumbled.
But Mr. Giuliani's aides say that if anything, the public will begin to see even more of the Mayor being "mayoral." He will spend a great deal of time outside Manhattan to contrast himself to Ms. Messinger, stressing issues like closing the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island and beginning free transfers between buses and subways. Although such events are not political, strictly speaking, they constitute the core of the Mayor's campaign to emphasize "the politics of performance," in Mr. Goodman's phrase.
"The best thing the Mayor does is what he does each and every day on the job," Mr. Goodman said. "Whether or not a camera is out there that comes from the campaign, that is something that New Yorkers are seeing each and every day, courtesy of the press and media. So you might say that the most important commercials in the campaign have already begun."

HEADLINE: Unseasonal Treat: Gasoline Prices Stay Low

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
With the needle pointing to empty on his Chevrolet Blazer, Mark Rilley slowed at the Amoco station in Tenafly, N.J., and considered filling up on regular unleaded for $1.149 a gallon.
Cheap as that was, Mr. Rilley was on a tight budget, and he knew gasoline prices had been declining for weeks. So he kept going, and a block later hit pay dirt: Exxon's sign read $1.139. He pulled in and filled up with 23 gallons. His saving: 23 cents. 
 "I shop around," said Mr. Rilley, a painter in his late 20's who drives to jobs across New York and New Jersey, his equipment piled up in the back of his sport utility vehicle. "I'm glad to see it go down."
As millions of Americans hit the highways this Memorial Day weekend, they are getting a break on their gasoline bills. Nationally, the average price for a gallon of regular unleaded gas has dropped 4.5 cents in the last three months, to $1.24. In some parts of the country, the drop has been even more precipitous. At the Exxon station in Tenafly, for example, the price has slid to slightly less than $1.14 from $1.26 in March.
Gasoline prices have dropped even though Americans are expected to do more traveling this summer than ever before.
Moreover, the decline is in sharp contrast to a run-up of almost 18 cents a gallon at the outset of last year's summer vacation season. That surge set off a furor against the oil industry, and gasoline prices became a Congressional campaign issue as well as a target of Congressional investigations.
Nobody is complaining now, though. "This has been a very uneventful season at the gas pump," said Michael Morrissey, a spokesman for the American Automobile Association. The association's latest monthly survey found that prices were 9 cents to 10 cents a gallon lower in May than a year earlier.
Last year was actually more typical; prices generally drift up as people begin making more pleasure trips in the late spring, putting pressure on gasoline supplies.
But this year, the increase in demand has been more than offset by a huge drop in the price of crude oil, the raw material from which gasoline is refined, to $22 a barrel from $28 early this year. Crude oil prices have sagged because production is up in much of the world and because international sanctions against Iraq were eased this year, permitting the export of 700,000 barrels a day.
So, most experts expect the price of crude, and the price of gasoline at the pump, to stay low for the foreseeable future. "We should see flat and maybe lower gasoline prices," said Kevin Lindemer, a senior director at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting group.
That is not to say there will not be upward spikes here and there as temporary shortages develop. Such imbalances are more likely because the industry's inventories of gasoline have slid by 4 percent in the last year, to about 197 million barrels.
That still represents a 24- to 25-day supply, but the shrinking national reserve has made the market for gasoline more skittish. With refineries running close to capacity, users and distributors often react to protect themselves by bidding up prices for future delivery. This week, for example, gasoline for June delivery went up as demand rose and inventories did not build significantly.
Even so, prices tend to move up and down so quickly that the fluctuations have little effect on prices at the pump. "It's unlikely that you are going to see any significant impact on the consumer level," Mr. Lindemer said.
Indeed, the Federal Energy Information Administration, an agency within the Energy Department that tracks prices and supplies, has forecast that this summer gasoline should cost a penny to 2 cents a gallon less than it did last summer, even though consumption is expected to rise by about 1.8 percent, to a record 342 million gallons a day. Gasoline now costs about 8 cents less than last Memorial Day weekend, said Jay Hakes, head of the agency.
The only exception to the trend, he said, is California, where prices are 14 cents a gallon above the national average because the state requires a special gasoline to reduce pollution.
Thus refiners will be under pressure to keep up. The refining industry, however, has become more nimble in switching its mix of products to meet surges of demand. For example, it reacted quickly last winter to build up heating oil inventories.
"I don't see that the capacity to produce gasoline will be tested," said Edward Murphy, an official with the American Petroleum Institute, the industry trade group. Mr. Murphy said he would pile his wife and five children in the family van this weekend and head for parts unknown.
Meanwhile, extra capacity is being added. The Tosco Corporation, which kept a large refinery in Trainer, Pa., closed for a year for a $100 million refurbishing, has reopened it. It is producing 150,000 barrels of gasoline a day.
Last spring, the decision by Tosco to close the refinery thrust it into the center of the political storm over surging prices, with some members of Congress calling for investigations into whether the move was deliberately aimed at making gasoline more expensive. The Department of Energy later concluded that the shutdown had not affected prices.
Adjusted for inflation, gasoline prices are about the same as they were in the 1950's, the golden age of gas guzzlers. And indeed, most Americans pay scant attention to the price per gallon anymore.
At the Exxon station in Tenafly, John F. Kober lifted the hood of his 1988 Mercury Cougar as the car was being filled up and pointed with pride to the 305 cubic-inch V8 engine. "I can't worry about whether it's going to be one cent a gallon more driving this," he said.
Mr. Hakes, the head of the Energy Information Administration, is not so blase.
Though he drives a 1990 Mazda that gets more than 30 miles a gallon, he said, he shops around for the cheapest price. Moreover, he added, "as a public official, I worry about the price of gas."

HEADLINE: For a Suspect in an Officer's Killing, a Long Slide Into Ruin

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
He followed his family into the garment trade but left that business of sequins and velvet in a haze of distrust. He followed his childhood friend into cutthroat stock sales, but long days of cold calls only deepened his debt. When Scott E. Schneiderman finally struck out on his own, the police say, it was with a gun in his hand, cocaine in his blood and a desperate plan to rob his father.
But the designs of Mr. Schneiderman failed once again, the authorities say, this time in abrupt violence and death. In the dark of an early morning last week, he was carried out of his father's Manhattan apartment on a stretcher, just moments after worried police officers had rushed a dying colleague from the same building. Now there lingers the mystery of how a mild-mannered stockbroker came to be charged with murdering a police officer. 
 
The Hitchcockian elements to Mr. Schneiderman's story have puzzled investigators and stunned friends and family. Some say that cocaine may have altered his behavior. Others describe his estrangement from his father in proportions of Greek tragedy. But another telling element is emerging: Mr. Schneiderman was struggling financially -- a circumstance made all the more galling, perhaps, by the affluence of his father and longtime friends.
His father owns a Chelsea penthouse and collects expensive cars and watches. His friends live in exclusive, gated communities on Long Island and vacation in the Hamptons. Scott Schneiderman, meanwhile, often worked on weekends, and lived with his wife and daughter in a rented duplex in Bayside, Queens. Surrounded by the wealth of others, he found himself toiling near the bottom of the stockbrokerage world, chasing elusive commissions.
Mr. Schneiderman, 33, spent the second half of 1996 working for a Long Island concern, making cold calls to strangers and selling himself as a reliable investment consultant. He quit that company in December, leaving behind $5,000 in debts and the impression of a man in the wrong business. Then he tried his skills at a Manhattan firm called D. L. Cromwell Investments; in the two months he worked there, he did not collect a penny in salary, and owed more than $4,000 for incidental expenses.
Lloyd M. Beirne, the company's president, scoffed at the contention of prosecutors that Mr. Schneiderman was making $3,000 a week. "I don't think we have anyone here making $12,000 a month," he said. He added that his now-former employee stood to collect his first paycheck on June 15, for an amount less than $500.
Mr. Schneiderman may have seen an end to his financial straits in the large amounts of cash kept in his father's safe, the police say, which would explain why he donned a mask, packed a .25-caliber Beretta, and broke into the penthouse shortly after midnight last Monday. He botched the robbery, they say, then got into a shootout with Officer Anthony Sanchez, 31, the father of a 6-year-old boy. As the officer lay dying in the stairwell, they say, he took the officer's revolver and fled to hide in the basement, where he was soon found.
Mr. Schneiderman's financial condition now figures in matters beyond motive, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and others call for his execution. The Manhattan District Attorney's office is trying to block his request to be represented by the Capital Defender's Office, which would bear the cost of his defense. The question hinges on one's ability to afford adequate representation and, at this stage, prosecutors say that Mr. Schneiderman was making too much money to be eligible.
Mr. Schneiderman had been among society's anonymous majority: law-abiding, well-liked, a good husband and a doting father. Before the shooting, he had joined a neighborhood barbecue; in the days to come, he was to have attended a Yankees game. Now, as an accused killer of a police officer, he finds himself an outcast.
"I'm destroyed that an old friend of mine is in such trouble," said Andrew Greene, who helped to introduce Mr. Schneiderman to the stockbroker's world. "My heart is bleeding for the officer's family and for my friend's wife and daughter. I couldn't even begin to understand what has happened."
Until Monday, Scott Schneiderman's life was more Lomanesque than violent. He is the second of two sons born to Raphael Schneiderman, a garment-industry executive, and his first wife, Ann. The parents divorced in the mid-1970's; the father married Niki Livas, a fashion designer, while Scott Schneiderman continued to live with his mother and brother, Jeff, in Bay Terrace, Queens.
He graduated in 1981 from Bayside High School, where he was known as a quiet, above-average student. After attending the State University of New York at Stony Brook, he graduated with a bachelor's degree in economics from C.W. Post College in 1986, and immediately joined the family business, Zum Zum Fashions.
The company specializes in evening wear, from cocktail dresses to prom gowns. "What sets them apart from the rest of the market is they're always on the cutting edge," said a garment-industry executive, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "They are first with new fabrics and first with color palettes. And their silhouettes are a little bit more innovative."
The company has earned valuable publicity over the years. In 1996, for example, the winner of the Miss Teen USA pageant won, among other prizes, what was billed as a "wardrobe of exquisite Zum Zum evening gowns, prom and party dresses designed by Niki Livas." And it has received quiet censure; last year, the Government fined the company $50,000 for care labels on garments that led to damage of the material.
At the center of company control is Raphael Schneiderman, a man who, at 59, seems determined to challenge the passage of time. He wears his graying hair in a ponytail, rides motorcycles, almost invariably dresses in black, is again divorced and is now dating a 27-year-old woman. His lawyer describes him as someone who does not often express emotion. Others in the industry describe him as serious, even gruff.
Mr. Schneiderman's older son, Jeff, handles sales and production for the company. His younger son, however, had a more troubled career in the family business. Scott Schneiderman worked for the company for two years, branched out on his own for a year, then returned to the fold in 1990 to manage a company showroom in southern California. But in 1994, his father dismissed him. The police say that the elder Schneiderman suspected his son of stealing. The company's lawyer, Eli Uncyk, said simply: "He was kind of careless. And the decision was made that he shouldn't stay in the business."
Now married to Andrea Silverman and with an infant daughter, Scott Schneiderman found himself with no job and no prospects. But in July 1995, Mr. Greene helped him land a job as a stockbroker with the Lake Success, N.Y., firm that he worked for, Stratton Oakmont Inc. Given that firm's seamy reputation, Mr. Schneiderman received an unfortunate introduction into the world of stocks.
For several years, both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers had tried to shut down Stratton Oakmont for questionable and high-pressured sales practices. The company motto, according to Forbes magazine, was to the point: "Never hang up the phone until the customer buys or dies." While profits were high, so too were the Government fines and millions of dollars in arbitration losses to furious customers, for offenses like unauthorized trading and failing to heed orders to sell.
Mr. Schneiderman left Stratton Oakmont in July, just as the firm was imploding. In the coming months, the N.A.S.D. would expel the firm from the securities industry and levy a $10 million fine against four of its officers, including Mr. Greene, on charges of defrauding an investor. Stratton Oakmont no longer exists.
Despite his experience at the bucket shop known as Stratton Oakmont, Mr. Schneiderman followed Mr. Greene moved down the road in Lake Success to another investment firm, J. B. Sutton Inc. A company official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, described Mr. Schneiderman as so laid back and mild-mannered "that he was almost like a guy in slow motion." The official added: "He did not fit your stereotypical stockbroker profile. He never made a lot of money in this business. This was not his calling in life."
When Mr. Schneiderman left J. B. Sutton in December, he owed the firm more than $5,000 that has not been repaid. But he never shared his financial problems with his wife, associates say. And while he struggled to keep everything together -- with a leased Jeep and a rented apartment -- he is believed by the police to have developed a habit for cocaine.
Two months ago, Mr. Schneiderman tried once more to be a successful stockbroker. He joined D.L. Cromwell, a Florida-based firm that had just opened an office in Manhattan's financial district. But it was not until mid-April that his stockbroker's registration was renewed, allowing him to solicit business.
Mr. Schneiderman would arrive at work at 8:30 in the morning, an hour before the stock market opened, and stay until 8 P.M., well after the market close. He would sit at a desk in a room where shouting is not uncommon and make pleading calls to strangers, all the while monitoring the market as reflected by the green and red lights flashing on his computer monitor. He was working on commission, not salary, and was indebted to the company for the $4,000 it paid to cover his registration fees.
In recent weeks, there had been talk of Mr. Schneiderman relocating to the Boca Raton office one day, and working as a manager for the firm. Mr. Beirne, the firm's president, said that after learning that Mr. Schneiderman's father was a garment-industry executive, the new employee's colleagues all had the same reaction, "All that business is going to get thrown his way." That changed, he said, "when everyone learned that he didn't get along with his dad."
Late last Sunday night, when other stockbrokers were poring over Barron's and preparing themselves for the Monday opening of the market, Mr. Schneiderman left Bayside in his leased Jeep. In addition to a gun, a ski mask and duct tape, he took some cocaine, the police say, some of which he used. Then, they say, he committed an armed robbery against his father, and killed a police officer coming to his father's aid.
No one in the Schneiderman family would comment on their relative, who is being kept on a suicide watch in jail. But his father attended the wake of Officer Sanchez on Long Island last week and told his widow that he would pay the college tuition of the Sanchez boy.

HEADLINE: Report Oversells Immigration's Meager Benefits

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Anyone who reads beyond the first two paragraphs of "Academy's Report Says Immigration Benefits the U.S." (front page, May 18) has to wonder, What benefits? 
 The alleged benefit appears to be a $10 billion annual increase in gross national product in a $7 trillion economy. That is a one-seventh of 1 percent increase. The cost of that minimal boost is massive population growth, loss of wages among less-skilled Americans, an increase in the high school dropout rate, exacerbation of the wealth gap and substantial tax burdens for state and local governments. Is it really worth it?
The other alleged benefit, according to the academy, is that immigrants will pay for the retirement of baby boomers. Low-wage immigrants, who are heavily dependent on social services, will finance the retirement of affluent retirees?
The academy overlooks another obvious fact: Immigrants get old, too. Within a few years of the baby boomers' retirement, we'll have to figure out how to pay for Social Security for a lot of elderly immigrants.
A better headline for this article might have been "Academy's Report Says Immigration Benefits Some in the U.S., at Great Expense to Most."
 
DAN STEIN
Exec. Dir., Federation
for American Immigration Reform
Washington, May 19, 1997

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 302 words

HEADLINE: Report Oversells Immigration's Meager Benefits;
Help Workers Compete

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In your May 18 front-page article on the National Academy of Sciences immigration report, James P. Smith, who led the study, is quoted as saying that though native-born Americans without a high school education have seen their wages fall slightly, the vast majority of Americans are enjoying a healthier economy. The 1990 Census found that 44 million Americans (about 25 percent of the adult population at that time) did not have a high school degree. 
 Mr. Smith may be right about the vast majority, but a very significant portion of our adult population has seen wages decline over 15 years.
The solution is not controls on immigration but opportunities for adults to improve basic skills, pass the high school equivalency exam and enter skill training or community college. Unfortunately, all of the Federal, state, local and private money available for these programs is less than $1 billion per year, or $23 per person without a high school degree. If we add to the 44 million those Americans with a high school degree but literacy skills below a ninth-grade level, the per-person expenditure drops to less than $15.
We are becoming a country of two populations -- one with the education to compete in the global market for good wages and benefits, and the other whose education leaves them competing against recent immigrants and workers in low-wage countries. This is unacceptable to decent people and dangerous for our national future.
We cannot increase wages with tax cuts that produce more low-wage jobs, but we can do it with investments in the education of both our native-born and immigrant work force.
 
JOHN P. COMINGS
Cambridge Mass., May 19, 1997
 
The writer is director of the National Center for the Study of Adult Learning and Literacy at Harvard.

HEADLINE: Esther Goldfrank, 100, Dies; Studied Pueblos in Southwest

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
Esther Goldfrank, an accidental anthropologist who did pioneering research among the Pueblo Indians of the Southwest in the 1920's and churned out papers on the experience for the next half-century, died on April 23 at a nursing home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. She was 100.
As a Barnard economics major whose sole exposure to anthropology had been an introductory course during her senior year, Miss Goldfrank, a Manhattan native whose maiden name was Schiff, would hardly seem to have had the credentials to go sashaying off to New Mexico at the age of 24 as a front-line scientific investigator. 
 But she had received a B in the course, and apparently had made an impression on the professor. A year after her graduation in 1918, she was holding down a stifling job on Wall Street when she got a note asking if she would like to be his secretary.
Within months, she was in the field with the man she and a generation of other young female protegees called Papa Franz and the world knew as Franz Boas, the German-born social scientist widely recognized as the father of American anthropology and the mentor of such giants as Margaret Mead and Ruth Benedict.
For all his stature, Boas was a figure of some controversy within the anthropology community.
Among other things, he played down the fledgling field's emphasis on biology and concentrated on studying the cultural variations of disparate societies, each of which, he maintained, was as valid and valuable as any other.
Although he had laid the foundations for cultural anthropology through his work with Eskimos in the 1880's and later with the Kwakiutl and other Indians of the Pacific Northwest, Boas was persuaded to turn his attention to the Southwest in the early 1920's by his patron, the redoubtable Elsie Clews Parsons, the wealthy, Barnard-trained social worker who had become a force in anthropology after becoming enchanted with the Pueblo Indians of New Mexico.
It was she who financed the Boas expeditions and paid Miss Goldfrank's salary, but Miss Goldfrank did not remain a secretary long. Almost immediately she expanded her duties to include interviewing Pueblo residents and painstakingly recording the meticulous observations of behavior that was the hallmark of the celebrated Boas methodology.
Miss Goldfrank concentrated initially on kinship, the mundane study of things like what one calls one's mother and who is considered a brother, which was the anthropological rage of the day.
She inadvertently broadened the scope of her scholarship and enriched the field of anthropology when she met a woman at a well and was invited to her home in the Cochiti Pueblo.
The woman was Carolyn Quintana, the daughter of a legendary Conchiti storyteller, and Miss Goldfrank was so enthralled with her detailed and vivid descriptions of the minutiae of Conchiti culture that she moved into the Pueblo and began taking notes.
Among the results were a stream of papers, including a 1927 monograph, "The Social and Ceremonial Organization of Conchiti."
Miss Goldfrank did most of her field work from 1920 to 1922, the year she married Walter S. Goldfrank, a Manhattan businessman and widower with three young sons. Except for a brief return visit to New Mexico in 1924, partly to alleviate postpartum depression after the birth of a daughter, Miss Goldfrank spent most of the next two decades as a homemaker and mother in White Plains, although an unusually prolific one who kept the typewriter clacking.
After the death of her husband in 1935, Miss Goldfrank moved back to Manhattan and made one more important field trip, this this time to Alberta, Canada, which led to other papers, including a 1945 monograph, "Changing Configurations in the Social Organization of a Blackfoot Tribe During the Reserve Period."
By then her 1940 marriage to Karl A. Wittfogel, a social scientist and former Communist, had altered the focus of her scholarship. Mr. Wittfogel had worked in China in developing his celebrated theory that the construction and control of irrigation canals had concentrated the power of ruling elites and spawned despotism, and Miss Goldfrank joined the staff of his short-lived China project at Columbia and applied his theories in her own continuing writings on Indians.
Miss Goldfrank published her memoirs privately in 1978. She titled the book "Notes on an Undirected Life."
Miss Goldfrank, whose second husband died in 1988, is survived by a daughter, Susan Lenhoff of Israel; a stepson, Thomas Goldfrank of Mamaroneck; 6 step-grandchildren, and 12 step-great-grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 1997, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Esther Goldfrank, an anthropologist who studied the Pueblo Indians, included an incorrect reference to the publication of her memoirs, "Notes on an Undirected Life," in 1978. They were published by the Queens College Press; they were not published privately.

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Roundabout Tour of Southwest Glories

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
AROUND the turn of the century, when few people visited or even knew about remote natural wonders in the southwest like Zion Canyon, regional boosters came up with a slogan to attract tourists: "See Europe if you will but see America first."
In early April, I took them up on the idea by driving from Phoenix to Los Angeles, normally a straight shot of 369 miles on Interstate 10, taking about six hours. But I made it in eight days and 1,670 miles -- striking north from Phoenix to Flagstaff; circling east into the Navajo and Hopi reservations; cutting across the Arizona Strip (the isolated area north of the Grand Canyon, to Utah), and then wandering west over the deserts of Nevada and California. Most of the way I stayed on secondary highways so thronged by astonishing sights that to call them scenic is to drastically understate. 
 Generally, I had warm days and frosty nights and the great, uplifted area around the Grand Canyon, known as the Colorado Plateau, to myself. I got a little lonesome sometimes -- though being alone made the trip seem like a great adventure. And all along the way, I met Europeans -- like a French tour group, full of oo la la's for the Painted Desert, and a lone Italian woman who pulled in next to me at an overlook above Navajo Bridge near Lee's Ferry, Ariz. In evident scenery shock, she got out of her car, took off her sunglasses, and said, "I don't know why anyone goes to Brooklyn and those places."
I could ask myself almost the same question. I'd seen the Grand Canal of China, but why had it taken me so long to visit the deserts and canyons of the American Southwest?
Maybe I'd been waiting for just the right deal, which I found in a See America package, designed to help Avis Rent a Car System reposition a surfeit of automobiles left in Arizona and Florida by one-way renters. The package offers travelers extremely attractive incentives to drive the cars to California or the Pacific Northwest from Arizona, and to the Northeast or Midwest from Florida, with no drop-off charge, unlimited miles, trip protection insurance (including a primary collision damage waiver), eight-day car rental, seven nights' accommodation in chain motels, a customized itinerary, 10-minute long-distance phone card and one-way air fare to or from the departure city.
For instance, if you're in Los Angeles you get air fare to Phoenix so you can drive home; if you start out in Phoenix, you get a return plane ticket from Los Angeles; or if your plans are somewhat more complicated, as mine were, you get a $100 credit toward a flight booked by Preferred Holidays, the travel service handling the See America package.
The basic price from Arizona to California was $299 a person, double occupancy, or $523 for solo travelers like me (though while I was away, rates dropped even lower, and new options were added, like a package for one-way car rental only, at $6.99 a day). When I explained to the agent at Preferred Holidays that I needed a plane ticket from New York to Phoenix, with a return from Los Angeles, she got me a round-trip ticket on USAirways for an amazing $268. With the $100 See America airfare credit, the total package price came to $666.
With so much country to see, I set about plotting the perfect route, using a map and a booklet that Preferred Holidays sent me with state-by-state listings of the Howard Johnson, Days Inn, Ramada, Super 8 and Travelodge motels where I could book rooms. Unfortunately, most of them were in relatively large towns like Flagstaff, Ariz., and St. George, Utah, some distance from a number of the places I wanted to visit -- which is why I had to cross Monument Valley off my list. But I couldn't bear to miss the Anasazi ruins in Canyon de Chelly (pronounced shay), the Colorado River at Lee's Ferry, and all the topographical marvels of the lonely Arizona Strip.
Nor did I simply want to drive by places like these. I needed time to get out of the car, hike, explore and picnic.
To do all this, I booked an extra night at Marble Canyon Lodge near Lee's Ferry, which I paid for apart from the package -- $45 for a small double, with a patio facing the Vermilion Cliffs. The rest of the time, I reserved rooms in participating motels: a Ramada in Flagstaff; a Days Inn in Holbrook, Ariz. (about 130 miles southwest of Canyon de Chelly); two nights in another Days Inn in St. George (45 miles south of Zion National Park); a Howard Johnson's in Las Vegas; Days Suites in Victorville, Calif. (about 175 miles south of Death Valley), and the Ramada Plaza Hotel LAX South in Los Angeles.
"Who ever heard the returning traveler exclaim over one of the great motels of the world he stayed in?" William Least Heat Moon says in "Blue Highways." Still, I found clean, reasonably comfortable rooms in all the chain motels, though the Days Inns were most consistently attractive. And the Ramada in Los Angeles was downright lovely, with a sheltered swimming pool, fountain and patio, and a rack rate of $109 to $139.
Early on, I discovered that each motel voucher was actually worth $42, and that the prices for highway accommodations in the southwest are amazingly low, averaging around $35 a night. A motel I passed in Mesquite, Nev., took the record, though, with a nightly rate of $11.99.
Meals were somewhat more expensive. I ate my share of Big Macs, and found two good steakhouses, Black Bart's in Flagstaff, where I was able to order an excellent burger off the children's menu for $5.25, and the Butterfield Stage Company on old Route 66 in Holbrook, with barbecued chicken and unlimited trips to the salad bar for $9.95.
The very best road food I sampled was a Navajo fry bread taco at the Tuba City Truck Stop Cafe, about an hour south of Lee's Ferry, for $6.20. But my favorite meals were picnic lunches made from provisions I kept in a little cooler I bought before leaving Phoenix (for $14). Cold cuts, cheese, fruit, granola bars and juice were rendered delectable by beautiful scenery.
In the Avis lot at Phoenix's Sky Harbor International Airport, I checked to make sure that my economy class Pontiac Sunfire with California plates had a spare tire and manual. I'd planned the trip so that I could visit at least one site every day, without having to drive more than 350 miles between sunrise and sunset. I started right there in Phoenix at the Heard Museum of Native American Art and Culture (admission $6), a graceful Spanish colonial-style building near downtown. Among other things, it has a wonderful collection of kachina dolls (collected by Senator Barry M. Goldwater and the Fred Harvey Company), representing the spirit world of the Hopi and Navajo people.
Then I drove 130 miles north to Flagstaff on I-17 -- surprisingly fast, since that very day, the speed limit had been raised from 65 to 75 miles per hour. Along the way, the elevation rose, too, from about 1,000 feet above sea level in Phoenix to 7,000 feet in chilly Flagstaff, huddled up against the snowcapped San Francisco Mountains. Technically, I was climbing to the Colorado Plateau, and I found it thrilling because there, in the words of John McPhee, lie North America's "geologic operas" -- its Grand, Zion, Bryce, Paria and Marble Canyons, mountains, mesas, and endless rows of cliffs with names like Echo, Grand Wash, and Hurricane.
The rather austere Ramada Limited on Lucky Lane in Flagstaff was so close to I-40 that I fell asleep to the drone of traffic. But I was up with the sun the next morning -- literally, because first thing, I visited the Lowell Observatory atop Mars Hill just west of downtown (admission $3), where I got to look through a special telescope at the sun. It showed up as a calm red disk even though it shines every second as brightly as 4.5 billion 20-megaton hydrogen bombs.
Fortunately, it was still high in the sky when I reached Holbrook, about 90 miles east of Flagstaff via I-40, which parallels old Route 66 and the railroad tracks. So I had plenty of time to buy groceries (for about $17), check into a nice Days Inn, and then head 30 more miles east to the Petrified Forest National Park (admission $10 per car). There, I toured the remains of a swamp that covered the region 225 million years ago, when, scientists say, Arizona was about where Panama is today, and picnicked on a petrified log, shot through with amethyst and jasper. At the north side of the park, there are viewpoints for the Painted Desert -- a region of carbuncled badlands decorated for spring with sprays of evening primrose and snowball sand verbena.
I went to bed at 9 and left Holbrook the next morning at 5, headed about 130 miles to Canyon de Chelly National Monument, a three-branched system of twisting gorges 200 to 1,000 feet high cut by streams that rise in the Chuska Mountains to the northeast. Between 350 and 1300 A.D, the mysterious, height-defying Anasazi people settled into masonry apartments carved into the sides of the red sandstone cliffs, with ladders for access to the canyon lip. Today, the ruins of their pueblos remain, while Navajo farmers raise corn and peaches in the bottomlands, lined by cottonwood trees and patches of quicksand.
I know about the quicksand because I arrived at the canyon visitors center near the town of Chinle just in time to join a group hike led by a Navajo guide named Hank Tsosie ($10), who wore his long lustrous black hair in a ponytail and is a member of the Coyote Pass and Two Rivers Running Together clans. We entered the canyon on the trail to the split-level White House Ruin (occupied from 1040 to 1275), listened intently as Hank told us about the healing properties of snakeweed, and reached canyon bottom as a beautiful Navajo woman was letting her goats out to pasture. Then we rolled up our jeans and doffed hiking boots to walk downstream in the cold river, wading through shallow water and benign quicksand (into which we sometimes sank to our thighs). A beautiful slog, altogether, though longer than I'd planned.
INDEED, it was midafternoon by the time I hit the highway again to drive one of the longer segments of the trip, about 200 miles from Canyon de Chelly across the three great mesas of the Hopi Reservation to Tuba City, which sits astride the Echo Cliffs. There, I turned north on Highway 89 -- the route of Mormon pioneers sent in the late 1800's to colonize a country even more unforgiving than the Great Salt Lake. My breath stuck in my chest when I reached 467-foot Navajo Bridge on Highway 89A, built in 1928 (but superseded by a new bridge just downstream, finished in 1995). Set against the emerald green Colorado River at mile zero of the Grand Canyon, it glints like Navajo silver, crafted on a grand scale.
I had a cozy overnight at the Marble Canyon Lodge, a nice run the next morning to Lee's Ferry, which was one of the principal Colorado River crossings before the construction of the bridge, and then another invigorating drive 200 miles west across the Arizona Strip, passing the northern entrance to the Grand Canyon National Park (still closed for winter at the time of my visit). I saw the woody, snow-patched Kaibab Plateau; Shinarump Cliffs; Mount Trumbull far to the south, and Pipe Springs, where the Colorado Plateau surveyer, John Wesley Powell, stopped. Then just before St. George, Utah, I spied the 2,000- to 3,000-foot walls of Zion Canyon -- only I didn't realize what they were.
I figured it out the next day when I drove to Zion ($10 to enter) from my Days Inn in St. George. There, I asked a ranger at the visitors center just north of Springdale, Utah, how the canyon carved by the North Fork of the Virgin River differs from the Grand. "It's younger," he said.
It's also not as wide, and you can drive along canyon bottom almost to the point where the scary narrows begin. But I hiked up to the lip at 6,508-foot Observation Point, an eight-mile round trip, passing at least 10 varieties of wildflowers.
I visited Zion on a perfectly blue-skied Saturday. Over the next three days, I strolled the Strip in Las Vegas with a nice couple from New Jersey whom I met at the $7.95 buffet in the MGM Grand, where I ate much too much prime rib and stuffed crab; drove hot lonely miles across Death Valley, and then cruised into the smog pocket lodged atop Los Angeles. But nothing topped Zion. I should have stayed there for seven nights. I should have seen Bryce, Cedar Breaks and Capitol Reef.
It is some consolation to tell myself that I did the broad survey version of the American Southwest. Next time, I'll go back and specialize. It's unparalleled country.
 
Bottom line
 
The Basics
Besides the cost of the See America package, I spent $215 on food, admissions and an extra night at Marble Canyon Lodge, and $75 on gas.
Information on the See America package, which lasts until June 30 (travel must begin by June 20), is available from Preferred Holidays, (800) 508-5454. The package from Florida to the Midwest or Northeast costs $300 a person, double occupany, and the package for Arizona departures (with drop-offs in California, Portland, Ore., and Seattle) starts at $250 a person, double occupancy. Other options include four-day car rental and lodgings only for $99.50 a person, double occupancy, and one-way car rental only, $6.99 a day.
Preferred booked my flights on USAirways (800) 842-5374: New York to Phoenix, and then Los Angeles to New York, for $268 total.
For most of my trip, the Indian Country Map by the Automobile Club of Southern California -- and state maps of Arizona, Utah, Nevada and California -- guided me. The best book I know on the Colorado Plateau is "Land of Living Rock" by C. Gregory Crampton, and Robery L. Casey's "Journey to the High Southwest" is an excellent resource for the Four Corners area.

PUB-DATE: May 25, 1997,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 27; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4169 words

HEADLINE: John Sexton Pleads (and Pleads and Pleads) His Case

BYLINE: By James Traub 

 BODY:
People who choose the intellectual life tend to maintain a bemused, even disdainful distance from the hyperbolic enthusiasm and salesmanship that constitute so much of the workaday world. This is one reason that academic institutions have so much trouble finding strong leaders. John Sexton, a theologian and an expert in civil procedure, has been dean of New York University Law School since 1988. It's safe to say that almost all of Sexton's colleagues are grateful that he is able to conduct himself in a way that they themselves would find unthinkable. 
 Earlier this year, I accompanied Sexton to Chicago, wher ehe was to address a lunch for local alumni, applicants who had been admitted to N.Y.U. Law but had not yet decided whether to attend and Federal judges, who had been invited strictly for decoration. The luncheon was held in the Cite restaurant atop the 70story Lake Point Tower, where the decor runs to mirrors, ornate chandeliers, and ceiling-height windows that let in the sunshine dancing off Lake Michigan.
Sexton moved to the lectern. "You've got to remember that this is a family affair," he said. Sexton, who is 54 and married and has two children, tends to use "family" metaphorically to refer tot he sanctified community at N.Y.U. Law School that he is forever marshaling and ministering to. But he also had a real family in mind - Victoria Gouletas, class of '99; her dad, Nicholas, who was the developer of Lake Point Tower and was paying for the event, and a whole tableful of Gouletases.
Earlier that morning, Sexton had asked Nick for a $1.5 million contribution to the law school, demonstrating his love for Nick's natal place by reciting the opening lines of "The Odyssey" in Greek; Gouletas had not been noticeably moved. Now Victoria and her dad were seated at the dais. Sexton, who is metabolically incapable of deliverying a speech from behind a lectern, walked over to Victoria, placed a hand on her head and told a story demonstrating the young woman's public-spiritedness. "If my daughtah Katie grows up like her," he said in his scrupulously preserved Brooklynese, "done deal." Victoria squirmed.
"Secondly," Sexton boomed, "we have a grandmother in the room! And grandmothers are responsible for it all. So we should give a round of applause to Grandma Maria for giving us such a great family." Grandma Maria, the Gouletas matriarch, was dressed in black, her hair pullled back tight. Sexton walked to her table, got down on his knees, but his arms around her neck and gave her a kiss. Maria Gouletas, her eyes shining, tipped up her face to receive it.
It is possible, of course, that a perfect cynic, a Music Man, could get away with this sort of thing. But Sexton is not a cynic. Like all truly great salesmen, he makes you believe his own line because he believes his own line because he believes it, too.
It is possible, of course, that a perfect cynic, a Music Man, could get away with this sort of thing. But Sexton is not a cynic. Like all truly great salesmen, he makes you believe his won line because he believes it, too.
After disentangling himself from Grandma Maria, he told his audience that N.Y.U. was "the finest law school in the world." Even Sexton may not have believed that. He was speaking in what he calls his "aspirational" mode. He also said, "Sixteen senior people who were recognized as the leaders in their field have left Harvard, Yale, Chicago, Stanford and Michigan to come to us since 1990." This is very close to the truth. As for the students, he said: "If you're next to any of them, take their autograph. The only two schools that one the objective criteria were stronger at the median than us were Yale and Stanford." This factoid requires so many footnotes as to be almost meaningless, but there's no question that the law school under Sexton's leadership has markedly improved the quality of its students body.
During Sexton's nine-year tenure, N.Y.U. has gone from being a very good law school to being a premier law school. "There is no school that has made the quantum leap in terms of development across the board that N.Y.U. has," says Arthur Miller, Harvard's legendary professor of civil procedure. "And in terms of the development of a law school, John Sexton is the greatest dean in the United States."
JOHN SEXTON WOULD BE THE FIRST TO SAY that he is not wholly responsible for N.Y.U.'s rise, though wehter this is genuine modesty or simple caution is impossible to know. N.Y.U. Law School was a humble institution located on two floors of a Greenwich Village office building when Arhtur T. Vanderbilt became dean in 1943. Vanderbilt created a scholarship program to draw bright students from around the country, and between the money that he raised and the real-estate deals that he forged, the law school was able to build Vanderbilt Hall, the brick, would-be-Ivy League structure that sits on Washington Square South and continues to house most of the law school's offices and classrooms.
Vanderbilt also had the inspired idea of buying the Mueller Macaroni Company, which supplied the school with a steady source of income. When the trustees sold the company in 1977, N.Y.U. became of the nation's richest law schools overnight. Norman Redlich, who became dean in 1975, went on a building spree that eventually added two dormitories, a vastly expanded library and a renovated building to house the school's clinical program. By the mid-80's, N.Y.U. was a nationally recognized law school, known for turning out tax lawyers for the big New York firms and dedicated advocates for Legal Aid and the A.C.L.U.
In the great law-school pecking order, though, it fell well below Columbia, its uptown rival, and it was not considered hospitable to the kind of theoretical inquiry then sweeping the lawschool world. "There was a sense that being an intellectual was elitist," says Lawrence Sager, a constitutional-law professor at N.Y.U.
When Redlich announced that he was stepping down, Sexton, then a recently tenured professor, was the candidate of the theoreticians. His academic pedigree was impeccable: Harvard Law, Law Review and clerkships with Appeals Court Judge David Bazelon and Chief Justice Warren Burger. But Sexton was not a prominent scholar, and he was not distinguished only or even primarily by his credentials. He had a priestly way about him, with a hand on the arm and an ear always ready for confession. He loved the law school as if it were the Mother Church. But he was also worldly; he talked like a ward heeler, knew everyone's name and understood the importance of alliances. It was a gift he came by naturally: his grandfather had led the Jefferson Democratic Club in Brooklyn and was Jimmy Walker's Tax Commissioner; his father had been a Brooklyn lawyer, a frequenter of taverns and also a leader of the Jeffersons.
Sexton's skill as a political operator and his extravagant charm made some of his colleagues uneasy. They wondered, as Lawrence Sager says, whether Sexton was truly artless or whether he had in fact constructed an "extraordinarily elaborate public persona." Sager says he's still not sure. And then there was the issue of ambition. "He always struck people as a young man in a hurry," faculty member says.
But there was a good argument to be made that a young man in a hurry was exactly what the law school needed. Sexton and the people around him believed that N.Y.U. Law had to become the kind of school that atttracted talented scholars. When he became dean, Sexton preached fervently about a new kind of law school in which a model of "engagement" would replace the model of "independent contractor." He offered young people the chance to join "the Enterprise" - the term he coined for a community of like-minded souls that at the time existed only in his imagination.
Sexton promised a skeptical junior faculty that he would bring in top "lateral" - scholars who were thinking about leaving other schools. And then he did it. In 1991, Lea Brilmayer, a recognized star in the field of international juris-prudence, left Yale for N.Y.U.; the next year, Richard Stewart, a figure of equal prominence in environmental law and a former professor at Harvard, accepted a position at the law school. In recent years, four major figures have left the University of Chicago for N.Y.U.
One afternoon not long ago, as Sexton was sitting in his office, sketching out his vision for the first few years of the next millennium, a call came in. Sexton said, "No, put it throught." He wanted me to hear this "Is this Al Sykes, N.Y.U. professah?" The faculty had just extended an offer to Sykes, an expert in international law at Chicago. Sexton had a huge grin on his face. "It is part of the dream to have you come here. ... Make a list of anything that's on your mind that I can help with. The way we will work this process is I will ask you to be the recording secretary for our conversations. And at the end, when I'm getting ready to send you a formal appointment letter, I'm going to ask you to give me a memo incorporating what we discussed, in your words, suitable for including in the letter from me to you. Your job is to tell me what will make it work for you, and my job is to make it happen if it is all within my power. We are not in a negotiating situation here. I don't think we've ever disappointed anybody. We love you here."
How can you say no to a man who wants for you only what you want for yourself?
JOHN SEXTON GREW UP IN A MTHIC PLACE and time - the beachfront community of Belle Harbor, on the Brooklyn-Queens broder, in the 1950's. He was raised in the true faith, which is to say that he believed devoutly in the Dodgers, the nuns and the Democratic Party. By age 11, Sexton was the big noise of Belle Harbor, an operator of world-class potential. One day, he recalls, he was playing stoop ball "and Mrs. Janowitz comes down the street pushing a baby carriage with two beach chairs and an umbrella. And I said: 'Mrs. Janowitz, why don't you keep your things in my parents' garage? I'll put them out on the beach in the spot where you like them, and I'll charge you $10 for the chair and $5 for the umbrella.' " Soon he had jurisdiction over 144 chairs and 70 umbrellas. "Then I recruited these two 10-year-olds to carry the stuff out on a stretcher, and I stood there like Rommel. This was 1953. A first-year associate at Cravath was earning $2,500. I cleared $3,000 during the summer."
At Brooklyn Prep, Sexton became a national debate champion, which is to say that he was not only very smart but also ferociously competitive. But rather than continuing with debate when he enrolled at Fordham College, he approached the nuns who ran St. Brendan's, the girls' parochial school in Brooklyn that his younger sister attended, and asked if he could start a debate program there. Sexton himself can't explain this bizarre desision. Perhaps he recognized that he could accomplish greater things as a coach than as a player.
Competing in an almost entirely male world, St. Brendan's won two national championships in Sexton's first five years and was always near the top during his 15 years as coach - despite the fact that he was working with girls who might not have attended college at all were it not for his intervention. Sexton was the Knute Rockne of debate. Despite his competitive zeal, though, St. Brendan's was the forerunner of his communitarian Enterprise. "It was a Communist society," Sexton says. "It was a hundred hours a week during the school year, and it wasn't just debate. We would go to 40 museums a year. We read the great books. And then we traveled for five weeks during the summer." Sexton got the girls scholarships and kept up with them, and even married one of them; the marriage lasted three years and ended in annulment.
While serving as the unpaid coach of the debate team, Sexton graduated from Fordham, wnet on for a doctorate in theology, maintained a full-time job teaching religion at a small Catholic college in Brooklyn and established a lucrative L.S.A.T.-prep course to raise funds for St. Brendan's and other penniless debate teams. He might well have spent his life as the Mr. Chips of Brooklyn, but in 1974 he applied to law school and accepted at Harvard after Laurence Tribe, an old friend from his debating days, intervened. Sexton found that he was very good at the law and that he loved law school. It took him less than a decade to go from Harvard graduated to N.Y.U. dean.
SEXTON IS ONE OF THE FEW LAW-SCHOOL deans who teach first-year classes. He insists that students call him John and makes himself available for ministering 24 hours a day. One of the first times I went to his office I found him sitting with two students, Greg Schmolka and Lainie Batoff. Sexton turned to me and explained, "There's a tradition that every year one couple gets formed in my civil-procedure class who get married." Schmolka and Batoff were tending in that direction. "The funny thing is," Sexton said to Schmolka, "the first semester I had you involved with Kim Gantcher. I mean, you were sitting next to her every day."
"We were friends from high school."
"It was a false signal." Sexton then asked them, as he asks every student, to name one thing they would do to make the school better. They were stuck. Sexton, in turn, lavished praise on them. Schmolka needed some bucking up; he hadn't got a clerkship he had been hoping for in California. Sexton said that it was for the best, because he didn't want the two of them spending the summer on separate coasts. Schmolka and Batoff saw the point. There would be further counseling.
More students came in; everyone agreed that Columbia, unlike N.Y.U., was tense and competitive and not fun. Sexton was spinning around in his chair, his palms under his thighs. His black loafers were going tap, tap, tap. He was feeding on the students, and they on him.
Sexton is the living embodiment of the idea of "engagement." It's his own example that give substance to what might otherwise be a sappy idea. N.Y.U. is well known in the law-school world as a genuinely collegial place, where young faculty members needn't fear being shot down and factionalism is frowned upon. It is also a place where teachers are expected to take their pastorla responsibilities seriously. Frank Upham, one of Sexton's early recruits, says, "I wanted to come to a place where if you kept your door open and talked to students, you weren't considered weak."
At the same time, N.Y.U. seems to be in no danger of becoming too nice for its own good. The big New York firms that are the school's principal end-users aparrently can live with the Enterprise, since the average starting salary for last year's N.Y.U. graduates was $85,000, the highest figure in the country. Indeed, there is an underlying tension at the school between the desire for distinctness and the desire for competitve success. Among the elite law schools, N.Y.U. still has by far the most extensive clinical-law program, which teaches practical legal skills, but Anthony Amsterdam, founder and director of the program, worries that this may be changing as a result of Sexton's having bought into the "star system" that now rules legal education. "N.Y.U. can't be all things to all people," Amsterdam says. "I would look for ways to focus on the traditional strengths of N.Y.U. and attract the kind of student who would come here to learn to be a great litigator."
Sexton sees N.Y.U. in quite different terms. In 1993, he and several colleagues, and then alumni, began developing a Global Law program, which perfectly suits Sexton sense of law's larger purposes as well as his grandiose vision for N.Y.U. "Globalization" was in the air; the new program would confirm N.Y.U.'s status as a leadership school. It would be the first school to move beyond the traditional study of comparative international law to systematically examine transnational legal issues.
The alumni loved the idea. Sexton got a $5 million gift to give a dozen or so full scholarships a year to foreign students who already have law degrees. He was able to attract many of the world's leading English-speaking foreign legal scholars, partly because he was paying them good money to teach a seven-week course before their own semesters started. Things got gidy enough that Sexton seriously contemplated opening an N.Y.U.-supervised law school in Beiging. That didn't happen, but an arrangement with George Soro's Central European University, in Budapest, is looking increasingly likely.
Many faculty members consider "globalization" a meaningless buzzword and chalk up the project to Sextonian empire-building. One detractor at another law school describes the program as "a set of no-compete agreements with various foreign legal academics." Others see it as a masterful act of positioning. Lenoard Strickdean, the University of Arkansas law-school dean who headed the American Bar Association's accreditation team for N.Y.U., has some doubts about the actual depth of the program but says of Sexton, "His seizing the idea, his embellishment of it and his ability to sell it have created an extraordinary kind of meteor of achievement and enthusiasm."
Most deans consider fund-raising a necessary evil; John Sexton, shameless on behalf of his beloved institution, relishes the job. Sexton understood that the only way to finance the ambitious expansion of the faculty he envisioned was to substantially increase the endownment. Soon after he became dean, he convened a 50-member alumni body, brought them to the campus four times a year and ardently preache dthe virtues of the Enterprise. Martin Lipton, the chairman of N.Y.U. Law's board of trustees, says: "We had been trying for years to develop a national alumni network, and we were singularly unsuccessful. Three years after John Sexton became dean, we had a national network."
People who hadn't set foot in the school in 20 years started giving serious money. And Lipton himself made an earnest profession of faith when he announced that his firm, Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz - a bunch of N.Y.U. kids who had made very, very good - was donating $5 million to the school. Sexton is very aspirational on fund-raising. When consultants suggested a $40 million capital campaign, he countered with $75 million. After a series of upward adjustments, the official target is now $175 million, though Sexton is counting on $200 million.
"You talk to John Sexton and you think that almost anything is possible," says Al Engelberg, a patent lawyer who gave $5 million to establish the Center on Innovation in a Global Economy in on Innovation in a Global Economy in 1994. Last year, Sexton solicited a $5 million gift from an anonymous donor to give free tuition to students who choose to go into low-paying fields.
Sexton dreams of creating the first tuition-free law school. The idea is that graduates start paying money into a tution pool once they have started earning the big bucks. Sexton says he needs only $100 million or so to get the idea off the ground; he has already asked the same anonymous donor for a $50 million matching gift. He's sure that whoever eliminates tuition first will transform legal education. And who's to say he's wrong?
Last year, Sexton has a bolt of insight: somebody was going to give a $100 million gift to a law school. That law school had to be N.Y.U. The fact of the gift was almost more important than the use to which it would be put. By the time I met Sexton, he was scaling back, for the moment, to %50 million or even $20 million, which would still constitute the largest gift ever given to a law school. He had romanced a young donor, who was thinking seriously about the 50. He had the 20 virtually in hand, but it wasn't quite ripe for announcement. Another donor was serious at 10. And he had this fantasy about a five-year, $200 million gift from a major philanthropist, though the philanthropist didn't know about it yet. He had the whole thing written out on index cards. He saw an almost harmonic convergence of interests. Wouldn't just a little piece be enough? No way, Sexton said. "It only works if you do the whole thing."
Sexton has never lost his maniacally competitive edge - he has just placed it in the service of increasingly refined causes. When he talks about N.Y.U.'s competitors, the parish-priest manner drops away. Columbia he says, is "yesterday's war." As for Chicago, "We've sucked them dry." When I told Sexton that I would be talking with Columbia's dean, David Leebron, a rival dating back to Harvard days, he had two faculty members do some research, and they came up with a half-dozen cases in which N.Y.U. had beat out Columbia for a prized lateral. Leebron bristled at the list, insisting that his school had taken a serious run at only one of the six. When I brought that back to Sexton, he exploded.
"They would have given a digit for Larry kramer!" he fumed. It is, in fact, widely believed in the law-school world that N.Y.U. has eaten Columbia's lunch on faculty hires. Sexton also insists that N.Y.U. attracts better students than Columbia and that most students who get into both go to N.Y.U. Leebron says it's the other way around. Here the consensus falls slightly on Columbia's side, but the gap, if there is one, is clearly closing.
What makes Secton crazy is that the world hasn't learned what he considers a self-evident truth. In recent years, N.Y.U. has finished sixth in the annual U.S. News and World Report survey of law schools. This year, Sexton was praying for an improvement, but the school came out sixth again. He was crestfallen, but ready with the spin: since Stanford, Chicago and Columbia were tightly bunched just ahead, he explained, a tiny spurt could land N.Y.U. in third place next year. He ascribes N.Y.U.'s ranking this year to "reputational lag."
It might take longer to overcome that lag than Sexton thinks. One highly regarded legal scholar says of Sexton: "He's a great guy, and he's taken N.Y.U. from a scrappy institution to one of the leading players in American legal education. But the main accomplishment of N.Y.U. has been bringing a bunch of people from places like Chicago who want to be in New York for other reasons. The market test is which institution could get a core member of the other institution to move. There's no central player at N.Y.U. who Harvard or Yale would go out to get, whereas N.Y.U. would give an arm or a leg to get the core members of any other institution."
Maybe N.Y.U. isn't quite there yet, but nobody questions where it's heading. Lea Brilmayer, the first big lateral transfer, is probably going back to Yale - a big blow - but Sexton is trying, in his parish-priest mode, to show her that it might be better for her to stay. Al Sykes, of Chicago, is seriously pondering. Steven Holmes, a major figure in international law - with a major connection to George Soros - and William Allen, chancellor of the Delaware Chancery Court and a giant figure in corporate law, are coming next semester. And there is furious action going on beneath the surface. One morning, Sexton met me at the door of his office, giant plastic coffee holder in hand, and announced gleefully, "There's been an implosion at Harvard." The Harvard Law School faculty had failed by one vote to make a tenure offer to Jesse Fried, a young star in corporate law. N.Y.U. was Fried's second choice. And John Coates, another star, who was leaving Wachtell, Lipton, was leaning toward N.Y.U. over Harvard. "In terms of entry-level faculty," Sexton said, "we're now fighting essentially with Harvard for the endgame."
There was a whole play shaping up in corporate law, historically N.Y.U.'s weakest major field. Sexton dropped into his swivel chair, swiveled once or twice and said: "We've got Marcel Kahan. We've got Robert Daines, who I think maybe will grow up to be a Marcel, who we have identified as a numero uno. Maybe we'll get a shot at both Coates and Fried." (John Coates has since accepted an offer from Harvard.) "O.K., so now you go to the senior level. The blue-chippers, the top drawer, are Lucian Bebchuk at Harvard, Reinier Kraakman at Harvard, Henry Hansmann and Roberta Romano at Yale, Mark Roe at Columbia, Ron Gilson at Stanford and Geoff Miller here. So we got Miller, then we got Hansmann and Kraakman visiting this year. Kraakman has already said that he wants to stay another year. Kraakman and Hansmann are best friends." Sexton had also given a full-time job to Kraakman's wife, Catherine Krupnick, an anthropologist.
Sexton was leaning out over his little round table, and he was so excited that he was whispering. His eyes had a mandman glint. "We've gone from a standins stop seven years ago to a point where we're already one of the top two or three. If we get either Coates or Fried, and one, let alone two, of these three, then we're the player." Sexton looked up at me with a huge smile: he was talking numero uno.
