PUB-DATE: May 25, 1997,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: Cold Warmonger

BYLINE: By Priscilla Johnson McMillan; Priscilla Johnson McMillan is a Fellow of the Davis Center for Russian Studies at Harvard University.

 BODY:

WE NOW KNOW
 Rethinking Cold War History.
 By John Lewis Gaddis.
 425 pp. New York:
 Oxford University Press. $30. 
 SINCE the Soviet Union came apart a little over five years ago, historians have awaited the opening of long-sealed archives in Moscow and other capitals of the former East bloc, hoping for new light on old questions. Now, at last, some of the archives have opened a crack, and a handful of hard-working scholars from East and West have started mining them for their historical treasure.
In "We Now Know," John Lewis Gaddis, the respected dean of cold war historians, surveys what these scholars have unearthed and compares their gleanings with some of our earlier suppositions. The key issues that, believe it or not, are still earnestly debated within the scholarly community and on which he seeks enlightenment are these: Who was chiefly to blame for the almost 50-year confrontation between the Soviet Union and the West; and could Americans have done anything to avert it?
Now that he has read some of the documents, Mr. Gaddis's answer is the same one he gave a few years ago in a celebrated article in the journal Foreign Affairs -- the leader solely responsible for unleashing the costliest war in history was Stalin. "Once Stalin wound up at the top in Moscow," Mr. Gaddis writes, "and once it was clear his state would survive the war, then it looks . . . clear that there was going to be a cold war whatever the West did."
To say that the recently released materials do not shake Mr. Gaddis's earlier view of Stalin's responsibility is not to say that he found no surprises. Take the question of the role played by Communist ideology. Mr. Gaddis, like many historians in the West, had come to believe that Marxism-Leninism had declined into little more than the empty armor of legitimacy, an after-the-fact justification for measures actually taken for reasons of Realpolitik. But looking at the new documents, he points to critical junctures when, he says, Communist ideology not only mattered, but actually determined the behavior of East-bloc leaders. He cites as an example Stalin's insistence after World War II that the next war to break out would take place among capitalist countries. Stalin subscribed to Lenin's teaching that capitalist nations were too willing to profit at one another's expense to work together for long. This expectation, Mr. Gaddis says, blinded the Soviet dictator to what was going on under his nose when the rapacious behavior of Soviet troops in Germany and the Communist seizures of power in Eastern Europe caused the Americans and Western Europeans to develop the Marshall Plan and then NATO in a long-lasting coalition directed against him.
Mr. Gaddis points to other instances long after Stalin died in which Marxist-Leninist ideology played a vital role. Late in the 1950's, for example, Nikita Khrushchev and his colleagues almost literally fell in love with Fidel Castro. Mr. Castro's enthusiasm for Marxism-Leninism and his obvious charisma beguiled the Soviet leaders into committing themselves heavily to the Cuban revolution. Such a commitment in the far-off Caribbean at first made little strategic sense and proved outrageously expensive, but Khrushchev and his colleagues hoped Cuba might be the spark that would ignite revolutions all over Latin America. Mr. Gaddis quotes Mr. Castro: "Nikita loved Cuba very much. . . . He had a weakness for Cuba, you might say -- emotionally, and so on -- because he was a man of political conviction, a man with a political doctrine, a political theory. . . . He thought in terms of capitalism versus socialism." Mr. Castro made the aging bureaucrats in the Kremlin feel like youthful revolutionaries again.
Examining the special qualities that each superpower brought to building alliances abroad, Mr. Gaddis contrasts the obstacles that Marxism-Leninism placed in the way of the Communist leaders with the opportunities that democratic practices provided to the West. Unlike the great historian George Kennan, whose presence pervades this book and who had warned early on that democracies were ill-suited to the pursuit of foreign policy, let alone the maintenance of empire, Mr. Gaddis believes that the democratic habits of deal making, compromise and tolerance served the United States well when it came to holding the Western coalition together.
In the end, Mr. Gaddis says, it was nuclear weaponry that imposed its terrible discipline and forced both sides to temper their moral and political absolutes. As President John F. Kennedy understood when he acquiesced to the Berlin wall in the summer of 1961, and as he and Khrushchev learned in some final way during the Cuban missile crisis the following year, the price of possessing the power to destroy civilization was that one dared not use it. Again and again, each time the superpowers confronted one another face to face or through surrogates -- whether in Cuba, Berlin, Korea, Vietnam or Afghanistan -- they accepted humbling constraints and, on occasion, even the appearance of defeat rather than risk global destruction.
Nuclear weapons, Mr. Gaddis believes, had a paradoxical, almost contradictory, impact on Soviet-American relations. On the one hand, he says, they prolonged the cold war. Because the possession of huge nuclear stockpiles, rather than social and economic strength, became the measure of a nation's power, no one noticed that by the early 1960's decay of the Soviet Union was already "virtually complete." The possession of nuclear arms masked its feebleness and, as a result, the cold war lasted longer than it would have had these weapons never existed.
On the other hand, they helped bring the cold war to a peaceful end. Vindicating the famous policy that Mr. Kennan enunciated in 1947, the existence of nuclear weaponry "contained" Soviet expansionism until the country collapsed of its own weight at the end of 1991. The bomb unexpectedly bought time for the policy of containment to complete its work.
For all the authority with which Mr. Gaddis makes his judgments, the timing of his book, and even its title, raises questions. For he has taken unequivocal positions on issues that are still, and with good reason, being hotly debated. Mr. Gaddis says in his preface that he wishes he could say he had slogged dutifully through the "archives in Moscow, Warsaw, Prague, Berlin, Budapest, Beijing, Hanoi and Havana" but that he has had to rely instead on the patience and linguistic skills of the scholars who are publishing their translations and interpretations in the Bulletin of the Cold War International History Project at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington. If, however, the author had seen the full range of evidence unearthed by some of these scholars, he would very likely have taken more nuanced positions. For instance, he declares here that "Stalin never wanted a separate East German state." Yet documents that have emerged in Moscow and Berlin during the past few years show, to the contrary, that for four years after the end of World War II Stalin was undecided, and kept open the option of a separate East Germany.
Indeed, the fate of postwar Germany, the outbreak of war in Korea and Stalin's relationship with Mao Zedong all shed light not so much on the extent of Stalin's domination as on the manner in which he exercised it. He kept his cards hidden, dropped a tantalizing hint now and then and allowed a situation to ripen until he was ready to clamp on the deadly vise of control. Most historians who have read the newly declassified documents agree with Mr. Gaddis that Stalin's allies were often abject, but they also point to instances where there was more give and take inside the Soviet bureaucracy or between Moscow and its allies than had previously been supposed.
It seems fair to ask whether this book has come out too soon. True, something can be said for an established scholar's making an early attempt at synthesis, at relating what is already known to newly discovered materials. Still, a book that deals mainly with the Stalin and Khrushchev years might have been delayed, since major collections not yet examined by Western historians may be on the point of becoming available and surprises of undeniable magnitude are almost certain to emerge. Alternatively, Mr. Gaddis might have called his book "What I Now Think."

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
In Pittsburgh, Fall of the Art of Sports

BYLINE: By BILL MODOONO; Bill Modoono was sportswriter for another vanished institution, The Pittsburgh Press.

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
It falls this afternoon at 3:30. Normally, these things take place just after dawn, but there's a service at a nearby church this morning, and, well, this is best done when the fewest people are around. Such is demolition.
The stated reason is safety. When the 24-story building at 500 Wood Street downtown is dynamited into oblivion this afternoon, the fewer people in the vicinity, the less likely anyone is to get hurt. Excluding the city's collective psyche, that is. 
 Granted, the building is being destroyed for an uplifting civic purpose. In its place will come a department store, from the aptly named Lazarus chain. Such commercial ventures -- especially ones like this that are heavily financed by the city itself -- are extremely rare for aging downtowns in the Rust Belt, and Pittsburgh would love to crow about the rebirth this store represents.
That argument will be difficult to make today because when the building falls, a 15-story mural known locally as the city's "sports heroes mural" will go with it. Maybe you've seen it on network sports telecasts from Pittsburgh; producers had an affinity for showing it during lulls in the action.
Not that you could blame them. The mural depicted five of the city's greatest sports stars: the Great One, Roberto Clemente; Le Magnifique, Mario Lemieux; two defensive stalwarts from the Steelers' Super Bowl era, Mean Joe Greene and Jack Lambert, and Bill Mazeroski, shown waving his cap and circling the bases after hitting one of the most famous home runs in World Series history, the one that beat the Yankees in 1960.
You could quibble with the choices -- No Bradshaw? No Stargell? -- but the overall presentation works. This is Pittsburgh sports in a nutshell: some talent, some grit, some downright orneriness and an occasional transcendent moment. That's about right.
When the artist, Judy Penzer of New York, unveiled the work in 1992, she said, "My intention is to capture both the heroic quality of these great athletes and the love and devotion the people of Pittsburgh have for their sports stars."
Unfortunately, the mural didn't last long enough to reach landmark status here. And its passing today pales in comparison with a larger, truer loss -- the death of Penzer, who was one of 230 people who died last summer on TWA Flight 800.
Was it great art? Does it matter? Pittsburgh may not know art (a native son, Andy Warhol, had to go to New York to find fortune), but it knows sports. And while the timing of the demolition is purely the result of economic factors unrelated to sports, you could pardon Pittsburghers for thinking otherwise. In terms of symbolic gestures, this is positively ominous.
The sports scene here has reached a nadir deeper than the hole the demolished building falls into today. At least its past was worthy of murals. Its present is less inspiring; its future, depressing.
You never know where you'll find a sports hero, of course, but suddenly Pittsburgh seems to be the least likely place to look. The city, which Rand McNally in 1985 called America's most livable, has in 1997 become sports' most leave-able. In recent years, Pittsburgh has lost more than its share of mural-worthy luminaries: Manager Jim Leyland and Barry Bonds and Bobby Bonilla from the Pirates; Steelers All-Pros such as Neil O'Donnell, Chad Brown and Kevin Greene, and Penguins favorites such as Kevin Stevens, Paul Coffey and Ulf Samuelsson.
Last month, two more joined the list. Lemieux, whose career was cut short by a series of ailments including back pain and Hodgkin's disease, retired after 13 seasons. He says he will stay in the city, but his only local action will be on the area's golf courses. And Rod Woodson, a perennial Steelers All-Pro who was named to the N.F.L.'s 75th anniversary team, could not reach a contract agreement with management and will apparently play somewhere else next season. Not even his ownership of a big restaurant here with his name on it, or his plan to live here after retirement, was enough to keep him with the local team.
Sure, change is part of sports, and the economics of free agency send players scurrying from all cities. But here, the goings far outnumber the comings and most likely will for some time. Pittsburgh may not be the Steel City it once was, but it's still proud of its shot-and-a-beer appetites. Modern-day sports, however, has a diminished interest in the shot-and-a-beer crowd.
It doesn't take much imagination to paint grim pictures here. The Penguins face the future minus the superstar who saved the sport in the city. They play their games in the National Hockey League's second-oldest arena. And putting a team on the ice without a reasonable chance of winning a title, and without the most popular player in its history, is a blueprint for box-office disaster.
The Pirates have long been a box-office disaster; the difference now is the team's strategy of unloading all its established players to build an affordable, competitive team from the bottom up. The Pirate management hopes to generate enough enthusiasm to get citizens behind a proposed baseball-only stadium. If not, ownership has an escape clause enabling it to move the franchise. And supporting losers -- even noble, fiscally sound ones -- has never been Pittsburgh's forte.
Even the Steelers, the main source of Western Pennsylvania's self-esteem in sports, have worried the populace in recent years. In each of the last three off seasons, they have lost two or more top players to free agency. Team officials claim to need either a new football-only stadium or an expensive makeover for 27-year-old Three Rivers Stadium to remain competitive in the N.F.L.
The Rooney family -- Art Sr., the late patriarch, was left off the mural, but he already had a statue -- still owns the franchise and would never leave, or at least everyone assumes the franchise would never leave. Similar assumptions were made in neighboring Cleveland. Come to think of it, the end of the fabled Browns-Steelers rivalry was another loss for the city.
Things don't get much better on the amateur level. The once-glorious University of Pittsburgh has not had a winning football season since 1991 and has not been to a bowl game in the 90's. This fall, the Panthers will have their fourth head coach in less than a decade.
Duquesne University has a storied basketball past and a present reality that includes no appearances in the N.C.A.A. tournament for 20 years. Pitt's immediate hoop prospects are brighter, or they were brighter until the promising 7-foot sophomore Mark Blount decided to leave early for the N.B.A.
Even the recent good news carries a negative tone -- Arnold Palmer's recent successful cancer surgery being the best example.
Still, let's not overstate today's event: it's just a mural going down. The city may seem devoid of heroes, but it's not as if it can't have more. You just wonder how heroes will ever find the place.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Broken China

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Last week President Clinton outlined his plans to renew China's most-favored-nation trading privileges. He made the announcement to a group of business leaders at the White House. Here's what the President should have said to them, but didn't.
Ladies and gentlemen, I've asked you here today to be the backdrop for my renewal of China's trade benefits, because I knew you'd be a friendly audience, since many of you do business with China. So let me begin first with a message to all of you: 
 Wake up, you morons! You are so greedy and shortsighted. You profit enormously from your business dealings with China. But you refuse to acknowledge that those dealings take place in an overall framework of U.S.-China relations, and that framework is now eroding. Yet you won't lift a finger to help shore it up. You ostriches make me sick!
Look around you. A year ago key Republicans and Democrats were forging a new bipartisan consensus on China, healing the rift created by Tiananmen. Bob Dole, Newt Gingrich, Warren Christopher, Sam Nunn, Bill Bradley and I were all giving the same speech about China -- all advocating a nuanced policy of engagement with Beijing that would build bridges where possible, draw red lines where necessary.
Today that consensus has fractured into so many pieces I've lost control of my China policy. My ability to get my way on the biggest issues involving China is now seriously in question.
What happened? Heck, what didn't happen? Our trade deficit with China ballooned to $40 billion, which drove many labor activists to conclude that China's not the Big Red Menace -- it's the Big Wage Menace. They fear that millions of Chinese working for 50 cents an hour are going to take millions of U.S. jobs. (They're actually taking jobs from other low-wage countries like Thailand, not us.) Then the Christian right decided to go on the warpath against China, because of its birth control policies and its crackdown on unregistered evangelical churches. Then you had Congress in a tizzy over China's alleged campaign payoffs and arms sales. The net result is a crumbling foundation for our relations with Beijing.
On top of it all, the old wise men who could validate a policy of engagement with China are ignored by this parochial Congress. Newt may listen to Henry Kissinger, but his troops don't. They don't even listen to Newt. They might listen to you, though. So here's what you're going to do:
(1) You're going to stop with your pious hogwash that everything in China will turn out fine if Congress will just leave you alone to make money there. Yes, commerce with China is a necessary condition for promoting reform there, but it's not sufficient. To be both effective and true to our values, we need to have an active policy of promoting more freedom there. So you're going to lobby your Congressmen and tell them that you understand their concerns about China's behavior, but that everyone just beating their breasts about China won't change anything. Things will only improve if business, human rights and labor activists work together, with China, to insure that as it grows economically, it becomes a more open, pluralistic and law-based society. And the best way to do that is by promoting rule of law in China.
(2) I want the Business Roundtable and the Chamber of Commerce to set up a $50 million fund, matched by Congress, that will bring Chinese law students, judges, lawyers, even prosecutors, to the U.S. to complete their legal education and to gain exposure to our legal system, and to support legal education programs in China. The Chinese leaders don't oppose these programs because they know they can't grow their economy without a more rule-of-law-based system. They are just betting that they can institute rule of law in every area except politics. Fine, I'll take that bet.
I know this focus on rule of law won't change the mood in America toward China overnight. Some groups here need a big enemy like China, and Lord knows, China makes it easy for them. But for those who really are interested in making a difference there -- not just in moral preening -- this rule of law approach could be the basis for building a new consensus. It's good for human rights, it's good for business, and it's good for China. Without a new consensus, this relationship is going to go right over a cliff, and it's going to take your business and my foreign policy along with it.

HEADLINE: Samuel Proctor, 75, Dies; Led Abyssinian Baptist Church

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
The Rev. Dr. Samuel DeWitt Proctor, a preacher, educator and former pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, died on Thursday at Mercy Medical Center in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. He was 75 and lived in Somerset, N.J.
The cause was a heart attack he suffered on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. His wife, Bessie, said he was stricken while talking with students at Cornell College, in Mount Vernon, Iowa, where he had gone to lecture. 
 In 1972, he succeeded the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the former Congressman, as pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, perhaps the most influential black institution in New York, at 138th Street and Lenox Avenue. Dr. Proctor held that post until 1989, when he was succeeded by the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d.
It has been said that Dr. Proctor, a veteran administrator, refocused the church, which had been the base for Mr. Powell's move into politics, on its mission. Dr. Proctor said that during the two decades of his own tenure as pastor, the church's annual operating budget rose to more than $1 million from $146,000. In those years, he maintained a relatively low profile on public issues.
When he retired as pastor, many members said they would miss his low-key approach to problems confronting blacks and what has been called his "quiet activism." Henry Knight, who had been a member of the church for four decades, said, "Dr. Proctor worked a quiet magic."
For his part, Dr. Proctor said at the time that new challenges called for new approaches. "The movement in the 60's," he said, "had so much drama and impetus because the targets were so clear. The pain is still clear but the target is amorphous. How, after all, do you march against sin? We have as much trauma in 1989 trying to define the issues as we did in the 60's trying to muster the courage to fight for those issues."
Born and raised in Norfolk, Va., Dr. Proctor studied at Virginia Union University in Richmond, the University of Pennsylvania, Crozer Theological Seminary and Yale Divinity School and received a doctorate in theology in 1950 from Boston University. He was ordained in 1943 and went on to hold various posts in education, including the presidency of Virginia Union University, and administrative posts with the National Council of Churches, the Peace Corps in Nigeria and Washington, and the Office of Economic Opportunity and elsewhere before going to the Abyssinian Baptist Church.
He was a professor of education at Rutgers University from 1969 to 1984 and preached, spoke and taught at numerous sites in recent years. He served on the boards of Middlebury College and other educational institutions. The books he wrote include "How Shall They Hear? Effective Preaching for Vital Faith" (1992, Judson).
The first two grades of a college preparatory school named for Dr. Proctor are to open this fall in Ewing Township, N.J. Eventually the school, financed by tax dollars, is to comprise grades 7 through 12.
Besides his wife of 52 years, the former Bessie Louise Tate, he is survived by his sons, Herbert, of Roselle, N.J., Timothy D. of Durham, N.C., Samuel T. of Detroit and Steven of New Brunswick, N.J.; five grandchildren; a great-grandson; a sister, Harriet Tyler of Philadelphia, and a brother, Dr. Oliver W. Proctor.

HEADLINE: In Afghanistan, a Triumph of Fundamentalism

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

 BODY:
By capturing the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif, the militant Islamic movement known as the Taliban has virtually completed its goal of reuniting Afghanistan under a single government for the first time in nearly 20 years.
On Saturday, when tanks flying the white flag of the Taliban rolled into Mazar-i-Sharif, only a few isolated pockets of resistance remained in four provinces. It is now probable that the Taliban's strict version of Islamic rule will be imposed on all of Afghanistan's 18 million people. 
 The swift collapse of the Taliban's enemies -- the "Northern Alliance" of relatively moderate Muslim leaders -- represents the culmination of a remarkable rise to power.
In less than three years, the clerics who lead the Taliban have risen from village obscurity in the southwest to absolute power. No Government has had similar authority since 1978, when a Communist revolution sent the country spinning into chaos.
If resistance crumbles in the northeastern provinces of Kunduz, Takhar, Baghlan and Badakhshan, which account for barely 10 percent of the country, Afghans will finally have the peace that many have said for years was all that really mattered. But it will have come at a steep price, especially for Afghan women, who have been subjected to restrictions with few parallels.
Taliban leaders have said for months that they would review bans on women in the workplace and on schooling for girls when the "security situation" improves. But these assurances have been given mainly under Western pressure, and many moderate Afghans say the Taliban's view of women is even less likely to change now.
Even if the Taliban succeed in attracting Western aid -- a doubtful prospect as long as they remain the targets of fierce criticism by human rights groups -- many Afghans who might otherwise have returned home from abroad may resist repatriation. The United Nations estimates that at least three million Afghans live abroad as refugees.
But the Taliban may pose a wider challenge, especially to the Muslim nations of what was Soviet Central Asia. Along with Russia, these nations -- Kazakstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan -- have been sharply critical of the Taliban, fearing that the movement will export fundamentalism across the Amu-Darya river, Afghanistan's northern border.
Moscow lost no time in issuing a warning after the Taliban victory at Mazar-i-Sharif. A Government statement over the weekend, referring to the Commonwealth of Independent States, the alliance of former Soviet republics, said that if the border is violated, "the mechanism of the C.I.S. collective security treaty will be immediately activated."
Taliban leaders in Kabul responded with a swift reassurance, saying they would adhere strictly to "a policy of noninterference in the internal affairs of other countries."
The United States has a less clearcut view. While deploring the Taliban's policies on women and the adoption of a penal code that provides for the amputation of thieves' hands and the stoning to death of adulterers, the United States has sometimes acted as though a Taliban government might serve its interests.
The Clinton Administration has taken the view that a Taliban victory would end a war that has killed 1.5 million Afghans; would act as a counterweight to Iran, whose Shiite Muslim leadership is fiercely opposed to the Sunni Muslims of the Taliban, and would offer the possibility of new trade routes that could weaken Russian and Iranian influence in the region.
For example, a proposal by the Unocal Corporation of California for a $2.5 billion pipeline that would link the gas fields of Turkmenistan through Afghanistan to Pakistan has attracted strong support in Washington, though human rights groups are likely to object to the plan.
Unocal is currently involved with the Total group of France in a $1 billion pipeline project in Myanmar, which is a target of United States economic sanctions over that country's suppression of human rights.
The Afghan project, strongly endorsed by the Taliban, is part of a broader concept under which the vast mineral resources of the former Soviet republics would be moved to markets along routes that would offer these countries a new autonomy from Moscow.
But the first issue for Washington will be whether to give diplomatic recognition to the Taliban, which had been in power in Kabul for eight months without being recognized by any government. That isolation ended within hours of the Taliban capture of Mazar-i-Sharif when Pakistan, which has given financial and military backing to the militants, said it was recognizing the Kabul Government.
Over the longer term, historians may examine the role played by outside powers in bringing the Taliban to power.
From the outset, the Afghan war amounted to a contest between two visions for Afghanistan: the modernizing, anti-clerical view of the Communists, and the conservative view of Muslim clerics. Later it developed into a cold-war battleground between the Soviet Union, which sent 110,000 troops to occupy the country, and the United States, which provided Muslim insurgents with billions of dollars of weapons.
In the end, though, it was neither Moscow's nor Washington's clients who triumphed but the Taliban, a force that nobody in Afghanistan had heard of before 1994.
If many in Afghanistan seem to accept this, moderate Afghans say, it is less because they yearn for a life that is rigidly policed from the country's mosques than because two decades of war, by destroying virtually everything associated with modern society, opened the door to men whose prescriptions for the country seem to be drawn from the medieval past.

HEADLINE: Baghdad Journal;
Iraqis Laugh Again and Lather Up

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 25

 BODY:
Sometimes it is the small things that make a difference, and that may be the case in the new nexus between the Government of Iraq, the United Nations and soap.
Until this month, the soap provided to Iraqis as part of a paltry basket of Government rations was universally reviled: colorless, latherless and smelling faintly of the lard from which it was usually made. 
 But, finally, Iraqis have a reason to smile. More than five months after Iraqi oil began to flow again under United Nations supervision, the rations that people received this month were more bountiful than at any time since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991. Along with flour, rice and beans, the latest baskets included fresh-smelling bars of soap, one reason that some Iraqis are talking about feeling human again.
"Of course it makes a difference," said Haifa Abul Amir, 24, a mother of two who shares a cramped house in the ragged Baghdad suburb of Huriya with her husband and her parents. "That other stuff wasn't fit for any person."
Adopted as a "temporary measure" to ease the hardships caused by United Nations efforts to squeeze the Iraqi Government, the oil-for-food plan that has begun to sweeten life here will expire on June 9, and it is not clear whether it will be renewed.
The United States has said it is not entirely satisfied that all revenues from the $2 billion worth of oil that Iraq was authorized to sell are being used properly. Iraq has complained that the United States has been overzealous, holding up delivery of food and other goods that should have arrived months ago. A report from the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, that is expected to address these issues is expected within days.
But with tons of food, detergents and even medical supplies beginning to enter Iraq, Iraqis who have complained for years of being pawns to bigger rivalries say they have begun to regain a measure of dignity.
"Now when we bake bread we run out to show it off to the neighbors," said Najad Salman, 44, the mother of Ms. Abul Amir. "The flour they gave us before couldn't make a decent loaf, but now we all are better off."
For Iraqis who have suffered through the years of sanctions, weathering illness and malnutrition, the change has been a long time coming.
Although various oil-for-food plans have been proposed by the United Nations for years, the Iraqi Government long rejected them as an infringement of its sovereignty. Even after it shifted course and gave a tentative go-ahead in January 1996, the final details took nearly a year to be resolved.
Iraqi oil did begin to flow again last Dec. 9, an event accompanied by lavish ceremonies and celebratory gunshots in the streets, but it took nearly three months before the first shipment of food -- chick peas, white beans and cooking oil from Turkey -- arrived.
A special United Nations committee in New York has blocked or put on hold nearly half of the contracts for food and other goods that have been submitted under a cumbersome approval process for which the Iraqis blame American interference.
As late as April, so few supplies of food and other goods had arrived in Iraq that the monthly ration provided by the Government to its 22 million citizens remained essentially unchanged. Rations were increased by a few pounds of flour per person only after the Government agreed to draw 40,000 tons of wheat from its own strategic reserves.
But in the last two months a burgeoning flow by land and sea has brought a total of 550,000 tons of food and other goods into Iraq, where they are being distributed by Iraqi officials under United Nations supervision. In the Kurdish areas of northern Iraq, which lie outside the control of the Baghdad Government, the distribution is handled by United Nations agencies.
Sugar and tea remain in short supply and the quantities distributed to Iraqis this month remained unchanged. But the supplies of all other goods have been considerably bolstered, increasing the average daily calorie allotment by about 90 percent, to about 2,300 per day.
The package still does not include meat or eggs, and it provides milk only for youngsters less than one year old. As many as one in four Iraqi children still suffer from some form of malnutrition, United Nations officials say, and most Iraqis still find it necessary to buy some goods on the open market, where a dozen eggs can consume about half a government worker's monthly salary.
"It's a drop in the bucket," Iraq's Information Minister, Hamid Yousef Hammadi, said of the help provided by the oil-for-food agreement, although he quickly added, "It's better than nothing."
The United Nations Humanitarian Coordinator for Iraq, Steffan de Mistura, declined in an interview to say whether he thought the oil-for-food deal should be extended, but his comments left his sentiments clear.
"The needs of the population are clearly identified, and they are large," he said.
Under the accord, Iraqi is permitted to sell only about one-fifth of the oil that it did before the Persian Gulf war. Of the $2 billion that it was permitted to earn from the sale of oil in the six months that will end on June 9, nearly 30 percent has been set aside to settle the claims of those displaced by the war and to pay for the costs of United Nations operations here.
But still, from those limited oil sales alone, the plan sets aside $805 million for food, $65 million for soap and detergent, $210 million for medicine, and tens of millions more for projects to improve electricity, water, agriculture and education.
Some Western diplomats say they worry that the scheme may simply allow the Government of President Saddam Hussein to divert resources that it once had to spend on food toward darker purposes. They say these could include efforts to rebuild weapons systems that Iraq has been compelled to destroy under the United Nations resolutions that were imposed after the Persian Gulf war.
But people in Baghdad who have begun to taste life's simplest pleasures again would rather talk about how their lot is improving.
"It smells nice, it cleans better, and at least it has a pretty color," said one of several woman who volunteered their praise, unprompted, for the pinkish bars of Jordanian soap passed out at a monthly ration of one and a half per person. "We all still have big problems, but I'm beginning to feel a little better about the little ones."

HEADLINE: Houses of Worship Struggle to Rebuild After Flood

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: GRAND FORKS, N.D., May 25

 BODY:
At the First Presbyterian Church here, last month's flood ruined interior walls and left green and purple song books stuck to ceiling beams in the basement choir room. At St. Mary's Catholic Church and School across the street, the gymnasium, cafeteria and day-care center were destroyed. And at the B'nai Israel Synagogue several blocks away, the furnace and electrical system were wrecked and the four Torahs had to be rescued by the synagogue treasurer riding a Jet Ski.
As these and other places of worship struggle to recover, they face problems common to religious institutions struck by natural disasters. While many churches and the synagogue here seem certain to survive, some churches are likely to close. 
 Unlike families, religious institutions are generally not eligible for Federal grants. Unlike businesses, they cannot borrow against future profits. And with thousands of people giving up on this city and moving elsewhere, religious institutions must find ways to meet even their usual budgets with donations from shrinking congregations.
The mid-April flood of the Red River damaged two-thirds of the homes in this town, which had a population of 50,000, and inflicted particularly heavy damage on places of worship, which are concentrated in older, riverside neighborhoods. The main floor of St. Mary's escaped the flood and has reopened but members of the synagogue had to meet on Friday night at the Grand Forks Air Force Base and First Presbyterian members gathered at the University of North Dakota this morning.
There was a mixture of hope and sorrow during and after services this weekend, as people mourned lost homes and businesses and began to debate whether to repair or replace their churches.
"It has been overwhelming," said Carole Peterson, the spiritual director at First Presbyterian, just before the service began in an auditorium at the student union. "The church is our home and if we can't go home, where do we go?"
Government agencies generally cannot give money to damaged churches, partly because of the constitutional separation of church and state and partly because of a perception that repairing religious institutions is not a priority in disaster relief. Instead, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has been providing free furnaces, electrical repairs and other safety-related assistance to families here. The agency's regulations allow assistance to religious organizations that primarily provide nondenominational community services, but this loophole is so narrow that it has seldom been used in recent years.
However, most churches have financial reserves earning interest, which are linked to taxpayer identification numbers. The numbers make them eligible for some of the loans that the Small Business Administration offers to businesses, at low interest rates. "As far as the Government's concerned, it's a business" if a church has a taxpayer identification number, said David L. Talley, a loan officer with the Federal agency.
Churches and other nonprofit institutions can borrow money for up to 30 years at interest rates as low as 4 percent to repair flood damage, he said. However, Congress has never chosen to make churches eligible for the "economic injury" loans that the Small Business Administration also offers to companies, which enable a borrower to make mortgage payments and pay other fixed costs until it can reopen.
Even the repayment of a low-rate loan can be a big financial burden for a religious institution. The United Lutheran Church, a block from St. Mary's, faces a $1 million bill to repair its 900-seat building, including a day-care center that served 200 children. Built in the early 1930's, the church is one of the nation's largest places of worship built in a pure Art Deco style, said the Rev. Timothy G. Johnson, the head pastor at United Lutheran. The church has zigzag, pyramid-style columns, doorways and stained-glass windows.
The church's annual budget is only $550,000. Even that may shrink because as many as 450 of the church's 3,000 members are moving out of town, abandoning damaged homes near the river, Mr. Johnson said. Melvin D. Carsen, the city tax assessor, has estimated that as many as 7,500 people may leave town.
Lutheran Disaster Relief, a national group, is paying the salaries of the church's pastors now, but cannot afford to rebuild the church.
As a result, the church's leaders have begun to talk about whether to merge with a nearby Lutheran church and end a longstanding rivalry. At the very least, United Lutheran would have to rebuild with less expensive materials.
"We will not look the same after this," said Mr. Johnson, who held services today at a funeral home because the church was unusable.
Places of worship here have taken different approaches to the arduous task of removing flood-damaged material from their basement social rooms, kitchens and other areas.
First Presbyterian, for example, which has yet to receive financial assistance from national Presbyterian groups, has been husbanding its meager financial reserves by relying on volunteer labor. Teen-agers wearing surgical masks but no hard hats or safety glasses used thick poles this weekend to tear down damaged fluorescent light fixtures and soggy interior walls, while periodically warning one another to stand clear of debris about to be dislodged from the ceiling. A steady procession of children and adults carried useless furnace parts and planks out of the building and threw them on a debris pile the size of a minivan.
"I tell the kids working for me, this is the only time in your life you can be this destructive and not get in trouble," said Mark Hoffmann, a civil engineer and church member. The church has no estimate yet for the cost of repairs. It may be more practical to build a smaller church farther from the river, the Rev. Gretchen Daneke Graf said.
United Lutheran has borrowed $100,000 from a local bank on generous terms, paying most of it to have a Minneapolis company remove debris from the church site. Volunteers from the congregation have been helping, but only under the supervision of the company, Quantum Fire and Water Restoration. "They have the building, and control access and liability," Mr. Johnson said.
Volunteers have cleared debris from the basement at St. Mary's Church. But the bare floors and walls there still must be cleaned and disinfected, required everywhere because the flood water was mixed with sewage and the rotting carcasses of drowned livestock. And the church still must figure out a way to replace the kitchen equipment and day-care toys, said Sharon A. Wilhelmi, the church's youth director.
Among many places of worship in old neighborhoods close to the river, the B'nai Israel Synagogue, which is so small that it relies on monthly visits by student rabbis from Cincinnati, seems to be recovering quickly. As soon as the water receded from the synagogue, 45 volunteers from Nechama, a Jewish disaster relief group, came here on an overnight bus trip from Minneapolis.
The volunteers removed the mud and ruined equipment from the basement kitchen, furnace room and social hall, while helping congregation members repair their homes. The volunteers also donated $10,000 to the synagogue, said its president, Robin Silverman. For $4,000, a Texas company installed fans and a dehumidifier and pumped chemicals into the walls to reduce the risk of mold.
Donations have poured in from 40 states, allowing the synagogue to offer $3,000 to every family in the congregation that needs it. A synagogue repair fund has already raised $70,000, roughly half the total needed. Mrs. Silverman said she was confident the rest of the money could be raised without a Government loan.
But at least 10 of the 50 or so Jews in Grand Forks are moving to other cities now. "It's going to be a while before we get any new families," Mrs. Silverman said. "We will be a very tiny group for a few years."
Many other places of worship are also likely to be smaller, while struggling with the financial burdens left by the flood. "This tragedy has changed Grand Forks," Mr. Johnson said. "It has changed the way churches will operate and it has changed the people in churches."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK TO SELL MENTAL FACILITIES

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Thirty years after New York State began dismantling its sprawling network of psychiatric hospitals, once the largest in the nation, the Pataki administration plans to sell off all but a tiny fraction of the unused buildings and grounds at 20 centers for the mentally ill and the retarded.
The parcels total almost 6,500 acres, or 10 square miles, including waterfront property on the North Shore of Long Island, 68 acres in the heart of Queens, 3 nine-hole golf courses and 1,000 century-old buildings. 
 The proposed sale -- covering 12 psychiatric centers and 8 developmental centers for the mentally retarded -- would be one of the largest transfers of public land to private hands in recent New York history. The proceeds would be used to help pay off more than $285 million in state bonds on the largely unused acres and their decaying buildings.
Any money left over would go to community programs for the retarded and mentally ill, according to the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency overseeing the bidding, which is to begin in August.
"We're going to look at each bid, each proposal and each facility on a case by case basis," Gov. George E. Pataki said in a recent interview. "We'll try to achieve the highest return for the taxpayers, reduce the bonded indebtedness and put the property back on the tax rolls."
But Mr. Pataki cautioned that the sale might not bring in enough money to pay off the bonds, which require that the properties be sold at full market value if the total debt cannot be paid. That would make it all but impossible, Mr. Pataki said, to accommodate local officials who want to retain some of the land for public use. Their opposition has stymied redevelopment plans in the past, particularly on Long Island.
Officials in Smithtown on Long Island, for example, want to preserve some property at the Kings Park Psychiatric Center for parkland, and those in the Village of Thiells in Rockland County want some of the land at the Letchworth Village complex for the local school district.
But state officials say that a strong real-estate market makes them optimistic about eventually disposing of the land and buildings, which they say cost about $40 million a year in debt service and maintenance.
The state has hired a company to do the marketing and to draft a brochure that dresses up the properties in the language of the local real estate agent, describing them as "generously landscaped" or "close to major highways."
"This is unprecedented, not only in the scale of the sites, but in their diversity," said Graham Roberts, senior vice president of Chesterton Binswanger International, the real estate firm hired by the state to market the properties. "They're all over the state. There's an incredible diversity of redevelopment potential. This is truly one of a kind."
The 20 tracts range from the Kings Park Psychiatric Center, whose 552 acres roll down to a marina on the North Shore of Long Island -- real-estate brokers say it might fetch $250,000 an acre in a booming market -- to the St. Lawrence Psychiatric Center, 436 remote acres on the Canadian border that may draw only a few hundred dollars an acre. Somewhere in between sit the 961-acre Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center in Dover, with a nine-hole golf course, and the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center on 68 acres in Queens Village, Queens.
At Kings Park, the state needs to get an average of $74,275 an acre to cover the $41 million bond on the property. But at the St. Lawrence center, the state would need an average of $49,541 an acre to cover the $21.6 million bond, in an area where land sells for as little as $500 an acre.
Some of the most attractive amenities, like the golf courses and the marina, were built as "work therapy" by patients 50 years ago, when institutionalizing the mentally ill and retarded was the rule and the hospitals' populations teemed.
At its peak in 1955, the network served 93,314 patients, including 19,000 people at Pilgrim State Hospital in western Suffolk County, once the largest psychiatric hospital in the world. But beginning in the 1960's, mental health experts began emphasizing community-based treatment and the use of new drugs that made hospitalization unnecessary for many patients.
State officials in New York and elsewhere closed beds by the thousands, but were slow to finance community programs and specialized housing.
Today, there are only 7,645 beds in the state's psychiatric centers, and the State Office of Mental Health expects to cut the number of beds to 4,900 by the year 2002. A similar trend occurred at the state's developmental centers for the mentally retarded, where the number of patients has fallen to 2,815 from a high of 27,544 in the 1970's.
Of the 20 centers involved in the sale, 3 of the 12 psychiatric centers and all 8 developmental centers are already closed, including the Central Islip and Kings Park hospitals on Long Island. Others, like the Pilgrim complex, will keep some land and a few buildings after most of the property is sold.
The state will continue to run 18 adult psychiatric centers, and to oversee some 2,500 residential and outpatient psychiatric programs for adults and children in the state.
Glenn Liebman, executive director of the Alliance for the Mentally Ill of New York State, welcomed the closing and sale of the state hospitals, but said that he and other advocates for the retarded and mentally ill would demand that the proceeds go to community mental health programs.
Under a 1993 law, the state is required to finance community mental health programs with the estimated $220 million saved by closing several hospitals over five years. Mr. Liebman said the Pataki administration had already reduced aid to the programs in recent years. The administration has also proposed reducing that money even further to help reduce the debt on the properties before they are sold.
"They're tearing down facilities, but they're not putting in any services on the community side," Mr. Liebman said. "You can't keep deinstitutionalizing people and not provide them with services in the community."
Word of the impending sale was greeted with elation in recent days in Dover and Ogdensburg, rural towns hurt badly by the closing or shrinking of the hospitals, and with trepidation among Long Island's densely populated communities, which have been split between supporters of potential new jobs and tax revenues and opponents of overdevelopment.
In the 1980's, residents of Brentwood angrily denounced the building of a prison at the Pilgrim complex and later persuaded Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to close it. In Dix Hills, the residents successfully fought state plans in 1993 to build a headquarters for Olympus America at the Long Island Developmental Center.
Whatever the outcome of the sale, there is a great public benefit to retiring the debt and putting the land on the tax rolls, state officials said.
But some urban planners and politicians questioned the wisdom of a wholesale sell-off of valuable state assets without an overall economic development plan that designates specific uses for parcels, like parks, schools, affordable housing or, say, a research complex near a university.
"Kings Park, which is on the water and has a co-generation plant and a marina, could be very valuable for some developer," said Assemblyman James F. Brennan of Brooklyn, chairman of the Assembly's committee on mental health. "But something 30 miles north of Utica may not be. Corporate downsizing has left some communities in pretty bad shape. It's questionable who wants to invest at all. So what is the purpose of this?"
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the state's Empire State Development Corporation, countered that the properties had been sitting unused for too long. It is time to "get them back on the tax rolls," he said.
"There have been all kinds of studies," Mr. Gargano said, "but it's never produced a sale or a re-use." He declined to estimate how much money the sale would bring.
Mr. Roberts of Chesterton Binswanger said that residential and commercial builders, health care companies and hotel operators would be interested in the properties, not the 1,000 old and vacant buildings. But development of some of the land is restricted by environmental regulations, or in other cases encumbered by asbestos, underground pipes and old building foundations.
"Frankly, I think most of the buildings are going to get knocked down," he said.
Once a property is sold, it reverts to local zoning regulations, and any developer would have to have a fairly good idea of what kind of project would be acceptable to the local community before determining what to pay for the parcel.
State officials are hoping they have built a local consensus on the future use of the properties. Last year, local committees established by the state or town governments held public hearings on development proposals for Kings Park, the Long Island Development Center and the Pilgrim complex, perhaps the most valuable parcel of all because of its location at the intersection of the Long Island Expressway and the Sagtikos Parkway, a commercial and residential hub for Long Island.
The groups ultimately suggested 1,500 new homes, mostly for the elderly, at the Developmental Center; single-family homes and a shopping center at Kings Park and a sports complex, golf course and light industry for parts of the Pilgrim complex.
"The properties could be worth anywhere from $100,000 to $300,000 an acre," said David Pannetta, vice president of Oxford & Simpson, a real estate brokerage in Jericho. "The proper development of these lands will make Long Island a better place."
But civic groups still have an understandable "distrust as to what may happen," said Thomas Isles, planning commissioner for Islip and a member of the Pilgrim task force.
"I'm sure the potential bidders are going to have all kinds of schemes for what they want to do there," added Patrick R. Vecchio, town supervisor for Smithtown, which includes the Kings Park center. "We are not going to permit huge density there."
The heated atmosphere on Long Island is in sharp contrast with the sentiment in Ogdensburg, a town of 13,000 on the St. Lawrence River where the state psychiatric hospital was the largest employer. Opened in 1890, the St. Lawrence State Hospital swelled to a complex of 70 buildings, 2,264 patients and thousands of state jobs with good benefits. Now there are only 129 patients in a handful of buildings and fewer than 500 employees. Unlike the Nassau and Suffolk County residents, the leaders of Ogdensburg courted the building of a state prison on the property to offset the job losses. Richard Lockwood, mayor of Ogdensburg, is willing to consider almost anything.
"I used to say anything short of a radioactive waste dump would be considered," Mr. Lockwood said. "I was being a little facetious but we're anxious to see it developed."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: WHAT IS PLAYING IN THE GLOBAL VILLAGE -- BRITAIN;
A Blue-Collar Mirror

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Americans are bombared with statistics about what's hot and what's not in their culture. So deafening is the noise of American culture that it can be hard to hear what's happening in other cultures. But the differences in cultural tastes can be striking. Although the continuing globalization of mass media tends to favor the glitzy entertainment that Americans produce and enjoy, especially in movies, the Egyptians still prefer more serious television programming, while the people in Hong Kong read much more practical nonfiction books. And local music is preferred almost everywhere. What follows is a sampling of the images, sounds and ideas that are popular overseas and vignettes that try to explain them.
"Eastenders" is the quintessential British soap opera: gritty, realistic and firmly rooted in a working-class neighborhood that is a far cry from the fantastically upscale communities of most American soaps. 
 Set in London's East End, "Eastenders" follows the lives and fortunes of the residents of the fictional Albert Square, who work at low-level jobs in pubs and car-repair shops, grappling with social and financial problems like unemployment, alcoholism and mental illness.
In recent weeks, the show has focused on the marriage of Ricky Butcher and Bianca Jackson, which had been a long time coming. The bride had last-minute doubts, the couple fought and reconciled, and the groom got drunk at his bachelor party and woke up on his wedding day in a farmer's field.
The show, which has an average weekday audience of 20 million (more than a third of Britain's population of 56 million people) has been broadcast since 1985. Three new episodes are shown each week on BBC1, the country's original television station, which still draws the most viewers each day in spite of increasing competition from four other channels and a widening array of cable and satellite stations.
Twelve years is a long run for a British television drama; actors usually move on to other projects quickly. And no matter how popular a program is, there is little economic incentive to keep it on the air because BBC gets taxpayer subsidies; its shows are not advertiser-supported.
But this 30-minute early-evening program has its viewers hooked, and the BBC tries to give them what they want. "Public broadcasting has always dominated the country's output, and it brings with it a strong, rich vein of social realism which the audience is brought in to and responds to," said Jane Harris, the show's producer. SARAH LYALL

HEADLINE: Many Iranians Hope Mandate Brings Change

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, May 25

 BODY:
As it became clear on Saturday night that Iranians had defied their religious leaders by overwhelmingly electing a new President known for tolerance and moderation, Cyrus Mozaffarian, a jewelry and crafts vendor, had trouble keeping his mind on his work.
Like many Iranians, he was thinking about what the election of Mohammed Khatami will mean. 
 "This was a referendum about freedom," Mr. Mozaffarian said. "The voters were saying that we're tired of people snooping into our private lives. What we do at home is our own business. With Khatami in power, the Government is going to stop telling us what we can read, what we can watch and what we can do. We voted for change, and the Government will have to give it to us."
From behind the counter, Mr. Mozaffarian's young nephew smiled and shook his head in gentle disagreement.
"Khatami is not the boss and never will be," he said. "In this country the President does not decide. Maybe Khatami has certain ideas, but he won't have real power."
The discussion between Mr. Mozaffarian and his nephew mirrored a debate that is under way throughout Iran. Still stunned by what they did at the polls on Friday, many Iranians are realizing that even if this is not the dawn of a new era, it may prove to be the end of an old one. Never before in 18 years of Islamic rule have they so clearly rejected the will of the ruling Shiite Muslim clerics.
Near-final results announced today showed the astonishing dimensions of Mr. Khatami's upset victory. He won 69 percent of the vote, with his principal opponent, Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, taking just 25 percent.
The clerics, or mullahs, who run Iran, including the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, made clear that they favored Mr. Nategh-Nouri. Not only did their support fail to propel him to victory, it was also one of the main factors leading people to vote for Mr. Khatami.
"People want to show that this is a grown-up country now and that we can make our own decisions," said a businessman who returned to Teheran in 1992 after spending several years in the United States. "Religion is not the only thing that determines how people vote."
Like many Iranians, the businessman hopes that Mr. Khatami's openness will lead him to consider reshaping the economic system here, which is heavily state-oriented and not always encouraging to private or foreign investors.
With a decisive majority of voters behind him, Mr. Khatami will be able to claim a strong popular mandate when he is inaugurated in August. But in Iran, popular mandates are not as important as they are elsewhere. According to the revolutionary Constitution, God holds ultimate power here, and His will is expressed through the faqih, or supreme leader. Ayatollah Khamenei met with Mr. Khatami today and gave him "appropriate guidelines," the official Iranian press agency reported.
Faced with an intimidating restriction on his power, Mr. Khatami, who is himself a Shiite cleric, will have to move slowly and carefully. He has already made clear that he will press for the legalization of political parties and restrictions on religious vigilantes who raid private homes in search of liquor, video cassettes and other evidence of what they see as Western decadence.
But because some of the ruling mullahs and their powerful allies in Parliament are suspicious of his fidelity to revolutionary principles, he cannot go much further, at least for the time being.
His aides have said, for example, that he will not seek to lift the requirement that Iranian women cover their heads, arms and legs with modest clothing. His liberalism means only that, in the words of one aide, "he won't object if a little bit of hair shows from under the scarf."
One early clue to Mr. Khatami's intentions will come when he announces his Cabinet this summer. Technocrats and liberals have already begun jockeying for posts, but he dares not ignore the religious establishment.
Women were a strong part of Mr. Khatami's electoral coalition, and the country's most prominent female politician, Faezeh Hashemi, a member of Parliament and daughter of the outgoing President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, has already demanded a tangible show of gratitude.
She wants Mr. Khatami, for whom she actively campaigned, to appoint a woman to his Cabinet.
Such a move would be difficult for some conservatives to accept, but if a woman with a strong political base like Miss Hashemi is selected, they would find it difficult to object publicly.
As he moves slowly to create a more favorable climate for political and social reform, Mr. Khatami may soon begin to focus on the next parliamentary election, which is three years away. In last year's election, clerics disqualified many candidates whom they considered unacceptably liberal. One of Mr. Khatami's goals will probably be to win a measure of control over the process by which parliamentary candidates are selected.
Economic issues were important in the presidential campaign, with many voters saying they hoped that inflation could be controlled and others, especially young people, concerned that the economy was not expanding fast enough to give them jobs.
Although Iran has economic troubles, aggravated in part by a United States trade embargo, it is not in dire shape. Trade with European, Asian and even Latin American countries is flourishing. Most important, the country continues to produce the full oil quota allocated to it by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, assuring the state-owned oil concern of a steady revenue flow.
In foreign affairs, Mr. Khatami may have even less power than he has over domestic policy.
Aides have said that he favors improving relations with nearby countries like Turkey, where the Iranian Ambassador was recently expelled on charges of fomenting fundamentalism, and that he does not approve of meddling in the affairs of other countries.
How sincere he is, and to what extent he can change Iranian behavior abroad, is highly uncertain.
In the past Mr. Khatami has said he favors open debate on all topics, including relations with the West. If he should take the radical step of advocating new overtures to the United States, he would probably have considerable public support, since the population seems remarkably free of anti-American feeling. But Ayatollah Khamenei remains strongly opposed to any such initiative.
The Ayatollah said last week that he opposed "the slightest tolerance of America and of Western countries' interference and cultural onslaught." He said Iran would "stand against America and those who want to impose their will on our nation."
Nonetheless, the election of Mr. Khatami adds a new factor to the political equation here and in the region.
"We welcome this turn of events," David Bar-Illan, an aide to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, said after the results became clear.
