SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 2989 words

HEADLINE: SECOND SENTENCE -- A special report.;
As AIDS Increases Behind Bars, Costs Dim Promise of New Drugs

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Along the grim hallways of prison, AIDS is so familiar inmates give it nicknames -- "the beast," "the monster," "the beetle." Like a second sentence for many convicted drug addicts, AIDS now infects the nation's prisoners at nearly six times the rate of the rest of the population. But efforts to fight the disease behind bars have been hampered by uneven medical care and a short supply of the promising new treatments that are the weapon of choice in the outside world.
Corrections budgets have been overwhelmed by the cost of the new treatments, which have sent the annual expense of treating an H.I.V.-infected patient from about $2,000 to as much as $13,000. As a result, the drugs are not being widely prescribed in some prisons even though doctors acknowledge that it is unethical not to. 
 Many prison systems, including the Federal Bureau of Prisons, are only now developing guidelines for treating AIDS, or are following old protocols that do not take into account the new drugs, known as protease inhibitors. Now that treating AIDS and H.I.V. is becoming as complex as treating cancer, with drugs and dosages carefully calibrated to each patient's condition, many infected inmates are being treated by primary-care doctors and see a specialist only occasionally, if at all.
The AIDS virus has been caught between opposing forces behind bars. With hundreds of thousands ofdrug addicts locked up in the last decade, prisons have become a repository of infectious disease and present an opportunity for significant public health efforts. But prisons are under severe budget restrictions as their populations have soared and much of the public has come to view any services for prisoners beyond security measures as luxuries -- including medical care.
Health care experts view prisons as a prime place to attack the disease. In addition to helping individual inmates, they hope to change their high-risk behavior and lower the strength of their viruses, thereby reducing the chances that the disease will be transmitted in prison and when they are released.
"These people are part of the community who needs to be treated," said Frederick Altice, the director of the H.I.V. in Prisons program at Yale Medical School. "There has certainly not been a recognition of the magnitude of H.I.V. behind bars in most areas of the country."
No corrections system has felt the impact of the disease more than New York City's Rikers Island jails, where 26 percent of the women and 12 percent of the men are H.I.V.-positive, with about 3,000 inmates at any time requiring some AIDS services. After urging by health care professionals, the Giuliani administration recently approved a plan to start treating H.I.V.-infected inmates with the new drugs on July 1. (Now, only inmates who are on the drugs when they are jailed receive them.) The city expects to spend $5.4 million next year on the drugs, $1 million less than it now spends for all other inmates' medicines.
The New York State prison system, with the highest rate of infection of any system in the country, dramatizes the scale of the problem. In 1996, it housed an estimated 9,500 H.I.V.-positive inmates, or about 1 percent of all AIDS-infected Americans. The cost of AIDS treatment programs in the state prisons has jumped by 50 percent in the last four years, to $45.8 million.
The Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported that 1994 figures, the latest available, showed 5.2 AIDS cases for each 1,000 inmates, as compared with 0.9 cases for each 1,000 adults outside prison. But the C.D.C. said the numbers "probably were underestimated" since they did not include all jails. In addition, there is no uniform nationwide system of testing.
The available numbers show the rate of infection falling in New York State prisons and growing slowly, if at all, in other state systems, mirroring the national trend. But the total number of infected inmates is growing because prison population growth is so explosive.
"It comes with the life style," said Orlando Pontoja, 29, who is H.I.V.-positive and recently was released from prison in New York State after serving his second term for drug possession. "It's the way most criminals live, with drugs and hanging out and unprotected sex. It all comes together."
That way of life continues to some extent in prison, and officials in some places have tried to guard against the spread of H.I.V. Anne S. DeGroot, an AIDS doctor at Brown University who has written about H.I.V. in prison, reported last year that two states, Mississippi and Vermont, gave condoms to prisoners, as do jails in four cities: New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Washington. She reported that at a jail in Houston, bleach was available to inmates with instructions on how to clean needles.
Prisons are particularly well-suited for the use of protease inhibitors in combination with other drugs, the "cocktail" that has been shown to reduce viral activity in some patients dramatically. The treatment relies on identifying the virus early and on following a strict regimen of medication to guard against breeding a strain of the disease that is impervious to treatment -- a system that is easier to carry out in prison because the patients are under regular observation.
But the H.I.V.-positive population in prison is largely anonymous and therefore untreated. Just 14 states have mandatory testing, and many inmates refuse voluntary testing because they fear their illness will become known. In New York State, the estimate of 9,500 infected inmates is based on what are known as "blinded" blood tests. As of last years, officials knew the identity of about 3,200 of those inmates, according to corrections department documents. In California, where officials estimate that 4,000 inmates are now H.I.V.-positive, the identities of about 1,200 are known, officials there said.
"You have a lot of people who know they're positive who are in denial," said Sheila Morris, a prisoner in Washington, D.C., who is H.I.V.-positive. "I am surprised by people who are sick and won't admit it. They're more willing to admit they're drug addicts or murderers or pedophiles than admit they're sick and get care for it."
Ronald Bogard, a former general counsel of the New York City Health Department who has become a national spokesman on AIDS in prisons, said there had been little effort to determine the extent of the problem. "Not only do we not know, we don't really care, because of the people that are involved and the money that is involved," Mr. Bogard said. "Now the stakes have gone way up because of protease inhibitors."
Prison officials say they have been increasing medical training and other programs to address the AIDS problem for several years, and they recognize that the new drugs can both help inmates and cut hospital costs.
John Miles, a special assistant for corrections and substance abuse at the C.D.C., said corrections officials across the nation were increasingly embracing the notion of early detection of H.I.V. and effective treatment, but that financing remained their main problem.
"This is not just a hidden population," he said. "This is an invisible population. The public doesn't like to spend the money."

State Policies
The Rules Vary From Site to Site
The quality of treatment varies from prison to prison and state to state, often depending on whether court actions have forced improved medical care. In California, many H.I.V.-positive male inmates are treated at a hospital whose operation is subject to a 1990 Federal court consent decree. But a pending lawsuit says female inmates are receiving inadequate care, because of a shortage of specialists, among other problems.
In that case, Maxine Liggins, an AIDS doctor who worked at a women's prison, said in a December 1996 deposition that her supervisor at the prison, who was also a doctor, told her that "the patients were going to die, and therefore she didn't understand why people kept involving themselves in their care."
Nadim Khoury, a doctor and deputy director of health care services for the California state prisons, declined to comment on the lawsuit. But he said that uniform H.I.V. care was assured by systemwide guidelines and training sessions for doctors. He said the department expected to spend about $2.4 million on protease inhibitors this year.
Faced with the steep cost of the new drugs, many prison systems are moving haltingly to begin using them.
In Louisiana, where about 450 of the state's 27,000 inmates are H.I.V.-positive, no inmates receive the new drugs unless they are using them when they enter the system. Michael Hegmann, the medical director at Louisiana's Elaine Hunt Correctional Center, said providing the new drugs was "an ethical thing" but he said the state could not afford to give them to inmates not already taking them. Corrections officials are seeking $2 million for next year to pay for the drugs.
Even more troublesome to some doctors who have cared for inmates is the question of whether prison medical personnel can handle the increasingly complicated treatment of AIDS.
"Prison doctors around the country are not trained AIDS specialists," said Dr. Altice, of Yale Medical School, who treats inmates in Connecticut's prison. "We used to say that AIDS treatment is primary care. This is no longer true. We would no more have the average primary care provider deliver chemotherapy to cancer patients, than we would have the same people provide complex H.I.V. treatment."
Victoria Sharp, the director of the AIDS Center at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan who has treated both inmates and convicts paroled from prison, said she often saw patients treated by prison doctors who were on "very odd combinations" of drugs. She said the drugs were "very inappropriate. The result is they've been getting sub-optimal care."

In New York
A Case of Care Under Challenge
Joseph Cavese's life was defined by needles and guns. The syringes gave him AIDS. The guns got him prison terms for robbery.
Imprisoned and debilitated, Mr. Cavese experienced the vagaries of AIDS care in prison. As new treatments have begun to move the illness from a fatal affliction to chronic disease, the level of care has taken on greater importance.
With the old drugs, "you're talking about improving quality of life for two or three years," said Christopher Fletcher, the medical director of the Corrections Corporation of America, the private prisons company. "It's a lot different if you're talking about improving quantity of life for decades."
At Attica Correctional Facility, Mr. Cavese was cared for by Dr. Robert Takos, who said in a January 1995 deposition that he had little training in treating H.I.V., according to court records in a lawsuit brought by infected inmates against New York State corrections officials.
Dr. Takos, who was trained as an anesthesiologist, pleaded guilty to heroin possession in Mississippi in 1984, and as a result his license to practice medicine in New York was revoked, according to New York State Department of Education records. Dr. Takos acknowledged the addiction, and his New York license was reinstated in 1991 after a panel of doctors found him "truly remorseful, successfully rehabilitated and more than adequately re-educated," the records show. He began working at Attica in 1994.
 Mr. Cavese, one of the prisoners suing the state, said Dr. Takos told him that his condition was stable. When Mr. Cavese consulted with an infectious-disease specialist in November through a television hookup, the doctor prescribed protease inhibitors, but it took until the end of December for the prison staff to deliver the drugs to Mr. Cavese, his lawyers said. Dr. Takos did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
Mr. Cavese's health continued to fail, and in March he was moved to a prison infirmary near Utica to serve out a sentence for attempted burglary. A doctor there was less optimistic than Dr. Takos: He immediately told Mr. Cavese, 41, he was nearing death and asked him to sign a "Do Not Resuscitate" form, giving doctors the power to let him die if he slipped into a coma.
Mr. Cavese, who began shooting drugs at age 14 and was diagnosed with H.I.V. in 1985, said in a recent telephone interview that he received good care over the years at other state prisons, but at Attica, "medical treatment there was horrible."
Jack Beck, a Legal Aid Society lawyer who is representing prisoners in their lawsuit against the state prison system, said care in the system was very uneven.
"Some people are getting protease inhibitors and seeing infectious disease specialists," he said. "There are other people who get horrendous care. There is no consistency."
Inmates and their advocates say that care is considered good at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, a women's prison, and at the Greenhaven Correctional Facility. Medical care at both has been the subject of court action.
There, specialists regularly see patients and review their records, doctors familiar with those prisons said.
Prison officials defended AIDS care in the system, saying that 1,600 inmates were now on protease inhibitors and that prison doctors have received AIDS training "for the past several years" from specialists who traveled around the state and through educational programs broadcast by satellite.
They said the best indicator of the quality of care was the decline in AIDS-related deaths among inmates from a high of 258 in 1995 to 181 last year.
Catherine M. Abate, the State Senator who is the former city corrections commissioner, said "there needs to be standard care" in the system. "People are living longer, but that means the care and treatment must respond to that," she said.
The advent of protease inhibitors has also increased the importance of identifying infected inmates. The State Department of Health recently began a $5 million program to bring counselors to each of the state's prisons to educate inmates about AIDS prevention and increase voluntary testing. This effort augments AIDS support groups run by inmates.
"The message is with new treatment available people should know their status so they can get early intervention," Gus Birkhead, the director of the state's AIDS Institute, said. "Prior to that time people could have asked, 'Why should I know that I have a fatal disease for which I have no treatment?' "

The Treatment
Administering Protease Inhibitors
 Introducing protease inhibitors to inmates is fraught with complications. Given the risk of interrupting treatment, prison officials have to insure that prisoners adhere to their strict treatment schedules while incarcerated and also after they are released. This is a particular problem in jails, such as on Rikers Island, where the average stay is 46 days.
"My concern is people will be discharged, they won't have a place to go and we will be breeding a resistant strain of the disease," said Audrey Compton, the acting executive director of correctional health services for the Health and Hospitals Corporation in New York City.
For months, city health officials have been working to establish a network of health care providers in the city so that inmates leaving jail can be linked with a place to go to continue their treatment. Dr. Compton said the model for the network was similar to the city's approach to treating tuberculosis cases in the jails.
Making sure inmates get uniform care is a problem not only when they are released, but also when they move from one prison to another.
Two months ago, when the Corrections Corporation of America took over operation of the Central Treatment Facility prison in Washington, company officials wanted to increase the use of protease inhibitors, but found that Washington's prison system did not have uniform AIDS treatment guidelines. Company officials were concerned that as they started inmates on the treatments, they would be interrupted when inmates were transferred to another prison in the system.
Dr. Fletcher, the company's medical director, said he began working with corrections officials on establishing standardized care throughout the Washington system. Concerns have also been raised, because inmates going to the medical dispensary three times a day to receive treatments could pose a security risk, or, if they were given a supply of medicine to take on their own, the pills could end up in the prison's underground economy.
So prison staff members are dispatched every few hours, said the prison's warden, Lonnie M. Moore, "to give them their medicine and watch them take it."

The Law
Influencing AIDS Treatment
Treating inmates for AIDS is not just a matter of medical ethics or efficient medical care. Lawsuits around the country arguing that the denial of adequate care constituted "cruel and unusual punishment" have improved AIDS treatment.
In Connecticut, where about 6 percent of the state's 15,000 inmates are H.I.V.-positive, care has been governed by a court-approved consent decree since 1989, officials there said. Infected inmates have regular access to infectious disease specialists, some of whom work for the prison system. There is a strict program for H.I.V. risk-reduction education, and prison officials are required to make monthly reports to the state court on their AIDS care program.
After a Federal lawsuit over AIDS care in Georgia, the state instituted a system of monitoring AIDS cases, put uniform-treatment guidelines in place and made protease inhibitors available to all H.I.V.-positive inmates.
"A sick person on the street can go to an emergency room," said Maddie LaMarre, the clinical services coordinator for the Georgia prison system. "But these people can't because they're under lock and key, so that puts a big responsibility on the person holding the key."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Treating Prisoners With AIDS"
As sentencing laws have put more drug users behind bars, many states are now dealing with large numbers of prisoners who have AIDS or are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. New treatments are reducing the number dying from the disease, but they are also driving up costs for the states. HEADLINE: In '97, Commencement Topics Come From Within

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Tim Russert, managing editor of the NBC News program "Meet the Press," who will give five college commencement addresses this year, says he likes to tell students at the small Jesuit schools where he prefers to speak that their education will allow them to compete successfully with even graduates of Ivy League schools.
"Then," he said, "I tell them, 'I have one piece of anecdotal evidence to support that -- me!' " 
 He then begins the story of his life, about growing up poor, becoming the first in his family to go to college -- at John Carroll College in University Heights, Ohio -- and how he still strives to achieve "a life of personal success and service to others."
In mining his own life for speech material, Mr. Russert is not alone. It is as though commencement speakers feel increasingly compelled to validate their observations with personal tales of poverty, physical suffering or triumph over adversity.
The confessional style may have been inspired by speeches in other settings, like when Vice President Al Gore recounted at the Democratic National Convention last August his sister's death from lung cancer.
"Talking about personal tragedies is definitely a trend -- look at all the books about that on the best-seller list," said Grada Fischer, president of the Fischer-Ross Group, a New York lecture agency that handles commencement speakers.
"Dealing with our emotions -- and with such things as wellness -- is a big part of our culture today," she said. "That's what people want to hear about, and speakers know that's the way to create an impact."
Speaking at Barnard College last week, Anna Quindlen, the author and former columnist for The New York Times, spoke at length about how, during her sophomore year at Barnard, she cared for her mother, who was dying of ovarian cancer.
As a result, Ms. Quindlen said, she learned that when a life is not as threatened as her mother's had been, "life is glorious, and you had no business taking it for granted."
And Carole Simpson, an ABC network television correspondent, publicly castigated herself when she told students at Howard University in Washington: "Don't wait, as I did until I was over 50, to realize that the most important things on earth to me are not ABC News, or my lovely home or my celebrity. It is my husband of 30 years, Jim, and my two children, Adam and Mallika."
L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University, who usually delivers the school's commencement address himself, leaves aside his own life story but does talk about the struggles of several members of the graduating class.
"I don't give their names when I tell about them," he said, "but the students quickly realize who I'm talking about, and you get bubbles of recognition first in one part of the audience and then bubbles somewhere else when I'm talking about another student."
Mr. Oliva explained that he adopted this approach after recently going to great trouble to find a commencement speaker who, it turned out, was willing to speak only about "matters like the European Common Market which had no relation to the lives of the students."
There are, of course, many who still devote their remarks to issues, policies and problems.
George Rupp, the president of Columbia University, said he was so moved by President Clinton's "summit on volunteerism" that he threw away his prepared text and spoke instead about "the need to revitalize our common life as a necessary part of individualism."
David M. Lee, a University of Connecticut alumnus who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1996, told students at his alma mater about the discovery of superfluid helium a quarter of a century ago, and, drawing upon that experience, urged his listeners "to take advantage of unexpected developments."
And, not surprisingly, President Clinton's speech at Morgan State University, a historically black school in Baltimore, sounded much like a state of the union address as he ticked off items on his agenda, from maintaining a strong economy to developing an AIDS vaccine.
A former President, Jimmy Carter, also delivered a standard commencement speech at Duke University on May 18, drawn there by the fact that his grandson Jason Carter was in the graduating class.
But not every public official felt so constrained. In her address at Boston College last Monday, Attorney General Janet Reno dealt briskly with threats to law and order like the rash of arsons at black churches and illegal immigration. And then she said, "When I was 8 years old, we lived in a little wooden house. . . ." You knew what was coming.
Ms. Reno told how, when her family outgrew their first house, her mother set about constructing a larger one. Because her father worked long hours at his job, it was her mother who dug the foundation, poured the concrete floor and installed the electrical wiring and plumbing. The house withstood Hurricane Andrew in 1992. The lesson, Ms. Reno said, is, "Build your life the right way, and don't be intimidated by the complexity."
One of the more powerful speeches this year -- it drew gasps and brought tears to the eyes of those in the audience -- was delivered at Ithaca College by Dot Richardson, the Olympic softball medalist, who is also an orthopedic surgeon.
Ms. Richardson began by telling how she overcame the prejudice against female athletes, and then described how her crowning moment at the Atlanta Olympics -- which she said was foreshadowed in a dream -- unfolded when she dived for a ball, did a somersault, sprang up and threw out the runner at first base.
She next told how -- before accepting an invitation to the White House -- she brought her gold medal to the children's hospital in Los Angeles with which she is affiliated.
"I wanted to make sure every one of those kids got to wear that medal," Ms. Richardson said.
After chatting with a young girl in the intensive care unit who had undergone brain surgery four days earlier, she said, she noticed that the girl's mother and sister and several nurses standing nearby were crying.
"What did I do wrong?" she said she asked a nurse.
"Dot, you don't understand," came the reply. "This girl has not spoken a single word since her surgery."
The message? "People, there will be moments in our lives when we will be given the opportunity to make a difference in the lives of others."

HEADLINE: Playing Loose With History

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel, a visiting professor of international affairs at George Washington University, is the author of "Temptations of a Superpower."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Fifty years ago the Mar shall Plan united but also divided -- Europe. In editorials and commencement addresses we celebrate it today as an unparalleled act of enlightened generosity.
That it was. Through an infusion of American money much of Western Europe was restored to prosperity and democracy. 
 But it is wrong for Clinton Administration officials and their supporters to extol the Marshall Plan as a model for an expanded NATO, as they are now doing. We forget that the earlier creation, as the price of its success, helped sunder the strained links between the two parts of the continent, Eastern and Western Europe. Given a similar effort to unite more of Europe today, the United States may actually be sowing the seeds for another partition between Russia and the West -- only this time the division will be wholly unnecessary.
In 1947, when American officials put together the economic recovery program for a war-devastated Europe, they faced a terrible dilemma. What to do about Russia? To bring what was then called the Soviet Union into the Marshall Plan would greatly complicate the efforts to revive capitalist economies in Europe, provide markets for American exporters and construct a trans-Atlantic free trade system.
Furthermore, the United States Congress, warned a few months earlier by the Truman Administration of a Communist threat to Greece and Turkey, would almost certainly refuse to provide billions of dollars for a program from which Moscow would benefit. Yet to exclude the Soviet Union blatantly, to create two rigidly opposed economic and hence political systems in Europe, would be to reinforce the very "iron curtain" that officials had inveighed against.
George Kennan, the official in charge of formulating the Marshall Plan, argued that the Russians had to be invited to participate. If they were not, the United States would be blamed for seeking to divide Europe. He cleverly resolved the problem by leaving the door open to the Kremlin, but imposing such rigid economic conditions that Stalin would likely turn down the offer for fear of weakening Russia's hold over its satellites.
As Mr. Kennan later wrote, Russia and the East European states would "either exclude themselves by unwillingness to accept the proposed conditions, or agree to abandon the exclusive orientation of their economies." Charles Bohlen, then serving as assistant to Secretary of State George Marshall, later confirmed that the plan was framed in such a way as to "make it quite impossible for the Soviet Union to accept."
Ultimately, that is what happened. The Russians stalked out of the planning talks and took the Eastern European states with them. Vyacheslav Molotov, Stalin's Foreign Minister, declared that the Marshall Plan would "divide Europe into two groups of states . . . creating new difficulties in relations with them."
Within months Stalin clamped down on Hungary, imposed a Communist regime on Czechoslovakia, and tried, through a blockade of West Berlin, to pressure the Western allies to give up their plans to create a West German state from their zones of occupation. Soon thereafter came the two rival military alliances, first NATO, then the Warsaw Pact.
The cold war was on in earnest. Europe was divided in two and would remain that way for 40 years. It was the Soviet Union that put up the barricades and that bears the greatest responsibility. But their actions, though brutal, were not irrational.
As George Kennan himself later wrote, the coup in Czechoslovakia and the pressures on Berlin "were defensive reactions on the Soviet side to the initial success of the Marshall Plan" and the decision to set up an independent state in Western Germany.
Is there a lesson in this story for today? Soviet Russia, consumed by dogma and ruled by a paranoid dictator, bears little in common with the democratizing, free-market Russia of today. Except for one thing: Both are Russian. Both share a history of authoritarianism, of heroic repulsions of invasions from abroad, of attraction to and fear of the West, and of a determination to be a power in the world commensurate with its cultural greatness.
Russia also, indeed eternally, is both a part, and not a part, of Europe. American policy makers, in an effort to expand economic institutions and cold-war alliances, declare that the United States is a "European power." But this is more true of Russia, and efforts to deny this fact will inevitably have unhappy consequences, both for the Russians and for the Europeans.
 That is why the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan should be not only a cause for self-congratulation, but also as a cautionary tale. The plan succeeded in its ambitions, and the price was high. Officials at the time knew what the price was and were willing to pay it. Soviet Russia was our foe, and we were locked in a struggle for the control of Europe.
Today Russia is our friend, or so we say. For the moment it is very weak politically and economically. It poses no serious threat to anyone -- not even to separatist groups on its own territory, as the failed effort to subdue the Chechen rebels revealed.
Yet it is at this moment that United States officials have pushed to expand NATO, the cold-war military alliance intended to hold back an invading Red Army. They describe this expansion as uniting Europe. And they imply that this is only the first step of an expansion that will ultimately include states that just a few years ago were part of the Soviet Union.
The push to expand NATO has been driven not by any hostile behavior by Russia. Rather, it stems from the Administration's desire to take the initiative on foreign policy rather than merely react to crises; to please certain domestic ethnic groups, and to maintain a dominant American role in Europe's military future. But the result may stimulate hostile Russian responses. This would be particularly likely if the accommodationist Yeltsin Government is succeeded by a more nationalistic and self-confident one.
Although the Russians have recently been granted a seat in the balcony through the proposed NATO-Russia council, this is far less than equal treatment. What is needed today is not an expanded alliance to contain Russia, but a sincere effort to incorporate it as a full and equal member into a wider European security network. There was some effort to do so under the now-abandoned Partnership for Peace. This should either be revived, or the plan for NATO expansion taken to its logical conclusion with the incorporation of Russia. To rule this out is to reinforce the belief in Moscow that NATO is being expanded as an anti-Russian alliance.
Instead of intoning the Marshall Plan as a slogan, the Administration should draw a lesson from it. Living in a time of danger, the architects of the Marshall Plan were prepared to pay its costs because they believed that they had no other choice.
Today's NATO expanders in Washington are driven not by fear, but by a combination of ambition and opportunism. They want to build an enduring structure, in emulation of their illustrious forebears, and to leave a legacy that will outshine that of their intellectual predecessors. But the legacy they leave could be far different from the one they imagine. Their predecessors opened up a door that Stalinist Russia refused to enter. Today's leaders are locking a door that democratic Russia is knocking on, hoping for admission.

HEADLINE: Price Tags Help Save Louisiana's Coast

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Valuing natural services, as described in "How Much Is Nature Worth?" (Science Times, May 20), is especially timely in Louisiana, where we are battling the ongoing loss of our coastal ecosystem.
Dr. Robert Costanza and Dr. Stephen Farber, two authors of the new study on the worth of global ecosystem services, have helped Louisiana begin to quantify the tremendous value that our state's coastal wetlands have for the entire nation. 
 Water purification values of at least $100 billion, hurricane and storm protection values in the billions, and the most productive fishery in the lower 48 states are economic benefits that flow directly from our coastal marshes.
These endangered natural values supplement over $100 billion in human infrastructure for commerce, mineral extraction and navigation, which are also being put at greater risk by the decline of the marshes.
The dollar amounts are only one benefit we receive from natural services, but they help us make the case for reversing the decline of estuaries, wetlands and other irreplaceable ecosystems in the name of the public good.
 
DOUG DAIGLE
Baton Rouge, La., May 21, 1997
 
The writer is program director of the Coalition to Restore Coastal Louisiana.

HEADLINE: Wary Hong Kong Collectors Send Art Abroad for Safety

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Hong Kong's impending change from British to Chinese Communist rule has led to an exodus of Chinese art, with residents sending their collections overseas out of fear that China may prevent the export of items deemed to be cultural patrimony.
Some dealers estimate the value of this precious cargo at more than $1 billion, making it a migration of artworks that rivals the Japanese purchases of Western paintings in the 1980's. 
 China assumes control of Hong Kong on July 1. In contrast to Hong Kong, which has virtually no rules impeding the export of art and antiques, China has regulations governing any work of art over 50 years old. Since questions about future art export policies were first raised, China has given only general assurances that Hong Kong's commercial laws will not change in the next 50 years unless the territory itself changes them. Even when pressed, officials will say nothing specific about art.
Many collectors, accustomed to buying and selling works on the free market, have therefore been seeking safe harbor for their Chinese ceramic, porcelain, bronze, jade, wood and painted works. "I've been meeting with a lot of insurance agents to appraise items that are to be shipped abroad," said Glenn Vessa of Honeychurch Antiques in Hong Kong.
Such treasures are headed to the United States, Canada, Britain, Singapore and elsewhere. Some have been placed in museums in Denver, Washington, Phoenix and other cities, occasionally as gifts but usually on long-term loan. Others are disappearing into warehouses or into the second homes that some Hong Kong residents bought overseas as possible refuges. A few have been put up for sale.
China's takeover of Hong Kong is causing other ripples in the art world, too. For a start, it has helped fuel the recent boom in Chinese art.
"The political events are certainly drawing an enormous amount of attention to China and to Chinese art and culture," said James B. Godfrey, director of Chinese art and Asian business development at Sotheby's, the international auction house. "And that," he said, "has helped generate excitement and tension in the Asian art market," attracting new buyers and pushing up prices.
Prices would climb higher still if China does limit exports from Hong Kong and Chinese artworks thus become more scarce abroad. And Hong Kong's vibrant art trade would suffer as business shifted to dealers and auction rooms in Taiwan and especially in New York City, which is already capturing an increasing share of the Chinese art market.
Smuggling of art from the Chinese mainland, a chronic occurrence that is unlikely to cease, is also expected to change. Despite the strict rules, China thrives as the source for artworks new to the market. The border authorities often look the other way as smugglers move them overland to Hong Kong and then to markets around the world. Perhaps paradoxically, smuggling through Hong Kong will be more difficult once it is part of China.
"There's a big temptation for people to move from China to Hong Kong, so the border will be reinforced" for traffic of both people and restricted goods, said Alice Lam, co-chairman of Sotheby's Asia, based in Hong Kong. Smugglers would be forced to find new channels via plane or boat.
As a result, "the market for very old Chinese art, for archeological works of art, will be very, very gravely affected," said Michael Guidhaus, a longtime dealer in Chinese art in London. "It will be possible for the Chinese to smuggle out to other places like Taiwan or Macao. But it's much more difficult and it's further away, and it will be more expensive for that reason. That will put enormous upward pressure on the works that are already out."

At First a Trickle, Now a Scramble
Art began trickling out of Hong Kong -- legally, if surreptitiously -- soon after Britain agreed to withdraw, in 1984. Some wealthy Hong Kong residents established dual citizenship, buying second homes abroad and furnishing them with their art and antiques. But many more, wanting to enjoy their possessions, procrastinated, thus setting up the last-minute scramble.
"Naturally, many put it off," said James J. Lally, who owns an Asian art gallery on East 57th Street in Manhattan. "There's been more activity in the last year."
No one knows how much more, though. Collectors are silent on their activity, afraid of attracting attention or disapproval of Chinese officials, whose vague statements that nothing will change have not assuaged their anxiety.
"The Chinese authorities say this is an overreaction, that the restrictions apply only to China and not to Hong Kong," said Philip Ng, managing director of Christie's Asia, based in Singapore. "But if you had millions of dollars in antiques, you'd rather play it safe, wouldn't you?"
To some Hong Kong Chinese, there is no debate. Art collecting is a family tradition, and many remember the Communists' rise to power nearly 50 years ago. "A lot of these families were in Shanghai in 1949 when the Chinese Communists said, nothing will happen, everything will be fine," Mr. Lally said. "And then the Communist regime confiscated their art. The Shanghai museum's best pieces are all from those private collections."
Times have changed on the mainland. Some economic freedoms have been granted. But civil and political rights have not followed. "The question is," said Constance Lowenthal, executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research, "will holders of great and important art be allowed to treat it as personal property or not?"
Anyone in China, resident or visitor, can buy antiques and artworks there. Taking them out is another matter. China has a patchwork of laws governing the export of art and antiques: the stringency of the restrictions depends on how old an artwork is, whether it is a ceramic or a painting or in another medium, the kind of wood that furniture is made of and whether something is deemed "best of type."
In general, experts said, anything 150 years or older will run up against a restriction, and some items made as recently as 50 years ago may, too. "They search at the border," Ms. Lam said. "Pieces that are allowed to leave China have a red seal."
But the laws are not always enforced, said Khalil Rizk, the owner of the Chinese Porcelain Company on Park Avenue. Gaining export approval is sometimes unpredictable. Mr. Godfrey of Sotheby's said, "Regulations don't seem to be enforced in any consistent manner."
And various smugglers have forged ties to officials who will allow some important pieces out, said dealers who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Lately, some dealers said, China has cracked down on some illicit art trade. "Mainland China is getting very tough," Mr. Guidhaus said. "They are executing smugglers." Other dealers said they believed that the border was as leaky as ever.
Officials in the Cultural Relics Bureau in Beijing "do not have nearly as much clout as the people who are profiting from this illegal trade," said Mr. Vessa of Honeychurch Antiques.
When it comes to Hong Kong, Chinese authorities may also be torn. They would like to leave Hong Kong's thriving art business alone, but they also fear losing more of their patrimony and may want to control corruption.
"It's possible they'll disregard what they've said" about allowing Hong Kong to set its own rules, Mr. Ng said. "Hong Kong is part of China, and the Chinese can do what they want."

Safekeeping of Art Preferred to Selling
So, for now, can Hong Kong residents. Only a few seem to have reacted to the potential threat of restrictions by selling their art. "It's not turning up on the market in quantities," Mr. Rizk said. "There are no shops with millions of Tang horses, because these people are not in need."
One who did sell is T. T. Tsui, a philanthropist. In November in Hong Kong and in March in New York, Mr. Tsui put his collection of pottery, bronzes and furniture on the block at Christie's. He raised nearly $16.3 million.
Many more people, Mr. Rizk said, "are sending things out for safekeeping." Second homes in such places as Vancouver, British Columbia, are the repository of choice. Families who lack safe-harbor homes are sending their art into secure, climate-controlled warehouses in Toronto, New York, London and Geneva.
"We are getting some of it," confirmed Thomas A. Pelham, a vice president of Fortress at Judson Art Warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, where 1,000 square feet of storage space rents for $2,600 a month. "It started back in 1991 and 1992, when all of a sudden we were doing more business from Asia."
It has since accelerated. Mr. Pelham will not say how much art he holds for Hong Kong residents. But he estimated that while in 1987 less than 10 percent of his Asian business involved private clients in Hong Kong, that number had climbed to 90 percent by the end of 1996. "It's still coming this year," he added.
Several museums have also become the lucky recipients of Hong Kong collections, usually on three- to five-year loans with provisions for renewal. The Denver Art Museum has three such collections: 30 pieces of Ming furniture owned by Dr. S. Y. Yip; 175 jade carvings and ornaments ranging from the 14th to the 19th centuries owned by Dr. and Mrs. Henry Wong, and more than 1,000 pieces, mostly Neolithic pots, owned by Warren and Shirley King.
Dr. Yip sent 20 more items from his furniture collection to the Phoenix Art Museum and 15 pieces of small furniture to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington, which is putting them on show beginning on June 22.
The British Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and the new Asian Civilization Museum in Singapore are also exhibiting art sent for safekeeping from Hong Kong, various art experts said.
The owners are said to be cagey about relating the loans to the transfer of power. "If you call them, they'll say they lent it because they feel generous," said Mr. Ng, who has had extensive conversations with many Hong Kong collectors. Privately, he added, they are likely to be more truthful.
If museums are the short-term beneficiaries of the uncertainty in Hong Kong, the territory's dealers may be the long-term losers. "The Hong Kong market is in confusion," said Mr. Lally, the Menhattan gallery owner .
Many dealers say there is gloom among along Hong Kong's famed Hollywood Road, the city's antiques row. "If the Chinese impose export restrictions, that will virtually eliminate the art trade in Hong Kong," Mr. Godfrey of Sotheby's said.
Many Hong Kong dealers have been very cautious about buying works for inventory. "They don't want to hold stock there," Mr. Lally said. Mr. Vessa said that some had closed down and moved abroad. "If you walk along Hollywood Road, you'll see a lot of shops that are newly vacant," he said. Some have shipped their inventory abroad, often to Taiwan, and stand ready to relocate if the Hong Kong government does change the rules.
Mr. Ng of Christie's predicted that the Hong Kong dealers who make a living selling smuggled goods would go underground.

Increasing Interest Shown by Collectors
Interest in collecting Asian art is meanwhile growing. Dealers and auctioneers alike say the times are comparable to the art boom's peak in the late 1980's. Prices are equally high or better, and there are even more buyers, in the United States, Europe, Australia and Asia -- , including Hong Kong residents and the new rich in mainland China. "If anything, because of the uncertainties they are continuing to be strong and active buyers," Mr. Godfrey said. "There's a concern that things won't be available on the market."
This spring, both Sotheby's and Christie's had record or near-record sales in New York, with strong interest in all categories from snuffboxes to pottery to furniture. Auctions have been brisk in Hong Kong, too. Christie's described one recent sale there as a "frenzy of activity not seen since the market's height more than seven years ago."
But dealers and collectors say New York has now become the place to buy the best Chinese art. Hong Kong remains strong in Ming and Qing Imperial porcelains. But for furniture, ceramics, bronzes, archeological material and most other categories -- the fastest-growing markets -- New York has the edge, many dealers said. London, once the center of the Chinese art market, has faded.
With more and more Asians willing to travel to sales or use the telephone to buy, the auctioneers and dealers expect New York's share of the market to grow. And any restrictive moves in Hong Kong would hasten that trend.
Some Hong Kong residents are putting on a brave face. "No one is saying they will bring these restrictions into Hong Kong," Ms. Lam said. They can only wait and see what happens after the Chinese flag is raised at midnight on July 1.

HEADLINE: Job Market Picking Up For Summer

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Job seekers will find improved opportunities this summer as employers look to add workers in an increasingly tight labor market, according to a new survey.
The study, by Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary staffing company, says 30 percent of 16,000 companies surveyed plan to expand their work forces in the July-August period. 
 Only 5 percent said they expected to cut employment, while 65 percent either plan no changes or do not know, the survey said.
At this time last year, 27 percent said they planned increases and 7 percent planned reductions. Manpower said the responses in its latest survey were the most optimistic since 1988.
"The need for workers is so widespread that there seems to be carry-over demand caused by the inability of companies to find the people they needed in earlier quarters," said Manpower's chief executive, Mitchell S. Fromstein.
The nation's unemployment rate hit a 23-year low of 4.9 percent in April.
Manpower said the strongest region for hiring this summer will be the Midwest, where 33 percent of employers plan to expand their staffs. That compared with 31 percent in the West, 28 percent in the South and 27 percent in the Northeast.
By industry, construction companies were the most eager to add workers, with 40 percent planning additions heading into the typically busy summer season.
The weakest industry by far was mining, with only 12 percent predicting new hiring.
Manpower's survey was based on telephone interviews with management personnel in 487 American cities. The company said the figures have a margin of error of plus or minus two percentage points.

HEADLINE: $25 Million Plea For Palestinians

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 26

 BODY:
The main United Nations agency aiding 3.3 million Palestinians is "technically bankrupt" at a time when social and economic stability are vital to Middle East peace prospects, its director said today.
Peter Hansen, head of the Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East, called urgently for $25 million to meet the agency's $312 million budget this year. 
 Mr. Hansen said the income of the 1.3 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip had fallen by 40 percent since the peace effort began four years ago, mainly because of Israeli border closures, which prevent Palestinians from working in Israel.
"That means that since the peace process started, the Palestinians have been losing 10 percent in their living standard every year," he said. "People are poorer than they were before. They are in need of more services." He spoke after a fund-raising tour in the Persian Gulf states and Southeast Asia.
Major donors, including the largest, the United States, whose share is $70 million, have paid. But the agency is seeking new donors to keep pace with a refugee population that expands by 5 percent a year, Mr. Hansen said.
The agency provides education, health care and social services to 3.3 million Palestinian refugees in Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, the West Bank and Gaza Strip. About one-third live in 59 camps.

HEADLINE: European Left Takes Heart From France

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, May 26

 BODY:
Gains by the French left in first-round parliamentary elections heartened Socialists in other parts of Europe today, offering a portent of the way Europeans will define their future in the face of a global economy dominated by the American market ethic.
From Bonn to Rome and Vienna, leftist parties portrayed the advances by Lionel Jospin's Socialist Party as a sign that European voters, as they confront the rigors of planned monetary union in 1999, would side with an economic vision of softer options based on the elusive twinning of jobs and social welfare. 
 The French result "shows that economic and financial policies, which raise unemployment through restrictive budgets and social spending cuts, are condemned to failure," said Oskar Lafontaine, the head of Germany's Social Democrats, who are to challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl in national elections late next year.
The outcome of the French vote is critical for Germany, Europe's troubled economic powerhouse, which sees the impetus for monetary union as driven by an axis between Paris and Bonn. The union is the centerpiece of Mr. Kohl's European vision.
The Germans do not expect French Socialists to renege on the commitment to monetary union made by the former President, Francois Mitterrand. But the party has set conditions for supporting the concept. German officials are concerned that a Socialist Government in Paris might strain the alliance by pressing demands unpalatable to German voters, who are troubled by the thought of losing their cherished mark to a softer European currency.
Chancellor Kohl displayed a characteristic caution about the first-round French results, saying that "one must let the results of the first round of the French elections take effect and wait for the second round."
Preparations for the new currency, the euro, have already led to budget cuts as governments try to get their books in order so that they qualify for inclusion.
That has raised a prospect of unfamiliar hardship in countries, particularly France and Germany, where unemployment is nearly at record levels and unions are gearing to confront Government plans to cut social provisions that are seen as a birthright, including generous sick pay and pensions.
The French vote is going to be taken as a signal of whether Europe's future lies in steeling for the global dictates of a market-driven order, or in trying to salvage the costly benefits that have taken root in Europe since the World War II. In other words: does Europe follow the prescriptions of Margaret Thatcher in the 1980's, or those of the debilitated continental left in the post-Iron- Curtain 1990's?
"The French result is even more significant than the already important victory of Tony Blair in England," said Armando Cossutta, head of Italy's hard-left Communist Refoundation Party.
"The left in France is campaigning on a much more advanced program, centered on a reduction in working hours and defense of the welfare state."
Against that, Jose Maria Robles Fraga of the governing Popular Party in Spain said that "anyone who wants the future of Europe entrusted to a coalition of Socialists and Communists has not understood anything that has happened since the fall of the Berlin wall."
Beyond the immediate responses, there was a more direct message for Germany.
A French Socialist victory following Mr. Blair's landslide in Britain would place an awkward question mark over the future of Europe's conservatives at the moment that Chancellor Kohl's center-right Christian Democrats are contemplating their electoral prospects next year.
The sense that countries as important as France and Britain were seething with a desire for change would sit uneasily on Mr. Kohl's 14-year-old administration, which many Germans see as paralyzed in its efforts to reform financial and economic policy to meet changing European and world conditions.
The unease would not be limited to the Christian Democrats. Germany's opposition Social Democrats are riven by disputes over what change should mean, and who should be its champion in the national elections: Mr. Lafontaine or his more popular rival, Gerhard Schroder.

HEADLINE: Immigrants and the Economy

 BODY:
The presence of immigrants in the work force is raising the living standards of most Americans by a small amount. That reassuring conclusion comes from a panel of scholars convened by the National Research Council. But job competition from immigrants depresses the wages of some low-paid native workers by a small amount, and immigrants impose sizable, though remediable, burdens on taxpayers in heavily hit states. These findings should calm most anxieties over immigration while pointing Congress to some sensible reforms.
The panel estimates that the yearly influx of about one million immigrants adds up to $10 billion of total economic output, more than the immigrants collect in wages. But $10 billion is a tiny part of a $7 trillion economy, and the estimate is best interpreted as evidence that immigrants do not harm native workers. The panel also estimated that immigrant workers pay more in Federal taxes than they collect in government services. 
 But immigrants, especially those who are poor and have children, do put a substantial burden on some states, like California, and some cities, like New York, because of their numbers. The panel estimates that an immigrant family in California collects about $3,000 more in public services, including school, than it pays in taxes. Native households in California therefore pay about $1,000 a year in taxes, on average, to provide services to immigrants. An obvious solution would be for Washington to compensate heavily burdened states.
The most troubling, though unsurprising, finding of the report was the burden on low-paid native workers. As the immigrant pool has switched to the relatively poor countries of Latin America from the relatively rich countries of Europe, the supply of low-wage workers has risen. The panel estimates that competition has driven down the wages of native high school dropouts by about 5 percent since 1980, less than many scholars had thought. Most black Americans, the panel finds, have escaped much harm because they do not generally live in pockets of heavy immigration.
As birth rates continue their steady decline, immigrants are expected to account for most of the nation's population rise over the next five decades. Indeed, young immigrant workers will help provide the tax revenues with which state and Federal governments will support the burgeoning ranks of retirees. But Congress need not stand aloof as steady immigration strains local government and harms low-paid native workers. Congress could give preference to immigrants who are highly educated or otherwise highly skilled because they would demand fewer social services and pay high taxes, thereby relieving the strain on local governments, yet not threaten unskilled workers.
The panel did not make policy recommendations. But its careful analysis suggests how Congress could tailor the composition of immigrants to minimize the strain on taxpayers and the burdens on poor native workers.

HEADLINE: France's Mercurial Politics

 BODY:
There is no mistaking the rebuff French voters gave the conservative Government of President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Alain Juppe Sunday in the first round of parliamentary elections. The opposition leftist coalition won 43 percent of the vote to the Government parties' 37 percent, with 15 percent going to the far-right, anti-immigrant National Front. Mr. Chirac's own job was not at stake. But the enormous conservative parliamentary majority elected four years ago has melted away. It is now a toss-up whether a conservative successor to Mr. Juppe, who resigned yesterday, or the leftists under the Socialist Party leader, Lionel Jospin, will win next week's decisive second round.
These results express discontent with the status quo, but no strong endorsement for any party's political prescriptions. The French are rightly worried about their country's prolonged economic stagnation and chronic double-digit unemployment. They are uncomfortable with the right's proposed response, which consists mainly of expanded privatization and painful reductions in the welfare state to meet the deficit targets set for Europe's planned single currency, the euro. But they are also dubious about the left's glib-sounding promise of painless government-spurred recovery. They reasonably fear that Socialist proposals for deficit spending, work-sharing formulas and large-scale job creation could frighten investors, re-ignite inflation and jeopardize France's eligibility for the new currency. 
 Whichever side wins a majority next week is thus likely to face a version of the same dilemma that has undone French governments of left and right for more than a decade. Francois Mitterrand carried the left to power in 1981 with a program of nationalization and government spending, only to find investors ditching the weakened French franc for German marks and other more reliable currencies. Mr. Mitterrand soon reverted to fiscal austerity. That restored confidence in the franc but undermined support for his Socialist Party, leading to two periods of divided government with Mr. Mitterrand as President and conservative majorities in Parliament.
Two years ago Mr. Chirac won the presidency for the right by promising to reduce unemployment without further austerity. But he too was forced into a quick reversal by the need to meet deficit targets for the single currency. The conservatives have been in trouble ever since.
France wants an economically and politically united Europe because history has taught it to fear an unfettered Germany. Germany no longer looms as a potential military threat. But France fears that without closely linking its economy and currency to Germany's, it could easily be relegated to Europe's second economic tier. France also sees a strong, economically unified Europe as a way to defend its cultural traditions against the threat of globalization, a threat many in France seem to reflexively identify with the United States.
But meeting the deficit targets for the single currency requires cutting popular government-paid benefits like early retirement, social security and free health care. That seems to many an unacceptably high price. When public-sector workers strike to defend their benefits, they generally win broad popular support.
Outsiders can feel some sympathy for this French dilemma. But as long as France remains unwilling to reconsider either its plans for ever tighter European financial integration or its unwillingness to reduce costly welfare benefits, it will remain volatile.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Will Denounce Trade Policy Toward China

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Breaking with the Clinton Administration again, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, plans to denounce normal trade relations with China on Tuesday, asserting that such terms would help China's leaders and "contribute to their tyranny and reinforce their contempt for America's resolve."
Calling current policy in Beijing "free-market Stalinism," Mr. Gephardt, in a speech to be delivered at the Detroit Economic Club, said that efforts to advance democracy through trade were futile. 
 "Economic growth for the elite will not lead to basic human rights for billions," he said, bluntly contradicting President Clinton's contention last Monday that trade ties are "the best way to bring China into the family of nations and to secure our interests and our ideals." Mr. Clinton elaborated, saying, "We hope that it will come to respect human rights more and the rule of law more."
Last week Mr. Gephardt, of Missouri, condemned the budget deal Mr. Clinton struck with Congressional Republicans as lacking "fairness."
That position was widely cited as just another move in preparing to run for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000 against Vice President Gore. But Mr. Gephardt said then, "That decision hasn't been made and won't be made for some time."
The Detroit speech, a copy of which was made available to The New York Times, is sure to renew that speculation, though his aides contended today that it was consistent with his vote against renewing normal trade status for China last June. But last June, the House approved renewal, 286 to 141, Mr. Clinton was running for re-election, and Mr. Gephardt did not embarrass him by making a speech on the issue. Now Mr. Clinton is not running and Mr. Gephardt may be.
On the budget, only a third of the House Democrats joined Mr. Gephardt in voting against the measure. Some who were dubious voted for it anyway, knowing they faced certain defeat and future television advertisements against them saying they opposed a balanced budget.
Mr. Gephardt may have more influence on the issue of renewing normal trade relations, known as "most favored nation" status, however, because the odds are uncertain and the political risks slight.
In the House, Mr. Gephardt joins an ideologically scattered coalition ranging from diehard socially conservative Republicans to labor union Democrats who already have high hopes of winning a vote to reject Mr. Clinton's decision. But they frankly concede they have little hope of winning in the Senate and none of overriding a veto by the President.
The House is likely to vote on extending China's trading status in late June or in July.
In the speech, Mr. Gephardt touched on a variety of complaints against the Chinese leadership. He criticized the United States' trade deficit of nearly $40 billion last year, calling it evidence that trade policy had been an economic failure. "We can't compete with slave labor," he said, referring to China's use of prisoners to make exportable goods.
And Mr. Gephardt, who focused on the trade issue while losing his party's Presidential nomination in 1988 to Michael S. Dukakis, used some of his strongest language to denounce China's role in the world, especially in the sale of cruise missiles and poison-gas equipment to Iran.
"Today's China,' he said, "is not content to keep its reign of terror inside its own borders. It blows its storm of calamity into the world's other outlaw nations."
But the bulk of his speech focused on human rights. With an eye toward the businessmen who usually dominate the Detroit Economic Club audience, he warned, "Human rights is, at its heart, about the rule of law. A government that can arbitrarily violate the liberty of its people cannot be trusted to abide by the rules of contract or the rights of companies."
Pushing his argument, he added, "Those who would drench Tiananmen Square with blood do not blanch at shredding a commercial or international obligation.
"For years," he said, "the business community has argued that its participation in the economy -- simply being there -- would yield results. So far, no real progress has been made. We now hear the same arguments for constructive engagement with China that we heard about South Africa. But nothing fundamental changed in South Africa until sanctions came."
"Constructive engagement," he said, "too often becomes convenient engagement."
He said that sanctions against South Africa and trade restrictions on the Soviet Union had helped end tyranny in those countries, and last year's Helms-Burton Law, with its penalties for countries that trade with Cuba, was intended to end dictatorship in this hemisphere.
Following those examples, he said, "The United States has no business playing 'business as usual' with a Chinese tyranny that persecutes Christian and Muslim leaders and leaders from many other faiths, precludes tens of millions from practicing their religion." He attacked China for its policy of "forced abortion" and for imprisoning Wei Jingsheng, an advocate of democracy.
"For brave men and women in China," he said, "freedom is more than fine words and easy rhetoric; for it they have sacrificed their personal liberty -- and too often, even their lives. Don't tell them that human rights are a Western idea, a European idea, and that no Asians need apply. Don't excuse tyranny by insulting its victims."
The only Chinese who profited from trade with the United States, he said, "were corrupt bureaucrats and brutal generals." He added, "Our current relationship, in effect, sanctions their repression."
"Tyrants cannot rule forever," he concluded, "and when the Chinese are freed from oppression they will ask: 'Where was the United States during our time of darkness? Did America stand with us or did she look the other way?' "
